lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 20 (UPI)—To day's session of the Vietnam peace talks was put off until next Thursday to allow French Government employes at the conference center to observe Ascension Day, a Roman Cath olic holiday.

headline: TV NETWORKS SCORED BY GARDNER GROUP
lead_paragraph: Common Cause, the citizens' lobby whose antiwar television program was denied network presentation, yesterday accused the three commercial television networks of “trying to stay out of trouble” rather than pre sent a full range of views on the nation's problems.

headline: Advertising:
lead_paragraph: At the request of the White House and the American Red Cross, the Advertising Coun cil will prepare a massive advertising campaign to focus the attention of the nation on the plight of our troops who are prisoners of war or missing in Southeast Asia.
author: By Philip H. Dougherty

headline: Allied and Enemy War Deaths Decline
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 20 (UPI) — A decline in battlefield deaths in Indochina last week was reported today for both allies and the enemy.

headline: Vietnam: Steps Toward Reunification
lead_paragraph: PARIS—In 1963, forty days before the end of the Diem regime, I urged my compatriots to seek a peaceful so lution in South. Vietnam through nego tiation. In my opinion this was insepa rable from a return to the 1954 Geneva agreements which foresaw among other things a halt in all foreign inter ventions and military neutralization of the two zones of North and South Vietnam.
author: By Ho Thong Minh

headline: Court Denies Parole Board Right To Curb Sobell's Political Dissent
lead_paragraph: Morton Sobell, who was con victed as a Soviet spy in 1951, won a Federal Court decision here yesterday permitting him to participate in demonstra tions of political dissent.
author: By Arnold H. Lubasch

headline: TURNPIKE PROTEST COMES UP IN COURT
lead_paragraph: BELLMAWR, N. J., May 20 (AP)—Cases of 97 peace dem onstrators accused of blocking traffic on the New Jersey Turnpike for five hours April 25 were dealt with in a nine hour court session here today.

headline: Theater: ‘Training of Pavlo Hummel’
lead_paragraph: David Rabe's play, “The Basic, Training of Pavlo Hummel,” at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, which opened last night at the Newman Thea ter, introduces a new and authentic voice to our thea ter. What Mr. Rabe is say ing—war is hell, especially when it is in Vietnam—is not at all original, and this is the play's major defect, but he does have a persuasive way of saying things.
author: By Clive Barnes

headline: Censured General Says He Is an Army Sacrifice
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) —Brig. Gen. George H. Young Jr., censured by the Army for failing to follow through ade quately on the Mylai investi gation, said today that he had been sacrificed to critics of the military.

headline: Chicago Banker in Belgrade
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 21 — The Nixon Administra tion, fearful of possible domes tic opposition, is not likely to take significant steps to liber alize East‐West trade before the 1972 elections, an influen tial Chicago banker said here today.

headline: Vietnamese at Saigon Airport, in a Sharp Change, Intercept, Smugglers
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21—The airport here, long a smuggler's dream, is turning into a nightmare not only for smugglers but also for ordinary travelers, much to the delight of the American advisers who have been urging strict meas ures for months.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: LAIRD URGES SAIGON TO ACT ON NARCOTICS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 21 (Reu ters)—Defense Secretary Mel vin R. Laird today said the South Vietnamese Government must be more realistic in facing up to the problem of how to stop narcotics from reaching American servicemen.

headline: Patents of the Week
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 21— A lightweight armored seat, for which a patent will be granted June 1, is already in general use by helicopter pilots in Vietnam. The bullet‐ proof bucket seat, made of ceramic mate rials, protects a craft's pilot from his knees to his neck. The Norton Company, Worcester, Mass., manufac turer of the seat, will re ceive Patent 3,581,620 as assignee of Eldon W. Hauck and Samuel H. Coes, engi neers on its staff.
author: By Stacy V. Jones Special to The New York Times

headline: 30 U.S. SOLDIERS KILLED IN ATTACKS ON VIETNAM BASES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, May 22—Thirty Ameri can soldiers were killed and 50 wounded in three devastating rocket and mortar attacks in the northern war zone of South Vietnam, the United States com mand announced today.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Lorrin S. Anderson New York, May 11, 1971

headline: New Drive Into Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21 (Reuters) — American helicopters have airlifted near ly 2,000 South Vietnamese troops into eastern Cambodia for a drive against two North Vietnamese divisions, military sources here reported today.

headline: House Inquiry Scored as a ‘Red Smear’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 21 —A leader of the antiwar coalition that organized the April 24 demonstration here charged to day that the House Internal Security Committee was en gaging in a “red smear” to di vert public attention from an tiwar activities.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Curb Is Sought on Mylai Statements
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., May 21 (UPI) — Col. Oran K. Hender son's lawyers sought today to prohibit the Defense Depart ment from making any more public statements about the My lai case on the ground that such statements were prejudicing the colonel's defense.

headline: Votes on Draft Bill Amendments Scheduled Over Next 2 Weeks
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) —The Senate agreed today to a series of votes over the next two weeks on key amendments to a bill to extend the military draft, which under existing law, would expire June 30.

headline: Security in Austin Is Expanded For Johnson Ceremony Today
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex., May 21—The number of guards to be on hand for the dedication of the Lyndon Baines Johnson Li brary tomorrow was apparently doubled today after antiwar groups said they would, storm police lines if necessary to make their views known.
author: By Martin Waldron Special to The New York Times

headline: EXEMPTIONS VOTED IN UNDECLARED WAR
lead_paragraph: SALEM, Ore., May 21—The Oregon, Senate passed today a bill to exempt Oregon service men from serving in wars that have not been declared by Congress.

headline: Carrier Returns to War
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21 (AP)—The United States air craft carrier Midway has re turned to the Indochina war after more than five years off the line for extensive modern ization, the Navy said today. The 25‐year‐old carrier has been on station in the Tonkin Gulf since Tuesday, and her planes have been attacking the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos.

headline: Nixon Hails Johnson Library at Dedication
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex., May 22—The $18.6‐million Lyndon Baines Johnson Library complex was dedicated today in a nationally televised ceremony that drew 3,000 guests, including former and present aspirants for the Presidency.
author: By Martin Waldron Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Is it possible we have heard a Presi dent talk again about a war to end wars? Surely, since Wilson, it is very late to believe such things.
author: (The Rev.) Frederick F. Johnson Rector, St. Paul's Episcopal Church Spring Valley, N. Y., May 10, 1971

headline: Relatives Seek Aid
lead_paragraph: GENEVA, May 22—A dele gation of 173 wives and rela tives of United States service men missing or held prisoner in Indochina arrived here today for a visit timed to coincide with the start Monday of a Red Cross conference that will con sider revising the 1949 Geneva Conventions protecting military and civilian war victims.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos — In the years when the Vietnamese Com munists had the use of the Cambodian seaport of Sihanouk vine and ample sanctuaries along the Cambodian side of the bor der with South Vietnam, the ef fects of the Indochina war on the populated regions of the Laotian panhandle were limited.
author: —Henry Kamm

headline: U.S. Visitor to Hanoi Hopeful on Prisoners
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 22—A representative of the American Friends Service Committee just back from Hanoi said today that he believed the North Viet namese were ready to negoti ate the release of American prisoners of war sooner than had previously been assumed.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Ban on Vietcong Flag Urged
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) —Legislation has been intro duced in Congress to make it a Federal crime to display a Vietcong or North Vietnamese flag while the United States is fighting in Southeast Asia. The bill was introduced by two Ohio Republicans, Representa tives Clarence E. Niller and Frank T. Bow.

headline: Y.M.C.A., in First Such Act, Calls for Total Withdrawal
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) —The Y.M.C.A. called today for “complete withdrawal of all military forces from Vietnam at the earliest possible time.”

headline: Students in Indiana At Peace Assembly Register for Voting
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS, May 22— Hundreds of high school and college students stood in line under the oak trees of Military Park today to register to vote for the first time at a peace rally organized by Allard K. Lowenstein, the former Repre sentative from Nassau County.
author: By Richard Reeves Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Attorney General John Mitchell has little cause for self‐congratulations [news story May 11], as the battle he brags of winning was really lost.
author: Paul Zuckerman White Plains, N. Y., May 11, 1971

headline: Enemy Bombards Bases In Vietnam in Fourth Day
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 22 — North Vietnamese forces tonight fired rockets and mortar shells into United States bases along the demilitarized zone for a fourth day. The Americans countered with artil lery barrages.

headline: Johnson Says Errors In War Were His Own
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex., May 22— While moving the guests at a barbecue following the dedication of the new Lyn don B. Johnson Library, the former President encoun tered Gen. William C. West moreland, the Army, Chief of Staff, who commanded American forces for him in Vietnam.

headline: Resor Voices Doubts on War And a Volunteer Army by '73
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) —The retiring Army Secretary, Stanley R. Resor, said today that he was leaving the Pen tagon with serious doubts about the wisdom of United States involvement in Vietnam and about whether the Administra tion can reach its goal of an all‐volunteer Army. by mid‐ 1973.
author: SPECIAL TO THE NEW YORK TIMES

headline: 69% in Poll Want More Data on War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 22 — More than two‐thirds of the people questioned in a recent survey said that they believed the Nixon Administration was failing to tell the American people all they should know about the conduct of the Viet nam war, the Gallup poll said today.

headline: Saigon Presidential Hopefuls Are Busy
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam May 23 — The South Vietnamese presidential election is still more than four months away, but three men have already started their unofficial cam paigning.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: McCarthy Hints Readiness To Lead a 3d Party in '72
lead_paragraph: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 23—Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy ridiculed several of the leaders of the Democratic party in a major speech today and suggested that he might be ready to lead a third party in the 1972 Presidential cam paign.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Advisers in Mekong Delta darned on Foe
lead_paragraph: CANTHO, South Vietnam, May 23—Senior United States military and civilian officers here in the heart of the Mekong Delta have warned American pacification advisers that the enemy is engaged in a low‐key phase of political consolidation while waiting for the Ameri cans to leave.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: Horse Show News
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Saigon Will Retry Student for Treason
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 23—The Government has decided to retry on charges of treason a young medical stu dent whose trial last year end ed when the Supreme Court ruled that the military field court judging his case was un constitutional.
author: Lewis C. Solmon Assistant Professor of Economics City University of New York New York, April 22, 1971

headline: Clark Calls Nixon ‘Lawless’ In Moves on War Protests
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) —Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, said today that it was “lawless” for the Nixon Administration to obtain a court order to evict antiwar veterans from the Capitol grounds during the April pro tests and then to refuse to en force the order.

headline: U.S. BASE NEAR DMZ SHELLED BY ENEMY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Men day, May 24 (AP)—North Viet namese units fired rockets into an allied base near the demili tarized zone last night for the fifth successive night of shell ings along the DMZ.

headline: Hanoi Aide, in Interview, Links Pullout Date and P.O.W. Issue
lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 22—Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's chief negotia tor in the Paris peace talks, said yesterday that the question of American prisoners could be “rapidly” and “easily” settled it President Nixon set a date for total United States with drawal.
author: By Anthony Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: Four Bills Seek Aid for Addicted G.I.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 23 — Apprehension that a deluge of drug‐addicted former service men may be released into American society is reflected in four bills coming up in Con gress to require the armed services to keep such men in uniform until they are cured.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Biologists in China Tell of Scientific Gains
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, May 23 — Two American biologists who are completing a unique tour of Chinese Conimunist research establishments said today that they had become convinced that China had developed “a lot of important scientific in formation of which we are un aware.”
author: By Seymour Topping Special to The New York Times

headline: Buddhist Immolates Himself In Antiwar Protest in Hue
lead_paragraph: HUE, South Vietnam, Tues day, May 25 (UPI)—A 16‐year‐ old South Vietnamese tailor ac tive in Buddhist student affairs burned himself to death here early today in an antiwar pro test, the police said.

headline: Administration Rejects Gallup Poll on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 24 (UP)—The Nixon Adminis tration said today that “the American people understand” its Vietnam policies, although a Gallup poll indicated that 67 per cent believed they were not being told all that was known on the subject.

headline: Kennedy Says Nixon Tried To Provoke Coast Students
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 24 (Reu ters)—Senator Edward M. Ken nedy said today that President Nixon deliberately attempted to, provoke students in San Jose, Calif., just one month after the Presidential Commission on Campus Unrest urged officials to exercise restraint in dealing with students.

headline: Colonel Says Every Large Combat Unit in Vietnam Has a Mylai
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., May 24 (UPI)—Col. Oran K. Hender son, the highest ranking officer still charged in the Mylai mas sacre, said today that every large American combat unit in Vietnam had committed similar atrocities.

headline: Actions by Mills Hint He Has '72 Objective
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N. C., May 24 — Can a 62‐year‐old small‐town Arkansas lawyer convert a powerful position in Congress into a pivotal role in Demo cratic Presidential policies next year?
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Dean Acheson: On Winding Down
lead_paragraph: The present debate about the Presi dent's intentions regarding troop with drawals from Vietnam arises from what he has said rather than from what he has done. The logic of the facts is plain. When Mr. Nixon an nounced the beginning of troop with drawals, the authorized troop strength in Vietnam was 549,000; actual troop strength probably a few thousand less. Withdrawals actually made since that time, plus the 100,000 announced by the President to be made by December 31, 1971, will amount to 365,000, leav ing a remainder from authorized. strength of about 185,000 in Vietnam. The average withdrawal rate over the thirty months of the operation has been 12,000 per month.
author: By Dean Acheson

headline: Diplomatic Notes
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 24— The warming breezes from abroad are treating the Nixon Administration to its first big diplomatic thaw and causing the men around the President to toy with the immodest thought that they must he do ing something right—in rela tions with Moscow and Pe king, in promot ing cease‐fire in the Middle East and perhaps even in managing the withdrawal from Southeast Asia. The pol iticians around the White House are especially pleased with the news about arms control and troop negotia tions and Ping‐Pong, which lets their President shine in his favorite role of statesman and should leave the Demo crats doubting that they can ever steal the peace issue from an incumbent.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 24—An inter view with Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's chief negotiator in Paris, by Anthony Lewis of The New, York Times, has made plain the essential illogic of Pres ident Nixon's stand on the so‐called “P.O.W. issue.”
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Medina Rearing Delayed
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., May 24 (UPI)—The pretrial hearing for Capt. Ernest L. Medina, charged with over‐all respon sibility in the Mylai massacre, was postponed today because the military judge was conduct ing a court‐martial in Hunts ville, Ala, The new “tentative” day for the hearing was set for June 16.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Mortimer May

headline: DISMISSAL IS SOUGHT OF MAYDAY CHARGES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) —The American Civil Liberties Union asked a United States District Court today to dismiss misdemeanor charges against thousands of persons arrested during antiwar demonstrations the first week of this month.

headline: Air Operations Continue
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, May 24 (AP)— United States aircraft carried on normal operations out of Camranh Bay today although fires burned more than 18 hours after the enemy attack.

headline: In Wake of Enemy Rocket Attack on Base Near DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 25—Enemy de molition experts crept into the huge American base at Cam rank Bay and blew up one and a half million gallons of avia tion fuel, the United States command announced yesterday.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: CRITICS SAY NIXON MISUSES JURIES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25 — The antiwar movement intro duced a new tactic today as leaders of the militant May day Collective said that they were starting a concerted at tack on grand jury practices in the nation's judicial system.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Senator Strom Thurmond has asked President Nixon to appoint Albert S. Watson, former Republican Represen tative from South Carolina, to the Court of Military Ap peals, and he has been told Mr. Watson would be ap pointed, subject to an F.B.I. sl.earance, a spokesman for Mr. Thurmond said yester day.
author: Albin Krebs

headline: Ex‐Aide in Pentagon Lends His Support To Col. Henderson
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., May 25 (AP)—The Army colonel who made the first Pentagon inves tigation of the killings at Mylai 4 today questioned Col. Oran K. Henderson's ability to probe thoroughly the incident and carry out his normal duties as a combat brigade commander.

headline: SENATE BARS CURB ON VIETNAM DUTY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25—The Senate rejected today, 52 to 21, a proposal that would have pro hibited the assignment of draft ees to combat in Vietnam after the end of the year without their assent.
author: By David E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: Javits, in Saigon, Sees Need for $2‐Billion in Aid Yearly After Pullout
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 25—Senator Jacob K. Dav its said today that South Viet nam would need at least $2‐ billion a year in economic and military support from the Unit ed States after American troops withdrew.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON ACCEPTS HANOI P.O.W. PLAN
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 26—The South Vietnamese Government an nounced today that it was ready to accept North Vietnamese conditions for the release of 570 disabled war prisoners from South Vietnamese prison camps.

headline: Generals Rescued
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 26 (AP)— Enemy soldiers shot down a helicopter carrying two allied generals yesterday, but the of Ificers were rescued uninjured.

headline: House Unit Cites Rise in G.I. Drug Use
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25—A Congressional study mission re ported today that heroin addic tion had become so great a problem among American serv icemen in Southeast Asia that its only effective solution was the withdrawal of all troops from the area.
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Joseph B. Milgram (letter May 7) requests that the proponents of U.S. withdrawal from Indochina ask them selves what North Vietnam is doing in those sovereign nations and why they do not withdraw. It is implied that only their withdrawal should signal our own.
author: Ruth L. Bertin

headline: Vote on Draftees' War Duty
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)—Following is the roll call vote by which the Senate rejected, 52 to 21, today an amendment by Senator Gay lord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, to a bill extending the draft law, to bar sending draftees to Vietnam unless they volunteer:

headline: ‘No Deal’ Involved
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, May 26—State Department of ficials said that there was “no deal” involved in the release. They said, they hoped, but had no reason to believe, that Hanoi would proceed to release Amer ican prisoners.

headline: From Dakto to Detroit: Death of a Troubled Hero
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, May 25—A few tenants living in the E. J. Jefferies Homes, a dreary public housing project in Corktown, an old Detroit neighborhood, can still re member Dwight Johnson as a little boy who lived in one of the rust‐brown buildings with his mother and baby brother. They think it strange, after all that has happened to Dwight, to remember him as a gentle boy who hated to fight.
author: By Jon Nordieimer Special to The New York Times

headline: PAUL ANKA MARKS 15 YEARS ON STAGE
lead_paragraph: Fifteen years is not very long in a show business ca reer (where was George Jes se! 15 years ago? Vietnam or Korea?) But when you are 29 and you have been in show business for 15 years, it must seem like a long time.
author: By John S. Wilson

headline: China Expert Sees Chance to End War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 26—An academic specialist in Chinese affairs told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that recent changes in China's foreign policy offered the United States an opportunity for a “genuine, face6saving res olution of the Indochina war.”
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: United Presbyterians End Assembly on 10th Day
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, May 26 — The United Presbyterian Church end ed its general assembly here this afternoon after making signifi cant decisions in the areas of the women's liberation move ment, civil rights and Protestant unity.
author: By George Dugan Special to The New York Times

headline: Jaywalking With a Two‐Time Loser
lead_paragraph: ITHACA, N. Y.—On my sixteenth birthday while visiting Los Angeles, I crossed Wilshire Boulevard against the light. I was arrested. The judge let me off with a lecture, on account of my age, and because I had come from New York where people don't know that laws are to be obeyed.
author: By Howard A. Rodman

headline: Pullout of Equipment a Problem, Too
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 26—As the American role in the war declines, officers are discovering that disposing of the installations and supplies in Vietnam is more complicated than it was to build them or bring them in.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: ABRAMS CAUTIONS ON LAXITY BY G.I.'S
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, May 27 (AP)—Gen. Creighton W. Abrams said to day that a “herculean effort” was needed to keep United States troops as alert as they need to be during the Ameri can disengagement from the Vietnam war.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Dovish Senators and Representatives —many of whom seem to think they can soar to the Presidency on their white‐winged reputations—often assert that the North Vietnamese would glad ly return American prisoners of war if only we would remove our troops im mediately and declare our interest in Vietnam summarily ended.

headline: U.S. Pressure Reported Behind Saigon's Decision to Accept Hanoi P.O.W. Plan
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 26.—The United States ap plied firm pressure on the Sai gon Government to persuade it to meet all of Hanoi's condi tions for the release of 570 dis abled North Vietnamese prison ers, informed sources said to night.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Pharmacies Barred to G.I.'s in Drug Fight
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 26 — The U. S. military command has declared all Viet namese pharmacies off limits to American servicemen in South Vietnam.
author: Hobart Taylor Jr

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Some war‐protester tactics employed in Washington, D.C., during and since the Mayday weekend seemed wholly incompatible with the public well being. The official reaction appeared to include many elements which were infinitely worse — which were, in fact, a flagrant threat to free government in this country.

headline: Antismuggling Accord Due
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 26 (Reuters)—The South Viet namese Premier, Tran Thien Khiem, said today that his Gov ernment and Cambodia were ready to sign an agreement aimed at controlling smuggling, including that of heroin and other narcotics, into South Viet nam.

headline: Electronic Gadgets Making Security a Big Business
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, May 26— Thieves beware: The tech nology of the second half of the 20th century, the detec tion devices of Vietnam and the modern miracles of com munication are zeroing in on you.
author: By Jerry M. Flint Special to The New York Times

headline: U. S. Court Orders Washington to Limit Protest Prosecution
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 26— The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Co lumbia ordered city officials tonight to suspend prosecution of demonstrators arrested in the capital earlier this month in those cases where they did not have “adequate evidence to support probable cause for arrest and charge.”
author: Hobart Taylor Jr

headline: Defection Hearing Set
lead_paragraph: QUANTICO, Va., May 27 (AP)—A preliminary hearing in the case of Marine Sgt. Jon M. Sweeney, an accused defector charged with aiding the enemy in Vietnam, will be held June 15, the Marine Corps said today.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The basic reasons for our payments deficit are the Vietnam war and the loss of competitive power by American business. The Vietnam war has caused an enormous drain of dollars from productive use at home to complete futility abroad.
author: Benjamin H. Beckhart

headline: U.S. War Toll Put at 38 in Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 27 (AP)—The United States command reported to day that 38 Americans died in combat in Indochina last week. It was the highest total in three weeks, but it did not include all of the 30 men killed in three North Vietnamese shelling attacks last Friday.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: “The most momentous fact about the pattern of American politics,” the late Clinton Rossiter wrote at the be ginning of the sixties, “is that we live under a persistent, obdurate, one might almost say tyrannical two‐party system. We have the Republicans, and we have the Democrats, and we have almost no one else. ...”
author: By James Reston

headline: Foe Repulsed in Cambodia, Saigon Says
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, May 28 (AP)—In a surge of heavy fighting reported yes terday in eastern Cambodia, North Vietnamese troops stormed into the town of Snoul but were repelled by South Vietnamese forces with the aid of American airpower.

headline: PRESIDENT SHUNS 1972 BALLOT ROLE
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 27— The White House has apparent ly decided to use stand‐in can didates for President Nixon, rather than to put his name on the ballot, in most of next year's primary races against Administration opponents.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: 5 PEACE ACTIVISTS ASK AID ON TAXES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 27— Five young peace activists are making an appeal for contribu tions to enable them to pay off a $15,000 debt to the Inter nal Revenue Service and avoid seizure of their automobiles and other property.

headline: Nuremberg Has Not Failed—Yet
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE—Burke Marshall's positive assertion “that the Nuremberg experiment has failed” may he an understandable reaction of revulsion against the Mylai incident and frus tration at the Calley verdict. But to dismiss the principles of Nuremberg because of these feelings Is to invite a reversion to what, in the early years of this century, were regarded as ac ceptable legal doctrines concerning war.
author: By Bruno V. Bitker

headline: U.S. Women Stand Vigil At Peace Talks in Paris
lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 27—More than 100 American women whose husbands or sons are missing in action in Southeast Asia stood silently outside the building where peace in Vietnam was be ing discussed today.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: House Team Asks Army to Cure Addicts
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 27—A Congressional investigating team urged in a report made public today that the Army be required to identify and re habilitate the 26,000 to 39,000 American heroin addicts in South Vietnam before returning them to civilian life.
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: V.F.W. Chief Says Withdrawal Should Match Prisoner Release
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) —The head of a war veterans group said yesterday that Unit ed States troop withdrawals from Vietnam should be done at a rate matching the release of United States prisoners of war.

headline: FOE SAID TO FAIL AGAIN AT SNOUL
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, May 28 (AP)—A new battle for the eastern Cambo dian town of Snoul was fought yesterday, and allied forces said they had won it.

headline: Top Pentagon Aides Instructed To Stay Silent on Mylai Cases
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., May 28 (AP)—The Pentagon's top of ficers were told by a military judge today to stop making statements about action taken against Army officers impli cated in the alleged cover‐up of the killings at Mylai.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Max Fink M.D

headline: A Beauty Contest With a Difference: Saigon's First, and Girls Didn't Weep
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 28 — No one showed their legs, but one girl sprinkled gold sequins on her eyelids while another wore long black lace gloves. At least five contestants had such jutting silhouettes it was believed they wore padded brassieres. Nearly all 30 con testants wore at least one pair of false eyelashes, and everyone seemed to smell of hair spray.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: MITSUBISHI RUNS A TIGHT MEETING
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, May 28—A shout ing, fist‐swinging confrontation between anti‐war protesters and rightists turned the semi annual general shareholder meeting of giant Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., into pandemonium today.
author: By Takashi Oka Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Ursula Zilinsky

headline: HUGE AID TO CITIES OPPOSED BY AGNEW
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 — Vice President Agnew spoke out sharply today against the idea of the Federal Govern ment's moving hastily and with massive expenditure of funds to help the cities as soon as “the din of crisis and the rhet oric of disaster begin to be heard.”
author: By John Herbers Special to The New York Times

headline: A Volunteer Army?
lead_paragraph: With the Selective Service extension bill now the pending business on the Senate floor, the handful of antiwar liberals who have opposed draft repeal are being challenged in open debate. Forced to reconcile their opposition to the Indochina war with their support of the system which is its prime source of unwilling manpower, the prodraft doves have developed an extensive ar ray of objections to repeal; a common theme has been the beneficial impact of draft eligibility as a stimulus to antiwar protest. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the best‐known opponent of ending the draft, articulated this con cern in a recent speech: “It is unwise to insulate from the horrors of war middle and upper class Americans who might lead the pretest against sense less foreign adventures. I frankly would question, for example, whether the current pressure for de‐escalation of the Indochina war would be as great if young men from every social background were not threatened with service in that war.”
author: By Stewart W. Kemp

headline: Woodside to Get A New Memorial For War Victims
lead_paragraph: The community of Wood side, Queens, will receive a new war memorial and pub lic park tomorrow as part of its 48th observance of Memorial Day.

headline: Television
lead_paragraph: THE hot topic is suddenly drug addiction. It's not new, just hot. Ad dicts in the city, in su burbia, in middle America, in Vietnam—come the headlines and the analyses, and it's time for instant crisis and breast‐beating. Of course the problem has been gestating in the public arena for years but perhaps it is best to let bygones of official adminis trative blindness be bygones. Perhaps.
author: By John J. O'Connor

headline: Rockets Kill 12 at Danang
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Sunday, May 30 (Reuters) — Twelve civilians were killed and 11 were wounded when North Viet namese rockets struck five houses in the northern city of Danang this morning, the South Vietnamese command reported.

headline: The Peace Movement Is Using The Wrong Strategy
lead_paragraph: IN the spring of 1971 light really did appear at the end of the bloody tunnel in Vietnam.
author: By Michael Harrington

headline: Jo Hornblower Marries Alix Tower
lead_paragraph: BEDFORD, N. Y., May 29 —Miss Alexandra Cheston Tower, who received a B.A. degree in English from Stan ford University in March, was married here this afternoon to Jonathan Marshall Horn blower, a veteran of service with the Army in Vietnam.

headline: Kerr on ‘The Basic Training of Hummel’
lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH one's first supposition is that “The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel” is going to be another outburst against the Vietnam war, and though David Rabe's play at the Public does waste a con siderable amount of time go ing through the familiar mo tions of barking commands at clog‐trotting trainees, the evening is actually something else. It is a play about the self‐assertion of an agreeable cipher:
author: —Walter Kerr

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Those who advo care a negotiated settlement of the war in Indochina instead of a unilat eral American withdrawal from a continuing war fought with American support for Saigon, are bound by the logic of their views to oppose the re‐election of President Thieu next October. His “four‐no” policy (no coalition, no neutralism, no Commu nist party and no land concessions to the Communists) precludes any hope of negotiation.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Foe Shifts Attacks to the Saigon Region
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 29 (AP)—The enemy command shifted its attacks last night and today to the Saigon region and the southern half of South Vietnam.

headline: NAVY ANNOUNCES AMNESTY ON DRUGS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sun day, May 30—Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt, Chief of United States Naval Operations, today an nounced a 30‐day amnesty pro gram to rehabilitate Navy drug addicts in South Vietnam.

headline: Vietnamese Students in San Diego Bewildered by Hostility They Encounter
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, May 30 — In the living room of a small bungalow just off the San Diego State College campus, 10 Vietnamese students sat listening to a recording of a plaintive song from their homeland:
author: By Everett R. Holles Special to The New York Times

headline: House Member Says Nixon In '68 Vowed a Fast Peace
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) — Representative Donald W. Riegle Jr., Republican of Michi gan said today that he was told by Richard M. Nixon in the Presidential campaign of 1968 that if the Republicans won “we will end this war in six months.”

headline: The Critics Have Lost Their Cool
lead_paragraph: ROXBURY, Conn.— Any assertion that “our war in Indochina is based on killing civilians” is, I believe, com pletely and demonstrably untrue, If this charge of attempted genocide had been accurate, surely the populations of both North and South Vietnam would have been decimated by now. Instead, there has been an actual esti mated increase of about 2,000,000 people in South Vietnam since 1965, and of estimated hundreds of thou sands in North Vietnam.
author: By Hanson W. Baldwin

headline: Ky Confirms Plan to Seek South Vietnam Presidency
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 30 (Reuters)—Vice Presi dent Nguyen Cao Ky confirmed at an impromptu news confer ence today that he was a can didate for President in the Oct. 3 election but told newsmen to wait a few clays for further details about his plans.

headline: Screen: 'The Great Chicago Conspiracy Circus'
lead_paragraph: If you recall last year's Off Broadway "Chicago 70," which was put on by the Toronto Workshop Company at the Martinique Theater here, you're hereby apprised that the 16mm. color film version on view at the Film Forum through next weekend is essentially the same improvisational dramatization. It includes excerpts of the 1969-70 trial of the "Chicago 8" with infusions of "Alice in Wonderland," juvenile classroom recitations and pseudo-radio broadcasts. The film version, labeled "The Great Chicago Conspiracy Circus," is decidedly true to its title as "circus," "conspiracy" and justifiable polemics, but it is rarely moving as movie drama.Basically, a moviegoer is affected by what he sees and even if the truth, like the politics of our time, is both tragic and comic, it has to be strongly visualized as well as declared on screen. There is a great speaking of minds from the actual record in "The Great Chicago Conspiracy Circus" but, unfortunately, there is not a great deal to stir the hearts or the eyes of the uninitiate.As noted, the polemics as well as the confusion of a baffled Judge Julius J. Hoffman facing the taunts and life-style (and the psychedelic dress) of the disparate likes of Abbie Hoffman, Bobby Seale, Allen Ginsberg (reciting some of his explicitly sexual poems) and Country Joe McDonald singing his anti-Vietnam rock, are forceful and to the point.One is also Impressed that maintaining law and order before defendants and attorneys who are trying to stress that the court is not their idea of law and order any more than is Mayor Richard J. Daly's rule of Chicago strikes effective notes for both the Establishment and a younger generation divorced from it.Kerry Feltham, the director, who has employed practically the same cast that George Luscombe used in the play, has drawn forthright declamations from all of them, both black and white. And, it must be noted that, while it is sometimes confusing, different actors are sometimes switched to play the same role, such as Judge Hoffman's, and do prove their versatility.The cast, to name a few such as Mel Dixon, Jim Lawrence, Peter Faulkner, Neil Walsh and Diane Grant and not to slight the others, are Yippie, hippie and serious enough to project authentic dedication to their art and dialogue. But like the documentary "Breathing Together: Revolution of the Electric Family," seen here last month and also dealing with the trial, "The Great Chicago Conspiracy Circus," which was photographed on sets with a mirror background, is generally as static as a photographed play.What the Toronto Workshop Company has to say is obviously ingenious theater even if it is political and perhaps partisan. But it is, sadly enough, good rhetoric that does not add up to an exciting or innovative film.
author: By A. H. Weiler

headline: Rogers Hears 175 At Colgate Reject Role in Asian War
lead_paragraph: HAMILTON, N. Y., May 30— More than a third of Colgate University's graduates—175 out of 479—stood up quietly this afternoon to confront Secretary of State William P. Rogers with a pledge, “If drafted, we will not accept a combat role in Indochina.”
author: By Peter Kihss Special to The New York Times

headline: 400 FINED $5 EACH IN ANTIWAR MARCH
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Mass., May 30 (UPI)—About 100 Vietnam vet erans and more than 300 sym pathetic townsfolk were fined $5 each today for having violated curfew regulations during a peace demonstration and campout on historic Lex ington Green.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Max Gordon

headline: Souphanouvong Visits Hanoi
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, May 30 (AP)—Prince Souphanouvong of Laos, leader of the Communist. Pathet Lao, paid an unpublicized visit to North Vietnam last week with a delegation of Laotian offi cials, including military leaders, the Hanoi Radio reported today.

headline: GALLEY SENTENCED TO LIFE FOR MURDERS AT MYLAI 4; LENGTHY REVIEW TO BEGIN
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 31—First Lieut. William L. Cal ley Jr. was sentenced to life imprisonment today for slaying at least 22 South Vietnamese civilians three years ago at the hamlet of Mylai 4.
author: By Romer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Reports by Saigon on Toll Inflicted on Enemy in Laos Are Arousing Doubts
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31 — The campaign against Communist supply lines in Laos is over, but statistical warfare continues to rage, rem iniscent of the days when American commanders put the stress on “the body count” to demonstrate success in the Viet nam war.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Verdict Protested Anew; 3 Try to Jail Themselves
lead_paragraph: The outcome of the trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. stirred renewed and mount ing protests yesterday, with many Americans expressing their feelings through tele grams, petitions and resolu tions, and a few—both public figures and private citizens — taking more dramatic action.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: White House Reaction
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., March 31 (AP) — At the West ern White House, the press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said the regulation “seems to be directed towards support of the President and his Vietnam policy.” Asked by reporters if Mr. Nixon agreed that United States involvement in the war should be ended by January, 1973, Mr. Ziegler said. “It's our objective to accomplish these objectives as soon as possible.”

headline: Doc Blanchard Retires
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex., March 31 (AP) — Col. Felix (Doc) Blanchard, all‐America fullback at Army in 1944‐46, retired from the Air Force yesterday. Blanchard flew 113 jet fighter missions in the Vietnam War.

headline: Thieu Terms Laos Drive Saigon's ‘Biggest Victory’
lead_paragraph: DONGHA, South Vietnam, March 31—President Nguyen Van Thieu declared today that his troops' recent thrust into Laos had attained “the biggest victory ever” for the armedforces of South Vietnam.

headline: Hard Labor Defined
lead_paragraph: FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., March 31 (UPI)—Maj. Cleve Cunningham, public informa tion officer at Fort Leaven worth, said tonight that the “hard labor” Lieutenant Calley was sentenced to “happens to be only a term.”

headline: New Effort Against Trail
lead_paragraph: DONGHA, South Vietnam, March 31 — A “new phase” in the South Vietnamese effort to disrupt the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos was announced here today by President Nguyen Van Thieu.

headline: CASUALTIES HEAVY AS ENEMY BURNS TOWN IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 1 — Enemy troops have attacked and burned most of a district capital in the northern part of South Vietnam, reportedly inflicting heavy casualties on civilians and their militia.

headline: Thieu Comments He Was Confident Guilty Would Pay
lead_paragraph: DONG HA, South Vietnam, March 31 — President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that he had been confident that justice would punish those guilty of the killings at Mylai.

headline: NEW DRIVE BEGINS IN AREA OF MYLAI
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31—South Vietnamese troops have begun a sweeping operation in the general region where the Mylai massacre oc curred three years ago that may force as many as 16,000 people from their homes.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Liberals Seek ‘War Crimes’ Inquiry
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 31 — With the aid of some Vietnam veterans, a group of liberal Democrats sought today to pre vail upon the House Armed Services Committee to conduct a public inquiry into alleged American war crimes in Viet nam.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: HOUSE DEMOCRATS ASK PULLOUT BY '73
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 31 — House Democrats called today for an end to United States involvement in Indochina by the start of 1973.
author: By Marjorie Hunter Special to The New York Times

headline: Chinese Fishing Boat Sunk In Collision With Soviet Ship
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, March 31 — The Soviet Union announced tonight that a Soviet freighter had col lided with and sunk a Commun ist Chinese fishing schooner in the Gulf of Tonkin off the North Vietnam coast last night.

headline: Life for Lieutenant Calley
lead_paragraph: The military court that ruled against unnecessary barbarism in war in convicting Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. of murder in Vietnam was wisely consistent in rejecting the barbarism of capital punishment when it sentenced the young officer to life imprisonment.

headline: Agnew Describes Fulbright As Arrogant and Frustrated
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)—Vice President Agnew today described Senator J. Wil liam Fulbright as an arrogant, frustrated presidential candi date who was currying favor with the news media and feed ing Hanoi's hope for a divided United States.

headline: Pravda Scores Pentagon
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, March 31 — The Communist party newspaper, Pravda, charged today that Lieutenant Calley was a “scape goat” and that his trial had been part of “a whole series of ma chinations by the Pentagon to save from justice most of those involved in the crime.”

headline: Kremlin Rules Out Easing Of Bars to Western Ideas
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, March 31—Rank ing Soviet Communist party, leaders lashed out at Moscow's ideological adversaries today and told the party's 24th Con gress that there should be no letup in resistance to ideas not approved by the Kremlin.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Bans Weeklies Again
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1 (AP)—Saigon authori ties have banned the April 4 issues of Time and Newsweek from sale in South Vietnam for articles considered “hostile to national security.” It marked the second week in a row that the magazines have been banned here. The action does not affect sales to American military personnel in post ex changes.

headline: U.S. Veterans of Vietnam War Rally on Wall Street for Peace
lead_paragraph: A veteran of the war in Vietnam who has three Purple Hearts, a Bronze Star and a Silver Star told a noontime Wall Street rally yesterday, “We are all of us in this country guilty for having allowed the war to go on.”

headline: 400 College Leaders Condemn War Policy in Letter to Nixon
lead_paragraph: More than 400 student presi dents and college editors have signed an open letter to Presi dent Nixon condemning his policies in Vietnam and charg ing that the Administration “seriously misinterprets the mood of both the campus and the countryside.”
author: By John Kifner

headline: Agnew Denounces ‘Home‐Front Snipers’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1— Vice President Agnew called critics of the war in Indochina “home‐front snipers!” today and accused them of having fos tered a negative attitude to ward American combat vet erans.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: The ‘Forgotten’ G.I.'s Near Khesanh
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 30—The American in fantrymen who have been patrolling the jungle‐covered mountains west of Khesanh —fighting and sometimes dy ing in obscure small‐unit clashes while supporting the South Vietnamese invasion of Laos—feel that they are for gotten men.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: F.B.I. CHECKED GROUP RELAYING P.O.W. MAIL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) —The Federal Bureau of Inves tigation confirmed today that it had questioned relatives of prisoners of war about the peace group that relays mail to and from American prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

headline: DRAFT UNTIL 1973 IS VOTED BY HOUSE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1 — The House voted overwhelming ly tonight to continue the mili tary draft until the middle of 1973 and sharply increase pay and allowances for servicemen.
author: By David E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As the South Vietnamese stream back across the border, the official dispatches‐7‐and President Nixon him self—describe the military action in Laos as successful.
author: Saul Levitt

headline: Opposition to Galley's Conviction and Sentence Grows in Nation
lead_paragraph: With telegrams, offers of money and demonstrations, Americans in both the public and private sectors expressed growing opposition yesterday to the conviction and sentenc ing of First‐Lieut. William L Calley Jr.

headline: Recapture of Base. Overrun by Enemy Reported by Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, April 2—A two‐day battle in the Central Highlands in which a North Vietnamese regi ment stormed into a South, Vietnamese fire base and then was pushed out again was re ported today by the Saigon command.

headline: New Phase of Indochina Debate
lead_paragraph: News Analysis
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Foe Recaptures Laos Post
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 1 (Reuters) — North Vietnamese forces launched a heavy coun terattack around the royal cap ital of Luang Prabang in north ern Laos and recaptured a stra tegic hilltop position, a De fense Ministry spokesman said today.

headline: PRESIDENT ORDERS GALLEY RELEASED FROM STOCKADE
lead_paragraph: President Nixon yesterday ordered First Lieutenant Wil liam L. Calley Jr. released from the stockade at Fort Benning, Ga., and returned to his guar ters on the base while his mur der conviction is being re viewed.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: Dissidence Unit Has Dossier on 14,000
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1 — A Department of Justice intel ligence unit that has replaced an Army Intelligence detach ment as the Government's main watchman of political dis sidence has compiled computer ized dossiers on nearly 14,000 Americans.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Georgians in House Shift To Opposition to the War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1—A break appeared today in the once solid Southern flank in the House supporting the Viet nam war as two conservative Democrats from Georgia ani flounced their opposition to continuation of the fighting.
author: By Join W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Critics of U.S. Oil Policies in Vietnam Shift Focus of Their Attacks
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1 — Critics of the Nixon Adminis tration's oil policies In South Vietnam are shifting the focus of their attacks.
author: By Philip Shabecoff Special to The New York Times

headline: Week's U.S. War Toll: 58 Dead, 542 Wounded
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1 (AP)—The United States command reported to day that 58 Americans were killed in combat last week and 542 were wounded. It was the highest American death toll in a month and the Iargest number of wounded in six months.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: For millions of Americans, the Calley verdict has raised terrible questions about the responsibility for things that have happened it Indochina in the last six years. It is right and inevitable that we examine that record of the past. But it is more urgent that we face one simple fact about the present:
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Americans Closing The Support Bases Used in Laos Drive
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, April 3 (AP)—Long lines of helicopters flew southward out of Quangtri in northeastern South Vietnam yesterday as the United States was closing down its support role for the recent South Vietnamese thrust into Laos.

headline: Marine Serves a Year In 12 Vietnam Killings
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, N. H., April 2 (UPI)—Pvt. Michael A. Schwarz of Weirton, W. Va., convicted of murder ing 12 Vietnamese women and children near Danang in February, 1970, was released today from the Portsmouth naval prison.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Hugh B. Hester

headline: White House Mail
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 2 (UPI)—The Western White House said today that tele grams continued to pour in at a rate of 100 to 1 favoking clemency for Lieutenant Caney.

headline: Trial Is Defended by Army
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2—The Army, defending itself against public outcry against the trial and conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., said to day that it had “a moral and legal obligation” to prosecute him.
author: By Emanuel Perlmutter

headline: Mail on Calley, Especially From South, Takes on Emotional Tone
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2 — One Californian protested with poetry in a letter: “A single leaf does not turn yellow without the silent knowledge of the whole tree.”

headline: HEARINGS START ON A MYLAI CASE
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., April 2 —Preliminary hearings opened here today in the court‐mar tial of Col. Oran K. Henderson, the fourth and highest ranking Army man to be tried on charges arising from the killing of civilians at Mylai 4 almost three years ago.
author: By Emanuel Perlmutter

headline: G.O.P. Antiwar Letter
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) —Fast‐spreading sentiment in Congress for ending the Viet nam war received new impetus today as five House Republi cans joined the effort to pull out all American troops by the end of the year.

headline: DECISION BY NIXON ON CALLEY HAILED
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's order re leasing First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. from the stockade pending a review of his case continued to receive widespread public and private support yes terday.
author: By John Darnton

headline: Gov. Wallace Sees Galley;
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ga., April 2 — First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., now confined to a tiny apartment while his conviction for murder is appealed, spent his first day out of the Fort Benning stockade greeting a parade of visitors that included Gov. George C. Wallace.
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: Woman's Peace Walk Is Over After 45 Days and 450 Miles
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2 — Looking weary but smiling broadly, Mrs. Louise Bruyn walked up the white marble steps of the Capitol at noon today, ending a 450‐mile peace walk that she began 45 days ago in her home town of New ton, Mass.

headline: WESTMORELAND SAYS HE HARBORS NO GUILT
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, April 2 (AP)— The Army Chief of Staff, Gen. William C. Westmoreland, who was the commander of Ameri can troops In Vietnam at the time of the Mylai slayings, said here today that he was sur prised at the outcry following the conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley.

headline: Antiwar Editor Plans Trip To Vietnam on Mail Seizure
lead_paragraph: The editor of an antiwar newspaper for servicemen said yesterday that, he would go to Vietnam to investigate the ef fect of an Army directive con fiscating antiwar literature ad dressed to soldiers in Vietnam.

headline: School Integration Is Termed Harmful To Blacks in South
lead_paragraph: A leader of the Southern Christian Leadership Confer ence told a rally at City Hall Park yesterday that black peo ple in the South would be “better off” with school segre gation.

headline: YALE PARLEY HELD ON ANTIWAR ADS
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, April 3—Two hundred advertising people from New York gathered at Yale University today to dis cuss strategy on “unselling” the war in Indochina to the American people.
author: By Steven R. Weisman Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Who Could Conceive of This?’ Asks Army Doctor at Khesanh
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 20 — The 29‐year‐old Army doctor, who has been treating wounded Americans here for 49 days, recalled with dread the time when a G.I. asked him a question.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: CLASH AT TEACH‐IN UPSETS HARVARD
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 3 —Since the disruption of a pro war teach‐in on March 26, Har vard University administrators have been meeting almost con tinuously with students to ex press their concern over the need to protect free speech.

headline: Officials at Fort Benning Silent On New Calley Move by Nixon
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ga., April 3— While First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. settled into the clois tered routine of his semi‐seques tered life, United States Army officials here at Fort Benning remained silent today on Presi dent Nixon's decision to make a final review of the Lieuten ant's court‐martial conviction for murder.
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: They marched First Lieut. Wil liam Laws Calley Jr. to the stock ade at Fort Benning, Ga., last week. The longest court‐martial in military history had ended, and Calley stood convicted and sentenced to life in prison for the premeditated murder of not fewer than 22 unarmed, un resisting Vietnamese men, wo men and children at Mylai 4 on March 16, 1968.
author: —Richard Hammer

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.—The pressures of politics and war seem remote on this lovely stretch of California coastline, but last week there was no earthly way to avoid them. Mr. Nixon had come here 10 days ago to rest and sort out his thoughts before his television ad dress on Vietnam this Wednes day night. Yet, the world would not let him alone and he seemed, suddenly, a President under siege.
author: —Robert B. Semple Jr

headline: BUILD‐UP AT DMZ BY FOE REPORTED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 3 — Intelligence reports reaching Washington indicate a continu ing North Vietnamese build‐up north of the demilitarized zone and new enemy troop move ments in Laos, Cambodia and the northern part of South Vietnam.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: FIERY RUN, Va., April 3—For a while it almost looked as if somebody were going to propose giving Lieuten ant Calley the Congressional Medal of Honor. Not since the firing of Gen. Dougias MacArthur during the Korean war has there been such an outburst of sympathy for an American soldier. So at last Vietnam has produced an officer everybody recognizes—an anti hero for a war without glory or no bility and a symbol for a time of moral confusion.
author: By James Reston

headline: NIXON DECLARES HE WILL REVIEW THE CALLEY CASE
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 3—The White House announced today that President Nixon would personally review and decide the case of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. “before any final sentence is carried out.”
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Wounded G.L.'s Bitter Over Calley Conviction
lead_paragraph: At the Memphis Veterans Hospital, where many Viet nam veterans are being cared for, the conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. last week was greeted with expressions of deep bitter ness.

headline: Ex‐Beret Says He Killed Agent on Orders of C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Marasco, one of the eight Green Berets who were charged but never tried in the slaying two years ago of a South Vietnamese suspected to have been a double agent, says that he shot and killed the man on “oblique yet very, very clear orderes” from the Central Intelli gence Agency.
author: By John Darnton

headline: ENEMY ATTACKS BASE FOR 4TH DAY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 4 —Military, spokesmen reported today Vila South Vietnamese troops re pulsed another fierce attack yesterday on a small fire base in the Central Highlands near the Laotian border.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—One objective of the 45‐day allied operation against the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos was to prevent a Com munist offensive in the northern regions of South Vietnam. But last week, only a few days after the operation ended, North. Viet namese and Vietcong forces struck in a series of attacks that were more costly in Amer ican and South Vietnamese lives than any in the area since last summer.

headline: Marine Out of Prison For Vietnam Slayings
lead_paragraph: WEIRTON, W. Va., April 3 (AP) — Michael Schwarz, home after a 10‐month prison term for the murder of 12 South Vietnamese civilians, celebrated a belated Christ mas with his family today while telling of hopes to re turn to Vietnam.

headline: Rabbis' Group Urges Pullout In Vietnam by Year's End
lead_paragraph: The Central Conference of American Rabbis called on President Nixon yesterday to withdraw all American mili tary forces from Vietnam by the end of this year.

headline: Gallup Finds 79% Disapprove of Verdict
lead_paragraph: The overwhelming majority of Americans—79 per cent— disapprove of the court‐mar tial finding that First Lieut. William L. Calley was guilty of the premeditated murder of at least 22 South Vietnam ese at Mylai in 1968, accord ing to the Gallup Poll.

headline: Calley Verdict Brings Home the Anguish of War to Public
lead_paragraph: In cities and towns across the nation, to a people who have lived secure in homes and shops and factories untouched by the roaring guns and bombs of modern warfare, the case of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. of the United States Army seems clearly to have brought home a sense of the anguish of war.

headline: The President and Mylai
lead_paragraph: No development in the whole tragic history of the Vietnam war has produced a more spontaneous outcry than, the conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. The protests have brought into unaccustomed unity such divergent national figures as Gov. George C. Wallace Alabama and Dr. Benjamin Speck, to say nothing millions of Americans not normally given to public expressions of outrage.

headline: ‘No Comment,’ Says C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 3—The Central Intelligence Agency said today that it had no corn. ment to make concerning Mr. Marasco's statement.

headline: NOTRE DAME PRIZE GOES TO KUNSTLER
lead_paragraph: NOTRE DAME, Ind., April 3 —William M. Kunstler accepted last night the 1971 Senior Fel low Award of the University lof Notre Dame with a call to “end the war now—by what ever means necessary, short of violence to human beings.”

headline: Curfew Changed in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 (Reuters)—Curfew hours for American servicemen in Saigon have been readjusted to conform with the existing Vietnamese curfew. The new hours of curfew are from 1 A.M. to 5:30 A.M. local time in stead of from 10 P.M. to 6 A.M.

headline: COOPER AND CHURCH PLAN NEW MEASURE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) —A new Cooper‐Church amend ment is planned and it will ask President Nixon to set a date for total withdrawal of all United States forces from South Vietnam, its authors said today.

headline: Rookie Wins Greensboro Golf Playoff
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 4—Brian (Bud) Allin, a 26‐year‐ old red‐haired rookie, crashed through to success in big league golf today when he won the Greater Greensboro open at the first extra hole of a sudden‐death playoff. Sinking a 32‐foot birdie putt, the former Army lieutenant, who served 18 months in Vietnam, beat Dave Eichelberger and Rod Funseth after all three had tied with 72‐hole totals of 275 at the Sedgefield Country Club.
author: By Lincoln A. Werden Special to The New York Times

headline: Cambodians Withdraw
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Mon day, April 5 (Reuters)—A mili tary spokesman said today that North Vietnamese regulars be gan a series of attacks last night and forced Cambodian troops to withdraw from posi tions on the eastern bank of the Mekong River.

headline: Sunday in Saigon: A Lazy Festivity
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4—This Sunday in Sai gon started for some today with antiwar songs and a party in a dimly lit cafe and ended for others with Gabriel Faure's Requiem in the Ro man Catholic Cathedral and a Chinese opera on television. In between, most people passed the day trying with varying degrees of success to forget the Laotian operation, the rest of the war, politics and high prices.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Gen. Maxwell Taylor writes [Op‐Ed March 10]: “Since our involvement in Vietnam there have been only three strategic alternatives from which to choose—ito advance, to retreat or to stand fast.”
author: NEWBOLD MORRIS Teton Village, Wyo., March 15, 1971

headline: A Pacification Adviser Charges Corruption
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4 — United States offi cials are disturbed by a lack of information from American ad visers in the field concerning the real status of pacification in South Vietnam.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Enemy Raids Cast Doubt on Claims of Success in Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4 —Professional American and South Vietnamese soldiers who have assessed favorably the re cent operations in Laos have been unpleasantly surprised by the last week's heavy enemy at tacks in South Vietnam.
author: By Craig It. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Hughes to Propose Panel To Fix War Crimes Blame
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) —Senator Harold E. Hughes said today that he would pro pose the creation of an interna tional commission of leading jurists to set standards for as sessing blame when innocent civilians are killed in a war.

headline: The Cry of America
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The, trial of William Calley is over; now is the trial of the nation. The camera swings from the impassive face of the man who pre sided over the death of some 22 civil ians. Now the glaring light rests upon the people in whose name and by whose power many thousand times that number have died in distant Asia. If at the court‐martial the agony pierced the Army, and one of its young lieutenants, now it is ours.
author: By Francis B. Sayre Jr

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: In the Johnson Administration, peo ple used to talk about “the nun gap” as a necessity in getting the United States out of Vietnam. By that they meant that there had to be a reason able period of time between the American exit and the first Communist attack on a nun—in other words, the collapse of the anti‐Communist Gov ernment in Saigon.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: U.S. Finds Soviet Speeches Cautious
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 4—Sen ior officials of the Nixon admin istration regard United States Soviet relations as in an “in determinate state” in which minor irritants often tend to overshadow major political issues.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Appellate Court Backs N.Y.U. On Closing in 1970 Disorders
lead_paragraph: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court has ruled unanimously that New York University need not refund tui tion for 19 days of classes can celed last May during student disorders over the invasion of Cambodia.
author: By Robert D. McFadden

headline: 608 Copters Reported Damaged
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, April 4 (UPI)— Enemy gunners damaged 608 United States helicopters dur ing the six‐week Laos offen sive, shooting down 104 of them, Lieut. Gen. Hoang Xuan Lam told South Vietnam's Sen ate Defense Committee in a report made available today.

headline: Vietnam Peasants Return to a Hamlet, Hungry and Bitter Toward Regime
lead_paragraph: PHUQUI, South Vietnam—The peasants of this hamlet have returned home two years after having been forced from their huts during an American military sweep, but their lives are, disrupted and many are bitter and hostile toward the Government.

headline: Foe Bolsters Force In Laos
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 5 Reuters)—A Laotian Defense Ministry spokesman said today that the North Vietnamese were reinforcing their position around the royal Laotian capital of Luang Prabang and bringing in antiaircraft guns.

headline: Trail Raided Again
lead_paragraph: QVANGTRI, Thursday, April 6 (Reuters)—South Vietnamese commandos staged another raid today against the Ho Chi Minh trail in southern Laos.

headline: VIETNAMESE POST FIGHTS OFF WAVES OF ENEMY TROOPS
lead_paragraph: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 6 — A South Vietnamese artillery base near the Laotian border was reported under heavy shelling yesterday after having withstood waves of North Vietnamese ground attacks the day before.

headline: CONGRESS DIVIDED OVER CALLEY CASE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) — Members of Congress, crossing party lines, split sharply today over the case of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and President Nixon's plan to make the final decision on his punishment.

headline: The Consequences of Laos
lead_paragraph: President Nixon undoubtedly is tempted to accent the positive as he draws up a new balance sheet on the Laotian invasion for his report to the nation tomorrow on further American troop withdrawals. Public optimism about the outlook in Vietnam has always been felt necessary by the Administration to justify the troop rundown, which Mr. Nixon has committed himself to continue at the current rate of 12,500 a month or faster.

headline: Senators Tale Opener;
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 5—The Washington Senators won their opening‐day game today for the first time in nine years—an event of no small importance in this somewhat dispirited town.
author: By Edwin L. Dale Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Force in Vietnam Now Down to 300,000
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 5 (AP)—The United States Command announced today a reduction of 4,600 American troops in South Vietnam, dropping the total number to 301,900, as of last Thursday, the lowest since late summer, 1966.

headline: Convicted Marine Waits
lead_paragraph: QUANTICO, Va., April 5 (UPI)—Marine Pvt. Michael A. Schwarz, convicted a year ago of murdering 12 Vietnamese women and children, reported for duty at Marine Corps schools here today to await “some kind of discharge” or a review of his appeal. Private Schwarz was sentenced to life imprisonment by a court‐martial in Vietnam, but the sentence was later reduced to one year, a dishonorable discharge and loss of payment and allowances. He was released last Friday from naval prison.

headline: Abernathy Leads Protest on Wall St.
lead_paragraph: About 4,000 demonstrators stood for nearly two hours in the chilling shade of Wall Street yesterday afternoon to take part in the opening of the “spring offensive against repression.”
author: By James F. Clarity

headline: 92 IN CAPITAL HELD IN ANTIWAR RALLY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 5—The District of Columbia police arrested 92 antiwar demonstrators, most of them young seminarians, near the White House today.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Saigon Senators Say Minh Could Win
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 5—Two South Vietnamese opposition senators predicted today that Gen. Duong Van Minh could win next October's presidential elections if the voting was free and honest.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: McCloskey's Challenge
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 5—‐Representative Paul “Pete” McCloskey Jr., the California Republican who has raised the flag of rebellion within the G.O.P. against President Nixon's war policy, leaves today for Vietnam. Asked why he is going, he replies, with quiet intensity, “to get the facts.”
author: By William V. Shannon

headline: Foreign Press Criticizes Nixon's Decision on Galley
lead_paragraph: LONDON, April 5—In many countries friendly to the United States there has been a highly critical reaction to President Nixon's intervention in the Calley case.
author: By Anthony Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: How to End the War Now
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam—The invasions of Laos and Cambodia are no solution for the people of Indochina. Nor is. Vietnamlzation. The Nixon plan to “end” the war fails to take into consideration that a negotiated political compromise is the only way to peace.
author: By Don Luce

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is probably correct to conclude that the prosecution and conviction of Lieutenant Calley are consistent with the broad principles laid down at the Nuremberg Trials. But it does seem to me very important to bear in mind that the accused persons at Nuremberg were not the Lieutenant. Calleys. They were rather among the most responsible policy makers in Hitler's Germany.

headline: Ammunition Abandoned
lead_paragraph: QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, April 5 (AP)—South Vietnamese forces pulling back after their retreat from Laos were leaving thousands of unused artillery shells and other ammunition at bases in the northwest corner of South Vietnam until United States officers complained, informed sources said today.

headline: U.S. PULLOUT BY ’72 SOUGHT BY HARTKE
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 6 — Senator Vance Hartke, a strong opponent of the Vietnam war, said here today that the United States could end its involvement in the war by setting date for withdrawal by the end of the year.

headline: TV: An Early‐Morning Appraisal of Galley Trial
lead_paragraph: It's all a matter of priorities. Yesterday the news department of the National Broadcasting Company offered a two‐hour program examining the trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and a two‐hour priogram featuring harmless little studies of such subjects as quintuplets and fox hunting in England. One was on evening prime time; the other started at the blurred hour of 7 A.M. You have one second to guess which was on at which time.
author: By John J. O'Connor

headline: PACIFICATION PUSH BERIN IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 6—The, most ambitious and costly pacification prograni yet planned for South Vietnam has been put into effect by Saigon and Washington.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: HENDERSON SAYS CASE IS TAINTED
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., April 6 (UPI)—Charging the Army's case was tainted by improper procedures, lawyers for Col. Oran K. Henderson petitioned a military court today for records of the inquiry that led to charges he had lied to investigators about the Mylai killings.

headline: ‘War Crimes’ Testimony
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, April 6—A small group of legislators sat impassively today as, one by one, a half dozen young veterans of the Vietnam war quietly told of their “war crimes.”

headline: Freed Marine on Leave
lead_paragraph: QUANTICO, Va., April 6 (AP) —pvt. Michael A. Schwarz of the Marine Corps, who was released from a naval prison last Friday after serving a year for the murder of 12 Vietnamese civilians, was granted appellate leave today and departed for his home in Weirton, W. Va. Appellate, leave Is a statua under which no duty is imposed and no pays is granted.

headline: Foe Seizes Posts in Laos
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 6 (AP) —North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao forces have overrun seven Government positions in northern Laos, the Defense Ministry announced today.

headline: 4 IN HOUSE PLAN HEARINGS ON WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 6—A group of liberal House Democrats announced plans today to conduct public, informal nearings into the “command responsibility” for United States “war atrocities” in Vietnam.

headline: South Vietnamese Commandos Attack Enemy Base in Laos in a 10‐Hour Raid
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 7 (AP)—Two hundred South Vietnamese commandos were landed in Laos behind a smoke screen yesterday for a 10‐hour attack on base area on the enemy's supply‐trail network.

headline: Total of 38 Convicted Of Murder in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 6—In response to queries, a spokesman for the Army said today that 81 men had been charged with crimes in Vietnam similar to that for which First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was convicted.

headline: Aiken Says Nixon Will. Set ’72 Pullout In Address Tonight
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 6—Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont predicted today that President Nixon would announce in his televised speech tomorrow a schedule that would lead to the removal of all American forces from Vietnam by sometime next year.
author: By John W. Finney By The Associated Press

headline: Text of Calley Prosecutor's Letter to the President
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 6—Following is the text of the letter sent to the President by Capt, Aubrey M. Daniel 3d, the prosecutor in the Calley case:

headline: G.I.'s in Vietnam Await Nixon Speech on Withdrawals
