lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam April 6—When President Nixon makes his announcement on troop withdrawals, some of the most attentive listeners will be the 300,000 G.I.'s at positions from the demilitarized zone to the Mekong River delta.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Colley Prosecutor Asserts Nixon Undermines Justice
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April. 6—Capt. Aubrey M. Daniel 3d, the prosecutor in the Army courtmartial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., has protested to President Nixon in a letter that the President's intervention m the case has weakened respect for the legal process.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: James Reston's March 26 column “Divided Command in Saigon” demonstrates that the electoral interests of Thieu and Nixon are irreconcilable.

headline: The President's Vietnam Pledge
lead_paragraph: The President's Vietnam Pledge

headline: SOUTH VIETNAMESE WILL REPLACE G.I.'S
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 8 (AP)—The South Vietnamese Government said today that the 100,000 American soldiers who will be phased out of Vietnam from May 1 to Dec. 1 “will be gradually replaced by our own troops.”

headline: President's Galley Move Arouses Political Debate
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON. April 7—The increasingly political debate over the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. took a new tack today as Democrats and Republicans clashed over whether President Nixon had improperly intervened in the case.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Agrees to Resume Paris Peace Negotiations
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 7 (Reuters)—North Vietnam agreed today to resume the peace talks here tomorrow after a three‐week interruption; a spokesman for the Hanoi delegation said.

headline: SALUTE RETURNED TO A BOY BY NIXON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 7—When President Nixon's image came on the television screen in the living room of the James Platt home tonight in Avella, Pa., four‐year‐old Kevin Taylor looked up and said, “There's President Nixon, Mommy.”
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 South Vietnamese Bases Are Reported Under Heavy Attack
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 8 (AP)—Heavy fighting was reported around two besieged South Vietnamese fire bases in the rugged Central Highlands yesterday. Headquarters in Saigon said that nearly 400 North Vietnamese troops were killed in day‐long fighting, most of them by air strikes.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: An Admiral Speaks His Mind
lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va.—One too often remains silent on issues which gnaw the vitals of his being. Along with a multitude of others I have long deplored the continuing decline of our country's prestige. Now, the disgraceful trial and conviction of Lieutenant Calley removes any reticence to offer constructive criticism of our government.
author: By Edward C. Outlaw

headline: Text of the Address by President Nixon
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's nationally televised address last night on troop withdrawals front Vietnam, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: Agnew Calls News Media Doubts Over Laos a Sign of Wide U.S. ‘Masochism’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 7 —Vice President Agnew said today that “most knowledgeable people” believed that it was too soon to judge the effectiveness of the South Vietnamese military thrust Into Laos. Yet, he said, the news media are pronouncing it a failure.

headline: 2 to Sue on F.B.I. Dismissal Because of Peace Activity
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) —Two young women charging that they were forced to resign from the Federal Bureau of Investigation because of off‐duty involvement with antiwar activities said today that they would sue J. Edgar Hoover to get their jobs back.

headline: Nixon Earlier Ordered Withdrawal of 260,000
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 7—Before tonight's announcement, President Nixon had ordered the withdrawal of 260,000 American soldiers from South Vietnam in four stages.

headline: QUAKERS ASSAP NIXON WAR STAN;.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, April 7 —The Philadelphia Yearly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends, long the country's leading Quaker organization, rebuked President Nixon today for coupling references to his Quaker heritage with a defense of his Administration's war policy in southeast Asia.
author: By Donald Janson Special to The New York Times

headline: Planners See Risks for ’72 in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 7 —Senior military planners generally believe that President Nixon's announcement of substantial new troop reductions makes it clear that 1972 will be the riskiest year in Vietnam since disengagement started two years ago.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: NIXON PROMISES VIETNAM PULLOUT OF 100,000 MORE GI'S BY DECEMBER; PLEDGES 10 END U.S. ROLE IN WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 7—President Nixon scheduled tonight a withdrawal of 100,000 more American soldiers from South Vietnam by Dec. 1.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: In a Vietnam Town, Few Feel at Home
lead_paragraph: GIANGHIA, South Vietnam, April 2 — Quangduc has the fewest people of any of the 44 provinces of South Vietnam, and if those who live there had their way it would be smaller by nearly half.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: The Calley Issues
lead_paragraph: The extraordinary letter of Capt. Aubrey M. Daniel 3d, Army prosecutor in the Calley case, is at one and the same time a magnificent expression of American idealism and a stark and stunning indictment of the role played in this affair by Richard M. Nixon, President the United States.

headline: ‘What Has Happened to Us?’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—This evening, when Lieutenant Calley was solemnly compared on network TV with Jesus Christ by a “spokesman for the people” who said Lieutenant Calley's punishment was as heinous as the crucifixion, I felt sick to my stomach.
author: By Samuel C. Brightman

headline: REACTION TO TALK MIXED IN CAPITOL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 7 —President Nixon's speech on Indochina was greeted tonight with praise by Republicans and with criticism by Democratic doves. Underlying the initial Congressional reaction was disappointment that the President had not gone further in defining a goal of total withdrawal from South Vietnam.

headline: MADISON, WIS., VOTE FAVORS A PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis., April 7 —Madison voters supported yesterday by more than 2 to 1 a resolution calling for an immediate cease‐fire and withdrawal of all United States forces from Southeast Asia.

headline: A War Distorted
lead_paragraph: Whatever was to happen to William Calley, one result of the first Mylai trial was certain in advance: the United States Army was going to be found Guilty. The Army couldn't win. If Calley had been let off: a whitewash. If he had been (as he has been) condemned: a scapegoat for the higher brass. That's the way the media set it up and, in the courtrooms of our global village, the media, as we all know, are prosecutor, judge and jury.
author: By James Burnham

headline: Washington Notes
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 8—Pentagon generals and admirals, expert at feint and flank attack, have demonstrated in a series of bureaucratic skirmishes that they do not intend to be dominated by President Nixon's fledgling Office of Management and Budget Not all the details have emerged, but in the most Portentous clash the Joint Chiefs of Staff executed a successful maneuver around the office's director, George P. Shultz, and the Secretary of Defense, Melvin R. Laird, to prevent a cut of $1.5‐billion to $2‐billion in the final defense request for the fiscal year 1972.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Move Denounced at Paris Talks
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 8— PresidentI Nixon's announcement of continuing troop withdrawals was described today by the North Vietnamese and the Vietcong as “a maneuver aimed at disguising the prolongation and widening of the war.”
author: By John L. Hess Special to The New York Times

headline: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.
author: By Alexander R. Hammer

headline: Section of Road Seized
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 8 (AP)—North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops were reported today to have seized a two‐mile section of Route 4, which links the capital city of Pnompenh with the port of Kompong Som, on the Gulf of Siam.

headline: G.I. TOLL IN WEEK AT 9‐MONTH HIGH
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 9 — The United States command reported today that 88 American soldiers, were killed in combat in Indochina last week, the highest toll for a week in nearly 10 months.

headline: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.
author: By Alexander R. Hammer

headline: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.
author: By Alexander R. Hammer

headline: Soviet Congress Nearing End; Politboro to Be Named Today
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, April 8 — The 24th Congress of the Soviet Communist party neared its conclusion today with a final round of praise for the Kremlin's policies and a secret afternoon session for the formal selection of the party's Central Committee.
author: By Deward Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘TIGER CAGE’ PRISON ATTACKED BY REID
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 8—Representative Ogden R. Reid, the ranking Republican member of the House Foreign Opertions subcommittee, charged today in letters to two Administration officials that the treatpent of Communist prisoners in South Vietnam represented a continuing violation of the Geneva Convention.

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 8—There was general agreement here today that President Nixon gave a little ground last night to all the factions that have been tugging at his Vietnam policy.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.
author: By Alexander R. Hammer

headline: Little Stir in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 8—President Nixon's announcement of the withdrawal of 100,000 troops by December created little stiy, in Saigon today.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS

headline: U.S. Aides See Situation In Cambodia Deteriorating
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 8—The military, political and economic situation in Cambodia has been deteriorating over the last two months, according to knowledgeable sources within the Administration.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.
author: By Alexander R. Hammer

headline: War and Proportionality
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: While agreeing with A. Frank Reel (Op‐Ed March 31) that the Yamashita decision 25 years later appears to have been essentially an exercise in vengeance and to have violated historic principles by punishing a man for the position he held rather than for the acts he had committed or had omitted, I believe that Mr. Reel falls into grave error in concluding from this that the laws of war serve only to glorify war and to hide its true import.

headline: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.
author: By Alexander R. Hammer

headline: U. S. Base Shelled
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Friday, April 9 (Reuters) —North Vietnamese gunners shelled an American helicopter base here today in South Vietnam's Central Highlands. About eight rockets and mortar shells hit Camp Holloway but no casualties or damage was reported.

headline: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.
author: By Alexander R. Hammer

headline: 10 IN HOUSE SCORE NIXON ON GALLEY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) —Ten House Democrats said today that President Nixon's intervention in the Calley case had been “extremely improvident.”

headline: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.
author: By Alexander R. Hammer

headline: Colley and Writer Get $100,000 Book Advance
lead_paragraph: First Lieut. William J. Galley Jr. and John Sack, a writer, received a $100,000 advance for publication of Lieutenant Calley's memoirs, Thomas Guinzberg, the president of Viking Press, Inc., said today.

headline: Nixon Planning to Clarify Caney Case Intervention
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 8—President Nixon intends to issue a “clarification” of his intervention in the Calley case, White House sources said today.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Books of The Times
lead_paragraph: BAD NEWS. By Paul Spike. 152 pages. Holt, Rinehart and Winston. M.O.
author: By Thomas Lask

headline: 3 SENATORS AVER NIXON SAID HE HAD PULLOUT DEADLINE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 8 —Three Senate leaders said today that President Nixon indicated at a private briefing yesterday that he intended to withdraw all United States troops from Indochina by a specific date, but the White House vehemently denied it.

headline: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.
author: By Alexander R. Hammer

headline: Economic Analysis
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's “Vietnam pullout” speech of Wednesday night, on the surface, failed to stir any big waves in the stock market yesterday. But leading Wall Street analysts noted in private conversations that what stock prices failed to do—namely, take a spill—offered proof of the market's internal strength. And this means, or so these Wall Streeters reason, that over the rest of 1971 and into 1972 the out look is for pronounced gains in equity prices.
author: By Vartanig G. Vartan

headline: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.
author: By Alexander R. Hammer

headline: Let's Hear From Hanoi
lead_paragraph: One American dying in combat is one too many. But our goal is no American fighting man dying in any place the world. Every decision I have made in the past, and every decision I make in the future, will have the purpose of achieving that goal. —President Nixon in his Wednesday night address on Vietnam.
author: By James Reston

headline: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.
author: By Alexander R. Hammer

lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.

headline: U.S. Drops Efforts to Try Ex‐G.I.'s Over Mylai
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 8—The Defense and Justice Departments said today that they had given up attempts to prosecute 15 former servicemen linked to the Mylai killings by Army investigators.
author: By Dana Adam Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.

lead_paragraph: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.

headline: Billy Graham: On Calley
lead_paragraph: MONTREAT, N. C.—The first tams I became suspicious that the United States might become involved in Indochina was in January, 1961. I had just played golf with President‐elect John Kennedy, the then Senator George Smathers of Florida, and Billy Reynolds, president of Reynolds Aluminum.
author: By Billy Graham

headline: Mr. Nixon's Vietnam Politics
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's latest restatement of his Vietnam policy is essentially a political document, taking into account the present state of American politics, the impending peace demonstrations in Washington, rising antiwar sentiment in the Congress, the Calley outcry and the approaching Presidential campaign. These factors were undoubtedly a prime consideration in leading him now to a commitment to end totally the American military involvement in Vietnam by a date that, though unstated, can hardly be much later than Election Day in November 1972.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: THE KING (in disguise): lifethinks I could not die anywhere so contented as in the King's company, his cause being just….
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Montagnards Who Fled Cambodia Get Little Aid
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnarn, April 9—About 8,000 Cambodian mountain tribesmen who sought refuge in South Vietnam after the Vietnamese Communists captured their native regions last year are suffering from hunger and neglect although ample American funds have been allocated for them.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Behind the Protests
lead_paragraph: The United States is fighting a war in Vietnam. It has come to pass that in modern warfare deliberately inflicted civilian casualties are taken for granted. Nonetheless, Gen. William C. Westmoreland, Chief of Staff, assures us, “It was clearly known to our troops that they were to avoid civilian casualties at all costs.” Atrocities were to be reported and punished accorded to the rules of the Geneva Convention. General Westmoreland admits that many civilians have been killers in Vietnam; but to allege that any responsibility or guilt rests in the high command is, according to him, “absurd.” He places the responsibility on troops “led by inexperienced lieutenants and sergeants,” who are being tried.
author: By Samuel Atkin

headline: Laos and the ‘Infection
lead_paragraph: Why was the protest so great at the invasion of Cambodia, and so small when the almost klentioal thing happened in Laos? Why the veritable scream of objection, closing down some 700 campuses last May, and an almost complete silence at the time of Laos?
author: By Rollo May

headline: Nixon, Leaving Church, Encounters Protesters
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)—President Nixon drove a block away from the White. House today to attend afternoon services at historic St. John's Episcopal Church and, on emerging, encountered a sprinkling of noisy antiwar demonstrators.

headline: Calley Judge Backs Nixon on Review of the Trial
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) — President Nixon's intention to review the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. is his right as commander in chief, according to the military judge at Lieutenant Calley's trial.

headline: Foe Breaks Up Rally
lead_paragraph: VITHANH, South Vietnam, April 9 (UPI)—An enemy mortar battery broke up a rally and awards ceremony today for Vietcong defectors in this provincial capital in the Mekong delta. Seven civilians were wounded, military sources said.

headline: Army Officers Disturbed By Caney Case Outcome
lead_paragraph: FORT BELVOIR, Va., April 9 —The trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and its aftermath have left many members of the professional officer corps of the United States Army in a state of anguish and alarm.
author: By Drew Middleton Special to The New York Times

headline: A.B.C. Gives Democrats Reply Time
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 8—The American Broadcasting Company agreed today to give the. Democratic party 30 minutes of prime television time to respond to the Indochina policy statement President Nixon delivered Wednesday on all three major networks.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: One of the most distressing recent developments in universities was typified when, according to your March 27 news account, several hundred demonstrators from three radical groups “shouted, booed, chanted and clapped” and prevented five scheduled speakers at a pro‐war teach‐in at Harvard University from being heard.

headline: Vietnamize At Home
lead_paragraph: Now that the Vietnamization of the war is under way in Vietnam, it's time to end the Vietnamization of our political system at home. This domestic Vietnamization—the draft, the attitude toward dissent, the ubiquitous secret agents—has driven an entire generation into despair about their country. Now that the national purpose has changed abroad, our domestic actions must seek to bring the young back into the political process.
author: By James Reston Jr

headline: Besieged Fire Base Fights Off Attack by Hanoi Commandos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 10 (AP)—North Vietnamese commandos reportedly defied a hail of bombs and napalm early today and tried to penetrate beseiged Fire Base 6 in the Central Highlands but were repulsed.

headline: Army Makes Apology For Memo on TV Man
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 9 (AP)—The United States command has apologized to the Columbia Broadcasting System for a memorandum to information officers stating that Morley Safer, a C.B.S. newsman, was visiting Vietnam with an “ulterior motive.”

headline: We Must End the War
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN—Everyone who believes, as I have, in the rule of law as an expanding, organizing force in national and international governance, has now to face the implications of the Calley trial and verdict. I have tried to do so, and have found that I almost cannot.
author: By Burke Marshall

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Despite the moral indignation of our militant peace groups and dovish Congressmen urging precipitate, total or specifically timed withdrawal of our armed forces from Indochina, not one of these allegedly moral or humanitarian groups has suggested, mentioned or adopted a resolution to change our amoral, restrictive and anachronistic immigration laws so that, subsequent to our total withdrawal, the tens, possibly hundreds of thousands of innocents, scheduled to be victims in Communist blood‐bath, may be saved.

headline: ‘We Accuse’
lead_paragraph: These are excerpts from an editorial published jointly during Holy Week by four publications: Christian Century, Christianity and Crisis, National Catholic Reporter and Commonweal. The editors say that the joint declaration is unique in religious journalism in this country and this fact indicates the deep concern of these publications about the continuing involvement of the United States in Vietnam.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is argued that Hanoi would be left free to decide its course of action should there be an announcement of a specific date by which all U. S. forces would be withdrawn from Vietnam and that whatever leverage now exists to press negotiations by Hanoi would be vitiated to our disadvantage, particularly with respect to our prisoners.

headline: G.O.P. War Critic Arrives In Vietnam for 4‐Day Visit
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 9 (AP)—Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr.arrived here today for a four‐day visit to South Vietnam and charged that President Nixon had stepped up the air war over Laos while trying to gain votes by reducing United States casualties among ground forces.

headline: Pause in Memory Of War Prisoners Gets Slight Notice
lead_paragraph: Except for the Fire Department, most New Yorkers seemed unaware of Mayor Lindsay's proclamation calling for “a moment of silence and concern” at 3:15 P.M. yesterday for American prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

headline: The New Individualism
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 10.— The Easter Parade this year in America was riot of modern individualism, a costume party, a masquerade ball, and the clowns never looked more gay, or carefree or felt worse.
author: By James Reston

headline: COAST DRIVE SLATED BY ANTIWAR GROUP
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, April 10 (AP) — A nonprofit corporation to generate public pressure against the Vietnam war and war in general will begin a broadcast campaign next week on the West Coast, according to Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska.

headline: North Vietnam to Elect A New Legislature Today
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, April 10 (UPI) —North Vietnamese voters will elect a new National Assembly tomorrow from a list of 522 candidates nominated by the Communist party and seven independents.

headline: Letter to the Editor 6 — No Title
lead_paragraph: Senator. Fullbright's mendacious attack on Israel in his speech before the Yale Political Union is a blatant play on the fears of the American people of becoming involved in another Vietnam.
author: Maurice Lieberman; Brooklyn April 5, 1971

headline: VOLUNTEERS PRESS WAR PROTEST PLAN
P.O.W. Treatment Protested
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) — The American National Red Cross said yesterday that it had received more than 72,500 letters protesting treatment of American prisoners of war in North Vietnam. The letters are in response to an article appearing in the April issue of the Reader's Digest, which describe conditions under which many prisoners of war are being held.

headline: Book Sales Off, Spock Says
lead_paragraph: PUEBLO, Colo., April 10 (UPI) —Dr. Benjamin Spock says his antiwar efforts have caused a decline In sales of his long‐time best seller, “Baby and Child Care.” “I'm afraid that people like Spiro Agnew did persuade a certain number of people that if they used my book to make a formula or change a diaper, it would change their children into brats,” the pediatrician said. “Other people got the idea that their children might turn into traitors if they read my book.”

headline: Children Sing Requiem in Land of Unrest
author: By Craig R. Whitney; Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. REPORTS RAID IN NORTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 11 (AP) — Two Air Force F‐4 fighter‐bombers attacked radar‐controlled antiaircraft guns inside North Vietnam and destroyed two of them in the 21st “protective reaction” strike over the north this year, the United States command announced today.

headline: U.S. Pilots Find Enemy Traffic Moving Freely on Trail in Laos
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, April 7—American fighter and observation pilots who fly regularly over the Ho Chi Minh Trail report that traffic is moving freely along the enemy supply network now that the South Vietnamese have wound up their operation in Laos.
author: By Henry Kamm; Special to The New York Times

headline: Enemy Airs Voices of Saigon P.O.W.'s
author: By Gloria Emerson; Special to The New York Times

headline: The Persisting Illusion
Hanoi Army Paper Assails Saigon's Strategy in Laos
author: By Tad Szulc; Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon and Galley:
author: —R. W. Apple Jr

headline: North Vietnamese Elect A New 420‐Seat Assembly
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Monday, April 12 (Reuters) — North Vietnamese citizens voted yesterday in their first general elections since 1964.

headline: Dole Sees Peril for Nixon If War Does Not Slacken
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)—Robert J. Dole, the Republican National Chairman, said today that if the Vietnam war was still going on at the present level next year, President Nixon would have trouble winning re‐election.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A MAJOR BATTLE SEEN DEVELOPING NEAR LAOS BORDER
lead_paragraph: TANCANH, South Vietnam, April 11—The defenders of a South Vietnamese artillery position called Fire Base 6 in the mountains eight miles southwest of here, besieged since the beginning of this month, are now said to expect a battle equal in intensity to the fighting in Laos in February and March.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Changes Held Possible The Washington Star
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, April 11—The new North Vietnamese National Assembly, which is constitutionally required to meet within two months, will elect a Cabinet as well as a President. This could provide the occasion for changes in the Government leadership in Hanoi.

headline: Two Congressional Panels Plan Studies of U.S. Role in Indochina
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 11 —New hearings on Indochina directed to the moral and humanitarian questions raised by the United States role in the war — are to be held concurrently in the Senate and the House of Representatives later this month.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Agnew Sees Pullout Peril
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, April 11 (AP)—If all United States troops were immediately withdrawn from. Vietnam, the action would be followed by a potentially harmful right‐wing protest, Vice President Agnew is quoted as saying.

headline: Youth Panel Holds U.S. Policy Is Rigid on Communism
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 11—A study group of the White House Conference on Youth has charged that those who shape United States foreign policy have become frozen in a “reflexive anti‐Communism” leading to the “ugly” embroilment, in Vietnam, a “distorted sense of the national interest” and division and ferment at home.
author: By Nan Robertson Special to The New York Times

headline: Ex‐Marine, Republican, War Critic Paul Norton McCloskey Jr.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 11—When he arrived in South Vietnam on Friday, Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. stopped only long enough at Saigon's Tansonnhut Airport for pictures, then headed for Danang, far to the north near the demilitarized zone. It was a typical gesture in several ways: It showed his disdain for the official briefings that visitors usually begin with. It showed his willingness to get down to the hard work of research immediately and it showed his flair for publicity.

headline: U.S. Plane Fires Missile
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12, Monday (Reuters)—A United States Navy A‐7 bomber struck at radar positions near the Bankarai pass in North Vietnam, the American command reported today.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Article 1 — No Title
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) —The executive branch's communications director, Herbert G. Klein, said today that President Nixon had not decided what to do with Lieutenant Calley, who was convicted and sentenced to imprisonment for ‘killings at Mylai.

headline: Six Arrested in Syracuse In Disruption at Cathedral,
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE, April 11 (UPI)—Six person, including a Lutheran minister, were arrested today at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception after walking down the aisle during an Easter mass carrying a wooden cross, with a Vietnamese peasant's hat attached.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: CALLEY EXONERATION URGED BY THURMOND
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) —Describing the victims at Mylai as “casualties to the brutality of war,” Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, today urged the exoneration of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hesburgh Bids Catholic Schools Learn From Youth
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, April 12 —The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, told Roman Catholic educators here today that today's students had demonstrated closer concern for the church's traditions of human dignity and human rights than had the Catholic schools.

headline: ‘Life Photograph,’ Drama By Michaels, Due Next Fall
lead_paragraph: “Life Photograph,” a drama by Sidney Michaels on a 1954 Vietnamese theme, will be presented on Broadway next fall by the team of Jack Milstein, Stanley Gould and Leonard Feldman. Arthur Penn is being sought to direct.

headline: West Point Graduate, Foe of War, Wins Discharge
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., April 12 (AP)—First Lieut Louis P. Font, a West Point graduate who has been seeking a discharge as a conscientious objector because of the Vietnam war, was honorably processed out of the Army today, a Fort Meade official reported.

headline: POVERTY AGENCY TO AID VETERANS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 12—The White House announced today a pilot project aimed at informing low‐income veterans of the Vietnam era of benefits available under the G.I. Bill.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: PRESSURE BY FOE RISES IN CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12—Enemy forces in Cambodia are increasing their pressure on the 22,000 South Vietnamese troops there, while the Government forces still search for the momentum they lost seven weeks ago when their commander, Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri, was killed.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Sentences Eased for 27 Guilty in Vietnam Killings
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 12—The 22 American servicemen, including First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who have been, convicted of the premeditated murder of Vietnamese citizens were all sentenced to life in prison.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 12—A vacation In Which scant attention was paid to the news may provide a poor perspective, but what offers a good one these days? And in the instant case, two strong impressions did work their way tmsolentifically through more personal concerns.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Crisis of Confidence
lead_paragraph: When President Nixon addressed the nation last week he appeared painfully aware how tenuous had become the confidence of the American people in their leadership. Repeating his promise to end the war, he recalled the many earlier occasions of similar assurances and asked, almost wistfully, “But‐can you believe this?”

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pacification Wrecked in a Highlands Area
lead_paragraph: PHUNFION, South Vietnam, April 10 — Three weeks of heavy fighting in the highlands south of Pleiku has left the pacification program and a score of hamlets in this district of refugee settlements in ruins, according to American advisers who endured a 12‐hour siege of the district headquarters compound. They say that another attack could come at any time.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Editors Urge U.S. Law to Shield Newsmen Against Court Action
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)—The American Society of Newspaper Editors was urged today to press for a national law to protect reporters from court orders, fines and jailing, to force them to disclose news, sources.

headline: Laird Says Air and Navy Units Will Stay After Pullout of G.I.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 13 —Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the United States would maintain a naval and air presence in Southeast Asia after American ground troops had been withdrawn from Indochina.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: The Postwar Economy
lead_paragraph: What will be the economic impact of the windup of the Vietnam war? The question has acquired urgency with the announcement by President Nixon that he will reduce American troop strength in Vietnam from 284,000 now to 184,000 by Dec. 1, 1971.
author: By Leonard S. Silk

headline: Brigade Is Decommissioned
lead_paragraph: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., April 13 (AP) — The Fifth Marine Amphibious Brigade Was decommissioned today, with its 10,000 men being absorbed by the First Marine Division, now moving out of Vietnam. A ceremony marking the return of the First Division to Camp Pendleton is scheduled for tomorrow.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Because of the widespread popular assumption of the legality (not, of course, the propriety) of President Nixon's intervention in the Calley case, a word might be in order on the law of the matter.

headline: G.O.P. Foe of Nixon Sums Up Views He Found in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13 (UPI)—Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., the California Republican, who has said that he will challenge President Nixon in ?? 1972 primaries if he not ended the war by then, said today that most Americans he had met in South Vietnam felt “that we can leave by the end of the year.”

headline: U.S. Downgrades 2 More Vietnam Commands
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13—The United States command soon will downgrade its command system in South Vietnam's two middle military regions to reflect the United States Army's transition from a combat role to a support and advisory function, military sources disclosed today.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: BESIEGED OUTPOST GETS SOME RELIEF
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 14—Lead elements of a big South Vietnamese relief force reached Fire Base 6 in the Central Highlands last night and more reinforcements poured in today, easing the pressure on the frontier outpost, which has been under siege for two weeks.

headline: Antiwar Women Chain Themselves to Fence
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 13—Thirty‐esven members of a group calling itself Women for Peace and Justice chained themselves this morning to a fence around the Old Executive Office Building, adjacent to the White House.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The letter written by Capt. Aubrey M. Daniel 3d to President Nixon should be read and studied by everyone in America who is interested in the administering of justice. When the President long ago spoke about the need for lowering voices, Captain Daniel was one of those who took him seriously.

headline: South Vietnam's Police Force Gaining In Size and Status as U. S. Increases Aid
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13 — The South Vietnamese national police force is quickly expanding in size and influence here, largely because of increased American financial support and an organizational change that moved the police command to the highest levels of the Government.
author: By Thomas C. Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Now that the facts of Mylai have been proved before a court of law, wonder whether any thought has been given to honoring those who were present and refused to obey the reprehensible order to kill unarmed captives. To refuse to obey any direct orders in the field bespeaks high courage as well as moral sense, and the honorable questioning of orders should not pass unnoticed.

headline: FIGHTING IS HEAVY NEAR FIRE BASE 6
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Small Vietnam, Thursday, April 15—North Vietnamese troops used flamethrowers against South Vietnamese forces in heavy fighting on two sides of Fire Base 6 in the Central Highlands yesterday.

headline: Agnew Says No to Suggestion He Take On Peking in Table Tennis
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 14—Vice President Agnew, who has won national renown as a spray‐shooting golfer, turned down today a suggestion that he demonstrate his prowess as a table tennis player in mainland China. The suggestion came from one of the Vice President's closest friends
author: By E. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Philip C. Clarke deplores “the illogic of pundits who demand total, unilateral United States withdrawal from Vietnam.” [Letter, March 31.]

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As Admiral Outlaw said in his April 8 Op‐Ed article: “One too often remains silent on issues which gnaw the vitals of his being.”

headline: WAR HEARING SET BY SENATE PANEL
U.S. War Pullout Urged
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Apr. 14 (AP)—The Southern Christian Leadership Conference called today for the total withdrawal of United States troops from Vietnam. The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, head of the organization, said it wanted all American troops withdrawn by the end of August.

headline: U.S. Jungle‐Clearing Bombs Now Turned on Troops
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam April 14—Military officers here say the United States command used seven‐and‐one‐halfton‐bombs in the Central Highlands this week primarily to clear the thick jungle canopy from North Vietnamese storage areas near the Laotian border, but also to kill enemy soldiers who might be nearby.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Marines Deactivated
lead_paragraph: Saigon, April 14 (Reuters), —The Third Marine Amphibious Force was deactivated today at a ceremony in Danang, where the marines first landed in March, 1965. The force, the largest ever deployed by the Marine Corps overseas, once numbered 80,000 men fighting the Vietcong in the five northernmost provinces of South Vietnam.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 15—According to well‐informed Ping‐Pong circles, the United States and China are now turning a “new page” or beginning a “new era's or something like that, but the China experts here are suspicious of all sweeping cliches.
author: By James Reston

headline: Antiwar Activist Joins Army
lead_paragraph: An antiwar activist reported for Army service here yesterday, but outside the induction center he announced that he would do all he could to organize GI's to fight for a prompt end to the war in Southeast Asia. Twenty sympathizers demonstrated for a half‐hour outside the induction station at 39 Whitehall Street, where 23‐year‐old Steve Wattenmaker, a campus coordinator for the Student Mobilization Committee, reported just before 7 A.M.

headline: Saigon's Troops Open a Drive on Enemy Regiment in Highlands
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 15 (AP)—South Vietnamese troops supported by United States aircraft opened a drive in the Central Highlands today against North Vietnamese forces that have been on the attack there for 15 days, South Vietnamese headquarters said.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am dismayed by the article by the Very Rev. Francis B. Sayre Jr. On the one hand he tells us that we are all to blame for the crimes of Lieutenant Calley and the criminal policy which put him in Vietnam. On the other hand he takes a swipe at “righteous” and “naive citizens,” “the marching kind.”

headline: 11 WAR PROTESTERS SEIZED AT I.R.S. HERE
lead_paragraph: Eleven persons were arrested yesterday afternoon when demonstration against taxes to support the war in Vietnam ended in a sit‐in outside the offices of the Internal Revenue Service at 120 Church Street.

headline: Agnew Grants Request for Mass Antiwar Demonstration on Capital Lawn
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 15—Vice President Agnew said today that he had decided to grant a request by an antiwar group to hold a mass rally on the West Lawn of the Capitol later this month.

headline: Beyond Ping‐Pong Diplomacy
lead_paragraph: As the Chinese People's Republic moves now to reestablish long‐severed external contacts, there is much in its conduct reminiscent of the similar Soviet process in the mid‐1950's, the years just after Stalin's death.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I for one violently oppose the April 5 Op‐Ed article by the Very Rev. Francis Sayre Jr. I do not feel our nation is on trial and I do not derive pleasure from self‐incrimination. I certainly do not feel, as does the Very Reverend Sayre, that “almost all we have been wont to count as precious in this world” is being slaughtered.

headline: They, Back at Talks, Offers Nothing New
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 15—Xuan Thuy, chief of the North Vietnamese delegation at the peace talks’ here, returned to the conference table today after a sevenweek absence but he brought no change in his country's position with him.

headline: 3 Republican Senators Ask Withdrawal Deadline
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 15—Complaints came from the Republican side of the aisle in the Senate today that President Nixon had not gone far enough with his plans of disengagement from the Vietnam war.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In your paper of April 7 it was reported that the printing cost of testimony of veterans who served in Vietnam which I have inserted in the Congressional Record “could run to at least $40,000.” This estimate is inaccurate.

headline: NIXON BARS HALT IN RAIDS TILL FOE FREES ALL P.O.W'S
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 16—President Nixon said tonight that United States air power would continue to be used “against North Vietnam and its forces” as long as a single American prisoner was held by Hanoi.

headline: Poll Finds Majority Think Calley Was a Scapegoat,
lead_paragraph: The American people believe that First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was made the scapegoat. for the massacre of civilians in the South Vietnamese village of Mylai, according to a poll conducted for the American Broadcasting Company.

headline: 7‐MAN JURY CHOSEN TO TRY CAPT. KOTOUC
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., April 16 (AP)—A jury of seven career Army officers was seated today for the trial of Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc on charges of maiming and assaulting Vietcong suspect near the hamlet of Mylai, shortly after the killings of Vietnam civilians in 1968.

headline: A HANOI AIDE SEES NO SHIFT BY CHINA
lead_paragraph: PARIS April 16—The North Vietnamese spokesman declared here today that Communist China's policy of supporting his country's cause was “invariable.”
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The recently revealed new United States‐Vietnam pacification program outlines plans to use “children of both sexes over the age of seven in supporting units,” for an expanded civilian anti‐guerrilla combat organization in rural areas.

headline: Johnson and Clark Linked To Surveillance Planning
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 16—Documents indicating the extent of the involvement of President Johnson and his Attorney General Ramsey Clark in the governmental surveillance of political dissidents have been obtained here from Government officials.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Excerpts From an Interview in Washington With the President by Six Newsmen
lead_paragraph: Q. Mr. President, you mentioned ending our involvement in the war in Vietnam and yet the Secretary of Defense said the other day that our Air Force and naval power would remain in South Vietnam. How do you reconcile those two statements? Or is there a conflict there, in your opinion?

headline: SWEEP BY SAIGON REPORTED OPENED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON South Vietnam April 16 — A large force of South Vietnamese infantrymen who came out of Laos last month has reportedly begun moving west again into the Ashau Valley, a major enemy base area near the Laotian border southwest of Hue.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: 11 MORE ARE CITED IN BERRIGAN CASE
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, April 16 —The Federal Bureau of Investigation served subpoenas today on 11 more persons ordering, them to appear before the Harrisburg, Pa., grand jury involved in the Berrigan case.
author: By Bill Kovach Special to The New York Times

headline: Policy on Treatment of Vietcong Suspects Assailed
lead_paragraph: SAIGON South Vietnam April 16 — Two Congressmen Who are opponents of the war in Vietnam today criticized the program designed to weed out and punish Vietcong political leaders and agents in the civilian population.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Antiwar ‘Sleep‐in’ at Washington Monument Is Barred
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON April 16—Attorneys for the Federal Government obtained an injunction today that would prevent a group of antiwar veterans from sleeping overnight on the Washington Monument grounds next week.

headline: Saigon Flies in Fresh Troops to Bolster Fire Base
lead_paragraph: FIRE BASE 6 South VietApril 16—The South Vietnamese Army flew 400 fresh troops to the top of this narrow battle‐shattered hilltop base today. For 15 days North Vietnamese force has besieged this strategic position near the Cambodian and Laotian borders in the South Vietnamese highlands.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Army Investigator In War Crime Case Dies of Gun Wound
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) —An Army investigator exam ining charges that a major gen eral and another officer cov ered up alleged American atrocities in Vietnam has died from what the Pentagon called an apparently self‐inflicted gun shot.

headline: World War I Fliers Recall Days of Glory
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 17—The foes of the Red Baron gathered here today not to curse him but to recall their exploits against German squadrons.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Recruiters Offer a Vietnam Alternative
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON. April 17— Army recruiting sergeants are offering this year's high school graduates a likely way to avoid both the draft and a trip to Vietnam. It is called “the European option.”
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: U.A.W. Refuses to Back Antiwar Protest
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, April 17—Leon ard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers, made a passionate plea here today for an end to the war in Vietnam but said that the union Aid not officially support the protest in Washington planned for next Saturday.
author: By Agis Salpukas Special to The New York Times

headline: OBSERVER
lead_paragraph: About midnight several days ago, a man appeared on the television screen in the cellar of our house to tell about a killing he had committed. Everybody else in the house had gone to bed. I mention this because the odd aspect of this whole business, looking back on it, was one watcher's personal re action to this midnight of television and, in order to convey any sense at all of the peculiarity of the thing, I have to give you a glimpse of my personal situation.
author: By Russell Baker

headline: Is McCloskey The McCarthy of '72?
lead_paragraph: ON Feb. 10, Congressman Paul N. (Pete) McCloskey Jr., a 43‐ year‐old Californian previously known chiefly for his victory over Mrs. Shirley Temple Black in a spe cial election in 1967, made a speech at Stanford University. It was an un usually biting speech for any mem ber of Congress to have made; com ing as it did from a Republican who had been in Washington for only three years, it verged on heresy. Mc Closkey suggested a “national dia logue” to discuss the impeachment of President Nixon as a means of changing the President's war policy, argued that Mr. Nixon and Presi dent Johnson had breached the Con stitution “through the arrogant use of power,” and asserted that “what we are doing in Laos is as great a crime as those we executed Japa nese and German officials for in World War II.”
author: By R. W. Apple Jr

headline: National Notes
lead_paragraph: For neither love nor money could Common Cause get the time of day — or night — last week.

headline: Muskie Ends ‘Fruitful’ 2‐Day Political Visit to New Hampshire
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H., April 17 —“I've never regarded the people of New Hampshire as an automatic constituency,” said Senator Edmund S. Muskie of the neighboring state of Maine.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: M. P. in Vietnam: A Thin Line Between Discipline and Harassment
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 17—He is a tall, courtly man who says—unlike most American soldiers—that being here has made him more hu man.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—“It was a very hard decision,” said a South Viet namese army captain in Pleiku last week. “The North Viet namese got into the Montagnard villages, and were firing at heli copters. We used a psywar mis sion [an airplane with a loud speaker] to call the Monta gnards and try to get them out of the enemy locations but the North Vietnamese did not let the villagers out. We set a time for them to leave, and then we would bomb. After noon on the final day we bombed, many villages. After, we found many bodies. Some of the Monta gnards had stayed in their vil lages and there were too many enemy.”
author: —Craig R. Whitney

headline: No Resistance Met
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, April 17 (AP) — South Vietnamese troops probed deeper into the Ashau Valley today without meeting any resistance.

headline: Locking In on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Seventeen years ago, Vice President Richard M. Nixon, speaking before the American Society of Newspaper Editors, sent up his famous trial balloon proposing that if necessary American ground troops be employed in Indochina to prevent a Communist take‐over there. Seventeen years to the day and 44,000 American deaths, later, President Richard M. Nixon, speaking before the American Society of Newspaper Editors, made it clear that American troops will not be totally withdrawn from Indochina until one part of that country—namely, South Vietnam—has developed “the capacity to defend [itself] against a Communist take‐over.” Plus ca change.…

headline: Hanoi Assails Nixon Refusal To Set Date for Withdrawal
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 17 (AP)—North Vietnam accused President Nixon today of having ad vanced “absurd pretexts” for not yielding to the Communist demand that a date be set for total United States withdrawal from South Vietnam.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 17 — In the capital these days, nothing fundamen tal has changed, but everybody senses that change is coming. The problems, the headlines, the arguments and the cast of characters are all the same, but the deeper tendencies or trends of events are a little different.
author: By James Reston

headline: Searching for culprits to blame a bad war on
lead_paragraph: Two of the men who brought us the war on television think they know why the United States got stuck in Vietnam. Marvin Kalb of C.B.S. and Elie Abel, who used to work for N.B.C., say that four and a half of our last six Presidents (F.D.R. is the full, Nixon the hedging half exception) “often appeared to be out of touch with the real world” when they made East Asia policy. They were unwitting dupes, of too many Calvinist forebears, Pearl Buck nov els and Charlie Chan films. For Kalb and Abel would have us be lieve “the inexorable progression— from Yankee Clipper to Yangtse gun boat to helicopter gunship” was “not an aberration,” but rather the con tinuous expression of a simple minded missionary zeal to make Asia safe for Americans.
author: By John Franklin Campbell

headline: A NEW INCURSION IN LAOS POSSIBLE, ABRAMS INDICATES
lead_paragraph: HUE, South Vietnam, April 17—Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the United States military com mander in Vietnam, said here today that a new South Viet namese incursion into Laos from the Ashau Valley, 25 miles west of Hue, “could not be ruled out.”
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: The continental shelf of Asia, running from waters off Burma to the seas between China and Japan, has become the focus of an in tense search for oil. More than 50 companies are drilling, doing geological studies or hold ing concessions. This activity has drawn the attention of some antiwar groups that have charged that the United States is fight ing in South Vietnam to protect oil industry interests. Thus far, most Congressmen appear to consider the charges unsubstantiated. The Saigon Government, however, is interested in attracting the oil industry to the area. On industry's side, preliminary seismic studies of offshore Vietnam have labeled it as geo logically “a good risk.” Only two countries in the entire area are producing oil in substan tial commercial quantities—Australia and In donesia. Indonesia, the center of most of the activity, is now producing about 900,000 bar‐ rels a day, almost entirely from onshore wells, but output is expected to climb to more than a million barrels a day this year, with the bulk of the addition coming from offshore wells. In the waters off Burma, Malaysia, Thailand and Cambodia, the activity is confined to surveys or preliminary drilling. Every Asian nation would like to find oil at home or at least nearby, and this quest has brought Japan, South Korea and Taiwan into con flict over jurisdiction and rights to grant con cessions in certain sections of the East China Sea. Communist China also is interested in oil in the area. United States awareness of this was demonstrated last week when it warned the Gulf Oil Corporation, which has an exploration contract with the Chinese Na tionalists, that it could not protect survey or drilling ships in the disputed areas around the Senkaku Islands.

headline: Vietnamese Discuss Fall Voting
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 18—As South Vietnam approaches its presidential election campaign, the voters —whose ballot is compulsory —voice a wide range of emo tions, often tinged by deep weariness with war.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: McCloskey Asks Halt In Bombing of Indochina
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters) — Representative Pauu N. McCloskey of Cali fornia today called on Presi dent Nixon to end what he said appeared to be the deli berate destruction of Laotian villages by calling an immedi ate halt to bombing through out Indochina.

headline: NEW ALLIED DRIVE NOT STARTED YET, U.S. AIDES ASSERT
lead_paragraph: LAVANG, South Vietnam, April 18—The joint American and South Vietnamese invasion of the enemy‐held Ashau Valley will not get under way until Wednesday at the soonest, ac cording to ranking American military sources here at the operation's forward command post just south of Quangtri.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: The Electoral Option in Vietnam: I
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—For more than two decades American officials have pro vided a vast range of rationales for our involvement in South Vietnam. But only one consistent theme emerges: to permit the South Viet namese freely to choose their govern ment. President Nixon has reiterated this American objective. As recently as April 7 he reminded us that Ameri cans are fighting in Vietnam so that the people there can “choose the kind of government they want.” If the South Vietnamese are able to ex ercise a free choice, we will have achieved an honorable, albeit costly, victory.
author: By Chester L. Cooper

headline: KY SEES LONG ROAD TO SELF‐DEFENSE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 18 (AP) — Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that it would take 15 or 20 years before South Vietnam was cap able of defending itself, but he added that the current pace of American troop withdrawals was “reasonable.”

headline: 10,000 Gather at Rhode Island's Capitol for Start of ‘Dump Nixon’ Campaign
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 18 —More than 10,000 advocates of peace in Indochina gathered today on the steps and lawns of Rhode Island's Capitol for the kickoff of a national “Dump Nixon” campaign.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special To The New York Times

headline: Jackson Says the Economy, Not War, Is Prime Issue
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, April 18 (UPI)— The nation's economy—not Vietnam—should be the major issue of Democrats in the 1972 political campaigns, according to Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, who is a possible candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomi nation.

headline: WEEK OF PROTESTS ON WAR TO START
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 18 — The first contingents of an ex pected total of 1,500 Vietnam war veterans began arriving here this afternoon in prepara tion for a week‐long series of antiwar protests named Oper ation Dewey Canyon Three.

headline: South Korean Division To Quit South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Mon day, April 19 (AP) — South Korea plans to withdraw an infantry division from South Vietnam before the end of this year, Foreign Minister Choi Kyu‐Hah said today. The withdrawal would in volve 13,000 to 15,000 of the 50,000 South Korean troops now in South Vietnam.

headline: G.I.'s Ambushed Near Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 19 (UPI)—A hun dred enemy soldiers ambushed an American patrol 31 miles northwest of Saigon Saturday afternoon in the closest large‐ scale fighting to the capital so far this year, United States military spokesmen said today.

headline: College Students and Air Cadets Find Each Other ‘Just Like Everybody Else’
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., April 18—“Hey, you guys aren't the fascists I thought you were,” a beard ed Princeton senior said in great amazement to a trim, blue‐uniformed cadet at the Air Force Academy here.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Ky Says Aim Should Be Political Victory
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 19—Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that his country should work to achieve a political resolution of the war, not press for a military victory over the Communists.
author: By Craig R. Whitney special to The New York Times

headline: ALLIES REPORTED PROBING IN ASHAU
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 20—Government reconnaissance troops were re ported pushing through the Ashau. Valley yesterday in preparation for an allied drive against that long‐time enemy stronghold near the Laotian border.

headline: Charge by G.O.P. War Foe On Bombing of Laos Denied
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 19 (Reuters) — The State Depart ment today denied charges by Representative Paul N. Mc Closkey, California Republican, that the United States was embarked on a policy of sys tematically wiping out. Laotian villages by bombing.

headline: U.S. Forces in Vietnam Close to 284,000 Target
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 19 (Reuters)—The num ber of United States forces in Vietnam fell last week to within 4,000 of President Nixon's May 1 target of 284, 000 troops.

headline: Army Transfers Officer Critical of Laos Push
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 20 (AP)—The United States Army has re lieved the commander of a helicopter battalion because he criticized the allied opera tion in Laos and allowed a television crew to film heli copters using napalm on enemy positions, it was learned today.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: LULA, Ga., April 19—In the window of the Red Top Restaurant here, in red, white and blue letters, a public appeal has been prominently posted. It reads:
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: 1,000 Veterans Begin Week's Protest Against War With Capital March
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 19— About 1,000 veterans, protest ing against United States in volvement in the Indochina war, began a week‐long dem onstration in the capital to day with a march from Arlington Memorial Cemetery past the south gate of the White House to the Capitol steps.

headline: G.I.'s in Ashau Valley: A Long, Bitter History
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 19—There are times when, as a young officer put it, the war in South Vietnam resembles an old film running backward.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: The Electoral Option in Vietnam: II
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—It is difficult for an American to second‐guess an elec tion in the United States, All the more so when he tries to predict one abroad. But, based on what one can glean from the mood of the South Vietnamese in the 1967 election and what one can divine of their present mood, a conse quential, non‐Communist, pro‐peace opponent to President Thieu might have at least an even chance.
author: By Chester L. Cooper

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Martin Zakis Albany, April 9. 1971

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Myron S. Kaufman Washington, April 6, 1971

headline: 400 Delegates to Youth Conference Give Top Priority to ‘People's Peace Treaty’ to End Vietnam War
lead_paragraph: ESTES PARK, Colo., April 20 — The biggest unofficial meeting so far at the White House Conference on Youth has listed the “people's peace treaty” to end the war in Viet nam as its highest priority.
author: By Nan Robertson Special to The New York Times

headline: Soviet Is Hailed as Bulgarian Reds Meet
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 20— With praise for the Soviet Union, rather moderate attacks on both the United States and Communist China and promises of a better life for this coun try's 8.5 million citizens, the Bulgarian Communist leader opened his party's 10th congress here today.
author: By Alfred Friendly Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Goodell Says He Will Run Against Nixon in Primary
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, April 20 (AP) —Former Senator Charles E. Goodell of New York said here tonight he would challenge President Nixon for the Repub lican Presidential nomination in 1972 if Mr. Nixon's policies on Vietnam did not change.

headline: Senators Open Hearing on Ending War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 20— Before an applauding audience of veterans of the Vietnam war, the Senate Foreign Rela tions Committee opened hear ings today on “how to end the war.”
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: BURGER PROHIBITS CAMPING ON MALL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 20— Chief Justice Warren E. Burger late today reinstated a district court ban against overnight camping on the Mall by Viet nam veterans demonstrating for an end to the war.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Hopes Thin for the Millions Adrift Across Indochina
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 20—Uprooted, some times by those who are called friends and sometimes by those called enemies, millions of living victims of the war are adrift in Indochina.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: (Major) Albert Sidney Britt 3d

headline: PATROLS IN ASHAU ENTER 2D WEEK No Major Allied Clash With Foe in Valley Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 21 (AP) — Allied reconnaissance in the Ashau Valley of South Vietnam entered its second week yes terday with still no report of any significant contact with enemy troops in what has long been one of their strongholds.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: T. Dumont

headline: Senate Study Finds Drug Abuse by G.I.'s A Rarity in Combat
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) — A Senate subcommittee staff report said today drug abuse is on the upswing in the armed forces but rarely occurs in com bat.

headline: PENTAGON REVEALS RISE IN ‘FRAGGINGS’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) —“Fragging” incidents among United States troops in Viet nam doubled in 1970 over the previous year, the Pentagon dis closed today.

headline: Religion Professor Sentenced
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif., April 20 (AP) — Dr. Robert McAfee Brown, professor of religion, has been sentenced to five days in jail for taking part in a Good Friday protest of the Viet nam war at the Berkeley draft board. Together with 16 others, the Stanford University profes sor was convicted of obstruct ing a public thoroughfare. Giv en a choice yesterday of paying a $50 fine or going to Santa Rita prison farm, all chose jail.

headline: Saigon Marines Are Airlifted to Positions Near Ashau
lead_paragraph: LAVANG, South Vietnam, April 21—American helicopters today flew about 1,500 South Vietnamese marines to landing zones north of the Ashau Val ley, where reconnaissance in preparation for allied attacks has been under way for more than a week.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Raid Plan Reported
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) —Senator Walter F. Mondale said today he had letters from an American troop commander indicating United States Forces planned a ground attack deep into North Vietnam early this year.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: McCloskey Says U.S. Hid Extent of Laos Bombings
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 21— Representative Paul N. Mc Closkey Jr. said today that the State Department had deliber ately concealed the extent to which American planes had bombed villages in northern Laos.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Porter Asks Permanent Award Of Licenses for Radio and TV
lead_paragraph: Paul A. Porter who, as for mer chairman of the Federal Communications Commission under President Roosevelt, was known as a tough regulator of broadcasting, urged yesterday the permanent award of licens es to radio and television sta tions.
author: By Jack Gould

headline: Court Declines to Overrule Burger's Order on Mall ‘Sleep‐in’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 21 — ??e Supreme Court declined ??lay to overrule Chief Justice arren E. Burger's order yes day that barred camping on ?? Mall here by Vietnam ??vans demonstrating against the war.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Vote Is Nearly 3 to 1
lead_paragraph: ESTES PARK, Colo., April 21 (AP)—Tabulation of the votes earlier today showed that the delegates had approved by nearly 3 to 1 the resolution recommending to President Nixon an immediate halt to United States military action in Southeast Asia and with drawal of all American forces and logistical support by Dec. 31.

headline: Newsmen Held Threatened
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) — Representative Mc Closkey said today that news men covering the Indochina war were afraid they would be beaten or killed if they wrote articles, critical of the Laotian Government.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Gottfried Haderler

headline: U.S. Jet Fires in North
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday (Reuters) — A United States Navy A‐7 fighter bomber fired a rocket at an antiaircraft missile sight in North Vietnam's Mugia Pass Tuesday, the Ameri can command reported today. The pilot was said to have fired the rocket when his equipment detected that the North Viet namese were preparing to fire a missile.

headline: Saigon Airport a Smugglers' Paradise
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 21— Smuggling at Tan sonnhut Airport here has grown to such overwhelming dimen sions that “the sole function of customs at the airport seems to be to assist the smugglers to bring in their contraband without hindrance,” according to an official United States re port.

headline: CAMPUSES QUIET ON WAR PROTEST
lead_paragraph: Enthusiasm on college cam puses for the antiwar demon stration in Washington this weekend has been generally running low.
author: By Michael T. Kaufman

headline: Calley Letters Easing Off And Shifting, Check Finds
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP1) —The flood of angry letters pro testing the murder conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. has subsided on Capitol Hill, and Congress is now hearing from a small minority in sup port of the trial and verdict.

headline: TV: Stimulating Topical Debates on ‘Advocates’
lead_paragraph: Called “The Advocates,” it's a weekly one‐hour pro gram co‐produced by Public Television stations WGBH in Boston and KCET in Los Angeles. It also offers a re freshing alternative to the predictably dull news inter view usually tucked away in the gray recesses of a Sunday afternoon.
author: By John J. O'Connor

headline: REDS AT PARIS TALKS HAIL WAR FOES IN U.S.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 22 (AP)—The Hanoi and Vietcong delegates at the Vietnam peace talks ex pressed “warm feelings” today for the antiwar demonstrators in the United States.

headline: Washington: For the Record
lead_paragraph: April 22, 1971 THE PRESIDENT

headline: Why Veterans March Against the War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—All this week Amer ican veterans who served in Vietnam are protesting against the continua tion of the war and for immediate withdrawal. Tomorrow they will join the ranks of other Americans in a mass demonstration against the Nixon Ad ministration's continued false promises and in support of Congressional bills to stop the bloodshed on both sides and end the war now.
author: By Jan Barry

headline: Books of The Times.
lead_paragraph: ROOTS OF INVOLVEMENT. By Marvin Kalb and Elie Abel. 336 pages. Norton. $8.95. AMERICA'S ASIA. Edited by Edward Friedman and Mark Selden. 458 pages. Pantheon. $10.
author: By Richard R. Lingeman

headline: 5 TOP DEMOCRATS ASК NIXON TO SET DATE FОR РULLOUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 22 — Five Democratic Senators, all potential Presidential nominees, urged President Nixon tonight to establish a terminal date for the withdrawal of all Amer ican forces from Vietnam.

headline: More Troops Flown In
lead_paragraph: LAVANG, South Vietnam, Friday, April 23—More Govern ment troops were airlifted yes supply concentrations con terday into a mountainous area near the Laotian border where a search for enemy troop and tinued.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Fighters Strike Missile Bases in North Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, April 23 (AP) — United States fighter‐bombers struck three times yesterday at missile and antiaircraft sites in North Vietnam and just across the border in Laos, the American command announced.

headline: Excerpts From Democrats' Remarks on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a Democratic response, broad cast and televised last night on the American Broadcasting Company network, to Presi dent Nixon's April 7 speech on troop withdrawals. The speakers were Senators Hu bert H. Humphrey of Minne sota, George S. McGovern of South Dakota, Birch Bayh of Indiana, Henry M. Jackson of Washington, Harold E. Hughes of Iowa and Edmund S. Mushie oft Maine.

headline: G.I. Deaths Pat at 56, A Rise of 14 for Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 22 (Reuters)—Fifty‐six Americans were killed in combat in Indochina last week, the United States com mand announced today.

headline: Man in the News
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 22— Early in 1968, not long after his graduation from the Navy's officer candidate school, Lieut. j.g. John Forbes Kerry visited Vietnam for the first time when his ship stopped over in Danang after a brief tour in the Gulf of Tonkin. “I went ashore and saw the barbed wire, the ma chine guns and a ‘woodpile’ of dead Vietcong bodies,” Mr. Kerry recalls, “and it hit me all at once. This was my first contact with the land war, and at first it looked like something out of the movies. Then I re alized—I said ‘my God, what is going on here—this is really a war.’ “

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: PARIS April 22—The Com munist delegates at the peace conference said today that Pres ident Nixon had pledged to keep American troops in Vietnam indefinitely.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: NOCHEM S. WINNET Philadelphia, April 12, 1971

headline: Judge Lets Veterans Sleep on the Mall; Rebukes U.S. Aides
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 22—An angry Federal judge sharply criticized the Justice Depart ment tonight as he dissolved an injunction against camping on the Mall by Vietnam veter ans demonstrating against the war.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: NEW YORK
lead_paragraph: When the mayors of America's ma jor cities visited New York this week, three things were fairly obvious: First, they felt the crisis of the cities was the major threat to the security of the nation—more serious than Vietnam or anything else. Second, they felt that the bankruptcy and anarchy of the cities were underestimated by the peo ple and by the state and Federal Governments; and third, they felt—in fact they knew — that their campaign for President Nixon's “revenue‐shar ing” and tax‐reform programs was failing.
author: By James Reston

headline: BUCKLEY DEFENDS PRESIDENT ON WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 22— Senator James L. Buckley of New York and three other Re publican Senators took the Senate floor today to defend President Nixon's withdrawal policy in Vietnam.
author: By Richard L. Madden Special to The New York Times

headline: Veteran Posed as Pilot To Build Antiwar Role
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)—The Air Force said to day that Alfred H. Hubbard, identified Sunday in a nation wide telecast as a Vietnam veteran and a former Air Force captain and pilot, ac tually had been a sergeant with no record of service in Vietnam.

headline: HARRYING OF ENVOYS DENOUNCED BY BUSH
lead_paragraph: George Bush, the United States permanent representa tive to the United Nations, made a vigorous denunciation last night of recent harrass ment of foreign diplomatic missions here.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I have hoped that press analysts would offer more than morning‐after commentary on President Nixon's April 7 Vietnam speech. They have not done so.
author: Ernest R. May

headline: Ashau Sweep Continues
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, April 24 (AP)—The allied search for enemy troop and supply concentrations in and around the Ashau Valley went into its 11th day with no significant contact reported.

headline: Veterans Discard Medals In War Protest at Capitol
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 23 — In twos and threes, the medals flew over a wire fence that had been hastily erected in front of the Capitol and landed at the feet of the statue of Chief Jus tice John Marshall, at the build ing's west entrance. The men, who had won the medals in Vietnam were throwing them away.

headline: WAR RALLY TODAY EXPECTS NEW AID
