lead_paragraph: Organizers of the New York contingent in today's mass anti war rally in Washington are counting upon legions of “first time” protesters — from the suburbs, the trade unions, and from new political groups‐to offset what they agree is a noticeable drop in student in volvement in war protests.
author: By John Darnton

headline: Drumbeat in Washington
lead_paragraph: Thousands of demonstrators will assemble in Wash ington today to protest continuation of the Vietnam war. How much effect their march will have on Admin istration military policy is impossible to predict, but vanguard group made up of “Vietnam Veterans Against the War” already has accomplished one welcome reversal of Administration policy in an area important to the right of peaceful protest.

headline: San Diego Shifts on War, With Many Now Opposed
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, April 22—Harry Kripton was a hawk. “I really wanted us to go into Vietnam,” he remembered the other day. “I was more like John Wayne than John Wayne himself.”
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Raid in North Vietnam May Have Damaged 2 MIG's
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Saturday, April 24 —An attack by United States Navy jets on enemy antiaircraft defenses at the Quanlang air field in North Vietnam Thurs day afternoon “may have dam aged one or two MIG‐21 aircraft located on the ground near the site,” the United States com mand announced this morning.

headline: ..but Hope for Jobless
lead_paragraph: The Appalachia bill would be on its way to President Nixon's desk were it not that the House added an unrelated amendment authorizing $2 billion for a nation wide program of public works, principally water and sewage projects. The amendment authorizes up to 100 per cent in Federal grants in areas which have sub stantial unemployment—usually 6 per cent or more— among the entire work force or among Vietnam veterans.

headline: RED CROSS IN HANOI ASKED TO LIST NEEDS
lead_paragraph: GENEVA, April 23 — The League of Red Cross Societies has asked the North Vietnam Red Cross Society to specify what kind of supplies it would like to obtain from a $200‐ thousand donation by the Unit ed Nations Children's Fund, it wap disclosed today.

headline: Ex‐Marine Recounts 1969 U. S. Incursion in Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 23—A former Marine lieutenant told a group of Congressmen today that his unit penetrated nearly five miles inside Laotian terri tory in February, 1969, as part of a two‐week “interdiction and ambush” mission.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: Dream Ending

headline: Booby Trap Kills 7 G.I.'s
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, April 24 (AP)— Seven United States soldiers were killed and 12 wounded yesterday in the explosion of an American artillery shell that enemy troops had rigged as booby trap, the command re ported today.

headline: scuffles Mar Coast Rally After Parade Led by G. I.'s
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, April 24— Active duty servicemen led peaceful march of thousands through the streets of San Francisco today in a giant dem onstration against the war in Southeast Asia.

headline: ‘The Burden and the Curse’
lead_paragraph: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee opened hear ings last week on proposals to end the war In Vietnam in the face of President Nixon's evident intention to con tinue American military involvement in Indochina until the South Vietnamese attain “the capacity to defend themselves against a Communist take‐over”‐‐that is, indefinitely.

headline: HOFFMAN, AT 80, THRIVING AT U.N.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24 (AP)—Paul G. Hoff man, who gave up executive rank in the automobile industry to run the Marshall Plan, will be 80 years old Monday—and he is still working as an inter national civil servant.

headline: Foes of War Are Evicted From a Railroad Station
lead_paragraph: STAMFORD, Conn., April 24 —Antiwar marchers assembling at the Penn Central railroad station here to travel to Wash ington early today were evicted by the railroad police on the ground that they were travel ing by bus and not by train.

headline: Demonstrations in Ottawa
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, April 24 (UPI)— Participants in the leadership convention of Canada's New Democratic party staged small demonstration today to show their “solidarity” with antiwar demonstrations in the United States. About 400 dem onstrators gathered outside the Civic Arena, where the con vention is being held.

headline: To the Editor:
lead_paragraph: Concerning the morality of the war in Vietnam, the important question Is not whether ex‐President Johnson is techni cally liable for prosecution un der the Hague treaty of 1907. That is an academic matter.
author: Stefan Jovanovich New York City

headline: After Decade in Vietnam: An Anthropologist's View
lead_paragraph: Despite an atmosphere in South Vietnam of confusion and doubts, Dr. Hickey's voice has been a scholarly and often a sharp one. When he appears in Washington on May 13 to testify on South Vietnam's dis placed persons before the Sen ate Foreign Relations Commit tee, whose chairman is J. W. Fulbright, he will not be at a loss to suggest how to end the war.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: A Disillusioned Marcher No Longer Backs Nixon
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 24— “I voted for Nixon,” Charles Hughes said as he marched among the youths down Penn sylvania Avenue this afternoon. He was talking softly, but that single sentence brought a sur prising number of stares from those around him, and, rather defensively, he tried to explain.
author: By David E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Weyman O. Steengrafe

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 200,000 Rally in Capital to End War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 24— Antiwar marchers massed to day at a new rallying point, the Capitol, to urge Congress to assume the leadership they seek to bring the Indochina war to an immediate end.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Proud Protesters in a Calm Washington
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 24— This capital now absorbs mas sive antiwar demonstrations al most as calmly as it once absorbed the war.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: On the Planet Polluto
lead_paragraph: Can a nation that spends far more money destroying the ecology of Vietnam than im proving its own ever forestall its environmental degradation?
author: By Bryce Nelson

headline: WАR CHАLLENGES DISMISSED HERE
lead_paragraph: Two decisions by Federal judges here dismissing separate cases of two soldiers who had challenged orders sending them to Vietnam on the ground that the war was unconstitutional have been upheld by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

headline: U.S. PLANES BOMB 2 SITES IN NORTH
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 24—American fighter planes bombed two missile sites in North Vietnam yesterday, the United States command an nounced today. It also reported that in other action its planes had chased an enemy MIG‐21 out of Laos and had been fired on four times by antiaircraft rockets.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Should We Have War Crime Trials?
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Neil Sheehan's essay‐review on our Southeastern Asia situ ation (based on a 33‐book bibli ography collected by Mark Sacharoff) is a painstaking survey of our criminal record in that area — and a milestone in the coverage of the long drawn Indochina War . . . It is also one of those editorial acts that may soon translate itself into a political act, even a po litical force.

headline: Metamorphosis of a Hawk: Why an ex‐Navy Hero From Tennessee Attacked J. Edgar Hoover
lead_paragraph: THE first news last December was something of a surprise. Con gressman William R. Anderson, Democrat from Tennessee, former commander of the Nautilus, the nu clear submarine that made man's first voyage under the North Pole, had at tacked J. Edgar Hoover on the floor of the House of Representatives. A bit of news in itself, since Hoover is not often attacked, at least in public, by men whose jobs depend on elec tions. Even more rarely is he criticized by ex‐Navy heroes from rural Tennes‐ see. And not only was Hoover being attacked, but two Catholic priests, Daniel and Philip Berrigan, convicted of destroying draft‐board records and imprisoned in a Federal penitentiary, were being defended by Anderson. The fact that Anderson's district is a swath of the Bible Belt, where funda mentalists tend to prejudge Catholics with very grave suspicion, spiced the surprise.
author: By Robert Wool

headline: MITCHELL EXPECTS VIOLENCE TO COME
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)—Relieved that today's antiwar protest had occurred peacefully, Attorney General John N. Mitchell nonetheless persisted with his warning that there was substantial likeli hood of violence in the next two weeks of demonstrations here.

headline: Six Vietnam Veterans, on TV Charge That U.S. Betrayed Them
lead_paragraph: Six veterans of the Vietnam war, in a frank, free‐wheeling television discussion last night, accused the United States Gov ernment of having betrayed them and agreed that the Southeast Asia conflict was a racial war.
author: By Douglas Robinson

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am home on leave from Vietnam and I have read Burke Marshall's Op Ed article, “We Must End the War” (April 10.) As a responsible officer of the United States Army in Vietnam, should like to comment on this article from first‐hand knowledge.
author: John H. Cushman

headline: Many Copter Pilots Eager for Combat
lead_paragraph: FORT. RUCKER, Ala.—Capt, William Villaire, an Army heli copter pilot with a. tour in Viet nam behind him, takes a hard. bitten attitude toward military realities.
author: By Oseph Lelyveld Special to The New York Times

headline: All Sides Applaud Peaceful Protest in Washington
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 25 — The organizers of yesterday's antiwar demonstration and city officials said today, that they were pleased that the massive march and rally had not been accompanied by violence.

headline: 1,000 War Protesters Block Jersey Turnpike 4 Hours
lead_paragraph: SWEDESBORO, N.J., April 25 —All traffic was halted for nearly four hours tonight on a 25‐mile stretch of the New Jer sey Turnpike by about 1,000 antiwar demonstrators return ing from Washington.

headline: Nixon Conversation on Calley Reported
lead_paragraph: Washington Notes
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Demonstration in Washington
lead_paragraph: In what must rank as one of the more poignant and eloquent protests against this nation's continued involve ment in the war in Indochina, wounded and decorated veterans last week hurled their battle ribbons and medals at symbols of government in Washington representing the authority which sent them into battle. The massive numbers of antiwar demonstrators who gathered both San Francisco and the nation's capital over the weekend underscored the rising tide of disenchantment that sweeps now coast to coast, across much of American society.

headline: Secrecy on Ashau Drive
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, April 25—The joint United States and South Viet namese operation in the Ashau Valley area is 12 days old and still surrounded by official secrecy, leading some observers to wonder if something has gone wrong, or if the operation is just a training exercise for fresh Government troops.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Stratton for Shelving War Issue, But Women. Indicate Otherwise
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, April 25—Women members of the Democratic State Committee gave a cool reception, including some boos and hisses, tonight to Repre sentative Samuel S. Stratton's assertion that there is “very little difference” between Demo cratic and Republic positions on the Vietnam War.

headline: Agnew Disagrees but Cites Protesters for Orderliness
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, April 25 (UPI) — Vice President Agnew said today that he strongly disagreed with the aim of yes terday's antiwar rally in Wash ington and found it “grotesque” that some of the demonstrators had carried Vietcong flags.

headline: Resor Arrives in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 25 (A11)— The Secretary of the Army, Stanley R. Resort arrived today to study the progress of Vietnamization and to look into the problem of drug addiction in the Army.

headline: Chou Attacks U.S. but on a Mild Note
lead_paragraph: PEKING, April 25—Premier Chou En‐lai struck a relatively mild note in a speech at a ban quet held here tonight to mark the first anniversary of the summit conference of Viet namese, Cambodian and Lao tian regimes at war with the United States and its allies in Indochina.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, April 25 — In observance of Law Day, a group of New York law yers plan to march this Friday to Foley Square in lower Manhattan, there to speak about ending the war in Indo china. In several other cities commit tees of lawyers are working for an end to the war.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Excerpts From Nixon Talk on Confidence
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)— Following are ex cerpts from the text of Presi dent Nixon's speech today to the United States Chamber of Commerce:

headline: U. S. Unaware of Turncoats
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26—A Pentagon spokesman said today the Defense Department had no knowledge of any American deserters fighting with the Viet cong in Vietnam.

headline: VIETCONG APPEAL TO G.I.'S TO DESERT
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 26 — The Viet cong today called on American soldiers in Vietnam to stop fighting or desert and added that some American soldiers were fighting in the Vietcong ranks.

headline: Flights Over Laos By Hanoi's MIG's Reported by U. S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26— North Vietnamese MIG fighters have darted into southern Laos in the last few weeks “on sev eral occasions to threaten U.S. aircraft,” a Pentagon spokes man said today.

headline: Mao Said to Welcome a Nixon Visit
lead_paragraph: Chairman Mao Tse ‐ tung would welcome a visit from President Nixon and would be happy to talk with him, ac cording to Edgar Snow, the American writer who has had frequent access over the years to Chinese Communist officials.

headline: Agnew Calls Hoover's Critics Politically Motivated
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, April 26— Vice President Agnew strongly defended J. Edgar Hoover and the Federal Bureau of Investi gation here today in an 11 page, 28‐minute speech devoted entirely to the director, the agency and their critics.
author: BY Roy Reed Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Force in Vietnam Lowest Since July, 66
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 26 (AP)—United States troop strength in South Viet nam dropped to 281,400 men last week, the United States command announced today. The total was 2,600 below the ceiling set by President Nixon for May 1 and represented the lowest level in nearly five years.

headline: TRIAL TOED KOTOUC MAIMED PRISONER
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, April 26—A former soldier testified today in the court‐martial of Army Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc that the stocky intelligence officer cut off the first joint of a finger of a Vietcong suspect he was questioning a few hours after the mass killings at the hamlet of Mylai three years ago.
author: By Jon Nordheimer Special to The New York Times

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26—The anti war demonstration here last week and those still to come suggested again how widespread is the opposition to continuing the war. But there is not yet a shred of evidence to suggest that this demonstrable opposition is causing the Nixon Administration to change its basic course.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: PRESIDENT URGES BUSINESS TO SHUN ‘SENSE OF DESPAIR’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26— President Nixon told an ap preciative audience of business men today that despite a “sense of despair” in some elements of the population, there was no reason to lose “confidence” in the nation's economy, the aims of its foreign policy, or its sense of concern for the poor.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘People's Lobby’ Begs for End of War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26 — Anti war protesters clad in bur lap sacks and smeared with make‐believe blood pleaded on Capitol Hill today for an end to the conflict in Vietnam.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Munition Dump Destroyed As Foe Steps Up Attacks
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 27—A huge am munition dump in the side of a coastal mountain was exploded by enemy shelling early yester day, the third day of а wave of attacks through much of South Vietnam.

headline: Veterans Aide Cites Gains In Treating Drug Addicts
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) — Donald E. Johnson, Admin istrator of Veterans Affairs, testified today that good prog ress was being made in treat ing drug addicts among Viet nam war veterans who seek rehabilitation.

headline: U.S. Combat Deaths In Vietnam at 45,000
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 26 (AP) — The number of American deaths in com bat in Vietnam has reached 45,000.

headline: 2 Ex‐Johnson Aides Back Warmaking‐Power Curbs
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26 Two men who advised Presi dent Lyndon B. Johnson on the Vietnam war today endorsed proposals to impose legislative restrictions on the President's power to commit the nation to War.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: CAPETOWN — Britain's equivalent of Vietnam was fought here in South Africa Seventy years ago. The cruel Boer War ruined the British reputa tion for international morality, lost the respect of foleign friends for considerable period, and stirred up hornet's nest of political opposition at home.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Enemy Shells Bases 4th Consecutive Day
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 28 (AP)— Enemy gunners, taking advan tage of a period of moonless nights, staged small shelling at tacks against allied installa tions early yesterday for the fourth consecutive day.

headline: 33 Clerics Ask War Repentance Days
author: By Michael Knight

headline: Kotouc Cleared on One Charge But Maiming Accusation Stands
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, April 27 — The military judge in the Army court‐martial of Capt: Eugene M. Kotouc directed a verdict of acquittal today in one of two charges that the Government has brought against the stocky career officer.
author: By Jon Nordheimer Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Orders Ouster of Writer Who Reported on ‘ Tiger Cages’
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 27—The South Vietnamese Government has ordered Don Luce, a 36‐year‐old American writer, to leave the country before May 16.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: The Quest for Justice
lead_paragraph: In any society, the quest for justice is an endless and often frustrating journey. In the middle of a war being waged against a cruel, elusive enemy in an alien country, this quest takes on nightmarish qualities. Yet in Vietnam, as in other wars in the past, the American armed forces have to measure their conduct against this country's laws and ideals. No other standard would be either practical or morally tolerable.

headline: LAIRD SAYS SOVIET RENEWS ABM WORK
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 27— Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that construc tion had resumed at one or more of four antimissile sites on the outskirts of Moscow aft er a break of about three years.be deploying multiple warheads on some large SS‐9 missiles was true.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Rival Banquet Protests Law Day Speech by U.S. Security Official
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 27— Robert C. Mardian, the Justice Department”s chief internal security official, delivered to day the bar association's of ficial Law Day speech to 100 lawyers in a banquet room while three times as many law yers participated in a rival meeting in the adjoining room.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: War Foes Lobby, With Permission, at Capital Draft Headquarters
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)—Antiwar protesteri'but tonholed employes of the na tion's draft headquarters today with the blessing of the dirge tor. A few other demonstrators were arrested after spending the night in the office of Seno for Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the minority leader.

headline: ROGERS BIDS CHINA BE ‘CONSTRUCTIVE’ IN SOUTHEAST ASIA
lead_paragraph: LONDON, April 27—Secre tary of State William P. Rogers called on China today to begin to play a “constructive rather than disruptive role” in South east Asia.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: China and America: Beginnings
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.—The dramatic reversal in Sino‐American relations, is far more profound than mere Ping Pong diplomacy. Current contacts are actually increasingly semiofficial in nature.
author: By ISKWER C. OJHA and DANIEL TRETIAK

headline: RADICALS ASSAIL FULBRIGHT PANEL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 28— Representatives of a radical antiwar group accused the Sen ate Foreign Relations Commit tee today of a “lack of initia tive” in ending the Vietnam war and called Congress “the puppet of the madmen who are in power.”

headline: Laird Says Neutral Ships Would Evacuate P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 28 (Reu ters)—Defense Secretary Mel vin R. Laird said today he had been assured that ships of neu tral nations were available to evacuate prisoners of both sides in the Vietnam war if Hanoi would agree to transfer prisoners to third countries.

headline: BAYH, IN TALK HERE, SCORES NIXON AGAIN
lead_paragraph: Senator Birch Bayh of Indi ana, one of several seeking con sideration for the Democratic nomination for President, at tacked President Nixon last night for criticizing “new isola tionists” in the United States without specifying whom he meant.

headline: OBSERVER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 28—One of the most difficult jobs in Government these days is held by Jim Dandy, Assistant Secretary of State for Balder dash and Guff, which are not, as the casual newspaper reader may suppose, obscure islands in the Arabian Sea, but highly spiced ingredients essential to a well‐cooked foreign policy.
author: By Russell Baker

headline: SOVIET ANALYZES ALLIES' LAOS PUSH
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, April 28— The Soviet Defense Ministry news paper, in an analysis of the recent Laotian operation, said today that the South Vietnam ese suffered heavy losses be cause American advisers un derestimated the opposing forces in the area and were caught by surprise by the in troduction of tanks and heavy artillery.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Congressman Sees Deception in Ratio Of Noncombat Dead
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)—Representati William D. Ford has said that the mili tary's explanation of a recent rise of noncombat deaths in South Vietnam has not allayed his suspicions that the Penta gon is engaging in a “grisly numbers game” to hide hor rors of the war.

headline: Rogers Says U.S. Favors Exchanges Of Newsmen and Students With China
lead_paragraph: He also said a visit to main land China by President Nixon “might well be possible . . . down the road a piece” if re lations between Washington and Peking continued to im prove and China began to com ply with the rules of interna tional law.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Ex‐G.I. Alleges 30 Slayings Near Mylai
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 28— A former Army sergeant said today that he took part in the killing of about 30 Vietnamese men, women, and children in a village called Truong Khanh, near Mylai, in April 1969.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: KOTOUC DESCRIBES MAIMING INCIDENT
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, April 28—Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc took the witness stand today at his court‐martial and used the outstretched hand of his pros ecutor to demonstrate how he had chopped off the end of a prisoner's finger.
author: By Jon Nordheimer Special to The New York Times

headline: Ashau Sweep Continues
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 29 (AP) — An Americqn‐backed South Viet namese ground operation in the Ashau Valley area in the north ern quarter of the country en tered its third week yesterday. So far, however, no major con tact with the enemy has been reported.

headline: U.S. Jets Attack in North
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Thursday, April 29 (Reuters)—Two United States Navy F‐8 Crusader jets attacked North Vietnamese radar‐di rected antiaircraft sites 110 miles northwest of the demili tarized zone yesterdays the United States command an nounced today.

headline: S.L.A. Marshall: On the Nature of War
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Mich.—My attention has been drawn to an essay opposite your editorial page wherein Burke Marshall, acting as judge, jury and prosecutor, convicts all Americans of the crime at Mylai toward mitigating what was triggered by the direct ac tion of one lieutenant.
author: By S. L. A. Marshall

headline: HAMLETS WIPED OUT, EX‐MARINE TESTIFIES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 29 (Reuters)—A former marine corporal, Kenneth James Camp bell, said today that two North Vietnamese hamlets were wiped out in August, 1968, and their 30 civilian inhabitants killed by American artillery on the chance they may have been supplying rice to Communist troops.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Frank Masland

headline: Cambodians and Enemy Clash Again in Hand‐to‐Hand Battles
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 29 (AP)—Cambodian troops fought hand‐to‐hand battles with enemy soldiers today for the second consecutive day on Route 4, Pnompenh's supply route from the sea, the high command said.

headline: PENTAGON DENIES A NUMBERS GAME
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 29— The Defense Department said today that while combat casual ties in Vietnam declined 70 per cent between 1968 and 1970, noncombat casualties had re mained almost constant.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: Article 2 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 29—A spokes man for the Communist‐led pro visional Revolutionary Govern ment said today that the kill ings described by Mr. Notley in Washington had been broad er in scope than the witness realized.

headline: Ford Assails Muskie and Fulbright Stands on Mideast
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 29— Before a gathering of Jewish leaders, Representative Gerald R. Ford, the House Republican leader, today accused Senator Edmund S. Muskie and Senator J. W. Fulbright of undermining American support of Israel.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: NIXON INDICATES INDEFINITE STAY FOR VIETNAM G.I.'S
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 29— President Nixon said tonight that a residual force of United States troops would remain in South Vietnam indefinitely— “no matter how long it takes” —if Hanoi refused to release American prisoners of war.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: PEACE TOUR SET BY CONGRESSMEN
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 29 — More than 20 members of Con gress have agreed to travel around the country in a new antiwar program designed to bring constituent pressure on Senators and Congressmen re luctant to push for an early withdrawal of American forces from Vietnam.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Kotouc Is Acquitted of Maiming A Vietnamese Prisoner at Mylai
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, April 29—An Army court‐martial jury cleared Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc of guilt today in the maiming of a Vietnamese prisoner three years ago at Mylai 4, an act the officer said he had com mitted by accident.
author: By Jon Nordheimer Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Asks U.S. to Open Talks Now on Pullout Date
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 29—North Viet nam invited the United States today to open negotiations “this very day, or tomorrow, or another day” on setting a date for the withdrawal of all Amer ican troops from South Viet nam.
author: By John L. Hess Special to The New York Times

headline: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of Presi dent Nixon's news conference last night as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Sylvia R. Day

headline: Hanoi Reports a Prisoner Denies Capture of Tchepone
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, April 29 (Reu ters)—A captured South Viet namese officer was quoted today by the North Vietnam news agency as saying that Saigon troops never reached the strategic town of Tchepone during last month's strike against the Ho Chi Minh Trail in southern Laos.

headline: Another Way the U.S. Has Left Its Mark on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 29 — Although she is only 4 years old, Nina Deng remembers the day her fa ther, a United States Navy chief petty officer, went back to the states and his American wife. Her mother, Dang Thi Hoa, carried her to the door and tearfully waved good‐by. Her father cried, too. He kissed them and prom ised to write every week.

headline: 45 Killed in Week; American War Toll Now Over 45,000
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Ap ril 29 (UPI) — The United States command announced to day that 45 Americans died in combat last week in Indochina, raising the total in the war since the beginning of 1961 past the 45,000 mark.

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 29 (AP)—United States B‐52 bombers struck at targets in the northwestern corner of South Vietnam today in another intensive effort to force North Vietnamese troops from jungle bases, the United States com mand said.

headline: Ceausescu Goes to Peking
lead_paragraph: VIENNA, May 31 (UPI)— President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania left for Peking today at the head of a Communist party and Government delega tion that will visit China, North Korea, North Vietnam and Mongolia, the official Rumanian press agency said.

headline: Washington Notes
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 31 — President Nixon's basic speech for political occasions seems to be taking shape on this theme: Peace soon, then prosperity.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: A.C.L.U. Notifying Protesters
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) —The American Civil Liberties Union undertook the chore to day of notifying 2,400 defend ants arrested in antiwar demon strations here early this month that the Government has dropped charges against them. The District of Columbia cor poration counsel's office said the charges were dropped be cause it did not have enough information to prosecute.

headline: ENEMY REPORTED TO CAPTURE SNOUL
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 31 — North Vietnamese troops reportedly drove a South Vietnamese task force today from the Cambodian town of Snoul, which United States troops captured more than a year ago.

headline: Cambodians Willing To Discuss Peace With North Vietnam
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 31 (Reuters)—The Cambodian head of state, Cheng Heng, said today that his Government was willing to open discussions to end the war in Cambodia if the Vietcong and North Vietnamese withdrew all their troops.

headline: All but 13 of 570 P.O.W.'s Refuse to Return to Hanoi
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 31—Only 13 of the 570 disabled prisoners offered re patriation have agreed to re turn to North Vietnam, officials said tonight.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: P.O.W.'S AN ISSUE IN KOREA WAR, TOO
lead_paragraph: The refusal of more than 500 North Vietnamese prisoners of war to go home to the North sounded a faint but familiar echo: this same issue of repa triation halted negotiations to ward an armistice in the Korean War for months in 1952 and 1953.

headline: Proposal Rejected in Paris
lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 31 (Reuters)— Representatives of the North Vietnamese and Vietcong dele gations to the peace talks re jected Mr. Cheng Heng's pro posal today as “nonsense” and expressed their support for the ousted Cambodian leader, Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

headline: G.I. Unit in Britain Assails Vietnam War
lead_paragraph: LONDON, May 31—A thou sand United States servicemen stationed in Britain announced their opposition to the Vietnam war today. It was the Iargest antiwar protest among Ameri can military personnel sta tioned here.

headline: Pullout Is Not Seen as Threat to G.I.'s in Field
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Scuti, Vietnam, May 31—The 70 per cent reduction in the number of American combat troops in Vietnam has left major United States bases and supply depots more vul nerable to attack but has not yet increased the danger to the ground troops still in the field, according to a survey of Amer ican field commanders.
author: JULIUS EPSTEIN Hoover Institution Stanford University Stanford, Calif., July 11, 1971

headline: Memorial Day Observed Traditionally and by Protests on War
lead_paragraph: Memorial Day. 1971. was ob served across the country yes terday in ceremonies that underscored division over the war in Vietnam and the 45,000 American combat deaths it has produced.
author: By Juan M. Vasquez

headline: Troop Strength in Vietnam Reduced by U.S. to 255,700
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam May 31 (AP) — The United States command announced to day that American troop strength in Vietnam was re duced another 3,600 men last week, bringing the total to 255,700. It is the lowest level in more than five years.

headline: MINNESOTA G.I. WINS A STAY OF WAR DUTY
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, June 1—A 20‐ year‐old Minnesota soldier re ceived a brief respite from Viet nam duty today when Federal District Judge Earl Larson de layed a hearing on his conten tion that his orders were illegal because war had not been de clared.

headline: Army Studies Charges Of Killing of 24 Civilians
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) — The Army said today it was investigating charges that United States airborne troops killed 24 to 40 Vietnamese women and children on a beach near Bongson in Sep tember, 1968.

headline: Nixon, Drugs and the War
lead_paragraph: In his news conference last night, President Nixon said it was important to keep the problem of drug addiction among American troops in Vietnam in perspective. His Administration, he said, was concentrating on getting at the sources of drugs in the world, that it was going to prosecute the drug “pushers,” treat the drug “addicts” and try to inform the American public on the general problem of drug ad diction.
author: By James Reston

headline: Antiwar Veterans Are Labeled ‘Irresponsible’ by Rival Group
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1— Representatives of a new group called Vietnam Veterans for Just Peace said today that they were angered and dismayed by the “irresponsible” protests of a “relative handful” of antiwar veterans in the capital last April.

headline: PRESIDENT GIVES ‘HIGHEST PRIORITY’ TO DRUG PROBLEM
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1— President Nixon pledged to night to undertake a “na tional offensive” to counter the problem of drug addiction among young Americans, in cluding servicemen who have become addicted while in South Vietnam.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: BROTHER OF PREMIER IS OUSTED IN SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1—Informed sources said tonight that Tran Thien Khoi, brother of Premier Tran Thien Khiem, had been removed as chief of the National Customs Investigation Division.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Hoping to be the first pilot to fly over the North Pole from Equator to Equator in a light plane, Sheila Scott flew off from London yester day in her Piper Aztec, first stop Nairobi.

headline: Marine's Plea Rejected In 5 Slayings in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)—The Supreme Court re jected today an appeal by a young marine convicted of slaying five Vietnamese civil ians near Hue in 1968.

headline: Saigon Denies Rout by Enemy at Snoul
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 2—The South Vietnamese task force that withdrew from the eastern Cambodian town of Snout on Monday is still inside Cam bodia, a Saigon spokesman said yesterday.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: TV: Some Interludes for the Restless Dial‐Twister
lead_paragraph: A holiday weekend at the shore. Rain. The television set. The little box does pro vide occasional compensa tions, even if only in reruns of movies with deliciously insipid plots. There is some thing atrociously comforting in watching “Night and Day” for the 17th time, in marvel ing at tall, handsome Cary Grant playing the diminutive Cole Porter and at Alexis Smith doing her familiar com mercial for the Good Woman.
author: By John J. O'Connor

headline: Cambodians Report Battles
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 1 (AP) — Cambodian troops guarding the eastern ap proaches to Pnompenh reported today they had killed about 200 North Vietnamese or Viet cong attackers in all‐day bat tles in the marshes on the eastern bank of the Mekong River about 5 miles from the capital. The current fighting is for tiny patches of high ground that are above areas that are expected to be flooded soon by monsoon rains.

headline: U. S. Comments on Pullout
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) —Jerry W.Freidham, the Pen tagon spokesman, said today that the South Vietnamese had intended to withdraw some main combat units from Cam bodia with the onset of the rainy season. The withdrawal, he said, “appears from here to be orderly and according to their plan.”

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, June 1 (AP) — A Federal district judge dismissed today a suit by Massachusetts. challenging the ‐constitutional ity of the Indochina war, reject ing contentions that the Presi dent has usurped the warmak ing powers of Congress.

headline: Envoys Guests of Thieu At Army Fete in Forest
lead_paragraph: FIRE BASE HOABINH, South Vietnam, June 1— With monsoon rains batter ing the palm leaves atop the dining hall of this fire base, President Nguyen Van Thieu, the American Establishment and diplomats gathered here this afternoon for an anniver sary luncheon — South Viet nam's 21st Infantry Division was 12 years old.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: MAYDAY ARRESTS UPHELD BY NIXON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1—In the sharpest news conference exchange since he assumed of fice, President Nixon praised tonight the behavior of District of Columbia police during the recent Mayday antiwar pro tests and said charges that con stitutional rights had been vio lated by the mass arrests were an “exaggeration.”
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Copter Crash Kills 7
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Wednesday, June 2 (AP)—The United States com‐ mand reported today the loss of two more Army helicopters and said one had crashed 24 miles northwest of Saigon, killing seven Americans aboard. It was one of the largest losses of life in a helicopter crash in recent months.

headline: Coordinator Is Named For G.I. Drug Program
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) — Everett G. Hopson, a retired Air Force colonel, was named by the Defense De partment today to coordinate its policies and programs for curbing drug abuse in the armed forces. Roger T. Kel ley, Assistant Secretary of De fense for Manpower and Re serve Affairs, who appointed Mr. Hopson, is expected to announce a program later this week for better identify ing and treating G.I. drug ad dicts returning from Vietnam.

headline: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of Presi dent Nixon's news conference in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: WAR‐CRIMES FIGURE DESCRIBES ‘THREAT’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) —Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Her bert said today that a military investigator had tried unsuc cessfully to stop him from fil ing war‐crimes charges by threatening to accuse him of assault in an alleged massacre of civilians at Bongson, South Vietnam.

headline: SAIGON ASSEMBLY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 3—The lower house of the South Vietnamese National Assembly today passed a controversial bill on presi dential election rules that could leave President Nguyen Van Thieu with no serious chal lenger in the election next October.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: No Light on Mayday
lead_paragraph: President Nixon did little in his news conference remarks on the arrest and prosecution of the Mayday demonstrators in Washington to clarify the difficult issues in that controversy.

headline: Deputy Waves Grenade
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2—The lower house of the Na tional Assembly was thrown into turmoil tonight when an anti‐Government deputy pulled a hand grenade from his pocket and threatened to blow himself up. He was protesting what the opposition viewed as an effort to push through a provision limiting the number of presiden tial candidates.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Calley: A View From Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam—It should be noted that the horrible massacre at Mylai was first brought to light by the Americans themselves. It was de nounced by American G.I.'s back from Vietnam and it was brought before American and world public opinion by the American press. Without them, the Vietnamese—it is shameful and pain ful for us to admit it, with our poor means of communication and our re stricted free press—would never know of the Mylai massacre.
author: By Tran Tan Quoc

headline: U.S. Used Billions of Leaflets in Indochina War
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2—The United States Army has printed during the Vietnam war 6,245,200,000 propaganda leaflets for air drops in Indochina.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: LAWYERS TO LOBBY FOR ANTIWAR BILLS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2 — A group of prominent lawyers announced plans today to lobby in Congress next week for pas sage of legislation that would end American involvement in Vietnam by the end of the year.

headline: Many Said to Fear Reprisals
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2 (AP) — Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam confirmed today that only 13 sick or wounded prison ers of war were to be re patriated to North Vietnam on Friday. He said most of those who refused to go feared re prisals from the Communists.

headline: 10 Held for Picketing Store
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex., June 2 (AP) —Nine men and a girl, among them eight soldiers from Fort Hood, were held in the city jail today on charges arising from their picketing of a jewelry store last night. Dave Zeiger from the Oleo Strut, a down town coffeehouse frequented by youths and soldiers protest ing the Vietnam war, said those arrested had said the store's salesmen solicited cus tomers from among soldiers passing by by talking with them and “profiting from their homesickness” before inviting them in to buy.

headline: General, Ex‐Aide Accused Of Murdering Vietnamese
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2—The Army accused Brig. Gen. John W. Donaldson today of murder ing six Vietnamese civilians and assaulting two others in the winter of 1968–69.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Abbie Hoffman Denies Riot Charges
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2—Ab bie Hoffman, the Yippie leader, pleaded not guilty to day to charges stemming from the antiwar demonstrations here last month by the May day Tribes.

headline: Heavy U.S. Raids Reported Near Snoul
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 3 (AP)—Re sponding to a South Vietnamese request, hundreds of United States bombers and helicopter gunships struckt at what were reported to be troops of three enemy divisions in eastern Cambodia yesterday.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Joseph W. Bishop Jr

headline: HANOI DENOUNCES SAIGON ON P.O.W.'S
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 2 (AP)—North Vietnam charged today that south Vietnam's offer to free Sick and wounded North Viet namese prisoners was a sham and denounced statements in Saigon that only 13 of 660 prisoners wanted to go home.

headline: Nixon Plans Agency On Drug Addiction
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 3—Pres ident Nixon is planning a new Federal agency to direct ef forts to stem the tide of drug addiction among returning Viet nam veterans and in the gen eral public.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: Senate to Get Modified Proposal for War Pullout in '71
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 3 — The legislative battle lines start ed to take shape in the Senate today on efforts to force a troop withdrawal from Vietnam by the end of the year and to require a 10 per cent cut in defense spending.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Pimen Assumes Throne Of Patriarch in Moscow
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, June 3 — With centuries‐old pomp and majes ty, Metropolitan Pimen of Kru titsy anad Kolomna was en throned today as the new Patriarch of the Russian Ortho dox Church.
author: By Bernard Gwertznian Special to The New York Times

headline: The Reluctant P.O.W.'s: Charges, Countercharges and U.S. Disappointment
lead_paragraph: GENEVA, June 3 — “Do you agree to being released in the North?”
author: By Thomas J. Hamilton Special to The New York Times

headline: Sweep Near the DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3 (AP)—The Saigon command announced today that 2,500 marines were conducting a sweep in the northwest corner of the country in an effort to smash a North Vietnamese troop build‐up.

headline: HANOI NOW SAYS IT WON'T ACCEPT RETURN OF P.O.W.'S
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 3—North Viet nam announced today that it was canceling all arrangements to receive sick and wounded prisoners of war from the South on the ground that only 13 out of 570 originally announced would be transferred.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: 13 Head for Rendezvous
lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE U.S.S. UP SHUR, Off South Vietnam, Fri day, June 4—Thirteen disabled North Vietnamese prisoners of war headed back to their home land last night in the air conditioned hospital ward of this luxurious troop transport.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Realignment’ in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: Reports from the key Cambodian border town of Snout indicate that the South Vietnamese withdrawal, which has been described by Saigon army spokesmen as a “realignment” of forces, was more like a rout, similar in many respects to the recent precipitate South Viet naniese retreat from Laos.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Richard N. Gottfried

headline: Thieu May Be Unopposed in Wake of House Vote
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3—In the South Vietnam ese Presidential election of 1967, there were 11 candidates, and Nguyen Van Thieu won with only 35 per cent of the vote. In the election on Oct. 3, it appears, the President may have only one opponent, or may even run upopposed, under a bill passed today by the low er house of the South Vietnam ese National Assembly.
author: By Craig It Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: The Obligation of History
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England — When Thucydides the Athenian described the twenty‐seven‐year war between Athens and Sparta at the end of the fifth century B.C., he declared that his work would be “a possession for all time.”
author: By A. Geoffrey Woodhead

headline: U.S. Losses Up in Week to 48 As Those of Saigon Drop to 452
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3 (Reuters)—The allied mili tary commands reported today that United States battlefield deaths increased last week while those of the South Viet namese decreased slightly. The estimated enemy toll, they said, dropped sharply.

headline: Baptists Criticize Delay on Bible Tract
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, June 3 — The Southern Baptist Convention— the largest Protestant denomi nation in America, with 11.6 million members — ended its three‐day annual meeting here today after stanchly upholding its traditional conservatism.
author: By George Dugan Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Michael Hamilton

headline: Job Outlook Is Bleak for Vietnam Veterans
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 4 —When Jim Pearson came home from Vietnam five years ago with several medals pinned to his paratrooper's tunic, he was in no great hurry to go to work.
author: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Laird Not Satisfied
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 4 (Reu ters) — Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird is stilt not saris field with attempts by the South Vietnamese Government to curb the flow of ?? American servicemen, the Pen tagon said today.

headline: House Panel Told About New Drugs To Combat Heroin
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) —Scientists told Congressional investigators today of a new group of drugs that they said might mark “an important medical breakthrough” toward solving the heroin problem in the United States and in South Vietnam.

headline: ENEMY'S SUPPLIES SEEM UNCHECKED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4—Allied military intelli gence officers are paying close attention to the heavy mortar and rocket fire that the enemy has been using since the close of the South Vietnamese thrust against the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos in March.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: 13 Downcast Prisoners, Spurned by Hanoi, Return to Danang
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, June 4—Thirteen disabled North Vietnamese prisoners, described as saddened and bewildered by the last‐minute refusal of Hanoi to take them back, returned here today after a 24‐hour sea journey to nowhere.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 4 — The contem porary critics of our society often speak of its “hyprocrisy.” It is a charge naturally resented by the so ciety's leaders, for with few excep tions they feel perfectly sincere in what they do.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Prisoners as Pawns
lead_paragraph: Hanoi's callous rejection of thirteen sick and wounded North Vietnamese prisoners of war represents the final breakdown of a major American‐South Vietnamese pris oner repatriation effort that never had much chance of success.

headline: Public Jobs for the Jobless
lead_paragraph: The Congressional bill to create public service jobs for the unemployed is a constructive response both to the immediate exigencies of the recession and to the long‐term needs of unskilled workers. With nearly five million persons out of work, including many recent veterans of Vietnam, the nation has a moral as well as an economic obligation to take effective action to offset the human consequences of a downswing in the business cycle. The bill, now passed in slightly different versions by both House and Senate, would be at least a modest help because it would subsidize state and local govern ments in hiring 150,000 workers to fill subprofessional jobs.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: The shantytowns that huddle close to the big American mili tary bases in Vietnam all have their “scag alleys” — the muddy lanes lined with corrugated iron and scrap‐wood huts where for $5 or so G.I.'s can buy enough heroin to keep at bay for day or so the irritations of military discipline, the boredom of rou tine jobs or the anxieties of com bat patrols at the tag end of an unpopular war.
author: —Tom Buckley

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: George McGovern

headline: Law
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—“I approve of what they did, and in the event that we have similar sit uations in the future, I hope that we can handle those sit uations as well as this was handled.”
author: —Fred J. Cook

headline: 61% in Poll Assert Entry Into the War Was U.S. ‘Mistake’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 5—Six out of 10 Americans now think it was a mistake for the United States to become involved in the Vietnam War, the Gallup Poll reported today.

headline: BATTLES REPORTED IN KHESANH AREA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam. Sun day, June 6 (AP) —North Viet namese rockets were reported to have struck the port city of Danang yesterday and heavy fighting was reported near Khesanh in the northwestern corner of South Vietnam.

headline: Minh Assails Saigon's New Electoral Law
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 6 — Gen. Duong Van Minh, considered the leading political rival of President Nguyen Van Thieu in the October elections, today publicly criticized South Vietnam's new electoral law.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Opposition Deputy, Jailed in Delta, Back in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 5—A prominent anti‐Gov ernment member of South Vietnam's lower house came out of jail this weekend after a brief and bizarre confrontation with authorities in his home district, with his own political fortunes greatly enhanced, and the Thieu Administration's rep utation embarrassingly tar nished.
author: By Craig R. Whitney  Special to The New York Times

headline: ANTIWAR ACTIVIST ASSISTS JOHNSON
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 5 —About a day after Doris H. Kearns, a bouncy, 5‐foot‐4 young woman from Long Island who teaches political science at Harvard, was picked as a White House Fellow under President Johnson four years ago, an article by her appeared in The New Republic under the head line “How to Remove L.B.J. in 1968.”
author: By Robert Reinhold Special to The New York Times

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam —Nothing symbolized the hopeless ness of the prisoner of war issue more than the view last Friday morning from the top deck of the U.S.S. Upshur, a comfortable troop transport sailing the South China Sea. The ship, carry ing 13 disabled North Vietnamese prisoners who wanted to go home, and a tug pulling a re modeled barge to transfer the captives to their countrymen were going around in circles.
author: —Alvin Shuster

headline: C. I. A. Identifies 21 Asian Opium Refineries
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 5— United States intelligence agents have identified at least 21 opium refineries in the bor der area of Burma, Laos, and Thailand that provide a con stant flow of heroin to Ameri can troops in South Vietnam.
author: Julius Epstein Hoover Institution Stanford University Stanford, Calif., July 11, 1971

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Warren S. Josephy's recent letter displays a failure to grasp basic prin ciples of the antiwar movement; “Viet namization” and, indeed, the entire Indochina policy of the current Ad ministration are based upon the prem ise that yellow Vietnamese lives are less valuable than overwhelmingly white American lives and, therefore, provide a ready substitute in the Asian carnage.

headline: The Vietnam Debate
lead_paragraph: Another serious setback for South Vietnamese forces and a fresh expression of Presidential determination to hang on in Indochina until the Saigon regime can defend itself lend weight to two carefully qualified moves in Congress this week designed to set a cutoff date for United States military action in Southeast Asia.

headline: After Vietnam— Another Witchhunt?
lead_paragraph: THE conviction and sentencing of an American soldier for the commission of war crimes has brought to a head a national crisis and a national debate that, in the period ahead, may well reach historic proportions. What is at stake is the survival of the United States as the representative of such virtues as jus tify the claim it makes to the alle giance of its citizens and the respect of the world. It is never easy, in the midst of a developing crisis, to see its historical significance, but we must nevertheless make the attempt.
author: By Louis J. Halle

headline: ACCUSED GENERAL GETS A PROMOTION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 5—The Army has promoted a brigadier general to major general while investigating alleged atrocities that occurred under his com mand in Vietnam In 1969.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Brother of Hanoi Aide Defects to the South
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 5 (Reuters)—The brother of one of the North Vietnam top diplomats has defected to the South Vietnamese author ities and will be presented to the press here Monday, a Government spokesman an nounced today.

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: Nguyen Van Thieu was elected President of South Vietnam in 1967 by only 35 per cent of the vote in an 11‐man race. A new election is scheduled for Oct. 3, and Mr. Thieu, according to Sai gon reports, would like to make sure his margin is greater this time. He may have the field all to himself.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was judged guilty of participating in war crimes, a broad element of the public hooted at the justice of an army that brought lieu tenants to the dock but wouldn't treat a general that way.
author: —Robert Sherrill

headline: VIETNAM VETERANS PLAN AN ‘INCURSION’
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, June 6 (UPI) — The Vietnam Veterans Against the War announced today plans for “a limited incursion of Vietnam veterans into middle America” for July 3–5 at Kan sas City, Mo.

headline: McCloskey Begins to Organize for Primary Campaign in New Hampshire
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N. H., June 6— Paul N. McCloskey Jr., the Re publican Representative who for several months now has been challenging his party and his President on the Vietnam war, started organization building in New Hampshire this weekend, and for some people here it seemed that history was repeating itself.
author: By Bill Kovach Special to The New York Times

headline: Get‐the‐Generals
lead_paragraph: PINE BLUFF, Ark.—One of the re percussions of the Calley trial is a move to Get‐the‐Generals. Why punish a young lieutenant and let the brass go free?
author: By Paul Greenberg

headline: Saigon Reports 83 of Foe Slain; Clashes Continue Near Border
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam. June 6—Sharp clashes between United States and South Viet namese forces and North Viet namese regulars continued to day around a Government base high above the main road be tween Khesanh and Quangtri, with a predawn enemy attack in which 83 Norh Vietnamese soldiers were killed, according to Government reports.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I. GETS 3 YEARS IN DEATH OF MAJOR
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Monday, June 7 (AP)—A 25‐ year‐old Army enlisted man was sentenced today to three years imprisonment and a dis honorable discharge for killing one of his officers and trying to kill another.

headline: DRUGS REPORTED TIED TO VIETNAM PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) — Representative Robert H. Steele, Republican of Connecti cut, said today that the high rate of heroin addiction among United States servicemen in Vietnam had prompted the Nix on Administration to seek a step‐up in its rate of troop withdrawals.

headline: Two Senators Assail U.S. on Laos War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 6—Sen ator Stuart Symington said to day that instead of the $52‐mil lion publicly acknowledged by the Administration, the United States was spending “hundreds of millions of dollars” in a clandestine war in northern Laos.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon's Electoral Law
lead_paragraph: News Analysis
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Copters Sink 11 Sampans
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Monday, June 7 (Reuters)— United States heli copters attacked two flotillas of Vietcong sampans at the mouth of the Mekong River yesterday, sinking 11 sampans and killing 22 Vietcong, a United States spokesman said.

headline: ‘SYNDROME’ FOUND IN RETURNED G.I.'S
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga.— —“Stogdill,” came the voice over the loudspeaker, “time to play pool.”
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Tactics Disputed in Fight to Win Release of P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 6—For two years, the Nixon Admin istration has been running a campaign of publicity, and per ?? to marshal American and world opinion behind it on the issue of American prison ers of war in Indochina.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: TV: Nuremberg's Relevance to the Vietnam War
lead_paragraph: Several years ago Bertrand Russell was one of the key organizers of an international tribunal to consider the ques tion of whether the United States was committing war crimes in Indochina. The gen eral reaotion was that Lord Russell was at best a senile fool, at worst a propagandis tic tool of Hanoi. That was several years ago.
author: By John J. O'Connor

headline: U.S. Troop Strength In Vietnam Cat by 4,800
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 7 (AP)—The United States command reported to day that American troop strength in South Vietnam had been reduced by 4,800 men last week. It also an nounced that six Marine Corps units totaling 1,240 men would return soon to the United States.

headline: Brother of Hanoi Official Explains Why He Defected to the South
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 7—The twin brother of a diplomat in North Vietnam disclosed today why he had de fected to the Saigon Govern ment after nine years in the National Liberation Front in South Vietnam.

headline: Hanoi Says U.S. Bombarded North Repeatedly in May
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, June 7 (Reu ters)—Hanoi today charged the United States with having con ducted “recurrent bombard ment” against the southern most part of North Vietnam in May.

headline: Judge in Mylai Case Denies Request for Secret Data
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., June 7 (UPI)—A military judge re fused today to subpoena the secret records of a House hear ing into the Mylai slayings for use at the trial of Col. Oran K. Henderson, who is accused of failure to fully report the inci dent.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Aubrey M. Daniel 3d, the Army prosecutor of Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. who criticized President Nixon for having injected himself into the case, will join the Wash ington law firm of Edward Bennett Williams this sum mer.
author: James F. Clarity

headline: JAVITS ‘BLESSES’ M'CLOSKEY'S BID
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 7— Senator Jacob K. Javits gave his blessing today to Represent ative Paul N. McCloskey's challenge to President Nixon but said he was personally “not yet prepared to sub scribe” to such political of forts.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. OFFICER HEED FOR WAR PROTEST
lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 7—An Air Force officer, placed under re striction on the eve of his de parture for the United States and discharge, said today he expected to face a court‐martial for taking part in a protest against the Vietnam war.

headline: Advertising:
lead_paragraph: The idea of “unselling” the Indochina war through a massive advertising barrage, which was only a seed in the mind of a Yale student this winter, has almost come to flower.
author: By Philip H. Dougherty

headline: B‐52 Raids Reported on Bunkers South of DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 8 (AP)—Four waves of B‐52's reportedly struck at enemy positions in northernmost South Vietnam yesterday in a move to counter a continuing: enemy threat there.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Lowell M. Greenbaum

headline: At a U.S. Air Base, ‘Yellow Alert’—And Boredom
lead_paragraph: PHUCAT, South Vietnam, June 2—It was a week of “high threat” at the most mod ern United States Air Force base in South Vietnam, which looks like a chunk of suburban Southern California. “High threat” means possible attack.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Reported Pushing Supply Effort, Repairing Laos Route to West of Trail
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 7 — North Vietnam has begun an unexpected effort to step up the flow of war materiel through southern Laos during the current rainy season, ac cording to senior American military analysts.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: SENATE VOTES RISE IN G. I. PAY OF $2.7‐BILLION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 8—In a stunning reversal, the Senate approved today a $2.7‐billion increase in pay for all the mili tary services.
author: By David E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: ENEMY ATTACKS NEAR PNOMPENR
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, June 9 (Reuters)— North Vietnamese troops struck hard at Government forces yesterday in a new attempt to seize the marshy eastern ap proaches to Pnompenh.

headline: Chou Calls On Smaller Nations to Unite to Resist Superpowers
lead_paragraph: PEKING, June 8—Premier Chou En‐Lai, warning that the danger of world war persists, called today upon small and medium‐sized nations to unite and resist bullying by super powers.
author: By Seymour Topping Special to The New York Times

headline: KUNSTLER CRITICAL OF GRAND JURY USE
lead_paragraph: William Kunstler, a lawyer who frequently defends anti war demonstrators, said last night that the Federal Govern ment was using grand juries to harass Vietnam war dissenters.

headline: Softer Vietcong Stand Reported
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) —Representative Robert L. Leg gett, Democrat of California, said today Vietcong negotiators in Paris had promised him re cently that if a date were set for total withdrawal of United States forces, they would re lease all their American pris oners “before that date.”

headline: B‐52 Strikes Continue
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 9 (AP)— Ground fighting reportedly di minished in South Vietnam yes terday, but United States B‐52's continued their strikes in the northern part of the country and the Central Highlands, in Laos and in eastern Cambodia.

headline: Clifford Offers Forrnula For U.S. to Quit Warin '71
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 8—Clark M. Clifford, former Secretary of Defense, said tonight he had reason to believe that the United States could reach an agreement now with North Viet nam to end American involve ment in the Indochina war by Dec. 31 and obtain the release of the American prisoners of war within 30 days.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: TV: Hard Look at Vietnam Coverage.
lead_paragraph: “All About TV” has been a staple of WNYC‐TV's Chan nel 31 for the last two sea sons. As a UHF outlet the channel is somewhat off the narrow path of popular tele vision fare. As a forum for discussing controversial is sues, the program is quite definitely off that path.
author: By Joan J. O'Connor

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: A year ago last May, Rep resentative William M. Mc Culloch of Ohio, ranking Republican on the House Judiciary Committee, fell in his Washington apartment while trying to open a win dow. No complications were noted in a hospital checkup at the time, but last fall a small blood clot was found in his skull.
author: Albin Krebs

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: John F. Clark

headline: White House Suggests Clifford Is Playing Politics and Raising False Hopes With Proposal on Prisoners
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 9—The White House suggested today that Clark M. Clifford, former Secretary of Defense, and others were raising “false hopes” about American prison ers of war “for domestic polit ical purposes.”
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Mayday Leader Put Under Bail So He'll Appear Before Inquiry
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 9—A Fed eral grand jury believed to be investigating the March 1 bombing of the United States Capitol acted today to insure that an organizer of the May day protest in Washington would appear when it con vened here next Monday.
author: By Agis Salpukas Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: John Khanlian

headline: New Drive in South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON South Vietnam, Thursday, June 10 (AP)—Sai gon headquarters announced yesterday that 2,000 to 2,500 South Vietnamese infantrymen, rangers and armored cavalry man began a sweep Tuesday 25 miles south of Pleiku in the Central Highlands.

headline: VETERAN ACQUITTED IN JERSEY SLAYING
lead_paragraph: MAYS LANDING, N. J., June 9—Craig Jackson, a 22‐year‐old unemployed Vietnam war vet eran, was acquitted today in Atlantic County Criminal Court of the street shotgun slaying of Patrolman John P. Burke in Atlantic City.

headline: SAIGON OPENS COAST FOR OIL EXPLORATION
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 10 (AP)—Eco nomics Minister Pham Kim Ngoc announced today that 160,000‐square‐mile area off the coast of South Vietnam was now officially open for petroleum exploration and ex ploitation.

headline: $250,000 U.S.I.A. Movie on Vietnam, 3 Years in the Making, Being Shelved
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 9 — After three years of work and an outlay of nearly $250,000. the United States Information Agency is letting a major prop aganda film on the Vietnam war slip into oblivion.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Temple Service Disrupter Gets Suspended Sentence
lead_paragraph: Anne Rosen, 22 years old, pleaded guilty in Criminal Court yesterday to charges of disor derly conduct in connection with the disruption of services at Temple Emanu‐el on May 29, 1970.

headline: Goodell Warns Graduates Of ‘Simplistic’ Thinking
lead_paragraph: Former United States Sena tor Charles E. Goodell told 746 graduates at Staten Island Community College yesterday that the younger generation could not just “wave a banner and change the world.”

headline: U.S. Generals Shifted
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, June 9 (AP)—Lieut. Gen. Wel born G. Dolvin assumed com mand today of all American forces in the northern provinces of South Vietnam. He replaces Lieut. Gen. James W. Suther land Jr., who has been named chief of staff of the United States European Command.

headline: INVESTIGATION IS SET ON ANTIWAR OFFICER
lead_paragraph: LONDON. June 9 — The United States Air Force an nounced today it would con duct a formal investigation into the conduct of Capt. Thomas S. Culver, the legal officer who took part in an antiwar protest in London on May 31.

headline: Humphrey Says Nixon Shuns Politics on War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) — Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Min nesota, supported today President Nixon's conduct of the Vietnam war against charges by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, that Mr. Nixon was timing his policy to help win re‐election in 1972.

headline: 18 U. S. Concerns May Seek Saigon's Oil
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10—The Economics Ministry announced today that South Vietnam would open bidt this year for oil exploration on its continental shelf in the South China Sea.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Bunker to Consult in Capital
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10 (AP)—The United States Ambassador, Ellsworth Bunker, is to return to Wash ington Sunday reportedly for consultations on the possibility of speeding American troop withdrawals from Vietnam.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is fascinating that when a group of young people threaten unsuccess fully to tie up a city over their protest that thousands are being killed, the Administration and the public thunder that mass arrests are not only in evitable, but appropriate.

headline: Hanoi and Vietcong Give Assurances on P.O.W. Issue
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 10—The North Vietnamese and the Vietcong said today that if the United States would set a date for its withdrawal from Vietnam, they would discuss a full exchange of prisoners without relation to any other questions.
author: By John L. Hess Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: HATFIELD OPENS VIETNAM DEBATE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 10 — The Senate began debate today on the McGovern‐Hatfield amendment, which would re quire the withdrawal of all American forces from Vietnam by the end of this year.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Sergeant Convicted of Stealing Funds of Vietnam Army Clubs
lead_paragraph: REDSTONE ARSENAL, Ala., June 10 (AP)—M. Sgt. William Higdon was convicted today of stealing $7,200 in cigarette promotion funds and taking $723 in kickbacks while run ning Army clubs in Vietnam.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 10—In his life long study of the art of diplomacy, Sir Harold Nicholson reached the conclu sion that imprecision of language was one of the greatest barriers to success ful negotiation between nations, and this is proving to be true once more in the Paris talks on Vietnam.
author: By James Reston

headline: Ky is Reported Planning Race With the Aid of Minh
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10 — Supporters of Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky, whose chances of running for the Presidency appeared con siderably diminished by new electoral legislation last week, now say he will try to run any way.
author: By Craig It Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. War Deaths, 19 for Week, At Lowest Level Since Late ‘65
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10—United States battle field deaths last week dropped to the lowest point since the start of the big American troop buildup in Vietnam in late 1965.

headline: SON OF MTARTHY FREE IN CAPITAL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 10 — Michael McCarthy, the 20‐ year‐old son of former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, was set free today after District of Columbia prosecutors said they were unable to produce evi dence to support a charge of disorderly conduct against him.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 11—All over Eng land this week children are coming home from school asking their parents for a few pence to give for relief of the East Pakistan refugees. In the newspapers the refugee tragedy has been the dominant story for many days; the largest‐circulation tabloid has spread a relief appeal over page one. The House of Commons has been de bating how Britain can do more to help.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The dying of Congressional Medal of Honor winner Dwight Johnson on the floor of a grocery store has the impact of a modern tragedy. Jon Nord heimer's perceptive report of May 26 portrays Sergeant Johnson's feelings of apathy and estrangement, demorali zation by unemployment, a sense of being exploited by the Army even while hospitalized. His haunting fan tasies about being shot at point‐blank range were finally lived out in his violent death.

headline: Referendum on War Voted
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N. H., June 11 (AP) —The New Hampshire Senate has approved and sent to the House a resolution that provides for a state referen (him on the Vietnam war at the state's Presidential primary next March.

headline: Americans Are Barred From Spy Raids in Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 11— The Nixon Administration has decided that Americans will no longer be permitted to enter southern Laos as leaders of teams keeping watch on enemy movements along the Ho Chi Minh Trail network.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Thang Re‐elected in Hanoi
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Saturday, June 12, (Reuters)—Ton Duc Thang has been re‐elected President of North Vietnam, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported last night, in a dispatch from Hanoi.

headline: Harriman Asserts Nixon Delays Pullout to Save Saigon Regime
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 11 — W. Averell Harriman, former United States representative at the Vietnam peace talks in Paris, said today that the Ad ministration was unwilling to discuss a date for the with drawal of American troops from Vietnam because “it is quite clear” that the President “wants to see the present Gov ernment in Saigon maintained.”
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM, June 11 (UPI) —Lieutenant Vequist said in an interview here yesterday that he had left the armed forces because “I just felt in my con science that I could not serve in Vietnam; I could not go along with the idea of killing people who had not really harmed American citizens.”

headline: Cambodia May Seek Aid
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, June 11 (Reu ters)—Two Cambodian generals flew to Saigon for talks with South Vietnamese military lead ers today as fighting just out side Pnompenh reached the heaviest level of the 15‐month old war.

headline: NGUYEN VAN TUOI
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 11 (UPI) — Nguyen Van Tuoi, publisher of the Vietnam Guardian, one of Saigon's three English‐language daily newspapers, died today after two‐week illness. He was 48 years old.

headline: Sergeant Given Discharge And a Fine for Kickbacks
lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., June 11 (UPI)—M. Sgt. William E. Hig don has been sentenced to a dishonorable discharge and fined $25,000 by a military jury that convicted him of accepting kickbacks and misappropriating funds while operating an en listed men's club in Vietnam.

headline: AIR FORCE OPENS OFFICER'S HEARING
lead_paragraph: LAKENHEATH, England, June 11 — The United States Air Force today opened an official public investigation of Capt. Thomas S. Culver, a legal offi cer involved in antiwar activ ities.

headline: U.S. TROOPS WAGE FIVE‐HOUR BATTLE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 11 (AP) — An American armored column patrolling the southern edge of the demilitar ized zone yesterday ran into a North Vietnamese force, touch ing off a five‐hour battle, the United States command report ed today.

headline: General, Censured Over Mylai Killings, Will Retire June 30
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) —An Army general censured for allegedly failing to meet the required standards of per formance in investigating the Mylai massacre will retire June 30.

headline: Saigon Announces Changes in Cabinet
