lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, June 12 — President Nguyen Van Thieu, moving to strengthen his Government's position before the legislative and presidential elections here later this year, today made the first important changes in his Cabinet since its formation in September, 1969.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Memo From the Joint Chiefs On September's Covert Raids
lead_paragraph: Memorandum from Maj. Gen. Rotten H. Anthis, an Air Force aide the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to Assistant Secretary of State Bundy and Assistant Secretary of Defense McNaughton, Aug. 27, 1964. The subject of the memo randum was given as “OPLAN 34A—September Schedule.”

headline: Summary of Taylor's Report Sent to McNamara by Joint Chiefs.
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from Summary of Ambassador Taylor's first mission report from Saigon, on Aug. 10, 1984, as transmitted on Aug. 14 by Col. A. R. Brownfield, acting special assistant to the Joint Chiefs of Staff for counterinsurgency and special activities, to Secretary McNamara, through Col. Alfred J. F. Moody, the Secretary's military assistant. Colonel Brownfield's covering memorandum said this summary had also been supplied to Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, and to Deputy Secretary of Defense Cyrus R. Vance, their appearance before the House Armed Services Conunittee on Aug. 18.

headline: Thieu Said to Reconsider Curb on Rival Candidates
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 12—After reshuffling his Cab inet to strengthen his position before the legislative and presi dential elections later this year, President Nguyen. Van Thieu appears to be having second thoughts about, a measure he supported to limit the number of candidates for the presidency.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Cable From President to Lodge On Escalation Contingencies
lead_paragraph: Cablegram from President Johnson to Henry Cabot Lodge, United States Ambassador in Saigon, March 20, 1964.

headline: State Department Aide's Report On Actions Taken After Tonkin
lead_paragraph: Part VIII, “Immediate Actions in the Period Prior to Decision,” of outline for Assistant Secretary Bundy, Nov. 7, 1964. Markings indicate that was drafted by Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Marshall Green.

headline: MINISTERS REPORT ‘CAREER STRESS’
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY, June 12— Most Protestant ministers have been victims of “severe career stress” at some point in their lives, much of it generated by problems with their congrega tions, according to a survey made public here last night.
author: By George Dugan Special to The New York Times

headline: Cable From Taylor Warning On the ‘March North’ Campaign
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from cablegram from Ambassador Taylor in Saigon to the State Department, July 25, 1964.

headline: U.S. Order for Preparations For Some Retaliatory Action
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from National Security Action Memorandum 288, “U.S. Objectives in South Vietnam,” March 17, 1964, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. The words in brackets are the study's. The paragraph in italics is the paraphrase by a writer of the study.

headline: Wolff Proposes Plan to Aid Vietnam Veterans on Jobs, Hospitalization and Drug Care
lead_paragraph: MINEOLA, L. I., June 12— Representative Lester L. Wolff has embarked on a se ries of programs to aid the plight of Long Island vet erans of the war in Vietnam in the areas of employment, hospitalization and drug ad diction.
author: By Roy R. Silver Special to The New York Times

headline: MODERN PENTATHLON TO AIR FORCE'S DRUM
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 12 (AP)—Capt. Loren Drum, a Vietnam veteran from Omaha, captured first place in the 1971 Modern Pentathlon trials at the end of eight days today.

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: Reporting on a private luncheon meeting between Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky and Ellsworth Bunker, the American Ambassador to for Vietnam, a spokesman for Mr. Ky said last week the two men had discussed a possible situation “that could be very embarrassing for the United States.” Under a law pushed through the National Assembly the week before, President Nguyen Van Thieu could turn out to be the only Presidential can didate running in the elec tions scheduled for Oct. 3.

headline: National Notes
lead_paragraph: Among Hollywood movie di rectors, the name John Ford ranks near the top. “The Grapes of Wrath,” “How Green Was My Valley,” “Stagecoach” and a host of high‐level westerns have borne his stamp.

headline: Vietnam Archive: Pentagon Study Traces 3 Decades of Growing U. S. Involvement
lead_paragraph: A massive study of how the United States went to war in Indochina, con ducted by the Pentagon three years ago, demonstrates that four administrations progrestively developed a sense of com mitment to a non‐Communist Vietnam, a readiness to fight the North to pro tect the South, and an ultimate frustra tion with this effort—to a much greater extent than their public statements ac knowledged at the time.
author: By Neil Sheehan

headline: The Covert War
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon papers disclose that in this phase the United States had been mounting clandestine military attacks against North Vietnam and planning to obtain a Congressional resolution that the Administration regarded as the equivalent of a declaration of war. The papers make it clear that these far reaching measures were not improvised in the heat of the Tonkin crisis.

headline: Highlights of Tonkin Period
lead_paragraph: Here, in chronological sequence, are highlights of the period covered in this article:

headline: 150 Protest at Coast Ball Honoring Agnew and Hope
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 12 (AP)—Peace demonstrators cursed, spit and kicked at auto mobiles carrying guests to an Army Ball, tonight honoring Vice President. Agnew and Bob Hope.

headline: Enemy Drive Is Said to Peril South Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 12 (AP)‐A new North Vietnamese drive threatened today to cut across southern Laos and give enemy forces control of more major road and river supply routes, reports from the Laotian capital.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The May 31 letter by Max Gordon excoriates President Nixon for his policies in Vietnam. While his harsh comments might have been emotion ally satisfying, they were characterized by distortions and specious reasoning.

headline: NIXON CRITICIZED AS MAYORS MEET
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, June 12 — President Nixon's foreign and domestic policies were sharply criticized and at times de fended today in a number of resolutions introduced at the opening session of the 38th annual United States. Confer ence of Mayors.
author: By Martin Tolchin Special to The New York Times

headline: McNamara Report to Johnson On the Situation in Saigon in ‘63
lead_paragraph: Following are the texts of key documents accompanying the Pentagon's study of the Vietnam war, for the period December, 1963, through the Tonkin Gulf incident in August, 1964, and its aftermath. Except where excerpting is specified, the documents are printed verbatim, with only unmistakable typographical errors corrected.
author: SPECIAL TO THE NEW YORK TIMES

headline: The Vietnam Elections
lead_paragraph: South Vietnam's approaching elections, for the Na tional Assembly in August and the presidency in October, pose critical problems for the United States.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 12—The official documents on the origins and develop ment of America's involvement in the Vietnam war are now being quietly circulated in Washington. They have not been released or “leaked” by the Nixon Administration, but they are now in the hands of some Congress men and Presidential candidates, and they are now being published by The New York Times.
author: By James Reston

headline: ‘64 McNamara Report on Steps To Change the Trend of the War
lead_paragraph: We seek an independent non‐Com munist South Vietnam. We do not re quire that it serve as a Western base or as a member of a Western Alliance. Vietnam must be free, however, to accept outside assistance as required to maintain its security. This assistance should be able to take the form not only of economic and social pressures but also police and military help to root out and control insurgent elements.

headline: Vast Review of War Took a Year

Mc Namara commissioned a major study of how and why the Unit ed States had become so deeply involved in Vietnam.

A summary was cabled to the Pacific command and the embassies in Saigon and Vientiane on Aug. 14 with requests for comments. According to the Pentagon study, the full draft was edited in the office of Assistant Secretary of Defense John T. McNaughton. Words that were deleted at that time are shown below in double parentheses; words that were inserted at that time are shown in italics. Boldface type denotes underlining in the original document. Also, according to the McNaughton office's editing, the second paragraph, beginning “We have agreed …,” was to be moved below, to follow the heading “Phase One—‘Military Silence’ (through August).”

headline: Letters to the Editor

Mr. Wicker notes that the public official who resists “political pressure” and refuses to take the “easy political course” is honored as a statesman.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Of all the political and diplomatic Brah mins that dot the Washington landscape—the former Cabinet members and retired ambas sadors—none carries a more im pressive set of credentials than Clark McAdams Clifford.

headline: Pacific Commander's Evaluation Of Washington's Action. Scenario
lead_paragraph: 2. Recent U.S. military actions in Laos and North Vietnam demonstrated our intent to move toward our objectives. Our operations and progress in Laos constitute one step along the route. Our directness and rapidity of reaction, in bombing North Vietnamese installations and deploying U.S. combat forces to Southeast Asia were others. Each step played a part. Their effect was to in terrupt the continually improving Com munist posture, catch the imagination of the Southeast Asian peoples, provide some lift to morale, however temporary, and force CHICOM/DRV assessment or reassessment of U.S. intentions. But these were only steps along the way. What we have not done and must do is make plain to Hanoi and Peiping the cost of pursuing their current objectives and impeding ours. An essential element of our military action in this course is to proceed in the development of our physical readiness posture: deploying troops, ships, aircraft, and logistic re sources in a manner which accords a maximum freedom of action. This is the thrust we should continue to pursue, one which is intended to provide more than one feasible course for considera tion as the changed and changing South east Asian situation develops. Remarks in the paragraphs which follow are sub mitted in light of this assessment and with the view that pressures against the other side once instituted should not be relaxed by any actions or lack of them which would destroy the bene fits of the rewarding steps previously taken in Laos and North Vietnam.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Perhaps the rationalization most fre quently advanced to explain our par ticipation in the immoral and senseless Vietnam war is that we are fighting to establish the right of the local pop ulation freely to elect a government of its own choosing. Passing over the fact that a logical extension of this doctrine would seem to warrant our intervention in Greece, Portugal and many other countries, it is surely a bitter irony, that the election law just adopted in Saigon will doubtless have the desired effect of insuring that President Thieu will be unopposed in his bid for re‐election. The silence from Washington Is practically deaf ening.

headline: North Vietnamese Re‐elect President And Other Leaders
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, June 12 (Reu ters)—North Vietnam's new Na tional Assembly has re‐elected almost all the nation's top lead ers, including its 83‐year‐old President, Ton Duc Thang.

headline: U.S. Plans to Increase Aid to Foreign Police Forces to Help Fight Subversion
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 13—The United States plans to increase Its assistance to police forces In 25 countries in Southeast Asia, Latin America and Africa to help them deal with guerril las and subversion.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Rusk Cable to Embassy in Laos On Search and Rescue Flights
Plan of Action Attributed To McNaughton at Pentagon
lead_paragraph: I. Analysis of the present situation. The situation in South Vietnam is de teriorating. Even before the government sank into confusion last week, the course of the war in South Vietnam had been downward, with Viet Cong incidents in creasing in number and intensity and military actions becoming larger and more successful, and with less and less territory meaningfully under the control of the government. Successful ambushes had demonstrated an unwillingness of the population even in what were thought to be pacified areas to run the risk of informing on the Viet Cong. War weariness was apparent. The crisis of the end of August—especially since the competing forces have left the govern ment largely “faceless” and have dam aged the government's ability to manage the pacification program—promises to lead to further and more rapid deteriora tion. The objective of the United States is to reverse the present down ward trend. Failing that, the alternative objective is to emerge from the situa tion with as good an image as possible in US, allied and enemy eyes.

headline: Fighting Rages for 5½ Hours At Besieged Vietnamese Base
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, June 14 (Reuters)— Fighting raged for five and a half hours yesterday near a be sieged South Vietnamese artil lery outpost in the Central Highlands, a South Vietnamese military spokesman said today.

headline: Some Key Figures in the Pentagon Narrative: Who They Are and Where They Are Now
lead_paragraph: Special assistant to Presidents Ken nedy and Johnson for national security affairs, 1961–66 … since 1966, presi dent of the Ford Foundation. Born Bos ton March 30, 1919 … graduated from Yale, 1940, majoring in classics and mathematics … ran as a Repub lican for seat on Boston City Council, 1941 … served as aide to Adm. Alan G. Kirk, World War II … foreign policy adviser to Thomas E. Dewey, Re publican Presidential candidate,.1948 joined Harvard faculty, 1949 … be came dean of Faculty of Arts and Sci ences, 1953 … named by President Kennedy to White House post … often described as principal architect of U.S. Vietnam policy … was recalled briefly by President Johnson during the Arab Israeli crisis in summer of 1967 … Often seen as a potential Secretary of State … just as visible — and con troversial — as foundation head as when directing foreign policy from White House basement office … now lives in New York.

headline: Norwalk Joins in Honoring Quiet Boy Who Died a Hero

author: By Roy R. Silver Special to The New York Times

headline: Taylor's Briefing of Key Officials On Situation in November, ’64
lead_paragraph: After a year of changing and inef fective government, the counter‐insur gency program country‐wide is bogged down and will require heroic treatment to assure revival. Even in the Saigon area, in spite of the planning and the special treatment accorded the Hop Tac plan, this area also is lagging. The northern provinces of South Viet‐Nam which a year ago were considered al most free of Viet‐Cong are now in deep trouble. In the Quang Ngai‐Binh Dinh area, the gains of the Viet‐Cong have been so serious that once more we are threatened with a partition of the country by a Viet‐Cong salient driven to the sea. The pressure on this area has been accompanied by continuous sabotage of the railroad and of High way 1 which in combination threaten an economic strangulation of northern provinces.

headline: Account of Taylor's Meeting With Saigon Generals on Unrest
lead_paragraph: … AMBASSADOR TAYLOR: Do all of you understand English? (Vietnamese officers indicated they did, although the understanding of General Thi was known to be weak.) I told you all clearly at General Westmoreland's dinner we Americans were tired of coups. Appar ently I Wasted my words. Maybe this is because something is wrong with my French because you evidently didn't un derstand. I made it clear that all the military plans which I know you would like to carry out are dependent on gov ernmental stability. Now you have made a real mess. We cannot carry you for ever if you do things like this. Who speaks for this group? Do you have a spokesman?

headline: ‘Cautiousand Equivoce’

Two analysts of this period, in fact, differ in their characterization of his deci sion at the two‐and‐a‐half‐hour White House meeting on Dec. 1, 1964, a month after the election, when the bombing plan was presented to him.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD

In the face of increasing American self‐doubt, they have held to their belief in the strength of our society and in our willingness to bear responsibilities abroad.

headline: Vietnam Archive: A Consensus to Bomb Developed Before ’64 Election, Study Says
lead_paragraph: The Johnson Administration reached a “general consensus” at a White House strategy meeting on Sept. 7, 1964, that air attacks against North Vietnam would probably have to be launched, a Pentagon study of the Vietnam war states. It was expected that “these oper ations would begin early in the new year.”
author: By Neil Sheehan

headline: Screen: Nicholson's 'Drive, He Said':Movie Marks Actor's Debut as Director Tale of College Athlete Opens at Tower East
lead_paragraph: "Drive, He Said," loosely adapted by Jeremy Larner and Jack Nicholson from Larner's 1964 Delta Prize novel, and directed by Nicholson (his directorial debut), comes close to being the sort of movie about the anxieties and dilemmas of the sixties that no one ever made in the sixties—which were constantly confused with the more innocent fifties. It is not a great film, but it is an often intelligent one, and it is so much better than all of the rest of the campus junk Hollywood has manufactured in the last couple of years that it can be indulged its sentimental conventions.Specifically, it's about a star college athlete, Hector Bloom, to whom basketball is what boxing is to Private Prewitt what playwriting maybe to Tennessee Williams and what risking an arm or a leg or a life probably is to Peter Gimbel. Like some forms of art, it is, simultaneously, a heightened response to the world, a mystical retreat from it, and a practical way of getting along in it.In the course of his senior year, Hector begins to feel, in his word, disconnected. The old game doesn't quite mean what it once did. He is more than a little surprised to find that he is in love with Olive, the professor's wife with whom he's been having an affair, and he is shocked when the joy of his discovery isn't shared by Olive, who is not so simply pregnant.Hector admires and envies the campus radicals, who are so committed to a cause that they can interrupt a basketball game for an anti-Vietnam demonstration, staged as guerrilla theater. He himself hasn't the faintest idea where he is going or why. When a pro ball club asks him to sign, he demands only that the club improve the quality of the frankfurters it sells to the public, and cut the price from 50c to a quarter.In fact, Hector is so disconnected—at least in terms of the character as written—that it comes as a major surprise, late in the film, to learn that he is a Greek major. This bit of information, which I assume is presented seriously, is as unsettling as learning that someone you thought you knew extremely well is, in reality, one-half of a pair of twins. It means that an important (or, at the least, a time-consuming) part of Hector's life has been kept secret.Also fairly secret is Hector's state of mind, though William Tepper, a tall, dark-haired young man who may or may not have studied the collected works of Dustin Hoffman, defines well enough Hector's individual attitudes of frustration, anger and what might be called romantic campus lassitude. A reading of Larner's novel fills in a lot of these gaps, but otherwise the novel might mislead the filmgoer into expecting satiric fantasy (which the movie never achieves), having to do with unnamed wars (not in Vietnam), with a lot of bizarre characters who might have been created by Waugh, and with middle-class American-Jewish intellectual and social life.One result of this secrecy—perhaps simplification is a better terms—is that most of the other characters in the film, just because they are the supporting characters in the film as well as in Hector's life, are more thoroughly and quickly defined, and thus more vivid and appealing than Hector. I especially liked Karen Black as the besieged Olive, a woman who once might have ben fated to be misunderstood and badly used by men, but who finally liberates herself; Robert Towne, as her husband, who would prefer to dry his beard with an electric comb than wory about cuckoldry; Bruce Dern, as the intensely clean-living coach, and Michael Margotta, who looks like a young Elisha Cook Jr., as Hector's radical roommate whose ultimate act of survival provides the film with its obligatory, if shopworn, irony.Most importantly, al of the film's characters, and all of the performances, are touched with the kind of unexpected sensibility and decency that are rare in most films of this genre. It's a quality that I associate with the performances Nicholson himself gave in both "Easy Rider" and "Five Easy Pieces." Nicholson not only is good with actors, but he also chooses to avoid most of the visual (and aural) clichés of the day, and when he does indulge himself—as in the fine basketballl sequences—they no longer seem clichés since the rhythm of the sport more or less demands the treatment. I wish I could report that Hector was as interesting as the film that surrounds him.
author: By Vincent Canby

headline: Washington: For the Record
lead_paragraph: THE PRESIDENT Activities. The President had a morning meeting with top diplomatic ambassadors, Secretary of State William P. Rogers, Treasury Secretary John B. Connally Jr., H.E.W. Secretary Elliot L. Richardson and Attorney General John N. Mitchell to discuss the narcotics problem in Vietnam and the United States. The President participated in swearing‐in ceremonies for Mrs. Jayne Baker Spain as a vice chairman of the Civil Service Commission. Later in the afternoon the President saw the United States Ambassador to West Germany, Kenneth Rush, and then he met with railroad union leaders. The President also met with his top economic advisers.

headline: Letter From Rostow Favoring Commitment of Troops by U.S.
lead_paragraph: Following on our conversation of last night I am concerned that too much thought is being given to the actual damage we do in the North, not enough thought to the signal we wish to send.

headline: New Warnings of Failure
lead_paragraph: Before the opening of the air war in the spring warnings were sounded high in the Administration that it would not succeed. Now there were warnings that a ground war in the South might prove fruitless. The warnings came not only from Under Secretary of State George W. Ball, long known as a dissenter on Vietnam, but also from John A. McCone, Director of Central Intelligence, who felt the actions planned were not strong enough.

headline: McNamara's Memo on July 20, 1965, On Increasing Allied Ground Force
lead_paragraph: In a memorandum to the President drafted on 1 July and then revised on 20 July, immediately following his return from a week‐long visit to Vietnam, he recommended an immediate decision to increase the U.S.‐Third Country presence from the current 16 maneuver battalions (15 U.S., one Australian), and a change in the mission of these forces from one of providing support and reinforcement for the ARVN to one which soon became known as “search and destroy”—as McNamara put it, they were “by aggressive exploitation of superior military forces... to gain and hold the initiative... pressing the fight against VC‐DRV main force units in South Vietnam to run them to ground and destroy them.”. . .

headline: I. Introductory
lead_paragraph: We believe that the best available way of increasing our chance of success in Vietnam is the development and execution of a policy of sustained reprisal against North Vietnam—a policy in which air and naval action against the North is justified by and related to the whole Viet Cong campaign of violence and terror in the South.

headline: George Ball Memo for Johnson On ‘A Compromise Solution’

author: By Philip H. Dougherty

headline: Vietnam Archive: Study Tells How Johnson Secretly Opened Way to Ground Combat
lead_paragraph: President Johnson decided on April 1 1965 to use American ground troops for offensive action in South Vietnam because the Administration had discovered that its long‐planned bombing of North Vietnam—which had just begun—was not going to stave off collapse in the South, the Pentagon's study of the Vietnam war discloses, He ordered that the decision be kept secret.
author: By Neil Sheehan

headline: Nixon Confers With Envoys and Top Aides on Curbing Drug Flow
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 14—President Nixon summoned six United States ambassadors and Administration officials to the White House today to discuss ways of curbing the flow of narcotics into the United States.

headline: Prime Minister Wilson's Warning To Johnson on Petroleum Raids
lead_paragraph: I was most grateful to you for asking Bob McNamara to arrange the very full briefing about the two oil targets near Hanoi and Haiphong that Col. Rogers gave me yesterday...

headline: COURT STEP LIKELY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 14—Attorney General John N. Mitchell asked The New York Times this evening to refrain from further publication of documents drawn from a Pentagon study of the Vietnam war on the ground that such disclosures would cause “irreparable injury to the defense interests of the United States.”
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It was reassuring to see that Hanson W. Baldwin's Op‐Ed article (May 31) gave serious consideration to the question of civilian casualties in South Vietnam. For too many years it has been difficult to get this kind of attention focused on the plight of people caught in the war.

headline: Draft by William Bundy On Results of Policy in ‘65
lead_paragraph: This memorandum examines possible developments and problems if the US pursues the following policy with respect to South Viet‐Nam:

headline: Goldwater Says He Knew of War Plan
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 14—Senator Barry Goldwater, the Republican Presidential candidate in 1964, said today that he had known one month before the clashes in the Gulf of Tonkin that President Johnson was planning to widen the war in Vietnam.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Let The Eat Lead
lead_paragraph: Lead poisoning is a small thing, little horror compared to the Vietnam war, or the fact that parts of Brownsville look like Laos, or the moon.
author: By Sack Newfield

headline: Medina Faces Judge Today
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., June 15 (AP) — Capt. Ernest L. Medina, charged with assault and murder of 102 civilians during the Mylai raid, will go before an Army judge here tomorrow for his first pretrial hearing.

headline: The Endless Tragedy
lead_paragraph: For the first time in the history of the Republic, the Attorney General of the United States has tried to suppress documents he hasn't read about a war that hasn't been declared. This is one of the final ironies of this tragic Vietnam war, but it won't work for long.
author: By James Reston

headline: Addiction in Vietnam Spurs Nixon and Congress to Take Drastic New Steps
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15—Growing evidence of widespread drug addiction among Vietnam servicemen and veterans appears to have been the chief factor that galvanized the President and Congress into action on all the nation's narcotics problems. Congress is showing eagerness to provide laws and money as the President proposes to set up new machinery to deal with the problem. President Nixon is expected to announce this week the appointment of Dr. Jerome H. Jaffe, the 37‐year‐old head of the Illinois Drug Rehabilitation System as his adviser. Mr. Nixon is also expected to create a new, overall Federal agency to combat drug abuse, of which Dr. Jaffe may be the director.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: The House and the War
lead_paragraph: “I have been a member of the House since January 1965, and in all that time I have never once had an opportunity to vote directly on the most important issue before the country—the Vietnam War.”

headline: Times's Vietnam Series Circulating in Pentagon
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15—The first three installment of The New: York Times series on the Defense Department's secret study on Vietnam have been circulating in the Pentagon after having been routinely reproduced in an internal news, publication.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: If the “Pentagon Study” of the Vietnam war is to be believed—and sadly I think’ there is more there to believe than to disbelieve—it is evident that the American people have been lied to and distrusted by their own leaders and representatives.

headline: Saigon Says Paratroops Break 3‐Week Siege of Artillery Base
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15 (Reuters)—South Vietnamese paratroops reportedly broke a three‐week enemy siege of a Government artillery outpost in the Central Highlands today after capturing a huge enemy complex just outside the perimeter wire.

headline: The Vietnam Documents.
lead_paragraph: In an unprecedented example of censorship, the Attorney General of the United States has temporarily succeeded in preventing The New York Times from continuing to publish documentary and other material taken from a secret Pentagon study of the decisions affecting American participation in the Vietnam War.

headline: Moscow Terms Documents Record of Official Duplicity
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, June 15 (AP)—The Soviet press agency Tass said today that the secret Defense Department documents published by The New York Times were a “record of official duplicity.”

headline: Humphrey Expresses Surprise
lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 15 (AP)—Senator. Hubert H. Humphrey, who was President Johnson's Vice President, said today that the secret Pentagon study on Vietnam published by The New York Times was “never brought to my attention.”

headline: Excerpts From Rogers News Conference
lead_paragraph: Q. Mr. Secretary, Mr. [Clark M.] Clifford's proposal was rejected by Mr. [Ronald L.] Ziegler at the White House on the grounds that it sets too precipitous a deadline that the South Vietnamese at that stage would not be in a position to defend themselves. When will the Administration think the South Vietnamese will be in such a position and, secondly, does Mr. Ziegler's answer imply the opposition of the Administration to setting a date certain in return for the release of the prisoners is a matter of timing or principle?

headline: Medal of Honor Presented To Seven at White House
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) —President Nixon conferred the Medal of Honor on seven Vietnam combat veterans at private White House ceremony today.

headline: Advisory Team Cutback
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15 (AP) — The United States command announced today a cutback in the system of American advisory teams for South Vietnamese army units.

headline: NIXON TO ASK AID FOR G.I. ADDICTS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15—President Nixon's new antinarcotics program, scheduled to be unveiled at the White House Thursday, will include proposal that servicemen who have become addicted to drugs in Vietnam be requested to undergo three weeks of mandatory treatment at West Coast rehabilitation centers, informed Government sources disclosed today.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Texts of Government Papers in Complaint Against The Times arid judge's Order
lead_paragraph: Complaint

headline: SENATE STUDY SET
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15—Amid continuing Administration criticism of the publication by The New York Times of data from a secret Pentagon study on Vietnam, Senator Mike Mansfield said a Senate committee would hold public hearings on how the United States had become involved in the war.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: U. S. Plans Ways to Bolster Saigon for ‘72 Enemy Push
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15—The Nixon Administration is engaged in a broad policy review aimed at determining courses of action that might improve South Vietnam's ability to withstand military assaults next year, after most American forces have been withdrawn.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Rogers Bars the Abandonment Of U.S. Goals to Free Captives
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15—Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States could not abandon its “national objectives” in Vietnam to meet the “ransom” being demanded by North Vietnam for the release of American prisoners of war.
author: By Terence Smite Special to The New York Times

headline: Salinger Expresses Suspicion
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 15—Pierre Salinger, the former press secretary. to President Kennedy, expressed his suspicion tonight that the Nixon Administration was responsible for the leak of a secret study on the Vietnam war to The New York Times.

headline: ARGUMENT FRIDAY
lead_paragraph: United States District Judge Murray I. Gurfein yesterday ordered The New York Times to halt publication of material from a secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war for four days. Argument on publication thereafter will be heard Friday.
author: By Fred P. Graham

headline: U.S ‘Conned’ Australia On Troops, Laborite Says
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, June 17—Publication by The New York Times of secret papers on the Vietnam war has caused a controversy here on the Australian involvement in the conflict.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It would be the height of folly and the path of dishonor for the United States to withdraw completely from Vietnam by Dec. 31 of this year. The inescapable reality in the formulation of American policy is that the American nation has made a solemn commitment, consecrated by the lives of nearly 50,000 of our dead, to the right of the South Vietnamese people freely to determine their own future.

headline: Senate Roll‐Call Vote On Vietnam Deadline
Senate, 55 to 42, Defeats McGovern‐Hatfield Plan
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 16—The Senate, in a victory for the Nixon Administration's Vietnam policies, refused twice today to set a deadline for the withdrawal of American forces, from Indochina.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Misleading, Canada Says
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, June 16—Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, Mitchell W. Sharp, complained today to the United States Ambassador, Adolph W. Schmidt, that the account in the Pentagon papers published by The Times of Canada's role as an intermediary between Washington and Hanoi was misleading.

headline: European Allies Make No Complaints
lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 16—America's European allies say that they have made no complaints to the State Department and asked no questions about the ?? by The New York Times of documents on the Vietnam war.
author: By Anthony Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: REPORTS SAY TEXTS MIGHT HELP SOVIET
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 16—The Defense Department declined to comment tonight on anonymous reports that Government officials feared that the Soviet Union could break United States Codes of the 1960's by studying the texts of diplomatic cables published by The New York Times.

headline: Opponents of War In Congress Decry U.S. Suit on Study
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 16—Congressional opponents of the war in Indochina criticized the Nixon Administration today for having sought and obtained a court order temporarily preventing The New York Times from publishing further material from a secret Pentagon study on Vietnam.
author: By David E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: The Government has alleged that The New York Times, in publishing the Defense Department's own record of the nation's involvement in Vietnam, “has prejudiced the interests of the United States and the publication of additional excerpts... would further prejudice the defense interests of the United States and result in irreparable injury to the United States.” That is a travesty of fact and common sense.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Medina Judge to Sift Influence Charges
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., June 16 (UPI) — A military judge sidetracked today the pretrial hearing of Capt. Ernest L. Medina on charges of mass murder at Mylai and ordered a separate hearing on whether improper command influence had been exerted in bringing him to trial.

headline: MAYORS DEMAND PULLOUT BY 1972
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, June 16—The United States Conference of Mayors, by a 54‐to‐49 vote urged President Nixon today to pull all United States troops out of Vietnam by Dec. 31.
author: By John Herbers Special to The New York Times

headline: World Press Overwhelmingly Supports Publication of Documentation on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Editorials in the press here and abroad have overwhelmingly supported the publication by The New York Times of a series of secret documents dealing with the origins of the United States involvement in the Indochina War.

headline: Fulbright Sees ‘Deception’
lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 16—Senator Fulbright said tonight that publication of the documented Vietnam war history would help restore the American constitutional balance.

headline: Former Saigon Leader Recalls Ouster
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 16—Gen. Nguyen Khanh, who led the Government of South Vietnam and was commander of its armed forces in 1964, said here today that he was in constant conflict during that period with the United States Ambassador, Maxwell D. Taylor.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Laird Refused ’69 Fulbright Request For the Pentagon Study on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 16—Eighteen months ago, in a letter to Senator J. W. Fulbright, the Secretary of Defense, Melvin R. Laird, described a secret Pentagon study of American involvement in Vietnam as a “compilation of raw materials to be used at some unspecified, but distant, future date.”
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Reactions Range From Support to a Charge of ‘Near Treason’
lead_paragraph: Reactions ranging from commendation to a charge of near treason were issued by a variety of organizations yesterday in the controversy over publication by The New York Times of material from a secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war.

headline: Newley's 'Summertree' Opens:Hume and Yafa Work Revisits the 40's Death of a Serviceman Fixes the Action
lead_paragraph: Anybody old enough can remember, and anybody not old enough may imagine, the mood of sentiment about the land and the ordinary people and the quality of tree-shaded life in middle-America that gripped the popular arts, and especially the movies, during and for a few years after World War II. The mood passes—for a good many reasons—by the early 1950's, but a certain nostalgia for it remains. That nostalgia has been felt in several movies recently—movies that mean to recreate the 1940's—and it now appears brought up to date in Anthony Newley's "Summertree," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters and which attempts indicting the barbarities of Vietnam in terms of decent emotional strategies developed to illustrate life on the home front 30 years ago.I never saw the successful Ron Cowen play upon which "Summertree" is based, but I gather there have been a lot of changes—mostly directed toward "relevance" and a slight juicing up of the action. There is a new character, a little black boy (Kirk Callaway), who speaks for separatism. And the girl friend (Brenda Vaccaro) is now a somewhat older woman who already has a husband—in Vietnam. But the boy (Michael Douglas) with each toss of his rugged head, each glance from his friendly eyes, bespeaks Young America. And the gruff dad (Jack Warden) who nervously loves his son and finally betrays him into war, and mom who cares and puts on the coffee — they are an older America that appropriately lives for the young. Barbara Bel Geddes plays mom, and one closed-mouth smile of hers is surely worth 350 apple pies cooling in the kitchen window.The central image of the summertree itself — a backyard retreat where the boy goes to dream his life into being—survives in rather ridiculous ways: especially in a bit of tinkly music, and a worm-eaten leaf pattern superimposed on the screen over his first night of lovemaking with the girl friend. And his death, which is in fact the reason for the drama, is there also, as a final bitter irony of the war that the movie, not too stupidly, admits wholly through the medium of the television screen."Summertree" is a bad movie, but its badness proceeds not from its intentions, which seem honorable, or from its stylistic analogies to past modes, which in different hands could have been interesting. The badness exists, rather, moment by moment, in the insufficiency of each acted scene, in the niggling insecurity of Newley's camera, in the improverishment of each evocation of a quality of life—from the boy's dull guitar playing, which is supposed to be great, to the father's love of hunting, which should recreate the landscape, but only signifies a thoughtless and cruel pastime.Nobody's performance quite works in "Summertree," but it is possible at least to respect Jack Warden's tense privacies and Michael Douglas's restraint in projecting a youthful goodwill without either petulance or excessive charm. Brenda Vaccaro is reasonable off-type casting, but she does not seem resourceful enough even to explore the limits of this small, appealingly pathetic role.
author: By Roger Greenspun

headline: A HEARING TODAY
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department asked United States District Judge Murray I. Gurfein yesterday to order The New York Times to turn over for the Government's inspection the secret Pentagon study from which its Vietnam series has been drawn.
author: By Fred P. Graham

headline: BALL SAYS DISSENT WAS ENCOURAGED
lead_paragraph: MADRID, June, 16 —Former Under Secretary of State George W. Ball said today that his opposition, in the mid‐1960's, to the increasing United States military commitment in Vietnam had been welcomed and encouraged by then President, Lyndon B. Johnson.

headline: Troops Sweep Saigon Region, Preparing for Parade Saturday
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 17 (AP)—More than 10,000 South Vietnamese troops are reported conducting a security sweep around Saigon to protect a parade Saturday in honor of Armed Forces Day.

headline: Ceausescu, in Hanoi, Vows Rumanian Aid Till ‘Victory’
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, June 16 (Agence France‐Presse)—President Nicolae Ceaucescu of Rumania pledged to aid North Vietnam until final victory” when he arrived here from North Korea yesterday on an official visit.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A sense of outrage, like a poor knife, gets dulled by use, and such has been the effect for many of us of Vietnam. But mine has been usefully sharpened again by the Pentagon Study, and, as usual, personal experience helped.

headline: Sulzberger Terms Documents ‘History’
lead_paragraph: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times, said yesterday that the documents on the origins of the Vietnam war whose publication has been curbed by court order are “a part of history that should have been made available long ago.”

headline: Official Defends Canadian Role In Taking Messages to Hanoi
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, June 17 — The Canadian Government defended itself today against accusations’ that in transmitting messages from Washington to Hanoi in 1964‐65 it had been “an errand boy bearing threats of an expanded war” and that it had compromised its role as a member of the International Control Commission.
author: By Edward Cowan Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:A. G. Woodhead's piece on Thucydides (Op‐Ed June 4) brutally misrepsents the greatest historian of antiquity in attempting to enlist him as supporter of Lyndon Johnson's policy of madness in Vietnam.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hanoi and Vietcong at Paris Talks Cite Times Series as Proof U.S. Is Aggressor
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 17—The Vietnamese Communists today cited the parts of the Pentagon report on Vietnam published this week in The New York Times as further proof of their contention that the United States was an aggressor.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Seizes 14 Dailies
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tune 17 (Reuters) — The issues of 14 daily newspapers were confiscated today for allegedly violating government press codes, informed sources said. It was not immediately clear what articles published by the confiscated papers had drawn the Government's wrath.

headline: Congress and the War
lead_paragraph: President Nixon has won more time for his Vietnamization policy this week with the defeat in Senate and House of separate proposals designed to speed the end of the American military involvement in Indochina.

headline: PRESIDENT ORDERS WIDER DRUG FIGHT; ASKS $155‐MILLION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 17 —President Nixon said today that drug abuse had “assumed the dimensions of a national emergency,” and he asked Congress for $155‐million more for campaign of rehabilitation, research, education, enforcement and international control of drug traffic.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: Fighting in Laos
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, June 17 (AP) — Heavy fighting was reported today in southern Laos between the key Government town of Pakse, in the Mekong River Valley, and the Boloven Plateau to the east, which was seized by North Vietnamese forces last month. Defense Minister Sissouk Na passak said that 700 enemy soldiers had been killed and three tanks and four antiaircraft guns destroyed in recent days.

headline: Excerpts From Oral Arguments on U.S. Effort to Obtain Documents From Times
lead_paragraph: MR. HESS: Your Honor, the Government brought on an order to show cause yesterday before your Honor late in the afternoon, asking that this motion be brought on today and asking for inspection of the documents in the hand of The New York Times. This is pursuant to Rule 34 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:The Pentagon Study of the Vietnam War (June 13) is a disclosure of Machiavellian duplicity. We have sent our young people to die in battle, we have devastated vast areas and we have slaughtered countless civilians on the pretense that we were defending allies from aggression. The record now seems clear that we betrayed our ideals as we arrogantly applied our power to further our political goals.

headline: Mayor Calls U.S. Suit A Threat to Freedoms
lead_paragraph: Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that The New York Times should be permitted to continue publishing its series on the United States involvement in the Vietnam war and added that “it would be useful for public education.”

headline: Most Authors Were Given A Promise of Anonymity
lead_paragraph: The majority of the approxi mately 36 authors who wrote the narrative‐analysis sections of the Pentagon papers were career military and civilian officials who were promised anonymity when they were recruited for the project, according to former Government officials anonymity, only a relatively small number of authors’ names have so far emerged. These include the following:
author: ByNeil Sheehan

headline: Kennedy Asks U.S. Data
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 17—Senator Edward M. Kennedy called today for full disclosure of secret Government data on Vietnam policies and actions during the Administration of President John F. Kennedy.
author: By Marjorie Hunter Special to The New York Times

headline: Soviet Seizes on Secret Papers To Criticize Policies of Nixon
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, June 17—The Soviet Union sought today to turn the publication of parts of the Pentagon papers on the Vietnam war into an attack on the policies of the Nixon Ad‐ministration.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Johnson's Publisher Says Data Won't Affect Book on Presidency
lead_paragraph: Former President Lyndon B. Johnson has completed the manuscript of his forthcoming book on his White House years and does not plan to change his account of the Vietnam war as a result of the publication of parts of a secret Pentagon study covering the same period.
author: By Henry Raymont

headline: Minh Calls on Saigon to Keep Fighting, but in the Cause of Peace
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17—General Duong Van Minh, who was expected to declare his “peace” candidacy today for the October presidential elections, called for South Vietham's armed forces to keep fighting, but for a. “righteous cause”—peace.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:Instead of digging into the history of the 1964‐1965 period under the Johnson Administration, I suggest that The Times undertake to discover and present the decisions that already have been made by the Nixon Administration to be implemented in the spring of 1973.

headline: U.N. Aide Reiterates ‘65 View Of Thant on the Vietnam War
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, June 17 —A United Nations spokesman today in effect reiterated a six‐year‐old statement by Secretary General Thant that if the American public had known the facts about Vietnam in early 1965 it would have agreed then that the bloodshed there should end.
author: By Henry Tanner Special to The New York Times

headline: House, Like Senate, Bars Deadline in Troop Pullout
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 17—The House, following the lead of the Senate, refused today to impose a Congressional deadline on the President for withdrawal of American forces from Indochina.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Excerpts From Latest Editorial Reaction in U. S. and Abroad to Publication of Documents on Vietnam War
lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the continuing editorial reaction in this country and abroad to the publication by The New York Times of secret documents dealing with the origins of the United States’ involvement in the Indochina war:

headline: Rusk States He ‘Never Heard’ Of Study Before Times Series
lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ga., June 17 (AP) —Former Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today he had “never heard” of the secret Pentagon. Vietnam study that The New York Times has been temporarily enjoined from publishing.

headline: Hanoi Denounces Treaty
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, June 17 (Agence France‐Presse) —The official Communist party newspaper Nhan Dan said today that the treaty on Okinawa “marks a new, dangerous step in the development of the collusion between American imperialism and the reactionary Sato administration,”

headline: U.S. Deaths in Combat Last Week Put at 25
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17 (AP)—The United States command said today that 25 Americans died in combat in Indochina last week.

headline: Excerpts From President's Message on Drug Abuse Control
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)—Following are excerpts from President Nixon's message to Congress today proposing an emergency program to combat narcotics addiction:

headline: Saigon's Marines Said to Repel Attack on Outpost Near DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 18 (AP)—Outnumbered South Vietnamese marines, helped by American jets and helicopters, reportedly beat off a North Vietnamese attack yesterday on their jungle outpost in the northwestern corner of the country.

headline: Paper Gives List Identifying Material It Has
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department failed yesterday — at least for the present — to obtain a court order forcing The New York Times to turn over for the Government's inspection the secret Pentagon study from which the newspaper's series on the Vietnam war has been drawn.
author: By Fred P. Graham

headline: Ky Says He Didn't Miss Target—Entire North
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17 (AP)—Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky says it is untrue that he bombed the wrong target in the first reprisal strikes against North Vietnam on Feb. 8, 1966, because, he says, all of North Vietnam was a good target.

headline: Freedom and Security
lead_paragraph: “Here various news we tell, of love and strife,
author: By James Reston

headline: Australian Leader Asks Inquiry On '65 Commitment of Troops
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, Friday June 18 — Prime Minister William McMahon has called for an urgent report by a highlevel committee on the circumstances under which Australia committed troops to the war in Vietnam.
author: By Robert Trumbull Special to The New York Times

headline: F.B.I. Continues Investigation 0f How Times Got Documents
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington said yesterday that it was continuing its investigation to determine how The New York Times obtained a copy of the secret Pentagon study on Vietnam.

headline: One Study Participant Sees No Security Harm
lead_paragraph: TRENTON, June 18 (AP)—A Princeton University educator said today that he had played “a small part” in the preparation of the secret Pentagon papers and that he knew of nothing In the classified study that would harm the nation's security.

headline: U.S. Orders ‘Atlanta Plan’ in Building
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, June 18 — Assistant Secretary of Labor An.. thur A. Fletcher announced today the immediate implementation of an Atlanta Plan that is aimed at bringing more black workers into the higher‐paying areas of the construction trades in metropolitan Atlanta.
author: By Thomas A. Johnson Special to The New York Times

headline: Study Said to Show Diem Barred Vote
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)—The Washington Post said today that a Pentagon study asserts there was no connivance in 1955 between the United States and the Saigon Government to prevent the elections throughout North and South Vietnam that had been agreed upon by the 1954 Geneva Conference.

headline: Testing to Start Tomorrow
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 18—The urinalysis tests on all soldiers and officers, male and female, will begin Sunday, the United States Command announced today.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 18 —The press is no more perfect than any other institution. Newspapers can be vulgar or silly or craven; they can cry “freedom of the press” when nothing is at stake but their desire to sensationalize for profit.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: THE TIMES SERIES STILL HELD UP PENDING COURT RULING TODAY;
lead_paragraph: Federal District Judge Murray I. Gurfein refused yesterday to permit The New York Times to resume publication immediately of its material from a secret Pentagon study on Vietnam although The Washington Post began publishing a series of articles based on the study in its Friday issue.
author: By Fred P. Graham

headline: Appeals Court Decision
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 19—Following is the text of the decision by three judges of the District of Columbia Circuit Court of Appeals, overruling a lower Federal court decision and ordering The Washington Post of halt publication of a series of articles on the roots of the Vietnam war:

headline: Nixon Sees 30% ax Cut In Revenue‐Sharing Plan
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, June 18—President Nixon, in another regional conference designed to arouse support for his domestic programs, today called his proposal for revenue sharing “the only hope” for reducing local property taxes.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Press Weekly and Guild Score ‘Censorship’ Effort
lead_paragraph: Editor & Publisher, the newspaper industry's weekly trade magazine, said in an editorial yesterday that “the attempt of the Nixon Administration to suppress publication by The New York Times of a Pentagonprepared digest about the origins and developments of the Vietnam war is an assault on the freedoms of the American people and an affront to their intelligence.”

headline: Excerpts From Arguments in U.S. Case Against Times Over Vietnam Documents
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDER M. BICKEL, for The Times—Your Honor, the new matter I wish to bring to your attention came to our attention first thing this morning. The Washington Post has begun publication, under a headline, and I will go into that in a moment more thoroughly, ‘'Documents Reveal U. S. Effort in 54 to Delay ?? Election,” heavily quoting from the same documents that The New York Times is alleged to possess, and the publication proceeds from portions of those documents which The New York Times has not yet published. It is the first in a series.

headline: U. S. Weighed Moves to Halt The Times Series Within Hours of First Publication
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 17 —Within hours after The New York Times published secret Pentagon documents Sunday, Attorney General John N. Mitchell and Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird began discussing possible attempts to stop the articles.

headline: Nixon's Drug Control Plan introduced Into Congress
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 18 —The Administration introduced into Congress today legislation to authorize President Nixon's $155‐million program for control of drug addiction.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: Presbyterian Unity Is Foreseen; Compromise War Stand Taken
lead_paragraph: MASSANETTA SPRINGS, Va., June 18—The one‐million‐member Presbyterian Church in the United States (Southern)” ended its six‐day General Assembly here this afternoon determined to stay together.
author: By George Dugan Special to The New York Times

headline: Hearing Ends in Britain On Captain's Protest Role
lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 18 — A preliminary investigation into the part taken by Capt. Thomas S. Culver of the United States Air Force in a protest against the Vietnam war ended today.

headline: PRECEDENT SEEN
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 18—A high Administration spokesman says that President Nixon is more concerned that a precedent might be set for future disclosures of secret documents than he is over whether The New York Times endangered national security by publishing a Pentagon study.
author: By Marjorie Hunter Special to The New York Times

headline: WASHINGTON POST RESTRAINED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 19—In a 2‐to‐1 decision this morning the United States Court of Appeals reversed the ruling of a lower court and ordered The Washington Post to stop publication of a series of articles, based on classified information, on the history of the nation's involvement in the Vietnam war.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Books of The Times
lead_paragraph: Were you surprised to read that a spokesman for the State Department last Monday had no comment to make on this newspaper's publication the previous day of excerpts from the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war “because the department had not had time to locate its copy, of the report, or even to determine..whether it had one"? Maybe you thought the spokesman was stalling? I believed him'—just having finished “The Foreign Affairs Fudge Factory,” John Franklin Campbell's scathl ing diagnosis of elephantiasis and fragmented responsibility in our foreign‐policy bureaucracy—and’ was only surprised that the 47‐volume report was located’ a mere “several hotirs later.” Mr.. Campbell, Foreign Service officer on leave; is the young managing editor of a lively new magazine, Foreign Policy; he is a wit, muckracker, a stable‐cleaner. His devastating picture of the disarray of our foreign policy is a plea to simplify, restore and demoralized State Department.
author: By Walter Clemons

headline: Gesell Ruling on Post
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 18—Following is the text of the decision of Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell tonight refusing to halt The Washington Post from continued publication of a series of articles on the roots of the Vietnam war:

headline: 2 NIXON BACKERS TO SEEK PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 18 —Two pro‐Administration Republicans will pose a new Senate test of President Nixon's Vietnam policies next week by proposing a troop withdrawal in nine months if agreement is reached on release of prisoners of war.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Classifying for Security, Web of Complexity
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 18 —Brrp, brrp goes the high‐speed teletype and on the page appears, “TOP SECRET/NODIS—HARVAN/CRITIC. GP 2.”

headline: EX‐PENTAGON AIDE PHONES MESSAGE
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18 (AP) — The Massachusetts Institute of Technology said today it had heard from Daniel Ellsberg, the former Government adviser who is alleged to have given classified documents on Vietnam to The New York Times.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Danang Shelled on Saigon's Armed Forces Day
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, June 19 (AP)—Enemy gunners shelled Danang early today on South Vietnam's Armed Forces Day.

headline: Text of Gurfein Opinion Upholding The Times and Kaufman Order Extending Ban
lead_paragraph: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK 71 Civ. 2662 UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, Plaintiff, v. NEW YORK TIMES COMPANY, et al, Defendants, GURFEIN, D. J.

headline: Text of Court of Appeals Opinion Restraining The Washington Post From Publishing Articles and Dissent
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 19—Following is the text of the opinion by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today in The Washington Post case; as well as the text of the dissenting opinion by Judge J. Skelly Wright.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: The press is still riding the tide of tradition in the courts against the rising power of the Presidency, but even when it prevails in its conflicts with the White House, its power is limited.
author: By James Reston

headline: OBSERVER
lead_paragraph: In Washington classified documents are piling up in the corridors of the Pentagon, the State Department and the White House, and the men who are supposed to leak them to the press are in despair.
author: By Russell Baker

headline: POST CASE OPINION
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Decision for Freedom
lead_paragraph: District Judge Murray L. Gurfein's decision yesterday denying the Government's plea for a preliminary injunction to bar this newspaper from publishing articles about a secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war marks a significant victory for press freedom in the United States and for the right of the American people to be informed about the operations of their Government.

headline: VETERANS'
lead_paragraph: Returning Vietnam veterans are being treated as “10th class” citizens lacking jobs and adequate medical facilities a condition that reflects complete misunderstanding of their situation, according to speakers yesterday at a special conference on veterans’ problems.
author: By Gene Currivan

headline: Saigon Parades Army's Growing Power
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, June 19—The South Vietnamese Government celebrated Armed Forces Day today with a snappy show of its growing military muscle and promises from President Nguyen Van Thieu that the army would assure a South Vietnam “free of Communism in any form.”
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: For Gesell, Controversy Is Routine
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 19—Controversial decisions are almost routine for Gerhard Alden Gesell, the Federal District judge who late last night refused a Government request to halt The Washington Post's publication of a series of articles based on a Pentagon study.

headline: Study Said to Show Bomb Lulls Were Meant to ‘Placate’ Public
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) —The Washington Post reported tonight that secret Pentagon papers showed that the Johnson Administration's strategists had little expectation that the pauses in the bombing of North Vietnam in 1965 and 1968 would produce peace talks.

headline: The Capt in Who Commanded Lieutenant Caney
lead_paragraph: FORT MCPHERSON, GA.“ONE of the men made a drawing of a mangy old alley cat with a bandage on his tail sitting on a full garbage can. We had it silk‐screened onto sweatshirts, one for each man. Above the picture was our nickname, ‘Charlie Cats,’ and, below, the formal name, ‘Company C, First Battalion, 20th Infantry Regiment.’ No one outside the company knew we were getting them, and it was really something when we all turned out in the sweatshirts, bloused fatigue pants and boots for the battalion organization day.”
author: By Tom Buckley

headline: 5,000 Youths Attend a Register‐to‐Vote Rally in Park
lead_paragraph: Against a backdrop of large banners reacting “When You Got the Vote, You've Got to Use It—So Use It!” 5,000 youths in Central Park yesterday roared their approval of speeches and messages denouncing the war in Vietnam.
author: By Irving Spiegel

headline: Sunday Times of London Prints Article on Series
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Sunday, June 10 —The Sunday Times of London published in this morning's issue a summary and analysis of The New York Times reports on the Pentagon's secret study of American involvement in the Vietnam war,

headline: SECRECY BACKED
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., June 19 —The White House asserted today that one compelling reason for its vigorous legal action against The New York Times and The. Washington Post was its belief that the Government “cannot operate its foreign policy in the best interests of the American people if it cannot deal with foreign powers in a’ confidential way.”
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: The Death He Foresaw Comes to a G.I.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam June 19 (UPI) — It was not yet dawn, but the 20‐year‐old G.I. was already awake, apprehensive lest a particular morning had come It was recalled later that he had been saying for several weeks that he woke up each morning thinking it was his last.

headline: PANEL WILL RULE
lead_paragraph: United States District Judge Murray I. Gurfein refused yesterday to enjoin The New York Times from publishing further articles based upon a secret Pentagon study of the origins of the Vietnam war.
author: By Fred P. Graham

headline: WISCONSIN V.F.W. OUSTS PEACE POST
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. June 19 —A local Veterans of Foreign Wars Post has been suspended for conducting activities against the Vietnam war. Its officers say they will wage court fight against the suspension.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: PUBLIC: Q. “Mr. President... Representative Laird of Wisconsin declared that the Administration is preparing to move the Vietnam war into the North. Is there any substance to this claim?”

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 28, 1964, campaigning hard against Barry Goldwater, President Lyndon B. Johnson told an audience at Manchester, N. H.:
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Army Dismisses Charge Of War Crimes by General
lead_paragraph: FORT MONROE, Va., June 19 (AP)—The Army has announced that it has dismissed war crimes charges brought against retired Lieut. Gen. Jonathan 0. Seaman by a young lieutenant who has since left the service as a conscientious objector,

headline: Servicemen in Hospital Earn Diplomas in Bed
lead_paragraph: Many young servicemen who are confined in St. Al bans Naval Hospital in Queens, some of them wounded in Vietnam, are studying for high school degrees In what may be the country's most extensive bedside educational program.

headline: The Classified Minds
lead_paragraph: CONWAY, Mass.—I suppose I should take an ironical satisfaction in the attempt of the Attorney General to silence The Times, The Times having so recently silenced me. But I don't and can't. When a drama critic, or what passes for one, concocts a review to kill a play nothing is at issue but the worth of the play and the compe tence of the critic.
author: By Archibald MacLeish

headline: Hanoi and Rumania Accuse U.S. of Prolonging War
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam June 20 (Agence france. presse) —North Vietnam and Rumania in a joint communiqué today Condemned the United, States for attempting to “prolong, in tensity and extend” the ?? in Indochina.

headline: Ft. Knox Medical Officers Ask Pullout by Year's End
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 20 (AP)—A group representing 38 medical officers at Fort Knox published a statement today de manding the withdrawal of all American military personnel and advisers from Vietnam by the end of this year.

headline: McGovern Predicts Defeat Of Nixon Over the Economy
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI)— Senator George Mc Govern, Democrat of South Dakota, said today that un employment and other eco nomic,.conditions could cause the defeat of President Nixon next year.

headline: Reactions Focus on Security Rules
lead_paragraph: The controversy over the legal, ethical and political im plications of the publication of secret documents on the United States involvement in Vietnam continued yesterday as present and former government of ficials described their reactions to the papers in speeches and interviews across the country.
author: By Lacey Fosburgh

headline: B‐52'S AGAIN RAID INFILTRATION AREA JUST BELOW DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, June 21—United States B‐52 bombers yesterday con tinued intensive raids against North Vietnamese infiltration routes just below the demili tarized zone where they are reported to have dropped more than 700 tons of bombs in the last week.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Rally in Prospect Park Asks That All Ages Protest War
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn peace organiza tion held a rally in Prospect Park yesterday afternoon to protest the war in Vietnam and to show other Americans that in the pursuit of peace there could be no generation gap.

headline: AIR FORCE CHARGES OFFICER WITH THEFT
lead_paragraph: TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 20 (UPI)—An Air Force major has been charged with stealing electronic equip ment from transport planes he flew between the United States and Vietnam.

headline: The Vietnam Papers
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 25, 1964, some three weeks after President Johnson's election, The Times observed editorially ‘that “another Vietnam reassessment is under way … [and] if there is to be a new policy now, if an Asian war to be converted into an American war, the country has a right to insist that it be told what has changed so profoundly in the last two months to justify it.” The country was not told.

headline: 3 Judges Will Rule on Secret Papers
lead_paragraph: The court struggle between the Justice Department and The New York Times over publica tion of secret information will move to the Federal Court of Appeals today. With lawyers for both sides operating on an accelerated legal timetable, the case is likely to reach the Su preme Court by the end, of the week.
author: By Fred P. Graham

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: John W. Hushen Director of Public Information Department of Justice Washington, June 9, 1971

headline: Fair Vote in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Even with the most scrupulous self‐restraint, the huge American military, diplomatic, intelligence and propa ganda establishment in Saigon could not help but be a looming presence in the background of the forthcoming Vietnamese national elections. Unfortunately, there is some reason to believe that the American influence in Saigon may not be either neutral or self‐restrained. The logic of the Nixon Administration's “Vietnamization” policy makes American officialdom naturally sympathetic to the electoral cause of this country's political ally, President Thieu.

headline: Chaplains' Role Questioned Because They Support War
lead_paragraph: Despite widespread church opposition to the Vietnam war, support for the United States war effort remains strong among many military chaplains. The chaplaincy, largely as a result, is under renewed fire by critics seek ing an end to the institution of clergymen in uniform.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal

headline: Mansfield Offers Amendment For a Pullout Within 9 Months
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 21— Senator Mike Mansfield, the Ma jority Leader, unexpectedly in troduced today an amendment to the Selective Service bill calling on the President to with draw all American forces from Indochina within nine months.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Excerpts From Ruling Denying Injunction Against Washington Post
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 21— Following are excerpts from a transcript of the oral ruling today by Judge Gerhard A. Gesell refusing to grant an injunction against publication of classified Pentagon docu ments in The Washington Post:

headline: Mitchell Explains Position
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (Al) —It is essential that the Amer ican public get full information on the Vietnam war, but this in formation should be made pub lic only “at the appropriate time and in appropriate circum stances,” Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today.

headline: The War: The Record and the U.S.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.—The publica tion by The New York Times of the secret documents about U.S. Govern ment decisions on the Vietnam War provides fuel for two great debates: one over what the United States did in the 1960's, and the other over what The Times did this June. Let me enter into that second debate.
author: By Roger Fisher

headline: U.S. PULLOUT RATE DROPS IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 21 (UPI)—American troop strength in Vietnam dropped last week by 2,300 men to a total of 244,900, the United States command announced to day.

headline: Letter From Head of Pentagon Panel
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 21— Following is the text of a letter on Jan. 15, 1969, from Leslie H. Gelb, head of the task force that wrote the Pentagon study on the Viet nam war, to the then Secre tary of Defense Clark M. Clifford, on the group's final report:

headline: Medal Winner Links His Bravery to Marijuana
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 21 (AP)—A Metal of Honor winner says he was “stoned” on marijuana the night he fought off two waves of Vietcong soldiers and won America's highest military honor.

headline: B‐52's Pound Enemy
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Tuesday, June 22 (AP)—American 8–52's report edly dropped 60 tons of explo sives around Fire Base Fuller yesterday in an attempt to smash a North Vietnamese force that assaulted the moun taintop outpost.

headline: The War: The Record and the U.S.
