author: By W. W. Rostow

headline: U.S. Reports a 0.5% Rise in Consumer Price Index Here in May
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Price Index in the New York metropolitan area rose by 0.5 per cent in May, the same increase as registered in the country as a whole, the Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported yesterday.
author: By Grace Lichtenstein

headline: RULING FOR POST
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 21—A Federal district judge ruled today that The Washington Post could resume publishing a series of articles on United States involvement in the Viet nam war, but the Circuit Court of Appeals quickly ordered delay until 5 P.M. tomorrow.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: ARMY INQUIRIES SET ON VIETNAM DEATHS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) —The Army announced today that a grand jury type of in vestigation had been ordered for Brig. Gen. John W. Donald son, charged with the murder of six Vietnamese civilians.

headline: Excerpts From the Government Brief
lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the Government brief sub mitted yesterday to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, seeking to prevent publication by The New York Times of further articles in its series on Viet nam:

headline: Advertising: Frankfurt and Mattel Link Up
lead_paragraph: Stephen O. Frankfurt, who reached the heights in the agency business, is starting a new career at age 39.
author: By Philip H. Dougherty

headline: Calley Prosecutor Testifies Army Blocked His Bid to Call Medina as Witness
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., June 21—Aubrey M. Daniel 3d, the young Virginian who success fully prosecuted First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. for the massacre at Mylai, testified to day that the Army had blocked his attempt to call as a Govern ment witness Capt. Ernest L. Medina, who is about to stand trial here for over‐all respon sibility in the incident.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Globe Relates '68 Decision
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, June 22 (UPI)— The Boston Globe reported to day that the concluding part of the classified Pentagon study on the Vietnam War says that President Lyndon B. Johnson had decided to support South Vietnam but to reduce Ameri can troops in a policy that Pres ident Nixon later termed viet ntimization.

headline: ELLSBERG IS TO MAKE STATEMENT SHORTLY
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, June 22 (AP)—The Boston Globe said today that Daniel Ellsberg, who was linked last week with the disclosure of secret Pentagon documents on Vietnam, to newspapers, plans to make a statement on his part in the matter.

headline: SENATE BACKS A VIETNAM PULLOUT IN 9 MONTHS IF P.O.W.'S ARE FREED
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: 1968: L.B.J. and Rostow in White House
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—I am grateful to The Times for affording me this op portunity to explain why I think the action of the paper in Publishing se lected portions of the highly classified Gelb study was contrary to the na tional interest.
author: By Maxwell D. Taylor

headline: REVIEW OF REPORT PROPOSED BY U.S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 22—The Government offered today to begin an interagency review of the secret Pentagon study of American involvement in Viet nam to determine how much of it could be declassified.
author: By David E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: Seoul Weighs Vietnam Pullout in '72
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 22 — South Korea has informed the South Vietnamese Government it is thinking seriously of with drawing all of its nearly 50,000 troops from Vietnam over the next 18 months according to Nixon Administration and diplo matic sources.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Text of Mansfield's Pullout Amendment
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 22— Following is the text of the Mansfield amendment to the Selective Service bill, as adopted today by the Senate:

headline: Boston Globe, Third to Publish Articles on Secret Study, Is Restrained by Court
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, June 22 — The Boston Globe today became the third newspaper to publish ma terial drawn from the secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war. The Justice Department immediately moved to bar the newspaper from publishing fur ther material on the ground that national security was jeop ardized.
author: By Bill Kovach Special to The New York Times

headline: Foe Attacks Delta Village and Aid Force
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 23 (AP)— Guerrilla forces swept through a village in the Mekong Delta early yesterday and then am bushed a Government relief force, reportedly inflicting heavy casualties.

headline: General Denies Decision to Try Medina Was to Protect Army
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., June 22—The commanding general of the Third Army denied today that the decision to court martial Capt. Ernest L. Medina had been dictated by any de sire to protect the Army's pub lic relations image.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: F.B.I. Men Visit Congressman on Papers He Holds
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 22 — Two agents of the Federal Bu reau of Investigation inter viewed Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. today about doc uments he has relating to the Vietnam war.
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Who Elected The Times?
lead_paragraph: The public reaction to the publica tion of the Pentagon Papers has been overwhelmingly on the side of the newspapers, but there is a strong and vehement view that it is wrong, dan gerous and even criminal for a news paper to assume responsibility for publishing private official documents without the consent of the Govern ment.
author: By James Reston

headline: Senate Roll‐Call Vote On Pullout Amendment
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) —Following is the roll‐call vote by which the Senate, 57 to 42, adopted an amendment to the draft extension bill sponsored by Senator Mike Mansfield stating as United States policy a staged withdrawal of Amer ican troops from Indochina coupled with the return of prisoners over a nine‐month period:

headline: Text of Order Curbing Boston Globe
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, June 22—Follow ing is the text of an order issued today by the United States District Court restrain ing The Boston Globe from further publication of its Vietnam articles:

headline: V. A. to Add 27 Drug Addiction Centers
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 22— The Veterans Administration announced today a more than five‐fold expansion of its spe cial drug addiction clinics to cope with a flood of military addicts from Vietnam and other overseas posts.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: 1968: L.B.J. and Rostow in White House
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO‐ Anyone With the self righteousness of a Melvin Laird or a Tom Wicker has little difficulty de termining the proper outcome of the present controversy between the Gov ernment and The New York Times. But certitude is only an anagram of and not a synonym for rectitude. The respective battle cries of “free speech” and “national security” frame the question; they do not answer it.
author: By Philip B. Kurland

headline: Sun‐Times Tells of Ouster
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, June 22 (AP)— The Chicago Sun‐Times said today that it had obtained top‐secret State Department documents showing that high‐ ranking Kennedy Administra tion officials “had “advance knowledge of the coup d'etat that toppled Predident, Dinh Diem of South Vietnam.

headline: Washington Appeals Court Continues Ban on The Post's Series on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 22 — Nine Federal Appeals judges continued tonight a ban against publication by The Washington Post of articles based on secret Pentagon documents. They said that the ban would remain in effect until they ruled on the propriety of the Government's attempt to stop the articles.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Times Case Heard, Restraint Extended; U.S. Action Halts a Boston Globe Series
lead_paragraph: The United States Court of appeals here heard arguments yesterday on the Government's effort, to enjoin The New York Times from publishing secret information on the Vietnam war. A prompt decision was Promised.
author: By Fred P. Graham

headline: 100,000 Jobs for Veterans Goal Of Appeal of a Business Group
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 22— The Nixon Administration will announce tomorrow a pledge by the National Alliance of Busi nessmen, a group of volunteer business executives, to seek out at least 100,000 jobs over the next 12 months for Vietnam veterans.

headline: Senate Votes Closure in Debate on Draft
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23 — With only a week to go before the Government's basic au thority to conscript men into the military service expires, the Senate voted today to cut off debate on the bill to extend the draft.
author: By David E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: Diem Ouster Described
lead_paragraph: MIAMI, June 23 (UPI)—The article published by the Knight papers said that the Pentagon documents indicated the fol lowing:

headline: Goldberg Urges Easing Of Secrecy on U.S. Data
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23— Arthur J. Goldberg, the Amer ican delegate to the United Nations during the Johnson Ad ministration, asserted today that only 10 per cent of the Government's sensitive docu ments should remain secret for long.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Senator Mansfield's Compromise
lead_paragraph: The Administration narrowly escaped a direct consti tutional confrontation with Congress Tuesday when the Senate defeated by only one vote an amendment to the Selective Service Act aimed at cutting off funds for United States military operations in Indochina in nine months if North Vietnam agreed to free American prisoners of war.

headline: Senate to Set Up Joint Group that Will Hold Hearings On Origin of the War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23— The Senate leadership laid the groundwork today for creation of a special joint panel of the Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee and the Senate Armed Services Committee to hold public hearings into the origins of the Vietnam war.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Leader of War Study Sees No Security Threat So Far
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23 — A former Governnient official who had over‐all responsibility for the preparation of the Pentagon's study on the Viet nam war said today that, in his view, hone of the material published so far, could endan ger the national security.
author: By Terence Smite Special to The New York Times

headline: A.C.L.U. Scores Pentagon's Drug Plan
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23 — The American Civil Liberties Union challenged today the right of the armed forces to tell law enforcement agencies the results of urinalysis tests that servicemen returning to this country from Vietnam must now undergo.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: TOP HANOI AIDE DUE TO HEAD PARIS TEAM
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 23 (Reuters)— A senior North Vietnamese leader, Le Duc Tho, is return ing to Paris to head Hanoi's negotiating team in the peace talks here, the North Vietna mese delegation said today.

headline: TIMES SERIES IS DELAYED AGAIN; PAPER TO APPEAL TO HIGH COURT;
lead_paragraph: The United States Court of Appeals here ordered a further. delay yesterday in the publi cation by The New York Times of material from Pentagon pa pers on the American involve ment in the Vietnam war.
author: By Fred P. Graham

author: James A. Michener Tinicum, Pa., June 21, 1971

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: H. H. Cooper Alexandria, Va., June 19, 1971

headline: Coast Grand Jury Studies How Times Got Papers
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, June 23— A Federal grand jury here is investigating how the secret Pentagon study on Vietnam reached The New York Times.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: 1966: L.B.J.and Ky in Honolulu
lead_paragraph: Publication by The New York Times and other news media of portions of the secret Pentagon Vietnam study has raised basic questions of propriety that have long been a simmering issue between government and a free Press. Now it is out in the open.
author: By James C. Hagerty

headline: Rostow on Bombing
lead_paragraph: In an interview yesterday on the ABC Evening News, Walt W. Rostow, a former White House adviser to President Johnson, was asked if he thought it proper for President Johnson to have depicted himself in the 1964 Presidential campaign as the “candidate of reason and restraint” in the light of recent disclosures from Pentagon docu ments that there was an as sumption during the campaign “that it would be necessary to bomb North Vietnam.”

headline: Flag Honoring Hero Stolen
lead_paragraph: NORWALK, Conn., June 23— An American flag was reported stolen today from the flagpole of the Pfc. Daniel J. Shea Memorial here. The memorial, at Calf Pasture Beach, honors a posthumous winner of the Medal of Honor in Vietnam and 15 others who were killed there. The Honor America Committee has offered a $100 reward for the flag's return.

headline: In '51, Nixon Criticized Truman Secrecy on Korea
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) —Twenty years ago, Richard M. Nixon accused the Truman Administration of holding back classified documents for political rea sons.

headline: Johnson Trip Cited
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Thursday, June 24 (UPI)—The Chicago Sun‐Times said today that President John F. Kennedy sent Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson to Saigon in May, 1961, to persuade South Vietnam to request United States ground troops.

headline: Cambodians Report Headquarters Lost By Enemy Regiment
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 23 (AP)—The Cambodian com mand said today that its troops had overrun a North Vietnam ese regimental headquarters within 15 miles of Pnompenh and had inflicted heavy cas ualties.

headline: Pressure Maintained Near DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 24 (AP)—North Vietnamese forces were report ed keeping up pressure on allied outposts south of the de militarized zone yesterday, while fighting elsewhere in South Vietnam subsided into small and scattered skirmishes.

headline: PANEL BACK WASHINGTON POST
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23— The United States Court of Ap peals ruled tonight that The Washington Post had a Consti tutional right to publish articles based on a secret Pentagon study of how the United States became involved in Vietnam, but restrained the newspaper from continuing its series until Friday night to allow a Gov ernment appeal.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Ellsberg, on TV, lames U.S. for 25 Years of War
lead_paragraph: Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, who is reported to bave given the se cret Pentagon study on Vietnam to The New York Times, ap peared on television last night to make, his first public state‐ ments since publication of the study began.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: Mitchell's Statement On Rulings by Courts

headline: '67 COALITION BID LAID TO M'NAMARA
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, June 23 —The Knight newspapers to day published an article, said to have been based on the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war, stating that former Secre tary of Defense Robert S. McNamara proposed a coalition government in Saigon in 1967 after he became discouraged with the ground war.

headline: Chicago Data Not Secret
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, June 23—The Jus‐tice Department made no at tempt today to prevent The Chi cago Sun‐Times from publishing further information the news paper, said it had received from “sources involving the Pentagon study.”

headline: Text of Statement by Nixon Aide
lead_paragraph: Following is the text of the statement made by Ronald L. Ziegler, White House press secretary, on the release of the Pentagon study to Congress:

headline: Schlesinger: Truth or Reputation?
lead_paragraph: In seeking to suppress the Vietnam documents, the United States Govern ment asserted that their continued pub lication in The New York Times would “cause irreparable injury to the de fense interests of the United States.” If this assertion were true, then the case against publication would have been strong indeed. The protection of military security constitutes an entirely proper limitation on the freedom of the press and on the “people's right to know.” When on Dec. 4, 1941, three days before Pearl Harbor, the Chicago Tribune published the secret Army war plans; When on June 7, 1942, dur ing the battle of Midway, a Chicago Tribune story revealed that we had broken the Japanese naval codes, these were disclosures that might well have caused irreparable injury to the de fense interests of the United States.
author: By Arthur Schlesinger Jr

headline: CONGRESS RECORD ON SECRETS MIXED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23—The Congressional committees pre paring to receive copies of the Vietnam study have mixed his tories and somewhat ambiguous attitudes about the keeping of secrets.
author: By Christopher Lydon Special to The New York Times

headline: Ex‐Aide Tells of Coup
lead_paragraph: Roger Hilsman, Assistant Secretary of State for, East Asian affairs in the Kennedy Administration, said yesterday that President Kennedy arid his top advisers “had no detailed knowledge of the time or place” of the coup against President Ngo Ding Diem of South Vietnam on Nov. 1, 1963.
author: By E. W. Kenworthy

headline: Nixon Will Give Secret Study to Congress
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23 — President Nixon announced to day that he would, make avail able to Congress the complete 47‐volume Pentagon study of United States involvement in Vietnam.
author: By John Berbers Special to The New York Times

headline: L.A. Times Reports on Papers
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, June 23— (AP)—The Los Angeles Times reported that the National Se curity Council rejected a rec ommendation by a State De partment expert in 1963 that the United States should pull out of Vietnam because it could not win the war against the Communists.

headline: GOLDWATER ASSAILS DECISION BY TIMES
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, June 23 (AP)—Sen ator Barry Goldwater, the un successful Republican presiden tial candidate in 1964, wrote in Thursday's edition of The Chris tian Science Monitor that The New York Times “showed a shocking lack of responsibility” in publishing a Pentagon study on the history of the Vietnam war.

headline: Text of Post Case Opinion
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23 — Following is the text of the opinion of the United State Court of Appeals concerning The Washington Post's right to print articles on the secret Pentagon study of United States involvement in the Indo china war:

headline: 3d Army Legal Chief Contradicted at Medina Hearing
lead_paragraph: FORT MCPHERSON, Ga., June 23 —Two young Army lawyers testified today that the Third Army's chief legal officer had told them it would be a “waste of time” to raise the issue of command influence as ground for dismissal of charges against Capt. Ernest L. Medina.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Transcript of Ellsberg Interview on TV
lead_paragraph: Following is the transcript of an interview with. Dr. Daniel Ellsberg by Walter. Cronkite on the C.B.S. Tele vision 7 P.M. news program last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: G. I.'s in Vietnam Say Test for Heroin Addiction Can Be Beaten
lead_paragraph: LONGBINH, South Vietnam, June 23—The homeward‐bound G.I.'s taking the Army's new urinalysis test for heroin use here believe the test is not ac curate, that even if it were, it can be beaten, and that even if it can't be beaten, it doesn't make any difference.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: THIEU SIGNS CURB ON CANDIDATE LIST
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 23—President Nguyen Van Thieu today signed into law a measure designed to restrict the number of opponents he will face in the South Vietnamese presidential elections Oct. 3.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: President Nixon already has a con stitutional crisis with the press on his hands and he may be about to have another, this time with Congress. It would arise if Congress adopts the Mansfield amendment, which the Sen ate already has appended to the draft extension bill.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Grand Jury Questions Another Friend of Ellsberg
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, June 24—A Federal grand jury that is in vestigating the disclosure of a secret Pentagon study on Viet nam focused today on the activities of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: PAPER ON COAST ESCAPES ACTION
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department an nounced yesterday that it would not take legal action “at this time” against The Los Angeles Times and the 11‐ newspaper Knight chain, which yesterday published articles said to be based on secret Gov ernment documents.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: SAIGON RETAKES KEY BASE AT DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, June 25—Fresh South Viet namese troops were flown in American helicopters to the bomb‐shattered Firebase Fuller and retook the mountaintop position early this morning, just a day after it had fallen to North Vietnamese troops.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: The War: The Record and the U.S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—There is not the slightest doubt in my mind that The New York Times will receive many journalistic awards for its publication of the Pentagon Papers on Indochina. After all, a scoop that runs a million and a half words is not exactly to be sneezed at in journalistic circles.
author: By Barry Goldwater

headline: Excerpts From Petition to High Court by The Times
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 24— Following are excerpts from the petition by The New York Times to the Supreme Court for review:

headline: U.S. Deaths in Combat Pat at 25 Last Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tune 24 (UPI)—The United States command reported to day that 25 Americans died in combat in Indochina last week. This was the same number as the previous week and well under the average of 46 a week so far this year.

headline: The War: The Record and the U.S.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass—Everything se cret degenerates, was Lord Acton's warning. Sunlight is the most powerful of disinfectants, was Justice Brandeis' admonition. But concrete issues of dis closure and secrecy have a way of making even the most ardent liber tarians see that the right to know is not one‐dimensional, all warp and no woof. Brandeis himself was the intel lectual father of a legal right of privacy.
author: By Paul A. Freund

headline: U.S. LOSES IN MOVE TO CURB POST
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 24 — The Justice Department failed today to win a new hearing in the Court of Appeals on its ef fort to stop The Washington Post from resuming publication of information contained in the secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Dedicates Plaque To His Mother in Indiana
lead_paragraph: VERNON, Ind., June 24— President Nixon paid a nos talgic visit today to his mother's birthplace in rural Indiana and used the occasion to exhort several thousand well‐wishers to cling to the values that she knew as a Quaker girl around the turn of the century.
author: By John Rerbers Special to The New York Times

headline: To Vietnamese, Safety Before Politics
lead_paragraph: DUCDUC, South Vietnam, June 18—The villagers here, a district seat of huts and muddy paths, do not look ahead. Their war is only a short distance away and memories of the at tack last March by North Viet names troops are very fresh.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: The War: The Record and the U.S.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass—The Pentagon study on Vietnam reveals how a small group of technocrats and crisis man agers, acting in secret and relying on the espionage provisions of the Federal code to conceal their deception, con spired to engage the United States in an ever‐widening war of aggression in Indochina.
author: By Noam Chomsky

headline: STAND ON PULLOUT CLARIFIED BY SEOUL
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, June 24—South Korean officials said today that the Seoul Gov ernment was discussing with Saigon its plan to withdraw only one division of South Korean troops from Vietnam at present.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 24—The partial disclosure of the Pentagon Papers has already produced two important devel opments. It has forced the Administra tion to turn over all the documents in the McNamara study to Congress for analysis, and it has started a powerful movement to reform the present sys tem of distributing and classifying of ficial information.
author: By James Reston

headline: Coast Paper Says U.S. Barred Aide's '63 Plan to Quit Vietnam
lead_paragraph: The New York Times is re strained by Federal court order from publishing further articles in its Vietnam series. This dis patch was based on an article in The Los Angeles Times and was distributed by The Asso ciated Press to all its news paper, radio and television subscribers.

headline: Britain Voices Concern About Confidentiality
lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 24— The British Government said to day that it has informed the State Department of its con cern for the confidentiality of diplomatic exchanges.

headline: A CHARGE DROPPED IN SERGEANT'S TRIAL
lead_paragraph: QUANTICO, Va., June 24 (AP) — A military judge dis missed today one charge and amended others in the case of Sgt. Jon M. Sweeney, the only United States serviceman to be charged with communicating with the enemy in Vietnam.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: (Rev.) S.j. David P. Belliveau Fall River, Mass., June 17, 1971

headline: Hanoi Aide, Back in Paris, Adopts Conciliatory Tone
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 24—Le Due Tho, a high‐ranking member of the North Vietnamese hierarchy, returned to the peace talks here today after more than a year's absence and said he was ready to stay “as long as my presence is needed.”
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Pope Emphasizes Peace Efforts In Vietnam and the Middle East
lead_paragraph: ROME, June 24—Pope Paul VI emphasized today the ef forts of the Roman Catholic Church to promote peace in Vietnam, the Middle East and other trouble centers.

headline: Soviet Defends Its Policy of Improving U.S. Relations
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, June 24—The So viet Union today defended its policy of seeking better rela tions with the United States as necessary to reduce the risk of a new world war.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 24— Whatever their merit as history and whatever their fate in the courts and in the press, the Pentagon papers on the origins of the Vietnam war have be come a major fact of life for all three branches of the Gov ernment.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Chemist Questions Reports That G.I.'s ‘Beat’ Drug Test
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 24—A Washington chemist questioned today the truth of statements by soldiers in Vietnam that they or their friends had “beat en” the urinalysis system being used in Vietnam to detect mili tary personnel returning to the United States who have taken drugs within 72 hours of the test.

headline: RULING DUE TODAY ON MEDINA TRIAL
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., June 24—A military judge said today that he would rule to morrow on whether Capt. Er nest L. Medina would stand trial on Charges of premedi tated murder of 102 South Viet namese civilians at Mylai.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Court Documents in U.S. Appeals of The Post Case
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 24 — Following is the text of a denial by the Court of Ap peals today of a Government petition for a rehearing in The Washington Post case and excerpts from the Gov ernment's petition to the Supreme Court:

headline: TIMES ASKS SUPREME COURT TO END RESTRAINTS ON ITS VIETNAM SERIES;
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 24 — The New York Times asked the Supreme Court today to permit it to resume publication of material from the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: Pentagon Study Prominently Reported in Europe
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 25—“It's a great lesson for us,” said a young French journalist.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Study Said to Show McNamara Pessimism on War
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, June 25 (AP)— The St. Louis Post‐Dispatch said today that former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara labeled the pacification pro gram in South Vietnam “a bad disappointment” in 1966 and told President Johnson he saw “no reasonable way to bring the war to an end soon.”

headline: PATHET LAO RENEWS CALL FOR CEASE‐FIRE
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 25—The pro Communist Pathet Lao has re newed a proposal to the Vien tiane government for a cease fire in Laos followed by talks to bring about “peace and na tional agreement.” The pro posal was announced by the North Vietnamese delegation to the peace talks here and con firmed by reports from both Vientiane and Hanoi.

headline: N.A.B. BOARD BACKS C.B.S. ON ‘PENTAGON’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) —The board of directors of the National Association of Broad casters went on record today in support of Dr. Frank Stanton of the Columbia Broadcasting System and of newspapers that have printed excerpts from a secret Pentagon study of United States involvement in Vietnam.

headline: SUPREME COURT AGREES TO RULE ON PRINTING OF VIETNAM SERIES;
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 25 — The Supreme Court agreed to day to hear arguments tomor row on the Government's ef fort to enjoin The New York Times and The Washington Post from publishing material from the Pentagon papers on Vietnam.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: AGNEW SEES PRESS IN ‘CHEAP OPERATION’
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX, Arizona, June 25 —Vice President Agnew, in a spirited defense of the Nixon Administration's record in at tempting to end the Vietnam war, called the newspaper pub lication of top‐secret Pentagon papers a “common, cheap, fenc ing operation.”

headline: Newsmen at House Hearing Accuse U.S. of Attempting Censorship
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 25— Representatives of the nation's news media accused the Gov ernment today of attempted censorship in blocking publica tion of the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war.
author: By Marjorie Hunter Special to The New York Times

headline: Extending Draft, Not War
lead_paragraph: Congressional efforts to speed the end of American military involvement in the Indochina conflict have be come focused appropriately this year on Selective Service legislation now moving toward final action.

headline: Federal Warrant Is Issued For the Arrest of Ellsberg
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 26—The Justice Depart ment announced this morning that a Federal magistrate in Lds Angeles had issued a war rant for the arrest of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg on charges that he had “unauthorized possession of top‐secret documents and failed to return then.”
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Medina Trial Set on Noncapital Basis
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., June 25—Capt. Ernest L. Me dina was ordered today to stand trial for murders at Mylai but the possibility that he could get the death penalty was eliminated.
author: By Ramier. Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: 1965: McNamara inspects American troops in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: In South Vietnam, the U. S. had stumbled into a bog. It would be mired down there a long time. —Nihita Khrushchev to Ambassador Thompson, July 1962.
author: By Daniel Ellsberg

headline: G.I. DRUG CRACKDOWN UNDER WAY IN DELTA
lead_paragraph: CANTHO, South Vietnam, June 25 (AP)—The most sweep ing crackdown so far against illegal drug use by American servicemen in South Vietnam is under way in the Mekong Delta.

headline: From Government Data
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, June 25 (UPI)— The Chicago Sun‐Times, in its copyrighted story signed by Morton Kondracke and Thomas B. Ross, said its information had come from secret Govern ment documents.

headline: PAPER IN ST. LOUIS DEFENDS ARTICLES
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis Post‐Dispatch yesterday published 38 columns of articles drawn from the Pen tagon papers on United States involvement in Vietnam.
author: By Murray Illsom

headline: Newsday Threatened With Suit For Use of Johnson's Memoirs
lead_paragraph: Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, yesterday published an account of the American involvement in the Vietnams war that it said was based on galley proofs of Lyndon B. Johnson's forthcoming Presi dential memoirs.
author: By Henry Raymont

headline: Veterans, Once Home, Want to work and Forget
lead_paragraph: ROSWELL, N.M. — One by one, the young men of Roswell who fought the war in Vietnam are coming home to reclaim their place in the burning desert sun.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Paper Says Nixon Disregarded C.I.A. Advice on a War Pullout
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, June 25 (AP)—The Chicago Sun‐Times said today that Government documents re vealed that the Central Intel ligence Agency had advised President Richard M. Nixon in 1969 that if the United States withdrew from Vietnam “all of Southeast Asia would remain as it is for another generation.”

headline: 1965: McNamara inspects American troops in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass.—Long before the Attorney General turned on The Times to try to suppress publication of clas sified documents, historians had suf fered from the Government's denial of access to confidential records with out which they could not write serious history.
author: By William L. Shirer

headline: 1965: McNamra inspects American troops in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The Pentagon study disclosures engender mixed emotions, although the elements in the mix are not of equal weight. Not even a deter mined opponent of a damnable war can, I think, greet the episode with undiluted joy, for it adds new ingredi ents of unmeasurable consequence to what has become a Greek tragedy without a last act.
author: By Townsend Hoopes

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Representative Wilbur D. Mills had more trouble yes terday convincing people that he is not a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nom ination.
author: James F. Clarity

headline: SWEEP REPORTED NEAR FALLEN BASE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnams June 25 — A hunt was reported under way near the de militarized zone today for the scores of enemy mortar and rocket emplacements that con tributed to the Government's loss of Fire Base Fuler yester day.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: TWO‐HOUR DEBATE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 26 — The Supreme Court, heard two hours of arguments today and then took under advisement the Government's effort to en join The New York Times and The Washington Post from publishing Material from the Pentagon, papers on Vietnam.
author: By Fred P. Omani Special to The New York Times

headline: Paper Says Humphrey Opposed Bombing in '65
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, June 26 (AP) —The Baltimore Sun reported today that Hubert H. Humphrey, when he was Vice President, urged President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1965 not to bomb North Vietnam.

headline: U.S. GETS WARNING ON ARMY ADDICTS
lead_paragraph: The executive director of Odyssey House warned yester day that unless drug‐addicted veterans of Vietnam were re habilitated before their release from the armed services they would contribute to a “massive increase” in America's growing heroin problem.
author: By Richard Severo

headline: Transcript of Oral Argument in Times and Post Cases Before the Supreme Court
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 26 — Following is a transcript of the oral argument held today before the United States Supreme Court in The New York Times and The Washington Post cases. Spealzers were not identified in the official transcript, but unofficial identification has been made wherever possible.

headline: Ellsberg: From Hawk to Dove
lead_paragraph: Of the figures who have emerged from the renewed public controversy over Am erican decision‐making in Vietnam, probably none has gone through more intense changes than Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, the once hawkish analyst for the Rand Corpo ration, who became a com mitted opponent of the war he helped to shape.
author: By Paul L. Montgomery

headline: Study Said to Show Johnson Resisted Incursions
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP) —The Knight newspapers re ported today that documents from the secret Pentagon study show that United States mili tary leaders were putting pres sure on President Lyndon B. Johnson to expand the Vietnam war into Laos, Cambodia and North Vietnam in 1966 and 1967.

headline: ELLSBERG INTENDS TO GIVE UP TO U.S.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, June 26 — Two law yers representing Dr. Daniel Eilsberg said today that he would give himself up here to the Federal Government Mon day moirning.
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: National Notes
lead_paragraph: “Tony was in a hurry and wanted the job done” and was willing to pay $5,200 for it; Tony “got angry” when the job was delayed month, after month for nearly half a year and withdrew his offer; Tony was prevailed upon to provide the money again and “was supposed to know everything” that would aid in the successful completion of the job.

headline: Enemy Said to Wipe Out Three Intelligence Teams
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Juno 26 (AP) — Field informants reported to day that three teams, on intel ligence missions led by Amer icans had been wiped out be hind enemy lines in South Viet nam and Laos.

headline: Survey Finds Fear of U.S. ‘Breakdown’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 26—A national survey on the hopes and fears of the American people shows a “new and ur gent concern over national unity, political stability and law and order.”
author: By John Berbers Special to The New York Times

headline: The Detroit News Criticizes Papers for Publishing Study
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 26 (UPI) — Newspapers that have published portions of a secret Pentagon study on the origins of the Viet nam war have been used by the peace movement for a prop aganda point, The Detroit News said in a front‐page editorial in its Sunday editions.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Had it not been for the United States, the history of South Vietnam would not have included “anything that looked like a war,” declared Daniel Ellsberg at midweek. By week's end, the United States had begun trying to prove that had it not been for Mr. Ellsberg, the man reported to have leaked the “Pentagon Papers,” there would not have been anything like the wholesale disclosure of the Pentagon's private history of the in South Vietnam.

headline: Clash of Power Groups in U. S. Seen by a Soviet Commentator
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, June 26—A Soviet commentator sought to explain today how it could happen that parts of the secret Vietnam papers, evidently embarrassing to the United States Govern ment, were published in The New York Times and, other newspapers.

headline: Disengagin From Vietnam
lead_paragraph: The war in Vietnam has lasted longer than any armed conflict out side our borders in which we have been engaged in the nearly two cen turies of our independent existence, and disengagement end complete with drawal are still question mark. The conflict has engendered divided opinions, manifested in bitter and po tentially dangerous confrontations arming our people, and we still are un certain what it was We Sought and why, where we should now proceed, and what courses of action would beat servo our national interests.
author: By Matthew B. Bidgway

headline: Reports Doubted
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 26 — A Pentagon spokesman said today that it was “very unlikely” that Americans were involved in intelligence operations of the type described in reports from Saigon.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The day after the Senate approved Senator Mike Mansfield's Vietnam troop withdrawal amendment last Tuesday, the majority leader had poached eggs with the President at the White House. Perhaps Vietnam histories still to be writ ten by the Pentagon will provide a memorandum of conversation of the breakfast table encounter between Mr. Nixon and the Dem ocratic leader who had provoked a Congressional confrontation with the President's Vietnam policies.
author: —John W. Finney

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—To readers of spy novels, the words “Top Se cret” conjure up a number of visions: of windowless rooms far beneath the Pentagon where be spectacled men spend days and nights under heavy guard read ing coded messages; of armed couriers and impenetrable vaults where reams of sensitive docu ments are forever shielded from the eyes of all but a very few.
author: —John M. Crewdson

headline: MUCH OF CAMBODIA STILL HELD BY FOE
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 26—One year after the depar ture of the last American ground forces from Cambodia, the Vietnamese Communists are still in control of three‐quarters of the sparsely populated coun tryside, but most Cambodians and foreign diplomats here still believe that the enemy has his eye one South Vietnam, not on pnompenh.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Court Enjoins Post‐Dispatch; 2d Article on Study Withheld
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP)— The St. Louis Post‐Dispatch announced today that it had been restrained from further publication of articles based on the secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war.

headline: Marines ‘Lean and Mean’ For Post‐Vietnam Role
lead_paragraph: PARRIS ISLAND, S. C., June 27—The Marine Corps is still building men.
author: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Supreme Court Decision On Vietnam Study A waited
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 27—The New York Times and The Wash ington Post waited today for a Supreme Court decision on the Government's effort to prevent further publication of the Penta gon's secret history of Ameri can involvement in Vietnam.
author: By Christopher Lydon Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 27—When problems of conscience and politics are involved, the criminal law is always likely to be a crude weapon, dangerous to those who use it. That will surely be so in the case of Daniel Ellsberg. For the case may make the idea of “law,” as it has been applied in the context of Vietnam, seem an ironic reflection of distorted values.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: CROSSING OF DIG BY 2 REGIMENTS OF FOE REPORTED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27 — Military sources said to day that at‐least two North Vietnamese regiments had in filtrated across the demilitar ized zone into South Vietnam in the first large enemy move ment through the zone in about three years.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Jews Urged to Deal With National Issues
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, June 27 — Two Jewish leaders said today that American Jewish organizations were so preoccupied with Jew ish issues that they were ne glecting other problems affect ing the nation.
author: By Irving Spiegel Special to The New York Times

headline: Mayday Groups Planning New Protests
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE, June 27 — Sponsors of the Mayday anti war demonstrations in Wash ington last spring announced plans today for new demonstra tions in August and this fall, hoping that publication of the Pentagon papers would bring even more support.

headline: Washington Notes
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 27 — Within the next month or so, President Nixon and Secre tary of State William P. Rogers are expected to decide on a number of ambassadorial transfers.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Abrams a Reader at Service in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27—Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, commander of Amer ican troops in Vietnam, and United States Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker were lay readers in a sparsely attend ed Ecumenical Service of Prayer for Peace, Brother hood and Christian Unity this afternoon in the Roman Cath olic Cathedral here.

headline: 1961: J.F.K., Rusk and McNamara confer
lead_paragraph: The furor over the Pentagon Papers has been exciting for reporters, lucra tive for lawyers, intriguing for readers in the general public and conceivably even enlightening—although the possi bility is great that misleading would be a more accurate word. The question now is whether the nation can derive from the experience some positive and lasting benefit.
author: By Roger Hilsman

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Boy Who Aided Vietcong Says He Was Tortured by the Police
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, June 16—“I am so frightened,” the 12‐year‐old boy who had worked for the Vietcong whis pered over and over.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: 1961: J.F.K., Rusk and McNamara confer
lead_paragraph: BONN‐I can scarcely imagine any journalist of any country who reads of the struggle of The New York Times to publish the Vietnam papers not feel ing involved. Seldom has the natural born conflict between Government and press presented itself in such a repre sentative fashion.
author: By Rudolf Augstein

headline: U.S. PULLOUT PLAN IN 1962 REPORTED
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Tuesday, June 29 (AP)—The Christian Science Monitor, printing what it said were excerpts from hitherto unpublished portions of the secret Pentagon papers, report ed today that for 21 months in 1962–64 the United States “laid plans to pull almost all Ameri can troops out of Vietnam over a five‐year period.”

headline: Ellsberg Yields, Is Indicted; Says He Cave Data to Press
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, June 28—Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, deplored today that he had given the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war to the press. Moments later he surrendered to the United States Attorney here for arraignment on charges of unauthorized possession of secret documents.
author: By Robert Reinhold Special to The New York Times

headline: HOUSE REJECTS VIETNAM PULLOUT VOTED BY SENATE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 28 — The House refused today to ac cept a Senate amendment call ing for withdrawal of troops from Vietnam in nine months if American prisoners of war were released by North Viet nam.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: LAIRD SEES PERIL IN $7‐BILLION CUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 28 — Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird warped Congress today that a proposed out of $7‐billion In military spending would have a “catastrophic impact” on de fense programs.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: DECISION DELAYED ON VIETNAM STUDY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 28—The Supreme Court put off today a decision on the Government's efforts to block The New York Times and The Washington Post from publishing, material from the Pentagon papers on Vietnam.

headline: They Mouthed Morality
lead_paragraph: Walt Rostow has stated the moral case for the war in Vietnam in these pages. No one who knows Mr. Ros tow doubts his sincerity or depth of moral commitment. But the issue is not what it has been said to be— that those who made the decisions about the war were indifferent to Moral considerations. The issue is the impersonal one as to the actual nature of these considerations, and the kind of logic that should be used in thinking about them.
author: By Charles Frankel

headline: House Vote on Withdrawal
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP)—Following is the roll‐call vote by which the House rejected today the Senate's call for troop withdrawal front Indochina in nine months if United States prisoners of war were released by North Vietnam. The vote was on killing a motion to order House conferees to accept the Senate provision.

headline: Amnesty Group Says Saigon Bars Inspection of P.O.W. Camps
Congress Gets Pentagon Papers, Locks Them Up
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 28 — The pentagon papers, packed in cardboard boxes marked “top secret,” were delivered to Con gross today and quickly planed in locked vaults.
author: By Marjorie Hunter Special to The New York Times

headline: MISSISSIPPI BLACK CHARGES JOB BIAS

headline: Coast Jury Acts
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 28—Among the other debates set off by publica tion of the Pentagon Papers is one on the solemn question whether the John son Administration lied to the people, while escalating the Vietnam war, or merely misled them artfully.
author: BY Tom Wicker

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: There is one sentence in your editorial of June 21 “The Vietnam Papers,” that does more to spotlight the whys and wherefores of our in volvement in Vietnam than all the volumes and essays that have been written to date on this subject . . . “not venality, not evil motivation, but rather an arrogant disregard for the Congress, for the public, and for the inherent obligation of the responsibili ties of leadership in a democratic society.”
author: Charles J. Donohoe Jr

headline: U.S. Troops in Vietnam Decrease to 241,700
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28 (AP) — The United States command announced today that American troop strength in Vietnam decreased by 3,200 men last week and totaled 241,700 last Thurs day. It was the lowest total since the end of March, 1966, when there were 231,200 American servicemen in the country.

headline: We Have to Make Them Listen
lead_paragraph: It is said that “power corrupts, and absolute power corrupts absolutely.“ We could probably expand that to include nearly absolute power corrupt ing nearly absolutely.
author: By Richard J. Donahue

headline: SAIGON'S TROOPS REOCCUPY CAMP
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 29 (AP) — The South Vietnamese command an nounced yesterday that its troops had reoccupied a dev astated artillery outpost that had been abandoned last week just below the demilitarized zone.

headline: Mr. Nixon and the Prisoner Smokescreen
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N. J.—The basic con cern that emerges front extended new discussions with the delegations to the Paris peace talks of North Vietnam and the Provisional Revolutionary Government of South Vietnam is their continuing belief that the prisoner issue is a smokescreen behind which President Nixon intends to go on with the war.
author: By Richard Falk

headline: 3 Ask U.S. to Release '53 China Study
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 28— Three prominent China scholars called on the Nixon Adminis tration today to release the secret portions of a State De pertinent study of the Chinese civil war.
author: By Terience Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Pro‐Regime Student Leader Slain at Saigon University
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28 (AP) — A pro‐Govern ment student leader was shot and killed today in a Saigon University courtyard 10 days after he was named deputy chairman of the “Saigon Student Union.

headline: Veterans' School Aid Urged
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI)—Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland, introduced legisla tion today designed to grant $1,000 a year to Vietnam vet erans who want to continue their education. The bill also would direct the Veterans Ad ministration to pay eligible veterans up to $175 monthly subsistence.

headline: It Was and Is the Most Open of Wars
author: By Barry Zorthian

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: It is stunning, literally, to see W. W. Rostow (Op‐Ed June 22) still pushing the domino theory, and the other theories that have bloodied his hands and your hands and Lieutenant Galley's hands and my hands and the hands or all U.S. citizens.
author: Edwin Kennebecic

headline: ABORTION BACKED BY UNITED CHURCH
lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 29—The biennial general synod of the two‐million‐member United Church of Christ ended its five‐day meeting here to night after calling for the re peal of all legal prohibitions of physician‐performed abortions.
author: By George Dugan Special to The New York Times

headline: Air Force to Try Officer For Part in War Protest
lead_paragraph: LAKENHEATH, England, June 29 (AP)—The United States Air Force today or dered Capt. Thomas L. Cul ver, accused of having vio lated military law by demon strating against the Vietnam war, to face a general court martial.

headline: The Personal Touch
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Whatever may be the value of the Pentagon Papers to historians, they offer to the political philosopher an invaluable insight into the essentially personal character of our Government and its tendency to insulate the American people from the hard debates from which vital policies flow.
author: By George E. Reedy

headline: Torture and Blubber
lead_paragraph: WEST BARNSTABLE, Mass.—When I was a young reader of Robin Hood tales and “The White Company” by Arthur Conan Doyle and so on, I came across the verb “blubber” so often that I looked it up. Bad people in the stories did it when good people pun ished them hard. It means, of course, to weep noisily and without constraint. No gpod person in a story ever did that.
author: By Kurt Vonnegut Jr

headline: The Very Big Lie Technique
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Daniel Ellsberg hasn't told the rest of us anything we didn't already know. He just gave us the names and dates.
author: By. David Harris

headline: The Screen: 'Glory Boy':Violence Is Outcome of Veterans' Return
lead_paragraph: Some movies, often the very greatest, are genuinely difficult. Some others, never the greatest, are merely obscure. It is in this second category, films that by their own confusions and inadequacies fail to make the kind of sense they so unclearly intend, that Edwin Sherin's "Glory Boy," which opened yesterday at the Baronet and Forum theaters, belongs."Glory Boy" is yet another movie made not about, but under the shadow of, the Vietnam War. When its young hero (Michael Moriarty) returns home to his father's run-down farm north of San Francisco, he brings with him a stupid but relatively harmless Army buddy (William Devane) and a Regular Army sergeant (Mitchell Ryan) who is more or less waiting put his 30 days before re-enlisting.The sergeant is no friend, merely somebody picked up because his stern jaw, his medals and his military manner will please the old man. But behind his tough exterior seethes a soul of sulfuric acid, and after he has humiliated dad, knocked unconscious a hitchhiking college girl (Topo Swope) so as to rape her, and dynamited the fish in the trout stream, it becomes fairly obvious that he is a one-man social, moral and ecological disaster.Between the father (Arthur Kennedy) and the sergeant there is a certain equivalence, for the old man has in gentler ways ruined everything he has touched (so you shouldn't miss the point, he keeps praising the farm as a Garden of Eden) and he too represents the militarism of an age—the age of World War II. The film recognizes that the two wars are not equal—the father is fallen from sentimental ideals; the sergeant is pure evil force—but symbolically and, at last, literally, the two cancel each other out.I think this is the most significant action in "Glory Boy," though there are several others, and there is a whole household full of representative types—including the girl who, unaccountably, comes back to cook and clean and put flowers on the dining room table. But except for what fits together all too neatly, nothing seems to belong with anything else, and it all feels like watching a series of strung-together three-minute sketches. Sherin's direction stresses action in the middle distance not all that bad, but limiting and the multiplication of pregnant pauses — so that sometimes it looks as though the actors really are standing around wondering what to do next.Almost everybody figures out something reasonable in time—except for William Devane, who plays for a kind of instant insanity and ends up suggesting, say, Jerry Lewis as Macbeth. But the two principle kids, Michael Moriarty and Topo Swope, really are something special—appealing without courting appeal, sympathetic without the production of any unnecessary charm. Michael Moriarty particularly brings a rather intricate intelligence to an almost incomprehensible role. But both he and Miss Swope introduce a quality I should never have expected in this movie—a quality of articulate and active lucidity.
author: By Roger Greenspun

headline: Early U.S. Choices in Indochina
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) —The Pentagon study, as read by Senator Gravel, concluded that United States involvement in Indochina began with a choice between supporting French colonialism or Ho Chi Minh Communism and that the United States sided with the French.

headline: SESSION ON P.O.W.'S HEARS V.F.W. CHIEF
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 29— Herbert R. Rainwater, the com mander in chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, told a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee today that a “logical approach” to the problem of American prisoners of war in Indochina “would be to have Hanoi set a date for our withdrawal con tingent upon the release of our men.”

headline: Gravel Speaks 3 Hours
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, June 30—Senator Mike Gravel read to reporters last night. what he said were parts of the Pentagon papers on the history of the United States involve ment in Indochina.
author: By David E: Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Plane Shot Down
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 29 (AP) — Enemy gun ners reportedly continued to shell several fire bases just south of the demilitarized zone and shot down a United States fighter‐bomber.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Mrs. Richard M. Nixon was decorated yesterday with the Grand Cross of the Order of the Sun, the highest honor bestowed by Peru.

headline: U.S. Won't Curb Monitor
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 29 — The Justice Department said today that it would not move to enjoin The Christian Science Monitor from continuing its series on the Vietnam war. The decision followed a brief dis cussion with the editors about the articles not yet published.
author: By Marjorie Hunter Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I have been following with great interest the case of the publication of the secret Pentagon documents on Vietnam. The sensitivity of the pub lished material is being debated. In my opinion, the most important Issue in this case is the way this information was obtained. Even if the publication of these “historic documents” would not “severely damage the national in terest,” the fraudulent manner of their acquisition creates a very dangerous precedent.
author: DENNIS D. AGALLIANOS Brattleboro, Vt., June 22, 1971

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Roger Fisher, in his Op‐Ed article of June 22, states, as if any reasonable man would agree, that “there is no doubt but that the Government should be able to classify as Secret or Top Secret documents involving the con fidential planning of high military and political strategy.” What a colossal conceit.
author: Albert Fauross

headline: U.S. Ignored Ho Chi Minh Pleas For Aid, Monitor Article Says
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Wednesday, June 30 (AP)—The Christian Science Monitor said today that the United States “ignored eight direct appeals for aid fro mthe North Vietnamese Communist leader, Ho Chi Minh, in the first five winter months following the end of World War II.”

headline: Saigon Generals Doubt Foe Gains Strength Near DMZ
lead_paragraph: DONGHA, South Vietnam, June 29—Two South Vietna mese generals today countered reports of a mounting enemy offensive just south of the de militarized zone by saying there actually were fewer Com munist troops in the area than in previous years.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: White House Cable to Lodge On Pressure for Saigon Reforms
lead_paragraph: Cablegram from White House to Ambassador Lodge, Sept. 17, 1963. The Pentagon study says this message followed a meeting of the National Security Council but adds, “There is no evidence on the degree of consensus of the principals in this decision.”

lead_paragraph: Excerpts from memorandum for President Kennedy from Secretary McNamara and General Taylor, dated Oct. 2, 1963, and headed “Report of McNamara Taylor Mission to South Vietnam.”

lead_paragraph: Cablegram from Secretary Rush to Ambassador Lodge, Aug. 29, 1963. The Pentagon study says the message followed a meeting of the National Security Council.

headline: Bar on Boston Globe Lifted
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, June 30—A tem porary restraining order bar ring The Boston Globe from printing articles based on its copies of the Pentagon docu ments was lifted today almost immediately after the Supreme Court announcement.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Charles M. Martin

headline: Shock for Washington
lead_paragraph: Six days later the dam broke. South Vietnamese Special Forces troops in white helmets carried out midnight raids against Buddhist pagodas throughout the country. More than 1,400 people, mostly monks, were arrested and many of them beaten. Two days later, the army generals conspiring against President Diem first sought official American sup port.

headline: 1961 Rusk‐McNamara Report To Kennedy on South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from memorandum for President Kennedy from Secretary of State Rusk and Secretary of Defense McNamara, Nov. 11, 1961, as provided by the Pentagon study.

lead_paragraph: Cablegram from McGeorge Bundy to Ambassador Lodge, Oct. 25, 1963.

lead_paragraph: Cablegram from Ambassador Lodge to McGeorge Bundy, Oct. 30, 1963. The Pentagon study identifies this message as a reply to Mr. Bundy's cablegram.

headline: Questions for Kennedy
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon study shows President Kennedy facing three main questions on Vietnam during his term of office'whether to make an irrevocable com mitment to prevent a Communist vic tory; whether to commit ground combat units to achieve his ends; whether to give top priority to the military battle against the Vietcong or to the political reforms necessary for winning popular support.

headline: Notes on Kennedy Meeting On Diem Regime in July, 1963
lead_paragraph: Memorandum by Roger Hilsman, Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, on a meeting held at the White House July 4, 1963. Besides President Kennedy and Mr. Hilsman, participants were Under Secretary State George Ball; Under Secretary of State Averell Harriman; McGeorge Bundy, Presidential assistant for national security, and Michael V. Forrestal, Southeast Asia specialist on the White House staff.

headline: Aftermath of Decision

author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Texts of the Supreme Court Decision, Opinions and Dissents in Times‐Post Case
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 30—Following is the text of the decision by the United States Supreme Court upholding The New York Times and The Washington Post against an effort by the Federal Government to halt publication of articles and documents based on the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war and the texts of the concurring and dissenting opinions:

headline: Highlights of the Period
lead_paragraph: The Kennedy Administration's “com plicity” in the 1963 overthrow of Presi dent Ngo Dinh Diem is documented in the Pentagon study, which says that this episode “inadvertently deepened” United States involvement in the Vietnam con flict.

headline: Highlights of the Period
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon study reaches no con clusion as to how the course of the Vietnam war might have changed if John F. Kennedy had lived—but it sums up the Kennedy years as a time of significantly deepening United States involvement.

headline: U.S. Ambassador's '60 Analysis Of Threats to Saigon Regime
lead_paragraph: Following are texts of key documents accompanying the Pentagon's study of the Vietnam war, dealing with the Ad ministration of President John F. Kennedy up to the events that brought the overthrow of President Ngo Dinh Diem in 1963. Except where excerpting is specified, the documents are printed verbatim, with only unmistakable typographical errors cor rected.

headline: '61 Memo From the Joint Chiefs On Commitment of U.S. Forces
lead_paragraph: Memorandum on “U.S. Forces in South Vietnam” from the Joint Chiefs of Staff to Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara, May 10, 1961.

headline: Times Vietnam Series and Pentagon Texts Due in Paperback
lead_paragraph: A complete collection of The New York Times series on the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war, including texts of docu ments, will be published in paperback by Bantam Books next week.
author: By Henry Raymont

headline: Kissinger to Visit Saigon On 10‐Day Overseas Tour
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) —Henry A. Kissinger, Presi dent Nixon's national security affairs adviser, will leave to morrow on a 10‐day fact‐find ing mission that will take him to South Vietnam and other Far Eastern countries and then to Paris, the White House said today.

headline: Diem at the Fulcrum
lead_paragraph: President Kennedy's decision in May deferred—but did not settle—the issue of combat troops for South Vietnam. Throughout the summer and fall of 1961 the Administration's debate on that crucial matter was significantly affected by the attitude of President Diem, according to the Pentagon account. Initially, it relates, Vice President John: son found the South Vietnamese leader reluctant; in midsummer he warmed to the idea somewhat; by fall he was ap pealing to the United States to become a co‐belligerent.

headline: Let's Declassify
lead_paragraph: More than half a century ago Wood row Wilson called for “open covenants openly arrived at.” It was a good idea then, although the other statesmen of the time didn't think so. They made a lot of secret deals, and a generation later the world had its biggest war yet.
author: By Richard Hudson

headline: Cable From Taylor to Kennedy On Introduction of U.S. Troops
lead_paragraph: Cablegram from Baguio, the Philippines, by General Taylor to President Kennedy, Nov. 1, 1931.

headline: ELLSBERG CALLS DECISION ‘GREAT’
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 30 —Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, who has said he gave the Pentagon pa pers to the press, praised the Supreme Court decision today as “a great one.”

headline: Pentagon Papers: Study Reports Kennedy Made ‘Gamble’ Into a ‘Broad Commitment’
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon's study of the Vietnam war concludes that President John F. Kennedy transformed the “limited‐risk gamble” of the Eisenhower Administra tion into a “broad commitment” to pre vent Communist domination of South Vietnam.
author: By Hedrick Smith

headline: 96 Navy Addicts ‘Confess’
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30 (AP) — The United States Navy said today that 96 men had turned themselves in during the first Trial month of its dung amnesty program in South Vietnam. The program is being extended indefinitely.

Besides General Krulak, participants were Vice President Johnson; Secretary Rusk; Secretary McNamara; Deputy Secre tary of Defense Roswell L. Gilpatric; McGeorge Bundy; General Taylor; Edward R., Murrow, director of the United States Information Agency; Lieut. Gen. Murshall S. Carter, Deputy Directon of the Central Intelligence Agency; Richard Helms and William E. Colby of the C.I.A.; Frederick E. Notting Jr., former Am bassador in Saigon; Assistant Secretary Hilsman, and Paul M. Kattenburg the State Department, head of the Interdepartmental Working Group Vietnam.

headline: ‘FINAL’ BATTLE SEEN DURING 1973 BY THIEU
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30 (UPI) — President Nguyen Van Thieu forecast to day a “final confrontation” be tween South and North Viet namese military forces in 1973 after completion of United States and allied troop with drawls.

headline: ‘An Enlightened People’
lead_paragraph: The historic decision of the Supreme Court in the case of the United States Government vs. The New York Times and The Washington Post is a ringing victory for freedom under law. By lifting the restraining order that had pre vented this and other newspapers from publishing the hitherto secret Pentagon Papers, the nation's highest tribunal strongly reaffirmed the guarantee of the peo ple's right to know, implicit in the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States.

headline: State Department Study in Late '62 On Prospects in South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from research memorandum from Roger Hilsman, director of the State Department Bureau of Intelligence and Research, to Secretary of State Rush, Dec. 3, 1962. The memorandum bore the title “The Situation and Short Term Prospects in South Vietnam” and a footnote said that the report was based on information available through Nov. 12, 1962.

headline: ‘Political Decay’
lead_paragraph: Until the eruption of Buddhist demon strations against the Diem regime in May, 1963, much of the American pub lic was oblivious to the “political de cay” in Vietnam described in the Pen tagon account: the atmosphere of sus picion, the pervasive but latent disaf fection with the autocratic Diem regime, the taint of corruption, the suppressed discontent in the Army.

headline: Further Rusk Cable to Lodge On. Diem‐Nhu Relationship
lead_paragraph: Cablegram from Secretary Rush to Ambassador Lodge, Aug. 29, 1963.

headline: Memo From Joint Chiefs Urging A Greater Role in South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from memorandum from the Joint Chiefs of Staff to Secretary of Defense McNamara, Jan. 13, 1962. On Jan. 27, 1962, Mr. McNamara sent memorandum to President Kennedy with a covering letter that said in part: “The Joint Chiefs of Staff have asked that the attached memorandum . . .be brought to your attention. The memorandum requires no action by you at this time. I am not prepared to endorse the experience with our present program in South Vietnam.”

headline: Most Congressional Leaders Applaud Court Decision
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 30— Congressional leaders today generally applauded the Su preme Court decision on publi cation of material from Penta gon papers.

headline: Sulzberger Expresses ‘Complete Joy’ at Ruling
lead_paragraph: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York. Times, said yester day that his reaction to the Supreme. Court's decision was “one of complete joy and de light.”

McNamara, Deputy Secretary of Defense Roswell Gilpatric, Secretary of State Dean Rush, Allen W. Dulles, Director of Central Intelligence, and Gen. C. P. headline: McNamara as Speer
lead_paragraph: PARIS—In his memoirs, Albert Speer quotes a 1944 article in The London Observer that described him as “a type which is becoming increas ingly important in all belligerent countries: The pure technician, the classless bright young man without background, with no other original aim than to make his way in the world, and no other means than his technical and managerial ability. It the lack of psychological and spiritual ballast, and the ease with which he handles the terrifying technical and organizational machinery of our age, which makes this type go far now adays. This is their age; the Hitlers and Himmlers we may get rid of, but the Speers, whatever happens to this particular special man, will long be with us.”
author: By Sanche de Gramont

headline: Kennedy Position on Coup Plots
lead_paragraph: Cablegram from White House to Ambassador Lodge, transmitted on Central Intelligence Agency channel, Oct. 5, 1963. The Pentagon study says this mes sage emanated from a meeting of the National Security Council.

lead_paragraph: Cablegram from the United States Embassy in Saigon to the State Depart ment, Oct. 1, 1961. A copy of the message was sent to the commander in chief of Pacific forces.

headline: U.S. and Diem's Overthrow: Step by Step
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon's, secret study of the Vietnam war discloses that President Kennedy knew and approved of plans for the military coup d'état that over threw President Ngo Dinh Diem in 1963.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Max Salvadori

headline: A Challenge for the U.S.
lead_paragraph: However serious the problem in South Vietnam, the situation in Laos was far more critical. “The Western position was in the process of falling, apart as Ken nedy took office,” the Pentagon account says.

headline: Court Move Hailed At Washington Post; More Articles Due
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 30 — Executives of The Washington Post applauded the Supreme Court's decision today and pub lished in their Thursday issue, three articles based on their partial collection of the Penta gon, papers.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 30—Back in the fifties, Mort Sahl used to recite what was then considered a bitter portrayal of the Nixon family at home. Mrs. Nixon, as the story went, was sitting on one side of the fireplace, knitting an American flag. Mr. Nixon was sitting on the other side of the fireplace, reading the Constitution— in search of loopholes.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Use of U.S. Troops Decided in April '65
lead_paragraph: President Johnson decided on April 1, 1965, to use Ameri can ground troops for offensive action in South Vietnam be cause the Administration quickly found that sustained bombing of North Vietnam— begun on March 2—was not going to stave off collapse in South Vietnam.

headline: Fighting Intensifies Below DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 1 (AP)—Fight ing intensified yesterday along South Vietnam's northern fron tier just below the demilita rized zone.

headline: New Omens of Peril
lead_paragraph: In what the analyst calls the first flush of self‐satisfaction, Ambassador Lodge cabled Washington on Nov. 4 pre dicting that the change of regime would shorten the war against the Vietcong be cause of the improved morale in the South Vietnamese Army.

headline: A Sterner Objective
lead_paragraph: On May 11, two days after Vice President Johnson's departure for Sai gon, President Kennedy made his deci sions. As recorded in National Security Action Memorandum 52, a copy of which accompanies the Pentagon study, the. American objective was stated more bluntly and more ambitiously than in typical public pronouncements. The memorandum said the American objec tive was “to prevent Communist domi nation of South Vietnam,” whereas six days earlier President Kennedy him self spoke at a news conference of vaguer desire “to assist Vietnam to ob tain its independence.”

headline: Colby, U.S. Chief of Pacification for Vietnam, Gives Up Duties and Returns Home
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30—William E. Colby, the chief of the American pacifica tion effort in South Vietnam, gave up his duties today and flew home to Washington be cause of the illness of a daughter.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: BURGER DISSENTS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 30— The Supreme Court freed The New York Times and The Wash ington Post today to resume immediate publication of arti cles based on the secret Penta gon papers on the origins of the Vietnam war.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: Leading Figures at Time of Coup

Alexis Johnson, Deputy Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, and was either a “talking paper” for a meeting that included Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Secretary of Defense McNamara “or a revision put together later in the day, after the meeting.”

headline: Covert Warfare Sponsored by U.S. in '64
lead_paragraph: President Lyndon B. Johnson's Administration, amid his hesita tion and reluctance to take final decisions, was sponsoring co vert South Vietnamese warfare against North Vietnam starting in February, 1964, and drawing up plans that spring for overt war.

headline: ‘Consensus’ on Bombing Reached Before the Election
lead_paragraph: Leaders of the Johnson Ad ministration reached a “con sensus” at a White House strategy meeting on Sept. 7, 1964, the Pentagon study of the war says, that sustained air attacks against North Vietnam would probably have to be launched, and indicated a start for early 1965.

headline: Vietnam ‘Program of Action’ By Kennedy's Task Force
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from “A Program of Action for South Vietnam,” May 8, 1961, presented to President Kennedy by an interdepartmental task force comprising representatives from the Departments of State and Defense, the Central Intelli gence Agency, the International Cooperation Administration, the United States Information Agency and the Office of the President.

headline: ACTION BY GRAVEL VEXES SENATORS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 30— Many Senators privately ex pressed dismay, shock and chagrin today at Senator Mike Gravel's release of parts of the Pentagon's secret study of the Vietnam war. But it appeared that no disciplinary action would be taken against the Alaska Democrat.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Intelligence Estimate on '63 Unrest
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from Special National Intelligence Estimate 53‐2‐63, “The Situation in South Vietnam,” July 10, 1963.

headline: Notes on McNamara Memorandum For Johnson After Vietnam Visit
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from notes accompanying the Pentagon study, from memo randum for President Lyndon B. Johnson from Secretary McNamara, Nov. 1965.

headline: Memo on Pentagon Meeting Following Up Honolulu Session
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from memorandum by Richard C. Steadman, special assistant Secretary of Defense McNamara, Feb. 9, 1966, summarizing a Pentagon meet ing after the Honolulu talks. According to Mr. Steadman the participants eluded the Secretary, his deputies, the secretaries of each of the armed services and other Defense Department officials.

headline: Impetuous Senator Maurice Robert Gravel
lead_paragraph: Man in the News
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U. S. Aide Says Pullout Will Benefit Vietnamese
lead_paragraph: QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, June 30—Marco Mendez, the senior American adviser in Quangtri Province, the South Vietnamese province closest to the demilitarized zone, says he thinks it will be a good thing for the Americans to leave here even if the 10,000 North Viet namese troops later seize con trol of the province.
author: By Craig It Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: On the Morality of the War
lead_paragraph: DETROIT—The military involvement of the United States in Southeast Asia is more than a hotly debated political issue. “Vietnam” is an urgent moral question demanding an examination by all thinking Americans. That war is always a moral matter should be clear enough.
