Political and military policies which provide soldiers and weapons for the purposes of death and destruc tion require a moral judgment of the individual citizens with whose tax money and, in some cases, very lives those policies are implemented.
author: By Thomas J. Gumbleton

headline: Priests of Vietnam
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.—In Paris re cently I concelebrated mass with two Catholic priests from North Vietnam. It was a memorable experience for me and several other American priests to join in the official liturgy of the church with those whom our Govern ment considers the enemy.
author: By Richard B. Griffin

headline: Further McNaughton Memo On Factors in Bombing Decision
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from memorandum by Assistant Secretary of Defense McNaugh ton, “Some Paragraphs on Vietnam,” third draft, Jan. 19, 1966, as provided the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the analysts' para phrase or explanation.

headline: Week's G.I. Death Toll One of Lowest of War
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 1 (AP)—The continuing disengagement of American forces from the war zone was reflected again today in the United States command's weekly casualty summary, which reported 21 Americans killed in action last week.

headline: White House Is Exploring Offer Made in Paris Talks
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 1—The White House began explor ing today the possibility that the latest Vietcong proposal at the Paris peace talks might form the basis for serious negotiations to end the war in Vietnam.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: State Department Memorandum In November on Bombing Pause
lead_paragraph: Following are texts of key documents accompanying the Pen tagon's study of the Vietnam war, covering the period late 1965 to the summer of 1966. Except where excerpting is specified, the documents are printed verbatim, with only unmistakable typographical errors corrected.

headline: Notes From McNamara Memo On Course of War in 1966
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from notes accompanying the Pentagon study, from a memo randum for President Johnson from Secretary McNamara, “Military and Political Actions Recommended for South Vietnam,” Dec. 7, 1965, and notes on revision of the memo, Jan. 24, 1966.

headline: Johnson's Remarks to Officials Of U.S. and Saigon at Honolulu
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from remarks by President Johnson to senior United States and South Vietnamese after the issuance of a joint communiqué at their Honolulu conference, Feb. 9, 1966, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. The paragraph in italics is the study's explanation.

headline: Heavy B‐52 Raids Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Friday, July 2 (AP) —Seven waves of United States B‐52's attacked North Viet namese positions just below the demilitarized zone yester day in the heaviest concen trated raids since last August, the United States command said.

headline: Cable From Westmoreland In August on Manpower Needs
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from cablegram from General Westmoreland to Gen. Earle G. Wheeler Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Adm. U. S. Grant Sharp, commander in chief of Pacific forces, Aug. 10, 1966, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study.

headline: We Must Get Out, Not Sometime, but Now!
lead_paragraph: AMHERST, Mass. — The American people are being asked to believe that Vietnamization is working, and that within the foreseeable future we will be able to bring all our farces home. It must be realized, however, that this dubious possibility is contingent upon our being able to leave in Saigon strong government sympathetic to our purposes, a result we have been un able to achieve through seventeen years of unremitting effort.
author: By William Wallace Ford

headline: Leading U.S. Military Planners
lead_paragraph: William Childs Westmoreland

headline: Bombing and a Pause
lead_paragraph: In April, 1965, when President John son secretly changed the mission of the Marines at Danang from defense to of fense and thus commited the United States to the ground war in Vietnam, the sustained bombing of North Vietnam was relegated to a secondary role, the Pentagon study declares. Discussing this bombing campaign, known as Operation Rolling Thunder, the study adds:

headline: Hanoi Hails Chinese Party
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 1 (Agence France‐Presse)—The Hanoi press today gave promi nent treatment to the 50th an niversary of the Chinese Com munist party and published on its front pages the text of a message of congratulations.

headline: Minnesota Asks to See Pentagon Study in Court
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, July 1 — The Minnesota Attorney Gen eral asked the Federal Gov ernment today to bring all 47 volumes of the Pentagon study into court.

headline: U.S. Air Strike on Rocket Sites Reported in Foe's Part of DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, July 2 (UPI) — Nineteen United States planes reportedly have attacked part of the North Vietnamese side of the demili tarized zone in an attempt to destroy enemy rocket sites that have been firing at allied bases for two weeks.

headline: McNaughton Memo for McNamara On Anti‐Infiltration Barrier Plan
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from a memorandum to Secretary of Defense McNamara, “A Bar rier Strategy,” as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. According the narrative, the memorandum is unsigned but is by Assistant Secretary Defense McNaughton, in whose handwriting the copy is marked “1/30/66” and “copy given to RSM 3/22/66.” The study further says that the document is based on a draft memo of Jan. 3, 1966, “A Barrier Strategy,” by Prof. Roger D. Fisher of Harvard Law School.

headline: U.S. Announces Biggest Single Vietnam Pullout Yet
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 1 —The United States today announced the largest single withdrawal of American troops since the phased pullouts began two years ago.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: ELLEN ASSERTS OTHERS AIDED HIM
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 1 — Dr. Daniel Ellsberg said to day that “other individuals,” whom he would not identify, had assisted him in distributing to the press the secret Penta gon papers on Vietnam. He said that he was the primary source for all the newspapers that have published articles based on the documents.
author: By Robert Reinhold Special to The New York Times

headline: Rostow's Memo on Bombing Of Hanoi's Petroleum Facilities
lead_paragraph: Excerpt from memorandum from Walt W. Rostow, Presidential assistant for, national security, to Secretary of State Rusk and Secretary of Defense. McNamara, May 6, 1966, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Para graphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

headline: VIETCONG OFFER TO TRADE P.O.W'S FOR MAT IN '71
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 1 — The Viet namese Communists announced at the peace talks here today that they were ready to re lease all war prisoners they hold in North and South Viet nam by the end of this year if all American troops are with drawn by then.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Bombing Evaluation By Institute for Defense Analyses
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from report by Institute for Defense Analyses, “The Effects U.S. Bombing on North Vietnam's Ability to Support Military Operations South Vietnam: Retrospect and Prospect, Aug. 29, 1966, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

headline: The Fuel‐Depot Issue
lead_paragraph: During the spring of 1966, the Pen tagon study says, the question of bomb ing North Vietnam's oil‐storage tanks became a “major policy dispute.”

headline: Text of the Vietcong Peace Proposal
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 1 (Reuters)— Following is the text of the Vietcong's seven‐point peace proposal presented at today's session of the Vietnam peace talks:

headline: Doubts Start to Emerge
lead_paragraph: The ineffectiveness of Rolling Thunder and General Westmoreland's mounting demand for troops soon began to create doubts among the “Vietnam principals,” the Pentagon study says. During the pause in the bombing, both Mr. Mc Naughton and Secretary McNamara wrote lengthy memorandums outlining the change in their feelings.

headline: Pentagon Papers: Vietnam Study Links '65 ‐'66 G. I. Build‐Up to Faulty Planning
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon's secret study of the Vietnam war indicates that the rapid expansion of American forces in 1965 and 1966 occurred because “no one really foresaw what the troop needs in Vietnam would be” and be cause the ability of the enemy forces “to build up their effort was con sistently underrated.”
author: By Fox Butterfield

headline: Opening in Paris?
lead_paragraph: The Communist offer to release all prisoners of war if the United States agrees to withdraw its forces from Vietnam by the end of this year may open the way to a breakthrough at the Paris peace talks.

headline: Open‐Ended Strategy
lead_paragraph: When President Johnson decided in July, 1965, to accept General Westmore land's request for 44 combat battalions and to endorse his search‐and‐destroy strategy, he “left the U.S. commitment to Vietnam open‐ended,” the study, declares.

headline: DECISION ON PAPERS IS HAILED IN JAPAN
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, July 1 — All major newspapers here gave the Su preme Court decision on The New York Times and Washing ton Post banner headlines and devoted several pages to ex tensive analysis of the issues involved.

headline: House Unit, 25‐13, Votes to Cite C.B.S., Stanton for Contempt
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 1—The House Commerce Committee voted today to press a con tempt of Congress citation against the Columbia Broad casting System and its presi dent, Dr. Frank Stanton, for re fusing to cooperate with a Congressional investigation of the controversial documentary “The Selling of the Pentagon.” The vote was 25 to 13.
author: By Christopher Lydon Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON NETWORKS SHUN DISCLOSURES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 1—The radio and televi sion networks here, which are controlled by the Government, have virtually been directed to ignore all mention of the con tents of the Pentagon papers.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Highlights of the Period
lead_paragraph: The United States military effort in Vietnam, according to the Pentagon study, continued to intensify—both on the ground and in the air—throughout 1965 and well into 1966, despite con tinuing evidence that this escalation was bringing “an acceptable outcome” no closer to realization.

headline: August McNamara Memo to Chiefs Challenging Troop Request
lead_paragraph: Memorandum, “CINCPAC CY 1966 Adjusted Requirements & CY 1967” from Secretary McNamara to the Joint Chiefs of Staff Aug. 5, 1966, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study.

headline: A London View of U.S. Presidents and Their Trials
lead_paragraph: The following is excerpted from commentary by The Economist of London:

headline: Mitchell Will Prosecute Law Violations in Leaks
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 1—At torney General John N. Mitchell said today that the Justice De partment was continuing to investigate the leaking of the Pentagon papers and he prom ised to prosecute anyone who had broken the law.

headline: Joint Chiefs' Order to Begin Bombing of Hanoi's Oil Facilities
lead_paragraph: Joint Chiefs of Staff's cablegram to Adm. U. S. Grant Sharp, commander in chief of Pacific forces, June 22, 1966, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study.

headline: CHARGE BY ENEMY REPORTED HALTED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 2 (AP) — Three hundred North Vietnamese reportedly charged up a mountain near the demilitarized zone last night but were turned back short of their objective, the artillery outpost at the top called Fire Base Fuller.

headline: Joint Chiefs' Memo Disputing McNamara View on Bombing
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from Joint Chiefs of Staff memorandum, signed by Gen. Earle Wheeler, Chairman, to Secretary of Defense McNamara., Oct. 14, 1966, as pro vided in the body of the Pentagon study.

headline: William Bundy's May 30 Memo On Reasons for U.S. Involvement
lead_paragraph: Excerpts front memorandum from Assistant Secretary of State Bundy, Circu lated at State and Defense Departments, May 30, 1967, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase explanation.

headline: Fist Fights Disrupt Peace Rally Here
lead_paragraph: Fist fights and brawling erupted continuously among participants at a peace rally last night, interrupting speech es, including one by a United States Senator who actively op poses the war.
author: By Steven R. Weisman

headline: Vietcong Offer Poses a Dilemma
lead_paragraph: News Analysis
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Joint Chiefs' April 20 Report To McNamara on Troop Needs
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from Joint Chiefs of Staff Memorandum 218‐67 to Secretary of Defense McNamara, April 20, 1967, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

headline: Pentagon Papers: McNamara, in '66, Urged Bombing Cutback and Softer Peace Terms
lead_paragraph: Robert S. McNamara, while Secretary of Defense, sought to persuade President Lyndon B. Johnson in October, 1966, to cut back the bombing of North Vietnam to seek a political settlement of the war —17 months before Mr. Johnson made that move on March 31, 1968.
author: By Hedrick Smith

headline: McGeorge Bundy's Memorandum To Johnson in May on Bombing
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from memorandum for President Johnson from McGeorge Bundy, headed “Memorandum on Vietnam Policy,” as provided in the bddy of the Pentagon study. According to the study, the document bore no date but a copy was marked in pencil “ree'd 5‐4‐67 12n.” Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

headline: DECEIT IN '64 RACE IS DENIED BY RUSK
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, July 2 — Dean Rusk, the former Secretary of State, said today that there was no “deliberate attempt to deceive anybody” about Ameri can involvement in Vietnam during the 1964 Presidential campaign of Lyndon B. Johnson.
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: Laird Increases Security On Papers at Rand Corp.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 2—Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has ordered tighter secu rity measures at the Rand Cor poration following discovery by the Pentagon of “deficiencies” in the way the Private research institute has safeguarded secret information.
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Friend of Ellslierg Sentenced In Refusal to Answer Questions
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, July 2—An thony J. Russo Jr., a friend of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, was sen tenced to jail today for refusing to answer questions before a Federal Grand Jury that is in vestigating the release of a se cret Pentagon study on Viet nam. The sentence was stayed, however, pending appeal.

headline: Replay of 1964?
lead_paragraph: The Administration's lukewarm reaction to the new Communist peace proposals in the face of what appears to be a deteriorating military situation in South Vietnam lends some weight to the fear expressed by Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, self‐acknowledged purveyor of the Pentagon papers, that the nation may be faced with “a replay of the year 1964.”

headline: Secretary McNamara's Position Of May 19 on Bombing and Troops
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from draft memorandum for the President from the office of Secretary of Defense McNamara dated May 19, 1967, and headed “Future Actions in Vietnam.” Text, provided in the body of the Pentagon study, is labeled “first rough draft—data and estimates have not been checked.” Para graphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

headline: Komer Report to Johnson After February Trip to Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from memorandum to President Johnson from Robert W. Korner his special assistant, Feb. 28, 1967, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

headline: U.S. Aides Cautious On. Vietcong Offer For Ending the War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July. 2—The Nixon Administration assumed an attitude of cautious skep ticism today toward the latest Vietcong proposal for a settle ment of the Vietnam war.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I. Guilty of Killing Officer
lead_paragraph: NHATRANG, South Vietnam, July 2 (AP)—Pfc. James D. Moy ler, 20 years old, of Chesapeake, Va., was convicted today of unpremeditated murder in the shooting of his commanding officer in January. He was sentenced to 15 years in prison.

headline: Leary Is Expected to Ask Swiss for Political Asylum
lead_paragraph: GENEVA, July 2—Dr. Timo thy F. Leary, the advocate of drug use, is expected to apply for political asylum in Switzer land to avoid extradition to the United States, usually well‐in formed sources in Berne said today.

headline: May 4 Memo on Force Levels By Systems‐Analysis Chief
lead_paragraph: Memorandum for Secretary McNamara, “Force Levels and Enemy Attri tion,” from Alain C. Enthoven, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Systems Analysis, May 4, 1967, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rand Aides Say Security Relied Largely on Trust
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 2—Officials at the Rand Cor poration believe that their se curity has been better than at most Government facilities, but, as one source said, “If you want to reduce the possibility of a leak to zero, you would have to hermetically seal the whole Defense Department.”
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: 6 Tell Panel of Plight of Unemployed
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 2—Louis Lantner is 24 years old. He is a graduate of Brown Univer sity and a former naval officer who served in Vietnam. He made a perfect score on his Fed eral service entrance examina tion. He has applied for jobs at 15 Government agencies, but with no luck.
author: By Nan Robertson Special to The New York Times

headline: Veterans Get Parade Right
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 2 (AP) — Federal District Judge Edward W. Day ordered the Bristol Fourth of July Parade Committee today to move the Vietnam Veterans Against the War from last place to the middle of the parade. After lie ruled yesterday that the veterans had a right to partici pate in the parade, the commit tee made the group the last unit in the parade. The vet erans went back to court and won today's order.

headline: McNamara Draft Memorandum For Johnson in November, '66
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from draft memorandum for President Johnson from Secre tary McNamara, dated Nov. 17, 1966, and headed “Recommended FY67 South east Asia Supplemental Appropriation,” as provided in the body of the Pentagon study.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 2—Law has always pervaded American life. Lawyers domi nate our politics and interpret our Constitution. Even the American Revo lution was cast in the form of a return to legality—a revolt against a lawless king.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Rostow Memorandum of May On the Bombing Program
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from a memorandum by Walt W. Rostow, Presidential assistant national security, to Secretary of State Dean Rusk, Deputy Secretary of Defense Cyrus Vance, Under Secretary of State Nicholas de B. Katzenbach, Assistant Secretary of Defense John T. McNaughton, Assistant Secretary of State William P. Bundy and Richard Helms, Director of Central Intelligence, dated May 1967, and headed “U.S. Strategy in Vietnam,” as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

headline: McNamara Memo of Oct. 14, 1966, Opposing Increase in War Effort
lead_paragraph: Following are texts of key documents accompanying the Pentagon's study of the Vietnam war, covering the period late 1966 to mid‐1967, in which Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara began to express disillusionment with the effec tiveness of the war effort. Except where excerpting is specified, the documents are printed verbatim, with only unmistakable typographical errors corrected.

headline: March 28 Westmoreland Cable To Joint Chiefs on Troop Needs
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from cablegram from General Westmoreland to the Joint Chiefs of Staff, “MACV FY‐68 Force Requirements,” March 28, 1967, as provided the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's para phrase, or explanation.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pressure for Wider War
lead_paragraph: As 1967 began, the study asserts, the stage was set for “a running battle” inside the Johnson Administration “be tween the advocates of a greatly ex panded air campaign against North Vietnam, one that might genuinely be called ‘strategic,’ and the disillusioned doves who urged relaxation, if not com plete suspension, of the bombing in the interests of greater effectiveness and the possibilities for peace.”

headline: Notes on Johnson Discussion With Wheeler and Westmoreland
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from the Pentagon study describing a conversation on April 27, 1967, between President Johnson and Generals Wheeler and Westmoreland. The narrative says the conversation was reported in notes by John T. Mc Naughton, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs. Italicized emphasis and words in parentheses are those of the Pentagon study.

headline: Westmoreland's March 18 Memo On Increase in Forces
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from cablegram from Gen. William C. Westmoreland, commander of united States forces in Vietnam, to Pacific command, March 18, 1967, provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

headline: Pentagon Papers: After Tet, Study Reports, Joint Chiefs Sought Virtual Mobilization
lead_paragraph: Amid the shock and turmoil of the Tet offensive in February, 1968, the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war dis closes, the Joint Chiefs of Staff and Gen. William C. Westmoreland sought to force President Lyndon B. Johnson a long way toward national mobiliza tion in an effort to win victory in Vietnam.
author: By E. W. Kenworthy

headline: Adm. Sharp's Progress Report On War at End of 1967
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from cablegram from Adm. U. S. Grant Sharp, commander in chief of Pacific forces, to the Joint Chiefs of Staff, dated Jan. 1, 1968, and headed “Year‐End Wrap‐Up Cable,” as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: “Residual” U.S. forces and bases in Vietnam will be hostages to Commu nist attack. They will probably be attacked, and require U.S. reinforce ments—or embarrassing forced with drawal. Thus the historical pattern‐ of escalation and counterescalation will be repeated.

headline: The Court's Decision
lead_paragraph: The decision of the Supreme Court allowing The Times and other newspapers to continue to publish hitherto secret Pentagon documents on the Vietnam war is in our view less important as a victory for the press than as a striking confirmation of the vitality of the American democratic form of government.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last Thurs day morning, as they have for more than three years, the chief negotiators at the deadlocked Vietnam peace talks filed into the conference room in the once luxurious Hotel Majestic in Paris. As always, Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, the Vietcong's chief representative, was smiling as she entered, and as always, she was carrying a briefcase.
author: —Terence Smith

headline: SAIGON'S SOLDIERS ATTACKING G.I.'S
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 3—Growing concern is reported in some areas of South Vietnam over a perceptible increase in hostile actions by men in the South Vietnamese armed forces toward the American military.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: The Battle at Home
lead_paragraph: By the end of the first meeting, on Feb. 29, the Clifford Group had produced an initial draft memorandum for the President. It began with a pessimistic appraisal, expressing doubt that the South. Vietnamese Army “as currently led, motivated and influenced at the top,” would buckle down to the job of pacifying the countryside, or that the Saigon Government “will rise to the challenge” and “move toward a govern ment of national union.”

headline: Wheeler's '68 Report to Johnson After the Tet Offensive
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from memorandum from Gen. Earle G. Wheeler to President Johnson, dated Feb. 27, 1968, and headed “Report of Chairman, J.C.S., on Situation in Vietnam and MACV Force Requirements.”

headline: Highlights of the Period
lead_paragraph: JANUARY‐FEBRUARY, 1968

headline: An Author of Pentagon Study Says Deceit Goes On
lead_paragraph: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., July 3—Melvin Gurtov, one of the authors of the secret Penta gon study of Vietnam, feels that the papers reveal a pattern of governmental deceit that is con tinuing in the Nixon Adminis tration.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: S.D. S. Group Seeking to Crash Peace Rally Clashes With Police
lead_paragraph: Student political radicals who had been barred from a peace rally at Hunter College clashed with the police yesterday in an unsuccessful effort to gain en trance.
author: By Emanuel Perlmutter

headline: Kramer to Make a Movie Dealing With Calley Trial
lead_paragraph: BERLIN, July 3 (AP)—Stan ley Kramer, the American movie director, whose film “Judgment at Nuremberg” de picted the Nazi war crimes trial, announced yesterday that he would make a film on the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.

headline: KY SEES NO OBSTACLE TO AN EARLY PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, July 3 (AP)—Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that he saw no obstacles on the South Vietnamese side to the new Communist peace proposal that all United States troops be withdrawn from the country by the end of this year.

headline: Straight‐A Student Disputed by School Over Ban on Talk
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, July 3— When Judy Schrut, an 18‐year‐ old straight‐A student was told she would not be among the student speakers at her high school commencement last month, she had her talk printed and distributed to each mem ber of the audience.

headline: New Troop Needs
lead_paragraph: A far different assessment came, on Feb. 12, with the Tet offensive at its hejght. General Westmoreland reported then to the Joint Chiefs and Secretary McNamara., that, as of Feb. 11, the enemy had attacked “34 provincial towns, 64 district towns and all of the autonomous cities.” This, the general said, the enemy had been able to do while committing “only 20 to 35 per cent of his North Vietnamese forces... employed as gap fillers where VC [Viet cong] strength was apparently not ade quate to carry out his initial thrust on the cities and towns.”

headline: The Series So Far
lead_paragraph: Events before Tonkin Incidents: Study says American‐run covert war against North Vietnam preceded Tonkin Gulf clashes by months.

headline: NIXON SETS GOAL OF ‘OPEN WORLD’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 3—Pres ident Nixon, starting America's 200th birthday party five years ahead of time, declared tonight his goal was “the building of an open world.”

headline: A Quarrel About the Past
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Quarreling about the past is one of the ways in which men seek to understand the present. We study history and debate its les sons because we have an inherent human need to find standards for judgment, sources of inspiration, and guides to wiser actions.
author: By William V. Shannon

headline: Cable to Envoys in Asia on Day Of Johnson's De‐escalation Speech
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from cablegram from State Department to United States Ambassa dors in Australia, New Zealand, Thailand, Laos, the Philippines and South, Korea, March 31, 1968, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. The message announced provisions of the major speech President Lyndon Johnson was to make hours later. Paragraph in italics is the study's para phrase or explanation.

headline: Orientation Memo for Clifford Telling How Targets Are Chosen
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from memorandum from Assistant Secretary of Defense Paul C. Warnke to Clark M. Clifford, newly appointed Secretary of Defense, March 5, 1968, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study.

headline: ‘A Fork in the Road’
lead_paragraph: In late February, the President sent General Wheeler to Saigon to consult with General Westmoreland on precisely how many more men he wanted. Gen eral Wheeler returned on Feb. 28 and immediately delivered a written report to the President, The report began by saying that General Westmoreland had frustrated the enemy's objective of proyoking a general uprising. But it went on to say that the offensive had been “a very near thing” for the allies and then ranged in bleak fashion over the situation in Vietnam:

headline: Burger Asserts Reform Is Not Role of Courts
lead_paragraph: Chief Justice Warren E. Bur ger believes that “some dis, appointments” may be in store for young people who are be ing attracted to legal careers “on the theory that they can change the world by litigation in the courts.”
author: By Fred P. Graham

headline: Saigon Opens Antinarcotics Campaign
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 3—In a loud, widely pub licized, banner‐filled ceremony, complete with band, the South Vietnamese Government offi cially opened its own antinar cotics drive here this week.

headline: COMPUTERS ERRED ON WAR PROTESTS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 3 —At the start of the first Vietnam moratorium on Oct. 15, 1969, Army computers put together a detailed catalogue of “antici pated” disturbances in nearly 200 city squares and college campuses around the country. Events proved it to be an essen tially misleading estimate of a peaceful day of antiwar pro test.
author: By Christopher Lydon Special to The New York Times

headline: NO THREAT IS SEEN TO ALLIED CONTROL SOUTH OF THE DMZ
lead_paragraph: QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, July 3—The recent North Viet namese drive against Saigon's forces in the craggy blue moun tains south of the demilitarized zone appears to have been aimed at demoralizing the South Vietnamese Army rather than immediately threatening the Government's control over its northernmost province, American officials believe.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: U. S. Policy in ‘Disarray’
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon study, which begins its account of American involvement in Vietnam with World War II, says that American policy from 1940 to 1950 has been a subject of “significant misun derstanding.”

headline: Mrs. Mitchell Suggests Press May Be Silenced
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 4 (Reuters) — Mrs. Martha Mitchell suggested today that the American press might be suppressed if it continued to reveal. Govern ment secrets.

headline: Dillon Cable to Dulles on Appeal For Air Support at Dienbienphu
lead_paragraph: URGENT. I was called at 11 o'clock Sunday night and asked to come im mediately, to Matignon where a restrict ed Cabinet meeting was in progress. On arrival Bidault received me in La niel's office and was joined in a few. minutes by Laniel. They said that im mediate armed intervention of US car rier aircraft at Dien Bien Phu is now necessary, to save the situation.

headline: Elections Balked
lead_paragraph: In July, 1955, under the provisions of the Geneva agreements, the two zones of Vietnam were to begin con sultations on the elections scheduled for the next year.

headline: Getting Them Out
lead_paragraph: There has been from the beginning of the Paris negotiations on Vietnam an eerie, mix of misunderstanding and doubletalk. As month followed month, any excuse for misunderstanding has evaporated, but unhappily the compul sion to doubletalk has remained.
author: By Charles W. Yost

headline: Leaders of the Insurgency
lead_paragraph: Vietcong organizer, nineteen‐fifties; Secretary, Lao Dong (Communist) party Central Committee for the Southern Re gion 1956; Secretary General Lao Dong party, 1959; since 1960, First Secretary of party . . . born into peasant family, Quangtri province in central Vietnam, 1908 . . . worked as secretary with rail ways, Hanoi . . . given 20‐year prison term for subversive activities, 1930: released 1936, resumed political work for Indochinese Communist Party . . given 10‐year sentence, 1940. . . re leased on Vietminh take‐over 1945 . . . led guerrillas against French in South starting 1946 . . . commissioner at Viet minh's military headquarters in South, 1952 . . rose in party, named First Sec retary, September, 1960 . . . led Hanoi delegation to 1967 50th‐anniversary celebations in Moscow . . . since Ho Chi Minh's death, has emerged as “first among equals” in collective leadership . . . has sponsored popular economic re forms . . . advocates “protracted war” strategy . . . said to be self‐effacing, pragmatic . . .

headline: Antiwar Protests Planned Here And in 14 Other Cities
lead_paragraph: About 1,800 delegates of the National Peace Action Coalition ended a three‐day conference at Hunter College yesterday by voting to stage antiwar demon strations on Nov. 6 in New York and at least 14 other cities.

headline: 1952 Policy Statement by U.S. On Goals in Southeast Asia
lead_paragraph: Statement of Policy by the National Security Council, early 1952, on “United States Objectives and Courses of Action With Respect to Southeast Asia.” According to a footnote, the document defined Southeast Asia as “the area. embracing Burma, Thailand, Indochina, Malaya and Indonesia.”

headline: Brink of Intervention
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1954, as the French military position in Indochina deterio rated rapidly and the date for the Ge neva conference approached, the Eisen hower Administration twice hinted to France that it was ready to intervene with American forces.

headline: Agnew Celebrates the Holiday on Flight to Singapore
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE, July 4—Vice President Agnew raised a glass, to both friends and critics as he celebrated July 4 some 35,000 feet above the South China Sea en route from Seoul to Singapore.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Airing of Pentagon Data Backed in Poll
lead_paragraph: A Gallup Poll made public to day indicates that, even before the Supreme Court ruled In fa vor of newspapers' right to publish the Pentagon papers, a majority of Americans familiar with the issue thought publica tion of the articles was “the right thing.”

headline: China Backs Vietnam Peace Proposals
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, July 4—China gave full backing to the latest Communist peace proposals for a settlement of the war in Vietnam in an editorial in Peking's Jenminh Jih Pao to day.

headline: Memo of Eisenhower‐Dulles Talk On the French Cease‐Fire Plan
lead_paragraph: Memorandum by Robert Cutler, special assistant to President Dwight Eisenhower, May 7, 1954.

headline: Report of Ho's Appeals to U.S. In '46 to Support Independence
lead_paragraph: Following are the texts of key documents accompanying the Pentagon's study of the Vietnam war, covering events in the Truman and Eisenhower Administrations. Except where excerpting is specified, the documents appear verbatim, with only unmistakable typographical errors corrected.

headline: '54 Report by Special Committee On the Threat of Communism
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from Part II of the Special Committee's Report on Southeast Asia, April 5, 1954. Part I was not made available with it.

headline: WILKINS ASSERTS YOUTHS ARE HARD
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, July 4 — To Roy Wilkins, two months away from his 70th birthday, the young black activists of today differ most dramatically from their predecessors in the “hard ness” of the younger men and their “lack of trust” of white people.
author: By Thomas A. Johnson Special to The New York Times

headline: Javits Foresees Vietnam Pullout by Mid‐1972
lead_paragraph: Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he believed President Nixon would an nounce on Nov. 1 “that Viet namization has been completed and that we are getting out just as rapidly as our troops and materiel can be redeployed.”

headline: Dulles Cable Barring Intervention
lead_paragraph: Cablegram from Secretary Dulles to Ambassador Dillon in Paris, April 5, 1954.

headline: Peking Gives Hanoi Aid
lead_paragraph: TOICYO, July 4 (AP)—China. agreed today to supply North Vietnam with additional mili: tary aid, the Chinese press. agency Hsinhua reported in a broadcast monitored here in, Tokyo. No details were given of what was covered in the agreement.

headline: Leaders of the Insurgency
lead_paragraph: Vietcong organizer, nineteen‐fifties; Secretary, Lao Dong (Communist) party Central Committee for the Southern Re gion 1956; Secretary General Lao Dong party, 1959; since 1960, First Secretary of party . . . born into peasant family, Quangtri province in central Vietnam, 1908 . . . worked as secretary with rail ways, Hanoi . . . given 20‐year prison term for subversive activities, 1930: released 1936, resumed political work for Indochinese Communist Party . . . given 10‐year sentence, 1940. . . re leased on Vietminh take‐over 1945 . . . led guerrillas against French in South starting 1946 . . . commissioner at Viet minh's military headquarters in South, 1952 . . . rose in party, named First Sec retary, September, 1960 . . . led Hanoi delegation to 1967 50th‐anniversary celebations in Moscow . . . since Ho Chi Minh's death, has emerged as “first among equals” in collective leadership . . . has sponsored popular economic re forms . . . advocates “protracted war” strategy . . . said to be self‐effacing, pragmatic . . .

headline: Rights Report Is Critical Of Wide Mayday Arrests
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 4—The District of Columbia Human Re lations Commission has report ed that more than half of the 10,000 young people arrested during the Mayday demonstra tions here two months ago did not violate any law.

headline: Eisenhower Committee's Memo On French Requests for Aid
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from memorandum for the record, Jan. 30, 1954, by Brig. Gen. Charles H. Bonesteel 3d on meeting of President's. Special Committee on Indochina.

headline: Texts of ‘Final Declaration’ at Geneva Conference And U.S. Statement Renouncing Use of Force
lead_paragraph: Following are the texts of the “final declaration” endorsed orally by France, the Vietminh, Britain, China, the So viet Union, Laos and Cambodia at the end of the Geneva conference in July, 1954, and of the statement of United States policy delivered at the conclud ing session by Under Secretary of State Walter Bedell Smith. The “final declaration,” along with the armistice agreement signed by France and the Vietminh, constitutes the Geneva ac cords on Vietnam.

headline: 3 G.I.'s Are Reported Killed By Enemy Shells at Danang
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 5 (UPI)—A mor tar barrage by enemy gunners struck a barracks filled with sleeping American soldiers at an air base in Danang at mid night and sent flames tracing through nearby buildings, mili tary sources said today.

headline: ‘Political Struggle’
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon study divides the de velopment of the insurgency in South Vietnam into roughly three periods:

headline: Details on Chinese Informant
lead_paragraph: Cablegram from Under Secretary Bedell Smith at Geneva to Secretary Dulles, July 19, 1954.

headline: Soviet Supports Proposals
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Monday, July 5, (Reuters)—Pravda, the Soviet: Communist party newspaper, pledging continued support for North Vietnam, said today that the recent Vietcong peace pro posals offered a good basis for, a political settlement in Viet nam and eventually the whole of Indochina.

headline: Canadian Says Pentagon Study Omits '66 Peace Offer by Hanoi
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 4—Ches ter A. Ronning, a retired Cana dian diplomat, said today that accounts he had read of the secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war did not describe a visit he had made to Hanoi in March, 1966, in which the North Vietnamese gave him what he considered to be major new peace offer.

headline: Kissinger and Thieu Confer on Pullout
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 4 — Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national se curity adviser, conferred with President Nguyen Van Thieu for two Moots today on a broad range of topics including future American troop withdrawals, economic and military aid and the latest Communist peace proposals.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: For years now, heroin addicts have been sent to State and Federal hospitals in the United States, detoxified and held for varying lengths of time, usually a few weeks, then released in the hope that they would not return to heroin. The results have not been encouraging. An overwhelming majority of ad‐ diets have returned to the places where they first became addicted and re sumed their habit. In fact, the success rate even among highly tbuted rehabilitation programs that work with addicts for years has not been encouraging.
author: By Richard Severo

headline: Highlights of the Period
lead_paragraph: South Vietnam, the secret Pentagon account contends, is essentially the cre ation of the United States, and the formative years were those of the Tru man and—in particular—the Eisenhower Administrations.

headline: Excerpts From Lansdale Team's Report on Covert Vietnam Mission in '54 and '55
lead_paragraph: ...This is the condensed account of one year in the operations of a “cold war” combat team, written by the team itself in the field, little by little in mo ments taken as the members could. The team is known as the Saigon Mili tary Mission. The field is Vietnam. There are other teams in the field, American, French, British, Chinese, Vietnamese, Vietminh, and others. Each has its own story to tell. This is ours.

headline: Vietnam Papers: Doubt Cast on View That the North Imposed War on the South
lead_paragraph: Under the heading “Origins of the Insurgency in South Vietnam,” the Pentagon's study analyzes the Viet cong movement and its role in the development of the war. The follow ing article, by Fox Butterfield, de scribes the analysts' findings.

headline: Cable by Dulles on Negotiations At Geneva on Vietnam Elections
lead_paragraph: Cablegram by Secretary Dulles to United States Embassy in Paris with copies to the United States Embassies in London and Saigon and to United States Consul General in Geneva for Under Secretary Bedell Smith, July 7, 1954.

headline: Chinese Communists' Position On a Neutralized Indochina
lead_paragraph: Cablegram from Under Secretary of State Bedell Smith at Geneva to Secre tary Dulles, July 18, 1954.

headline: 1954 Study by the Joint Chiefs On Possible U.S. Intervention
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from memorandum from Admiral Arthur W. Radford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson, May 26 1954, on “Studies With Respect to Possible U.S. Action Regarding Indochina.” The italicized emphasis appears in the original document.

headline: In the Mekong Delta, the New Politicking
lead_paragraph: PHUVINH, South Vietnam, July 2—The combination of showmanship, curiosity and controversy that Americans have long accepted as part of political campaigns rippled through this little Mekong Delta town today as Ngo Cong Duc, the local Congressman, came home to register for his re‐elec tion campaign.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Pentagon Papers: Eisenhower Decisions Undercut the Geneva Accords, Study Says
lead_paragraph: The secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war discloses that a few days after the Geneva accords of 1954, the Eisenhower Administration's National Security Council decided that the ac cords were a “disaster” and the Presi dent approved actions to prevent further Communist expansion in Vietnam.
author: By Fox Butterfield

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 4—Richard Nixon is approaching a decisive moment in his Presidency. Developments abroad and at home press for a fundamental reap praisal of his policy on Vietnam. His response on that issue in the coming weeks' could affect the character that history will give him—as a divisive President or one who, as he wished, helped to bring a shattered country together.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Dillon Reply on French Reaction
lead_paragraph: Cablegram from Ambassador Dillon to Secretary Dulles, April 5, 1954.

headline: Burger Calls Court In Fact Unanimous In The Times Case
lead_paragraph: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger says that the. Supreme Court “was actually unani mous” in principle in its 6‐to 3 decision last Wednesday against the Justice Depart ment's effort to bar publication of material from the top‐secret Pentagon papers in The New York Times and The Washing ton. Post.

headline: They Still Fly Off Carriers in Tonkin
lead_paragraph: ABOARD U.S.S. ORISK ANY, in the Tonkin Gulf, July 4—”I was here in the beginning, here again at the worst part when we were bombing North Vietnam, and now I'm here again at the end—at least I hope it's the end,” a Navy pilot on this aircraft carrier said as he prepared for a bombing mis sion over Laos.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Reston Hopes to Visit Hanoi
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, July 5 (UPI)— James Reston, vice president and columnist of The New York Times, said today that he would leave for China Thursday for a three‐week visit. Mr. Reston, who arrived here yesterday with his wife, said he hoped to go to Hanoi from China “to find out if the war is going to end.” He said he had applied for visas for North Vietnam but has received no reply.

headline: Agnew, in Singapore, Says U.S. Media Unintentionally Aid North Vietnamese
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE, July 5—Vice President Agnew renewed his criticism of the United States news media today, charging them with unintentionally as sisting the North Vietnamese by some aspects of their cov erage of the war in Indochina.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Force in Vietnam Is Lowest Since 1966
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 5 (UPI)—Some 2,200 more G.I.'s went home last week to cut the United States military force in Vietnam to 239,500 men, the lowest since March 31, 1966, the military command reported today.

headline: CAPT. MEDINA SEEKS EVIDENCE IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, July 5 (AP)— Capt. Ernest L. Medina, facing trial on charges of murder and assault in the 1968 raid on My lai, has left for Vietnam with an Army prosecutor and his military defense attorney.

headline: Minh Asks U.S. Pressure To Assure Fair Elections
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 5—Gen. Duong Van Minh, a potential challenger for South Vietnam's presidency this fall, has charged in an interview that President Nguyen Van Thieu is using intimidation and pressure to insure his re‐elec tion and has urged that the United States apply all its influ ence for a fair and honest contest.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Tests Said to Show Few Vietnam G.I.'s Are Heroin Addicts
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 5 (UPI)—Initial results of new tests devised to seek out and rehabilitate heroin addicts among homeward‐bound Amer ican soldiers disclose an addic tion rate of only 2 per cent, Military sources said today.

headline: Comment by Macomber
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) —William B. Macomber Jr., a Deputy Under Secretary of State, said today that only “a very small percentage” of the Pentagon papers could be dam aging if disclosed and that newspapers had largely retrained, from publishing those sections.

headline: How We Went to War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 5—“It is not enough to say that Mr. Johnson in 1964 was behaving in more or less the customary way. The question that mat ters is why men who lead democracies —even, and indeed especially, men who count themselves as standing on the left of center—behave like this. ... The problem which has burst out of its cage is the relationship between democracy and war.”
author: By William V. Shannon

headline: The Lessons of Vietnam
lead_paragraph: News Analysis
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: Unless Dr. Henry Kissinger can bring back from Saigon better news about Vietnamization than the pub lished reports suggest, the latest Viet cong proposals appear to have put President Nixon in an excruciating dilemma.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: U.S. MAY PUT OFF REPLY TO VIETCONG
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 6—The United States is giving such serious study to the Vietcong peace plan submitted in Paris last Thursday that a formal response is likely to be de layed, senior Administration of ficials said today.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Carl Colodne

headline: Medina Arrives in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Wednesday, July 7 (AP)—Capt. Ernest L. Medina, charged with murder and as sault in the Mylai case, arrived in Vietnam today to take dep ositions from witnesses. He is scheduled to stand teal July 26.

headline: The Purloined Papers
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—More than a cen tury ago Alexis de Tocqueville told us: “Scarcely any political question arises in the United States that is not re solved, sooner or later, into a judicial question.”
author: By Dean Acheson

headline: TRIAL IS SET AUG. 4 FOR MYLAI COLONEL
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., July 6 (AP)—A military judge refused today to dismiss one of four charges against Col. Oran X. Henderson of the Army arising out of the alleged covering up of the killing of South Viet namese civilians at Mylai in 1968. He set Aug. 4 as a tenta tive date to start Colonel Hen derson's court‐martial.

headline: VIETNAM INQUIRY URGED BY TAYLOR
lead_paragraph: Telford Taylor, former Unit ed States prosecutor at the Nuremberg trials, called on President Nixon and Congress yesterday to appoint a nation al commission to investigate the origins and conduct of the war in Vietnam.
author: By Henry Raymont

headline: Bar Group Bids Judges Set Example of Decorum
lead_paragraph: By unanimous voice vote of its 297‐member policy making unit, the American Bar Association adopted yester day a set of courtroom guidelines that urged judges to set the tone for orderly proceed ings by behaving well them selves.
author: By Lesley Oelsner

headline: ACTIONS ON VIETNAM DEFENDED BY GRAVEL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 6 — Senator Mike. Gravel defended to the Senate today his public reading of parts of the Pentagon papers on the United States involvement in Vietnam.

headline: Big Minh Denies That U.S. Had Role in Anti‐Diem Plot
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 (AP)—Gen. Duong Van Minh, leader of the group that over threw President Ngo Dinh Diem in 1963, was quoted today as denying that the United States had supported and encouraged the coup.

headline: Excerpts From Le Duc Tho Interview
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 6—Following are excerpts from the trans script of an interview today with Le Duc Tho, a member of the Politburo of the ruling Communist party of North Vietnam, conducted by An thony Lewis of The New York Times. Mr. Tho spoke in Vietnamese, which was translated into English by an aide, Phuong Nguyen Dinh. Two other aides, Tran Thien Can and Nguyen Thanh Le, were with him.

headline: ROSTOW SAYS TIMES DISTORTED ARCHIVES
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex., July 6 (AP)— Walt W. Rostow, former aide to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, has ac cused The New York Times of misleading the public with its account of the Pentagon pa pers, The Daily Texan said to day.

headline: HANOI AIDE SAYS P.O.W. AGREEMENT CAN BE SEPARATE
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 6—A high ranking North Vietnamese lead er said today that the new Communist offer to return war prisoners if American forces are withdrawn by the end of 1971 was not dependent on a political settlement in South Vietnam.
author: By Anthony Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: STORM BRINGS LULL TO WAR IN VIETNAM.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 (Reuters) — Typhoon rans and wind struck Indochina to day, cutting back American air strikes. Military spokesmen re ported a comparative lull in ground fighting.

headline: Captain's Gamble Aids Navy Addicts
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, July 6—Eight young sailors and marines who became heroin addicts in Viet nam will arrive here tomorrow to begin three months of in tensive treatment at the Navy's new West Coast drug rehabili tation center.
author: By Everett R. Holles Special to The New York Times

headline: BATTLEFIELD ACTION AT A LOW IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 7 (AP)—Battlefield activity in South Vietnam has sunk to one of its lowest levels of the war in the last week, military sources said today.

headline: 115 Prison Poems by Ho Are Printed by Bantam
lead_paragraph: “Calamity has tempered and hardened me/And turned my mind into steel,” wrote Ho Chi Minh in 1943, when the late Vietnamese Commu nist leader was a prisoner of Nationalist China in a South China jail.
author: By Henry Raymont

headline: Coast Businessmen's Unit Gives Support to Ellsberg
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, July 7—A group of businessmen declared their support today for Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, who has said he had provided the press with secret Pentagon papers on Viet nam.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Ward Morehouse

headline: WHITE HOUSE ASKS MO SEES SECRETS
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 7—The White House said to day that it had ordered the compilation of a list of all persons who have authority to see top‐secret documents.
author: By John Herbers Special to The New York Times

headline: Article 2 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Thursday, July 8 (UPI)—B‐52 bombers resumed bombing near the demilitarized zone last night and today after having been kept away from the area for a day by rough weather, military sources said.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 7, — Former Secretary of State Dean Acheson has entered the controversy over publica tion of the Pentagon Papers, suggest ing that en “ethical issue, or its ghost” has continued to “haunt” The New York limes. More specifically, he called fora “severe official' secrets act” and a self‐governing body for the press “to stimulate more ethical professional relations with the Gov erment.”
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: DATE TO END WAR SNARLS DRAFT ACT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) — House and Senate negotia tors failed again today to reach agreement on end‐the‐war leg islation, thus killing any chance of renewing the expired draft law before the middle of July.

headline: Lindsay Urges Lawyer Activism in A.B.A. Talk
lead_paragraph: Mayor Lindsay urged yester day an “activism” by lawyers that appeared to contrast with the expressed views of Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, who sat frowning at the Mayor's left as he spoke.
author: By Maurice Carroll

headline: Vietnamizing the Peace
lead_paragraph: The statement of a high‐ranking North Vietnamese in Paris that the latest Communist proposal on war prison ers and withdrawal is not dependent on a political settle ment in South Vietnam removes a major obstacle to serious negotiations. The peace plan was not clear on this point when it was introduced by the Vietcong dele gate last week. By suggesting that political questions could be discussed with the Saigon Government after the American withdrawal, the Communists in effect have proposed to Vietnamize the peace.

headline: U.S. Will Seek Clarification Of Communist Peace Plan
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 7 (Reu ters)—United States officials today stressed a need for fur ther clarification of the new Communist peace plan for Viet nam, and said that a formal American response would there fore be withheld in Paris to morrow.

headline: Kissinger Is Not Planning To See Hanoi Aide in Paris
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, July 7 (AP)— Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, said today he had no plans to meet Le Duc Tho, a member of the North Vietnam ese Politburo in Paris this weekend.

headline: A Saigon General Named As a Trafficker in Heroin
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 7 — A high‐ranking South Vietnamese general was named by a mem ber of Congress before a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee today as “one of the chief traf fickers in heroin in Southeast Asia.”
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Bar Parley Rejects End‐War Resolution
lead_paragraph: Delegates to the American Bar Association closed their three‐day convention here yesterday by voting not to urge the Government to withdraw from Vietnam “as soon as phys ically and logistically possible.”
author: By Fred P. Graham

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Elliot Bernstein

headline: C.I.A. Says Plan Seeks to Embarrass U.S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 8— The Central Intelligence Agency has told President Nixon that the new Vietcong peace proposal is aimed at embarrassing the United States “both at home and overseas” and encouraging the opponents of President Nguyen Van Thieu in South Vietnam.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Paper Says Morale Of Saigon Troops Is Failing
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 8 (Agence France‐Presse)—The North Vietnamese Army news paper, Quan Doi Nhan Dan, said this week that the United States was desperately, but vainly, trying to halt the collapse in morale of the South Vietnamese Army.

headline: U.S. Reply to Proposal of the Vietcong
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 8—Following is the text of the opening re marks made by David K. E. Bruce, head of the United States delegation, at the 120th session of the Vietnam peace talks here today:

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: PARIS—“The Japanese had been brought up on the theory that they were invincible. They had never been defeated in war. Now all their history books and schoolbooks must be re written in order to adjust history to facts. Are we Americans suffering from the same psychological superior ity complex that affected Japan in 1941?
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Air Force Captain Against the War
lead_paragraph: Man in the News

headline: Indonesia Votes
lead_paragraph: To nobody's surprise, early returns from the Indo nesian national election show the Government‐backed Sekber Golkar party taking a comfortable lead over the fragmented opposition. As one Westerner cynically com mented: “This election is in the great democratic tradi tion of Taiwan and South Vietnam.”

headline: The Chicago Tribune
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO—Thirty years from now historians may be recounting the story of how The New York Times obtained and printed secret Pentagon docu ments describing the background of the war in Vietnam.
author: By Clayton Kirkpatrick

headline: Drug Aide Here Terms Nixon Program ‘Too Little’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 8 — A Senate panel considering legis lation on the prevention of drug abuse heard expert testi mony today that President Nixon's $155‐million program was “too little and too late.”
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Court‐Martial Opens in Britain Of Officer Who Protested War
lead_paragraph: LAKENHEATH, England, July 8 — The United States Air Force opened court‐martial proceedings today against Capt. Thomas S. Culver, the first American officer charged with taking part in an antiwar pro test in Britain.
author: By Bernard Weinraub Special to The New York Times

headline: HOUSE APPROVES WIDER U.S. CREDIT TO FINANCE TRADE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 8—The House of Representatives voted today to expand export credit financing by the Export‐Import Bank but blocked a move de signed to liberalize East‐West trade.
author: By Marjorie Hunter Special to The New York Times

headline: Case of Pentagon Report May Be Before Grand Jury
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, July 8 (AP)— Cloaked in unusual secrecy, a Federal grand jury is conduct ing an investigation on which, United States Attorney Herbert F. Travers Jr. says, “there will be no public statement what soever.”

headline: U.S. War Deaths, at 45, Are Highest in 6 Weeks
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 8 (UPI) — Forty‐five Americans died in the Viet, nam war last week, the high est count in six weeks, the United States command re ported today. Twenty‐three were killed in combat and 22 died of disease or accidents.

headline: Kitty Hawk Quits Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 8 (AP) — The United States Navy announced today that the 80,000‐ton aircraft car rier Kitty Hawk has been with drawn from the Vietnam war and is now under operational control of the United States First Fleet in the eastern Pacific.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: “The survival of a non‐Communist South Vietnam,” the goal or President Nixon according to Tom Wicker, is. not a bad goal. In fact, over 50,000 American soldiers have died for this goal. Now it is in sight. The South Vietnamese Government is stable, the army increasingly competent and the countryside generally peaceful. Mean while, American combat casualties and commitments ire greatly reduced from two years ago.
author: Marion Mattingly

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Charles O. Porter

headline: General Bids Thieu Protest Drug Charge
lead_paragraph: NHATRANG, South Vietnam, July 8 — Maj. Gen. Ngo Dzu, who was identified yesterday by a member of the United States Congress as one of the chief heroin traffickers in South Vietnam, today asked President Nguyen Van Thieu to protest the allegation, according to the general's senior American ad viser, John Paul Vann.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Judge Not Lest Ye Be Judged
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The Pentagon Pa pers are in themselves quite deceptive. There is not one piece of paper from the President, nor one piece of proof of any of the so‐called decisions the Pentagon analysts assert were made. There is only the flight of memos between various levels of State and Defense. Every working newsman in Washington knows about contingency planning and is aware that while a hundred consensuses may be reached at lower levels, until the President de cides, there is no decision. This is elementary in the structure of the Presidency. What the President thinks, says and does is the decisive piece of action.
author: By Jack Valenti

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: While I praise The Times for the great public service it has performed with the Pentagon documents, I can not agree with your editorial opinion that this is a “ringing victory for free dom under law.”
author: Richard Strasburger

headline: 64% in Poll Say U.S. Is on Wrong Track
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 8—Near ly two‐thirds of the American people believe that their coun try has lost its proper sense of direction, according to a na tional survey by the Roper Or ganization. Many of them blame drug abuse and the Vietnam war.

headline: U.S, IN PARIS, ASKS A CLOSED SESSION ON VIETCONG PLAN
lead_paragraph: Text of Bruce's statement is printed on Page 2.
author: By John L. Hess Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S COPIERS JOIN DRIVE IN CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 9—United States helicopters airlifted 1,500 South Vietnamese troops into the Parrot's Beak section of eastern Cambodia yesterday for the start of a pincer move ment against enemy troop concentrations and supply lines.

headline: Poland Belittles Conflict Over Pentagon Papers
lead_paragraph: WARSAW, July 8—A Polish newspaper reader was quickly disabused today of his sug gestion that the controversy in the United States over the pub lication of the Pentagon pa pers represented evidence in favor of freedom and the dem ocratic system.
author: By James Feron Special to The New York Times

headline: Data Denied McNaniara, Ellsberg Says
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 9 — Daniel Ellsberg asserted today that Pentagon officials working for the Joint Chiefs of Staff kept from Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara the ex istence of a study of the 1964 Tonkin Gulf incident.
author: By Robeirt M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “The only practical Ameri can interest remaining in these nego tiations is to get out with a degree of honor. This is probably the last chance to do it.”
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Judge Calls U.S. Voiding Of Mayday Permit Illegal
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) —A Federal judge ruled today that the Government acted il legally on May 2 in revoking a permit issued to Mayday anti war demonstrators to assemble in West Potomac Park near the Lincoln Memorial.

headline: ‘PENTAGON PAPERS’ IN SECOND PRINTING
lead_paragraph: “The Pentagon Papers,” the paperback published by Ban tam Books in association with The New York Times, has gone into a second printing, a day after the first copies were shipped out on Thursday.

headline: WAR CRITICS CURB POLICE QUESTIONS
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, July 8 — The Philadelphia Police Depart ment, taken to Federal Court on charges of inhibiting the rights of demonstrators to free speech and ass??bly, has agreed to stop asking questions about political views and asso ciations.
author: By Donald Janson Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Martin Ulan

headline: Accused General in Saigon Terms Drug Charge a Plot
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 10 — Maj. Gen. Ngo Dzu, who has been ac cused by a United States Con gressman of being one of South Vietnam's chief traffickers in narcotics, said this morning that the charges were the “poor invention” of a jealous army rival, and that Communists might have had a subtle hand in the controversy.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Lindsay Names a Coordinator To Aid Drug‐Addicted Veterans
lead_paragraph: Mayor Lindsay yesterday an nounced the appointment of full‐time coordinator of addic tion services for veterans to deal with the problem of drug addiction among returning soldiers.
author: By Alfonso A. Narvaez

headline: Table on U.S. Foreign Aid
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 9—Following is the table released today by Senator William Proxmire listing (in thousands of dollars) United States military and economic assistance 43 countries:

headline: Steele Reaffirms Charges
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, July 9— Representative Steele today re affirmed his charges that Gen eral Dzu is “one of the chief traffickers in heroin in South east Asia.”
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi's Defense Chief Says U.S. Traps Itself in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 9 (UPI)—The North Vietnamese Defense Min later, Gen. Vo Nguyen Glap, said in an interview released today that the United States had trapped itself in a “tunnel without end” in Vietnam. Gen eral Giap said America has only two choices: “Stop the war or change strategy.”

headline: Captain Invites Air Force Jury To Hyde Park Site of Meeting
lead_paragraph: LAKENHEATH, England, July 9—A United States Air Force officer, accused of having taken part in an antiwar protest that began at Hyde Park Speakers Corner, today invited a military jury to appear there on Sunday.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Lieut.‐Gen. Glen W. Martin U.S.A.F

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Cyrus S. Eaton

headline: Investigation Is Reported
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) — A State Department official indicated today that both the United States and the South Vietnamese Governments were investigating Mr. Steele's charges.

headline: McCloskey Will Challenge President in 2 Primaries
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, July 9— Representative Paul N. Mc Closkey Jr., a 43‐year‐old Cali fornia Republican, announced today his candidacy for Presi dent.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Back from a vacation in Bermuda after suffering dizzy spell in New York three weeks ago, Secretary General Thant returned to work declaring that he was “fully recovered.” Mr. Thant, who is in his 10th year as Secretary General, the long est the post has been held by one person, said his deci sion to retire at the end of the year was “irrevocable.” Would he accept a draft if a tangle developed choosing his successor? “I don't think so.”
author: James F. Clarity

headline: Saigon Presses New Cambodia Drive
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 9 (AP) ‐‐ South Vietnamese troops pressed their new drive into Cambodia today but for a second day reported no contact with enemy units.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Henry B. Davis

headline: $1.7‐Billion of War Funds Unaccounted For in Audit
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 9—The General Accounting Office, the Congressional, watchdog agency, has.reported that it is unable to determine how $1.7‐billion of $2.1‐billion authorized for the pacification program in South Vietnam was spent or com mitted during the three‐year period ended July 30, 1970.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: A condemnation, a report, a defense
lead_paragraph: The calamity at Mylai will be with us for some time to come, and with the U.S. Army even longer, serving as a kind of metaphor for the Ameri can way of war in South Vietnam. Seymour Hersh in “My Lai 4” and Richard Hammer in “One Morning in the War” dealt with the facts of the massacre itself, and these three books carry the story a bit further. Two of them center on Lt. William L. Calley and the court martial, the third on the company of men who committed the killings.
author: By Ward Just

headline: Top U. S. Aide in Highlands Optimistic on Pacificaion
lead_paragraph: NHATRANG, South Vietnam, July 8—John Paul Vann, a re tired Army officer who has often been critical of the con duct of the Vietnam war, is now optimistically taking on what may prove to be his most difficult task in eight years here—eliminating most of the American presence in the least pacified military region of Viet nam, the vast Central High lands.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: FOES OF SPRAYING WIN COAST ROUND
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, July 10—Oppo sition from half a dozen con servationist groups has forced the Federal Forest Service to call off plans to use a powerful defoliant, once employed in the Vietnam war, as a protective weapon against California forest fires.

headline: The Last Word: The Balkan Model
lead_paragraph: The revelations in the Pentagon Papers are sure to give great impetus to revisionist historians. Those who are looking for explanations of American foreign policy in terms of military imperialism, the imperatives of the military‐industrial complex, capitalist expansionism or ideological imperialism will find evi dence to serve them. Those who see American foreign policy in terms of revolution and counterrevolution, whether they see the origins at Yalta or even back in 1917, will also find what they are looking for.
author: By Roger Jellinek

headline: U.S. Aides Fear Violence By Vietnamese Refugees
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 10— High United States pacification officials are reported to fear large‐scale urban violence be fore the end of the year in the densely populated Mekong Delta southwest of Saigon.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: New Addiction Clinics Will Open This Month
lead_paragraph: The Veterans Administra tion is scheduled to open 14 new drug addiction clinics this month.

headline: U.S. Plane A ttacked in North; B‐52's Pound Area Below DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 10 (AP) — United States bombers continued their raids below the demilitarized zone today, the United States com mand reported.

headline: Wash ington Notes
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 10— The White House gave classi fied copies of the Pentagon. Papers to the Senate and House with the explanation that Congress might other wise make “judgments” based on Incomplete newspaper ac counts of the top‐secret his tory of the Vietnam war. But the New Zea land Parliament, which has pro vided troops to serve in South Vietnam at the bidding of the United States, will have to Make do with the published versions.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon's Cabbies Skeptical on Elections
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 8—Saigon's cab drivers will vote in the coming elections, though like most ordinary Vietnamese, few feel the elec tions will make any difference.

headline: Secret Agent Testifies at Captain's Trial
lead_paragraph: LAKENHEATH, England, July 10—A United States Air Force undercover agent who infil trated the antiwar movement among American servicemen here testified today at the court‐martial of Capt. Thomas S. Culver.
author: By Bernard Weinraub Special to The New York Times

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On the surface, the 120th session of the Paris Con ference on Vietnam last week seemed as barren as the ones that went before: a debate on different wave lengths, an ex change of accusations and ques tions left hanging. Yet the jammed and sweltering press room of the conference hall was infused with that almost palpable excitement which attends a his toric moment. For the first time in three years of talks, it seemed that a vital decision might be in the making.
author: John L. Hess

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: A year ago the jubilant com mander of the South Vietnamese Army's IV Corps took a heli copter‐full of reporters to the scene of his troops' victory over Communist forces in the Cam bodian town of Preyveng. The commander, Maj. Gen. Ngo Dzu, posed for photographers beside a display of captured arms in the city, which was still smoldering from rocket, mortar and bomb explosions.

headline: Alaska Army Chief Named
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 10 (AP)—The chief of staff for the United States Army in Vietnam, Maj. Gen. Charles M. Gettys, will become command ing general of the Army in Alaska in early October, the Army said yesterday. He will replace Maj. Gen. James F. Hollingsworth, who is returning to Vietnam.

headline: An Imperfect Peace
lead_paragraph: The Communist peace offensive in Paris has con fronted President Nixon with an excruciating decision: to admit that “victory” is beyond our grasp and to pull out of Indochina, finally and fully, leaving the fate that tormented region to contending indigenous forces.

headline: Hanoi Reports Big Rice Crop
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 10 (Agence France‐Presse)— Hanoi and its four neighboring agricultural districts this year produced the biggest winter and spring rice crops ever re corded in North Vietnam, ac cording to statistics published here today.

headline: JOB DENIAL TIED TO ROSTOW VIEWS
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex., July 10, (AP)— A selection committee once con sidered Walt W. Rostow, Johnson Administration aide, for a.'dean's position at the Uni versity of Texas but decided against him, partly because of “his association with the ‘hawk’ Position on the Vietnam war,” according to correspondence disclosed here.

headline: 5 V. A. Pilot Clinics Still Experirrzenting on Drug Addiction Cures
lead_paragraph: BATTLE CREEK, Mich.— After six months of experiment ing with various combinations of cures for drug addiction, the Veterans Administration's five pilot clinics are still experi menting.While each clinic is free to operate as it chooses, most have their patients on some form of methadone therapy. That is, addicts receive mea sured doses of addictive metha done to wipe out their craving for heroin while undergoing continuous therapy, from psy chiatric to vocational, to get at the emotional root of their addiction.
author: By Andrew H. Malcolm Special to The New York Times

headline: The Calley Case Re‐Examined
lead_paragraph: AT Fort McPherson, Ga., bead quarters of the Third Army, two military lawyers have be gun combing the 5,070 pages and 800 exhibits composing the case of the United States v. First Lieut. William Laws Calley Jr. By the middle of this month at the earliest, and possibly as late as Labor Day, they will submit a recommendation for legal action to the Third Army commander, Lieut. Gen. Albert O. Connor.
author: By Stephan Lesher

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Now that The Times and Washing ton Post cases are disposed of by the Court, a relaxed exhaustion of either euphoria or dismay permits some post‐mortem reflections on the issues which it raised.

headline: The Economic Issue
lead_paragraph: On the assumption that a year from now the Vietnam war is over—or at least the American involvement is so reduced that most voters will ignore it—the 1972 national election is like ly to turn on the economic issue. But what is that issue? Conventionally it is defined as unemployment and in flation, and there can be no doubt that both of these are serious prob lems, directly and indirectly.
author: By Leonard S. Silk

headline: U.S. SAYS PLANES HIT GUNS IN NORTH
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11 (AP)— Two United States fighter — bombers attacked a cluster of antiaircraft sites in side North Vietnam today and knocked out seven guns that fired on an American plane minutes earlier, the United States command reported.

headline: The Price of Democracy
lead_paragraph: LONDON— From across the Atlantic, the first thing that hits one about the Pentagon disclosures is that nothing like them could have happened here. Our legal processes would have strangled them before birth. Let me hasten to say that I'm not suggesting that this is a point to us. All systems of your kind or ours —.what we call parliamentary demecracies—have some method of extracting information out of the executive and keeping it in check. Our method is by making the executive directly responsible to Par liament. Yours is in the last resort the press.
author: By C. P. Snow

headline: ROSTOW UPHOLDS JOHNSON POLICIES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 11 — Walt W. Rostow said today that the alternative to the Vietnam policies of President Lyndon B. Johnson possibly would have been a nuclear war.

headline: Agnew Finds Foreign Doubts on U.S.
