lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 11—Vice President Agnew asserted today that the leaders he had met on his tour have said, without exception, they felt that America's status as a world leader had been seri ously challenged by the publi cation of confidential Govern ment documents and by what the leaders described as a growing isolationist spirit in Congress.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon's Forces Widen Duties as Vietnamization Progresses
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6—The armed forces of South Vietnam have steadily widened their field of operations with the progress of Vietnamization.
author: By Drew Middleton Special to The New York Times

headline: ARMY EXPANDING DRUG ABUSE TEST
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 11— The United States Army has extended its program of drug abuse urinalyses that was be gun last month in Vietnam to the United States and Europe.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Agent Blue’ in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: The United States has been destroy ing growing crops in South Vietnam since at least November 1961 as part of its “resource denial” program. This is accomplished largely by the aerial application of an aqueous solution of sodium dimethyl arsenate, “Agent Blue”; applied at the rate of 9.3 pounds of active ingredients per acre. This is a highly persistent (and potentially hazardous) chemical not domestically registered for use on or near crops.
author: BY Arthur H. Westing

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I cannot write forcefully enough in support of William L. Shirer's position [Op‐Ed June 26] that history is the loser when Government documents are long suppressed.

headline: KISSINGER IN PARIS TO MEET WITH BRUCE
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Monday, July 12 — Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security ad viser, arrived here early today for discussions on the Vietnam peace talks amid speculation that he might visit Le Duc Tho, a member of the North Viet namese Nahum.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: We agree with your editorial of July 2 that the Communist offer to release all prisoners of war if the United States agrees to withdraw its forces from Vietnam by the end of the year opens the way to a breakthrough.

headline: Capital Asks Aid on Mass Arrests
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 12—The District of Columbia has asked the Justice Department's Law Enforcement Assistance Ad ministration for a $14,900 grant to help develop a contingency plan for the “humane” confine ment of persons arrested in mass protests.

headline: Kissinger Confers With American Delegation in Paris
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 12—Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser, spent a day in Paris confer ring with the American dele gation to the Vietnam peace talks.

headline: U.S. Troop Level in Vietnam At a Five‐Year Low of 236,300
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12 (UPI) — American military strength in South Vietnam dropped 3,100 men last week to a five‐year low of 236,300 The withdrawal pace was near ly 50 per cent ahead of sched ule, according to United States command figures disclosed to day.

headline: Goals Set by Women's Political Caucus
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 12— The Women's National Politi cal Caucus, a new organiza tion dedicated to increasing the political power of women, announced today the guide lines it will use in deciding what candidates it will support for public office.

headline: House‐Senate Committee Recesses for Week Without Ending the Deadlock on Draft
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 12—A House and Senate conference committee that has been try ing to reconcile differences in draft‐extension bills recessed for a week today, still dead locked over a Senate amend ment calling for total troop withdrawals from Vietnam.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Tirnes

headline: More G.I.'s in Vietnam Joining Drug Users’ Amnesty Program
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 12 — Lieut. Gen. Robert C. Taber, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for manpower, says that the Pentagon's new drug testing program in Vietnam is prompting more service men to participate in a drug users’ amnesty program.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: Flights Washed Out
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Tuesday, July 13 (AP) — A tropical storm named Kim brushed the northern sec tor of South Vietnam today, washing out United States air operations with up to 10 inches of rain, and swept north into the Gulf of Tonkin.

headline: New Zealand Critical
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 12—Prime Minister Keith Holyoake implicitly criticized the United States today after it had refused to make available a copy of the Pentagon report on the war in Vietnam.

headline: U.S. Replaces Baldwin, Americal Division Chief
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12 — The commanding general of the United States Army's 23d Division, the Americal, is being replaced, the American military head quarters announced today.

headline: Clash in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 12 (UPI) — North Vietnamege troops reportedly attacked Cambodian soldiers sweeping strategic marshlands 12 miles east of Pnompenh today.

headline: U.S. Aide Reports Criticism
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) — Foreign governments are complaining about newspaper publication of the Pentagon papers, Marshall Green, an As sistant Secretary of State, said today.

headline: Thailand Protests Publication in U.S. Of Pentagon Study
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 12 (UPI)—Thailand formally pro tested to the United States to day against the publication of data from the Pentagon papers.

headline: The Future Could Not Be Seen
lead_paragraph: The average reader of The New York Times, equipped with hindsight, is smarter than any President.
author: By Theodore C. Sorensen

headline: Laotian Advance Reported
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos July 12 (Agence France‐Presse) Mili tary sources said today that Government forces com manded by Gen. Vang Pao were advancing toward Green Peak Mountain, 19 miles northeast of the Plaine des Jarres and 38 miles west of the Laotian‐North Vietnamese frontier.

headline: Gruening Tells Officers’ Group Nixon Doesn't Intend to End War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 12— Ernest Gruening, the former Democratic Senator from Alas ka, said tonight that President Nixon “hasn't any intention of ending” the war in Vietnam “and never has had.”

headline: Free Press, Free People
lead_paragraph: Our democracy does not work well in secret. The Pentagon Papers illumi nate the arrogance of those in high places and the serious erosion, if not breakdown, of our constitutional sys tem of checks and balances.
author: By Ogden B. Reid

headline: Nixon Adviser on Drug Abuse Ends 3‐Day Survey in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON South Vietnam July, 13—President Nixon's special advisor on drug abuse finished today a three‐day tour of United. States military drug‐detection and treatment center in South Vietnam, but declined to specify what he had found.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A prominent Lebanese diplomat recently told me there is an intense rivalry between Red China and the Soviet Union for influence in the Arab Middle East. In Lebanon, the commandos get arms from both rivals, and most of those in Lebanon and Jordan were trained in Red China. My source also said it is suspected a num ber of commandos were trained in North Vietnam and even practiced fighting with the Vietcong against the South Vietnamese.

headline: ROBERT STACK FILES SUIT AGAINST C.B.S.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, July 13 (AP) —The actor Robert Stack filed a $25‐million damage suit against the Columbia Broad casting System today, charging that its controversial “Selling of the Pentagon” misrepresent ed his position on the Vietnam war.

headline: PORTER EXPECTED TO REPLACE BRUCE AT TALKS IN PARIS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 13—The Nixon Administration plans to replace David K. E. Bruce as chief United States delegate at the Vietnam peace talks in Paris on or about Aug. 15, senior of ficials, said today.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Johnny Sample, who played professional football for 11 years and capped his career by helping the New York Jets win the 1968 Super Bowl, was arrested in Philadelphia yesterday on charges of hav ing cashed 15 forged United States Treasury checks that were stolen from the mails.

headline: Ellsberg Says Kissinger Knew About Pentagon Papers in ’70
lead_paragraph: Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, the po litical scientist who made the Pentagon papers available to the press, said during a long television interview last night that Henry A. Kissinger, Presi dent Nixon's national security adviser, had been consulted about the Pentagon study be fore the project began.

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: PARIS—Communist strategy in this final phase of the Indochina war seems postulated on proving Abraham Lin coln was wrong and that it is indeed possible to fool all the American people all the time. Hanoi has reason to believe it may well demonstrate this cynical theorem's accuracy.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Saigon Court Upholds Thiea's Election Law
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 14 (AP)— The South Vietnamese Su preme Court yesterday up held the constitutionality of a newly enacted and con troversial election law that restricts the number of presi dential candidates.

headline: Dean Rusk on the Pentagon Papers
lead_paragraph: The following was excerpted from an hour‐long interview last week on N.B.C. Television with the former Sec retary of State, Dean Rusk.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Both The Times and the President of the United States are concerned about the safety and well‐being of the Ameri can people, but while your editor Is responsible only to your American readers, the President is responsible not only to Americans but also to for eign governments.

headline: COURT CONVICTS OMAR OFFICER
lead_paragraph: LAKENHEATH, England, July 13—A United States Air Force court‐martial found Capt. Thomas S. Culver guilty today of having taken part in an anti war demonstration in London on May 31 in violation of mili tary regulations.
author: By Bernard Weinraub Special to The New York Times

headline: Grand Jury Studies Disclosure of Papers
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, July 13—A Federal grand jury here has been pre sented information gathered by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents who have attempted to learn how secret Pentagon papers were made available to the press.

headline: Pentagon Accounts For Vietnam Funds Reported Missing
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 13—The Defense Department explained today what had happened to $1.7‐billion in United States support for the Government of South Vietnam that an audit by the General Accounting Office had not been able to trace.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: Thant Hopeful of Peace
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 13 Secretary General Thant considers prospects for a peaceful solution of the Viet nam war brighter now than at any time since peace talks be gan in Paris in May, 1968, a spokesman said today.

headline: Fighting Still Curtailed
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 13 (AP)—An almost com plete cessation in war action in South Vietnam extended today through a ninth day, and even United State air strikes were heavily curtailed by tropical storms.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Dean Acheson's conclusion that we need a “self‐governing body for the press … to stimulate … self‐restraint in publishing material ethically uncle sirable (“The Purloined Papers” Op Ed July 7) is a frightening, though perhaps unconscious, attack on consti tutional liberties.

headline: U.S. Said to Be Planning to Seek Indictment of a Times Reporter
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, July 14—The Justice Department was report ed today to be planning to ask a Federal grand jury here to hand down a criminal indict ment against Neil Sheehan, reporter for The New York Times, in connection with the revelation of the Pentagon pa pers. The grand jury is investi gating how the secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war was made available to the press.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In your article by Sanche de Gra moot [Op‐Ed July 1] on former Secre tary of Defense McNamara your writer mentions that Albert Speer, with whom Mr. McNamara is compared in an unfavorable way, was never a member of the Nazi party. Mr. Speer requested party member ship and joined the Nazi party in Jan uary of 1931. His membership number was 474,481.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Dean Acheson (Op‐Ed July 7) says that the “purloined papers” should have been returned to their owners, “the Government,” Like the Chief Jus tice, he views the papers as physical possessions, in the category of lost shirt‐studs or stolen five‐dollar bills. Even so, it seems odd to return the evidence of deceit and betrayal of public trust to the authors of the deceit.

headline: Vietnamese Refugees From Cambodia. Say They Don't Want to Go Back
lead_paragraph: TAMTHONG, South Vietnam, July 8—One year after the allied attack on Cambodia swept them into the Indochina war, the Vietnamese settlers in Cambodia who fled the fighting there have put down new roots in South Vietnam and, despite the hardships, say they want to stay.
author: By Inter Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Package Reply to Vietcong Not Planned, Ziegler Says
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14—The Western White House sought today to discourage speculation that President Nixon was preparing a “pack age response” to the Viet namese Communists’ seven point peace proposal of July 1.
author: By John Berbers Special to The New York Times

headline: Ky Says Thieu Tries to Rig Vote
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Vietnam, July 14— Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky accused President Nguyen Van Thieu today of, using dictatori al practices” to silence the op position, muzzle the press and insure his re‐election.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Soviet Details ‘Conspiracy’ Behind Pentagon Papers
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, July 14—Soviet readers, still curious about how it was possible for several American newspapers to pub lish secret Pentagon papers on Vietnam without the Govern ment's approval, were today given a conspiratorial explana tion that reflects some current Soviet thinking about America.’
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Reprimand and Fine For Antiwar Officer
lead_paragraph: LAKENHEATH, England, July 14—Capt. Thomas S. Culver was reprimanded today and fined $1,000 for taking part in an antiwar demonstration.

headline: Allied Bulldozers Are Clearing An Ex‐Vietcong Base for Crops
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 (AP)—United States and South Vietnamese troops with bulldozers and tanks began clearing a large wooded and scrub‐brush area north of here today to permit farmers to re turn to land that had long served as a Vietcong stronghold.

headline: AUSTRALIAN SAYS CHINA NOW FAVORS INDOCHINA PARLEY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 14—The Australian Embassy told the State Department today that China had expressed interest in participating in a new Geneva conference on Indochina.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘A Reasonable Chance’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Publication of the Pentagon Papers has increased a wide spread feeling that the public has not been adequately informed of United States intentions in Vietnam. The credibility of the Government was al ready at low point. To restore con fidence it is essential that the Admin istration now clarify its aims in Vietnam.
author: By W. Averell Harriman

headline: U.S. and Vietcong Plans For Peace Are Compared
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 15—Following is a chart com paring peace proposals by President Nixon in June, 1969, and October, 1970, with Vietcong positions in 1969 and July, 1971. Mr. Nixon has not yet replied to the latest Vietcong proposal.

headline: ‘Pentagon Papers’ Is Selling Quickly Publisher Reports
lead_paragraph: More than a million copies of the paperback edition of “The Pentagon Papers” are in print, according to Bantam Books, the publisher.

headline: DOLE SAYS TRIALS MIGHT HARM G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 15— Senator Robert Dole, the Re publcan National Chairman, said today that any decision to prosecute criminally the dis tributor of the Pentagon papers or the newspapers that printed them could be politically harm ful to the Republican party.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: House Unit Disdoses Civilian Killings in U.S.‐Backed Program
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 15 — Previously classified informa tion read into the record of a House Government Operations subcommittee today disclosed that 26,843 nonmilitary Viet cong insurgents and sympa thizers were “neutralized” in 14 months through Operation Phoenix, a counterinsurgency program in South Vietnam fi nanced by the United States.
author: By Felix Belam Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Credit Markets: Prices Hold Steady
lead_paragraph: Newswire accounts of United States proposal for Vietnam ceasefire lifted some bond prices early yesterday but most later settled back to levels reflecting little or no gain.
author: By Robert D. Hershey Jr

headline: U.S. War Dead Listed At 29 in Week's Report
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15 (AP) — The allied commands today issued cas ualty summaries for last week listing 29 Americans, 238 South Vietnamese and 1,105 North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops as killed in action.

headline: BRUCE SAYS ENEMY SETS HARSH TERMS
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July. 15 — David K. E. Bruce, the United States rep resentative at the Vietnam peace talks, told the Commu nists today that their latest pro posal for a settlement left their objectives unchanged and set “far‐reaching” and “harsh” conditions.
author: By Anthony Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: Man in the News
lead_paragraph: When a South Vietnamese lawyer who heads a small antiwar movement scheduled a reception in Saigon recent ly, the police kept all but one of the guests from entering.

headline: Ellsberg Obtains Delay on Coast Trial
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, July 15—Issuance, of an order requiring Dr. Daniel Ellsberg to go to Los Angeles to stand trial in connection with the Pentagon papers was put off for at least eight days today as his lawyers sought to show that the Government's case against him was based on illegal wiretap evidence.
author: By Joseph Lelyveld Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Reaction
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, July 16 (Reuters)—Presi dent Nixon's announcement was generally well received by South Vietnamese politicians here today although there was no official comment from the Government.

headline: Minh Charges U.S. Gives Election Help to Thieu
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15 (AP) — Gen. Duong Van Minh, a possible contender for the Presidency of South Vietnam, charged today that American support of President Nguyen Van Thieu could pre vent a fair and honest elec tion on Oct. 3.

headline: Saigon Ends Fruitless Drive in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 16 (AP) — Two thirds of a 1,500‐man South Vietnamese task force pulled back to South Vietnam yester day from a fruitless, one‐Week drive into eastern Cambodia.

headline: Kissinger Visit Capped 2‐Year Effort
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 15— Henry A. Kissinger's secret visit to Peking last week, announced tonight by President Nixon, capped two years of overtures by the United States to China, based on the President's con viction that Peking must be come a full‐fledged member of the international community.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Text of Statement by Bruce at Peace Talks in Paris
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 15—Following is the text of the opening re marks today by David K. E. Bruce, the United States dele gate, at the 121st plenary session of the Paris meet ings on Vietnam:

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Tom Wicker's almost savage reply to Dean Acheson's remarks on The Times publication of the Pentagon papers suggests that Mr. Acheson has struck a nerve when he wonders why the papers weren't returned to their owner as stolen goods.

headline: Private Charged in Killing Of Two Officers in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: FORT ORD, Calif., July 16 (UPI) — An Army private has been charged with the murder of two lieutenants and the at tempted murder of three other officers in Vietnam.

headline: The Talk of Lakenheath
lead_paragraph: LAKENHEATH, England, July 16—On the sprawling United States Air Force Base here, the trial of Capt. Thomas S. Culver was barely overshadowed this week by a widely anticipated and ea gerly discussed event: the opening of the new swim ming pool.
author: By Bernard Weinraub Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Move Pleases Reagan
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 (UPI)—Gov. Ronald Reagan suggested today that President Nixon might have left the exact date open for his planned trip to China because the date might be tied in with his hopes to, end the Vietnam war. He said he was happy about the trip.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 16—In “The Making of The President 1968” Theodore White records a comment by Richard Nixon on the function of the American Presi dency.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 16 President Nixon's success in ar ranging a trip to China evoked the widespread judgment here today that American policy, in Mao Tse‐tung's phrase, was taking a great leap forward.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Possibly the most important U.S. influence on the South Vietnamese elections will derive from the rate of pull‐out.

headline: 10 Vietcong Reported Killed
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, July 16 (Reuters)— A South Vietnamese military spokesman reported today that Government troops ambushed a Vietcong patrol 45 miles south west of Saigon yesterday and killed 10 guerrillas. There were no Government casualties, he added.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: We regard the news media's han dling of the Pentagon papers as weak, inconclusive and confusing to the pub lic. Granted, the media have shown courage and solidarity in defending the freedom of the press in America. However, apart from the admirable efforts of The Times, they have dis played, on the whole, little initiative or incisiveness in clarifying for the public the significance of the informa tion contained in the report.

headline: Move by President Seems to Outflank His Potential Foes
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 16— President Nixon appeared to day to have significantly de fused criticism of the Indo china war and outflanked his potential Presidential chal lengers with his announce ment that he would visit China.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: 8–52's Raid Foe Near DMZ; Scattered Fighting Is Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16 (AP)—While a series of small skirmishes dominated the ground war today, United States B‐52 bombers flew four more raids along South Viet nam's northern frontier in a continuing effort to block an enemy build‐up.

headline: Harris to Yield Senate Seat To Campaign for President
lead_paragraph: NORMAN, Okla., July 16— Senator Fred R. Harris, the son of an Oklahoma share cropper, announced today that he was giving up his Senate seat to organize a campaign for the Democratic nomination for President.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: NIXON IS EXPECTED TO VISIT CHINA AROUND END OF YEAR; TO SEE BOTH MAO AND CHOU
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July, 16—Officials at the Western White House said today that President Nixon's trip to China could be made late this year at the earliest and that he would confer with Mao Tse tung as well as Premier Chou En‐lai.
author: By John Herbers Special to The New York Times

headline: Typhoon Again Halts the Fighting
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 (AP)—Winds and rain in South Vietnam's northern region halted the fighting today for the third time in two weeks.

headline: Enemy Activity on Rise Near Saigon As Militiamen Replace Allied Troops
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17—With most American ground combat troops now gone from the, area around Saigon, and few regular South Vietnamese forces protecting its periphery, enemy activity has been increasing on the outer edge of the capital rgion.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: THIEU DENOUNCES N.B.C. DRUG CHARGE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 — President Nguyen Van Thieu today described as shocking and slanderous a National Broadcasting Company report alleging that he was using funds from the illegal drug market to finance his campaign for reelection.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Uneasy Malaysia and Singapore Bolster Defenses
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE, July 14—Half a million pamphlets announcing rewards of up to $6,900 for information leading to the arrest, killing or surrender of Communist terrorists are being distributed in the border areas of Upper Perak in Malaysia.
author: By Drew Middleton Special to The New York Times

headline: 4.5% IN G.I. TEST ARE HEROIN USERS
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 17—Tests of 22,000 American servicemen leaving Vietnam showed that 4.5 per cent of them had been using heroin, President Nixon's special assistant on drugs reported today.
author: By John Herbers Special to The New York Times

headline: VIETCONG INSIST PEACE CAN COME AT TALKS IN PARIS
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 17—A spokesman for the Vietcong delegation declared here today that the Paris peace talks still offered the best means of settling the Vietnamese war.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: The Last Word: Should Science Be Shot?
lead_paragraph: Things being what they are, which is not what most of would wish them to be, one can't walk down the streets of the mind these days without getting mugged by a Single Cause. The Single Cause usually has an accomplice, the Single Cure. Original Sin, sexism, anality, atavistic aggressive impulses, the school and/or economic system, the death of God, Vietnam, Dostoyevsky, Chairman Mao and Mayor Lindsay are among the Single Causes. Marijuana, Sesame Street, R. D. Laing, water beds, tactical nuclear weapons, Aesthetic Realism, the Living Theatre, the polymorphous perverse, Esalen and Jane Fonda are among the Single Cures.
author: By John Leonard

headline: SOUTH VIETNAM BARS 400 FROM HOUSE RACE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17—About 400 candidates for South Vietnam's assembly were disqualified today by local committes. The elections are to be held Aug. 29.

headline: Sihanouk Hails New Policy
lead_paragraph: PEKING, July 17 (Agence France‐Presse)—Prince Norodom Sihanouk, who from Peking leads the Cambodian resistance against the regime of Gen. Lon Nol, said today that he was pleased with the “new look of Chinese‐American policy.”

headline: In Danang Area, Unemployment Is the Enemy Also
lead_paragraph: HOAKHANH, South Vietnam—In the tiny cafe with its wooden tables and stools where men used to sit drinking Vietnamese beer in icefilled glasses, the owner grumbles that his customers have stopped coming.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: PARIS—Observers of the Vietnam peace talks went to bed here last Thursday night in a mood of some discouragement. That day's session of the talks, the 121st in three dreary years, had pretty well dispelled the hope that the July 1 initiative of the Vietcong would get some real negotiation going at last.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: For the Vietnam Farmer, Terror Is Never Far Off
lead_paragraph: TRUNGLAP, South Vietnam, July 13—Vo Van Duc, a 40‐year‐old farmer who was abducted with 19 others by the Vietcong last month, tells the story like a man who has memorized a nightmare.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The New Options at Paris
lead_paragraph: MIDDLEBURY, Vt. — Mrs. Binh's seven paints of July I offer mo... than just an opportunity to settle the prisoner issue. The plan :..le submitted at Paris on behalf of the Provisional Revolutionary Government could lead to an end of the Vietnamese war and a lessening of hostilities in Southeast Asia.
author: By Jim Blum

headline: Thais Believed Able to Stem Any Rise in Insurgency
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand—Premier Thanom Kittikachorn told Government workers here recently that United States withdrawal from Vietnam would increase “the danger to Thailand” because “the Communists will intensify their war of insurgency against us.”
author: By Drew Middleton Special to The New York Times

headline: Backers of Minh Gather to Attack Thieu and U.S.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 18—Some of President Nguyen Van Thieu's most tireless critics, who are supporting Gen. Duong van Mirth for president of South Vietnam, held their first public meeting today to denounce President Thieu, and to charge election rigging and American interference.

headline: Hanoi Accuses. U.S. on Nixon Doctrine
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Monday, July 19 (Reuters) — North Vietnam accused the United States today of dividing socialist countries under the Nixon Doctrine.

headline: FIRE BASE BUNKERS WITHSTAND BARRAGE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 19 (UPI)—The new concrete bunkers at the rebuilt Fire Base Fuller below the demilitarized zone withstood a heavy mortar barge by enemy troops without damage yesterday, and American B‐52 bombers responded with a strike against enemy position just north of the mountaintop base early this morning, a military spokesman said.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Man Held in Wounding of 3
lead_paragraph: STONINGTON. Maine, July 18 (UPI)—A man firing a rifle wounded three persons today. David Eaton, 23 year old, was arrested and charged with assault with intent to kill. The police said that he was a Vietnam veteran on parole from a burglary sentence. The wounded were James D. Haines, 23, of Ann Arbor, Mich, his wife, Sherri, and Karen Ray, 33.

headline: Senator Scott Foresees Vietnam Pullout by May
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 18—Hugh Scott, the Senate Republican leader, said today he believed that President Nixon's decision to visit Peking by May, 1972, indicated that there would be no AmeriCan combat troops left in Southeast Asia by that time.
author: By Henry Tanner Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu Terms Minh A Liar and Defends Role in Diem Coup
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 20—President Nguyen Van Thieu struck back at his political rivals tonight, calling Gen. Duong Van Minh a “coward and a liar,” and insisting that the presidential elections this fall would be fair and honest.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Pullout Rate Well Ahead of Schedule
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 19 (UPI)—The halfway mark in President Nixon's program to pull 100,000 more servicemen out of Vietnam by December was passed last week when 3,000 soldiers went home.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: M1AMI—If President Nixon's historic visit to China means that by mid1972 there is to be a negotiated settlement in Vietnam or a total American withdrawal from the war, then the Presidential election may well be settled in Peking. If not—if these remarkable new prospects somehow fail—then what will happen here in Florida next March 14 ought to be of considerable significance.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Chou Meets U.S. Scholars
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, July 19 (Reuters)—Premier Chou En‐lai of China today met a 15‐member delegation of American scholars who specialize in Asian affairs, the Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, reported. Mr. Chou had a “cordial and friendly conversation” with the Amencans, members of the Committee of Concerned Asian Scholars, which opposes American policy in Vietnam, the agency said.

headline: One and One Make War
lead_paragraph: “We know best” is the predictable reaction of crisis managers to angry popular assertions of principle. If secrecy is the first official refuge from emergency in the name of patriotism, deception is the second. The revelations in the Pentagon Papers involve not one form of deception but two. The first was perpetrated on the public in the name of crisis management. But the companion deception foreclosed all possibility of managerial practicality. It recalled Talleyrand's warning that a blunder is more serious than a crime.
author: By Eliot Janeway

headline: American Killed as Rockets Hit a Depot Near Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 19 (Reuters) — War activity remained at a low level today, with reports of only A few small, isolated skirmishes and a Vietcong rocket attack on a helicopter repair depot near Saigon.

headline: Pentagon Expected to Act On War Papers This Week
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 19—The Pentagon is expected to make some announcement this week on removing the secrecy label from part of its study of the Vietnam War, Jerry W. Friedheim, Defense Department spokesman, said today.

headline: Javits Says Nixon's China Trip Is Sign of Progress on Disputes
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE, July 19—Senator Jacob K. Javits said today that President Nixon would not be planning a trip to China unless major issues between the two powers “were already on the way to agreement.”
author: By Frank Lynn Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Feels Little Is New In Saigon's Trace Offer
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 19—The White House appeared to see little new today in a proposal by South Vietnam for a cease‐fire and elections to reunite North and South Vietnam.

headline: U.S. Giving Radar Sites to Vietnamese
lead_paragraph: U.S. Giving Radar Sites to Vietnamese VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, July 13—The United States Navy is building 16 radar sites for surveillance of ship movements along the coast of South Vietnam and plans to give them to the South Vietnamese Navy by next spring.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's decision to unfreeze relations with China and to visit that country has major significance for American domestic politics. In its initial impact, this diplomatic move is a political triumph for Mr. Nixon. Americans want peace, and no President ever looks better than when he is seen to be working for peace in a large, statesmanlike way.
author: By William V. Shannon

headline: U.S. Aide Defends Pacification Program In Vietnam Despite Killings of Civilians
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 19—The former head of the American pacification agency in South Vietnam acknowledged today that the agency's antisubversion program had resulted in “occasional” political assassinations and the killing of overcame these occasional Vietcong agents.
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Peking Reiterates Support Of Vietnamese Communists
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Tuesday, July 20 (Reuters)—The official Chinese newspaper, Jenmin Jih Pao, today reiterated Peking's full support for the Vietnamese Communists and warned American imperialists of “miserable failure” if it persisted in its present Indochina policy.

headline: BALL WARNS ON RISK IN ‘FLAMBOYANT ’ TRIP
lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 19—Former Under Secretary of State George W. Ball said today that President Nixon's coming trip to China was “flamboyant diplomacy” that could just as well have been carried out by sending the Secretary of State, and a step that holds risks for the President.

headline: Congress Puts Off Meeting On Extension of Draft Law
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) — Reinstatement of the draft law by Congress was put off today into at least a fifth week —and possibly into September — when House‐Senate conferees called off a meeting to try to break the deadlock over an amendment setting a deadline for an end to the Vietnam War.

headline: Nixon's Journey Is Discussed by Rogers and Envoys
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 19—The Nixon Administration sought today to halt speculation in Congressional quarters that President Nixon's forthcoming visit to Communist China would hasten settlement of the Vietnam war.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Secrets’ in the National Review: Memo Disavowed, Clue Given
lead_paragraph: National Review, the conservative weekly magazine, published yesterday, a selection of what it described as “highly classified documents” dealing with United States involvement in Vietnam, which it said had been leaked to the magazine.

headline: Draft Lottery Is Scheduled for Aug. 5 as Deadlock in Congress Is M aintained on Extension of the Law
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 20—The Selective Service System announced today that the next draft lottery would be held Aug. 5.
author: By David E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: NEW JURY STUDIES PENTAGON PAPERS
lead_paragraph: W ASHINGTON, July 20—The Government has dismissed Federal grand jury in Boston looking into the Pentagon papers case and replaced it with another grand jury. Government sources said the action was taken because of a leak to the press.

headline: Nixon, Chinaand Wall St.
lead_paragraph: The news of President Nixon's coming trip to Communist China, sensational as it is politically, produced virtually no effect on the stock market. Considering the elation of the President and his closest advisers, the historic importance of this shift in American foreign policy and the enormous play the event was given by the press and television, how can one explain Wall Street's minimal reaction? Was the market simply slow on the uptake? Will a euphoric double take occur later? Or was the financial community wary and doubtful that the President's planned journey was any occasion for joy?
author: By Leonard S. Silk

headline: Saigon Units Open Drive in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 21 — South Vietnam today reportedly launched its largest operation in six months in eastern Cambodia with the announced aim of providing security for the forthcoming South Vietnamese elections.

headline: CHOU EIVIPHASIZES U.S. WAR PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: PEKING, July 20 — Premier Chou En‐lai has told a group of American graduate students that a complete withdrawal of United States forces from Indochina must take priority over moves to improve ChineseAmerican relations.

headline: The Making of a Myth
lead_paragraph: MEDFORD, Mass—In its Pentagon disclosures the press has fallen into the same trap as those who overclassified the study in the first place. Because of its secrecy, the press has treated the study as if it contained astounding revelations, and has conveyed that view to the public. This obscures the simple fact that the Pentagon Papers provide minimal new information and raise more questions than are answered.
author: By Allan W. Cameron

headline: Vietcong Warn U. S.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 20 (UPI)—The Vietcong said today that the United States should deal directly with the Vietnamese instead of sending diplomats “scurrying” around the world to enlist support for an imposed solution to the Indochina war.

headline: MOSCOW AFFIRMS ITSTILL OPPOSES INDOCHINA PARLEY
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, July 20 — The Soviet Government today affirmed support for Communist China's admission to the United Nations and opposition to art international conference on Indochina.
author: By Bernard Gwertznian Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 in House Say U. S. Hides Extent of C.I. Drug Use
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON; July 20—Two Representatives who recently visited Vietnam and reported that heroin users made up 10 to 15 per cent of all American servicemen there accused the Nixon Administration today of “trying to sweep the problem under the rug.”

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 21—There is a striking difference between the re actions in this country and in China to President Nixon's announcement of his forthcoming visit to Peking. Here there are banner headlines, an out burst of optimism about the future and warm congratulations for the President,
author: By William V. Shannon

headline: U.S. REPORT TELLS OF GAINS BY ENEMY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 21 —A new assessment of the internal security of South Vietnam by the United States Embassy in Saigon shows that the enemy is gaining strength in up‐coun try areas evacuated by Ameri can forces as well as in parts of the densely populated Me kong River Delta.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Peking's Role in Vietnam Peace
lead_paragraph: President Nixon is wise to discourage speculation about the effect of his new China policy on Vietnam. Euphoric hopes in the country, stirred in part by earlier White House comments, could boomerang badly if the war not ended. But equally dangerous is the effect Mr. Nixon's own hopes for Chinese aid may have on his strategy for peace in Southeast Asia.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: His sonorous voice in fine form, Laurence Olivier made his maiden speech before Britain's House of Lords, and he gave it some neo‐shake spearean cadences. “I fear your lordships may find grim cause to reflect upon the prescient genius of the intro ducer of this tenderest of courtesies,” he said. “And if I fail to achieve it then must beg to suggest to your lordships that it would be most contrary to the chival ry for which your lordships’ house is so famous to with hold your gallantry and re fuse to indulge a maiden of 64.” Lord Olivier took the floor to speak in support of an industrial relations bill that would aid actors. When he was done, his peers ap plauded warmly, but they turned out to be a cold audi ence. When the vote on the Olivier‐sponsored bill came, it went down to defeat, 102

headline: Buckley Admits ‘Secrets’ Hoax; Many in News Media Taken In
lead_paragraph: William F. Buckley Jr., the publisher of National Review, acknowledged yesterday that the magazine's published col lection of “highly classified documents” was a hoax. It had fooled a large segment of the American news media.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: Official Denounces U.S.
lead_paragraph: PEKING, July 21 (Agence France‐Presse) — Deputy Pre mier Li Hsien‐nien said tonight that “the Chinese people will liberate Taiwan.”

headline: Last U.S. Combat Unit Below DMZ Pulls Out
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 22 — The last American combat battalion was withdrawn from the area just below the demilitarized zone as Communist shellings of the bases now manned by South Vietnamese continued today, military sources said.

headline: South Vietnamese Reported Reoccupying Corridor in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21 — South Vietnamese troops in eastern Cambodia were reported today to be re occupying part of a Communist infiltration corridor that they had left open after a retreat early in June.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Will Tighten Its Rules On Press Coverage of War
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21 (Reuters)—The South Viet namese command said today that it planned to issue a set of ground rules for the press that “will very much restrict reporting on military opera tions.”

headline: ARMY DISMISSES ATROCITY CHARGE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) —The Army announced today the dismissal of charges against Col. Joseph R. Franklin, who had been accused by another officer of covering up atrocities in Vietnam.

headline: 21 Die in Copter Crash
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Thursday, July 22 (Reuters)—Twenty‐one South Vietnamese rangers were killed and 36 other soldiers, including five American advisers, were injured when a United States Chinook helicopter crashed in northern Quangtin Province yesterday, the Saigon high command said today. A spokes man attributed the crash to “technical” causes.

headline: Parents of Dead Marine Lose Suit on ‘Illegal War’
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, July 21 (UPI) —A United States District Court judge has dismissed a $500,000 damage suit against the Government by a Danbury (couple who contend their son's ‘death in Vietnam's “illegal war” violated his constitutional rights.

headline: U.S. AIDES ACCUSED ON VIETNAM VOTE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 21 —Congressional investigators heard testimony today that United States officials in Sai gon were seeking to influence next October's national election in favor of President Nguyen Van Thieu and that the ballot ing would be a “mockery” of the democratic
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In a radio interview here recently, Walt W. Rostow complained bitterly against publication of the Penta gon papers by The Times on the ground that they represented a dis tortion, being incomplete, and accom panied by commentary which he viewed as misinterpretation.

headline: Hanoi Aide in Paris Accuses U.S. of ‘Perfidious Maneuvers’
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 22—North Viet nam's chief delegate, Xuan Thuy, apparently alluding to President Nixon's plans to visit Peking, accused the United States today of seeking to divide the Communist world by “perfidious maneuvers” in a “false offensive” for peace in Vietnam.
author: By Clyde H. Farnsworth;Special to The New York Times

headline: Rep. Steele Asserts Gen. Dzu Is Linked To Looting of Bases
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) — Representative Robert H. Steele said today that the South Vietnamese general he accused of being a heroin trafficker was also being investigated in con nection with the looting of two abandoned United States mili tary bases.

headline: GICOMBAT DEATHS LOWEST SINCE '65
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22—American battle deaths last week were the lowest in nearly six years, the United States command announced to day. It said the total reflected the continuing withdrawal of American troops and the low level of combat.

headline: No Credibility Gap On National Review At the White House
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 22—The newspapers and news agencies that accepted as genuine the “top‐secret” papers on Vietnam published by National Review this week were not the only ones embarrassed when William F. Buckley Jr., the conservative magazine's publisher, admitted yesterday that he had perpe trated a hoax. They had high official company.

headline: Clash in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, July 22 (AP)—South Vietnamese troops sweeping through eastern Cambodia in a new drive clashed for the first time today with North Viet namese forces.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I have been chagrined lately to see such eminent spokesmen as Cyrus S. Eaton (letter July 10) use the argu ment that since “the North Vietna mese were better informed about Washington actions and policies than the American people,” Congress should insure that more secret information is bared to the American public.

headline: U.S. Says Foe Is Building Road Across Buffer Zone
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) —The State Department said today that North Vietnam was building a road across the demilitarized zone into the northern section of South Vietnam, but refused to say whether such action violates the 1968 understanding that led to the end of United States bombing of North Vietnam.

headline: Anti‐War Veteran Accused of Exploiting P. O.W. Issue
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP)—A number of wives of American prisoners of war lashed out today at John F. Kerry, the peace‐group lead er, accusing him of using the prisoner issue as a spring board to political office.

headline: Nixon's China Goal: Genuine Diplomatic Turning Point
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 22—A week has passed since Presi dent Nixon scheduled his jour ney to Peking and shook up the world of diplomacy.
author: By Max Frankel;Special to The New York Times

headline: DRAFT MAY TURN TO EX‐STUDENTS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 23 — Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Gov ernment might be forced to start conscripting men previous ly deferred from the draft un less Congress passed a draft extension bill by September.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Contenders Running Fast
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, July 23—Contend ers for South Vietnam's presi dency are filling the air these days with charges and counter charges, some aimed at the United States, some at each other. A few are even intended to influence the voters.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: State Department Primer On the War Discontinued
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, there was a curious child who wrote a letter to a city called Washington, where the Pres ident lives, asking if some one would tell him, please, about this thing called Viet nam that the grownups were talking about all the time.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: Charges of Illegal Wiretaps Detailed in Ellsberg Brief
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, July 23 (UPI) — Lawyers for Daniel Ellsberg filed a nine‐page brief with Federal magistrate today, de tailing their contention that be cause of illegally obtained wire tap evidence Dr. Ellsberg should not stand trial for leaking the Pentagon papers.

headline: Foe Attacks a South Vienatnese Command Post
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 (AP)—A band of 15 enemy demolition men staged an attack early today on the headquarters in South Vietnam for the recently begun South Vietnamese sweep in eastern Cambodia.

headline: Reading of Pentagon Papers Set for Thursday on WBAI
lead_paragraph: WBAI, New York's listener‐ supported FM radio station, is planning a marathon reading of the controversial Pentagon papers, beginning Thursday at 10 A.M. and continuing until all the documents have been read. The reading will be in terrupted by the news, the war summary, musical breaks and excerpts from Tolstoy's “War and Peace.”

headline: Thieu Declares His Candidacy and Names a New Running Mate
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, July 24—President Ngu yen Van Thieu formally de clared his intention to run for re‐election this morning and announced that his running mate would be Tran Van Huong, a former Premier who is highly respected in South Vietnamese politics.

headline: Some Things Every Newspaper Should Know
lead_paragraph: “History is not woven with innocent hands,” wrote Lord Acton. “Among all the causes which degrade and de moralize men, power is the most con stant and most active.”
author: By Jeffrey st. John

headline: G.O.P. CONVENTION GOES TO SAN DIEGO
lead_paragraph: DENVER, July 23—The Re publican party decided tonight to hold its 1972 Presidential convention in San Diego, deep in politically conservative Southern California and con veniently near the summer White House in San Clemente.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: McCarthy in the Race?
lead_paragraph: Three years ago Senator Eugene J. McCarthy ran for President primarily to educate the American people on the nature of the Vietnam war—a mission he per formed with a high degree of success. By all accounts he is thinking very seriously of running again, this time, it would seem, with the more commonplace objective of becoming President of the United States.

headline: SAIGON ANNOUNCES NEW CAMBODIA DRIVE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 24 (AP)—The South Viet namese command today an nounced a second new drive inside Cambodia and said the troops had met no resistance so far.

headline: WITH RULES EASED, G.I.'S STAY AT BASE
lead_paragraph: CANTHO, South Vietnam, July 19—The G.I.'s are not vis iting the Toots Short Bar and Scientific Massage Parlor the way they used to, and the cyclo drivers and the urchins who of fer heroin for sale on the streets of this dirty delta city cannot remember when the price has been so low.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Moscow Avows It Desires Better U.S. and China Ties
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Sunday, July 25— The Soviet Union said today that it sought better relations with Communist China and the United States but warned both powers against anti‐Soviet col laboration.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—When a top Ameri can pacification official heard that Gen. Duong Van “Big” Minh had charged his political rival, President Nguyen Van Thieu, with using the Phoenix counter‐insurgency program to suppress political opposition, he laughed. “If that's what Big Minh thinks,” the American said derisively, “he doesn't know the Phoenix program, because it isn't good enough to do that.”
author: —Iver Peterson

headline: Senate Authorizes Funds For Indochina War Inquiry
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) —The Senate today adopted a resolution authorizing its Foreign Relations Committee to spend $100,000 on an inves tigation of policy‐making relat ing to United States involve ment in Southeast Asia.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: David N. Reps New York, July 9, 1971

headline: Black Aide Criticizes Nixon on Rights
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 — A black official in the Nixon Administration said today that the President's Southern strat egy was now denying many Negroes in the South the right to vote.
author: By Earl Caldwell Special to The New York Times

headline: Soviet Press, Taken In, Silent on Buckley Hoax
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, July 24 (AP)— The Soviet press has pub lished articles on the Na tional Review's report last week about “secret” Penta gon papers, but has not told its readers that the report was a hoax.

headline: Groppi Advocates Coalition of Blacks and Whites
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE, July 22—Near ly eight years ago, the Rev. James E. Groppi first led his Negro and white shock troops out of Milwaukee's central ghetto into the white, working class “lunch bucket” South Side, driving for open housing and equal opportunities.
author: By David A. Andelman Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. AIDES DEFEND BOMBING OF TRAIL
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 17 —Senior officers of the Seventh United States Air Force are con vinced that their raids against supply lines along the Ho Chi Minh Trail have prevented the enemy from launching major ground attacks in South Viet nam.
author: By Drew Middleton Special to The New York Times

headline: Games Cold Warriors Play
lead_paragraph: In weighing the chances of success for the projected Visit of President Nixon to Peking, it is essential to view his mission in the light of the estab lished American strategy and “com mitments” in Asia. The situation in that regard is all too clear, given especially the revelations of the Pentagon Papers.
author: By O. Edmund Clubb

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Benjamin H. Oehlert Jr. Palm Beach, Fla., July 16, 1971

headline: MEDINA FACES TRIAL TODAY IN 102 DEATHS
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., July 25 (UPI) — Capt. Ernest L. Medina goes on trial tomorrow charged with murdering 102 persons when soldiers under his command swept through the village of Mylai in March, 1968.

headline: KY, CAMPAIGNING, HINTS HE'LL QUIT
lead_paragraph: GIAKIEM, South Vietnam, July 25—Vice President Ngu yeo Cao Ky held out the pos sibility today of dropping out of the race for the presidency in a deal with Gen. Duong Van Minh, a possible candidate.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Embassy in Saigon Calls Babies of G.I's A ‘Serious Concern’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 25—The United States Embassy in Sai gon has informed the State De partment that “responsibility for American‐fathered illegiti mate children” in South Viet nam “has become a matter of serious and continuing con cern.”
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: 50 VIETCONG ATTACK HAMLET IN THE DELTA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25 (AP)—About 50 Vietcong soldiers slipped into a Mekong Delta hamlet today and at tacked sleeping villagers with hand grenades and rifle fire.

headline: G.I. USE OF HEROIN IS REPORTED CUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON. July 26, — Representative Robert H. Steele, the Connecticut Republican who has been at odds with the Nixon Administration over the extent of heroin use in Viet nam, said today that “very substantial progress” had been made in controlling service, men's use of the drug.

headline: MINH ANNOUNCES HIS ENTRY IN RACE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26—Duong Van Minh, the retired general who led the 1963 coup d'état against President Ngo Dinh Diem, announced for mally today that he would run against President Nguyen Van Thieu in the Oct. 3 election.

headline: Soviet Publishes a Book
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, July 26 (AP)—The Soviet Union has published a book on the secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

headline: Medina's First Juror Is Tentatively Accepted as Mylai Court‐Martial Opens
lead_paragraph: FORT MCPHERSON, Ga., July 26—The trial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina, accused by the Army of responsibility for the Mylai massacre, opened today in a small stuffy courtroom at Third Army Headquarters.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Delays Release of Pentagon Study
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 26 — Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has decided to delay re lease of any of the Pentagon papers because of “legal” and “security” problems.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Peter J. Riga (REV.) Professor of Religion La Salle College Philadelphia, July 2, 1971

headline: Some U.S. Analysts Believe Peking Could Not Help Settle the Vietnam War Except on Hanoi's Terms
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 26 — Mounting North Vietnamese and Vietcong attacks on Presi dent Nixon's new policy toward China have led some United States Government analysts to conclude that Peking, even if it so desired, would be unable to help settle the Vietnam war ex cept on Hanoi's terms.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Lifts Saigon Unit to Mountains Near Ashau
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 (UPI) —United States heli copters lifted a battalion of Government troops into moun tains southeast of the Ashau Valley today. Almost immediate contact with enemy troops was reported.

headline: U.S. Forces in Vietnam Now Down to 229,200
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 (UPI) — The United States military command said today that 4,100 Ameri can servicemen were pulled out of the war zone last week, reducing American troop strength in Vietnam to 229,200.

headline: Ky Declares He Won't Quit Election in Favor of Minh
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27 (Reuters) — Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said tonight that he would not bow out of South Vietnam's presidential election, scheduled to be held Oct. 3, and throw his support behind Duong, Van Minh, the retired general is considered President Nguyen Van Thieu's strongest challenger.

headline: Pentagon Data Cited as Parley Of Congress War Foes Opens
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnamese Plan to Resume Shifting Hill Tribesmen
lead_paragraph: DALAT, South Vietnam, July 23—Vietnamese province chiefs and military authorities in the Central Highlands are planning to resume a controversial pro gram of transferring tens of thousands of primitive hill tribesmen out of Communist controlled areas.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: 8 ACQUITTED IN ‘TEST’ OF MAYDAY ARRESTS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) —Eight persons arrested on the Capitol steps May 5 during antiwar demonstrations were acquitted today by a Superior Court jury of disorderly parad ing and unlawful entry.

headline: 5 Medina Jurors Are Selected For Tentative Quorum in Trial
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Shangri‐La to Bow Out
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, July 27 (Reuters)— The aircraft carrier Shangri‐La will be decommissioned at the Boston Navy Yard Friday. The 40,000‐ton vessel, launched Sept. 15, 1944, saw service in World War II, the Korean War and was on active duty in the Tonkin Gulf in support of troops in Vietnam. She will re main in the reserve fleet.

headline: ENEMY BLOWS UP 4 U.S. HELICOPTERS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 28 (AP)— Enemy demolition men stole into an allied base 30 miles north of here in predawn dark ness yesterday, blew up four American helicopters and dam aged a fifth.

headline: A PLAN IS OFFERED ON TROOP PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 28 — The Nixon Administration and Senate conferees were reported today to have worked out a compromise on the amendment on troop withdrawals from Vietnam that they hope will be acceptable to the House con ferees and Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 28—President Nixon's approach to Peking, no mat ter how welcome it may be, was planned in secrecy, decided by Presi dential fiat, carried out clandestinely and finally announced only as accom plished fact. Thus, whatever else it was, this grand diplomatic undertak ing was another exercise in executive omnipotence. Though aimed at peace, the operation so far has not been much different from the hidden proc esses that carried the nation into the war in Vietnam, and its consequences could be even more far‐reaching.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: 2 U.S. Copters Downed
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Thursday, July 29 (Reuters)—Two United States helicopters were shot down and destroyed in two separate inci dents in the Mekong Delta yes terday, a military spokesman said here today.

headline: Porter Is Appointed Chief U.S. Delegate To the Paris Talks
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 28— President Nixon today named William J. Porter to succeed the ailing chief United States delegate to the Paris peace talks, David K. E. Bruce.

headline: ELISBERG PRESSES CONGRESS ON WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 28 — Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, the former Pentagon researcher who says he gave the Pentagon papers to the press, called on members of Congress today to put their jobs, their power and their ca reers on the line to end the war in Vietnam.

headline: 3d Saigon Sweep Of East Cambodia Finds Few of Foe
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 28 (AP)—The third South Vietnamese sweep in eastern Cambodia within a week, which began early today, reportedly has made only minor contact with the enemy.

headline: Hanoi Leader Leaves
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 28—Le Duc Tho, an important member of the North Vietnamese leadership and a special adviser to the delegation here, left today for Hanoi.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Abby Thomas

headline: Five Veterans of Vietnam Seated as Jurors in Medina Case
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., July 28—Five men who believe that the commander of an in fantry company need not neces sarily be held responsible for the alleged massacre by his soldiers of more than 100 Viet namese civilians were seated today as the jury in the court martial of Capt. Ernest L. Me dina.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. MILL BROADEN G.I. HEROIN TESTS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 28—The United States mili tary command has decided to expand its antinarcotics pro gram in South Vietnam to test virtually every serviceman for heroin use, military sources said today.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Agents From 3 Nations Seize $4‐Million in Narcotics in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 28 (AP)—United States. Thai and South Vietnamese narcotics agents, working together, have seized a huge quantity of her oin and opium and arrested the leader of a ring supplying drugs to American soldiers in Viet nam.

headline: Saigon Panel Lifts Ban On 65 House Candidates
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 — A number of anti Government candidates won permission today on appeal to run in South Vietnam's lower house elections next month.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Reports 13 Deaths In Combat Last Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 (AP)—United States battle casualties in Indochina continued at near‐record low levels last week, while South Vietnamese and enemy losses increased, the allied com mands reported today.

headline: The Other Secrets
lead_paragraph: YORK, Me.— I have been reluc tant to enter into the scrimmage caused by the publication in The. New York Times and other newspapers of the documents procured from Dr. Daniel Ellsberg. This disinclination has been shattered by the news report that my former colleague, Dean Acheson, has injected himself into the contro versy. For I fear that his exceptional legal talents will be directed against the wrong target.
author: By Herbert Feis

headline: New Chief for 7th Air Force
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 (UPI)—Gen. John D. Lavelle assumed command today of the United States Seventh Air Force which is responsible for American air operations in In dochina.

headline: RUSK DENIES U.S. PLAN FOR WAR DECEPTION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) — Former Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that President Lyndon B. Johnson “did not have any plans” to widen the Vietnam war before the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin inci dent.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Theodore Sorensen's excuse that the Pentagon papers provide the modern citizen with hindsight that was un available to those responsible for the Vietnamese escalation [Op‐Ed July 13] is another attempt to perpetuate a pernicious myth—that American lead ership was unaware of the idiocy of such involvement. The advice against committing troops on the Asian main land that was offered by such diverse generals as Eisenhower, MacArthur and Ridgway is well known; but per haps forgotten by Mr. Sorensen was a perceptive speech on the Senate floor made on April 6, 1954, by Sen ator John F. Kennedy.
author: Herbert S. Parmet

headline: South Vietnamese Report a Sharp Clash in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, July 30 (AP)—A South Vietnamese task force in east ern Cambodia reported yester day that it had fought a wide spread four‐hour battle with enemy forces, the first sizable contact since it began its sweep the day before.

headline: Bruce Ends Role at Talks With Deadlock Unbroken
lead_paragraph: PARIS. July 29 — David K. E. Bruce retired as chief American delegate to the Viet nam peace talks today in an at mosphere of disappointment and recrimination.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Tests Indicate 5.5% G. I. Addiction, Panel Told
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 30— President Nixon's special con sultant on narcotics and dan gerous drugs told Senate inves tigators today that 5.5 per cent of servicemen tested in South Vietnam had shown indications of heroin addiction.
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Julius Epstein

headline: Jessel Is Cut Off on TV Show Over Reference to Newspapers
lead_paragraph: An interview with George Jes sel on the “Today” show yes terday was cut short when Ed win Newman objected to state ments the entertainer made about The New York Times and The Washington Post, linking them with Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper.
author: By George Gent

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Eric Sevareid

headline: DRAFT CONFEREES AGREE ON A POLICY ON TROOP PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 30 — House and Senate conferees broke the deadlock that has stalled the draft extension bill for the last month by reaching agreement today on a compro mise version of the Senate's Vietnam troop withdrawal amendment.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Enemy Is Reported Repulsed In Attack in Central Highlands
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 30 (AP)—The North Vietnamese broke a long lull in the Central Highlands today with an attack on a ranger camp and were repulsed, a Saigon spokesman reported.

headline: ANOTHER WAR CRIME IN VIETNAM CHARGED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 30—An other reported crime against Vietnamese nationals by mem bers of the Americal Division has come to light here in rec ords of the United States Court of Military Appeals.

headline: The American Way in Asia as seen by Robert Osborn
lead_paragraph: In his State of the World Message, President Nixon sought to demonstrate a non‐hostile disposition toward China. There were amiable references to “a dialogne with Peking,” and the possi bility of China's playing “a construc tive role in the family of nations.” But Washington would continue to oppose, the seating of Peking's dele gation in the U.N. at the expense of Taipei's representation, and we stand by our 1954 treaty with “the Republic of China on Taiwan.” In sum, no change.
author: By O. Edmund Clubs

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South. Vietnam, Feb. 28 — The South Vietnamese thrust against enemy supply routes in Laos is entering its crucial stage, in the view of authoritative American military sources here.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. MOVES TANKS TO SEAL FRONTIER TO ENEMY IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam Feb. 28—United States tanks and other armored units moved to the South Vietnamese‐Lao tian border today to prevent a possible eastward movement of a North Vietnamese tank force that supported the enemy as sault on a contested hill six miles inside Laos.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Edmund Stillman

headline: Sporting Club' Opens
lead_paragraph: Never, never have the good old days of Hollywood seemed so golden, at least lately, as with the unreeling of a new something-or-other titled "The Sporting Club" at the Coronet. What is this thing about?Apparently, a rustic hunting lodge in Michigan, where a group of guzzling high-livers from the city are holding a reunion, is supposed to signify structural America. Toward the end, the building is dynamited (after repeated hints that the Vietnam War is undermining things). The club members, men and women, stagger around in the ruins to a thunderous soundtrack rendition of "Battle Hymn of the Republic."Earlier, 20 minutes or so, there was a smaller-scale dynamiting of a new dam, at which a rally of war veterans and American Gothic types is being held. Hoping, praying that was the end, I reached for my shoes. No such luck.But the picture finally does end, after more hints, in a wallow of sex and violence (the facade of America?). As the color camera whips around in a frenzy of half-shadows, the braying club members strip down for a mass orgy. And we guarantee you've never seen such a repulsive array of flabby, middle-aged blubber.Studiously plunked down and magnified in a naturalistic, woodsy setting, the stilted, elliptical dialogue, the heavy stylization of the performances and the insistently pointed direction of Larry Peerce (of "Goodbye, Columbus," believe it or not), render it a plodding artificial bore.Lorenzo Semple Jr. has adapted the source, a novel by Thomas McGuane, which a reviewer for this newspaper said "almost put him to sleep." History repeats itself.
author: HOWARD THOMPSON

headline: Fulbright Hopes to Force Nixon's Advisers to Testify
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 — Senator J. W. Fulbright, criti cizing what he termed the “total breakdown” of communication between Congress and the Ad ministration on Vietnam, said today that he would submit a bill to compel the Secretary of State and other officials to ap pear before Congress to explain the Administration's policies.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: America's Moral Egocentrism
lead_paragraph: LONDON—To the distant observer a puzzling feature of American his tory in the last ten years has been the absence of ordinary political op position to the Vietnam war and the other vast American operations in Southeast Asia.
author: By J. Enoch Powell

headline: Nixon Aides Reported to Debate Setting Of a Definite Date for Ending 'War Role
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28— There is said to be a subtle but intensive debate in the upper ranks of the Government about whether President Nixon should now commit himself to the def inite termination of American involvement in the Indochina war.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The false nuclear alert on the morning of Feb. 20 may have been more than a “human error.” It was a timely warning of the abyss towards which we are perilously and rapidly drifting.
author: Alexander Witold Rudzinski

headline: Kennedy, in Visit to Carolina, Cites Calhoun But Not‐Sherman
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb.28 — Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts made a speech here Wit night that in cluded 41 typewritten lines of praise tof john Calhohn, South Carolina's Most favorite son.
author: By Roy Reed Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Ernest T. Clough

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: John Henderson

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Philip. C. Jessup

headline: 4,400 G.I.'s Withdrawn From Vietnam in Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 1 (AP) —The United States command said today that American troop strength in Vietnam dropped by 4,400 men last week and also an nounced the phasing out of 16 more Army units that will reduce the strength by an additional 3,280 men.

headline: Denies Cover‐Up Charge
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) — Cal. Oran K. Hender son denied today that he had deliberately tried to cover up the Mylai incident, as the Army has charged. In a statement is sued by his lawyer, he said “obstructionist tactics” by some Army officers had hurt his ability to defend himself during pretrial investigations.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Louis Wolf

headline: SAIGON RESERVES MOVE WESTWARD TO LAOS BORDER
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 2—South Viet namese troop reinforcements, assembled in the northeastern corner of South Vietnam, were moving westWard to the Lao tian border yesterday.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: From a Bronx Copter Pilot's Diary: Laos Is Far Worse Than Cambodia
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 1—Clarence J. Romero Jr. of the Bronx, a 20‐year‐ old warrant officer, has the most dangerous job in the air war over Laos. He pilots a tiny light observation heli copter (L.O.H.) at tree‐top level, waiting to draw fire.

headline: Bomb in Capitol Causes Wide Damage
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Match 1—A bomb, apparently planted by a group or person protesting against the Vietnam war, ex ploded early this morning in the Senate wing of the Capitol, causing extensive damage but no injuries.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Charles Sheldon

headline: The Pilot's Mother Expects Him Home
lead_paragraph: Warrant Officer Romero's mother, Mrs. Lydia Bloom, of 1710 Seward Avenue, the Bronx, said last night she was unaware that her son had been keeping a diary, but not surprised. “He's always been explicit about the things he believed in,” she said, add ing:

headline: Human‐Wave Tactics Noted
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 1 (Reuters)—The deputy commander of United States forces in Vietnam said today that the North Vietnamese, using human‐wave tactics in Laos, had forced South Vietnamese troops into the heaviest fighting of the Indochina war.

headline: Saigon's Cambodia Drive in Confusion After Death of Its Colorful Commander
lead_paragraph: TAYNINH, South Vietnam, March 1 — Bereft of leadership by the death of Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri in a helicopter crash last week, officers at his forward command post directing a 23,000‐man opera tion against North Vietnamese troops and supplies in cam bodia appear to be in a state of confusion and uncertainty.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: PRESIDENT WINS MIDWEST BACKER FOR TAX SHARING
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES, Iowa, March 1 —President Nixon's plea for support et his revenue‐sharing program, punctuated by a pledge to add $100‐million to rural development funds, re ceived the backing of a Demo. cratic Governor here today, but his appearance touched off a demonstration by a coalition of farmers, antiwar protesters and construction workers.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: AIR FORCE CURBS SLOT MACHINES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)—The Air Force is remov ing slot machines from its over seas bases and will have ban ished then entirely by July 1, 1972, Senators inquiring into military corruption announced today.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: G. Kershaw Green

headline: Medina Says Army Will Not Allow Him To Reply to Calley
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 1 — Capt., Ernest L. Medina accused the Army today of trying to keep him from challenging the testimony of First Lieut. Wil liam. L. Calley Jr. that orders to kill civilians at Mylai had come from Captain Medina.

headline: China Sea to the Caribbean
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The United States is now withdrawing its ground forces from Vietnam—all critics to the con trary notwithstanding. But this with drawal will not reduce the require ment for an American strategy offer ing some hope to the nations of Asia that the United States has an interest in their future.
author: By Arleigh A. Burke

headline: 4 in U. S. Copter Killed
