lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 2 (Reuters)— A United States helicopter was shot down and destroyed over Komnong Chain Province in Cambodia yesterday, killing four American crewmen, the American command announoed here today. The crash brought to 59 the number of United States aircraft lost in the area since April 20, 1970, when American and South Vietnamese troops thrust into southeastern Cambodia to clear out North Vietnamese and Vietcong bor der sanctuaries.

headline: Galley Judge Expected to Permit Medina Testianony
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 4‐‐Capt. Ernest L. Medina, who leis accused the Army of trying to prevent his testifying at the trial here of First Lieut. Wil liam L. Calley Jr., may be in vited to tettify after all.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Wants Lindsay To Stay a Republican
lead_paragraph: Herbert Klein, White House director of communications, said here yesterday that the Nixon Administration would like Mayor Lindsay to re main a member of the Re publican party.

headline: 4 Lost Photographers Presumed Dead
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam March 2—An American official here said today that the four photographers on a Vietnamese. helicopter that crashed in Laos Feb. 10 “mus now be pre sumed dead.”

headline: Copters Return From Laos With the Dead
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 27—The dead began to come into the emergency field hospital here today after 1 P.M.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Gives Medal of Honor To 7 in a White Hoare Fete
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) — President Nixon today presented the Medal of Honor, the nation's highest decoration for valor, to seven United States servicemen at a private White House ceremony.

headline: Ambush by Foe Kills 11
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 2 (AP)— The South Vietnamese com riand, reporting on its sweep against enemy bases in eastern Cambodia, said today that 11 of its soldiers had been killed and 16 wounded, in an ambush near the town of Suong.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 2—Henry Kissinger is in the center of a bitter controversy here for three reasons: (1) despite White House denials, he is undoubtedly the principal adviser to President Nixon on foreign policy; (2) that policy, particularly in Indochina, is opposed by influential members of the House and particularly the Senate, who feel they have a constitutional duty to examine the logic of the Presi dent's decisions; but (3) they cannot question Mr. Kissinger about Laos, the Middle East or anything else.
author: By James Reston

headline: Symington Protests Kissinger's Power
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 2— Senator Stuart Symington pro tested today that Henry A. Kis singer, the President's adviser on national security, had be come “Secretary of State in ev erything but title” and that as a result Secretary of State Wil liam P. Rogers had become a laughing‐stock in Washington.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Letter to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Laos Protests to Thant
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2—The charge, d'affaires of the Laotian Embassy in Washington, Lane Pathamma vong, called on Secretary Gen eral Thant today to protest the presence of foreign troops in his country. Similar protests were made recently to the So voiet Union and Britain, co chairmen of the 1962 Geneva conference that guaranteed the neutrality of Laos.

headline: Aiding Global Economy
lead_paragraph: Vietnam—and now Cambodia and Laos—have so dominated thought about the United States's international role that the nation's earlier reputation as rebuilder of the world economy has almost been blotted out. The most constructive aspect of President Nixon's State of the World Mes sage is his effort to look beyond the war in Southeast Asia and to set the United States back on its course as contribu tor to international economic development; this part of the message has received less at tention than it deserves.
author: By Leonard S. Silk

headline: SAIGON BOLSTERS ITS FORCE IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 3—More South Vietnamese troops crossed into Laos yesterday to counter a continued build‐up of enemy troops and armored forces in the battle area.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: PROMPT REPORTS ON MYLAI 4 CITED
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 3—The mass killing of South Vietnamese civilians at the ham let of Mylai 4 was reported to high‐echelon officers of the Americal Division within hours after the incident, a witness said today at the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Cal ley Jr.
author: By Homer Bigart; Special to The New York Times

headline: FOE SAID TO FIRE ACROSS THE DMZ AT U.S. AIRCRAFT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 4 — North Vietnamese gunners have fired antiaircraft missiles across the demilitarized zone at American planes flying over South Viet nam, the United States com mand reported yesterday.
author: By Alvin Shuster; Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘No Discussions’ at White House
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 3 — The White House said today that there had been “no discus sions” in the Nixon Administra tion about the prospect of a South Vietnamese military thrust into North Vietnam, with or without American support.

headline: Thieu Repeats Hint of Invasion of North
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 3 — For the second time in a week, President Nguyen Van Thieu has made a public statement hinting that an invasion of North Vietnam is not out of the question. But he did not commit his Govern ment to any such course of action.
author: By Craig R. Whitney; Special to The New York Times

headline: 40‐Hour Truce Observance
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Thursday, March 4 (Reuters) —United States and South Vietnamese forces will observe a 40‐hour truce today and tomorrow in western Kon tum Province of the Central Highlands to allow the promised release of 39 wounded South Vietnamese prisoners by the Vietcong, informed sources said today.

headline: Poll Finds Nixon Rating Lowest After Saigon's Invasion of Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 3 — President Nixon's popularity fell to the lowest level of his Presidency shortly after the South Vietnamese invasion of Laos, despite his recent appeal for support of domestic re forms, the Gallup Poll reported today.
author: By James M. Naughton; Special to The New York Times

headline: PIPELINE AN OLD ONE, PENTAGON CONCEDES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 3— Defense Department officials conceded today that a three‐ foot length of gasoline pipe line, displayed to reporters last week by Lieut. Gen. John W. Vogt as having been cut from the Ho Chi Minh Trail complex during the current incursion into Laos had in fact been ob tained earlier.

headline: House BiII Calls for Team To Oversee Vietnam Vote
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)—A Houge resolution to send a 15‐member team of United States observers to over see South Vietnam's Presiden tial election in October was introduced today by a group of 43 Representatives.

headline: General Is Accused Of Ousting a Major For PX Exposures
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)—An Army major testi fied today that he had been ousted from his job amid ru mors there was “a price on my head” because he had tried to disclose corruption in the oper ation of service clubs in Viet nam.

headline: Round Top's Director, 22, Now on Trails in Vietnam
author: By Michael Strauss; Special to The New York Times

headline: Cambodian Refinery Attacked
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 4 (AP)—The Cambodian high command reported that North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops attacked Cambodia's oil, refinery in Xompong Som to day and cut off Government troops sent to bolster the de fenders.

headline: KY SEEKS STEP‐UP IN U.S. AIR SUPPORT
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 4 — Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that unless South Vietnamese forces in Laos received increased American air support, they would be “in a difficult situa tion.”
author: By Iver Peterson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Battalion Is Flown 7 Miles Farther Into Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, March 5—South Vietname ese forces in Laos have be gun a new move westward in their drive to cut the North Vietnamese supply‐trail net work.
author: By Craig R. Whitney; Special to The New York Times

headline: Mylai Inquiry Ban Is Laid to General
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 4—Maj. Gen. Samuel W. Kos ter, who commanded the Ameri cal Division at the time of the alleged massacre of South Viet namese civilians at Mylai 4, forestalled an on‐the‐spot inves tigation of the incident, one of his field officers testified today at the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.
author: By Homer Bigart; Special to The New York Times

headline: Pentagon Reports Foe May Be Firing New Missile in Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)—A Defense Department spokesman said today that the North Vietnamese might be fir ing a new antiaircraft missile in Laos against United States aircraft supporting the South Vietnamese drive against en emy supply trails.

headline: Laotian Gamble
lead_paragraph: The risk of a further widening of the war in Indochina has been increased by the decision to push deeper Into Laos in the face of strong and increasingly effective enemy resistance.

headline: WAR FOE GUILTY IN DRAFT CASE
lead_paragraph: A Rockefeller University graduate student was found guilty yesterday at. the end of his. second trial for refusing, to be inducted into the Army be Cause of his Opposition to the war In Vietnam.
author: By Arnold H. Lubasch

headline: Transcript of President Nixon's News Conference on Foreign Policy Matters
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of Presi dent Nixon's news conference on for eign affairs televised last night from the East Room of the White House, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: Where the Laos Trail Leads
lead_paragraph: Both sides know the Nixon plan for “Vletnamizing” the Indochina war depends on at least partial victory in the continuing Laos battle. Partial victory means destruction of sufficient Communist stockpiles along the south ward channel of the Ho Chi Minh Trail to prevent Hanoi from mounting another serious offensive for another year,
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Saigon's Copter Pilots Are Criticized
author: By Gloria Emerson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Bombs and Balance
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON. March 4—Every few days now, somebody introduces a bill in Congress designed to influence the course of the Indochina war or bring America's participation in it to an end, but none of these has any real chance of success.
author: By James Reston

headline: LAIRD NOW DUBIOUS ON PIPELINE DISPLAY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 4— Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird acknowledged today that it “probably would have been better” if the Defense Depart ment had made clear that a, piece of pipeline shown at a Pentagon news conference had not been obtained during the current South Vietnamese op eration in Laos.

headline: Why We Fight in Laos
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.—As the critical battle shapes up for control over the infil tration routes through Laos during the current dry season, it may be useful to recall the history of that critical piece of the world's real estate.
author: By W. W. Rostow

headline: Nixon Accuses Symington Of ‘Cheap Shot’ at Rogers
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 4 — President Nixon accused Sena tor Stuart Symington of Mis souri of taking “a cheap shot” in suggesting that William P. Rogers had been Secretary of State in title only.
author: By John W. Finney; Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi, Protesting Air Attacks, Sends Deputy to Talks in Paris
lead_paragraph: PARIS, March 4—The Viet cong and North Vietnamese chief delegates stayed away from the Paris negotiations to day to protest American air at tacks on North Vietnam. Their deputies attended the 105th session, a grim and fruitless meeting.

headline: PRESIDENT SAYS LAOS OPERATION AIDS U.S. PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 4 — President Nixon said tonight that the allied operation in Laos had “very seriously dam aged” Hanoi's military ability and thus assured the continued withdrawal of American troops from South Vietnam this year and next.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr.; Special to The New York Times

headline: Worst Toll Since September
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 4 (AP) — The heavy fighting in Laos was reflected in the weekly casualty reports issued today by the allied commands here.

headline: Ex‐Colonel Relates How He Prevented A Brothel on Base
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) —A retired Army colonel told a panel of amused Senators of his running battle to prevent a brothel from being erected in the center of Army headquar ters in Vietnam.

headline: Hanoi Reports U.S. Force Near.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Saturday, March 6 (AP)—A Hanoi broadcast said today that four United States landing ships with 1,500 American marines aboard had approached close to the North Vietnamese coast in the southern panhandle “ready for action.”

headline: Washington: For the Record
lead_paragraph: Activities. The President sent • his urban community development message to Congress. Later in the morning the President met with Chairman Paul W. McCracken of the Council of Economic Advisers, Treasury. Secretary John B. Connally Jr., Federal Reserve Board Chairman Arthur F. Burns and Director George Shultz of the Office of Management, and Budget. The President had an afternoon meeting with Governor Rockefeller of New York. The President also met with this National Security Council.

headline: Hanoi Bids People Prepare to ‘Smash’ Assault
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, March 5—Premier Pham Van Dong has called on the people of North Vietnam to increase their “support to the South” and be prepared to “smash any war act” against the North.

headline: Jackson, in Split With President, Backs Peking's Entry lnto U.N.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 5 —Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, the most hard line anti‐Communist among the Democratic Presidential prospects, said today that the United States should accept as inevitable the early admission of mainland China to the United Nations.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Discloses Figures On P.O.W.'s and Missing
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 5—The White House made public today the following recapitulation of American prisoners of war and men missing in action to clarify President Nixon's statement at his news conference last night that “there are 1,600 Americans in North Vietnam jails under very difficult circumstances at the present time”:

headline: SLAYING ORDER FOR MYLAI DENIED
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 5 — The commander of the American task torce that assaulted the hamlet of Mylai ordered his officers to respect the lives of South Vietnamese civilians, the intelligence officer of the force testified today at the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Group Is Briefed In Paris by Hanoi Aides
lead_paragraph: PARIS, March 5 (AP)—An American citizens’ group trying to learn more about the issues of the Vietnam war met with North Vietnamese officials today. A conflict was shaping up over a meeting with United States officials.

headline: Maoist Strategy Likened To Complex Game of Go
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE. Mass., March 5—To Scott A. Boorman, a 21‐year‐old Harvard student who was born in Peking on the day the Red Army entered the city, Maoist revolutionary strategy in China is very much like giant game of go. In an attempt to help the Western mind grasp the enigma of China, he has built a “simulation model” in which Chinese military and political moves are likened to the complex methods by which a player of the oriental board game go—known as wei‐ch'i by the Chinese—attempts to isolate, encircle and capture enemy pieces.
author: By Robert Reinhold Special to The New York Times

headline: BATTLE EXPECTED NEAR LAOS TOWN
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 6 — More South Vietnamese troops moved westward across the enemy's supply‐trail network in Laos yesterday, and helicopter‐borne advance units were reported preparing a ring of troop landing zones near the key junction town of Tchepone.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: DEMOCRATS SCORED BY DOLE ON VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)—Senator Robert 3. Dole of Kansas, the Republican national chairman, said today that most of the Democrats who are considered potential Presidential candidates in 1972 have joined “the mob on the left” in a concentrated attack on America's defense establishment.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—When South Vietnamese troops thrust across the border into Laos four weeks ago to disrupt Communist supply lines, a key target loomed ahead down twisting Route 9. Less than 30miles away was the rubble of the town called Tchepone, a strategic junction point on the Ho Chi Minh Trail network and long a favorite target of American warplanes. The South Vietnamese appeared to bog down and the target seemed to fade as a major objective. But yesterday afternoon, South Vietnamese troops, some airlifted by American helicopters, landed in the debris and captured the town.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The Vietnam debate went off on an unexpected tangent last week. Suddenly, instead of debating whether the Administration's Vietnamization plan would lead to an end of the war, Congressional critics were arguing over whether William P. Rogers was Secretary of State in fact or whether Henry A. Kissinger was a modern‐day Rasputin dictating policy on the war from the sanctuary of the White House.

headline: Army Clears G.I. in Death Of U.S Woman in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) —The Army has conceded a case of mistaken identity and has dropped a charge of unpremeditated murder against a Maryland soldier in the fatal stabbing of a Red Cross woman near Saigon last August.

headline: Reader's Report
lead_paragraph: The trouble with Capt. Paul Damion, U.S.N., is that he is not only a hero but a martyr. Since the Inchon landing (for which he won a Navy Cross), Damion has been accumulating promotions and doubts, until the Vietnam war finds him a Navy Hamlet command of a nuclear‐powered destroyer. An impasse between tactics and conscience leads to dereliction of duty and the professional hara‐kiri that the captain seems to court. A Navy buff, Mr. Dibner is an imaginative investigator of the alignment between command decisions and morality. Unfortunately, he finds it necessary to construct a network of melodramatic detours to the youth and drug scenes, which dissipate the importance of the central idea.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The moral bankruptcy of our Indochina policy is well documented in two recent news articles. One describes the new prison to be built for the Saigon Government by the United States, at a cost of at least $400,000 and probably much more with the usual cost overruns. The second notes the sentencing of two South Vietnamese priests who dared to publish antiwar material, and who may well be headed for two of those new $1,400 isolation cells. Our Government has already revealed its intention fully to support and indeed Insure the success of this despotic and self‐serving regime in the forthcoming presidential elections.

headline: U.S. Copter Pilots In Laos Invasion Question the Risks
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 6 — Peter Hale, a 22‐year‐old warrant officer, climbed into his helicopter with the terrors of the previous day's mission still clear in his mind. Twelve miles west of here, beyond the Laotian border, the war's heaviest concentration of enemy antiaircraft guns was waiting.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Law
lead_paragraph: Ever since the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. began early in November at Fort Benning, Ga., an unseen presence has hovered, over the courtroom. Though Capt. Ernest L. Medina has been no closer than his present station at Fort McPherson in Atlanta, 100 miles away, there have been many moments during the past five months when his name has dominated the proceedings. And there have been other moments—not the least two weeks ago when Lieutenant Calley took the witness stand—when it almost appeared that it was Captain Medina, the. 34‐year‐old former commander of C Company, First Battalion, 20th Infantry, who was on trial for the murder of 102 unarmed Vietnamese civilians at Mylai 4.

headline: Summer of 1972 Would See 150,000 U.S. Troops Still in Vietnam, According to Pentagon Budget Estimate;
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 6—Defense Department planning calls for the possible retention of more than 150,000 United States troops in Vietnam in the summer of 1972 and some 50,000 the summer after.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON'S FORCES ENTERTCHERIE, KEY GOAL IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 6 — South Vietnamese troops moved today into the Laotian town of Tchepone, a major objective of their four‐week‐old offensive against, enemy supply lines.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Ho
lead_paragraph: It's not, clear why this short book got, written. Stylish as it is, there is nothing in it that cannot be found in other eloquent books on Vietnam and Ho by Jean Lacouture, Bernard Fall, Lucien Bodard, Graham Greene, Joseph Buttinger, Paul Mus and John McAlister, all of whom are referred to copiously. It does have the virtue of being clear, also straightforward in its point of view: Ho was on the side, of history and taught the world, or most of it, the futility of imperialism.
author: By David Halberstam. 118 Pp. Random. $4.95

headline: NIXON NOW TARGET OF U.S. HARD HATS Former Allies on War Shift to Criticiim on Pay Curb
lead_paragraph: The natibn's hard hate—:ttie construction workers who have given President Nixon stanch support for his Vietnam pollcies in sometimes boisterous demonstrations — seem more concerned now with what many call the President's antilabor stand.
author: By Robert E. Tomasson

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The draft law is up for renewal this June. What better way is there for all the dovish Senators, if they are indeed doves, to end the war in Vietnam than by not renewing the draft?

headline: The Soviet Version
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, March 6 (UPI)—Stating that Muhammad, Ali was deprived of his title because he refused to serve in the United States Army and fight in Vietnam, the Russian news agency, Tass, told its readers today that “Frazier was awarded the champion's title in 1968. This was done against the established order.”

headline: Dead End for the Prisoners
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's determination to maintain American troops in South Vietnam as long as there are American prisoners in North Vietnam offers no practical promise for release of the captives. It is in effect a formula whose unintended result is more likely to prolong indefinitely the agony of the war and the anguish of the prisoners and their relatives.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Within the next few weeks, squads of volunteer political activists will flock each evening to the spacious, sparsely furnished headquarters of the new public interest lobby called Common Cause to man a bank of telephones.

headline: 7 Killed in Vietnam Crash
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 6 (AP)—Five Americans and two South, Koreans were killed yesterday in the aerial collision of a United States helicopter and a Korean light observation plane, the United States command reported. The report said the collision had occurred 10 miles west of the coastal city of Quinhon.

headline: Et Al.
lead_paragraph: A massive collection of mostly Third World revolution‐inprogress polemics, essays, reports. Countries included: China, India, Vietnam, Korea, Indonesia, Palestine (sic), Iraq, Morocco, Algeria, the Congo, South Africa, “Portuguese” Africa, Cuba, Venezuela, Guatemala, Colombia, Puerto Rico, Uruguay, Bolivia, Quebec, “Black‐Brown America” (Chicanos and Panthers). All the biggies are here: Mao, Lenin, Huey, Eldridge, Giap, Fanon, Che, Kim I, Sung. Much of the material is new in English. Very assertive. A mass of disparate war cries.
author: Edited by John Gerassi. 384 pp. World. $15

headline: DOUBT ON VIETNAM EPORTED IN POLL Gallup Finds Public Lack of Confidence in President
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 6—The same lack of public confidence in Vietnam policies that faced President Johnson in 1967 now confronts President. Nixon, the Gallup Poll reported today.

headline: 2 VIETNAM CENTERS FOR PRESS TO CLOSE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 6 (AP) — The United States Military Command announced this week that the last two press centers in South Vietnam will be closed March 31. The command said the step was being taken for reasons of economy.

headline: Maoist Youths in Ceylon Attack the U.S. Embassy
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 6 —The United States Embassy was attacked this morning by 200 demonstrators, mostly young men, who climbed the embassy walls and threw Molotov cocktails at the building.

headline: Copter Crew in Laos Saved
lead_paragraph: QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, March 7 (Reuters) — Seven crewmen of an American helicopter shot down over Laos on Friday were rescued today after being stranded for 48 hours in an area surrounded by North Vietnamese troops.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, March 7 — Six years ago tomorrow the first American ground combat unit, 3,500 marines, landed in Vietnam. Their announced mission was to protect U.S. bases. As late as June, 1965, a State Department spokesman said that was still the role of the rapidly growing American force — thougth if fired upon, he said, “our troops naturally return the fire.”
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: RED CHINA CHARGES BOATS ARE HARASSED
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, March 7 Communist China issued a strong protest today against what it called a “deliberate provocation” by the United States and South Vietnam against two Chinese fishing boats in the Gulf of Tonkin.

headline: Syria Aids, Vietcong
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 7 (Reuters)—Syria donated five tons of medicines and a ton of cloth to the Vietcong today as a token gift for what was termed their struggle against imperialism.

headline: Soviet Tanks Seen in Laos Are Not Latest Models
lead_paragraph: Descriptions of the Sovietbuilt T‐54 tank seen in Laos indicate that the vehicle being used by the North Vietnamese is not the latest model.

headline: Hanoi Denies Capture
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Monday, March 8 (AP)—The North Vietnamese radio today called the announcement that South Vietnamese troops had captured Tchepone “a deliberate falsehood invented to cover up the true fact that the Saigon puppets and U.S. aggressors have been and are being defeated everywhere in southern Laos.”

headline: 1,000 U.S. PLANES BOMB FOE IN LAOS AND IN CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7 — The United States continued widespread bombing raids today, sending more than 1,000 planes into action against enemy forces In Laos and Cambodia.

headline: The Army and General Koster
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The Army made a grave error last January in dropping all charges in connection with the Mylai massacre against Maj. Gen. Samuel W. Koster, former superintendent of West Point and commander of the Americal Division at the time its subordinate units participated in the original assault on March 16, 1968.

headline: Counterattack Possible
lead_paragraph: HHESANH, South Vietnam, March 7 —South Vietnamese troops at the town of Tchepone were reported to be consolidating their newly gained positions on the Ho Chi Minh Trail today in anticipation of a possible counterattack from the north.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Ceylon Calls Out Troops After Attack on Embassy
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 7 —Ceylon's Prime Minister, Mrs. Sirimauo Bandaranaike, announced in the House of Representatives tonight that the Government had decided to call out all branches of the armed forces to insure the maintenance of law and order throughout the country.

headline: Enemy Supply Traffic increases North of Saigon's Drive in Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7—The flow of enemy supply trucks along the Ho Chi Minh Trail to the area of South Vietnamese operations in southern Laos has doubled in the last few days to return to the level it reached before the invasion of Laos on Feb. 8, American military sources here reported today.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Says Its Marines
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 9 (AP)—Two hundred fifty North Vietnamese soldiers were reported killed in Laos yesterday in a battle with South Vietnamese marines who were heavily supported by artillery barrages and American air strikes.

headline: Defense Minister In Australia Quits, Criticizing Gorton
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, March 8 —Defense Minister Malcolm Fraser resigned from the Cabinet today, charging Prime Minister John G. Gorton with “significant disloyalty” to him.

headline: DRAFT EXEMPTION BARRED TO CRITICS OF A SINGLE WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 8 —The Supreme Court ruled today that young men were not entitled to draft exemptions as conscientious objectors if they objected only to the Vietnam conflict as an “unjust war” and did not oppose all wars.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Enacts Reforms To Cut Rate of Inflation
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 8 — A series of economic reforms were enacted here over the weekend by the South Vietnamese Government to check inflation during a period of high Government expenditures.

headline: Historian, at a Seminar for Senators, Urges Curb on President's War Power
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 8—Henry Steele Commager, who introduced generations of students to American history, conducted a seminar at a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing today and reinforced the senators’ ‐fears that the President was Infringing on, the war‐making power of Congress.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Cambodia Drive Stalled
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 8—Informed American sources said today that most of the South Vietnamese operation against North Vietnamese troop concentrations and supply depots in Cambodia had come to a halt following the death of its dynamic first commander, Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri.

headline: U.S. Troops in Vietnam Down by 4,000 in Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 8 (AP) — The United States command announced today that American troop strength in Vietnam was reduced by about 4,000 men last week, reaching the lowest level in almost four and a half years.

headline: Excerpts From High Court Opinions on Selective Conscientious Objection to War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 8—Following are excerpts from the opinion by Justice Thurgood Marshall, writing for the Supreme Court majority in Gillette v. United States and Negre v. Larsen, in which the Court held that young men must be opposed to all wars, not just the Vietnam war, to qualify as conscientious objectors, and from a dissent by Justice Williams O. Douglas:

headline: Report on Peace Talks In Paris Is Retracted
lead_paragraph: PARIS, March 8 (AP) — An American pacifist group quoted as having said today that there had been recent private peace discussions, later retracted the statement.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor

headline: Shift of Best Troops to Cambodia and Laos Worries Saigon Area
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 8 — An apprehensive mood reigns. in the :co'untryside around Vietriarn:s capital city, whose, defense’ has. been left to irregulars and auxiliary forces while nearly 50,000 of Saigon's best troops have been moved out of the country’ to fight North Vietnameae troops in Cambodia and laos.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Business Called Wary
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 8 (UPI) —David M. Kennedy, United States ambassador at large, told American businessmen in South Vietnam today that United States business was not ready to invest in this war‐torn country.

headline: One Colonel Denies a Bribe
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) —An Army colonel denied to Senators today that he ever accepted bribes in Vietnam. A second colonel testified he was tricked by a general into taking one.

headline: TRIAL OF MEDINA ORDERED BY ARMY
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: CHOU ENDS A TRIP TO NORTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, March 8—Pre mier Chou En‐lai and Chinese Communist leaders have visited North Vietnam in a surprise development believed to be linked to the, war situation in Indochina.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Doubts Chinese Move
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 8—American officials said they, saw no evidence that the Chinese were about to commit troops or volunteers to the war. They said they had no evidence to substantiate press reports over the weekend that Chinese troops were being massed near the border of Laos.

headline: Park Says Seoul Is Studying Plans for Vietnam Pullout
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, March 9 (UPI)—President Chung Hee Park of South Korea says his Government is studying a timetable for eventual withdrawal of the 50,000 South Korean troops in Vietnam but that no immediate pullout is planned.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In a recent column James Reston faults the Nixon Administration for “betting on a military resolution” of the Vietnam war. With the record of the North Vietnamese at the socalled peace conference in Paris, what else can it bet on?

headline: U.S. Colonel Is Lost After Enemy Lures Helicopter to Laos
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam Wednesday, March 10 (AP)—North Vietnamese troops lured an American field commander's helicopter into Laos with false smoke signal and then shot it down, United States officers reported yesterday.

headline: CALLEY DISPUTED ON ELM DEATHS
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 9—The testimony of First Lieut William L. Calley Jr. that he had orders to kill everyone at Mylai except a few Vietnamese civilians who were to be used as human mine detectors was disputed today by a fellow officer.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Laotians Under Heavy Attack
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 9 (AP) — North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao forces are attacking in both northern and southern Laos and the military situation is grave, the Defense Ministry said today.

headline: Sergeant Enters Plea
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, March 9 (AP) — Sgt. Maj. William 0. Wooldridge and four other Army men pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of conspiring to defraud noncommissioned officers’ clubs in Vietman. The other defendants are M. Sgt. William E. Higdon, Sgt. 1st Cl. William C. Bagby and two retired noncommissioned officers, Narvaez Hatcher and Theodore Bass.

headline: War Foe Quits Army; West Point Graduate
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)—First Lieut. Louis P. Font, the West Point graduate whose opposition to the Vietnam war has kept him out of Southeast Asia and in one controversy after another for a year, has submitted his resignation at the Army's request, he said today.

headline: Hanoi Hails Peking's Might
lead_paragraph: HANOI North Vietnam March 9 (Agence France‐Presse) —The North Vietnamese press, in its first comment on Premier Chou En‐lai's four‐day visit to North Vietnam that ended yesterday hailed the modern armaments and technology at the Chinese army today.

headline: U.S. Reports 1,600 Blasts In Raids on Arms and Fuel
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam Wednesday March 10 — Mr strikes by United States fighterbombers in Laos reportedly set off 1,600 explosions of enemy fuel and ammunition supplies yesterday.
author: By Ner Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: PX INQUIRY IS TOED OF AWOL GENERAL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March (AP)—The Army's provost marshal in Europe told Senators today that a brigadier general went absent without leave at time his name was being mentioned in Senate testimony in connection with alleged corrupt activities in service club and post exchange systems in Vietnam.

headline: Nixon in Interview, Says This Is Probably Last War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON March 9—President Nixon in a rare onthe‐record interview, said yesterday that the Vietnam war was ending and added “In fact I seriously doubt if we will ever have another war. This is probably the very last one.”
author: By C. L. Sulzberger Special to The New York Times

headline: Test of Undeclared Wars Voted in Minnesota Senate
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL, March 9—The Minnesota Senate today passed, 43 to 21, a bill requiring the State Attorney General to test in Federal court the legality of any undeclared war upon the complaint of any Minnesotan Ordered to fight in it.

headline: 9 Trail Branches Reported Cut
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 9 (AP)—South Vietnamese troops in Laos now have cut nine major branches of the Ho Chi Minh Trail network, Saigon headquarters reported today.

headline: Saigon's Commander in Laos Drive Hoang Xuan Lam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON South Vietnam March 9—Many times each day in the last four weeks Lieut. Gen. Hoang Xuan Lam has ducked uneler a 10 inch wooden beam to come out of his bunker, turned right along the green rows of sandbags that cover it In triple layers and looked out over the Khesanh hills to see his soldiers getting In helicopters to do battle in Laos. The commander of the South Vietnamese forces in Laos has seen many of them come back dead or wounded.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: To talk in terms of Congress restricting the use of American power in the face of our expanding fiasco in Indochina, now plain and visible to all, is unrealistic because it asks our Commander in Chief to command with his hands, tied behind his back. This is why recent repeated efforts in Congress to do that have failed.

headline: U.S. Bombing Errors
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 9 (Reuters) — Bombs, napalm, rockets and gunfire from United States planes and helicopters killed eight South Vietnamese soldiers and injured 54 in two accidents east of Tchepone Friday, the United States military command reported today.

headline: Let's Unite on Vietnarnization
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Notwithstanding our past divisions over Vietnam policy, is it not possible for us to rally behind the President's Vietnamization program long enough to give it a fair trial?
author: By Maxwell D. Taylor

headline: Rogers Says Chou Tried to Soothe Hanoi
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 9—Secretary of State William P. Rogers tonight characterized the Hanoi visit of Premier Chou En‐lai of Cominunist China as an effort “to give some comfort to the North Vietnamese because they have been suffering setbacks.”

headline: Excerpts From the Interview Granted by President Nixon on Foreign Affairs
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 9 — Following are excerpts from an interview with President Nixon conducted here yesterday by C. L. Sulzberger, foreignaffairs columnist of The New York Times. The transcript, which is unofficial, was prepared by Mr. Sulzberger from his notes.

headline: AUSTRALIAN PARTY REPLACES GORTON AS PRIME MINISTER
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA Australia Wednesday March 10—John G. Gorton was deposed as Prime Minister of Australia today when he lost a vote of confidence by members of his Liberal party.
author: By Robert Trumbull Special to The New York Times

headline: PACIFISTS ATTACK U.S. STAIID IN PARIS
lead_paragraph: PARIS March 9—A band of 171 American pacifists ended today a pilgrimage during which they prayed with David K. E. Bruce, the chief United States truce negotiator, sang with his associates and explored the Issues of the Indochinese war with all parties here.
author: By John L. Hess Special to The New York Times

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The most interesting thing about President Nixon is that he regards himself as a genuine but practical pacifist who is slowly building a world which may never see another war. He attributes this urge to his maternal Quaker heritage, but he views his approach as necessarily pragmatic, cautious and based upon wide international experience.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: MEDINA REJECTS CALLEY ACCOUNT Tells Trial He Told Soldiers Before Mylai, ‘You Do Not Kill Women and Children’
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 10—With a hard, unblinking stare at his subordinate, Capt. (Ernest L. Medina testified today that he had never given First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. orders to kill women and children at Mylai.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: ARMY KEEPS FAITH ROLE OF COPTER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 9—Serious helicopter, losses in the allied offensive in Laos have not shaken the United States Army's faith in the “choppers” as an indispensable and revolutionary element in conventional and guerrilla war.
author: By Drew Middleton Special to The New York Times

headline: Charge Moderated
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., March 10 (AP)—The Army said today that the charges on which Captain Medina would be tried did not accuse him of personally killing 100 Mylai villagers during a sweep by his company.

headline: Misconduct by Vietnam G. I.'s Charged
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 10—The Army is investigating charges by a colonel who served in Vietnam alleging a variety of misdeeds by American and South Vietnamese and a coverup by one of his superiors.
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: China Pledges ‘Sacrifice’ to Aid Hanoi
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, March 10—Communist China and North Vietnam issued a joint communique today that spoke of new plans for cooperation between the two countries and Chinese preparedness to make “the greatest national sacrifices.”

headline: China Policy: Confrontation...
lead_paragraph: There is probably a large element of propaganda last weekend's highly publicized visit of Communist Chinese officials to North Vietnam, as Secretary of State Rogers has suggested—just as there is no doubt a considerable measure of bluff in recent South Vietnamese threats to invade North Vietnam.

headline: The Nixon Outlook: Internationalism and Commitment
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 10—President Nixon's highly personal definition of his foreign policy, given to The New York Times this week, amounted above all to a confident reassertion of the faith of the World War II generation of American “internationalists” against the challenge and disillusionment spread by the war in Vietnam. More directly than before, Mr. Nixon argued that he had kept the faith of the nineteen‐forties and nineteen‐fifties while the nation's once far‐sighted Establishment was running out on its principles toward isolation and “weakness.”
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: LAOTIANS DRIVEN FROM VITAL BASE
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 10 — The Laotian military command announced today the loss of a base that is vital for harassment and surveillance of the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in the southern panhandle.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Cambodia Reports Losses
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 10 (AP) — The Cambodian high command said today that 51,505 North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops have been killed and 21,133 wounded in nearly a year of fighting, while Government losses were 4,496 men killed and 8,624 wounded.

headline: Hanoi Reports Men in Asbestos Drive Trail's ‘Tunnels of Fire’
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 10 (Agence FrancePresse) — Truck drivers don asbestos clothing to drive through “tunnels of fire” created by American bombers along certain sections of the Ho Chi Minh Trail network, a North Vietnamese correspondent reported in the Hanoi press today.

headline: Vietnam Veterans Here Finding Job Hunt Tougher Than in 1970
lead_paragraph: Thousands of young veterans of the war in Vietnam are returning here to discover, often bitterly, that prospects for employment are acutely worse than a year ago.
author: By Lawrence Van Gelder

headline: LEADER SWORN IN BY AUSTRALIANS
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia, March 10—William McMahon, winner of his country's highest office on his third attempt, was sworn in as Prime Minister of Australia today shortly after the dominant Liberal party had deposed John G. Gorton in an explosion of long‐sImmering political animosities.

headline: Former General Says PX Charges Are Slanderous
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 10 —A demoted Army general, accused of helping profiteers to operate in the lucrative post exchange market, told the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations today that the charges against him were “unprecedented, unproved, untrue and slanderous.”

headline: More Chinese Aid Foreseen
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 10—Communist China is expected to step up deliveries of small arms and munitions and possibly start supplying trucks and light armor to North Vietnam to make up for the losses suffered in Laos, United States officials said today.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Heavy Fog Cuts Copter Flights in Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 11 —Heavy fog closed down air operations at the huge allied forward supply base at Khesanh yesterday and brought a near halt to American helicopter support of South Vietnamese troops in Laos.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: VIETNAM COVER‐UP LAID TO 2 OFFICERS
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, March 11—Military charges against a general and a colonel were drafted here today by a fellow United States Army officer who has accused them of covering up war crimes in South Vietnam.
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Consistency is by no means always a virtue, above all when dealing with foreign policy's changing kaleidoscope. The admirable thing about George Ball is not that he has been consistent in his attitude on Vietnam but that he fought for his views when they were unpopular and, now that they have become popular, refuses to let his emotions on this irrationally passionate subject distort his friendships or other opinions.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Saigon Is Said to Abandon Big Refugee Resettlement
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 11—The Saigon Government's plan to move refugees from the northern part of South Vietnam to the southern part has been quietly set aside in favor of resettling them within their native provinces, American officials said today.

headline: Excerpts From President Nixon's Address to National Conference on Judiciary
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., March 11 [UPI]—Following are excerpts from the text of President Nixon's address today to the National Conference on the Judiciary:

headline: SAM Site Laos Reported Hit
lead_paragraph: SAIGON Friday, March 12 (UPI)—United States military sources said today that American fighter‐bombers last week destroyed the only North Vietnamese surface‐,to‐air missile site ever discovered in Laos. They said that the nearly functional launching pad was spotted on a reconnaissance picture taken by a United States jet near the Laos‐North Vietnam border and that Air Force and Navy jets destroyed it.

headline: Last Calley Witness Says Mylai Troops Went to Vietnam Unready for Combat
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 11—The final witness in the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. said today that troops involved in the Mylai killings were so unready for combat that the brigade commander protested and asked for 60 additional days of training in Hawaii before the men were shipped to Vietnam in December, 1967.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: BRUCE SETS RECORD: A 4‐SENTENCE TALK
lead_paragraph: PARIS, March 11—David K. E. Bruce today delivered the shortest, speech on record at the Vietnam peace talks as he denounced what he described as the “propaganda maneuvers” of the Communist delegations.

headline: War Protester Walking to Washington Prays Here
lead_paragraph: Louise Bruyn, a dance teacher and housewife from Newton, Mass., crossed the Third Avenue Bridge into Manhattan yesterday morning, beginning the 23d day of a walk to Washington to protest the war in Indochina.

headline: Returning Green Berets Face Uncertain Future
lead_paragraph: FORT BRAGG, N. C., March 5 — The Green Berets have come home from Vietnam with their colors and decorations, checkered reputation and an uncertain future.
author: By Drew Middleton Special to The New York Times

headline: Overturn in Australia
lead_paragraph: The ouster by his own Liberal party of John Grey Gorton as Australia's Prime Minister is no great surprise. The dispute with his former Defense Minister involving the Australian Army's civil affairs role in Vietnam was merely the catalyst that fused enough opposition Liberal ranks to force Mr. Gorton's resignation.

headline: SAIGON'S FORCES LEAVE TCHEPONE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 12 (AP)—South Vietnamese troops who occupied the Laotian town of Tchepone last Saturday have withdrawn to positions in the surrounding hills, military sources reported yesterday.

headline: U.S. War Deaths Drop; Toll of Wounded Rises
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 11 (AP)—The United States command announced today that 44 Americans were killed in combat in Indochina last week, 25 fewer than the week before.

headline: Texas Senator Says Nixon Has Not ‘Leveled’ on Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 12—Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, whom President Nixon once counted among his “ideological majority,” said today that the President had not “leveled” with the American people or Congress about the “full extent of risk” involved in’ the current operation in Laos. “

headline: SAIGON'S FORCES IN LAOS PULL BACK
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 13 (AP) — South Vietnamese forces in Laos pulled back yesterday from positions near Tchepone, former transshipment point on the enemy's supply trail complex.

headline: New Drives Swell Number Of Vietnam War Refugees
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 12 —The number of war refugees in South Vietnam has risen dramatically—perhaps by as many as 150,000 — since new allied operations in Indochina were begun late last year, Congressional informants said today.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Sergeant Tells or Warnings
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 12 (Reuters) — North Vietnamese forces were warned of a South Vietnamese attack in southern Laos last October, or four months before it started, and were told they must crush it at any cost, a former North Vietnamese master sergeant said at a news conference here today.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Few news items could illustrate the discrepancy between sanity and military justice as clearly as the sentenoing of an Air Force colonel to three years in prison on a marijuana charge (news story Feb. 17) and the dismissal of charges and the various acquittals in the Mylai case.

headline: Sports of The Times
lead_paragraph: A young black photographer angrily said, “What's going on? The promoters are going to make millions off two guys who never even went into the Army and the poor doggies out in the mud who keep this system going might not even have gotten to hear it. Go find out how many American soldiers died in Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam Monday night while the fight was on. Dig this. Some 19‐year‐old kid, he's going out on patrol and going to get killed, maybe his last few minutes might have been brightened by listening to the fight, take his mind off where he was, connect him up with something big and glamorous going on out in the world.”
author: By Robert Lipsyte

headline: Kissinger in Talk With 3 Berrigan Case Figures
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 12—Henry A Kissinger held an extraordinary philosophical and political discussion last week with three antiwar protesters who have been named as coconspirators in the alleged plot to kidnap him.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Crosby Reported in Group Trying to Ransom P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., March 12 (AP)—Bing Crosby's brother says that the singer and a number of wealthy associates are trying to negotiate ransom for American prisoners of war held by North Vietnam.

headline: Article 15 — No Title
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) — The State Department said today that it opposed ransom to free United States prisoners of war and disavowed official backing for a reported move by Bing Crosby and some wealthy associates to do so.

headline: Ribicoff Says Rep. Rivers Tried to Block Inquiry on Army PX's.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 12—Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff said today that the late Representative L. Mendel Rivers, who was chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, had tried to stop a Senate inquiry into alleged corruption in Army post exchanges.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Pentagon Skeptical
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI) — Pentagon officials said today it would have been impossible for the North Vietnamese to know about plans for the Laos invasion last October because planning did not begin until December.

headline: Hanoi Gives Peking Aide Pot Made From U.S. Plane
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, March 13 (AP)—The North Vietnamese gave a flower pot made from fragments of a downed United States plane to a Chinese Communist official who visited Hanoi with Premier Chou En‐lai last weekend, Hanoi's official press agency reports.

headline: MUSKIE MAILINGS STRESS WAR ISSUE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 13—Senator Edmund S. Muskie, in a bid to strengthen his support among students and the liberal antiwar faction of the Democratic party, has undertaken a letter campaign to emphasize that he favors a fixed timetable for withdrawal of all United States troops from Vietnam.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON'S FORCES SAID TO ESTABLISH NEW BATTLE BASES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, March 14—South Vietnamese troops have moved into five or six new combat bases on a mountain ridge southeast of Tchepone, the junction area 25 miles inside Laos from which they withdrew Friday, high American officials said yesterday.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga. — There was a hush, almost a sense of disbelief in the small courtroom here at 10:55 last Thursday morning. After 45 days of testimony spread over nearly four months, after 104 witnesses and countless depositions and exhibits in one of the longest trials in American military annals, the last witness had left the stand.

headline: 35 WOMEN PICKET GRIDIRON DINNER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 13—About 35 members of the Journalists for Professional Equality picketed the main entrance to the Statler Hilton Hotel here tonight as members of the Gridiron Club and their guests arrived for the club's 86th annual dinner.

headline: Hanoi Calls Tchepone Drive a Seven‐Act Farce
lead_paragraph: HANOI North Vietnam, March 13 (Agence FrancePresse)—The newspaper Quan Doi Nhan Dan said here today that the; South Vietnamese had played the final act of, their “Tchepone victory comedy” by announcing the’ evacuation of their troops from the city.

headline: Letters
lead_paragraph: To THE EDITOR:

headline: FRENCHMAN FINDS SST'S. COSTS SOAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 13—Jean‐Jacques Servan‐Schreiber, Member of the French National Assembly and former chairman of the influential L'Express, said today that the Concorde, the British‐French supersonic transport airplane, “looks to us, on this side of the Atlantic, like an industrial Vietnam.”
author: By E. W. Kenvvorthy Special to The New York Times

headline: Klondike ‘70
lead_paragraph: Reading about the development of oil in Alaska reminds one of Vietnam. The huge oil companies are like the military. They have already spent more than $1‐billion in exploring and leasing the incredibly rich oil deposits on Alaska's North Slope. Most of this financial commitment occurred before the public really knew what was going on. As a result the oil companies, like the Pentagon, have created a vested interest where none existed before. Now, when critics try to reevaluate the purpose and worth of the whole enterprise, the companies blandly point to their investment. Error has become its own justification. The process of destruction, in the Arctic as in Asia, crushes blindly ahead.
author: By Steven V. Roberts

headline: Jane Fonda Antiwar Show Staged Near Fort Bragg
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., March 13 (AP)—Antiwar entertainers led by the actress Jane Fonda played to a full house at the Haymarket Coffee House tonight in a show spoofing ‘United States involvement in Vietnam, the Army and President Nixon.

headline: HANOI SAID TO GET CAPTIVE NEWSMEN
lead_paragraph: Journalists captured by the North Vietnamese in Cambodia are taken to Hanoi as a matter of policy, a North Vietnamese defector has reported. The statement appears in the current issue of a Hong Kong weekly, Far Eastern Economic Review.

headline: Leadership Needed
lead_paragraph: The most unassailable statement made by President Nixon in the interview with him published in this newspaper last week was that “there has never been so great a challenge to U.S. leadership.” Whether the President had in mind a challenge to the United States to show leadership in the world community, or a challenge to the President of the United States to show leadership within this divided country, the challenge is there on both counts. Yet nothing that Mr. Nixon said indicated that he has the slightest idea how to meet it.

headline: The interested parties prosecuted their interests
lead_paragraph: Perhaps nowhere in the world, including Vietnam, has America's record as a foreign power been consistently sorrier than in the small West African country of Liberia. Or so it seems from reading this new work by Charles Morrow Wilson, a veteran tropical hand with experience in Liberia and the author of some two dozen books over the last 40 years.
author: By J. Kirk Sale

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG—As the United States‐supported South Vietnamese drive into Laos pushed ahead last week, the question again was raised here and in various world capitals: Will Communist China intervene in Indochina?

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — Every afternoon at 4:15 when reporters gather for the war briefing, long known as the “follies,” an American officer reports that United States air power “supplemented the capability” of the South Vietnamese air force in operations in Laos the day before.

headline: McMahon Facing First Test As Australia's Prime Minister
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, March 13—Before returning from Canberra to his home in Sydney for his first weekend as head of the Australian Government, Prime Minister William McMahon took steps to attack problems inherited from his predecessor, John G. Gorton.
author: By Robert Trumbull Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 FIERCE BATTLES IN LAOS REPORTED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 14 — South Vietnamese forces in Laos fought two stiff battles over the weekend, an army spokesman said today.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Moorer Says Saigon Strike In Laos Is Nearly at ‘Peak’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)—Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that the South Vietnamese strike in Laos was “just about at the peak” and had “severely disrupted” North Vietnam's military operations.

headline: Mission Reported Completed
lead_paragraph: HAMNGHI, South Vietnam, March 14 (AP) — South Viet namese forces in Laos have ful filled their mission “according to plans,” their commanding general said today.

headline: Accidental Bombing
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 14 (AP) — An American fighter‐bomber mistakenly attacked South Viet namese ground troops in Laos today, in the fifth accidental bombing of the campaign against the Ho Chi Minh Trail, a United States military spokes man said. Ten paratroopers were killed and 12 wounded.

headline: POPE AGAIN DEMANDS VOICE ON JERUSALEM
lead_paragraph: ROME, March 14—Pope Paul VI today reiterated the Vati can's long‐standing demand for a role in any international de cision on the status of Jeru salem and Christianity's other shrines in the Holy Land.

headline: The ‘Wasted’ People
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Because of the ground invasions into populous areas of Cambodia and Laos and the pound ings from the air that have reached a tempo of a thousand sorties a day, a new vale of tears is flowing across Southeast Asia.
author: By Herbert Mitgang

headline: Kennedy Puts Vietnam Civilian Dead at 25,000 in 1970
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 14 — Senator Edward M. Ken nedy has estimated that at least 25,000 civilians were killed in the war in South Vietnam last year and that 100,000 were wounded.
author: By Neil Sheehan Special to The New York Times

headline: Calley Judge Bars Any Finding Of ‘Involuntary Manslaughter’
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 14 — The jury in the court‐ martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. must convict or acquit him of premeditated mur der, murder or voluntary man slaughter in the alleged mass killing of Vietnamese civilians at Mylai, the military judge said today.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: 500 G.I.'S AT DEBUT OF ANTIWAR SHOW
lead_paragraph: FAYEITEVILLE, N, C., March 14—With a gusto once re served for cadence counts, the battalion of young soldiers raise their voices in a lusty re frain:
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: ACCUSING COLONEL FILES HIS CHARGES
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, March 15 — An Army officer preferred formal military charges today against a general and a colonel he has accused of ignoring reports of alleged atrocities in South Viet nam in 1969.

headline: SAIGON'S TROOPS REPORTED TO QUIT OUTPOST IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 16—South Viet namese troops abandoned a fire base in Laos under heavy enemy pressure overnight, leaving be hind their artillery pieces, mili tary sources said today.

headline: Khesanh Base Shelled
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 16 —The allied base at Khesanh came under intense shelling yester day, forcing American helicop ters based there to scatter into the sky.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Antiwar Performers to Sue For U.S. Support of Show
lead_paragraph: A troupe of antiwar perform ers who were refused permis sion by the army to stage their show at Fort Bragg, N. C., said yesterday that it would file suit against the Pentagon in Wash ington this week.

headline: U.S. Force in Vietnam Now Down to 317,300
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 15 (Reuters) — The United States military com mand said today that as of March 11 the number of American personnel in South Vietnam had fallen to 317, 300, the lowest figure since Oct. 10, 1966.

headline: Calley Jury Is Shown a Picture Of Women's and Babies' Bodies
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 15 — The Government prose cutor in the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. held a photograph of corpses of women, children and babies before members of the jury today and asked if they really expected Lieutenant Calley to admit that these were the “enemies” he killed at Mylai.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: LAWYER LINK CITED IN PX INVESTIGATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)—Earl F. Cole, a former general accused of aiding al legedly corrupt American busi ness enterprises in Vietnam, is represented by a Washington law firm closely linked to lawyers representing other major figures in the case, Senator Charles H. Percy said today.

headline: New Premier of Australia Wins First Parliament Test
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, March 15 —Prime Minister William Mc Mahon, passing his first parlia mentary test since taking office five clays ago, defeated a mo tion of no confidence in his Government in the House of Representatives today. The vote was 62 to 58.

headline: SOUTH VIETNAMESE RETREAT 5 MILES FROM A LAOS BASE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 17 — South Vietnamese forward units in Laos have reportedly with drawn five miles eastward to ward their own border under increasing enemy pressure.

headline: Rogers Denies That U.S. Policy Is Affected by Oil Off Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 16— Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that reports of large oil deposits off the shore of South Vietnam “have absolutely no effect on United States policy.”

headline: Man Who Was Cited in PX Inquiry Assails Accuser
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 16— A businessman, accused of ex tensive abuses in his dealings with American military forces in Southeast Asia, has gone on television to deny a number of, charges against him and to lodge several of his own.

headline: VIETNAM G.I. FORCE OF 50,000 SEEN BY '73
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 16— Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird indicated today that few er than 50,000 American sol diers would remain in Vietnam by the end of 1972.

headline: Bribe Report Denied
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)—Martin J. Bromley, iden tified in Senate testimony as head of an international slot machine syndicate that made up to $100‐million profit in the last 10 years, told the subcom mittee today that he never of fered a $50,000 bribe to silence an Army general.

headline: Criticism Heads Agenda In BankAmerica Meeting
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 —Executives of the BankAmer ica Corporation, the parent holding company of the Bank of America, came to their annual meeting of stockholders here today prepared for criticism. They got plenty, although it came from a small minority of the some 500 stockholders gathered in the Masonic Me morial Temple auditorium.
author: By Robert A. Wright Special to The New York Times

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Army is in trouble in Indochina, not so much because of difficulties in mastering the new kind of war it has been summoned to fight but because of psychological reper cussions arising from doubts as to the validity or value of its mission. These doubts are more inspired by news from home than by enemy propaganda.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Rout Reported in Hanoi
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 16 (Agence France‐ Presse)—The Communist com mand in Laos issued an order to its troops today to “com pletely annihilate” and “prevent the withdrawal of South Viet namese troops, who it said were fleeing “in disorder.”

headline: GALLEY CASE GOES TO MILITARY JURY
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 16—The case of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who is charged with the murder of at least 102 unresisting South Vietnamese civilians, went to the jury this evening.
author: By Homer Bigart special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Lyman B. Lewis Geneva, N. Y., March 11, 1971

headline: Veterans Plan a War Protest in Capital
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 16— Vietnam Veterans Against the War announced today that the organization, which claims to have 8,000 members and chap ters in every state, would hold a five‐day encampment here next month “to protest the war and the lack of adequate serv ices for returned veterans.”

headline: SAIGON'S FORCES QUIT FOURTH BASE IN LAOS FIGHTING
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday March 18 — South Vietnamese troops evacuated another base in Laos today.

headline: 2 SENATORS HINT AT COLE PERJURY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)—Senate investigators said today that the sworn testimony of former Brig. Gen Earl F. Cole should be examined by the Treasury and Justice Depart ments for possible perjury and tax‐evasion prosecution.

headline: Priest Group Asks Optional Celibacy
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, Thursday, March 18—After nearly five hours of debate, representatives of more than half of the country's Ro man Catholic priests adopted a statement early today calling for major reforms in the priest hood.
author: By Donald Janson Special to The New York Times

headline: POLL FINDS CONCERN ON ECONOMIC ISSUE
lead_paragraph: Economic issues worry Amer icans now more than at any time since the 1958 recession, according to a Gallup Poll made public today.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: P. P. Tamagno Fort Lee, N. J., March 8, 1971

headline: Thieu, Facing Election, Sees Political Gains in Laos Drive
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 17—Presi dent Nguyen Van Thieu, facing an election this fall, has intensi fied his efforts to reap political as well as military benefits from the present South Viet namese campaign against Com munist supply lines in Laos.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Church Council Bars Award to Bob Hope
lead_paragraph: A group of activist clergymen who oppose the Indochina war has persuaded the Council of Churches of the City of New York to cancel its plan to present the 1971 Family of Man Award to Bob Hope.
author: By Grace Lichtenstein

headline: Mylai Inquiry Credited With Raising Morale
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE, March 18 (UPI) The Army Chief of Staff, Gen. William Westmoreland, said today that the Mylal inquiry had raised military morale by showing that improper ac tions would not be tolerated.

headline: New Zealand to Pull Out Unit
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 17, (AP)—Prime Minister Kieth Holyoake said today that New Zealand would withdraw its 131‐man artillery battery from South Vietnam at the be ginning of May.

headline: ‘According to Plan,’ U.S. Says
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) — The Defense Depart ment said today that the South Vietnamese forces in Laos were engaged in “mobile maneuver ing” and were proceeding “ac cording to plan.”

headline: Forces Move Back
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Thursday, March 18 — Some South Vietnamese forces in Laos continued to move southeast back toward the border yesterday, trying to consolidate their positions after running into intense Commu nist attacks.

headline: Illness of Juror in Calley Trial Threatens to Halt Deliberations
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Thurs day, March 18—The sudden ill ness of a juror late last night threatened a probable suspen sion of jury deliberations on the fate of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., charged with the pre meditated murder of 102 South Vietnam civilians at Mylai three years ago.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Funds Said to Be Key to G. I. Pullout Rate
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 17—The United States command in Saigon has told Washington that a lack of money for the Vietnam war has been more crucial in determin ing the rate of troop withdraw als than has the progress of Vietnamization or what the enemy does on the battefield.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: U. S. COPTERS LIFT 1,000 OUT OF LAOS; FIGHTING IS BITTER
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 19—Hundreds of battered and weary South Vietnamese soldiers were lifted out of Laos by American heli copters yesterday after some of the fiercest fighting of their campaign against Communist supply lines.
author: By Alvin Shuster special to The New York Times

headline: Week's G.I. Death Toll In Indochina Put at 45
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 18 (AP)—The United States command said today that 45 Americans were killed in combat in Indochina last week, an increase of one over the previous week. It listed 156 Americans wound ed, compared with 434 the week before.

headline: HANOI AND VIETCONG CONTINUING PROTEST
lead_paragraph: PARIS, March 18 (AP)—The thief North Vietnamese and Vietcong delegates boycotted the Vietnam peace talks today for the third week in succession to protest against What they called United States plans to extend the war into North Vietnam.

headline: U.S. Expresses Regret
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 18— The United States expressed deep regret today over Nor way's intention to establish dip lomatic relations with North Vietnam. A State Department spokesman said that the depart ment was notified yesterday by the Norwegian Embassy here that diplomatic relations would be established with Hanoi, and that the American Embassy in Oslo had been informed.

headline: 2 Generals Face Demotion Over Roles in Mylai Case
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 18 — Gen. William C. West moreland has recommended that Maj. Gen. Samuel W. Koster and the general who was his assistant in command of the Army division involved in the alleged masacre at the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 be demoted and rep rimanded, Pentagon sources said today.

headline: Berets Chute Into Bay State And Are Met by Protesters
lead_paragraph: NORTH ADAMS, Mass., March 18—A force of 105 Green Ber ets parachuted into Harriman Airport and the surrounding residential district today in a tactical combat training mis sion and were met by 1,500 onlookers, about 300 of whom were jeering antiwar protesters from Williams College.

headline: TESTIMONY READ TO CALLEY JURY
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 18—The jury in the Mylai mur der trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. concluded its sec ond day of deliberations today by asking for a reading of the evidence of several Witnesses concerning a charge that Lieu tenant Calley had murdered at least 30 Vietnamese at the southern edge of the village.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Cites Gains in Laos Amid Reports of Setbacks
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 18— The Nixon Administration sought today to maintain both its composure and its optimism in the face of mounting reports that the South Vietnamese were being compelled to retreat in Laos.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Setback for Foe Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 18 (AP)— “We are still in Laos, but con centrated near the Vietnamese border now,” a South Viet namese headquarters spokes man said today.

headline: Curb on Voting List Favored by Thieu Is Set Back
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 18—A provision in a draft electoral law to limit the number of candidates in the October presidential election was defeated today by a large vote in the Senate.

headline: Churches May Alter Process For the Family of Man Award
lead_paragraph: The Council of Churches of the City of New York will prob ably make a major change in the way it selects winners of its principal Family of Man award as a result of a controversy this week when it canceled plans to honor Bob Hope.
author: By Grace Lichtenstein

headline: A Mother's Personal Protest Against War
lead_paragraph: Thirty‐one days ago in Newton, Mass., Louise Bruyn, 40, left a hus band, two teen‐age daughters, a com fortable old nine‐room house, a half breed collie, a cat, her job as a modern dance teacher, her household chores, community activities and friends, and began to walk to Washington, alone. She is still walking.
author: By Lisa Hammel

headline: NEW YORK
lead_paragraph: Very little reliable information trick les out of China, these days, but two recent morsels are interesting. First, Chinese officials in Peking have been talking more freely and ominously to Western diplomats about the dangers of the Indochina war; and second, they have been emphasizing that, while they intervened in the Korean war, they withdrew all their troops from that country once the danger was over.
author: By James Reston

headline: PENTAGON BELITTLES REPORT ON PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 18— Defense Department officials today described as unimportant and not relevant to high‐level policy the reported complaint of some military leaders in Saigon about the pace and mo tivation of the rate of troop withdrawals.

headline: Norway's New Premier Says Ties With Hanoi Will Be Sought
lead_paragraph: OSLO, Norway, March 18— Premier Trygve Bratteli said today that his new Cabinet, which assumed office yester day, would move to establish diplomatic links between Nor way and North Vietnam.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wisc.—Harold Rohr, known to everybody as Babe, has been a local symbol of hard‐hat support for the Vietnam war. He is president of the Madison Building Trades Council. As an alderman a few years ago he fought the peace groups and opposed a referendum on the war.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Agnew Says U.S. Would Acknowledge a Laos Defeat
lead_paragraph: NEWTON, Mass., March 19 — The Nixon Administration would admit it publicly if South Vietnamese combat forces were mauled by the enemy in Laos, Vice President Agnew said to day.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: END OF LAOS DRIVE HINTED IN SAIGON; 2,000 WITHDRAWN
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, March 20—The South Vietnamese command an nounced yesterday that it had withdrawn 2,000 to 3,000 of its troops from action in Laos in 48 hours.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Controversy on Vietnam Policy Has Abated on Capitol Hill for the Moment
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 19— For the time being, at least, the controversy over the Viet nam issue has abated on Cap itol Hill.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: MYLAI GENERAL SAYS HE'S A ‘SCAPEGOAT’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) — Brig. Gen. George H. Young Jr., facing possible demotion for his role in the investigation of the Mylai slay ings, said today that he believed he was being made the Army's political scapegoat.

headline: Wisconsin Senate Passes A Bill Challenging the War
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis., March 19— The Wisconsin Senate has passed a bill challenging the Government's right to draft Wisconsin men to fight in un declared wars such as the In dochina conflict.

headline: Victory Demonstrations On
