lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)—Demonstrations for mili tary victory in Vietnam by July 4 will be held tomorrow in state capitals and the national capital, the United States March for Victory organization of the Rev. Dr. Carl McIntife an nounced today.

headline: Calley Jury Ends Its Third Day After Testimony Is Read Again
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING. Ga., March 19—The jury of six combat of ficers charged with determining the fate of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. ended its third day of deliberation today with out reaching a verdict.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Congressional Probe in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: At a critical moment of the Korean War, after Presi dent Truman had fired General Macarthur, Congressional hearings probed deeply and publicly into all aspects that controversial Asian conflict. The highest civilian and military officers of the executive branch, with the important exception only of the President, appeared before joint sessions of the Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees in May‐June, 1951. They submitted to 43 days of questioning, during which more than 3,000 pages of testimony were taken to enable the Congress and the country to come to a judgment on major undeclared war into which the country had been taken, without consultation, by Presidential decision.

headline: SAIGON ABANDONS TWO MORE BASES BATTERED BY FOE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 20—South Vietnamese troops retreated from two more bases in Laos today after the heaviest series of enemy attacks since the start of the allied thrust six weeks ago.
author: By Alvin Sruster Special to The New York Times

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — The long‐range weather forecast issued infre quently by 'the United States Command usually; passes un noticed in the flood of official verbiage. But the one issued last week contained an item of par ticular interest: The rainy season over the Ho Chi Minh. Trail net work is not likely, to, begin until well into May.
author: —Alvin Shuster

headline: Foe Reports B‐52 Downed
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam,March 20 (Agence France‐Presse)—An American B‐52 bomber was shot down in North Vietnam on Thursday, the Hanoi radio re ported today. It said the air craft was hit over Vinhhlinh near the 17th Parallel. Foreign military experts said that the North Vietnamese were using new antiaircraft rocket that cannot be detected by the elec tronic detection devices in these planes.

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: The delicate relationship between the Roman Catholic church and the Italian State has undergone some heavy shocks in recent months in the field of marriage and sex. On Dec. 1, after a five‐year battle, Parliament made di vorce legal. This month the Italian Supreme Court ruled that the 1929 concordats, which govern Vatican‐Italian relations, were not above scrutiny by Parliament or the courts. That had the effect of nullifying church efforts to have the divorce reform declared unconstitutional. And last Wednesday, the Su preme Court strucx down as unconstitutional & law writ ten during the Fascist regime banning dissemination of birth control information. Hitherto, birth control de vices had been sold only on

headline: 3,000 at Rally in Capital
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)—About 3,000 youths dem onstrated on the grassy ex panse south of the White House today in the first big gathering of the spring demonstration season. A series of speakers de manded an end to United States involvement in Southeast Asia, destruction of the capitalist sys tem and guaranteed jobs and wages for all citizens.

headline: The Nation.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — Until the spring of 1970, the peasants of Cam bodia's sleepy villages could lis ten with little concern to the daily air strikes across the Viet namese border. Today the bor der is no more.
author: —Tom Fox

headline: Calley to Lecture Against All Wars If He Is Acquitted
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 20 (AP)—First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. said today that if he is acquitted he will go on a worldwide tour delivering anti war lectures.

headline: POLICE MICROPHONE REMOVED FROM PARK
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del., March 20 (AP) — City engineers re moved a police microphone from a tree in Rodney Square today, several hours before demonstration protesting the war in Indochina.

headline: C. B. S. Is Challenged by Agnew To Admit‘Errors’ in 3 TV Films
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) — Vice President Agnew challenged the Columbia Broad casting System tonight to ad mit or deny his charges of “error and propagandistic ma nipulation” in three C.B.S. tele vision documentaries.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Jonathan B. Bingham

headline: National Notes
lead_paragraph: Shopper's Guide There are two brand‐name detergents on the supermarket shelf, both “large economy size.” Brand X, is priced at $1.59. Brand Y is only $1.29. The shop per's choice is obvious—or is it? Brand X actually contains 5½ pounds of detergent—Brand Y, only 4 pounds.

headline: U. S. Denies Loss
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)—A United States Defense Department spokesman said no United States B‐52's had been lost in Indochina “as the result of hostile action.” He said three had crashed in the area over the years, but that none had been struck by enemy fire.

headline: Calley Jury to Rehear Testimony of Four Witnesses
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 20—The military judge in the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. ruled to day that the jury may hear a reading of the entire testimony of four key Government wit nesses.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, March 20 (UPI)— Su Robert Thompson, the Brit ish guerrilla expert who is an adviser to President Nixon, be lieves the invasions of Cam bodia and Laos have removed the military threat to South Vietnam.

headline: For G.I.'s, Freedom Bird Means Home
lead_paragraph: LONGBINH, South Vietnam, March 20 (AP)—For the soldier, DEROS by any other name would smell as sweet. It is military jargon for Date of Es timated Return From Overseas. It means going home.

headline: Saigon and Pnompenh Assail Pillaging
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 20—A joint report by high South Vietnamese and Cambodian officials calls for radical measures to halt vi olence and theft by South Viet namese troops against Cambo dian civilians.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: GIAP SAYS AMERICANS CANNOT AVOID LOSING
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 20 (Agence France. Presse)—Deputy Premier Vo Nguyen Giap said yesterday that the United States, its “wild illusions shattered,” was un able to avoid total defeat in Indochina.

headline: M'GOVERN ASSERTS HE'D END THE WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 20— Senator George S. McGovern, the only declared candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, has asserted he would negotiate a settlement of the Indochina war within weeks of ‐being inaugurated President in 1973.

headline: 2 G.I. Platoons Near Laos Refuse Orders to Advance
lead_paragraph: QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, Monday, March 22—Two pla toons of American armored cavalrymen refused orders yes terday to advance along em battled Route 9 near the Lao tian border, and their com manding officer was relieved of duty, United States military spokesmen reported.

headline: Police Curtail Saigon's Black Market
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 21—Gone are the bot tles of Old Spice and Jade East shaving lotions that came from the United States Army post exchanges. For the huge black market on the sidewalks of downtown Saigon, where ped dlers used to spread out their illicit wares on Amy ponchos, is no more.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Coast G.O.P. Croup Censures McCloskey for Nixon Criticism
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, March 21 —The California Republican Assembly censured Represen tative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. today and urged him to join another political party because of his attacks on President Nixon's policy in Southeast Asia.

headline: Pathet Lao Says It Crushed Saigon Force of 1,500 Men
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Monday, March 22, (Reuters)—The North Viet nam News Agency reported today that pro‐Communist La otian forces had almost com pletely wiped out the Second Regiment of South Vietnam's First Infantry Division‐1,500 men—and shot down some 90 aircraft in attacks on Peak 660 in southern Laos that started Wednesday.

headline: BLAZE DESTROYS OFFICES AT TUFTS
lead_paragraph: MEDFORD, Mass., March 21 —A three‐alarm blaze destroyed offices at Tufts University's Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy early this morning.

headline: Dean Rusk: On the War
lead_paragraph: At this particular time I would men tion two situations that are highly dangerous. The first is the Middle East. There, the two sides that live in the area—Israel and its Arab neighbors— show very little indication of being willing to make the concessions that are necessary to establish peace.

headline: Nixon Aides Use Agnew Phrase of ‘Orderly Retreat’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 21— Administration officials con tinued to maintain today that the quickening South Viet namese withdrawals from Laos represented an “orderly re treat,” not a rout, and that the gains in the operation still out weighed the losses.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Troops, in Desperation, Scramble for U.S. Helicopters
lead_paragraph: HAMNGHI COMMAND POST, South Vietnam, March 21—The men who are considered South Vietnam's best soldiers are coming out of Laos, sonic in orderly fashion, others in panic. The North Vietnamese are right behind them.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: 2,000 RETREAT FROM LAOS, PURSUED BY HANOI UNITS; U.S. PLANES BOMB IN NORTH
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 22—More than 2,000 South Vietnames troops retreated hastily from Laos yesterday and today while North Vietnamese forces pur sued them, posing a possible threat to American installations supporting the six‐week‐old campaign.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: TESTIMONY RERUN FOR CALLEY JURY
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 21—The jury in the war crimes murder trial of First Lieut. Wil liam L. Calley Jr. returned to court today to hear a two‐hour rerun of Government testimony.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: The School‐in‐a‐Cart for G.I.'s
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU, March 22 (UPI) —The students Judith Par rish teaches from her “one‐ wagon schoolhouse” have a lot to remember.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 22—Some South Vietnamese soldiers, in the re treat from Laos, have been Clinging to the landing skids of American heli copters. Some have been falling to their deaths from these precarious perches, and in addition, “we just have to kick some of them off,” an Ameri can pilot has reported. “We have to think about ourselves, too. You just cannot lift this bird with fifteen guys clinging to it.”
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: House Committee Seeking a More Active Foreign Policy Role
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 22— The long‐dormant House For eign Affairs Committee, which has tended to be an acquies– cent partner to the executive branch, is staking out a more active, independent role in the formulation of foreign policy.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Excerpts From Nixon's TV Interview
lead_paragraph: Following lire excerpts from an interview with President. Nixon last night by Howard K. Smith of the American Broadcasting Company, as recorded by The New. York Times.

headline: NIXON SAYS DRIVE BY SAIGON HELPS REACH KEY GOALS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 22— President Nixon said tonight that the South Vietnamese drive in Laos “has made considerable progress” thus far toward the goals of insuring United States withdrawals from Vietnam, re ducing the threat to the Ameri can forces still there and de veloping the ability of Saigon's army to defend itself.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Pravda Reports Pullback
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, March 22—The Soviet press prominently dis played news of the South Viet namese pullback from Laos to day.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: (The Rev.) Frederick F. Johnson

headline: HIGH COURT TAKES DOW PROXY CASE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) — The Supreme Court agreed today to review a lower court decision that the Gov ernment asserts drastically up sets procedures for handling business proxy cases.

headline: A ‘WEEK OF CONCERN’ FOR P.O.W.'S OPENS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 22— A “national week of concern” for the American prisoners of war and servicemen missing in action in Indochina opened here today amid growing Con gressional feeling that an alter native to President Nixon's policy on the prisoners must be found.

headline: General Won't Punish G.I.'s for Refusing Orders
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March, 22 — A command ing general said today, he did, not plan to take disciplinary action against 53 of his men who refused an order to move forward to secure a damaged helicopter and their command ing officer's armored vehicle.

headline: Enemy Troops Repulsed After Assault on Khesanh
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 23 — North Vietnamese soldiers carrying satchel charges broke into Khe sanh today behind a heavy ar tillery barrage, but were driven out with heavy losses, the United States command said.

headline: Hearing Set for Captain
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, March 22 (UPI)—The Army an nounced today that the initial pretrial hearing in the court martial of Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc for the alleged maiming of a Vietnamese near Mylai would, be held here April 13.

headline: Pentagon Defends Use of Tear Gases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 22— The Defense Department argued today that tear gases and plant killers were legitimate, humane weapons of war that should not be abandoned by the United States.

headline: Calley jurors Hear Reading of Testimony by 3 Witnesses Telling of Officer's Part in Deaths at Mylai
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 22—The story of the alleged massacre of South Vietnamese women and children in an ir rigation ditch outside the ham let of Mylai three years ago was told again today to the military jury weighing the fate of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Appeal For Hartke‐Roudebush Recount
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 22— The Supreme Court agreed to day to consider If the Consti tution bars Indiana officials from recounting the votes in the disputed election of Sena tor Vance }lattice over former Representative Richard L. Rou debush.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Suggests Press Distorts Policy
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 22— Although his language was tol erant and his mood almost: de liberately polite, President Nixon suggested tonight that his Indo china policy has been distorted by incomplete and at times un fair coverage by the nation's news media.
author: By. Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Soviet Aid Said to Run $2‐Billion Yearly
lead_paragraph: Soviet military aid to Com munist and underdeveloped. countries amounted to more than $19‐billion in the years from 1955 to 1970, according to authoritative sources in the United States and Allied gov ernments.
author: By Drew Middleton

headline: Dean Rusk: On the Presidency
lead_paragraph: These remarks by former Secretary of State Dean Rusk are excerpted from a conversation he held last month with Georgia broadcasters at the University of Georgia's School of Journalism. The conversations were broadcast by WSB in Atlanta; this is the second of two articles derived from the broadcast. Mr. Rush is now Professor of Interna tional Law at the University of Georgia.

headline: U.S. Strikes Missile Bases
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 23 — United States fighters and bombers struck at missile sites inside North Vietnam yesterday for the second consecutive day as South Vietnamese troops re treating from Laos continued to encounter heavy enemy as saults.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Advertising:
lead_paragraph: Ira Nerken is proving again that one lone person with the proper spark and, drive can get the ball rolling in this country.
author: By Philip H. Dougherty

headline: HANOI AIDE TERMS RETREAT BLOCKED
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 22 (Agence France Presse)—A high‐ranking North Vietnamese officer wrote today that the South Vietnamese forces were in the midst of a “bloody retreat,” but that it was “too late” for the bulk of their troops to escape from southern Laos.

headline: U.S. Forces Reduced To 312,900 in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 22 (AP)—The United States Command said today that American troop strength in South Vietnam had dropped to 312,900 men by last Thursday, a decrease of 4,400 from the previous week.

headline: PUSH CUT SHORT, PENTAGON ADMITS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 23 — The Defense Department ac knowledged today that South Vietnamese troops might have stayed longer in Laos if the Communists had not reacted as strongly as they did to the attacks on their vital supply line.
author: By Tad Szulc  Special to The New York Times

headline: Gains for Laotians Reported
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 23 (UPI)—Laotian troops supported by artillery and air strikes went on the offensive today and recaptured a position held by North Vietnamese forces five miles northeast of the royal capital of Luang Prabang, mili tary sources reported.

headline: ARMOR QUITS LAOS WITH HEAVY LOSS; 5,000 STILL THERE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 24 — A South Vietnamese armored force of 100 tanks and heavy tracked vehicles fought its way out of Laos yesterday.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: North Vietnam Disputes Nixon
lead_paragraph: PARIS, March 23 (AP) — North Vietnam, contesting Presi dent Nixon's assessment of the Laos incursion, said today that it had “completely failed.”

headline: Appeals Court Dismisses Medina Suit Against Time
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, March 23 (UPI)— The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit affirmed today a lower court ruling dismissing a $2‐million libel suit filed by Capt. Ernest L. Medina against the publish ers of Time magazine.

headline: Retreat From Laos ...
lead_paragraph: The precipitate withdrawal of South Vietnamese troops from Laos well before the anticipated arrival of the mon soon may not represent the humiliating rout that is sug gested by fragmentary reports from the combat zone. But it is painfully clear, despite persisting efforts Washington and Saigon to put the best possible face on a bad situation, that the Laotian operation has fallen far short of the expectations of American and South Viet namese military planners.

headline: GALLEY ATTORNEY CRITICIZES JURORS
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 23—The chief defense lawyer for First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. complained at a hear ing today that the jury of six officers seemed more interested in “wining and dining” than in reaching a verdict.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Rearing Set for Medina
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 23 (Reuters)—Pretria hearings in the court‐martial of Capt. Ern est Medina, charged with the premeditated murder of more than 100 South Vietnamese ci vilians at Mylai; will begin at Fort McPherson, Ga., on May 24, the Army announced today. Captain Medina was Lieutenant Galley's officer at the time of the alleged massacre.

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 23—The allied thrust against Communist supply lines, now drawing to a close, may have achieved some limited military success and killed thousands of the enemy, but in political propaganda terms Hanoi seems to have won the day. In this situation, unlike the aftermath of last spring's joint American and South Vietnamese offensive against the Cambodian sanctuaries, the allies are com ing out looking like losers, whether they are or not.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: ...Increases the Credibility Gap
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's ill‐disguised criticism of press and television for their reporting of the Laotian campaign likely to benefit him as much as ancient Persian gen erals were benefitted by killing messengers who brought bad news.

headline: On Route 9, an Ambush Every Day
lead_paragraph: LANGVEI, South Vietnam, March 23—The last four miles of Route 9, down which exultant South Viet namese troops moved unop posed to the Laotian border six weeks ago, have become a daily ordeal for the Amer ican tank crews that are covering, their retreat under heavy fire.
author: By Iver Peterson  Special to The New York Times

headline: Dole Doubts Fairness
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 24 (AP)— Senator Robert Dole, Republican of Kansas, said today that he felt the Administration “definitely has a hard time getting its views across in the nation's televised medium.”

headline: Hanoi and Vietcong, in Protest, Cancel Session at Paris Talks
lead_paragraph: PARIS, March 24—Hanoi and the Vietcong, protesting against the latest American bombing of North Vietnam, today called off tomorrow's session of the Paris negotiations.

headline: Saigon ‘Cowboys’ Race the Draft
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 24—Four “cowboys” sitting in a cafe spoke of their restlessness, their contempt for the attitudes of their parents, their anger at having to go into the army and their need to be entertained while there is still time.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: Major elements of television are bracing for a tilt with Congress and the Nixon Administration on the exercise of reportorial independence by a journalistic medium that operates under a Federal Government license. The issue, one of the oldest in the evolution of broadcasting, is coming to a climax over the coverage of fighting in Laos. In a step believed to be without parallel in radio or television, Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Company, former journalist himself, is sending a personal letter to every member of the Senate and the House, objecting to a recent Congressional review of film footage from Laos.
author: By Jack Gould

headline: Thieu Said to Have Curbed Offensive to Reduce Loss
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 24‐Well‐placed Pentagon sources say that President Nguyen Van Thieu decided to curtail South Vietnam's offensive in Laos despite suggestions from some senior American militarymen that he send in replacements and try to stay on for a few more weeks.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Shrugs Off Move
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 24 (Reuters) — The State Departmerit spokesman, Charles W. Bray 3d, as about the Communist move, said today, “If I could shrug my, shoulders audibly, I would do so.”

headline: JURORS DEFENDED BY GALLEY JUDGE
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 24 — Cries of “whitewash” would inevitably follow an acquittal of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and angry criticism of another kind would just as surely greet a conviction, the military judge said today while defending the Calley jurors against defense charges of “wining and dining” and dilatory conduct.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: F.B.I. Files Tell of Surveillance Of Students, Blacks, War Foes
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 24—Copies of Federal Bureau of Investigation documents that have been mailed anonymously to several newspapers and individuals indicate that the agency is engaged in active surveillance of student, Negro and peace groups.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Most Objectives Held Attained
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 24 (AP)—Lieut. Col. Tran Van Am, chief spokesman for the South Viet. namese command, said today that Government forces had accomplished SO to 90 per cent of their objectives in the Laos operation.

headline: Lodge, Nixon's Voice at Vatican, Gets Enviable Papal Audiences
lead_paragraph: ROME, March 24 — Whenever President Nixon's special envoy to the Vatican, Henry Cabot Lodge, is about to see Pope Paul VI he dons a dark blue suit and blue necktie and does some last‐minute reading on Indochina in the confidential files from Saigon, Washington and Paris.
author: By Paul Hofmann Special to The New York Times

headline: Minute of Silence Urged
lead_paragraph: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that he would ask the city to observe one min‐ute of silence on Good Friday, April 9, and that he would proclaim‐April 28 as Prisoner of War Day.
author: By Mayor For Prisoners

headline: Democratic Council Backs Funds Cutoff For the War by '72
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 24 —The Democratic party's Policy, Council voted unanimously today to support a Congressional, cutoff of all funds for American military operations in Indochina after Dec. 31.
author: By R W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON DRIVE IN LAOS ENDS AS 1,500 LEAVE LAST BASE; ENEMY KEEPS UP PRESSURE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam Thursday, March 25 — The South Vietnamese drive against enemy supply lines in Laos ended yesterday, 44 days after it began.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: HANOI TRADE MISSION RECOGNIZED BY CHILE
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 25 —A Mirth Vietnamese commer cial mission was formally rec ognized by Chile today as a first step toward establishment of diplomatic relations between the two countries.

headline: Foe Lists Raid Casualties
lead_paragraph: HANOI March 25 (Agence Prance‐Presse)—United States bombing raids over the south ern provinces of North Vietnam have caused some 100 casual ties since the beginning of the month, according to a corn muniqué published here today.

headline: AMERICANS BEGIN TROOP PULLBACK NEARlAOSBORDER
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, March 26—United States units began pulling away from the Laotian border today as concern continued that North Vietnamese troops would try to intensify their attacks against American installations.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 25— Although President Nixon de, nied this week that he had just passed through his winter of discontent, there is little doubt around the White House that this is his stormiest season yet.

headline: Galley Jury Deliberates 9th Day; Submits No Requests to Judge
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 25—For the first time since they received the case nine days ago, the military jurors in the trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. deliberated today without asking the judge questions or requesting any re‐reading of testimony.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 25—Nothing Is harder to conduct than coalition warfare with divided counsel and com mand. This cost the allies hundreds of thousands of lives in, the two World Wars when the separate nations could not agree on who had the decisive voice on the battlefield, and it is clear from the recent operation's in Laos that the United States and South Viet nam are now running into that dan gerous pproblem in the final phase of the war.
author: By James Reston

headline: What is the President's Policy?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The politics of was in Southeast Asia is not, as some ob servers have been saying, simply a rerun of 1967 and 1968.
author: By Eugene J. McCarthy

headline: KENNEDY DECRIES LAOS OPERATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 25— Senator Edward M. Kennedy today described the South Viet namese incursion into Laos as “a nightmare” that has ended in a “humiliating retreat” car ried out “so obviously in panic.”
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Kotouc Trial Is Set
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., March 25 (AP)—Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc, accused of cutting off a suspected enemy's finger during an interrogation after the alleged massacre at Mylai 4, will be tried April 26, the Army announced today.

headline: U.S. WARNS HANOI ON DMZ BUILD‐UP
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 25 — The Defense Department issued a veiled warning today that air strikes against North Viet namese artillery and rockets might have to be ordered if they fired from new posi tions within the demilitarized zone that straddles the border between the two Vietnams.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I. Mood at Battered Khesanh: ‘We Don't Want to Be Relieved‐We Want to Get Out’
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Viet nam, March 25—When Spe cialist 4 Gregory Geneviva heard at noon today that the American troops of the 101st Airborne Division would shortly be leaving the huge allied base here, with the Vietnamese drive into Laos at the feeble end of its final chapter, he shook his head and sighed:
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. SEEKS REVIEW OF CHICAGO 7 CASE
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, March 25—The United States Attorney's office filed a Motion here today re questing a new hearing on the contempt sentences of the sev en defendants in the Chicago conspiracy trial.

headline: Protestants See Paris Envoys; Urge U.S. Withdrawal Pledge
lead_paragraph: PARIS, March 26—A group of 46 American Protestant church leaders, clergymen and laymen urged the United States today to pledge unconditional withdrawal of its troops from Indochina in the immediate future to facilitate a political settlement at the Vietnam peace talks.

headline: Rogers Hints Boycott
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) —Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States intended to continue negotiations for peace in Vietnam but held open the possibility that the United States and South Vietnam might boycott the next round in Paris.

headline: Henderson Hearing Set
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., March 26 (AP)—The initial pretrial hearing for Col. Oran K. Henderson, charged with dereliction of duty in connection with the investigation of the alleged Mylai massacre, will be conducted here next Friday, the Army said today.

headline: Army TV in Saigon Airs ‘Selling of the Pentagon’
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 26—The official Army television station here aired the Columbia Broadcasting System's “Trie Selling of the Pentagon” twice—last Saturday at 6 P.M. and yesterday at 5 P.M.

headline: Hope for Vote on Calley Rises As Jury Asks Copy of Charges
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 26—The military jury in the trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. approached its second weekend of deliberations today by asking for a more legible copy of the Army specifications of charges against the 27‐year‐old officer.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: BLACKS GIVE NIXON MAY 17 DEADLINE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 26—Black members of the House of Representatives said today that if President Nixon has not begun to act by May 17 on a set of demands they presented him yesterday they would take the issue to the people.
author: By Paul Delaney Special to The New York Times

headline: C. B. S. Team Wins Award for a Vietnam Project
lead_paragraph: A Columbia Broadcasting System tearn that produced “The World of Charlie Company,” a portrait of the life of United States soldiers in Vietnam, has won the 1971 Overseas Press Club's George Polk Memorial Award, it was announced yesterday.

headline: Saigon Patrols Moved Up To Help Retreating Units
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 27—Several hundred South Vietnamese marines were sent to patrol in small units along the Laotian border yesterday, and some were ordered back into Laos to reoccupy a hilltop position overlooking the Khesanh plateau of northwestern South Vietnam.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: WAR FOES BREAK UP TEACH‐INATHARVARD
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 26 (UPI)—Several hundred antiwar demonstrators broke up a teach‐in on Indochina shortly after it started tonight at Harvard University.

headline: Clashes Near Border
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Saturday, March 27 (AP) — Scattered clashes were reported in northwestern South Vietnam yesterday as allied troops continued to withdraw eastward.

headline: AID FOR FARMERS PLEDGED BY THIEU
lead_paragraph: LONGXUYEN, South Vietnam, March 26 (UPI) — President Nguyen Van Thieu informally opened his re‐election campaign today by announcing a five‐year plan to bolster the rural economy by cutting Imports but increasing exports of such commodities as rice.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Edward Jayne

headline: Chou Sees Nixon Widening The War Before Election
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Saturday, March 27 —Premier Chou En‐lai predicted last night that President Nixon would expand the war in Indochina to coincide with Presidential campaigning in 1972 in the United States.

headline: Foe Blocks Cambodian Road
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 27 (Reuters) — The North Vietnamese have oc cupied a 10‐mile stretch of Route 4 linking Pnompenh with Cambodia's only deep water port of Kompong Som, the high command said today.

headline: DEMOCRATS SCORED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI)—Senator Robert J. Dole of Kansas, the Republican Na tional Chairman, said today that the peace movement was led by politicians who “pander to the war‐weariness of the American people.”
author: BY G.o.p. Chairman

headline: Rogers, in Policy Report, Sees ‘Preoccupation’ With Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 27— Secretary of State William P. Rogers told Congress today that the United States' “national preoccupation with Vietnam has pre‐empted our attention from other areas of concern” in the world.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Brady Bryson

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — When South Viet namese troops moved across the border into Laos last month, many seemed nervous, but also jubilant and eager to show the North Vietnamese and the world that the pupils had learned their lessons well from teachers who were about to go home.
author: —Alvin Shuster

headline: Vatican Names Hanoi Bishop
lead_paragraph: ROME, March 27 (UPI)—The Vatican has announced the ap pointment of the Msgr. Pierre Marie Nguyen Nang as Bishop of Vinh, North Vietnam. He was consecrated about two weeks ago in Hanoi Cathedral.

headline: Lodge Confers With Pope
lead_paragraph: ROME, March 27—President Nixon's spceial envoy to Pope Paul VI, Henry Cabot Lodge had gin audience with the Pon tiff today. Vatican sources said that a wide range of subjects was believed to have been dis cussed, including the sitaeua tion in Vietnam and the. Mid dle Eats, and East‐West pro blems.

headline: ANTIWAR RALLIES SET FOR CAPITAL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 27 — A coalition of antiwar and civil rights organizations is planning a month‐long series of demon strations this spring, including a mass rally April 24 on the steps of the Capitol and an at tempt to “stop the Govern ment.”
author: By John Kifner Special to The New York Times

headline: Homicide Rate Rises 30% In First Part of 1971 Here
lead_paragraph: The rate of homicides in New York — which set records in 1969 and 1970 — is now run ning at least 30 per cent over the same period last year.
author: By Richard Severo

headline: Spirit of Saigon's Army Shaken in Laos
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 27—The morale of many soldiers in South Vietnam's fi nest military units, who fought the North Vietnamese in Laos, is shattered.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: G.O.P. in St. Paul Hears Reagan And Goodell Divide Over Nixon
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL, March 27— Gov. Ronald Reagan of Cali fornia and former Senator Charles E. Goodell of New York clashed here yesterday over the policies and prospects of the Nixon Administration. But Minnesota Republicans have taken precautions to avoid an early fight between their rival followings within the party.

headline: CALLEY JURY ASKS TO REHEAR 8 MORE
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 27—After deliberating nearly 70 hours, the military jury weighing the fate of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. indicated today that it was still far from a verdict by asking for a re reading of the testimony of eight more witnesses.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: The White House and Con gress are in a state of crucial and paradoxical confrontation with the medium of television. President Nixon uses TV to seek support for his policies and to humanize his public image; mean While his Administration and supporters in Congress are busy Ohallenging the home screen's catdibility and subjecting one or more of the networks to a drumbeat of criticism.
author: —Jack Gould

headline: POLITICIANS LEAD ANTIWAR RALLIES
lead_paragraph: Four members of the House of Representatives and a num ber of state and local officials staged a series of antiwar ral lies in the Bronx, Queens and Westchester County yesterday to raise support for a new move in Congress to cut off funds for the war in Indochina by the end of 1971.
author: By Robert D. McFadden

headline: U.S. and South Vietnamese Negotiators Move for a One Week Delay in Paris Peace Talks
lead_paragraph: PARIS, March 27—The Unit ed States and South Vietnam rejected today a Communist proposal to hold the next ses sion of the Vietnam peace talks April 1 and proposed April 8 instead.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: FOE ATTACKS G.I.'S NEAR LAOS BORDER
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 27 — Enemy gunners continued rocket and mortar attacks on United States troops, near the Laotian border today amid increasing signs that all major American units at this giant base would be pulled out soon.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 27—Presi dent Nixon's almost desperate efforts to increase his public support recently, have resulted only in a decline in his standing in the popularity polls, and the reason is fairly obvious.
author: By James Reston

headline: FOE KILLS 33 G.I.'B, WOUNDS 76 IN RAID SOUTH OF DANANG
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 29 — Thirty‐ three American soldiers were killed and 76 wounded early yesterday when enemy forces attacked and partly overran a United States Army artillery base in northern South Viet nam.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: JUDGE MAY PROD GALLEY'S JURORS
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 28—The military judge in the Mylai murder trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. an nounced today that he would consult with defense and pro secution attorneys tomorrow on whether to prod a jury that has deliberated longer than any other in the history of military justice.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Commando Raid Foiled
lead_paragraph: QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, March 9, (Reuters)—Bad wea ther and heavy anti‐aircraft fire today prevented about 300 South Vietnamese commandos from raiding a North Vietnam ese divisional headquarters in southern Laos, pilots and some of the troops said.

headline: HANOI PARTY HEAD REACHES MOSCOW
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, March 28 — Le Duan, the leader of North Viet nam's Communist party, arrived in Moscow last night with ranking Vietcong and Pathet Lao officials to attend the 24th Soviet Party Congress and dis cuss Indochinese developments with Soviet leaders.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: F.B.I. File Theft Stirs: Anger and Joy Among the Residents of Media, Pa.
lead_paragraph: MEDIA, Pa., March 26 — Too small to be incorporated as a city, this residential borough of 6,300 population some 10 miles southwest of Philadelphia is not too small to have a three‐room suite of offices for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
author: By Donald Janson Special to The New York Times

headline: Laotians Report Foe Retreats
lead_paragraph: LUANG PRABANG, Laos, March 28 (AP) —The Laotian command said today that Gov ernment troops had forced a North Vietnamese regiment back five miles from the em battled royal capital of Luang Prabang in two days of heavy fighting.

headline: State Legislators Start Nationwide Antiwar Drive
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) — More than a score of state legislators bearing peti tions signed by 627 lawmakers began today what they said was a state‐to‐state campaign to end the war in Indochina.

headline: A MISSILE FREEZE URGED BY JACKSON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 28— Senator Henry M. Jackson pro posed today a one‐year agree ment with the Soviet Union freezing the deployment of most land‐based missiles. He said this would “arrest the de cline in the security” of the United States nuclear deterrent.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Jewish Women Debate Alienation of Their Children
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, March 28 — “We have to meet our Jewish kids where they're at,” a group of Jewish mothers were told here today. “They saw, long before many of their parents did, the evils of racism, the blight of urban poverty and the immo rality of the war in Vietnam.”
author: By Ming Spiegel Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 28— Archibald Cox is a Harvard law pro fessor who served with great distinc tion as Solicitor General of the United States. His well‐known report on the troubles at Columbia University re fleeted a particullar sympathy for stu sons for their unrest. His person ex presses a New England sense of moral conviction.
author: BY Anthony Lewis

headline: Highest Attack Toll
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, March 29 (AP)— Available United States com mand records dating back to the beginning of 1967 indicate the American death toll at the artillery base south of Danang was the highest in that time in any single attack on a United States installation, although more Americans have been killed in day‐long running bat tles.

headline: 1968 Effort for a Major G.I. Build‐Up in Vietnam Is Reported
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 28— A former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen, G. Wheeler, reportedly encour aged Gen. William C. West moreland, then United States commander in Vietnam, to re quest large‐scale troop rein forcements during the Com munists. Lunar New Year of fensive in 1968.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Ephraim Cross New York, March 23, 1971

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Mary Redmer Josephson

headline: Some Saigon Troops in Laos, But Activities Are Kept Secret
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 30 — Some South Vietnamese troops con tinued operating inside Laos yesterday near the area from which a large Government task force withdrew last week.

headline: The Members of the Court‐Martial Jury
lead_paragraph: FORT KENNING, Ga., March 29 (AP) — Following are sketches of the six mem bers of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.'s court‐martial fury:

headline: U.S. Forces in Vietnam Now Down to 306,500
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 29 (UPI) — American troop strength in South Viet nam dropped by 6,400 last week, bringing it to a total of 306,500, the United States command said today.

headline: U.S. Base Attacked Again
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 30 (AP) — Still stunned from Sunday's attack, the Americal Division's artil lery base south of Danang cameunder enemy mortar attack early yesterday.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Harvey Glassman

headline: Calley, in Interview Before Verdict, Said He Hoped Mylai Would Help End Wars
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 29—“I hope Mylai isn't a trag edy but an eye‐opener, even for people who say war is hell,” said First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who was con victed today of the premedi tated murder of 22 Vietnamese civilians.

headline: Americans in South Vietnam Attribute the Setback in Laos to Faulty Planning and Intelligence
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 29—United States Army advisers and other observers in the field are ascribing the South Vietnamese. Army's perform ance in Laos to difficulties the allies had failed to anticipate and to tactical challenges it had not been trained to meet.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Men at Pentagon Decline To Comment on Verdict
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 29— The second‐ranking civilian in the Department.of Defense said tonight that the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was “a pretty, wrenching experience” for the Army.

headline: Two Sentences Possible
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 29 (AP)—The same jury that convicted Lieutenant Cagey of three counts of premeditated murder must choose between only two punishments, life in prison or death.

headline: GALLEY GUILTY OF MURDER OF 22 CIVILIANS AT MYLAI; SENTENCE EXPECTED TODAY
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 29 — First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was found guilty to day of the premeditated murder of at least 22 South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai three years ago.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: DEMOCRATIC WHIP ASKS U.S. PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 29— Breaking with other members of the House Democratic lead ership, the Democratic whip, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massa chusetts, called today for with drawal of all United States military forces from Indochina by the end of the year.
author: By Marjorie Hunter Special to The New York Times

headline: 3 Ex‐Students Charged by Harvard in Protest
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, March 29— Harvard University filed crim inal charges today against three former students for ʺtrespassing and disturbing an assembly of people” in connection with the disruption of a pro‐war teach in at the university last Friday night.

headline: Text of the Calley Verdict
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 29—Following is the text of the verdict in the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., read by Col. Clifford H. Ford:

headline: Mylai History: From Rumor to Verdict
lead_paragraph: The story of the military action at the hamlet of Mylai on March 16, 1968, which has stunned the national conscience and outraged world opinion, existed in a twilight zone of rumor and uncertainty for more than a year after it happened.
author: By Robert D. McFadden

headline: ‘Confident’ McGovern Stumps Here
lead_paragraph: Senator George S. McGovern of South Dakota, the only an nounced Democratic candidate for the Presidency, declared here yesterday that he had started his campaign so soon to get “the kind of surging and meaningful dialogue that used to characterize our political campaigns.”

headline: Nixon's Aides Insist Drive In Laos Was Worth Price
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 29— President Nixon has begun to review the post‐mortem studies of the South Vietnamese inva sion of Laos, which cover some serious military misjudgments as well as claims of strategic benefit,
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Judgment at Fort Benning
lead_paragraph: The Government prosecutor in his summary remarks told the six‐officer jury trying First Lieut. William Calley: “You gentlemen are the conscience of the United States Army. You are the conscience of this country, Your duty is clear... to find the accused guilty as charged.”

headline: Reagan Plans Asian Trip
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 29 (UPI)—Gov. Ronald Reagan disclosed today that he intends to pay an official visit to Japan this fall and is thinking about extending the trip to Vietnam.

headline: Calley Family Gathers
lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Fla., March 29 (AP)—Lieutenant Galley's family gathered today at the home of a sister, Mrs. Mary Keesling

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a working newsman, I'm all for freedom of the press. Better yet, press both free and responsible. Criticism, to be sure; but constructive criticism — and rational alternatives. No publication or network, however dominant its position, can long deserve public trust if its bias and prejudice keep showing through.
author: Philip C. Clarke

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It would serve no useful purpose at this late date to revert to the timeworn argument about the justification of our intervention in Vietnam in the first instance. Whether justified or not, events seem to have proved that this war was a tragic mistake. And the issue with which we are squarely confronted today is haw long we are to remain prisoners of this mistake.

headline: Many in U.S. Perturbed By Conviction of Calley
lead_paragraph: The reaction yesterday of public officials and private citizens around the country to the conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. indicated that many Americans were perturbed and for a variety of reasons.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: Excerpts From Brezhnev's Report to the 24th Soviet Communist Party Congress
lead_paragraph: Following, as distributed in English by, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, are excerpts front the report presented to the 24th Soviet Communist party Congress at its opening yesterday in Moscow Leonid I. Brezhnev, General Secretary of the party:

headline: Nixon to Announce New Cut in Troops on April 7
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE Calif., March 30 — President Nixon plans to announce the next round of American troop withdrawals from Indochina in a live television address the evening of April 7.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu Reports a Raid on Base in Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 31 (AP)—President Nguyen Van Thieu announced that South Vietnamese commandos raided a North Vietnamese base area on the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos today‐

headline: MUSKIE REGRETS SILENCE ON WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 30 —Senator Edmund S. Muskie is sorry now that he did not make public as far back as 1965 his “real doubts about our involvement” in the Vietnam war. Instead, he said, he voiced his concerns privately to President Johnson.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Text of Calley Statement
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 30—Following is the text of a statement to the court today by First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.:

headline: U.S. Bombs Guns in DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Wednesday, March 31—Four American warplanes bombed a North Vietnamese artillery site in the northern half of the demilitarized zone yesterday, the United States command reported.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Part of Route 4 seized
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, March 31 (AP)—North Vietnamese troops yesterday reportedly seized a 10‐mile stretch of Route 4, Cambodia's principal road link between the capital and the deepwater port of Kompong Som.

headline: Impact of Calley Trial
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Mar 30—Historically, war crimes trials have been the business of victors. The United. States has broken with the tradition by convicting in midwar one of its own men, First Lieut. William L. Caney Jr., of murder‐. ing Vietnamese civilians, and thus has confronted its footsoldiers and its commanders with a series of legal conflicts. As so often happens, the pinch appears tobe primarily upon the foot soldiers. Lieutenant Calley's conviction demonstrated, if there was any doubt, that the excuse that “I was just following orders” will not work. He contended that he had been ordered to “waste” the villagers at Mylai, but the Uniform Code of Military. Justice says that this is no defense if “a man of ordinary sense and understanding would know [the order] to be illegal.”
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: ANTIWAR TEACH‐IN ON AGAIN AT N.Y.U.
lead_paragraph: With frequent allusions to gloom and frustration and with just as frequent calls for a revivified broad‐based, anti‐Administration effort, the Vietnam antiwar teach‐in returned yesterday to New York University.
author: By Michael T. Kaufman

headline: Saigon G.I.'s Indignant Over Galley Ruling
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 30—The immediate reaction of many G.I.'s here to the conviction yesterday of First Lieut. William Calley Jr. wit indignation.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Calley Pleads for Understanding
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 30—Gasping for breath, First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. made a final plea for understanding today as he faced the military jury that convicted him yesterday of the premeditated murder of at least 22 South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: SENATOR DENIES OIL IS ISSUE IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 30—Senator Philip A. Hart said today that recent articles raising the possibility that oil reserves off the coast of South Vietnam are the “real reason” for American involvement in Southeast Asia were “inaccurate and misleading.”

headline: Army Orders the Seizure of Antiwar Mail Sent to G.I.'s in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 30—A confidential Army directive obtained from Vietnam shows that Army commanders have been ordered to intercept and confiscate personal, first‐class mail containing antiwar or other dissident publications sent to soldiers there.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Humphrey to Decide This Year on '72
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 30—senator Hubert H. Humphrey told a group of college students today that he would reach a decision on whether to run for the Presidency towards the end of the year, after he sees how the other Democratic candidates are faring.

headline: Laotians Reported Checked
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 30, (AP)—A Laotian drive against enemy troops menacing Luang Prabang was reported checked today by North Vietnamese dug in three miles north of the royal capital in northern Laos.

headline: Mother Tells of Warning
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) — The mother of an American prisoner of war in Vietnam said today that an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation warned her to have nothing to do with the pacifist group that relays mail between the prisoners and their families.

headline: Yamashita Precedent
lead_paragraph: Twenty‐five years ago the first American war‐crimes trial resulted in the hanging of Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita. I was one of his defense counsel before the American Military Commission in Manila and before the Supreme Court in Washington.
author: By A. Frank Reel

headline: FULBRICHT PLANS HEARINGS ON WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 30—The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, signaling an end to the truce in the Indochina debate, decided today to push ahead with public hearings on “how to end the war.”
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: 3 Robbed of $100,000 at River House
lead_paragraph: Three armed, well‐dressed robbers stole more than $100,000 in jewelry from Mrs. Arthur Hugh Bunker, sister in‐law of the American Am bassador to South Vietnam, Ellsworth Bunker, and two friends early yesterday morning in the private drive way of River House at 435 East 52d Street.
author: By Martin Gansberg

headline: Drop in U.S. Capability Worries Military
lead_paragraph: Senior Army, Navy and Air Force officers believe that the United States capability to in tervene militarily in support of American and allied interests abroad has been drastically re duced.
author: By Drew Middleton

headline: Saigon Reports 31 of Foe Killed; Arnerical Division Deactivated
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31 (AP)—The South Viet namese military command said today that a Vietcong battalion of about 200 men shelled and assaulted South Vietnamese in fantrymen yesterday near a dis trict town 40 miles northwest of Saigon.

headline: FULBRIGHT SEES CONGRESS VOTING INTERIM AID PLAN
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 — Senator J. W. Fulbright, Chair man of the Foreign Relations Committee, predicted today that Congress would approve an interim solution to keep foreign aid alive, but he indi cated opposition to the formula being devised by the Nixon Administration.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON—On March 30,1967, Presi dent Johnson had all the Democratic state chairmen to the White House for a reception. As each shook the Presi dent's hand, a photograph was taken —to be sent to the chairman as a use ful political memento.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Vietnamese Delay Convoy
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 1 (AP) — A crowd of angry Vietnamese surrounded a United States army convoy and prevented it from leaving the scene of an accident for 1½ hours, Army spokesman reported today. The incident occurred yesterday on Highway 1, 44 miles south of Danang.

headline: Saigon Begins the Release Of 2,938 Enemy P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31—The South Vietnam ese Government today released the first of nearly 3,000 Viet cong prisoners under a recently announced amnesty.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: How Area's Senators Voted Last Week
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31—Fol lowing are the votes of delega tions from New York, New Jer sey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the week ended yester day.

headline: Legal Obstacles Blocking Boston Grand Jury in Its Investigation of the Release of Pentagon Papers
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Oct. 31 — After nearly three months of inves tigation, a Federal grand jury looking Into the unauthorized distribution and publication of the Pentagon papers appears to be far from completing its in quiry.
author: By Robert Reinhold special to The New York Times

headline: CONNALLY HOLDS TALKS WITH THIEU
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam Nov. 1—Secretary of the Treasury, John B. Connally met with Pres ident Nguyen Van Thieu today in talks covering the future of continued American economic aid to South Vietnam and the Senate vote last week to kill the fereign assistance program.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: CONGRESS CHIEFS AGREE FOREIGN AID SHOULD CONTINUE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1— Congressional leaders agreed today that the foreign aid pro gram should have a new lease on life, but there was wide dif ferences about the duration and scope of any extension as well as the shape of any per manent legislation to follow.
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Strength in Vietnam Is Lowest in Six Years
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 (AP)—American troop strength in South Vietnam dropped below 200,000 to day for the first time in near ly six years.

headline: Col. Herbert Denied Leave To Appear on Cavett Show
lead_paragraph: Lieut. Col. Anthony Herbert of Fort McPherson, Ga., has been denied leave to appear on the Dick Cavett television show here tonight on Chan nel 7.

headline: HANOI STILL INSISTS ON OUSTER OF THIEU
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 1 (AP)—North Vietnam made it clear today that the removal of President Nguyen Van Thieu was still an essential part of the seven‐ point Communist peace plan.

headline: Australia Is Said to Plan to Aid In Training Cambodian Troops
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2— Australia has agreed to provide instructors and facilities in South Vietnam for the training of several battalions of Cam bodian troops, informed sources said today.

headline: SENATE PX STUDY FINDS WIDE GUILT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 — A Senate subcommittee, conclud ing a three‐year investigation of financial corruption in the military, filed a stern indict ment today of servicemen, Pen tagon administrators and big business.
author: By Walter Rugaber;Special to The New York Times

headline: HANOI CHARGES U.S. HAS EXTENDED RAIDS
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Wed nesday, Nov. 3 (Agence France Press)—The Foreign Ministry charged today that the United States Air Force had extended its bombings of North Vietnam to include the country's north ern province of Laichau, 160 miles northwest of Hanoi.

headline: Cambodian Siege Broken
lead_paragraph: PRAKHAM, Cambodia, Nov. 2 (Reuters)—A Cambodian arm ored column today broke through to this town 56 miles north of Pnompenh, lifting a weeklong siege by eight North Vietnamese and Vietcong bat talions.

headline: U.S. Navy Jet Reported to Strike Missile Site in North Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov 3 (AP)—An American Navy jet that was bombing the enemy's supply trail in Laos was reported to have darted over neighboring North Vietnam, yesterday to at tack an antiaircraft battery that had fired two missiles at it

headline: NIXON APPROVES HERBERT ADVANCE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 — President Nixon has approved the Army's recommendation for promotion of Lieut. Col. An thony E. Herbert, whom the Army sought to oust after he charged two fellow officers with covering up alleged at trocities committed by Ameri can servicemen in Vietnam.

headline: 291 Reported Killed
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 2 (AP)—The Government today reported 291 North Vietnamese and Vietcong killed in the cam paign at Prakham.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: A. Sock New York, Nov: 1, 1971

headline: 3,000 HONOR DIEM AT SAIGON RITES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 2—In a vast outpouring of nostalgia, 3,000 people, in chiding some prominent politi cal leaders, gathered in the rain today around the un marked grave of Ngo Dinh Diem, and for the first time since he was overthrown as President eight years ago, pub licly sang his official song, “Long Live President Diem,”
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: AID. LISTS WORK PERILED BY SENATE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3—The Agency for International bevelopment sent to Congress today a long list of the programs it said would come to an end if last Friday's Senate action killing the foreign aid authorization bill is allowed to stand.

headline: Pentagon Denies U.S. Raid In North Vietnam Near China
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3—The Pentagon categorically denied today a charge by the North Vietnamese Government that the United States Air Force had extended its bombings to include the northern province of Laichau, 160 miles northwest of Hanoi.

headline: COL HERBERT PUT UNDER NEWS CURB
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Nov. 3—The United States Army instructed Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert today to refrain from speaking with members of the news media without specific permission from his commanding officers.
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: LAIRD, IN VIETNAM, CONFIDENT ON AID
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 3—Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird arrived here tonight and voiced confidence that Congress would restore the foreign aid program because “this is a time to show strength, not weakness.”

headline: Gravel Case Continued
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Nov. 3 (AP)—The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit granted a continuance today in the senatorial privilege case of Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, who is trying to block subpoenas issued to two associates by a Federal grand jury investigating newspaper publication of portions of the Pentagon Papers. A hearing in the case was rescheduled for next Wednesday.

headline: Referendums Fail to Reveal a Pattern
lead_paragraph: There was no discernible national pattern Tuesday in referendums on money and other matters.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: High School Students Hold Rally For War Protest on Saturday
lead_paragraph: Several hundred high school students held a rally on the Central Park Mall in the rain yesterday in preparation for Saturday's March Against the War.

headline: McMahon Says US. Pledges Indian Ocean Force to Counterbalance Soviet
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 —Prime Minister William McMahon of Australia said today that he had been assured by President Nixon and Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird that the United States would provide a “counterbalancing force” to the growing Soviet naval power in the Indian Ocean.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Foreign Relations Group Yields Ellsberg Seminar Paper to F.B.I.
lead_paragraph: The Council on Foreign Relations, a study group of prominent Americans who analyze international issues under strict rules of confidentiality, has responded to a subpoena by turning over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation a seminar paper delivered last year by Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.
author: By Nicholas Gage

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Dennis J. Doolin

headline: Man Who Sheltered Diem Recounts '63 Episode
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 3—“When I got a call from a secretary in the palace saying that President Ngo Dinh Diem wanted to come to my house to hide, I was very surprised,” said Ma Tuyen, a leathery‐faced businessman who was once head of Saigon's large and powerful Chinese community. “One does not expect such visitors.”
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Puts Week's War Toll at 2, Concedes There Might Be More
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 4—The United States command announced today the lowest number of battle deaths for one week for Americans since United States forces started fighting in South Vietnam in 1965.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Attantan's Suit Against Times On War Papers is Dismissed
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Nov. 4 (AP)—A Federal judge has dismissed lawsuit asking $5‐million in actual damages and $1‐billion in punitive damages from The New Times for publishing the Pentagon Papers.

headline: STUDY FINDS MOST LACK TRUST IN U.S.
lead_paragraph: The American people have been losing confidence in the Federal Government over the last six years and now view Washington with more cynicism than ever, a team of University of Michigan social scientists has found after conducting repeated attitude surveys.
author: By Boyce Rensberger

headline: Helping Veterans
lead_paragraph: DeWitt Wallace, co‐chairman of Reader's Digest, says of the United Service Organzations: “As the war in Vietnam winds down, large groups: of our young men are being released from military service in numbers that our economy has been unable to absorb. Thousands of veterans are returning to New York and surrounding communities. This influx poses an urgent challenge and opportunity.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4—It is now just a year before the Presidential election of 1972, and President Nixon finds himself in a very odd situation. The economy is in deep trouble, with both inflation and unemployment running at unacceptable levels. The war is still on in Vietnam, and it is hard to remember a time when the nation's relations with Canada, Japan, Western Europe, Latin America and the underdeveloped countries of Asia and Africa were in such a state of anxiety and mistrust; but in the face of this general slippage, the President's political stock seems to be rising.
author: By James Reston

headline: U.S. Says Hanoi Curtails P.O.W. Letters
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 4—The United States accused North Vietnam today of cutting down vastly on the number of letters it has allowed American prisoners of war to send home.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Goldberg Protests the Surrender of Ellsberg Paper
lead_paragraph: Arthur J. Goldberg said yesterday that he was “shocked and surprised” by the decision of the Council on Foreign Relations, of which he is a member, to turn over to Federal authorities a paper delivered, at a Council seminar last year by Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: Laird Said to Tell Saigon U.S. Is Speeding Pullout
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 5 (AP)—Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has told the South Vietnamese that the United States is speeding troop withdrawals to get thousands of G.I.'s home for Christmas, informed sources reported to. day.

headline: Connally Says He Will Bring No ‘Hard Line’ to Japan Talks
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 5 —United States Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally said here today that he was not going to Japan with either a hard bargaining attitude or a package of proposals to resolve economic problems between the two countries.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: A Voice From Exile
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL—The Vietnam war is more than half way through its seventh year; it is an American institution now, which criminally lays waste to Indochina with an unmatched technological barbarism, smashes and alienates America's young both in uniform and out, and drives several hundred thousand young Americans underground and a hundred thousand more into exile.
author: By Roger Williams

headline: State Department Says New Senate Aid Proposals Would Cripple South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5—The State Department said to ?? that the Senate Foreign ?? dons Committee's new foreign aid proposals could have a crippling effect on South Vietnam's economy and seriously impair Cambodia's ability to defend herself against North Vietnamese forces.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: 17 South Vietnamese Are Killed In an Ambush in Mekong Delta
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 5 (AP)—Heavy South Vietnamese casualties were reported today in an ambush in the Mekong Delta, with 25 per cent of a company of about 100 militiamen said to have been put out of action.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Philadelphia's Mayor‐elect, Frank L. Rizzo, the former Police Commissioner, announced his first cabinet appointment. For Fire Commissioner, he passed over 17 higher‐ranking civil service firemen to appoint a 47‐year‐old battalion fire chief who, has been with the department since 1949. The appointee, whose salary will jump from $15,000 to $27,000 a year is Joseph Rizzo, the Mayor‐elect's younger brother.
author: Albin Krebs

headline: FIGHTING CONTINUES AT CAMBODIAN POST
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6 (AP)—A general lull in combat in South Vietnam was nearly a week long today. But in eastern Cambodia sharp fighting continued around Government garrison besieged by North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops, and the South Vietnamese command announced a new operation just inside Cambodia.
author: SPECIAL TO THE NEW YORK TIMES

headline: Status of The Movement: The ‘Energy Levels’ Are Low
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON.
author: By Joseph Lelyveld

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird stepped off his plane here last Wednesday and fumbled briefly for something to tell the waiting reporters. When he took office, he began, there were 549,500 American troops in Vietnam; today there are fewer than 200,000.
author: — Iver Peterson

headline: SEOUL ANNOUNCES VIETNAM PULL‐OUT
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 6 —President Park Chung Hee announced today that 10,000 South Korean troops would be brought home from South Vietnam, beginning next month. The withdrawal of these troops, is scheduled to be completed by next June, in the first phase of a plan to withdraw all 48,000 South Koreans now stationed in that country.

headline: National Notes
lead_paragraph: When the Knapp Commission adjourned its public hearings into police corruption a week ago, its counsel, Michael Armstrong, said that he fully expected a string of indictments to follow. In two separate actions last week, a Federal grand jury indicted a dozen New York City policemen.

headline: LAIRD CONCLUDES VISIT TO VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6—Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird concluded three days of meetings here today and indicated that the United States, was ready to accelerate the pace of its troop withdrawals.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Miss Margaret Anne Devine Wed
lead_paragraph: Miss Margaret Anne Devine, a financial analyst with Esso International, was married here yesterday afternoon to Robert Emmett Moore, who returned from service as an Army lieutenant in Vietnam in September and is enrolled at the Columbia University Graduate. School of Business.

headline: U.S Cuts Civilian Role, Too, in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6—Along with the American combat role in Vietnam, the United States advisory program, with its separate army of soldiers and civilians, is winding down.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Thousands Join in War Protest
lead_paragraph: Thousands of men, women and children from the metropolitan area joined in a parade here yesterday to protest the war in Vietnam, the wage freeze, racism, what happened at Attica and what was going to happen at Amchitka.
author: By Martin Gansberg

headline: Colonel Herbert:
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA—After two convoluted years, the case of Anthony B. Herbert seemed last week to have reduced itself to a simple question: Is he telling the truth?
author: — James T. Wooten

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: Convicted Dean

headline: HERBERT TO LEAVE ARMY IN 3 MONTHS
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Nov. 7—Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert, a combat hero of two wars who charged two superior officers with covering up atrocities' in Vietnam, announced today that he would retire from the United States Army in February because of “intolerable” pressures on his family.
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: Australian Combat Role Ends in South Vietnam
lead_paragraph: NUIDAT, South Vietnam Nov. 7 (Reuters)—Australia's combat role in the Vietnam war ended today when 1,100 men of the Fourth Battalion withdrew from Nuidat, which has been the main Australian base in Vietnam for five years.

headline: STUDY SHOWS U.S. PRESSES AIR WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 — A comprehensive study of the air war in Indochina by a Cornel University group concludes that while the Nixon Administration drastically curtailed American ground combat, it is maintaining a high level of bombing and, in Cambodia and Laos, has in fact intensified the air war.
author: By Neil Sheehan Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S Planes North of DMZ Attack Antiaircraft Guns
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 7 (AP)—The United States command announced that four American fighter‐bombers today attacked an antiaircraft site near North Vietnam's Donghoi air base, 40 miles north of the demilitarized zone.

headline: 175 Protest at White House Against Indochina Bombing
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8—About 175 antiwar demonstrators lay on the sidewalk outside the White House this afternoon to protest continuing American bombing in Indochina.

headline: United States and World Law
lead_paragraph: The American role as world policeman has been a subject of debate since the large‐scale escalation of the Vietnam war. The issue has been whether it was the responsibility of the United States to oppose aggression everywhere and to take it upon itself to uphold the rule of Jaw in the world. Few challenged the theoretical desirability of upholding international law.

headline: U.S. PLANES RAID THE NORTH AGAIN
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 9 (AP)—American planes staged retaliatory attacks on antiaircraft positions in North Vietnam yesterday for the second successive day, the United States command reported.

headline: Laird, Home, Hopeful on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) —Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird returned today from his three‐day visit to Saigon with an optimistic assessment of the Vietnamization program and a recommendation for President Nixon further withdrawals of soldiers from Vietnam.

headline: U.S. Force in Vietnam Now Down to 191,100
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 8 (AP) — The United States command announced today that American military strength in Vietnam dropped by 5,600 men last week to 191,100. The reduction was the biggest weekly cut in six months.

headline: CHARGE REDUCED IN COLONEL'S CASE
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 8 —The military judge in the court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson dismissed tonight one of two counts of lying under oath to an Army panel investigating an alleged coverup of the slayings of civilians at Mylai, South Vietnam.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: COL. HERBERT GETS A LEAVE OF 30 DAYS
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Nov. 8 (AP)—Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert, who has accused the Army of harassing and “muzzling” him because he charged fellow officers with covering up Vietnam atrocities, was granted a 30‐day leave today as he made plans to apply for retirement.

headline: 105 Antiwar Protesters Seized at White House
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9—The police arrested 105 demonstrators today for blocking a White House driveway in the second day of a protest against continued American bombing in Indochina.

headline: CIVILIAN TESTIFIES IN COLONEL'S CASE
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 9—I A Foreign Service officer who served in Vietnam testified today that, if there had been a massacre of civilians at Mylai 4, he would have “expected” to have been told about it by his sources in the field.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: 6 Killed in Captor Crash
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 10 (AP) — A United States helicopter flying to the aid of besieged South Vietnamese troops crashed today 17 miles east of Saigon, killing five Americans and one South Vietnamese.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: For a few hours yesterday, Senator George McGovern thought that Lieut. Col. Anthony Herbert, the muchdecorated soldier who is retiring from the Army in a dispute with his superiors ever alleged atrocities in Vietnam, was going to join his Presidential campaign staff.
author: Albin Krebs

headline: Chou Bids Japan Accept Peking's Stand on Taiwan
