lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Nov. 9—Premier Chou En‐lai of China has said that the Japanese Government, must show a “clear‐cut attitude” on the future of Taiwan if Tokyo wishes to establish diplomatic relations with Peking.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Senate Begin Debate on First Of 2 ‘Interim’ Foreign Aid Bills
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 — A new round of debate on foreign aid began in the Senate today as the first of two “interim” bills approved by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee last Thursday reached the floor.
author: By Felix Belaib Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: B‐52's Attack Enemy
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Nov. 9 (UPI)—United States B‐52 bombers attacked enemy positions near Quangtri in the northeastern part of South Vietnam today for the first time in more than a year, military, spokesmen reported.

headline: Excerpts From Chou Text
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Nov. 9—Following are excerpts from the official record of an interview given by Premier Chou En‐tai of China to Moto Goto, managing editor of Asahi Shirnbun, in Peking on Oct. 28. The second of two installments of an English translation of the transcript appeared in The Asahi Evening News today.

headline: Saigon Political Figure Is Slain; Mentioned as Possible Premier
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 10 (AP)—A political figure who reportedly was being considered for premier of South Vietnam was assasinated at noon today at an intersection in Saigon.

headline: Last Chance for Peace
lead_paragraph: The extraordinarily optimistic claims for the Vietnamization program made by Secretary of Defense Laird after a combat zone inspection tour have opened the way for a dramatic Presidential announcement next week. Whether soundly based or not, the Laird comments seem designed to provide a rationale permitting President Nixon to step up the present pace of troop reductions in Vietnam. Since even maintenance of the present pace would terminate the American ground presence before the end of next year, Mr. Nixon is in position now, if he is so disposed, to offer the Communists a terminal date for American military withdrawal.

headline: Hanoi Sets Limits for Holiday Parcels to P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: A committee on Vietnam prisoners announced yesterday that the North Vietnamese authorities had agreed to accept one 11‐pound package and one greetini, card for each American prisoner at Christmas.
author: By Sam Pope Brewer

headline: HENDERSON TRIAL HEARS CHAPLAIN
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 10 — An Army chaplain who served with the Americal Division in Vietnam said today that he had received a complaint about “unnecessary shooting” in the hamlet of Mylai 4 and had passed it on to high‐ranking officers.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Retirement Under Pressure
lead_paragraph: Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert, though undaunted by two wars and eight injuries on the battlefield, has surrendered to what he considered intolerable pressure on him and his family by the Army which he has served with distinction for over twenty years. His decision to retire in February was taken despite the fact that he had been officially cleared of a slanderous efficiency report and, more recently, been promoted to his permanent regular rank of major.

headline: U.S. COURT WEIGHS REQUEST BY GRAVEL
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Nov. 10—The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit took under advisement today a request from Senator Mike Gravel that a grand jury investigation into the Pentagon papers be required to provide him with a list of witnesses and questions to be asked of them.

headline: Confirmation by Hanoi
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Nov. 11 (Reuters)—North Vietnam announced today it would allow United States prisoners of war to receive Christmas cards and parcels from their families.

headline: HOUSE BACKS END OF RHODESIA CURB
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10—The House passed a $21.3‐billion military procurement bill tonight after approving a Senate amendment that would permit the importation of Rhodesian chrome in defiance of a United Nations embargo.

headline: American B‐52's Again Strike Foe Besieging Cambodia Town
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Nov. 11 (AP)—United States B‐52 bombers flying from Thailand struck for the second successive day at enemy forces around the besieged Cambodian town of Rumlong, 50 miles northeast of Pnompenh.

headline: The Americal Division Ends Role in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: CHULAI, South Vietnam, Nov. 11 (Reuters)—The 23; 000‐man Americal Division, the largest of the United States Army, ended its fighting role in South Vietnam today in a ceremony here at its home base, 350 miles northeast of Saigon.

headline: $71‐Billion Defense Fund Voted by House Committee
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 —The House Appropriations Cornmittee approved a $71‐billion military budget today after rejecting by a 2‐to‐1 margin an amendment cutting off funds for military operations in Indochina after June 1.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Journalism Unit Honors Times, C.B.S. and Cosmopolitan Editor
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11—The New York Times, the Columbia Broadcasting System and Helen Gurley Brown, edifor of Cosmopolitan magazine, received tonight the 12th annual Distinguished Achievement Awards from the Journalism Alumni Association of the University of Southern California.

headline: Medina Aide Testifies at Mylai Trial of Colonel
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 11 — The former executive officer of the infantry company that swept through the hamlet of Mylai 4 said today that, despite his close relationship with men in the unit, he never heard a word about the killing of unarmed civilians.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 11 — A new American policy has been evident at the Vietnam peace talks since the arrival of William J. Porter two months ago as chief United States negotiator.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Lindsay Impresses Party's Big Contributors During Formal Washington Visit
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11—Mayor Lindsay made his first formal appearance today before an arm of the Democratic National Committee, and many said later that they were impressed.
author: By David K. Simpler Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Alvan L. Barach M.d

headline: SENATE, 65 TO 24, VOTES $1.5‐BILLION FOR MILITARY AID
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11—The Senate approved a $1.5‐billion authorization for foreign military aid today after restoring a $318‐million cut by the Foreign Relations Committee from the Administration's request.
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Week's U.S. Wounded Lowest in 6½ Years
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11 (AP)—The number of Americans wounded in combat last week decreased to 13, a fifth of the number the week before and the lowest total in more than six and a half years, the United States command announced today.

headline: JAILED PUBLISHER RELEASED BY SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11—One of South Vietnam's most widely known political prisoners, Nguyen Lau, a former newspaper publisher, was released from prison tonight after serving two years and seven months.

headline: Nixon Lays a Wreath At Tomb of Unknown
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11—President Nixon today placed a red, white and blue floral wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery.

headline: War Hasn't Changed for the Men Who Stay Behind
lead_paragraph: QUANGNAM PROVINCE, South Vietnam, Nov. 9—Mrs. Billy Roddie of Brady, Tex., thinks her husband, an infantryman, is coming home from Vietnam because his division, the Americal, is leaving. But he is not: he is here, where he has been nearly every day for the last three months, on a combat patrol in the elephant grass 10 miles west of Danang.
author: By Fox Butterfielid Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. GUNSHIPS KILL 8 SAIGON SOLDIERS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 13 (AP)—The United States command said yesterday that American helicopter gunships supporting a South Vietnamese army battalion had accidentally killed Government soldiers and wounded 21.

headline: Soviet Foreign Aid Estimated at $2.2‐Billion a Year
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Nov. 12 — With the American aid program hanging in the balance, Soviet economic and military foreign aid, including that to Cuba and North Vietnam, is now running at about $2.2‐billion a year, with little likelihood of any serious reduction soon, according to Western specialists.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: SIGN TO FOE SEEN
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12—President Nixon announced today that he would withdraw 45,000 more American soldiers from South Vietnam by Feb. 1, retaining a force of 139,000 men to strengthen his hand in seeking a negotiated settlement of the war.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: HERBERT IS ACCUSED OF BEATING CIVILIANS
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX, Arix., Nov. 12 (UPI)—The Arizona Republic, of Phoenix, and The Chicago Sun‐Times printed interviews with Maj. Gen. John Barnes today in which he accused Lieut Col. Anthony Herbert of beating unarmed Vietnamese villagers and conducting himself like “a cold‐blooded killer.”

headline: Saigon Upholds Decision
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 13 (AP)—The South Vietnamese Government said today that President Nixon's decision to cut United States troop strength by 45,000 over the next two months was based on improved security.

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 —For the first time in his long and agonizing program of withdrawal from Vietnam, President Nixon felt free enough from the pressures at home to address his troop‐cut announcement today primarily to the Communist leaders in Hanoi, Moscow and Peking. He wants to make a deal. at least of limited proportions, and he wants to see whether the final acts of disengage ment can buy a bargain.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Veterans View Job Fair With an Air of Cynicism
lead_paragraph: James M. Houston protected Marine truck convoys near South Vietnam's Ashau Valley 18 months ago, while Donato Napoli cruised the Mediterranean on a guidedmissile destroyer and Michael Rivera serviced heavy Army tanks on a hot, dusty Texas proving ground.
author: By Thomas A. Johnson

headline: U.S. Sources in Saigon Say Americans Will Continue to Fight
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 13—Military sources said today that President Nixon's statement that American ground combat offensive operations had ended in Vietnam did not mean that American troops would stop fighting or dying.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Transcript of President Nixon's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Affairs
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12—Following, as made available by the White House, is a transcript of President Nixon's news conference today:

headline: Pullout Plan Stirs Praise And Concern in Congress
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12—President Nixon drew applause from both sides of Capitol Hill today for accelerating troop withdrawals, but Congressional doves expressed concern that the Administration was becoming committed to maintaining a residual force in South Vietnam.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Troop Totals Since '69
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)—Following are statistics tracing increases and decreases in United States military manpower during the Vietnam war:

headline: Hanoi Reported Massing Supplies for Major Drive
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 13—Military sources reported today that the enemy was massing supplies in North Vietnam in preparation for a major push down the Ho Chi Minh Trail network and into Cambodia and Laos.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13—In the last few months, the Administration has been putting the cops on the Washington reporters again, and there is a lot of talk around here, most of it a lath: melodramatic, about some dark Administration plot intimidate its critics in the press and the networks.
author: By James Reston

headline: HANOI DENOUNCES NIXON TROOP PLAN
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 13—North Vietnam today denounced President Nixon's announcement of further American troop withdrawals from South Vietnam.

headline: Near Saigon, Ghostly Legends Grow Around Statue of a Grieving Soldier
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 12—The most haunting war memorial in Vietnam—a 13‐foot statue of a seated soldier grieving for the dead —has become a shrine for many Vietnamese.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Silence is consent; it is not golden in the case of a man who both speaks and acts on behalf of a convicted mass murderer and then neither speaks nor acts on behalf of this country's most decorated veteran of the Korean conflict.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Not long before President Nixon showed up to substitute for the White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, at the 4 o'clock briefing on Friday, United States Park Police hauled away another batch of the antiwar demonstrators who kept flopping on the White House sidewalk all week to play dead—Vietnamese dead.
author: —James M. Naughton

headline: Vietnam Bonus Bill Vetoed
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Nov. 13 (AP)—Gov. Francis W. Sargent has pocketvetoed a hill providing $10‐million more for the states Vietnam bonus program.

headline: Life is Difficult for Ethnic Vietnamese Minority in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 7—Pharr The Dien was arrested five months ago because she did not pay the full tax assessed against ethnic Vietnamese, as foreigners in Cambodia.

headline: Tass Is Critical
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Nov. 13 (AP)—The official press agency Tass said today that President Nixon's announcement that 45,000 more troops would be withdrawn from South Vietnam by Feb. 1 merely confirmed that the United States would continue its “former course” in Vietnam. The agency added that “the speech of Nixon contained no suggestions on a political settlement of the Vietnam conflict.”

headline: National Notes
lead_paragraph: Down on the Farm?

headline: Vietnam Action Light
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Nov. 13 (AP)—Action remained at a low level in South Vietnam today with Saigon headquarters reporting 60 enemy soldiers killed in six small skirmishes across the country. Spokesmen said there were only light Government casualties in one of the engagements.

headline: Et Al.
lead_paragraph: A timely study of Congress's and the President's decisionmaking powers in the area of foreign policy. Mr. Wilcox has worked for State and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, sees post‐World War II trust between the two departments as having declined during the L.B.J. Administration. The cause was a crisis of confidence over the Dominican Republic intervention and, of course, because of doubts over Vietnam. He thinks there should be more consultation and interchange of information, but points out that situations differ: that in the Cubancrisis Congressional debate might have led to war, while in the Dominican intervention it might have led to a less precipitous policy. There is much good sense here, although the lack of historical perspective curtails the scope of the book.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: THIEU, IN ADDRESS TO NATION, ORDERS ECONOMIC REFORM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 15 — President Nguyen Van Thieu today outlined his Government's long awaited economic reform program, which will include devaluation of the piaster and a modernization of the country's fiscal and commercial system.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: London: A Dance Haven at The Place
lead_paragraph: Arts Abroad
author: By Bernard Weinraub Special to The New York Times

headline: B‐52'S RAID IN LAOS, CAMBODIA, VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 14 (Reuters)—United States B‐52 bombers struck suspected enemy troop concentrations in Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam today. A United States spokesman said that no assessment report of the damage was immediately available.

headline: In U.S. 5 Years, Lonely Vietnamese General Awaits Call Home
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 —In South Vietnam he lived in an elegant French colonial villa, commanded thousands of troops and administered the five northern provinces as a personal fief.

headline: Now, if Muskie Were a '72 Candidate...
lead_paragraph: Senator Edmund S. Muskie, who said that he was not a candidate for President but told what he would do if he were, came to New York yesterday to talk about making government work better and wound up discussing Vietnam, Social Security, politics, Ireland and Mayor Lindsay.
author: By Martin Gansberg

headline: Laird Says South Vietnam Can Handle Any Attack
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) —Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today he would do “whatever is needed and necessary” to protect diminished United States forces in South Vietnam in case of another enemy offensive. But he said he believed the South Vietnamese could handle any such assault.

headline: Article 1 — No Title
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) —The Pentagon today acknowledged existence of the Rand Corporation report, but said that there was only one copy and that it was at United States headquarters in Saigon. A spokesman said the report's author had not been commissioned by the Defense Department but acted on his own in preparing the study. Officials refused to comment further.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: President Nixon is looking strong Politically these days, with Phase Two of his new economic policy in effect and with a faster rate of withdrawal from Vietnam winning headlines. That seems to put him on top of two of the three big issues—Mr. Nixon's personality is the other—with which the Democrats might defeat him next year.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Saigon Asking Support for Reforms
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 15—The South Vietnamese Government began an intense effort this evening to enlist public support and to offset the expected public outcry against a rise in prices expected as a result of economic reforms announced early today.
author: By Iver Peterson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Rand Chief Quitting
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Nov. 15— Henry S. Rowen resigned as president of the Rand Corporation today, and well ‐ informed sources, said his departure had been caused partly by Pentagon dissatisfaction with Rand's role in the release of the Pentagon papers.
author: By Steven V. Roberts; Special to The New York Times

headline: Big U.S. Troop Cuts Seen In Vietnam by End of June
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 — Nixon Administration sources said today that Gen. Creighton W. Abrams had been directed to plan on a tentative force reduction of 130,000 to 155,000 men in Vietnam by next June 30. That would mean that the American force would be down to 30,000 to 55,000 men by midsummer.
author: By William Beecher; Special to The New York Times

headline: More Americans Withdrawn
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 15 (UPI) —The United States command announced today that 2,800 more Americans were withdrawn from South Vietnam last week, reducing the authorized troop strength to 188,300 as of last Thursday. This is the lowest level since December, 1965, when there were 184,300 United States servicemen in the country.

headline: Text of Policy Statement by Chinese Delegate Before General Assembly of U.N.
Oslo Plans Ties With Hanoi
lead_paragraph: OSLO, Norway, Nov. 15 (UPI) —The Norwegian Storting (Parliament) approved a Government proposal today to establish diplomatic relations with North Vietnam. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said Norway would contact the North Vietnamese authorities for formal recognition and establishment of diplomatic relations.

headline: J. F. Kennedy's Use of Force
lead_paragraph: Letters to the Editor
author: John Tower; United States Senator from Texas Washington, Nov. 9, 1971

headline: Medina Says He Lied to Colonel About Mylai Toll
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 15 — Former Capt. Ernest L. Medina, the commander of the American troops that killed South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai 4 in 1968, admitted today that he had lied to Col. Oran K. Henderson about the number of villagers killed in the combat assault. Mr. Medina, who resigned from the Army last month, three weeks after his acquittal on charges of murder and manslaughter arising from the Mylai incident, also testified that he had “not been completely candid” in previous statements made under oath to Army investigators. In a quiet voice, Mr. Medina agreed with Maj. Carroll J. Tichenor, the military prosecutor, that, because of his falsehoods, he had “completely disgraced and dishonored the uniform he once wore. Mr. Medina, who is now a helicopter company executive in Menominee, Mich., appeared as a defense witness at Colonel Henderson's court‐martial. The colonel is being tried on charges that he covered up reports of the Mylai incident and that he later lied in an appearance before an Army board of inquiry.
author: By Douglas Robinson; Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. IS SAID TO QUASH STUDY ON VIETCONG
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, West Germany, Nov. 15 (AP)—The news magazine Der Spiegel says the Pentagon has suppressed a study by the Rand Corporation that concluded that high ideological motivation was behind Vietcong battlefield successes.

headline: 2 COPTERS COLLIDE, KILLING 4 AMERICANS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 16 (AP)—The United States command reported yesterday that two American helicopters had collided about 70 miles northwest of here, killing the four crewmen aboard one and injuring the four on the other.

headline: Antiaircraft Battery in the North Is Attacked by U.S. Jet Fighter
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 17 (AP)—An American fighter‐bomber attacked an antiaircraft battery yesterday 70 miles inside North Vietnam and reported that it had damaged at least one enemy gun, the United States command announced.

headline: Laos Posts Reported Lost
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 16 (Reuters)—A Defense Ministry spokesman said today that North Vietnamese troops had forced Laotian soldiers to abandon two positions near the southern town of Muong Phalane just west of the Ho Chi Minh Trail. Muong Phalane is on Route 9 due west of the northernmost part of South Vietnam.

headline: 61 Foes of Indochina War Arrested at White House
lead_paragraph: Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Said to Join Attack
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 16 (AP)—American helicopter gunships from South Vietnam reportedly attacked North Vietnamese positions less than 10 miles southwest of here today in an attempt to dislodge the enemy from an outpost village.

headline: Chaplain Testifies That He Dismissed Reports on Mylai
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 16 —An Army chaplain testified today at the court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson that he had received complaints from another chaplain about indiscriminate shooting at Mylai 4, but had dismissed them as the words of a man “who was always crying wolf.”
author: By Douglas Robinson; Special to The New York Times

headline: South Vietnamese Wounded Jam Military Hospitals
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 16—In the largest South Vietnamese military hospital, which is considered the best, there are 1,800 beds for nearly 4,000 patients, so some men must sleep on verandas and others on the floor. The continuing casualties among South Vietnamese troops are the reason for the overcrowding at Cong Hoa Hospital, which is in a Saigon suburb.
author: By Gloria Emerson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Mr. Nixon's Vietnam Strategy
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's developing Vietnam strategy increases the risk of indefinite American involvement an unending Indochina war. While the President added nothing fundamentally to the old policy mix by his announcement of a withdrawal target of 45,000 troops over the next two months, his press conference remarks last week tended to confirm earlier fears about where he is heading.

headline: Saigon's Food Prices Rise 50% After Devaluation
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 16— The talk on Saigon's streets and in its markets today was of the city's sharply rising prices and the Government's sharp devaluation of the piaster, which has caused a jump of nearly 50 per cent in the price of some foods.
author: By Iver Peterson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Vigil for the Dead of Vietnam
author: Ann Morrissett Davidon; Haverford Pa., Nov. 4, 1971

headline: Out of the Swamp?
lead_paragraph: LONDON—The probability is that real peace negotiations and direct secret contacts between the United States and Communist sides in the Vietnam war will start some time this winter. Such is the clear inference to be drawn from President Nixon's outline of the American position last Friday.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: NIXON WILL IGNORE CALL BY CONGRESS FOR VIETNAM CUTS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17— President Nixon, in a rebuke to Congressional doves, an nounced today that he would disregard an amendment set ting forth the policy that United States troops should be with drawn promptly from Indo china, subject only to the re lease of American prisoners of war.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: 16 Seized in Capital Protest
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17—The police arrested 16 antiwar dem onstrators today for blocking a White House driveway in a continuing protest against American bombing in Indo china. The demonstrators had a permit to lie on the sidewalk outside the White House. While more than 10 demonstrators lay on the sidewalk, 16 others moved to the driveway and were arrested, Bail was set at $50.

headline: U.S. Jets Attack in the North For the 77th Time This Year
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 18 (AP)—Four American supersonic fighter bombers destroyed one antiair craft artillery gun and damaged another yesterday in the 77th raid inside North Vietnam this year, the United States com mand said today.

headline: Ford Seeking Vietnam Deal
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Nov. 17 (UPI)— The Ford Motor Company con firmed today that it had sub mitted a proposal to the South Vietnamese Government that would, if approved, make Ford the first major automobile com pany to establish assembly op erations in that country.

headline: U.S. Rebuffed on Secrecy In Pentagon Papers Inquiry
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 (AP) —A Federal judge ruled today that Anthony Russo, who re fused to testify in secret be fore a grand jury in the Penta gon Papers case, did not have to testify unless the Govern ment agreed to furnish him a transcript of his testimony.

headline: The Institution of Lying
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—President Johnson's memoirs contain extensive information drawn from classified documents—in cluding some of those contained in the Pentagon Papers.
author: By David Wise

headline: 15 Vietnamese Senators Assail Thieu Economic Plan
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Nov. 18 (UPI)—A group of op position Senators attacked President Nguyen Van Thieu's new economic plan today and said the South Vietnamese econ omy was collapsing.

headline: U.S. Increasing Air Support of Cambodian Forces
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 18 (AP)—Official Ameri can sources reported today that with the military situation in Cambodia becoming critical, United States warplanes have stepped up their support of Cambodian soldiers.

headline: Paris Peace Talks, Still at an Impasse, Are Briefest So Far
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 18—William J. Porter, the chief American ne gotiator at the Vietnam peace talks, maintained his tough of fensive of the last few weeks by saying almost nothing today.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Dr. Margaret Mead, the an thropologist, was chosen in Paris as this year's winner of the Kalinga Prize, awarded by UNESCO for particular merit in the popularization of science. The prize, which carries a stipend of $2,400, is named for an ancient In dian empire renowned for its peaceful policies more than 2,000 years ago. Previous recipients include Sir Julian Huxley, the biologist; Konrad Lorenz, the zoologist, and Bertrand Russell, the philos opher.

headline: Nixon vs. Congress on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: President Nixon has set himself against a majority Congress and the nation with his curt rejection of Congressional declaration that it is “the policy of the United States” to withdraw all of its military forces from Indochina “at the earliest practicable date … subject to the release of all American prisoners of war.”

headline: DEFENSE BUDGET CUT $33‐BILLION BY SENATE GROUP
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 — The Senate Appropriations Committee cut $3.3‐billion from the defense budget today but refused to impose mandatory Vietnam troop withdrawals upon the Administration.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Officers Testify Agents Didn't Tell Of Mylai 4 Killings
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 18 —Two intelligence officers who served in the Americal Division testified today that their South Vietnamese agents and inform ants had never made any men tion of civilians killed by Amer ican soldiers at Mylai 4.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: The Screen:Documentary on Cuba Is at New Yorker
lead_paragraph: Felix Greene, the British cameraman-journalist-author, who gave us feature-length color close-ups of "China!" in 1965 and "North Vietnam" two years later, continues his role as a movie Marco Polo for the embattled Left in "Cuba Va!", his latest color documentary on a nation largely concealed by a "curtain." As in the previous cases, he illustrates a contented people, who admittedly haven't yet achieved their revolutionary goals but are, as the title translates, moving forward.Using some old black-and-white footage to stress the enrichment of the few wealthy, both local and foreign, and the deprivation of the masses of the poor and ignorant Latin Americans, Greene, who shot his color film over the last year or so, makes visual comparisons in generally calm and effective style.With Premier Fidel Castro appearing on a few occasions to explain that Cuban freedom could be achieved only by revolution after 400 years of foreign domination, the film's natural bias is apparent but not overpowering. It opened yesterday at the Bleecker Street Cinema.The "85 per cent" illiteracy that existed 12 years ago when Castro ousted the former dictator, Fulgencio Batista, is given cheerful counterpoint by happy youngsters and adults receiving free education and instruction in trades in various immaculate up-to-date urban and rural schools. The admitted fact that did not meet its 10-million-ton sugar cane goal last year is offset by various scenes showing the harvesting of eight and a half million tons, a record crop.A viewer is fascinated by workers from other areas chipping to voluntarily to help with the cane, tobacco and other harvests; by a fine teachers college, medical school with many distaff students, and an especially modern psychiatric hospital near Havana; by an orchestra devoted to Western classics that is viewed, somewhat less favorably, than an excellent modern dance team working with native rhythms as another sign of Cuba's socialistic approach to the arts.One is impressed by younger composer-guitarists such as Silvio Rodriguez, Noel Nicola and Pablo Milanes, whose fine voices extol their brave new world. And one assumes that Mr. Greene knows what he is talking about in noting that "the cinemas are filled and a nightclub has to be booked weeks in advance."One also get glimpses of modern highways being built and slums being razed and a climactic scene showing Cubans reacting forcefully in Havana demonstrations when their captive fishermen were freed by Americans last year. The over-all impression sought by Mr. Greene is a bright present and a brighter future. But despite his largely happy vistas, his "Cuba Va!" leaves a nagging feeling that it is only a partial view of current history that still desperately needs fuller explanations.Also on the bill is "Reggae," a 60-minute documentary on Jamaican music filmed at a concert in London last year and intercut with observations on its origins and purposes. As an outgrowth of traditional African, calypso, rock, soul and blues, its beat is infectious.And, even though Mike Raven, a British disk jockey, explains that "Reggae" was the name of the first record label to feature that genre and that it is also a form of protest, it is basically an item for the buffs, who should appreciate it most.
author: By Howard Thompson

headline: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19— As Senator James L. Buckley was announcing last Tuesday that Secretary George W. Romney had promised to re view plans for a controversial low‐income housing project in Forest Hills, Queens, he appeared to be startled when asked if he had carried that area in last year's elec tion. The Con servative‐Re publican said with a smile that he really did not know how well he had run in the Forest Hills area and maybe that illustrated his political innocence.
author: By Richard L. Madden Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Given the justifiable and under standable concern of the American people for a greater allocation of our national resources to domestic and welfare needs—and given the public repugnance to the Vietnam involve ment and the unfair spinoff of back lash against the military—there is a desperate need for a wider public un derstanding not only that the balance of military power is shifting against the United States, not only that it is the first duty of the national Govern ment, to “provide for the common de fense” of our country, but as well that our domestic and welfare priorities mean nothing if we grow so militarily inferior that the enemy takes over.

headline: U. S. Catholic Bishops Call For End to Indochina War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19— The American Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church ap proved today a resolution call‐I, ing for an end to the Indochina war “with no further delay.”
author: By Eleanor Blau Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON ANNOUNCES STRICT PRICE CURBS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 (AP) — The Govern ment announced today that it was imposing price controls to curb rises that followed deval uation of the piaster.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Times’ recent field coverage from South Vietnam has persistently omitted reference to the highly suc cessful land reform program, even though you editorially referred to it upon passage in 1970 as “probably the most imaginative and progressive non Communist land reform of the twenti eth century” (April 9, 1970). Recent stories have cryptically referred to “rural prosperity” (e.g., Sept. 5) with out further elaboration.

headline: Moorer Sees No Threat
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 — Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chair man of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that North Vietnamese forces posed no immediate threat to Cambodia despite reports from Saigon that enemy forces have cut the major supply route between Pnonmenh and a 20,000‐man task force on the northeastern front.

headline: Saigon Says Cambodians Seek Artillery
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 (AP) — Government officials said today that high Cambodian officers had flown to Saigon to ask for South Vietnamese engineers and artillery to help relieve enemy pressure on a Cambodian task force cut off northeast of Pnompenh.

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19—De pending on one's perspective in the foreign‐policy debate, Con gress is impotently marching up the hill and clown again or is gradually encircling a once powerful Presidency.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Premier Due in China
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Nov. 19 (Agence Prance‐Presse)—Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam will arrive here tomorrow on an official visit at the invita tion of the Chinese Govern ment and the Central Commit tee of the Comthunist party.

headline: The Bus Is Coming' Is Engrossing
lead_paragraph: If you yearn for just one drama of small-town racial tensions that is strong, probing and impressively balanced, then see "The Bus Is Coming." It has no cast "names" and those lurid ads are as misleading as the title, since a school integration issue is handled only marginally. But this first, inexpensive project of a new black film unit called K-Calb, based on the West Coast commands nothing but admiration.With taut economy, tingling crescendo and a superb rounding out of characterizations, the picture closes in on a young black veteran of Vietnam, caught between equally explosive whites and blacks as he investigates his brother's murder. See this engrossing film, which has a cast headed by Mike Simms and Burl Bullock, excellent color photography by Mike Rhodes and keen direction by Wendell James Franklin. The catch is one puzzling bit of action at the finale.As for Horace Jackson, the scenarist-producer, he is an important man. K-Calb is off to a beautiful start.
author: HOWARD THOMPSON

headline: SAIGON PREPARES CAMBODIA DRIVE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON; South Vietnam, Nov. 20—South Vietnamese military, sources reported today that a 10;000‐man force was poised at the Cainbotlian border for a new attack on Communist base areas northeast ‘Of Pnompenh which has been under increased pressure from the enemy for nearly two weeks.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Defoliant Leaving Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 20, (Rueters)—More than a million gallons of herbicide Orange, a defoliant once sprayed over jungles in Vietnam, will be taken back to the United States for destruction, an American military spokes man said today.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The message from Congress was clear: Bring the troops home. But the White House did not seem to be listening.

headline: Young Democrats to Back Drive for Vietnam Pull‐out
lead_paragraph: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Nov. 20 (AP)—Delegates to the Nation al Young Democrats’ conven tion here pledged tonight to support only those Presidential candidates who were commit ted to immediate and complete withdrawal of American forces from Southeast Asia.

headline: 500,000 in Peking Greet North Vietnam's Premier
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Nov. 2 (Reuters)—A top‐level North Vietnamese dele gation, headed by Premier Pham Van Dong, arrived in Peking to day to a tumultuous welcome by more than 500,000 people.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The Vietnam war and the turmoil in domestic, politics that followed have profoundly changed the Democratic party, producing in most of its leaders less rigid attitudes toward foreign policy, a stronger com mitment to the rights of racial and political minorities and greater interest in the views of women and the young.

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: On March 13, 1959, Jean Olivier, a Frenchman convicted of murdering two, children after raping one of them, was executed by guillotine. He was the last Frenchman to suffer such a fate. Then‐President de Gaulle had refused to commute his sentence, a selective practice that the general followed. He commuted most of the average dozen death penalties imposed in France an nually but during his tenure there was Usually at least one guillotining a year.

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Nov. 20 (Agence France‐Presse) — Premier Pham Van Dong, evidently seeking to dispel suggestions that Hanoi and Peking are in disagreement over President Nixon's proposed visit to China, tonight lauded the “devoted and powerful sup port” of China for North Viet nam. He spoke at a dinner.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: The prospect in Vietnam for the rest of this year and well into 1972 is American withdrawal through air power. Last week — as if to punctu ate President Nixon's warning 10 days ago that “air strikes on the infiltra tion routes” would continue “in sup port of the South Vietnamese until there is a negotiated settlement”— American pilots clambered aboard heli copter gunships, fighter‐bombers’ and B‐52's and strafed and bombed Com munist targets in South and North Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.

headline: Vietnam Vets Bring New Characters to Cast of Addicts: Bemedaled Junkies
lead_paragraph: Those Vietnam veterans who return to the city's streets with a craving for drugs have nurtured it on opiates so pure they were to the usual junkie's fare what a magnum of champagne is to a pint of Thunderbird. Ba sically two kinds of stories are told about what happens to them in their new jungle set ting. In the first story, the veteran is cast as a green horn. “They don't have the animalistic qualities required to survive out there,” said an ex‐addict now working at a treatment cen ter. “They haven't been to jail. They haven't lived in cellars. They're not what you'd call real thieves.”
author: By Joseph Lelyveld

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: One cannot help but be taken aback by Senator Henry Jackson's recent con tentions that a third (or rather fourth) party would not hurt the Democrats in 1972 and that those who would be in clined to join such a movement might just as well get out of the party now.

headline: Bombing Raid Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 22 (AP) — The United States Command to day announced one of the deepest bombing raids this year inside North Vietnam, against an antiaircraft‐gun emplace ment near Vinh.

headline: North Vietnam Premier Hails China's Nuclear Gains
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Nov. 21—China's nuclear arsenal was brought up for special mention by Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam in a speech in Peking yesterday.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: Enemy Losses Put at 36
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 23 (AP)—By nightfall of the first day of the new drive into Cambodia, South Vietnamese field commanders reported that 36 North Vietnamese soldiers had been killed in small scattered clashes north of Route 7, about 90 miles northwest of Saigon. No South Vietnamese casualties were reported.

headline: General Says He Knew of No Atrocities When He Told Henderson to Act on Mylai
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 22 —A retired officer who had been censured by the Army for his role in the Mylai 4 incident said today that he had no knowledge of atrocities carried out by American troops when he ordered Col. Oran K. Henderson to investigate the attack.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Troop Tour No 21 for Hope
lead_paragraph: Bob Hope will make his 21st holiday trip to American servicemen around the world at Christmas time. He will visit Hawaii, Okinawa, South Vietnam, Italy, Spain and Guantanamo, Cuba. The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that filmed highlights of the tour would be shown on Jan. 17.

headline: SAIGON FORCE PUT AT 5,000 IN DRIVE
lead_paragraph: TAYNINH, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 23 — Military sources reported yesterday that at least 5,000 troops are involved in new South Vietnamese drive into eastern Cambodia.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Freed in Saigon Amnesty Are Home but Uneasy
lead_paragraph: HOALOI, South Vietnam, Nov. 11—Two of the many men missing from this village have come home, but neither dares believe that he will be left alone to lead the quiet life he wants.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: B'NAI B'RITH SEES EXTREMISM PERIL
lead_paragraph: GROSSINGERS, N.Y., Nov. 22—Opposition to Israel and to the United States support for the Jewish state is replacing Vietnam as a key issue of left and right‐wing extremists, according to an analysis by the Anti‐Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.
author: By Irving Spiegel Special to The New York Times

headline: Colonel Denies He Knew of ‘Excessive’ Mylai Killing
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 23 —Col. Oran K. Henderson took the witness stand in his own defense today and told a military jury that at no time in his inquiry into the Mylai 4 assault had he known that there had been “excessive killing” of civilians by American troops.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Millionaires: A Handful, but They Are Powerful
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 23 — They make barbed wire and wash G.1. fatigues. They raise fighting cocks and sit on tiger‐skin rugs. They own banks and hold high Government office. They are South Vietnam's most powerful and persuasive minority — its two dozen or so millionaires.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Plans Troop Airlift To Chup Plantation Today
lead_paragraph: KREK, Cambodia, Nov. 23—South Vietnamese field commanders said today that several thousand paratroops would be lifted by helicopter tomorrow from this advance headquarters to attack longestablished North Vietnamese troop concentrations and supply depots in the Chup rubber plantation.

headline: EUROPE TROOP CUT BARRED BY SEN ATE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23—The Senate deferred to Presi dent Nixon today by rejecting a proposal for a 60,000‐man reduction in the American forces in Western Europe.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: The word began to spread among his Washington supporters that Senator Edmund S. Muskie was tiring of snacks of milk and cookies While flying around the country on his undeclared campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination. So a group of women in the suburbs of Washington started “Mondays for Muskie,” on which they prepare the goodies the Maine Senator prefers: Swedish cardamon cakes, apricot balls, smoked nuts, chocolate cakes and Chinese egg rolls. In the switch from stuffing envelopes to stuffing the candidate, the women also make quiche Lorraine and chopped chicken livers, and freeze it until needed. If any other candidate has such support, he hasn't announced it.

headline: North Vietnamese Are Received by Mao
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Nov. 23 (Reuters)—Mao Tse‐tung made another public appearance last night, receiving Pham Van Dong, the Premier of North Vietnam, and other visiting North Vietnamese officials.

headline: 60 Vietnam Veterans Begin OTB Jobs Today
lead_paragraph: More than 100 Vietnam veterans have finished or are about to finish basic training with the Offtrack Betting Corporation for jobs as ticket‐sellers, cashiers and administrative assistants.

headline: Pressure Reported Relieved
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 23 (AP)—Cambodian military sources reported today that the drive the South Vietnamese began into Cambodia yesterday had already relieved some of the enemy pressure on the front northeast of Pnompenh.

headline: NEW SAIGON UNITS IN CAMBODIA PUSH
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 25 — More South Vietnamese troops moved unopposed yesterday into the Communist base areas in eastern Cambodia that they had occupied before the beginning of the rainy season last May.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Prosecutor Calls Henderson Inconsistent
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 24 —The military prosecutor at the court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson hammered at the defendant today in an effort, to show that the former brigade commander must have known that many civilians had been killed at Mylai 4.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Suit Asks Nixon to Set Date For Withdrawal in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Nov. 24 (AP) —A Vietnam veterans group and eight individuals filed suit here today in United States District Court to force President Nixon to set a final troop withdrawal date in Indochina.

headline: Court of Appeals Vacates an Order In Ellsberg Case
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Nov. 24 — A contempt order against Mrs. IdeIla Marx, mother‐in‐law of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, was vacated today by the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.
author: By Robert Reinhold Special to The New York Times

headline: Drive to Aid War Orphans Opened Here
lead_paragraph: Eli Cohen of Quakerstown, Pa., is “just about” 8 years old and almost always articulate. Occasionally, he lapses.
author: By Enid Nemy

headline: Army to Punish 5 Officers In Attack on Vietnam Base
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27—The Army has told five highranking officers, including a two‐star general, that it plans to demote or reprimand them as a result of an enemy attack on a fire base in South Vietnam last March that resulted in 33 deaths and 76 injuries.

headline: Politics and Scholarship
lead_paragraph: In 1839 Lord Macaulay reviewed Gladstone's “The State in Its Relations With the Church.” In that book, Gladstone, then still a Tory, contended that Government should propagate religious truth. Macaulay's review argued for the liberal position that Government ought to be neutral on religious questions because it was illsuited to decide them. Churches and other institutions could much better promote society's spiritual interests, and Government would do well to respect that division of labor.

headline: CAMBODIA ACTION IS LIGHT THUS FAR
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 25 (AP) — Thousands of South Vietnamese troops maneuvered in eastern Cambodia without opposition today, with action in their four‐day drive limited to strikes by B‐52's and a few small raids by reconnaissance elements of company strength.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving at the Western White House in. San Clemente, Calif., started early, and in the President's office. At 6:45 A.M. Mr. ‘Nixon was telephoning greetings of the day to Cabinet members, Congressional leaders and Governors Reagan of California and Rockefeller of New York. Later, he sat before, two’ television.sets to watch’.the Nebraska‐Oklahome and’ Dallas CowboysLos Angeles Rams; football games. For dinner, at 6 P.M., there was turlxey sweet potatoes with marshmallows, green beans amandine and pumpkin pie. At the table were the President, Mrs. Nixon, Rose Mary Woods, the President's personal secretary, and Dr. Walter Tkach, his physician.Luigi Longo, the ailing, 71‐year‐old leader of the Italian Communist party, went to the hill town of Genzano—known as Little Stalingrad because of Communist strength and militancy there —to marry his long‐time companion, Brune Conti. The marriage at Town Hall came just a year after Italy's divorce law went into effect. Mr. Longo was recently divorced from former Senator Teresa Noce, with whom he had not lived since 1948.

headline: G.I.'s Feel It's Their Last Thanksgiving in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 25—American servicemen in South Vietnam celebrated Thanksgiving quietly today, with 241,000 pounds of turkey, 4,500 cans of cranberry sauce and the feeling that this would be their last Thanksgiving in Vietnam.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: CASTRO FORESEES AMITY WITH U.S.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CRUZ, Chile, Nov. 25 —Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba predicted today an era of “true friendship” between the United States and Latin America, but not while President Nixon is in the White House.
author: By Juan de Onis Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I.'s Leave as Saigon's Problems Grow
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 23—In the past few weeks cargo ships loaded with American jeeps, trucks, air‐conditioners, plumbing equipment and bulldozers have sailed for home. Several thousand happy. G.I.'s have passed the heroin tests and flown hack to the world.”
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘The Majority of Americans Are Isolationists’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Few, if any, I believe, of our people are isolationists as some of the so‐called interventionists or internationalists would like to portray them. Practically all of our people recognize that we cannot ignore the rest of the world, that we cannot stop trading with other nations, that we cannot stop negotiations looking toward the reduction of our military forces and the diminution of the threat of a world conflict. Basically, I would say that the majority of the people of America are isolationists in that they believe it is time to judge every proposal and every program in terms of whether, in the broadest sense, it is in the best interest of our country and not whether it is in the best interest of Egypt or Israel or the political rulers of South Vietnam or Cambodia or Laos or, for that matter, in the best interest of England or France or Germany.
author: By Burton K. Wheeler

headline: 13 Units of 3,233 G.I.'s Pulled Out of Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 26 (AP)—'the United States command announced today the cutback of 13 more Army units with a total strength of 3,233 soldiers in a continued speed‐up of pre Christmas withdrawals from Vietnam.

headline: Enemy Said to Be Building Up Supplies
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 26 (AP) —South Vietnamese forces continued to look for en emy bases in eastern Cambodia today amid reports ot.:a big North Vietnamese supply, build up on the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos.

headline: Charges Against a Rabbi Dismissed by Judge Here
lead_paragraph: Charges against a rabbi and a graduate student, who were arrested last year for allegedly disrupting services at Temple Emanu‐el have been dismissed in Criminal Court.

headline: War Critics Conduct Fast
lead_paragraph: PLYMOUTH, Mass., Nov. 26 (AP)—A group called the Viet nam Veterans Against the War collected $200 for a South Vietnamese children's hospital Thanksgiving Day in an all day fast capped by a 10‐minute service at Plymouth Rock.

headline: Hanoi Joins With Peking In Hard Line
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Nov. 26—China and North Vietnam re stated today a tough, no‐coin promise line on the Indochina war in a joint communiqué marking the end of a goodwill visit to Peking by Premier Pham Van Dong of North Viet nam.

headline: ‘WITNESS’ FOR PEACE TO BEGIN TOMORROW
lead_paragraph: A nationwide interreligious “movement of witness concern ing the moral issues in the In dochina war” will be started tomorrow with prayers for peace and justice in front of the White House and in churches across the country.

headline: In Vietnam, the Children Paint Images of War and Peace and Love.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—“Whatever you want to paint, paint,” a middle‐aged teacher told the 400 eager young Vietnamese children. They scurried about, dipping little plastic cups and metal trays into a bucket of water in preparation for a two‐hour competition, Vietnam's fourth annual children's drawing contest.

headline: SAIGON OFFENSIVE IN CAMBODIA LAGS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 27 (AP)—A South Viet namese general said today he did not expect to find sizable enemy forces in eastern Cam bodia, raising doubts about the nature of a 25,000‐Man Vietna mese operation there.

headline: THE ALGERIAN WAR STILL STIRS FRENCH
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 27—Algeria was France's Vietnam, and nine years after the end of the war there, the divisions and moral crises it created are still in evi dence.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters
lead_paragraph: To THE EDITOR:
author: Richard A. Falk, Center of International Studies, Princeton University. Princeton, N. J

headline: THIEU OPPOSITION LYING LOW NOW
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 27 — Le Van Thai, an Important political adviser of the former Vice President, Ngu yen Cao Ky, seldom dares to go home these days. For near ly two months, he has been closeted with his leader in an enclave of Saigon's Tansonnhut Air Base and when he wants to visit his wife and daughter he has to get in a taxi and sneak home on back streets to avoid police surveillance.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Attempt Is Thwarted
lead_paragraph: WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., Nov. 27 (AP)—A 23‐year‐old man attempted to board an Eastern Airlines plane today with the intention of hijacking it to Vietnam, the state police said.

headline: United States‐Vietnam Relations, 1945–4967
lead_paragraph: Historians of modern international relations frequently must rely on documents which, although authentic, were selected and released as political weapons. The Bolsheviks after the Revolution pf 1917 published secret treaties and correspondence from the Czarist archives to discredit the war aims of the ‐Allies. The Germans in 1920 compiled 40 volumes of documents on European diplomacy 1871–1914 as a defense against the charge that Germany was guilty of starting the war.
author: By Gaddis Smith

headline: President, Alter 3 Years, Is Still Balked by Congress
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27— President Nixon and Congress are approaching the end of the third year of their troubled and occasionally turbulent relation ship in much the same way they began it—with the President in command of foreign policy, the field that most engages his energies, but frustrated and on the defensive in domestic mat ters.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: A TOWN IN U MINH BACK IN BUSINESS
lead_paragraph: DONGHUNG, South Vietnam, Nov. 19—Until a few months ago Donghung was a ghost town, its substantial houses burned down by the Vietcong in 1965 and its rich rice fields abandoned.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Navy's ‘Seals,’ Super‐Secret Commandos, Are Quitting Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 28—The last members of a special group of United States Navy commandos, whose intel ligence operations in the Me kong Delta have included kid nappings of suspected Vietcong agents and many unreported clashes with guerrillas, are be ing pulled out of Vietnam.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Anti‐Communist Publisher Of 2 Saigon Papers Slain
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 29 (Reuters)— The publisher of two anti‐Com munist Chinese‐language news‐ papers was shot to death in his home in Saigon today by a woman, thought to be a Viet cong agent, the South Vietnam ese police reported.

headline: Fulbright Forces Press Policy Curbs
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28— The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, admittedly on the defensive in its struggle with the White House, will make a last‐ditch effort this week to preserve some foreign policy restrictions on the executive branch.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON'S DRIVE GETS HEAVY U.S. SUPPORT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 28 (Reuters)—American B‐52 bombers, helicopter gun ships and 8‐inch mortars placed along the border lent support to South Vietnam's new incur sion into Cambodia during the weekend, military announce ments here said today.

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 28 —The court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson, the high est‐ranking officer to face judgment in the aftermath of the mass slayings at Mylai 4, is drawing to a close here in a red‐carpeted courtroom about a world and a half away from the dreary battlefields of Viet‐nam. Sometime in the next few days, once the last‐min ute legal wran gling is done, a military jury oftwo generals and five colonels will retire to decide whether the former infantry brigade commander did or did not will fully cover up the slaying of more than 100 unarmed civil ians by American troops.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Rodney D. Driver Exeter, R. I., Nov. 21, 1971

headline: COLONEL DEFENDS HIS MYLAI INQUIRY
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 29 —Col. Oran K. Henderson told the seven‐member jury of of ficers at his court‐martial today that, had he been told that more than 100 civilians had been killed at Mydai 4, he would have conducted “a for mal investigation.”
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: KIN OF P.O.W.'S BEAR PLEA FOR AID TO U.N.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 29—The families of Amer icans held prisoner in Vietnam came here today with an ap peal for assistance. They de parted 12 hours later with little to comfort them, but vowing to keep trying.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Winnie Ruth Judd. con victed of the “trunk murder” of a friend in 1931 and sen tenced to be hanged, was freed yesterday by the Ari zona Board of Pardons and Paroles.
author: James F. Clarity

headline: U.S. COURT BACKS WAR PAPERS CASE
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Nov. 29 — The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit ruled to day that a Federal grand jury may resume its investigation of the release of the Pentagon papers under certain restric tions.

headline: 33 ON U.S. COPTER VANISH IN STORM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 30 (AP)—A Uni ted States Army helicopter with 33 Americans aboard disap peared over the weekend along the storm‐swept northern coast of South Vietnam, and a day long air and sea search yester day found no trace of it.

headline: The Agony of the U.S. Army
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—To many of our people the Army is a controversial issue. It is not easy to think of that apolitical, proud old body of citizen soldiers in that way. Wars can be controversial and so can generals and weapons, but not the Army.
author: By L. James Binder

headline: N.B.C. to Show Kennedy Vietnam Role
lead_paragraph: The involvement of the Ken nedy Administration in the Vietnamese war is to be ex amined by the National Broad casting Company in a two‐part documentary to be seen on the evenings of Dec, 21 and Dec. 22.
author: By Jack Gould

headline: 2 U.S. HELICOPTERS DOWNED IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 30 (AP) —The United States command re ported today that two Ameri can observation helicopters had been shot down over the week end during heavy fighting in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam. Four crewmen were reported wounded.

headline: PULLOUT DEADLINE VOTED BY SENATE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30—The Senate, reaffirming its past support of a deadline for ending the Vietnam war, went on record today in favor of the total withdrawal of all American forces from Indochina in six months, provided American prisoners of war were released.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Prepackaged Hospitals Urged for Use of Poor
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30—Senator George McGovern urged today that some of the 2,500 prepackaged hospitals that the Government keeps in storage for disaster relief be converted into community health centers for the urban and rural poor.

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30—President Nguyen Van Thieu, who concluded his campain for re‐election tonight, can now step back and await what he undoubtedly will regard as a public mandate to govern for another four years.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Soldier Repays Stranger for '67 Favor
lead_paragraph: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 30—While serving with the Army in 1967 in Vietnam, Michael Delaney saved the life of a wounded American soldier he had never seen by talking to the man for 16 hours by radio, to keep him from sinking into a coma. In a courtroom here today, Army Sgt. James P. Dempsey repaid Mr. Delaney by pledging his stripes to salvage Mr. Delaney's future.

headline: OFFICER DISCOUNTED REPORTS ON MYLAI
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 30 —A former intelligence officer who worked for Col. Oran K. Henderson said today that while in Vietnam he considered reports of civilian slayings at Mylai 4 to be “Vietcong propaganda.”

headline: U.S. COMBAT DEATHS PUT AT 29 FOR WEEK
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Sept. 30 (AP)—The United States command announced today that 29 Americans were killed in action in Indochina last week. It was the first time in 11 weeks that United States combat deaths exceeded 20.

headline: Urgent Call for Peace
lead_paragraph: The 57‐to‐38 majority by which the Senate has once again passed Senator Mansfield's amendment for withdrawal of all United States forces from Indochina within six months—a cutdown from the original time limit of nine months—reflects spreading national disillusionment with President Nixon's Vietnamization policy. The vote is an impressive demonstration of the determination in Congress to reassert legislative authority, if necessary, to bring the war to the early end the President has promised but not delivered.

headline: Ky, Addressing Anti ‐ Thieu Rally, Urges Vote Boycott
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Friday, Oct. I—Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky addressed a last‐minute political opposition meeting behind a barricade of Government policemen today and urged the voters to boycott this Sunday's elections, in which President Nguyen Van Thieu is the only candidate.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: 6 Antiwar Sailors Given Refugein Catholic Church
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 30 (AP) —Six sailors who are opposed to the war were given refuge in a Roman Catholic church today as their ship, the aircraft carrier Constellation, prepared to return to Vietnam.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Foe Attacks 2 Camps Near Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30—The Saigon command said today that Communist forces attacked two South Vietnamese base camps along the Cambodian border northwest of here yesterday.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: PODGORNY LEAVES ON TRIP TO HANOI
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Sept. 30—President Nikolai V. Podgorny left here today for Hanoi at the head of a high‐ranking economic and military delegation in what was viewed as an attempt to court North Vietnam's favor after similar effort by Peking.
author: By Theodore Shabad Special to The New York Times

headline: Uncontested Saigon Election Is Assailed at Paris Talks
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Sept. 30 (Reuters)—The uncontested South Vietnamese presidential election Sunday came in for some harsh words from Hanoi and the Vietcong today as the stalled Paris peace talks resumed after two‐week break.

headline: COLONEL'S LAWYERS OBJECT TO WITNESS
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 1—The court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson was conducted out of the presence of the jury today to allow for argument and testimony on a defense motion to prevent a key witness from appearing.

headline: Enemy Again Attacks Base in Cambodial
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 2 (AP)—Despite a nightlong pounding by allied aircraft, North Vietnamese troops were reported to have launched another ground attack early today against a South Vietnamese artillery base in eastern Cambodia.

headline: POMPIDOU SCORES U.S. IN GREETING CHINESE
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 1 — President Pompidou had the nine members of a Chinese delegation in for lunch at the Elysde Palace today and took the occasion to criticize the presidential election in South Vietnam Sunday and the American bombing of North Vietnam.

headline: Hanging Up on War
lead_paragraph: WEEHAWKEN, N. J.—Richard Mozdiak of the Internal Revenue Service telephoned me recently and offered me a last chance to pay three telephone tax bills from last year. No I said, won't pay—not while the Government uses my money for its illegal, immoral, inhumane and purposeless war in Indochina.
author: By Kennett Love

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Experts Hail Army's Program For Drug Addicts in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 — A team of six experts on rehabilitation of drug addicts returned from two weeks in Vietnam today with the message that the Army was doing first‐class job of treating soldiers involved with drugs. The team called the soldiers chances of recovery excellent.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: 9 Ashore as Carrier Sails; Navy Calls Them Deserters
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 1 (AP)—Nine young crewmen of the Constellation stayed inside a Roman Catholic church as the attack carrier sailed on schedule today for Vietnam. They were then declared deserters by the Navy.

headline: The Talk of Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1—The crowd of about a thousand pushed its way into the old French opera house across the street from the United States Embassy in what seemed at first to be a gathering of political figures to mark the end of the presidential election campaign. As it turned out, the one‐man candidacy of President Nguyen Van Thieu and the voting this Sun day were far from the thoughts of the Vietnamese in the Thong Nhut Theater, with its 14 swirling overhead fans. They were attending the weekly drawing of the national lottery and the number that emerged, 124916, brought someone somewhere 4 million piasters, or the equivalent of about $15.000.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Buddhist Anti‐Thieu Rally Is Attacked by the Police
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 2—South Vietnamese riot policemen made a tear‐gas attack last night on a Buddhist rally of about 300 people who were protesting tomorrow's uncontested presidential election.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Two Youths Arrested
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Oct. 1 (AP)—Two youths were arrested at the An Quang Pagoda today, one with a firebomb in his hand. The latter was beaten by the police and taken away in a jeep.

headline: Ellsberg Friend, Held 47 Days, Agrees to Testify and Is Freed
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 — Anthony J. Russo, who has been imprisoned for 47 days for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the Pentagon papers case, agreed today to appear and was set free.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. ENCOURAGED BY SOVIET TALKS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2—The Nixon Administration has emerged from its latest round of discussions with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, persuaded that its relations with Moscow are better now than at any time in the last three years.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘We Have to Choose Least of the Bad,’ Professor Says
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 2—Prof. Nguyen Ngoc Huy, who intends to cast his Vote for President Nguyen Van Thieu in the one ‐ man election tomorrow, knows that opponents of the Government have sonic legitimate complaints. But he insists that President Thieu, though he is the only choice is a good choice.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Court Orders Refund Of War Protesters' Bond
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) —The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has ordered the District to refund collateral forfeited by many of the 12,000 persons arrested during the Mayday antiwar demonstrations.

headline: Industrialist Who Financed Medina's Defense Heads Diversified Business Empire Built in Five Years
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 2—The career of Glenn W. Turner, the man who financed the defense in the court‐martial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina, hardly fits me pattern of ordinary industrialists.
author: By Martin Waldron Special to The New York Times

headline: Dear President Nixon, The last 24 hours has again been another day of pure hell for Americans in prison camps, cells ' cages in Southeast Asia
lead_paragraph: THE Air Force sends regular newsletters to the families of all the men it lists as captured by this country's enemies in Southeast Asia or missing in action there. Usually these communications are appropriately solemn, but sometimes they fall into a chatty, upbeat tone as they describe for the relatives the grassroots campaign—involving the writing of letters and sending petitions to Hanoi—that Legionnaires, Jaycees, church women and highschool students have undertaken on behalf of their husbands, sons and brothers. Most of this huge outpouring (amounting now to more than 50 million letters) has never reached Hanoi, and there is scant reason to suppose that Vietnamese officials able to read letters in English from Salinas, Kan., or Sante Fe, N.M., bother to do so. Yet such students of Vietnamese psychology as the Dallas multimultimillionaire H. Ross Perot have promised that “making the treatment of our men a visible issue in the United States will bring the North Vietnamese to their knees.” Vietnament Communists, Perot has discovered, suffer from an “inferiority complex” that leads them to crave.
author: By Joseph Lelyveld

headline: MILLIONS VOTING IN ONE‐MAN RACE IN SOUTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Sun. day, Oct. 3—Millions of South Vietnamese are voting today to re‐elect Prsident Nguyen Van Thicu, the only candidate in an election that has brought embarrasment to American officials and distress to many Vietnamese.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Mother With Sons Injured in the War Has Burned Her Voting Card
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 2—A Buddhist housewife who has seen her five sons go to war expressed her anger and disgust with the Saigon Government by burning her yellow voting card last week. It was a small demonstration—one in a series that was started here two weeks ago by housewives, students and disabled veterans—and it went unnoticed by the rest of the city.

headline: Will the Real Majority Stand Up for Scoop Jackson?
lead_paragraph: ONE day in the early spring of 1969, a high‐ranking aide to President Nixon and a trusted friend from Capitol Hill sat talking in a West Wing office in the White House. The aide lowered his voice and spoke, as politicians say, “within the family.” The President's proposed Safeguard ABM system, the subject of this strategy meeting, was in trouble in the Senate, he said. Beyond that, he foresaw no end of trouble on a wide range of defense and foreign‐policy issues, especially the Vietnam war. Soon, he said, it would be Nixon's War.
author: By Richard J. Whalen

headline: The Freedom to Speak
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—One of the historical lessons that the American people seem always to have difficulty learning is the truth of the warning enunciated so long ago: “Eternal vigilance is the price of liberty.” We can never rest on the laurels won by our ancestors, nor can we delude ourselves into thinking that our liberties, once having neen obtained, are forever secure.
author: By Sam J. Ervin Jr

headline: Students Cheering McGovern Pledge Of Draft Amnesty
lead_paragraph: BLACK RIVER FALLS, Wis., Oct. 2—Senator George McGovern is pledging that if elected President he will grant a general amnesty to draft evaders, including the thousands of young men who have exiled themselves abroad rather than serve in Vietnam.
author: By Christopher Lydon Special to The New York Times

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Self‐determination day in Saigon, once a pivotal date in President Nixon's withdrawal plan, comes now as just another long Sunday in the Vietnam agony. Around the White House, they smiled a little at the sick jokes of satirists of President Thieu's strenuous one‐man campaign against nay‐saying ballot‐rippers. President Nixon choked a little when he tried to pass off the exercise as at least better than Hanoi's kind of election.
author: — Max Frankel

headline: ROGERS EXPRESSES CONCERN ON MOVES REPORTED IN CHINA Says Administration Hopes Nixon's Trip to Peking Won't Be Affected
lead_paragraph: In the first official expression of the Administration's concern over events in China. Secretary of State William P. Rogers said yesterday that the United States hoped they would not affect President Nixon's plans to visit Peking.
author: By Tad Szulc

headline: Protests in Danang
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Sunday, Oct. 3 (AP)—In Danang. South Vietnam's second largest city, Buddhist monks and youths, students and veterans threw stones and firebombs and blocked intersections near at least nine major polling stations. They made it virtually impossible for voters to get in.

headline: ENEMY STEPS UP SHELLING ATTACKS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Sunday, Oct. 3 (AP)—Enemy forces reportedly doubled their shelling attacks across South Vietnam overnight and fired three rockets into Saigon early today, just a few hours before the polls opened for the presidential election.

headline: CARRIER DEPARTS AMID PROTESTERS
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 2 — When the aircraft carrier Constellation, which has been the target of antiwar demonstrators for six months, sailed for Vietnam yesterday, the military security was the tightest witnessed around this Navy base since World War II.

headline: P.O.W. Arithmetic
lead_paragraph: The campaign to free American P.O.W.'s has been clouded by confusion about their numbers. President Nixon this year spoke of “1,600 Americans in North Vietnam's jails.” In fact, it will be a stroke of good fortune if even half the 1,623 Americans listed ty the Defense Department as captured or missing in action prove to be alive.
author: — J.l

headline: To Waiting Wives' Of Officers the War Is One More Job
lead_paragraph: NEWBURGH, N. Y. —“We look at It not as ‘The War’ but as our husbands' job—right, girls?” Mrs. Michael M. Quinlan of Poughkeepsie, whose husband is an Army major in Quangnai, South Vietnam, won quick nods assent from the other officers' wives seated around her.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Balloting Choice in Vietnam Was Thieu or Trash Can
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 3 — South Vietnam's presidential ref erendurn today was a duty, a chore, or an incomprehensible and perhaps ominous ritual, depending on whom you tallied to in the country's cities, villages and hamlets.

headline: ARMY REVIEWING CASE OF COLONEL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) — Prodded by Congress, Secretary of the Army Robert F. Froehike is personally reviewing Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert's file to determine whether the officer, who is now facing forced retirement, was unjustly relieved of his command.

headline: SAIGON REPORTS THIEU CAPTURING 90% OF THE VOTES
