lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Oct. 4 — President Nguyen Van Thieu won a new four‐year term yesterday in a one‐candidate election marked by scattered protests, terrorism, intensified enemy shelling and the largest reported voter turnout in recent Vietnamese history.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Podgorny Greeted By Hanoi Turnout; Press Hails Soviet
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 3 (Agence France‐Presse) —Nikolai V. Podgorny arrived here today from Rangoon for his official visit. The Soviet President and his eight‐member delegation from Moscow were greeted at Hanoi's Gialam Airport by North Vietnamese officials including Le Duan, first secretary of the Communist party. Premier Pham Van Dong and Defense Minister Vo Nguyen Giap.

headline: Enemy Shelling of Hamlet Makes the Voters Wary
lead_paragraph: ANDUOC, South Vietnam, Oct. 3—The Vietcong fired a mortar shell into this hamlet 22 miles northwest of Saigon a half hour before the polls opened this morning, and only an intrepid handful of villagers came early to cast their ballots for President Nguyen Van Thieu or to deposit them as a negative vote, into the wastebaskets provided In each curtained booth.

headline: Dictatorship in Saigon
lead_paragraph: The lopsided election results announced by the Saigon Government can give no comfort to Americans or for that matter to democratically inclined South Vietnamese. President Thieu's proclaimed 91.5 per cent mandate in one‐man vote is the kind of result that could be expected from the regime in Hanoi, to which Saigon was supposed to offer a democratic alternative.

headline: SAIGON RELIEF FORCE AT CAMBODIAN BASE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4 (AP)—A tank‐led South Vietnamese rescue column fought its way through North Vietnamese lines this evening to relieve a besieged artillery base inside Cambodia, South Vietnamese spokesmen said.

headline: U. S. Aides Pleased
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (Reuters)—United States officials today reiterated their misgivings about South Vietnam's one‐man presidential election, but expressed satisfaction at the high voter turnout.

headline: Ellsberg Wins a Motion For Inventory of Property
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 (AP)—A motion for an independent inventory of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's records and other property was granted to the defense today by a United States District Court judge, William M. Bryne Jr.

headline: Colonel's Mylai Report Is Called Untrue
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 4—The former commander of helicopter battalion flying in support of attacking infantrymen at Mylai 4 said today that a report he had read of the incident while In Vietnam “didn't tell the truth.”
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: THIEU SAYS VOTING SHOWS DEMOCRACY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4—President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that his victory in the one‐man presidential election yesterday was a clear example of democracy in action.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: OBSERVER
lead_paragraph: “I received the impression that most people were unaware . . of ... an offer of secret talks by the N.L.F.”
author: By John Mendelson

headline: TALLY QUESTIONED IN DANANG VOTING
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Oct. 4—High American officials, Buddhist opposition leaders and independent observers today sharply challenged the Government's claims of a heavy turnout of voters in Danang and Hue in yesterday's presidential election.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Medina Quitting Army, May Be Out in 2 Weeks
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga. Oct. 4 (AP)—Capt. Ernest L. Medina, acquitted of murder charges in the Mylai assault of 1968, submitted his resignation to Third Army headquarters here today.

headline: PODGORNY GIVES PLEDGE IN HANOI
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Oct. 4—President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union gave the Vietnamese Communists a strong pledge of continued support and assistance today in their war against the United States and other opposing forces in Indochina.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: Washington: For the Record
Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Oct. 5 (AP)—President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union completed two days of talks in Hanoi today, the North Vietnamese press agency reported.

headline: Habib Sworn In as Envoy
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) —Ambassador Philip Charles Habib, a diplomat with long experience in Asia's divided countries of Korea and Vietnam, was sworn in today as the new United States Ambassador to South Korea.

headline: 150 in Paris Assail U.S.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 5 — About 150 youths demonstrated in front of the United States Consulate tonight against United States policy in Vietnam.

headline: SAIGON'S FORCES SAID TO ROUT FOE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 6 (AP)—A South Vietnamese general said yesterday that a badly battered North Vietnamese force was in retreat after 10 days of fighting along the Cambodian border northwest of here.

headline: Militant Students in Saigon Vow to Pursue Struggle
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 5—The militant students here, bitter opponents of President Nguyen Van Thieu and of the Americans, who support him, say they will continue their campaign against the President and his allies.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Colonel's Defense Seeks to Tell Jury of Lie Tests
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 5—Defense attorneys for Col. Oran K. Henderson argued today that his court‐martial jury should be permitted to learn that the defendant voluntarily took a lie detector test at the request of the Government.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: HENDERSON GAINS A POINT AT TRIAL
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 6 —The military judge in the trial of Col. Oran K. Henderson ruled today that a key prosecution witness would not be permitted to make a courtroom identification of the defendant.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnamese Food Far From the Front Lines—North Carolina
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, N. C.—Payday comes to Fort Bragg twice a month. Thirtynine thousand military personnel desert their 150,000‐acre base and head, by car, bus and thumb, along the plastic wasteland of Bragg Boulevard looking for fun.
author: By Raymond A. Sokolov Special to The New York Times

headline: SENATE APPROVES DEFENSE BILL, 82‐4
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6—The Senate passed today a $21‐billion military procurement bill containing a Vietnam troop withdrawal amendment and a provision permitting the importation of Rhodesian chrome in defiance of a United Nations embargo.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Reds Let French Expert Work at Angkor
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 — A noted French archeologist is being permitted by the North Vietnamese to cross back and forth through Communist lines in Cambodia to continue his lifelong work of preserving the ruins of Angkor.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: HARRIS ADDRESSES DEMOCRATS HERE
lead_paragraph: Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma took his “new populism” campaign for the Democratic nomination for President to New York City and Connecticut yesterday.

headline: B‐52'S BOMB FOE NORTH OF SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Thursday, Oct. 7 (AP)—Three Iwaves of B‐52 bombers pounded enemy positions along the Cambodian border today in a second day of follow‐up raids after a week and a half of frontier fighting.

headline: A Saigon General Told a Lie To Boost His Troops' Morale
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 6 (AP)—Lieut. Gen Nguyen Van Minh, commander of the military region that includes Saigon, said today that he had “told a lie” to raise the morale of his troops during the recent fighting along the Cambodian border.

headline: FOES OF THIEU SEEK TO NULLIFY ELECTION
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct — Opponents of President Nguyen Van Thieu today filed a suit in the Supreme Court calling upon the justices to declare last Sunday's one‐man Presidential election unconstitutional and to nullify the results.

headline: The Colonel and the Army
lead_paragraph: After a delay of more than one year, Secretary of the Army Robert F. Froehlke has agreed under Congressional pressure to review the disturbing case of Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert. The career of this up‐from‐the‐ranks professional soldier with an outstanding combat and command record was shattered by a still unresolved conflict between him and his superior officers. At issue is whether Colonel Herbert's efforts, first to stop and then to report atrocities allegedly committed by. American and South Vietnamese military personnel led, as he maintains, to the reprisals against him.

headline: Students Burn Truck
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Thursday, Oct. 7 (Reuters) — Buddhist students burried a Government truck parked outside an American billet here today in violent protest over the re‐election of President Nguyen Van Thieu in Sunday's election.

headline: CLASH IN CAMBODIA REPORTED BY SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Oct. 8 (AP)—The South Vietnamese command reported today a new flareup of fighting across the Cambodian border and said allied ground and air forces had killed 50 North Vietnamese soldiers without suffering any losses.

headline: U.S. Asks Reds at Paris Talks For Data on Dead Prisoners
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 7—William J. Porter, chief United States negotiator at the Vietnam peace talks here, today asked members of the Communist delegations for information about American prisoners known to be dead in Vietnam.
author: By Clyde H. Farnsworth Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Set to Announce Tough New Taxing Policies
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 7—The Government today was reported planning to announce soon a series of economic reforms intended to strengthen the South Vietnamese economy and reduce its dependence on American aid.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: MUSKIE CRITICIZES NIXON ON ‘DELAYS’
lead_paragraph: PATCHOGUE, L. I., Oct. 7—Senator Edmund S. Muskie criticized the. Nixon Administration tonight for what he termed the “politics of postponement” of solutions to problems of the economy, the environment and the war in Vietnam.
author: By David A. Andelman Special to The New York Times

headline: Advertising:
lead_paragraph: The Advertising Council and SSC&B have run into a major problem in their planned campaign on behalf of American prisoners of war in Southeast Asia. They can't get the copy cleared by the television networks.
author: By Philip H. Dougherty

headline: MOSCOW AND HANOI SIGN NEW AID PACTS
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Oct. 7 (AP)—The Soviet Union has signed new military and economic aid agreements with North Vietnam, Tass announced tonight.

headline: U.S. Death Toll in War Is Put at 21 for Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Oct. 7 (AP)—Twenty‐one Americans were killed in combat in IndoChina last week, eight fewer than the previous week, the United States command reported today.

headline: SOVIET‐HANOI TIES APPEAR BOLSTERED
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Oct. 8—President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union left Hanoi by air today, ending a five‐day visit that appears to have further consolidated Soviet‐North Vietnamese ties.

headline: Laird Voices Happiness
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) —Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird, voicing happiness over Sergeant Sexton's release, said today: “We remain concerned about the hundreds of other of our military personnel held” in Southeast Asia.

headline: FRESH ENEMY UNIT IN A BORDER CLASH
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 8 (AP)—Fighting broke out again today along the Camobodian‐South Vietnamese border. South Vietnamese infantrymen clashed with North Vietnamese regulars near Route 22 just south of United States Fire Base Pace, the area where the Saigon troops engaged the enemy Thursday.

headline: Damaging File Dropped From Col. Herbert's Record
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 —The Army has thrown out a damaging efficiency report that was added to the file of Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert after he charged two fellow officers with covering up alleged atrocities by American troops in South Vietnam. The action, announced today by Secretary of the Army Robert F. Froehlke at the Pentagon, clears the way for Colonel Herbert to stay in the military. Had the Army not elected to clear the colonel's record of charges of having “no ambition, integrity, loyalty or will for selfimprovement” and of having “a terrible appearance,” he would have been forced to retire from military service effective March 1, 1972, Mr. Froehlke said. The efficiency report, a periodic evaluation of officers' performance, was filed by Col. J. Ross Franklin, who had been, accused by Colonel Herbert of, derelietion of duty by covering up the alleged atrocities.

headline: Vietcong Release G.I. Held for 2 Years
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 8 (AP)—United States sergeant listed as missing in action was released by the Vietcong today after more than two years' captivity. He walked barefoot for eight hours through jungles to safety and reported that he had seen other American prisoners during the two years.

headline: Wide Soviet‐Hanoi Accord Initiated by Podgorny Visit
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Sunday, Oct. 10—North Vietnam and the Soviet Union have set up a joint committee that will work out details of long‐term economic, trade, cultural, scientific and technological relations between the two countries.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I. Freed by the Vietcong Lost 50 Pounds as P.O.W.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 9 (AP)—S. Sgt. John C. Sexton Jr., released by the Vietcong after more than two years as a prisoner of war, lost 50 pounds during his captivity, a United States military spokesman said today.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — President Nguyen Van Thieu's real problems began last week after he solved one that has commanded priority for months over other affairs of war and state—how to hold an election that would ensure an overwhelming vote for his continuance in office.
author: —Craig R. Whitney

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: John F. Sterling Jr

headline: Saigon Reports a Breakthrough To Battered Base in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct 9 (AP)—A column of 1,200 South Vietnamese rangers, led by tanks, was reported to have fought through North Vietnamese lines today and reached a battered artillery base in eastern Cambodia.

headline: Letter
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Roy C. Bates

headline: Vietminh Veterans Recall the War Against the French
lead_paragraph: TUYHOA, South Vietnam, Oct. 8—Many men of Phuyen province, famous for its guerrilla fighters in the, nine‐year war against the French, are silent now. Many do not even speak to their children of the war that they helped win.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: The Colonel's Vindication
lead_paragraph: Dismissal by the Army of a damaging efficiency report against Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert removes the threat of that officer's forced retirement from a lifetime of dedicated service. It should also clear the way for his return to the command positions and the promotion to which his previous combat performance entitled him.

headline: Colleen Pelleriti Wed to Captain
lead_paragraph: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Oct. 9 —Miss Colleen Mary Pelleriti was married here this afternoon to Capt. Carl P. Parlatore of the Air Force, who flew 230 combat missions in Vietnam as a jetfighter pilot. Msgr. George M. Claric performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in a military service in the chapel at Homestead Air Force Base, where the bridegroom is stationed.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: In the next twelvemonth of twilight war in Indochina, the United States will have to make hard decisions about some of the; engines of destruction being plapeti, in the hands of South Vietnatn's military regime. Each new troop withdrawal will be announced with the usual fanfare, but nothing is likely to be said about the made‐in‐America equipment that deals out horror to the people and the land.
author: —Herbert Mitgang

headline: Podgorny Back in Moscow
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Oct. 9 (UPI)—President Podgorny returned today from his visit to Hanoi, during which he pledged continuing Soviet support for North Vietnam. He visited India and Burma en route to Hanoi.

headline: FIGHTING REPORTED HEAVY IN CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 10 (AP)—Heavy fighting broke out today near the Pnompenhto‐Saigon highway in eastern Cambodia, the South Vietnamese command reported. South Vietnamese forces said that 46 North Vietnamese soldiers had been killed. Seven South Vietnamese soldiers were reported killed and 15 were wounded.

headline: How Congressmen From Area Voted During Week
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10—Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll‐calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.

headline: A RALLY TO ‘EVICT’ NIXON SET OCT. 26
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10—The Mayday, Tribe will return to the nation's capital Oct. 25, with plans to “surround and close the White House” during a rally the next day.

headline: KOREA G.I.'S FACE A DULL, SAFE LIFE
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 10 —For many of the 36,000 American soldiers serving in South Korea, life is made up of equal parts of tedium over being in Korea and relief over not being in Vietnam.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: More Vietnam G.I.'s Taken Oat of Combat
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 10 (UPI) — President Nixon's withdrawal program decreased United States fighting farces here by almost 2,000 men today as infantry and armored cavalry units were ordered to start packing.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Oct. 10—A British expert on Vietnam, a confirmed hawk, was talking about Northern Ireland. The trouble there, he said, was the weakness of the British Army's intelligence: If they had a list of 2,000 terrorists. and got them behind bars, all would be well.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: NATIONS PRESSED TO AID DESERTERS
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Oct. 11 —A campaign on behalf of American servicemen who desert because of their opposition to the war in Indochina was launched here today by 200 prominent men and women from 17 countries.

headline: Kennedy Asks Inquiry
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) —Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, called today for an immediate investigation of refusal of several American soldiers to go on a patrol in South Vietnam. “Any refusal by American soldiers to engage in combat is a cause of extremely serious concern,” Senator Kennedy said.

headline: Army Says Some G.I.'s Balked Briefly at Patrol
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 11—A United States Army spokesman said today that several American soldiers defending an allied fire base near the Cambodian border northwest of here balked for a time on Saturday night at going out on patrol.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Soviet Writer Says Peace In Vietnam Appears in Sight
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP)—The Soviet journalist Victor Louis said in The London Evening News today that a negotiated end to the Vietnam war “appears to be in sight.”

headline: Swiss to Recognize Hanoi
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Oct. 11 (UNI) — A communiqué on Swiss recognition of North Vietnam on the ambassadorial level was silmultaneously made public in Hanpi and Bern today. The No Vietnamese press agency reported.

headline: Chomsky Gets Subpoena
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Oct. 11 (UPI)—Prof. Noam A. Chomsky of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology said today that he had been subpoenaed to appear before a Federal grand jury in Los Angeles investigating the leaking of the Pentagon papers to the press.

headline: P.O.W. Is Freed by U.S. In Return for G.I. Release
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11—A North Vietnamese lieutenant was released today as part of a one‐for‐one prisoner exchange initiated by the enemy, United States officials said.
author: By Bernard Gwertzivman Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Japanese Increase Investment in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Oct. 11—Japanese consumer goods, television sets, radios, water pumps and diesel engines, some of the goods that have flooded the South Vietnamese market because of American ‐ supported import laws, are beginning to be produced by Japanese manufacturers here—the latest sign of their growing economic interest in Vietnam.

headline: 1,000 Sailors Said to Ask Ban on Carrier's Sailing
lead_paragraph: ALAMEDA, Calif., Oct. 11 (AP)—A group of 11 American servicemen said today that 1,000 crewmen from the aircraft carrier Coral Sea had petitioned Congress to keep their ship from sailing to another combat mission off Vietnam.

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU, Oct. 11 (UPI)—Nine, sailors who missed the carrier Constellation's departure from San Diego in protest against its return to Vietnam waters have been found guilty of three charges and sentenced to 30 days in corrective custody, the Navy announced today. The nine, who were arrested by Federal officials and flown to the ship, were tried before the Constellation's captain, J. D. Ward, at sea Saturday.

headline: U.S. Adviser Quits Vietnam to Show His Disgust
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 11—A 26‐year‐old Foreign Service officer, who spent 13 months in Vietnam as a refugee expert, quit his Job and left South, Vietnam last week without notice. He said his action was intended to show disgust with the United States role and policies in Vietnam.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON SAYS TROOPS CLASH AGAIN AT BASE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct, 11 (AP)—Fighting on both sides of the Cambodian border continued today but on a diminished scale, South Vietnamese spokesman said.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: The installation of Derek C. Bok as the 25th president of Harvard University, the nation's oldest, was a subdued affair compared with similar ceremonies.

headline: U.S. HELD UP LETTER BY P.O.W. TWO YEARS
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Oct. 11 (AP)—Army and Congressional sources are trying to iletermine why a letter that a recently released prisoner of war wrote to his family more than two years ago while a captive was not delivered until a week ago.

headline: A Man Is Defined by His Longings
lead_paragraph: NOTRE DAME, Ind.—The violent man arms himself, calculates how he will respond to assaults or degrees of aggression or insult, practices for each conceivable extreme situation, rehearses for the exceptional. For the same reason, we are a violent country, even apart from the war in Vietnam and even if our entire nuclear crop forever lies fallow.
author: By Robert E. Meagher

headline: 4 ARE SUBPOENAED IN ELLSBERG INQUIRY
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)—Four associates of Dr. Daniel Elisberg have been subpoenaed to testify before a Federal grand jury in Boston tomorrow and Thursday on the leaking of the Pentagon papers.

headline: WAR CHALLENGE REFUSED BY COURT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12—The Supreme Court laid to rest today any lingering thoughts that it might declare the Vietnam war unconstitutional.

headline: FOE SAID TO SHELL 11 ALLIED POSITIONS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 12 (AP) — Enemy gunners reportedly shelled 11 bases today along the Cambodian border 60 to 90 miles northwest of Saigon. The allies countered with artillery and air strikes.

headline: Drug Dependency of Servicemen In Vietnam Is Said to Level Off
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 — The rate of drug dependency oblong servicemen in Vietnam “seems to have reached a plateau” at 5.1 per cent, Dr. Jerome K. Jaffe, the President's director of antidrug programs, said today.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt; Special to The New York Times

headline: LETTER FROM P.O.W. JUDGED PROPAGANDA
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12—A letter from an American serviceman that proved he was alive took two years in reaching his parents because “somebody made the assessment that it was a propaganda leaflet,” Pentagon sources said today.

headline: Government by Force
lead_paragraph: EAST LANSING, Mich. — For more than a generation the major U.S. political thrust in Vietnam has been to develop stability. Despite our professions, of faith in representative government and democratic processes, we rarely have been at ease with vigorous and independent leaders among our junior allies or with legislative bodies such as the Vietnamese National Assembly when they show vitality and independence of judgment. The events that culminated in the South Vietnamese election Oct. 3 underscore that conclusion.
author: BY Wesley R. Fishel

headline: Joint Chiefs Said to Devise Costly Cambodia War Plan
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12—The Joint Chiefs of Staff are said to have designed a costly program of “pacification” and other unconventional warfare for Cambodia to protect South Vietnam's western flank as Americans continue their withdrawal from Indochina.

headline: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Affairs
Medina Offers to Testify At Colonel's Court‐Martial
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 12 —Capt. Ernest L. Medina, the Army officer who was acquitted last month on all charges arising from the Mylai slayings, arrived here today to offer his help to Col. Oran K. Henderson, his former brigade commander.

headline: Ransom Frees U.S. Convoy From Vietnamese Crowd
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam Oct. 12 (UPI)—An American truck convoy with 14 soldiers aboard was captured and held for ransom for nearly eight hours near here today by an angry crowd of disabled South Vietnamese war veterans.

headline: Reagan to Visit Saigon
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE, Oct. 12 (UPI)—Gov. Ronald Reagan of California will fly to Saigon tomorrow to meet with President Nguyen Van Thieu at the request of the White House, an aide said today.

headline: An Expression of Sorrow
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 12 (AP)—A spokesman for the United States command said that the money paid the South Vietnamese veterans near Danang today was an expression of sorrow and not compensation.

headline: In‐Law Refuses to Testify
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 (AP) —Spencer Marks, the brotherin‐law of Daniel Ellsberg invoked the Fifth Amendment and refused to testify today before a grand jury investigating the leak of the Pentagon Papers, his lawyer said.

headline: HENDERSON JURY TOED OF HIS OFFER
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 13 —The jury in the trial of Col. Oran K. Henderson learned today that the officer once offered, “in the Interest of strengthening the American people's confidence in its Army,” to take the blame for any cover‐up of mass slayings of civilians at Mylai, South Vietnam.
author: By Douglas Robinson; Special to The New York Times

headline: ELLSBERG INQUIRY PRESSED IN BOSTON
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Oct. 13—A Federal grand jury here inevstigating how the Pentagon papers reached the press was reported today to be moving closer to returning indictments.
author: By Nicholas Gage; Special to The New York Times

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Prince Rahim, an 8‐pound son and heir, was born to Aga Khan IV, the Harvard graduate who is spiritual leader of 15 million Ismaili Moslems in Asia and Africa, and his wife, the Begum Aga Khan.
author: Albin Krebs

headline: Month of Antiwar Rallies Begins Throughout the Country
lead_paragraph: Homebound workers mingled With several thousand demonstrators at a Vietnam Moratorium Day labor rally held yesterday on Seventh Aveiue between 36th and 37th Streets.
author: By Emanuel Perlmutter

headline: Laird Warns of Soviet Missile Build‐Up Far Exceeding His Earlier Estimates
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13— Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird expressed concern today over what he said was a continuing Soviet build‐up of landbased and sea‐based missiles. This build‐up, already “far outdistancing” the estimates he offered Congress seven months ago.
author: By William Beecher; Special to The New York Times

headline: Reagan to Convey to Thieu Congratulations From Nixon
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 13 (UPI)—Gov. Ronald Reagan of California said here, today that he would extend President Nixon's congratulations to President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam on his election victory.

headline: SENATE UNIT VOTES $250‐MILLION LIMIT ON CAMBODIAN AID
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 — The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to impose a $250‐million ceiling on military and economic aid to the Cambodian Government in the current fiscal year.
author: By John W. Finney; Special to The New York Times

headline: Enemy Demolition Squad Destroys Two U.S. Copters
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 14 (AP)—A small band of enemy demolition men slipped into an allied base eight miles northeast of Saigon early yesterday, blew up two helicopters and heavily damaged three others.

headline: Sergeant Freed by Foe Reunited With Parents
lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo., Oct. 13 (AP)—S. Sgt. John C. Sexton Jr., Who walked to freedom Friday near the CambodiaSouth Vietnam border after having been a prisoner of war for two years, was reunited with his parents today.

headline: U.S. War Dead at 8 in Week Fewest Since ’65
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 14 (UPI) — The United States command announced to day that eight Americans were killed in action in Indochina last week, the fewest for a week in more than six years.

headline: A Senator's Immunity
lead_paragraph: AMHERST, Mass.—The Nixon Ad ministration is at it again. First it tried to intimidate the television net works. In vain. Next it attempted, for the first time in our history, to silence the press by the threat of prior cen sorship. Again in vain. Now the Jus tice Department has launched an attack on the constitutional privileges of a co‐ordinate branch of the Gov ernment—the Congress of the United States and, by implication, every legis lature in the United States.
author: By Henry Steele Commager

headline: HENDERSON JURY HEARS GENVKOSTER
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 14 — Brig. Gen. Samuel W. Kos ter, who was demoted and cen sured by the Army an connec tion with the events at Mylai 4, testified today that his sub ordinates had never told him mass slaying of civilians occurred during the attack on the South Vietnamese hamlet.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: EX‐KENNEDY AIDE CALLED BY INQUIRY
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Oct. 14 — A for mer legislative assistant to Senator Edward M. Kennedy) has been subpoenaed to appear here before the Federal grand jury investigating how the Pentagon papers reached the press.
author: By Nicholas Gage Special to The New York Times

headline: Porter Sees Nixon Visits Disturbing Vietnam Reds
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 14—William J. Porter, the United States Am bassador to the Paris peace talks, suggested today that the Vietnamese Communists were “bothered” by the forthcoming visits of President Nixon to Peking and Moscow.

headline: Sharp Battle Near Krek
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Friday, Oct. 15. (AP) —A South Vietnamese armored task force reportedly clashed with North Vietnamese troops yesterday in a brief but savage battle northwest of here just inside Cambodia.

headline: Screen: Stember's '7254':Forum Offers Diffuse Saga of Young Man
lead_paragraph: The Film Forum rates credit for lending a helping hand to another aspiring, if unsung, moviemaker, by giving theatrical exposure to John Stember's first film, "7254," which will run at that intimate showcase for generally noncommercial fare today through Sunday. But good deeds and intentions aside, Mr. Stember, who is a fashion photographer, gives us a good deal less than meets the eye or the ear in this ill-defined and disconnected saga of a modern young man's angst in a world rent by wars and other dissensions.Mr. Stember, who produced and directed from his story and for his own company, SHA Productions, apparently was uncertain about just how he would project the problems endured by his vaguely limned but highly distraught hero.What we're exposed to is a series of vignettes photographed in color against mostly local backgrounds that give the impression of having been tossed in merely to indicate progressive anxieties.The anxieties appear to have basis in awesome facts. We see televised scenes indicating Hitler's holocausts, and others, up to and including Vietnam. Vietnam is what appears to have set off our troubled pettish hero, Alan Midgette. In disjointed scenes, he is oddly unresponsive to the pleas of his nude, beautiful but callow wife (Phoebe McAdams) to come to bed; to his loquacious, divorced mother (Ruth Ford) and her saccharine adoration, and to a vague, older friend (Paul Gallan), who, at one point, chases him desperately as he rows down a sylvan stream.Unfortunately, Mr. Midgette, a lank-haired, slightly delicate blond type sporting a flowing white scarf, is given to long, moody silences and few words that convey coherency or depth. In a reflective sequence shot for no real reason on a windswept beach through waving weeds, his Vietnam observations include, "Those are real babies crying, this war is a crime against nature."The dialogue, done in an ad lib, Andy Warhol technique, is not a crime against nature but it does little to put the principals in sharp focus. Nor does it do much for the meaning of the climax, which has our tortured Alan fleeing inexplicably from everyone at an airport.The title, "7254," a program note says, is the "Kodak designation for color negative film." Well, it wasn't used especially positively this time.
author: By A. H. Weiler

headline: SENATE UNIT VOTES $844‐MILLION CUT FROM AID REQUEST
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 — The Senate Foreign Relations Committee tentatively cut nearly $850‐million today from the Administration's $3.3‐bil lion foreign aid request.
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: 4,650 Pulled Out of ‘Combat
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Oct. 15 (Reuters) —The United States command today announced that 4,650 men had been withdrawn from combat. The cutback is the big gest since a reduction of 6,000 was announced last July 1. The current strength is just below 210,000 men.

headline: Reagan Meets: Thieu in Saigon And Defends One‐Man Race
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 15 — Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, on a three‐hour vis it to South Vietnam today, de livered a messagd from Presi dent Nixon congratulating President Nguyen Van Thieu on his re‐election.
author: By Fox Butterfeeld Special to The New York Times

headline: Charges Against General Are Dropped
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15— The Army, announced today that it had dropped charges against Maj. Gen John W. Barnes, who, along with Col. 3. Ross Franklin, had been ac cused by a fellow officer of dereliction of duty by failing to report alleged war crimes by merican and allied service men two years ago.

headline: Gun Position in North Attacked Alter a U.S. Plane Is Fired On
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 15 (AP)—The United States command announced today that an unarmed American plane was fired Upon from the ground yesterday while on a recon naissance mission over North Vietnam 95 miles north of the demilitarized zone.

headline: ‘The Common Denominator’
lead_paragraph: A Senate Foreign Relations Committee vote to limit economic and military assistance to Cambodia to $250‐ million and to put a ceiling of 200 on the number of American civilian and military personnel assigned to that country represents a timid attempt to prevent Cambodia from going the way of Vietnam—too timid, in our view. Like the $350‐million limit on spending in Laos already voted by the full Senate, the proposed Cambodian restriction is too generous to check effec tively a deepening United States involvement in what formerly, were fringe areas of the Indochina conflict.

headline: Medina Leaves Army; Feels ‘Like a Civilian’
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Oct. 15 (AP) — Capt. Ernest L. Medina, who was acquitted of charges in connection with the killing of South Viet namese civilians in 1968 at Mylai, was given an honor able discharge from the Army today.

headline: LETTERS
lead_paragraph: To the Financial Editor: I have been thinking over your article on the hard pressed private club (Sept. 26). To me, it's an alarming situation. Not because of the pressure on my clubs, or anyone else's, but because of the ominous implications for our liberty.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASIFIRVGTON — When the issue of supplying military and economic aid to Cambodia was first before Congress last year, Secretary of State William P. Rogers, with obvious reference to the Vietnam involvement, gave assurances that “we have no intention of slipping into the mistakes of the past.” Last week the question of whether the United States was going down the same “slippery slope” in Cambodia was revived by the Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee as It set a $250‐million limit on United States spending in Cambodia in the current fis cal year.

headline: U.S. Quits Base, Fear Moves In
lead_paragraph: LANDING ZONE DOTTIE, South Vietnam, Oct. 15—The Americans are gone from here now. Watching the last of them leave a few days ago, wrecking and burning what they did not take out in a convoy, the vil lagers of Binhlien both cursed them and felt sad. They are still angry because of what was de stroyed in four days of fires and what the huge bulldozers smashed and plowed under. But they are uneasy because, as one old farmer said:
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: The L. B. J. Library: The Life and Times Of Lyndon Johnson in Eight Full Stories
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.—“It's all here with the bark off,” Lyndon Johnson told blue‐ribbon crowd at the dedica tion of the L.B.J. Library here last May, nodding back toward the $18‐ million structure and implying that therein reposed the real lowdown on himself and his much‐discussed “place in history.” Like much else about the former President, that proposition is debatable. Indeed, after ambling through the library's museum and viewing all sorts of exhibits ranging from letters to Johnson from Bobby Kennedy and the Smothers Brothers to a display that has “Hello Lyndon” issuing from hidden tape recorder, yet finding barely any mention of the war in Vietnam, began to suspect that quite a bit of bark was still in place.Standing at the bottom of the mag nificent travertine stairway leading from the ground (first) floor to the Great Hall (second floor), the visitor can see the outside rows of stacks behind five‐story glass wall. Only the ground floor, the Great Hall and a portion of the top (eighth) floor, which contains a replica of the Oval Office of the White House, are open to the public. What remains are the stacks.
author: By Gary Cartwright

headline: Ex Officer, a War Protester, Now Helps G.I.'s as Lawyer
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England Oct. 12—Three months after Thomas S. Culver was found guilty of taking part in an antiwar pro test in London, the former Air Force legal officer site in his small home on Hamberstone Road advising dissident Ameri can servicemen and quietly shaping his future.
author: By Bernard Weinraub Special to The New York Times

headline: Jobless Veteran Held in Slaying Of Flatbush Woman by Stabbing
lead_paragraph: An unemployed Vietnam war veteran suspected of murdering a 22‐year‐old Brooklyn house wife who was stabbed 90 times and then burned was arrested late Friday night, the police an nounced yesterday.
author: By Murray Illson

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: PARIS — One of the shrewdest French diplomats I know predicted eight months ago: “If the United States and China can find a means of rapprochement we will see the way open up to a solution of the problem of Indochina, and other countries, including the Soviet Union, will have to subscribe to it.”
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Humphrey Now Welcome at Colleges
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 16 — Friendly students had tipped off Senator Hubert H. Hum phrey's aides that militants would disrupt his speech this week, but they did not know exactly how.
author: By Roy Reed Special to The New York Times

headline: CAMBODIAN BORDER IS RAIDED BY 8.52's
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 16 (AP)—American B‐52 bomb ers were said to have mounted one of the heaviest raids of the war along the Cambodian‐ South Vietnamese border today in a renewed effort to smother the three‐week enemy offensive at the frontier.

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—Nobody's hopes were up here last week be cause of the release by the Communists of S. Sgt. John C. Sexton Jr. and the recipro cal release of a North Viet namese prisoner. The general assumption was that it was a localized decision, not stem ming from any basic change of heart by Hanoi.

headline: The only battle anyone w
lead_paragraph: Vietnam is beginning to be History rather than News. Perhaps future his torians, like author Don Oberdorfer, will describe the recent and current conflict there as “the Second Indo china War,” finding its causes as murkily dynastic as we now regard the Wars of the Spanish Succession. The Gulf of Tonkin affair already starts to seem as obscure and distant as the Agadir Crisis of two genera tions ago, and those “famous victo ries” at Khesanh and the Ashau Val ley become as dimly irrelevant as the Battle of Ratisbon or the storm ing of Pietermaritzburg.
author: By John Franklin CAMPBELL

headline: Letters
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Wilson Carey McWilliams ap pears to have read “Washing ton Plans an Aggressive War” hastily at best. Otherwise, he could not have written that we proposed trials for those re sponsible for the Vietnam war.

headline: Memoir Terms Kennedy Role in Diem Coup a Blunder
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 Lyndon B. Johnson says in his White House memoirs that the Kennedy Administration's role in thil overthrow of President Ngo Dinh Diem was “a serious blunder” that caused political chaos in South Vietnam and be came a principal factor in Mr. Johnson's subsequent commit meat of ground combat forces there.
author: By Neil Sheelian. Special to The New York Times

headline: Col. Herbert Won't Press Case Against General
lead_paragraph: FT. McPHERSON, Ga., Oct. 16 (AP)—Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert said he would not press further charges against Maj– Gen. John W. Barnes, who has been cleared of covering up atrocities in Vietnam.

headline: SHELLING REPORTED NEAR CAMBODIA LINE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Oct. 18 (AP)—North Vietnamese gunners shelled United States and South Viet namese fire bases yesterday and the allies responded with more air strikes as fighting along the South Vietnam‐Cam bodia border entered its fourth week, the Saigon command re ported.

headline: Hanoi Group in Italy for Visit
lead_paragraph: ROME, Oct. 17—A delegation of North Vietnamese trade union officials arrived here to day from Moscow for a 10‐day visit to Italy, the first by an official group from Hanoi. The North Vietnamese are to meet with political, social and cul tural organizations.

headline: By Lyndon B. Johnson: Vietnam Problem
lead_paragraph: Following is the second in the se ries of excerpts from the memoirs of Lyndon Baines Johnson, which will lie published by Holt, Rinehart & Winston on Nov. 7 under the title “The Van tage Point: Perspectives of the Presi dency, 1963–1969”:

headline: Civil Rights Leader Reports On G.I. Problems in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Oct. 18 (AP) —Hosea Williams, national program director of the Southern Christian Leadership Confererice, returned yesterday from a four week visit to Communist China and 17 days in South Vietnam.

headline: AMNESTY IS ASKED FOR ALL WAR FOES
lead_paragraph: A group of 16 lawyers, writers and academicians has petitioned for amnesty for all those who have refused to fight in the war in Vietnam and for those who have run “afoul of military law during a war which many, think is itself illegal.”

headline: RUSSO BALKS AGAIN ON PENTAGON DATA
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18—Anthony J. Russo refused again today to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the Pentagon Papers after the Justice Department objected to giving him a transcript of his testimony.

headline: J. F. K. in Retrospect
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18—Every day of the year under rainy skies or sunshine, ordinary Americans and visitors from overseas come by the hundreds to a hillside in Arlington to visit the grave of John F. Kennedy.
author: By William V. Shannon

headline: Cambodian River Craft Sunk
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 18 (AP)—The Cambodian high command reported today that a Cambodian landing craft, part of a convdy of 15 vessels attempting to reach the besieged provincial capital of Kompong Thom, 80 miles northeast of Pnompenh, was sunk today by Vietcong on North Vietnamese shelling.

headline: Sharp Fighting Breaks Out Near Cambodia Line
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 19 (AP)—Sharp fighting broke out yesterday along the Cambodian border northwest of here, while to the northeast Vietcong units attacked a South Vietnamese hamlet and a military position.

headline: U.S. Force in Vietnam Reduced 4,000 More
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 18 (AP) — The United States command announced today that American military strength in South Vietnam dropped another 4,000 men last week to a total of 206,000.

headline: CONNALLY TO SEE THIEU INSTALLED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18—In a gesture that drew wide diplomatic attention, President Nixon has named Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally to represent him at the inauguration of the South Vietnamese President, Nguyen Van Thieu, on Oct. 31. Mr. Connally will make other stops in Asia and perhaps elsewhere, Administration sources said tonight.

headline: Connally to Visit 3 Nations In Asia After Thieu Inaugural
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) —The White House said today that Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally would visit Thailand, the Philippines and Japan and perhaps other Asian countries after he goes to Saigon to represent President Nixon at the inauguration of President Nguyen Van Thieu on Oct. 31.

headline: HOUSE SIDETRACKS WAR PULLOUT PLAN PASSED BY SENATE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19—Administration forces, by a 23vote margin, succeeded today in blocking a direct vote in the House on the Vietnam war issue, thus sidetracking a troopwithdrawal amendment passed by the Senate.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: U. S. BOMBS KILL 18 IN SAIGON UNIT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 20 (AP)—The United States command said yesterday that an American fighter‐bomber struck a South Vietnamese position near the Cambodian border and killed 18 Government soldiers in an error involving the designation of the target.

headline: By Lyndon B. Johnson: Bombing North After Tonkin Attack
lead_paragraph: IN August, 1964, an unexpected crisis developed, one that threatened for a time to change the nature of the war in Vietnam. During the early hours of Sunday morning, Aug. 2, a highpriority message came in reporting that North Vietnamese torpedo boats had attacked the destroyer U.S.S. Maddox in the Gulf of Tonkin. The duty officer in the White House situation room gathered all the available data, prepared a summary and sent it to my bedroom. The report began:

headline: Sites in North Attacked
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Oct. 20 (Reuters)—Two United States Thunderchief jets fired missiles at an antiaircraft missile site in North Vietnam yesterday, United States military spokesman said today. The jets were escorting bombers pounding the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos when electronic monitors showed the ground site had locked onto their positions in preparation for a launching.

headline: Inflation and Joblessness Called Key Issues in Survey of Editors
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19—The battle against inflation and unemployment has attracted public attention more than any other issue, a geographical sampling of 365 newspaper editors meeting here indicated.

headline: KENNEDY CRITICAL OF NIXON POLICIES
lead_paragraph: Senator Edward M. Kennedy charged the Nixon Administration last night with attempting to “destroy” the Constitution.

headline: ARMY REJECTS TAPE AT HENDERSON TRIAL
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 19—The military judge in the courtmartial of Col. Oran K. Henderson ruled today that the prosecution was entitled to examine a controversial tape recording before its use by the defense.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Originally, President Nixon's posted schedule ‘called for a meeting yesterday with “His Excellency, Sirimavo Bandaranalke, Prime Minister of Ceylon.” Fortunately, before the Prime Minister arrived, someone corrected the schedule to read “Her Excellency,” and Ceylon's head of state received a friendly reception in the President's office. Mr. Nixon, looking back on his visit to her capital 18 years ago, recalled, “I remember a party; it rained.” But he quickly added “I enjoyed Colombo.”

headline: RALLIES ON VIETNAM PLANNED IN CAPITAL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 —Details of prowar and antiwar demonstrations next week in Washington were announced by two groups here today.

headline: Vatican Unit Indicts Monetary System
lead_paragraph: ROME, Oct. 20—A Vatican commission asserted today that the international monetary system was fundamentally unjust because it permitted “a few rich nations” to make decisions affecting the welfare of the entire world.
author: By Edward B. Fiske Special to The New York Times

headline: Moral Victory for Mansfield
lead_paragraph: The White House succeeded in scoring a technical victory but suffered a moral defeat in the House this week by blocking a direct vote on the Mansfield amendment to the military procurement bill, which calls for withdrawal of American forces from Indochina within six months if the Communists free American prisoners of war.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Having been refused admission to, the White. House after he had been invited there, Representative Wayne L. Hays of Ohio now says he will not attend a dinner there late this month that President Nixon is giving for President Tito of Yugoslavia.

headline: General's Wife Awaits War's End, Too
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand (UPI) —Mrs. Creighton W. Abrams, wife of the United States commander in Vietnam, lives like thousands of other wives whose husbands are serving in Indochina. She remains quietly in Thailand, engages in voluntary work and waits for the war to end.

headline: Mrs. Abzug Forces Roll‐Call
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) —Representative Bella S. Abzug forced a rollcall vote on a routine military construction bill today and said she would make the same demand on every military measure until House leaders permit a vote on the Indochina war. The bill today, a compromise $2‐billion authorization for this year's military construction projects around the world, would norally have been passed routinely by voice vote.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Army's double standards flew in full color once more in The Times news story of waiting wives, Oct. 4, when Ralph Blumenthal wrote that wives and children of West Point men in Vietnam get family housing.

headline: Army Rests in Trial
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 20 (UPI)—The prosecution formally rested its case today in the court‐martial of Col. Oran Ti. Henderson on charges of suppressing information on the 1968 Mylai massacre. The Army's chief prosecutor, Maj. Carroll J. Tichenor, made the announcement to Judge Peter S. Wondolowski in late afternoon.

headline: SENATE UNIT VOTES $31‐BILLION AID
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20—The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a $3.2billion foreign aid authorization bill today. It did so after having restored $375‐million, or roughly half, of the cuts it had tentatively ordered in the measure last Friday.

headline: Saigon Warns Papers on ‘Detrimental’ Material
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20—The Government's Office of Information has issued a new directive to the press to avoid material “detrimental to national security and public order.”

headline: NEW SAIGON DRIVE IS ON IN CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 21 (AP)—The South Vietnamese command reportedly sent a 2,500‐man force yesterday into an operation in eastern Cambodia where North Vietnamese troops were said to have been in retreat after a four‐week drive.

headline: Court Defers a Ruling On Thieu's Re‐election
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20 (UPI)—South Vietnam's nine‐man Supreme Court today postponed for 24 hours a decision on whether to overturn the Oct. 3 re‐election of President Nguyen Van Thieu as unconstitutional.

headline: Mother‐in‐Law's Hearing Set
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Oct, 20 (AP)—The Justice Department has peti₭ tinned Federal court to have Dr. Ellsberg's mother‐in‐law jailed for contempt.

headline: Chou En‐lai: On U.S. Talks
lead_paragraph: PEKING—As soon as I was told that I should not leave the hotel for too long and too often so that everybody could be able to find me, it was quite clear to me that Premier Chou En‐lai was going to receive me.

headline: Editors Cite Times on Pentagon Papers
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20—The Associated Press Managing Editors Association presented its first Freedom of Information Citation today, honoring The New York Times for its publication of the Pentagon papers.
author: By Jonathan Kandell Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I think it is shameful and unfortunate that a Governor of one of our United States should choose to compare the election of South Vietnam's President Thieu to that of George Washington. It is shameful that Governor Reagan implies that our heritage has decayed to such an extreme that he can make such. an analogy.

headline: By Lyndon B. Johnson: Many Fruitless Peace Bids to Hanoi
lead_paragraph: IN the summer of 1965 I came to the painful conclusion that an independent South Vietnam could survive only if the United States and other nations went to its aid with their own fighting forces. From then until I left the Presidency, we had three principal goals: to insure that aggression did not succeed, to make it possible for the South Vietnamese to build their country and their future in their own way and to convince Hanoi that working out peaceful settlement was to the advantage of all concerned.

headline: U.S. WAR TOLL OF 5 LOWEST IN 6 YEARS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 21 (AP) — Five Americans, were killed in combat in Vietnam last week, the lowest weekly death toll in more than six years, the United States command announced today.

headline: British Officials Are Restrained
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Oct. 21—British officials were restrained almost to the point of silence today over Senator Kennedy's assertion in Congress that Northern Ireland was rapidly becoming Britain's Vietnam.

headline: Paris Peace Delegates Accuse Each Other of Stalling Tactics
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 21— Against background of continued mutual recrimination the 133d weekly session of the Vietnamese peace talks failed to make any visible progress today.

headline: The ‘Burden’ of the Constitution
lead_paragraph: The men at the executive levels of justice have trampled on traditions and ideals and principles: of justice. They see the Constitution as a burden, an ‘obstruction to he overcome, as technical barrier to be avoided when inconvenient, evaded where possible, and ignored if necessary. Pledged by oath to preserve, protect and defend the Constitution, instead they defile, dilute and debase it. Proclaiming that they will. strictly construe it, rather they constrict and destroy it Slowly, stealthily, they arrogate to themselves the powers that the Constitution meant to be shared ‘and’ powers that the Constitution never meant Govern ment to have at all.
author: By Edward M. Kennedy

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: PARIS—One of the most successful tactics employed by the Vietnamese Communist side to confuse U.S. opinion during peace negotiations here is the simple one of saying different things to different Americans and then blandly refusing to see contradiction in such views, much less explain them.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Saigon Court Upholds Re‐election of Thieu
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Oct. 22 (Reuters)—The South Vietnamese Supreme Court in an 8‐to‐1 decision today officially approved the uncontested reelection of President Nguyen Van Thieu on Oct. 3.

headline: U.S. Troops Leave Camodian Border
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 22—The last American combat units along the Cambodian border were pulled, out to'day from their fire base, which had been under daily ‘enemy shelling for the last four weeks.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Almost Every Place but Picasso's Town Noting His 90th Birthday
lead_paragraph: MOLJGINS, France — The most illustrious resident of this township will be 90 years old on Monday, and the occasion is being celebrated in Paris, Barcelona, Vallaurisbut not in Mougins.
author: By John L. Hess Special to The New York Times

headline: Rustic Utopia, doomed in advance
lead_paragraph: Old Man Ritter—a 77‐year‐old Vermonter, leathery, hard nosed, crotchety—has a reputa tion for eccentricity even among his fellow eccentrics. He also has apple orchards and a de caying farmhouse, untenanted. Enter Josh, a Vietnam veteran with long hair, painful memo ries and a dream of starting a commune. The two men meet and touch across the genera tions. “You a hippie?” Ritter asks. “There aren't any hip pies anymore,” Josh replies. Gears mesh, the relentless mills start to grind, and we're off on another inspection of the mori bund American dreams of agrarianism, Utopian socialism and the life.
author: By. James R. Frakes

headline: That wonderful emperor who gave you Pearl Harbor
lead_paragraph: H. A. L. Fisher once opened his memorable history of Europe with the affirmation that history was one emergency after another. Selected readings in recent years might sug gest that American‐Asian relations have been one damn conspiracy after another. The Pentagon Papers evoked Lyndon Johnson's conspiracy to wage war against North Vietnam; McCar thyism conjured up a conspiracy of pro‐Communist intellectuals and State Department officials losing China to the Chinese and/or Soviet Com munists; Pearl Harbor inspired a Roosevelt conspiracy to maneuver the nation into the European war through the back‐door of conflict with Japan; and Pearl Harbor also demonstrated a Japanese conspiracy to conquer Asia and dictate peace from the White House. With the publication of David Bergamini's “Japan's Imperial Conspiracy,” the history of modern Japan and the origins of the Pacific war have now been reduced to one grand conspiracy of the Japanese emperoro.
author: By James B. Crowley

headline: By Lyndon B. Johnson: The Tet Offensive
lead_paragraph: On March 31 1968 while sitting at my desk in the White House and facing the shiny eyes of the television cameras, I announced four major decisions. would not accept my party's nomina tion as candidate for another term. was stopping most; of the bombing of North Vietnam in the hope that would lead to peace. I had decided to make the expansion and modernization of South Vietnam's armed forces a goal of even higher priority. Finally, to meet existing needs, I had decided to make a small increase in the size of our own military forces in Vietnam.

headline: A shrug to the road ahead
lead_paragraph: A rapid survey of the sixties, competent, inclusive, brightly written—on the face of things, what could this be but good value?. The historian, a Rutgers professor, bends himself sen sibly at the start to demytholo gizing, praising Ike for talking rot and being resourceful, creaming Camelot for talking chic and being ineffective. He studies L.B.J. in triumph, the beginning of the desperate time in Vietnam, the emergence of the counter culture and the New Left. There's a chapter for the year of disasters, 1968 (Tet, the murders of Robert Kennedy and Martin Luther King, the Chi cago convention), and another in defense of the author's con viction that the‐end of the dec ade really ended something (“Epilogue: The Revolution Is Over”). And there are frequent diversions from straight chron ological accounting: summaries of pop culture trends; evoca tions of the early days of the period's heroes and villains (Cesar Chavez, Ralph Nader); profiles of new institutions (Women's Lib, Hell's Angels).
author: By Benjamin Demott

headline: Reader's Report
lead_paragraph: If Richard Jessup was un kind to ultra‐militant youth in his last novel “A Quiet Voyage Home,” he is doubly mean to their elders in this one. All the bad rumors about America come true, and are laid right at the doorstep of the genera tion now phasing itself out, from moral corruption to police brutality. The present victim of society's evils is an 18‐year‐old youth, emptied of illusions by two‐years’ combat service in Vietnam. (He lied about his age to enlist.) Terry Foxway comes back from the war a tabula rasa, void of all excess psychological baggage except his pragmatic conditioning for survival. The good old U.S.A. has a fine opportunity to write some nice things into Terry's personality, but everyone plays him false: his girl, his teach ers, his employers, the VIP's who admire his war record. From his parents he learns only an oppressive sense of empti ness. (“It was as if they had misplaced their lives.”)

headline: Antiwar Activities for Veterans Day Are Outlined in Washington
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 —Members of the peace move ment outlined plans today for Veterans Day antiwar activities on Monday.

headline: Saigon Students Set Fire To 6 Markets and 2 Vehicles
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnain Oct. 23 (UPI)—Militant anti Government students, angered that market vendors refused to honor their call for a general strike today attempted to burn six food markets in Saigon.

headline: National Notes
lead_paragraph: Some 100,000 young Ameri cans have fled the country, re fusing to be drafted or deserting the Army. Some 500 draft re sisters are in Federal prisons; another 3,000 have served sen tences for that crime. In mili tary stockades, 5,000 are serving sentences for crimes committed in Vietnam, another 4,500 are waiting trial and thousands more have been) less than honorably discharged from the services.

headline: TYPHOON LIMITS VIETNAM ACTION
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 23 (Reuters)—Typhoon winds reaching 140 miles an hour re stricted war action in the north today, the United States and South Vietnamese military com mands reported.

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: PARIS—It is a sad and sordid fact that armed forces of the three. West ern nations which like to consider themselves particularly civilized have been alleged to employ torture in re cent years while combating guerrilla and urban guerrilla enemies.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: 2,500 JOIN M'INTIRE AT CAPITAL RALLY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23—The Rev. Carl McIntire called today for victory in Vietnam, cancel lation of President's Nixon an nounced trip to China and re turn of prayer to public schools at his fourth rally in a year and a half.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Prof. Paul Griminger objects to con demnation of U.S. support of Saigon's corrupt, antidemocratic regime on the ground that the alternative is “domination by the even less demo cratic” Hanoi Government (letter Oct. 10). The argument, a common one, ignores both history and inter national law.

headline: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24— It is not true that the New York Congressional delega tion is just a bunch of East ern liberals. Eastern perhaps, but not necessarily “liberal.”
author: By Richard L. Madden Special to The New York Times

headline: By Lyndon B. Johnson: Withdrawal from the Race
lead_paragraph: INSTALLMENT IX

headline: TYPHOON KILLS 36 IN SOUTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 24—Typhoon Hester killed 36 persons, including three Amer icans, in South Vietnam's five northernmost provinces over the weekend, left tens of thou sands homeless and badly dam aged several American combat bases.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Edward. M. Kennedy U. S. Senator from Massachusetts Washington, Oct. 22, 1971

headline: Return of G.I.'s Delayed
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Oct. 24 (AP)— Thousands of American troops were mobilized to repair dam age estimated in the millions of dollars at three United States bases wrecked by Typhoon Hester. The bases are Chulai, the headquarters of the Amer ical Division, Danang and Camp Eagle, headquarters of the 101st Airborne Division.

headline: Antiwar Protesters Plan Washington Rally Today
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24, (UPI) —Antiwar activists will gather in Dashington tomorrow to be gin what they call “Phase One” of a two‐day plan to evict President Nixon from the White House.

headline: Scholars Seeking Right Not to Disclose Sources
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Oct. 24—A con certed legal effort to establish for scholars the same privilege to protect confidential sources that newsmen have won in some cases is being mounted in reaction to the continuing Government investigation into the publication of the Pentagon papers.
author: By Robert Reinhold Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Advisers Voicing Doubts on Saigon's Desire to Push Operation Phoenix
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25 —Many American ad visers in the provinces are voicing doubt about the willing ness of Vietnamese officials to carry out the controversial pro gram known as Operation Phoe nix, whose Purpose is to weed out Vietcong politicaL leaders.

headline: SAIGON SPEEDS AID TO TYPHOON VICTIMS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 26 (AP) — South Vietnam's Government took steps yesterday to aid victims of Typhoon Hester as officials reported 103 persons dead or missing and described the dam age as catastrophic.

headline: Advertising:
lead_paragraph: Fittingly, the day after Veterans Day Doyle Dane Bernbach is starting a job training program for veterans of Vietnam.
author: By Philip H. Dougherty

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25 (AP)—South Vietnam ese headquarters reported to day that 23 enemy soldiers were killed in two clashes in the Mekong Delta south of Saigon.

headline: Ellsberg Talks at Columbia On New Type of Veteran
lead_paragraph: Daniel Ellsberg, who has said he released the “Pentagon pa pers” to the press, spoke last night before 1,000 students at Columbia University under the sponsorship of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War?

headline: ONLY 500 PARADE ON VETERANS DAY
lead_paragraph: The annual Veterans Day parade here — held yesterday in a steady drizzle more than two weeks before the tra ditional Armistice Day observ ance—was marked by its low est turnout in years and by pleas for jobs for veterans.
author: By Jonathan Kandell

headline: The Herbert Case
lead_paragraph: The Army continues to remain silent concerning the charges by Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert that atrocities committed by American and Vietnamese intelligence personnel have been deliberately covered up. This can only create the suspicion that the Pentagon itself has joined in the alleged suppression of facts.

headline: Agnew Hails Veterans
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) A few hundred persons dot ted Arlington National Ceme tery in rainy weather today to honor America's veterans, in cluding those of the Vietnam war, who Vice President Agnew said had “paid a higher price than usual.”

headline: Survey of Attitudes Made by Americans
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25 — An official Amer ican survey of attitudes among refugees has found that many take a neutral view of the Viet cong and that they consider liv ing conditions under Commu nist control to be reasonably good.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietcong Report Freeing 4
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 125 (AP)—The Vietcong radio announced tonight that the Na tional Liberation Front had released four South Vietnamese prisoners in coastal Phuyen Province 10 days ago. The broadcast gave names, ages and ranks of four men—all regional and Popular Force militiamen. The South Viet namese Government has not reported the release of any prisoners in the area.

headline: Fame Travels With Senator Gravel, the Man Who Read Pentagon Papers Into the Record
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25— At 3 o'clock one day last week, Senator Mike Gravel, carrying a briefcase, a shav ing kit and a clean suit, left Friendship International Air port near Baltimore on a plane to Los Angeles.
author: ByDavid E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: Antiwar G.I.'s Arrested Near Ft. Hood
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex., Oct. 25 (AP) —More than 100 people— servicemen from nearby Fort Hood, their wives and support ers—were arrested today short ly after they began a Veterans Day march against the Vietnam War.

headline: U.S. Force in Vietnam Declines to 202,000
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25 (AP)—The United States command announced today that American troop strength in South Vietnam dropped by 4,000 men last week, bringing the force still remaining to 202,000.

headline: By Lyndon B. Johnson: First Steps Toward Peace
lead_paragraph: INSTALLMENT X

headline: G.I. Beaten by Civilians After Danang Traffic Crash
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25 (AP)—An American soldier was severely, beaten Sunday by an angry mob of Vietnamese civilians in DaNang and his vehiele was firebombed after it colided with a motor bike and injured two South Vietnamese, the United States command said.

headline: Arts Abroad
lead_paragraph: STUTTGART—Sixteen ma jor West German theaters, although none in the East, are in the process of staging a new play by Peter Weiss. No other play by Weiss—a writer of partly Jewish de scent who holds a Swedish passport—has thus far had a triumph comparable to his “Marat/Sade,” even though his experimental prose has been immense ly influential here. His earlier plays —on Auschwitz, Vietnam and Portuguese colonialism—had merely been successes. His most recent play before the new one, “Trotsky in Exile,” was rather weak both as a documentary and as a drama. Now “Hölderlin,” whatever its qualities and shortcom ings, is truly a major event, a play about the poet Fried rich Hölderlin.
author: By Francois Bondy Special to The New York Times

headline: 300 Arrested in Antiwar Protest Near White House
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26— More than 300 antiwar demon strators were arrested a block from the White House tonight when they sat down in the middle of Pennsylvania Avenue at the height of the evening rush hour.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Theodore J. Driesch Drexel Hill, Pa., Oct. 14, 1971

headline: Idyllic Island 50 Miles From Coast Is Picture of What Vietnam Might Be
lead_paragraph: PHUQUY ISLAND, South Vietnam, Oct. 21—The surf of the South China Sea breaks on the black volcanic rock and gently flows to the white beaches. The palm trees, heavy with coconuts, lean slightly with the breeze. The South Vietnamese who live in this idyllic setting 50 miles from the mainland worry not at all about the Vietcong but about market ing their fish, educating their children, caring for their sick, fixing the leaky roof on village headquarters and building an airstrip some day.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: By Lyndon B.Johnson: '68 Election and Final White House Days
lead_paragraph: Following is the last in the series of excerpts from the memoirs of Lyndon Baines Johnson, which will be published by Holt, Rinehart & Winston on Nov. 7 under the title “The Vantage Point: Perspectives of the Presidency, 1963‐1969”:

headline: Goldberg Disputes Johnson Memoirs on U.N. Post
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26— Arthur J. Goldberg today at tacked as false President Lyn don B. Johnson's version of how Mr. Goldberg left the Su preme Court to become the United States delegate to the United Nations in 1965.
author: By Neil Sheehan Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. TRUCK CONVOY ATTACKEDINVIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 26 (AP)—A daylight ambush of an Ameri can truck convoy and four other enemy attacks were re ported yesterday north of Sai gon.

headline: Nixon Deplores Jubilation of Delegates
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27— The White House expressed shock and dismay today at the behavior of some United Na tions delegates after the vote Monday night to admit main land China and expel the Na tionalists and said that such behavior might impair United States support for the world body.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Beatrice Boyer Flushing, N. Y., Oct. 4, 1971

headline: Vietnam Reduces Storm Toll
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 27 (AP) — As extensive new flooding was reported in the northernmost part of the coun try in the wake of last Satur day's typhoon, the Government today revised downward from 100 to 89 the South Vietnamese death toll in the storm. It said the number of deaths in a C‐47 crash as a result of the weather was 22, not 33 as reported earlier.

headline: French and Russians Sign 10‐Year Trade Agreement
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 27—The Soviet Union and France signed a 10‐ year economic agreement today as one of the major achieve ments of the visit here this week of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Merchant Who Slew Hero Wounds Robbery Suspect
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Oct. 27 (AP) — Charles Lee Van Landeghem, the store owner who shot and killed a Vietnam Medal of Honor winner, Sgt. Dwight H. Johnson, in a holdup attempt April 29, has shot and seriously wounded another apparent rob ber.

headline: AMNESTY GRANTED TO 3,000 VIETCONG
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 28—The South Vietnamese Government an nounced this morning that it would free from prison nearly 3,000 Vietcong in the largest such release of the war.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: SWEEP IN CAMBODIA FAILS TO FIND ENEMY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 28 (AP)—South Vietnamese rangers and ar mored units sought unsuccess fully yesterday to catch up with withdrawing enemy troops in the Cambodian border region northwest of here, the South Vietnamese command reported.

headline: VETERANS ISSUE TROUBLING HANOI
lead_paragraph: SAICON, South Vietnam, Oct. 27—“Previously my wife and I were in love. But be cause of the anti‐U.S. task I had to go far away. Recently I was able to return home and found that my wife had had a child by another man and that the child was four years old. I was very hurt. I hope you can give me some ad vice.”
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Cars Bombed in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 27 (AP) —Two more American cars were fire‐bombed by anti Communist demonstrators to day, bringing to 38 the number that have been attacked since early this month. No injuries were reported.

headline: Senator Gravel Seeks to Delay Jury Study on Pentagon Papers
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Oct. 27—Lawyers for Senator Mike Gravel, Demo crat of Alaska, sought today to halt a Federal grand jury in vestigating the release of the Pentagon Papers until it can be established that the Sena tor's constitutional privilege of free Congressional debate was not being violated.
author: By Robert Reinhold Special to The New York Times

headline: NIXON AND PEKING HOPING TO LIMIT SCOPE OF PARLEY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27— Henry A. Kissinger, fresh from a second exploratory visit to Peking, said today that Presi dent Nixon and the Chinese leadership hoped to restrict their substantive talks during Mr. Nixon's forthcoming China visit to issues between the two countries and would refrain from discussing issues involv ing third parties—including the issues of Soviet‐Chinese rela tions and the war in Vietnam.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Doubts Foe Will Free Captives in Reciprocal Act
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28— Administration officials said to day that they had no reason to expect the release of any Americans by the enemy in return for the freeing this Sun day of nearly 3,000 Vietcong prisoners in South Vietnam.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: South Vietnam Lets Reporters Visit P.O.W. Camp
lead_paragraph: CANTHO, South Vietnam, Oct, 28 — As part of its stepped‐up efforts to demon strate what it terms a “humani tarian” policy on the prisoner of‐war issue, the South Viet namese Government allowed a group of newsmen today to tour its prisoner‐of‐war camp here at Cantho in the Mekong Delta.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: 7 Americans Killed In Action Last Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 28 (AP) — The United States command reported to day that seven Americans were killed in action in Indo china last week, two more than the week before.

headline: U.S. May Give Saigon New Light Planes
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28— The Nixon Administration is considering providing South Vietnam with a new force of light armed aircraft to better equip it to take over the job of attacking supplies and troops moving down the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: SENATE, 47 T0 44, KILLS FUND CURB ON VIETNAM WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28—The Senate, by a three‐vote margin, today rejected a proposed amendment that would have specified that the President could not use funds in Indo china except to withdraw all American forces.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Judge Denies Motion by Gravel To Halt Pentagon Papers Jury
