lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Oct. 28—A motion by Senator Mike Gravel, Demo crat of Alaska, to halt a grand jury investigation into the pub lication of the Pentagon papers was denied today, but Federal District Judge W. Arthur Gar rity Jr. barred testimony by two key witnesses for 10 days.
author: By Robert Reinhold Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. TROOPS ON ALERT FORTHIEUINAUGURAL
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Oct. 29 (AP)—Expect ing increased enemy attacks, the United States command issued an order yesterday plac ing American troops on the alert for the weekend, cover Nguyen Van Thieu's inaugura tion for a second term.

headline: ‘Farce,’ Vietcong Charge
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 28 — The Com munist delegations to the Viet nam peace talks refused today to accept the liberation of pris oners by the Saigon Govern ment as a gesture of goodwill, and instead condemned it as a “farce.”

headline: Court Halts Jury's Inquiry on Pentagon Papers to Consider Appeal by Gravel
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Oct. 29—A grand jury investigation into the release and distribution of the secret Pentagon papers was halted for at least a week today by the, United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.
author: By Robert Reinhold Special to The New York Times

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Mary McCarthy returned to her alma mater, Vassar, for the first time since 1963, when her novel “The Group” disturbed alumnae who felt they had been maligned in the book. While Miss McCarthy lectured at seminars' and took part in other Vassar centennial activities, it was clear that all was not forgiven by the school or by the author. Miss McCarthy, for example, said she had accepted the invitation to the centennial in “a moment of generosity.” She also said the writing courses She took at Vassar in the nineteenthirties had made her style “retrogress.” Vassar's attitude toward her seemed expressed on its bookshelves. While the college book store and library had displays of boblcs by alumnae authors, including some by Miss McCarthy, not a single copy of “The Group” was shown.
author: James F. Clarity

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: Something New

headline: Vietcong Say They Used Bees to Rout U.S. Patrol
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 30 (Reuters)—The Vietcong Radio reported that guerrillas had released a swarm of bees toward a United States patrol recently, forcing them to beat “panicky retreat.”

headline: 10 IN U.S. COPTER DIE IN NHATRANG CRASH
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 30 (AP)—The United States command reported today that a big Army helicopter had crashed at sea Tuesday near Nhatrang, 195 miles northeast of Saigon and that all 10 Americans aboard had been killed.

headline: Saigon, With Officer Problem, Says New Graduates Are Better
lead_paragraph: THUDUC, South Vietnam, Oct. 20—When Ding Cong Hai failed the entrance examination to Saigon University last year, he was drafted and ordered to report to the sprawling Vietnamese officer candidate school here. He graduates shortly and will become a combat platoon leader in the infantry, to serve for the duration of the war—and who knows what that is, he said.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Delay on Calley Foreseen
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Oct. 30 (UPI)—It may be next summer before the court‐martial conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. will be heard by the United States Army Court of Military Review, the chief Judge, Maj. Gen. Kenneth J. Hodson, said yesterday.

headline: OFFICIALS SEEKING STOPGAP PROGRAM FOR FOREIGN AID
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30—The Administration took steps today to assemble a stopgap foreign aid program from the wreckage of the permanent program in the wake of the Senate's 41‐to‐27 vote yesterday killing the $3.5‐billion authorization bill.
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Guardian of the Ruins at Angkor Walks Delicate Path Amid War
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 30 — Discouraged over the world's failure to respond actively to her pleas to prevail on the Vietnamese Communists to evacuate the temples of Angkor and allow the magnificent ruins to be neutralized, Cambodia watches uneasily, while the French curator of her national monument continues to cross into enemy‐held territory to carry on his work of preservation.
author: By Henry Hamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Proposals for Reform Likely to Gain
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30—The Senate's unexpected rejection of the Nixon Administration's foreign aid authorization bill last night is likely to stimulate proposals for radically new approaches in United States assistance to other nations.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: THIEU TAKES OATH FOR 2D TIME, URGES SELF‐SUFFICIENCY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Oct. 31 — Amid tight security, President Nauyen Van Thieu took the oath of office this morning for his second four‐year term and promptly sought to prepare the South Vietnamese for the departure of American combat troops.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: U. S. Opens a Base to New Zealanders
lead_paragraph: >WOODBOITRNE, New Zealand, Jan. 31 — The United States Air Force opened one of its “classified” atmospheric observation stations to newsmen and representatives of student organizations yesterday at the request of the Prime Minister, Sir Keith Holyoake.

headline: Maskie Criticizes Nixon on the War And the Economy
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD, Jan. 31—Senator Edmund S. Muskie, the apparent front‐runner for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency in 1972, criticized the Nixon Administration tonight on the latest developments in Indochina and on the economy at home.

headline: Heavy Toll Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31—American pilots say they destroyed or damaged nearly 2,000 enemy trucks on the Ho Chi Minh Trail in January, probably the most succe.;stul month of air strikes against the trucks on record, according to military sources.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Cambodians and Ally Clash
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 31 (AP) — Fighting between South Vietnamese soldiers and their Cambodian allies broke out last night for the second time in 12 hours.

headline: California G.O.P. Hails Decision on Poverty Issue
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan.1 31—The California Republican State Central Committee (Toted today Gov. Ronald Reagan's claims of victory over the California Rural Legal Assistance Program.

headline: G.I. Held in Officer's Death
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31 (AP)—The United States command said today that Pfc. James D. Moyler of Chesapeake, Va., had been charged with murder in the shooting death of his commanding officer last Wednesday. Capt. William F. Reichert of Valley Stream, L.I., was killed at his company's base camp at Ankhe in the Central Highlands.

headline: U.S B‐52'S STRIKE FOE'S LAOS BASES AROUND THE CLOCK
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 United States 8–52's continued to bomb enemy supply bases in southern Laos around the clock today, but officials at the State and Defense Departments refused for the third consecutive day to comment on speculation that an allied attack at or across the Laotian border was imminent or under way.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Laotian Leader Questions U.S.
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Jan. 31 (Agence France‐Presse) —Premier Souvanna Phouma has been trying since this morning to verify rumors that a South Vietnamese invasion supported by United States air cover is imminent in Laos, informed sources said here.

headline: Laotians Report No Word Of an Incursion by Saigon
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 31—Officials said here today that they had received no official word of a reported incursion by South Vietnamese troops into southern Laos.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I have sympathy for—but a growing impatience with—the families of men who are in prisoner‐of‐war camps in North Vietnam or other parts of Indochina. They go to Paris and try to communicate with Hanoi. But Washington has the key to their sons' and husbands' cells, and the Nixon policy—by perpetuating our presence indefinitely through puppet regimes in Saigon and elsewhere—means that these men are sentenced for life. Furthermore; renewed bombing and air support in Cambodia mean inevitably that the number of men serving a life sentence in Hanoi and elsewhere will rapidly increase.

headline: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY AWED DRIVE IS ON IN AREA NEAR LAOS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 — Officials here reported today that a major new allied operation involving thousands of South Vietnamese and American troops was under way in the northwest corner of South Vietnam.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: SECURITY TERMED BLACKOUT REASON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 1 — From time to time in the decade‐long history of United States involvement in Vietnam, the American military command has imposed a curb on all news about a particular military operation for reasons described as security.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Laotian Stand Reiterated
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 1—Gen. Thongphan Knoksy, a Laotian military spokesman, reiterated today that Laos would be opposed to any military incursion by South Vietnamese troops.

headline: Thieu Using U.S. Surveys in Vote Campaign
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 1—National surveys of Vietnamese public opinion, which are prepared and analyzed by the United States mission here, are being used to assist President Nguyen Van Thieu in his re‐election campaign this year.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Expects Big Drive
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 1 (Agence France‐Presse)—Hanoi expects a huge intervention in southern Laos shortly by the South Vietnamese Army, backed by the United States Air Force, Nhan Dan, the Communist party daily, indicated today.

headline: Kosygin Denounces U.S.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Feb. 1 — Premier Kosygin said tonight that “an outrageous invasiou” of the southern provinces of Laos was under way and said that it further aggravated the situation in Indochina.

headline: Bunker to See Nixon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 1 — Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker left Saigon today for a week of consultation with President Nixon and talks with officials at the Paris peace negotiations.

headline: Secret Pact Reported The Washington Star
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Feb. 1—Authortative Laotian military sources said today that Laotian rightist generals had a secret agreement with the South Vietnamese that would permit South Vietnamese troops to cross into southern Laos in division strength if Saigon considered it necessary.

headline: Six G.I.'s Reported Killed in Attacks by Enemy
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 1—The United States command reported today that six American soldiers had been killed and more than 26 wounded in an upsurge of enemy attacks on American positions in South Vietnam.

headline: REPORT ON ATTACK AWAITED AS NIXON MEETS KEY AIDES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 —President Nixon called a meeting of his leading military and diplomatic advisers at the White House late today, apparently to review the progress of the major new allied operation under way in northwestern South Vietnam.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: 3 American Die in Ambush
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Wednesday, Feb 3 (Reuters) — Three Americans were killed and one was wounded during the night when the enemy ambushed a convoy of the 18th Engineer Brigade, the United States command reported today.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In judging President Nixon's statement that “he inherited the war,” which was repeated in your lead editorial of Jan. 10, may I suggest that the following be kept in mind?

headline: Foe's Return Reported
lead_paragraph: NEAK LEUNG, Cambodia. Feb. 2 (Reuters)—Senior Cambodian officers said today that the Vietcong were returning to sanctuaries cleared by South Vietnamese and United States troops last summer and building new ones opposite South Vietnam.

headline: LAOTIANS REPORT BIG ENEMY PUSH
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Wednesday, Feb. 3—Defense Minister Sisouk na Champassak announced today what appeared to be the beginning of a major North Vietnamese offensive in northern Laos.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: And Now Laos
lead_paragraph: A drive of South Vietnamese troops into the southern panhandle of Laos would, if it should occur, have profound implications for the future of the Southeast.Asian conflict, none of them encouraging for the prospect American disengagement from the area.

headline: Hanoi Party Heads Pressing for Gains In Economic Area
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 2 (Agence France‐Presse)—The Central Committee of the governing Workers party has called on the nation's armed forces and people to make new efforts “for ultimate victory and the progress of socialism in North Vietnam.”

headline: Paris Concerned Over Laos
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 2, (Reuters)—President Pompidou today expressed increasing concern over expansion of the Indochina conflict. He reaffirmed at a Cabinet meeting France's particular interest in Laotian independence and neutrality, amid reports of a South Vietnamese incursion into Laos.

headline: Incursion Issue Splits Laotian Leaders
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 2—Reports here of a possible incursion by South Vietnamese troops against the Ho Chi Minh Trail in southern Laos—so far tmconfirmed—have revived differences within the nation's leadeiship over the conduct of the war in Laos.

headline: Vietnam Fighting Increases
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 2 (AP)—Allied commanders reported a series of small ground clashes and a surge in enemy rocket and mortar attacks today. They said that as a result, battle action in South Vietnam was at its highest point in about 10 months.

headline: Japanese Report Invasion On
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Feb. 2 — The oftrumored invasion of Laos by South Vietnamese troops has begun, the Kyodo news agency reported today in a dispatch from its Saigon correspondent. Though all major Japanese newspapers here have correspondents in Saion, none of them matched the Kyodo report. In the absence of any confirmation, sources here tended to evaluate the report with caution.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2—There is an old rule of politics that you should never give your opponent a clear and easy target to shoot at, but President Nixon seems to be hoisting a new one every other day.
author: By James Reston

headline: U.S. Officers Mentioned
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (UPI)—The Soviet Government newspaper Irvestia said today:

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Jan. 16 Op‐Ed article by J. C. Thomson Jr. proposes an open admission of American defeat in Vietnam followed by a precipitate withdrawal:

headline: Kosygin Again Charges That U.S. Is Widening War in Indochina
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Feb. 2—Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin said today that the latest developments in Indochina demonstrated that despite repeated statements about peaceful intentions, the United States “still advances along the road of aggression.”
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Vast Truck Movement
lead_paragraph: QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, Feb. 2 (Agence France‐Presse) —Thousands of military trucks moved bumper to bumper today along the two highways leading toward Laos and North Vietnam. Along the sides of the roads troops with full field packs and arms were also moving in uninterrupted columns. Hundreds of helicopters passed overhead.

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON. Feb. 2—Sew eral times American field commanders and rear‐echelon planners have unsuccessfully requested authority to mount ground thrust into Laos to cut the Ho Chi Minh Trail.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: PARIS—During recent weeks both the North Vietnamese and Chinese have hinted by discreet questioning some nervousness about the chances that the United States might introduce tactical nuclear weapons in Indochina. This is obviously part of the psychological warfare preceding possible offensives by both sides.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Laotian Positions Overrun
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 3—Striking during the night in northern Laos, North Vietnamese troops overran several Laotian positions on the northwestern fringes of the Plaine des Jarres and near the royal capital of Luang Prabang, the Defense Ministry here reported.

headline: Westmoreland in Ethiopia
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 3 (AP)—Gen. William C. Westmoreland, Chief of Staff of the United States Army and former commander of the American forces in South Vietnam, arrived here today. He will visit a number of army installations and also tour the communications base at Asmara. From here he will go to India, Thailand and Iran.

headline: ANTIWAR MOVEMENT SETS APRIL RALLIES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3—The antiwar movement proclaimed itself reunited today and announced that it would hold demonstrations in the spring to protest the expansion of American air action in Indochina.

headline: Raids on Trail Continue
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Feb. 3 — The United States command today reported continued raids by B‐52's over the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos.

headline: South Vietnamese Attack In Cambodia Is Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 3 — South Vietnamese officials reported tonight that 10,000 Government troops were engaged in a new campaign in Cambodia to clean out what were described as enemy border sanctuaries.

headline: Soviet Says Laos ‘Invasion’ Perils Settlement Efforts
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Feb. 3—The Soviet Union today denounced what it called “the armed invasion by United States and Saigon puppet troops” in Laos.

headline: Senators Assail Secrecy
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3—The official embargo on news reports from Saigon about the South Vietnamese operation at the Laotian border was severely criticized today by several leading Democrats and Republican Senators.

headline: MAJOR DRIVE NEAR LAOS BY G.I.'S AND VIETNAMESE IS ANNOUNCED IN SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 4—United States and South Vietnamese troops have launched a major operation into the northwest corner of South Vietnam, the United States command announced. This cleared the way for a possible South Vietnamese strike against the Ho Ohi Minh Trail in Laos.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Laotian Island in Mekong Waits in Eye of the Storm
lead_paragraph: KHONG ISLAND, Laos, Feb. 3 — This island in the broad Mekong River is set in the eye of the storm but seems the most tranquil corner of Indochina.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Capitalist Music Brings Jail
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 3 (UPI) —A Hanoi newspaper said today that eight North Vietnamese musicians had been sentenced to prison terms of up to 15 years for having played what was termed capitalistic music.

headline: U.S. News Blackout in Saigon Tried To Keep Even Its Existence Secret
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4—For correspondents and military men alike, the newly lifted blackout of news from the northwest corner of South Vietnam was six days of confusion, cloak‐and‐dagger secrecy and a seemingly endless effort to keep secret even the fact that a news blackout existed.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York York

headline: U.S. Officials Say Invasion Of Laos is Still Possible
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 — Ofcials continued today to hold open the possibility of a South Vietnamese strike against the Ho CM Minh Trail in southern Laos.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Article 3 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 4—“Those goddam tankers!” Specialist 4 Steven Hill said as he leaned on his surveyor's staff the other day and peered through the mist at a line of artillery tanks grinding along the road his engineering battalion had just reopened to this damp, cloud‐swept field.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Laos to Protest Communist ‘Offensive’
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 4—Premier Souvanna Phouma said today he would protest to Britain and the Soviet Union, cochairmen of the Geneva Conference of 1962, over what he termed a new offensive launched this week in northern Laos by North Vietnamese and Communist — led Pathet Lao troops. He stated the protest would be over attacks yesterday on points near the royal capital of Luang Prabang and the capture the sume clay of Muong Suoi, an important Gpvernment defense position on western fringe of the Plaine des Jarres.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: TROOPS OF ALLIES MASS NEAR LAOS; CROSSING DENIED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 — Thousands of American and South Vietnamese troops, supported by armored columns and planes, were moving near the Laotian border today in the northwestern corner of South Vietnam.
author: By Alvin Shuster  Special to The New York Times

headline: Cambodians Join Vietnamese Operation
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 4—The Cambodian command said tonight that Cambodian troops were participating in the new sweep in Cambodia announced yesterday by South Vietnamese officials in Saigon.

headline: Memories of the ’68 Siege Linger at Foggy Khesanh
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 4—The ghosts of past battles mingle with the fog over this fortress in the mountains of the northwest corner of South Vietnam.

headline: 29 U.S. Battle Deaths Are Reported for Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 (AP) — The United States command reported today that 29 Americans were killed in action in Vietnam last week, compared with 50 the week before, and that 15 others died of accidents and other nonhostile causes.

headline: McGovern, Speaking at Dinner Here, Urges Presidential Primary in State
lead_paragraph: Senator George S. McGovern of South Dakota, here for dinner of the New York City Democratic Committee, said last night that he hoped the New York Legislature would approve a Presidential primary in the state in time for the 1972 campaign.
author: By Clayton Knowles

headline: Article 4 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 4 (Agence France‐Presse) —Hanoi was calm today despite reports in the official press of “tens of thousands of Saigon troops massed” on the Laotian border for an expected “escalation” ha the United States.

headline: U.S. Pacifist to Leave Japan
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Feb. 4 (Reuters)—Barbara Bye, an American pacifist, today ended a three‐month fight to enter Japan to conduct an antiwar campaign and said she would leave the country tomorrow. Miss Bye, a 26‐year‐old Quaker from Doylestown, Pa., has been at a Tokyo Airport hotel under guard since she was refused entry Oct 30.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb, 4—The main Issue in the latest allied offensive in Indochina is not the “news blackout” on military operations, but the policy question of why the South Vietnamese, with a million men under arms and an air force of over 600 planes, are still relying on massive U.S. air support to break up enemy troop concentrations and supplies.
author: By James Reston

headline: New Drives Into Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 (UPI) — Military spokesman reported today that 11,000 South Vietnamese troops had pushed across the border into the Fishhook region of Cambodia to join about 7,500 other Cambodians clearing enemy sanctuaries.

headline: Peking Ministry Warns U.S. On Laos Border Build‐Up
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Feb. 4—Communist China, in a statement condemning the allied troop build‐up along the Vietnam‐Laos border, said today that she would absolutely not allow the United States to “do whatever it pleases in Indochina.”

headline: Article 2 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 — It was, as one man put it, just a dusty and rambling combat outpost drawn like a girdle around a 3,000‐foot airstrip. But its name, Khesanh, became in 1968 one of the darkest horrors of the Vietnam war.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Wider War in Laos?
lead_paragraph: The strategy of widening the war territorially in Southeast Asia in order to reduce the American involvement defies all logic. Yet the Administration, having chosen that route in Cambodia, has had to argue that that strategy is succeeding. In the process, it may have convinced itself that the war should be widened further—into Laos.

headline: Saigon Defends an Invasion
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 4—South Vietnam today defended large‐scale operations into Laos and Cambodia by accusing North Vietnam of threatening its security through aggression in those countries.

headline: G.I.'s Feel They're Preparing the Way
lead_paragraph: LANGVEI, South Vietnam. Feb. 4—American soldiers on one of their largest and perhaps one of their last major combat operations, appeared relaxed today—because so far they have had no large clashes with North Vietnamese troops — and relieved—because they had orders not to attack the enemy in Laos, which is only a few miles from here.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: The Ho Chi Minh Trail: A Spidery, Constantly Shifting Route
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4—As in every year of the Vietnam war, the abatement of the monsoon rains last fall brought a quickening of enemy activity along the spidery track network through Laos that is known as the Ho Chi Minh Trail.

headline: Newsmen's Group In Saigon Protests Scope of Embargo
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5 — The Association of Foreign Correspondents in Vi etnam charged today that the American command's order bar ring mention of the six‐day news embargo on the military operation near the Laotian bor der had “deprived news corre spondents from exercising their elementary professional respon sibility.”

headline: South Vietnamese Forces Reported Preparing for ‘Imminent’ Drive Into Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5—Preparations were re ported under way today in the northwestern corner of South Vietnam for a South Vietnam ese attack on enemy supply routes in Laos.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Letter to the Editor 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: Letters to the Editor
author: MATTHEW LAUFER Bronx, Jan. 31, 1971

headline: Toll in Cambodia Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Feb. 5 (UPI) —Mil‐ itary spokesmen said here to day that South Vietnamese and Cambodian troops searching suspected enemy sanctuaries in Cambodia had reported killing 69 Communists in a battle yes terday. The allied toll was put at 7 South Vietnamese killed and 28 wounded.

headline: Deeper and Deeper in Southeast Asia
lead_paragraph: Letters to the Editor
author: GEORGE K. SARGENT 3d New York, Jan. 28, 1971

headline: New Pressure in Laos
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 5— North Vietnamese and Laotian Communist‐led forces today were reported to be continu ing their pressure on Govern ment forces in northern Laos with small‐scale attacks and aggressive patrolling near Sam Thong and Long Tieng, 80 air miles north of Vientiane. Both are Government‐hed mountain strongpoints near the Plaine des Jarres.

headline: U.S. OFFICIALS FEEL NIXON HAS DECIDED ON STRIKE IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 — Strong indications emerged here today that the Nixon Admin istration had decided to golf ahead with a strike by South Vietnamese troops against enemy supply lines in southern Laos.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Why We Escalated
lead_paragraph: Tomorrow marks the sixth anniver sary of America's massive intervention in Vietnam, a decision which was sig naled by the bombing of the North, a decision which ultimately cost Lyn don Johnson a second term and shat tered his dream of creating a Great Society.
author: By Arnold C. Brackman

headline: Name of Drive by Allies Tied to Wet ‘69 Battle
lead_paragraph: The allied operation in the northern part. of South Viet nam is code‐named Dewey Canyon II, after a 1969 cam paign in the same area in which United States Marines seized several hilltops just inside the Laotian border.

headline: Letter to the Editor 2 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: Letters to the Editor

headline: A Laotian General Cool to Bigger War
lead_paragraph: DONG HENE, Laos, Feb. 5 —The commander of Laotian combat troops in the center of the panhandle of Laos said at his beleaguered forward command post today that the situation was critical and he did not expect to be able to hold out under mounting North Vietnamese pressure.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: SOVIET IS TERSE IN APOLLO REPORT
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Feb. 5 — Soviet television viewers got a brief look tonight at Comdr. Edgar D. Mitchell and Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr. walking on the moon, juxtaposed with a long condemnation of what was called the “American and South Vietnamese puppet invasion” of Laos.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—To many here, it's the “last hurrah”—the last big American operation in Vietnam before the bulk of the Army goes home. The Green Machine hummed, the helicopters chat tered, the jets roared and 9,000 American troops moved into ac tion in South Vietnam's northern most province of Quangtri.
author: ‐Alvin Shuster

headline: No Comment in Washington
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6—The Administration refused all com ment today on charges that American‐supported South Viet namese forces had invaded Laos.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Once again debate welled up over the di visive issue of Indochina, and specifically whether the Admin istration's policy of “Vietnami zation” would speed disengage ment or lead to still deeper entanglement.
author: ‐Terence Smith

headline: Eisenhower Revisited— A Political Genius? A Brilliant Man?
lead_paragraph: IT has been slightly more than a decade since Robert Frost greeted the dawn of a “next Augustan age . . . of poetry and power” and Dwight D. Eisenhower, ex‐President, left Washington for Gettysburg—still an immensely popular figure who, had the law permitted and the spirit and the flesh been willing, could easily have been the man taking the oath of office on January 20, 1961, thus deferring the Augustan age for at least four more years. Eisenhower was held in high esteem for the rest of his life, but throughout most of the sixties those amateurs who sit in more or less professional judgment on Presidents—other politicians, his torians, journalists—came more and more into agreement that his eight years in the White House had been a period of meager accomplishment and lackadaisical leadership. The greatest failure, the consensus seemed to be, was one of anticipation. What a prescient statesman could have foreseen in the fifties, the argu ment runs, was that the ship of state was headed for a sea of troubles, and this the 34th President conspicu ously failed to perceive. He lacked foresight and imagination and thus bore considerable responsibility for the difficulties of the three men who succeeded him in the sixties.
author: By Richard H. Rovere

headline: CALLEY IS RELEASED AFTER SANITY CHECK
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 6 (AP—Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., released from Walter Reed Army Hospital in Washington upon completion of a sanity board hearing, has returned to Georgia to resume his court martial.

headline: Invasion On, Rebels Say
lead_paragraph: TOKYO. Feb. 6 (AP) — The Communist‐led Pathet Lao charged today that South Viet namese troops had invaded southern Laos and reached Tchepone, 20 miles inside the country, the Kyodo news ser vice reported.

headline: Military Justice on Trial
lead_paragraph: The dismissal of all court‐martial charges against Maj. Gen. Samuel W. Koster in connection with the Mylai tragedy raises serious doubts about the military's will ingness to discipline itself.

headline: OBSERVER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 — Suddenly it is extremely important to upper drawer White House people to be kidnapped. This began when the F.B.I. accused several nuns and priests of planning to kidnap Henry Kissinger of the White House staff. According to Hoover, the ecclesiastics intended to hold Kissinger until the United States agreed to end the Vietnam war.

headline: New Risks in Indochina
lead_paragraph: “If they're going to keep us out of it, I wish they'd keep us out of all of it,” a G.I. at Khesanh remarked the other day. “This way is like playing games.”

headline: VETERANS ASSESS ATROCITY BLAME 100 Who Served in Vietnam Hold Leaders at Fault
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Feb. 6—Some vet erans of the Vietnam war who say they saw and took part in atrocities insist that the bur den of guilt should be passed upward.
author: By Jerry M. Flint Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I. in South Vietnam Jailed In Shooting of a Teen‐Ager
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 (AP) — An American soldier was convicted today of negligent homicide in the shoot ing of a Vietnamese teen‐ager last December that touched off two days of anti‐American rioting in Quinhon and Saigon. A seven‐officer court‐martial

headline: Allied Troops at Border; Laos Invaded, Rebels Say
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 6—Thousands of South Vietnamese troops massed along the main highway to Laos today. They were only a few miles from the border.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Looking Toward the 1972 Campaign
lead_paragraph: Letters to the Editor
author: JOHN B. HARRISON East Lansing, Mich., Jan. 29, 1971

headline: JACKSON COURTED BY PARTY HAWKS Hard‐Line Democrats Urge Presidential Bid in ‘72
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 — Is there a place for a hawk in na tional Democratic politics?
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: No G.I.'s Used in Laos, Pentagon Says
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Monday, Feb. 8—The Nixon Administration said today that “No United States ground combat person ??el or advisers will be involved” in the incursion into Laos.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON UNITS DRIVE INTO LAOS TO STRIKE ENEMY SUPPLY LINE
lead_paragraph: Text of the Thieu statement will be found on Page 14.

headline: Text of Thieu's Message on Laos Drive
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 — Following is the text of Presi dent Nguyen Van Thieu's message, as released tonight by the South Vietnamese Em bassy here, on the operations in Laos:

headline: How Troops Entered Laos
lead_paragraph: ON THE LAOTIAN BORDER, Monday, Feb. 8 (Reuters)— South Vietnamese troops poured across the border into Laos early today beneath an um brella of American helicopter gunships.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Ernest Lieber M.D

headline: Student Peace Group Urges Protest Against Laos Action
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 7— A national student conference on a “people's peace treaty” ended today with calls for demonstration in Washington during the first week of May and nationwide local demon strations Wednesday to protest what the conference charged was an invasion of Laos. The conference ended before the formal announcement was made of the drive into Laos.

headline: Students Here Press Klein on Laos
lead_paragraph: Herbert G. Klein, President Nixon's Director of Communi cations, came here yesterday to talk to journalism students about Presidential news con ferences but spent much of his time answering their angry questions about Laos. United Press International reported.

headline: Heavy Enemy Fire Reported
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, Feb. 8 (UPI)— “We took so much fire I couldn't believe it,” a helicop ter pilot who was shot down during today's South Viet namese incursion into Laos said on his return here. “There were a lot of Communists all over the place.”

headline: Plan to Cut Enemy's Lines in Laos Long Rejected, Was. Revived 3 Months Ago
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 8—The old plan for a ground attack on the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos took on new life here at least three months ago in talks between South Vietnamese and American of ficials.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Condemnation in Paris
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 8—The Commu nist delegations to the Vietnam peace conference here joined with the French Government today in condemning the incur sion into Laos by South Viet namese forces as an extension of the war. Both the North Vietnamese and the Vietcong, however, refrained from threats to boycott the talks.

headline: China Charges Provocation
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Feb. 8—Com munist China has described the Laos incursion as a “grave prov ocation” against the Chinese people as well as the people of Indochina and the whole world.

headline: Geneva Accord Excerpts
lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the declaration signed at Geneva on July 23, 1962, by 13 nations including the United States, North Vietnam and South Vietnam:

headline: Fairfield U. Students Occupy Campus Center
lead_paragraph: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Tues day, Feb. 9—A group of stu dents protesting the Nixon Administration's policies in Laos took over the Campus Center at Fairfield University last night.

headline: Cambodians Voice Hope
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 8—Cambodians who learned of the South Vietnamese attack in Laos voiced hope tonight that it would take pressure off their own country. The news reached here tonight, but for the last week there had been rumors and speculation about the pen etration into Laos.

headline: SOUTH VIETNAMESE REACH FOE'S SUPPLY LINE IN LAOS; 2 U.S. COPTERS SHOT DOWN
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 9—South Vietna mese troops moved into some areas of the enemy's supply route network in southern Laos yesterday, hours after having swept across the border in armored columns and Ameri can‐piloted helicopters.

headline: U.S. Strength in Vietnam Declines to 335,000 Men
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 8 (AP) —The United States Command announced today that American troop strength in South Vietnam dropped Iast week by 800 men, lowering the total to 335,000.

headline: Purpose in Laos: A Shorter War
lead_paragraph: News Analysis
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Calls Move ‘Limited’;
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8—The United States today portrayed the American‐backed South Vietnamese invasion of Laos as a limited operation to protect “the security and safety of American forces in South Viet nam.”
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Enlarging the War
lead_paragraph: Hours after South Vietnamese troops crossed into Laos with strong American logistical and fire support, the State Department declared that this massive operation “is not an enlargement of the war.”

headline: Text of the U.S. Statement on Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb.8 (AP) —Following is the text of a statement made today by the State Department on the South Vietnamese incursion into Laos:

headline: A Newsman Charges His Camera Was Seized
lead_paragraph: QUANGTRI, South Viet nam, Feb. 8—A South Viet namese cameraman working on assignment for the Na tional Broadcasting Company said today that an American helicopter crewman forcibly took his movie camera from him and threw it from the helicopter as it flew South Vietnamese combat troops over Laos. According to the newsman, Hoang Trong Nghia, the crewman had said he was acting under orders.

headline: Soviet Warns U.S.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Feb. 8 (Reuters)— Tass, the Soviet press agency, warned the United States to day that it had taken on grave responsibility before world opinion by deciding on “fur ther dangerous expansion of aggression against the peoples of Indochina.”

headline: Benefits Seen in Vientiane
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 8— There was a general feeling here today that if the South Vietnamese incursion into southern Laos went well it would deal a serious blow to the North Vietnamese. It was felt that the drive could prove beneficial to Laos in the long run even if at the moment it added to the problems of her international relations.
author: By Tillman Durbin Special to The New York Times

headline: Pathet Lao Protests
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Feb. 8 (Reuters) —The pro‐Communist Pathet Lao in an urgent protest has asked Britain and the Soviet Union to take steps to compel the United States to halt its “aggressive operation in Laos.”

headline: First Battle lit Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Tuesday, Feb. 9 (Reuters) — South Vietnamese troops engaged in their first battle with North Vietnamese forces in Laos and lost three dead and 20 wounded, a Gov ernment military spokesman said here today.

headline: Incursion by Saigon Generates Only Scattered Protests in U.S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8—The South Vietnamese incursion into Laos generated only scat tered protests around the na tion today, in marked contrast to outbursts last spring follow ing the move into Cambodia.

headline: Thant Deplores Operations
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Feb. 8 (AP) — Secretary General Thant expressed fear today that operations in Laos by the North Vietnamese and now the South Vietnamese might be the death blow for the 1962 Geneva agreement. A statement issued by his office said: “The report ed incursion into Laos of South Vietnamese armed forces sup ported by the United States Air Force is one more deplorable episode in the long history of the barbarous war in Indo china.”

headline: Along the Road to Laos: Noise, Dust, Confusion
lead_paragraph: BANHOUEKATANG, South Vietnam, Feb. 8—The artil lery fired over this little bor der crossing into Laos all night, and the young South Vietnamese Rangers who climbed aboard their boxy ar mored personel carriers to invade Laos this morning said they had not been able to sleep well.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Understandable,’ Britain Says
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Feb. 8 (UPI)—Brit ain today termed the South Viet namese action in Laos “fully understandable.” A Foreign Office spokesman said that the British Government was in con stant touch with the South Vietnamese and United States Governments on the situation in Southeast Asia.

headline: Chronology of U.S. Involvement in Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. R—Fol lowing is a chronology of events and decisions that marked the increasing United States in volvement in Laos:

headline: Fighting Near Plain
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 9 (UPI) — North Vietnamese troops and Pathet Lao guerrillas have opened attacks against Government positions around ong Tieng, Laotian military pokesmen said today.

headline: Rain, Fog and Mud Slow Drive Into Laos
lead_paragraph: QUANGTRI. South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 10—Heavy rains and dense fog fell un expectedly over the South Viet ramose drive against enemy sup ply trails in Laos yesterday, virtually halting United States helicopter supply flights and other air support.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Richard M. Brett

headline: Laird and Rogers, Explaining Drive, Seem to Modify G.I Withdrawal Plan
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9—The Secretary of State and the Secretary of Defense went to Capitol Hill today with the message that the incursion into Laos would insure American troop withdrawals from Viet nam and shorten the war.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9—In this latest crisis in the. Indochina war, when we are being told once more that the latest adventure into Laos will surely put an end to the long agony, it may be pru dent to look back at the record.
author: By James Reston

headline: North Vietnam Election Set
lead_paragraph: HANOI. North Vietnam, Feb. (Agence France‐Presse)—North Vietnam will hold its first legis lative elections since 1964 on April 11, an official statement said today. The country will elect 420 members of National Assembly. The voting age in North Vietnam is 18.

headline: The Marines Stand Fast
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON— Marines are facing new challenges. Transition is the key word, undiminished professionalism is the standard. For the marines and for the Corps, the commandant set a minimum requirement lean, tough, professional, disciplined, fully combat ready. In spite of troop withdrawals that have reduced the Marine Corps commitment from a 1968 high of 86,730 to the present strength of 24,800, the marines' pacification and Vietnamization efforts continue.
author: By Lewis W. Walt

headline: Reds Said to Buy Laotian Rice
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 9— Well‐informed American sources here say that the South Vietnamese incursion into the Ho Chi Minh Trail area in the northern sector of the Laos panhandle will not cut the North Vietnamese off from food supplies.

headline: Laos Incursion Is Given Vietnamese Code Name
lead_paragraph: Operation Dewey Canyon II, the United States com mand announced in Saigon yesterday, is no more. The command has adopted the South Vietnamese designa tion, Lam Son 719.

headline: Soviet Gives No Sign. It Will Act on Laos
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Feb. 9—The So viet Union continued to de nounce the United States today for the allied incursion into Laos but gave no sign that it would take any action to bol ster the Communist cause in Indochina.

headline: U.S. AIDES BELIEVE THRUST MAY COST FOE YEAR OR MORE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9—Ad ministration planners asserted privately today that the allied military incursion into Laos could buy a year or possibly two during which it would be extremely hard for North Viet nam to mount an effective of fensive of any size in either South Vietnam or Cambodia.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Laotians to Explain Views
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 9— Laotian missions abroad acted today on a worldwide basis to explain Laotian objections to the advance begun yesterday by South Vietnamese troops, with United States air support, against North Vietnamese trans port routes and bases along the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Warns Allies
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 9 (Agence France‐Presse)—The North Vietnamese press and radio warned the United States and South Vietnam today that the “liberated zone of Laos” would be “the tomb of the Americans and their agents.”

headline: Britain Ready to Consult
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP)— Foreign Secretary Sir Alec Douglas‐Home today expressed Britain's readiness to consult with China and the Soviet Union on ways of negotiating an Indochina peace settlement.

headline: Road Damage Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 10 (AP)— South Vietnamese troops and tanks, pressing west in south ern Laos yesterday, were re ported slowed both by bad weather and by the craters gouged in the road by United States bombers.

headline: Protest Rallies and Marches Set For Today on Drive Into Laos
lead_paragraph: Protest rallies and marches by students opposed to the drive into Laos are scheduled for today in various places across the country, but indi cations are that they may be more subdued those those over Cambodia last spring.

headline: Ky Asserts an Invasion Of North Is Way to Win
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 9 (Agence France Presse)—Vice President Ngu yen Cao Ky has warned against treating the” South Vietnamese operation in Laos as a game of double or noth ing and has suggested that the best way to make sure of winning is to invade North Vietnam.

headline: G.I.'s Report Fighting
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 10 (UPI) — Some United States soldiers belonging to Troop D, Seventh Battalion, 17th Air Cavalry, said here today that 100 or more Amer ican ground troops had been in Laos during the last three days and had fought the Com munists, but United States spokesmen denied that any American ground forces were in Laos.

headline: Troops Frisky as They Entered Laos
lead_paragraph: Th following account was given by Nguyen Ngoc Luong, a Vietnamese part time correspondent of The New York Times who ac companied South Vietnamese troops into Laos.

headline: Laotian General Said to Ask for Reinforcements
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 10— Concern increased here today over the situation at Sam Thong and Long Tieng, the two im portant Governrinent positions southwest of Plaine des Janes that have come under inereas ing pressure from North Viet namese and Laotian Communist forces.

headline: ADAMANCY BY FOE IN PARIS EXPECTED
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 10—Any possi bility of serious negotiation at the Vietnam peace talks has apparently been written off for the next few months by the United States.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Rogers Says U.S. Supports An Indochina Peace Parley
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10— Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States would give its unqualified support to “any kind of conference, in any for mat” that would bring peace to Indochina.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Incursion Into Laos Fails to Overcome the Torpor of Vientiane
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 10 —Torpor runs high in Vien tiane, the most lively town in Laos, on any day, so it is difficult to tell that today is Makhabouxa, a major Bud dist feast and public holiday. But to those interested in official activities it became plain by midmorning that Government offices, instead of opening late, were not opening at all.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: THOUSANDS IN U.S. PROTEST ON LAOS
lead_paragraph: About 2,000 persons demon strated here last evening against the Laos incursion and about 3.000 marched on the Boston Common.
author: By Martin Arnold

headline: Airstrip Being Rebuilt
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Feb. 10 (AP)— South Vietnamese sources re ported that after the task force reached Tchepone today engi neers began rebuilding the town's abandoned dirt airstrip, which will enable the South Vietnamese to fly in supplies and reinforcements.

headline: 4 Photographers Missing as Copter Is Downed in Laos
lead_paragraph: A helicopter carrying sev eral news photographers was shot down yesterday in Laos. There was no indica tion of survivors.

headline: KY PREDICTS STAY IN LAOS TILL MAY AND FUTURE DRIVE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 10 — Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that South Vietnamese forces would probably remain in Laos until the dry season ends in May and predicted that they would go in again next year.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: SENATE GETS CURB ON USE OF TROOPS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10—A new effort to impose legislative restrictions on the war‐making powers of the President began in the Senate today amid indi cations that there is conserva tive support for it in Congress.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Copter Pilots Taking Some of Worst Fire of War
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 11—“I've been flying for six months, took my first hit yesterday, and since then I've taken 13,” said Maj. Burt Al len of Obion, Tenn., as he brought his bullet‐pierced heli copter in for a safe ??ding here today.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: 12 Jailed and Student Shot In Stanford Clash on War
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 11 —A high school student was shot, three other persons were injured and at least 12 were arrested last night as several hundred radicals protesting Stanford University's involve ment in the Southeast Asian war clashed with the police.

headline: DAVID KENNEDY GETS SAIGON ASSIGNMENT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (Reu ters)—David M. Kennedy, for mer Secretary of the Treasury, was assigned by President Nixon today to help South Vietnam repair its war‐ravaged economy and to plan for peace full development when the Indo china conflict ends.

headline: DRIVE TO CRASH SITE IN LAOS IS DOUBTED
lead_paragraph: QUANG TRI, South Vietnam, Feb. 11 (AP) — It appeared doubtful today that troops could reach the site of a heli copter shot down in southern Laos with four press photogra phers aboard.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Paul Bixler

headline: U. S. Reconnaissance in Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 11 (AP)—Official sources said today that United States recon naissance teams were operating inside Laos—but only in an intelligence‐gathering role—and that there were no American ground combat troops in that country.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Harry F. V. Edward

headline: AMERICAN TROOPS REPORTED IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: Reports broadcast by the American Broadcasting Com pany and the Columbia Broad casting System yesterday said that American ground troops were taking part in the South Vietnamese incursion into southern Laos, some in South Vietnamese uniforms.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Doris R. Marston

headline: 3 G.I.'S INDICTED IN CAMP BOMBING
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 11 — A Federal grand jury indicted today three Army enlisted men, one o them a Vietnam War veteran, on charges or stealing explosives and blowing up telephone exchange, an electric substation and a water works at Camp McCoy, Wis., last July.

headline: Operation in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. Feb. 11 (AP) — South Vietnamese military headquarters reported today that its troops operating in eastern Camboiia had killed 164 enemy soldiers in six engage ments.

headline: 24 U.S. Combat Deaths Reported in Last Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 11 (UPI)—United States headquarters said today that 24 Americans were killed in battle in Vietnam last week, the lowest seven‐day toll this year. But South Vietnamese combat deaths increased sharply.

headline: Communists at Paris Talks Say 10 U.S. Battalions Fight in Laos
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 11—Communist representatives at the Vietnam peace talks said today that 10 American battalions were en gaged in ground combat in Laos and named the divisions the units came from—the Fifth Mechanized, the 101st Airborne and the Americal. But the American spokesman, Stephen Ledogar, accusing the Com munists of “heaping exaggera tions upon lies,” said, “That's all nonsense.”

headline: Resistance Termed Light As Laos Drive Continues
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 12—South Vietnam ese forces were reported push ing deeper into Laos today in the fifth day of their drive against enemy supply trails and bases. But it was said they had not yet encountered the kind of ground resistance that was ex pected when the push began on Monday.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Charles O'Nell

headline: Hanoi Accuses U.S.
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 11 (Agence France‐Presse) — The Foreign Ministry charged today that American warships invaded North Vietnamese ter ritorial waters off Quangbinh Province in southern North Vietnam last night and shelled fishing vessels and junks, kill ing a number of persons and wounding others.

headline: Protest by Pathet Lao
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Feb. 12 (AP) — Prince Souphanouvong, head of the Pathet Lao, the Commu nist‐led Laotian rebels, has ur gently asked the cochairmen of the Geneva Conference to stop what he called an aggressive operation in Laos by United States and South Vietnamese troops.

headline: Big Gap at the Briefings on Laos
lead_paragraph: News Analysis
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: A.B.C. Report Is Denied
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 (AP)—The United States Command issued a state ment today denying a report by the American Broadcasting Company indicating that Amer ican advisers were operating with South Vietnamese air borner units in Laos.

headline: SAILOR IS FREED IN LOYALTY CASE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) — The United States Navy Court of Military Review has reversed the court‐martial conviction of Seaman Roger L. Priest of Houston on charges of promoting disloyalty in the armed fortes by publication of an antiwar newsletter.

headline: Laos Declares Emergency As Red Pressure Mounts
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 12— Laos declared a state of emer gency today and transferred in ternal security matters from the police to military officers. A Government statement said that the change had been made because of “recent develop ments in the military situation.”
author: By Tillman Durbin Special to The New York Times

headline: Bayh Supports 18‐Year‐Old Vote in All Elections
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON. Feb. 12— Senator Birch Bayh, sounding like a man with his eye on the 1972 national campaign, grasped the initiative today in the cam paign to lower the voting age to 18 an all elections.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: RED CHINA WARNS ON MOVE IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Saturday, Feb. 13—Communist China declared yesterday that it “will not re main indifferent” to the recent incursion into Laos by “large numbers of U.S. and puppet forces.”

headline: Polish Note Deplores U.S. Intervention in Laos
lead_paragraph: WARSAW, Feb. 12 — The Polish Government moved to day as a member of the In ternational Control Commission for Laos to seek an end to American military intervention there.
author: By James Feron Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Feb. 12—Stuart Hamp shire, the English philosopher, wrote recently of the impact of Freud's dem onstration that human behavior is gov erned less by conscious than by unconscious thoughts and feelings. It was a Copernican revelation for men who understood, he said; it destroyed the “comfortable feeling that we are easily in control of our own thoughts and purposes.”
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: U.S. Sees No Intervention
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12— United States officials said to day there were no indications that Communist China intended to intervene in the fighting in Laos.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Richard W. Vogel

headline: 2 MORE COPIERS OF U.S. DOWNED IN DRIVE ON LAOS
lead_paragraph: QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 13—The United States command announced early today that intense enemy antiaircraft fire had brought down two more American helicopters supporting the South Vietnamese drive against Communist supply trails in Laos.

headline: U.S. Denies Combat Role
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 12—The White House insisted again today that “there are no United States combat” forces or advisers committed” to the South Vietnamese operation in Laos.

headline: Massachusetts Official Files Suit Against War
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Feb. 12 (UPI)— State Attorney General Robert Quinn filed suit in United States District Court today on behalf of 12 Massachusetts soldiers challenging the con stitutional authority of De fense Secretary Melvin R. Laird to send them to fight in Southeast Asia.

headline: Ziegler Denies Threat to China
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 12 — Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, said here today that the Nixon Administration did not believe that the Souh Vienamese ef fort to cut the Ho Chi Minh Trail network would provoke Chinese Communists into cross ing the Laotian border in force.

headline: COMA TARGET OF LAOS PROTEST
lead_paragraph: Three offices in Columbia's School of International Affairs were wrecked and a student and three policemen were in jured yesterday after a meet ing held to protest the incur sion into Laos. One student was arrested.
author: By Richard Severo

headline: Copier Commander Robert F. Molinelli
lead_paragraph: Man in the News
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Says U.S. Marines Are Set for DMZ Landing
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 13 (Agence France Presse)—North Vietnam to day called on all its regions to prepare for an American military landing along the demilitarized zone.

headline: NEW ANTI‐U.S. RIOTING ERUPTS AT QUINHON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 13 (AP) — Anti‐American riot ing broke out in the coastal city of Quinhon again today. Rioters threw stones and set fire to American vehicles and a building before the South Vietnamese national police dis persed them with tear gas.

headline: Berlin Protest on Laos Held
lead_paragraph: BERLIN, Feb. 13 (Reuters)— Several thousand young left wing demonstrators marched through West. Berlin streets here today, protesting against the drive into Laos and calling for the immediate withdrawal of all United States troops from Indochina.

headline: South Vietnamese Drive Into Laos Put at 14 Miles
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 13— South Vietnamese troops were reported today to have advanced about 14 miles into Laos in their six‐day‐old drive to cut the enemy supply network there.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Edward S. Hermant

headline: Letters to the. Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Guilford Dudley 3d

headline: Saigon Is Using Deserters as Coolies
lead_paragraph: DONGHA, South Vietnam, Feb. 13—When Tran Nam and the other members of his unit crossed into Laos this week, they went as con victs under sentence. They carried no weapons. Nam was certain he would not return.

headline: OBSERVER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13—Everyone seems agreed now that the invasion of Laos is not an invasion but an in cursion. The newspapers call it an incursion. Radio and television call it an incursion. The official voices of the United States Government call an incursion.
author: By Russell Baker

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Richard J. Coughlin

headline: On Ho Chi Minh Trail, Painted Traffic Signs
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 13—The South Vietnamese opened for inspection today a mile‐long section of the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos. It turned out to have painted traf fic signs, and a latticework roof covered with camouflaging veg etation.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—Thousands of South Vietnamese troops, lifted and supplied by American helicop ters, continued their slow push into Laos last week and the ab sence of enemy resistance on the ground left Allied command ers both relieved and apprehen sive.
author: —Alvin Shuster

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Nine months ago, when American and South Vietnamese troops first swept across the border into Cambodia, the United States erupted in a paroxysm of anguish. By the end of the first week of the in vasion, its people were divided, its campuses closed, four young students were dead in Ohio and Kent State had become the ral lying cry for a generation. Twice in the course of that first week the President went directly to the people on television, once to explain his decision, a sec ond time to plead for a cooling of the rhetoric and time to prove the merits of what he had done.
author: —Terence Smith

headline: U.S. Copters Get Rain of Fire in Laos
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 14—As 40 American‐piloted helicopters ferrying South Viet namese troops into Laos pre pared to set down in the jun gle, mortar shells began raining on the clearing.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Feb. 14—Through the Johnson and Nixon Administrations, American policy in Indochina has fo cused almost entirely on military force. American troops are slowly withdraw ing now, but the war goes on by other means: Vietnamization, expanded bombings, close air support by Amer ican planes over wider fronts. The offi cial talk is still of punishing the enemy; it is the familiar talk of vic tory.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Air War in Laos
lead_paragraph: Shortly before South Vietnamese troops invaded the Laotian panhandle backed by awesome American air power, a Laotian general in the area told a New York Times correspondent he did not want American aerial support. “Every time the Americans are called in bomb, they destroy friends and not enemies,” he said.

headline: News of War in Laos Comes in Bits
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 14— The war in Laos is still an out of‐bounds, largely secret war.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: South Vietnamese Troops Reach Supply Trail in Laos, but Are Shelled by the Enemy
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Mon day, Feb. 15—An Air Force plane accidentally bombed “a friendly unit” yesterday morn ing near the United States‐sup ported base at Long Tieng in Laos, the military command here announced today.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: U. S. Bombers Strike Trail
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Feb. 14 (AP) — United States bombers roamed across the east‐west axis of the Ho Chi Minh trail in southern Laos today, the United States command said, attacking sus pected North Vietnamese moun tain outposts overlooking Route 9 on the approaches to the town of Tchepone.

headline: Peking Reports Rally Against Drive Into Laos
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Feb. 14—Sev eral hundred thousand people were reported to have attended a rally in Peking today to de nounce the allied move into Laos and pledge support for the Communist cause in Indo china.

headline: Hanoi Spurs Recruiting
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Feb. 15 (Reu ters) — An army recruitment drive is under way in North Vietnam, the Hsinhua press agency reported today. Re cruitment slogans in Haiphong read. “Be prepared at all times to join the army, go wherever our fatherland needs us,” the agency reported.

headline: Aid Rushed to U.S.‐Backed Base In Laos Alter Foe's Penetration
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 15— Reinforcements and supplies were flown today to the Ameri can‐backed base at Long Tieng, which was penetrated yester day by North Vietnamese com mandos.

headline: FOE'S TROOP FLOW IS REPORTED CUT BY DRIVE IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 16—Military offi cials asserted yesterday that the sweep westward into the Laotian mountains, where thousands of South Vienamese troops are trying to block the Ho Chi Minh Trail network, had already succeeded in cutting off the flow of enemy supplies and troops into the northernmost province of South Vietnam.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: THAIS ABANDONING HARD LINE ON REDS
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 15 — The American‐supported South Vietnamese incursion into Laos has been met here with official silence that is a measure of how far Thailand has come from the time when she was one of the most vocal supporters of a hard line against Communism in Asia.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Colonel in Vietnam Convicted in Drug Case
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 16 (AP)—Col. Gerald V. Kehrli of the United States Air Force was found guilty today of smok ing and possessing marijuana and of asking enlisted men in his squadron to obtain it for him.

headline: TRIAL OF CALLEY RESUMING TODAY
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 15 — The murder trial of first Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. enters its climactic phase to morrow with the resumption of the court‐martial of the 27‐ year‐old officer charged with the mass execution of unarmed South Vietnamese civilians dur ing the so called Mylai mas score.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Unstarchy U.S. General in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb.14—In the one‐room trail er near here occupied by Brig. Gen. John G. Hill Jr., the man in, charge of “protecting the people providing logistical support” for the South Viet namese drive into Laos, there Is only one small self‐indul gence: a coffeepot on a
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Casualty Reports by U. S. Again Raise Skepticism
lead_paragraph: FIRE SUPPORT BASE VAN. DERGRIFT, South Vietnam, Feb. 14—An enemy rocket made a direct hit two nights ago on an American bunker at this ar tillery base on Route 9 between Khesanh and Quangtri.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Strength in Vietnam Drops 2,100 to 332,900
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 15 (AP)—The United States command announced today that the number of American troops in South Vietnam dropped by 2,100 last week to 332,900 and that 1,555 more were being pre pared for withdrawal.

headline: Antiwar Troupe Formed to Tour Bases
lead_paragraph: Jane Fonda, Mike Nichols and Elliott Gould are among a dozen well‐known entertainers who have formed a comedy troupe in the hope of touring military bases across the coun try with an antiwar stage show for “the forgotten soldiers.”
author: By Lacey Fosburgh

headline: A Times Reporter in Vietnam Wins a Polk Award
lead_paragraph: Gloria Emerson, a member of the news staff of The New York Times, was among the winners of 12 categories of George Polk Memorial Awards announced yesterday by the Brooklyn Cen ter of Long Island University “for outstanding achievements in journalism during 1970.”

headline: A Colonel Is Given 3‐Year Drag Term
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 16—A United States Air Force colonel was sentenced today to three years in prison and was fined $15,000 for smoking marijuana, asking a sergeant in his squadron to get him some marijuana and giving some to four enlisted men.

headline: Medal of Honor Given To 12 Posthumously
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI)—With President Nixon looking on, the Medal of Honor was presented today to the families of 12 men killed in Vietnam.

headline: IMPEACH NIXON, G.O.P FOE URGES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16— Representative Paul N. McClos key Jr., Republican of Califor nia, said tonight that President Nixon should be threatened with impeachment as a means of changing the Administra tion's Vietnam policy.

headline: McGill Assails Class Disruption And Insists on ‘Right to Teach’
lead_paragraph: Dr. William J. McGill, presi dent of Columbia University, has condemned the attempt by a group of militant students to disrupt class in political science last Friday afternoon.

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: PARIS—The argument about the news embargo at the start of Laotian operations has become as ridiculous as it is bitter and distorted. What is wholly forgotten is the fact that Amer ican and other reporters in Indochina have been permitted to operate with a freedom, not to say abandon, that would have seemed paradisaical to their older colleagues of World War II.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: American Legion Hears Nixon Plea For a Strong U.S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16—Presi ??ent Nixon told several thou and members of the American ??egion tonight that the United States must remain as strong in peacetime as it has been in war ??ime in order to “maintain the ??eace.”

headline: Saigon Seeks to Shift Talks
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 16 (Reuters)—South Vietnam will suggest at the Vietnam peace talks in Paris on Thurs day that the meetings be moved to Southeast Asia, Foreign Min ister Tran Van Lam said today.

headline: LAIRD EXPECTING ‘SOME TOUGH DAYS’ IN LAOS CAMPAIGN
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16— Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird advised President Nixon and members of the Cabinet today to expect “some tough days ahead” in the allied ef fort to cut the Ho CM Minh Trail supply line In southern Laos.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Air Force to Try 14 In Study of Misuse Of Mess Hall Funds
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) —The Air Force announced to day that it would court‐martial two officers and 12 noncommis sioned officers charged with mishandling mess hall funds in Thailand.

headline: SAIGON LABOR CHIEF ASSAILS U.S. POLICY
lead_paragraph: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 16 —The head of the main federa tion of labor unions in South Vietnam said today that he feared that the United States and its allies were putting too much emphasis on winning militarily while leaving the Vietcong free to build up their political apparatus.

headline: Missile Sites in North Vietnam Attacked by U. S. 3d Day in Row
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 17—American jets attacked missile sites in North Vietnam yesterday for the third successive day, the United States command an nounced today.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: SANITY UNIT FINDS CALLEY ‘NORMAL’
lead_paragraph: FORT KENNING, Ga., Feb. 16 —First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., accused of murdering at least 102 unarmed Vietnamese civilians during the so‐called Mylai massacre, has been found “normal in every re spect” by an Army sanity board.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Harlan G. Haskell 3d

headline: Vietnamese General and a G.I. Who Want to See Victory
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 14—Brig. Gen. Pham Van Phu, commander of the First Infantry Division, which is among the forces pushing into southern Laos, and Specialist Charles Heffley of Brighton, Colo., have not met, although they work here a few hundred yards of each other.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Defense Says Calley Regarded Victims as an Enemy
lead_paragraph: FORT KENNING, Ga., Feb. 17—The chief counsel to First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. said today that the lieutenant did not feel he was killing “humans” when he ordered and participated in the execution of two groups of Vietnamese civilians at Mylai.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: KENNEDY ASSAILS VIETNAMIZATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) — Senator Edward M. Kennedy, said today the United States policy of Vietnamization was actually “a policy of violence” that has resulted in the “inva sion of Cambodia, the invasion of Laos.”

headline: Trial Reported Still Open The Washington Star
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 17— Informed sources said here to day that despite the South Vietnamese incursion, North Vietnam still retained the ca pability to move its men and supplies south through the Lao tian panhandle.

headline: New Enemy Units in Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 17—High military sources reported today that two additional North Vietnamese regi ments had moved into new positions in southern Laos in what appeared to be a serious threat to advancing South Vietnamese troops.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 — Following is a transcript of President Nixon's news conference today:

headline: Two Fire Bombs Hit Wall Of U.S. Embassy in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 17—Young men threw two fire bombs outside the American Embassy this afternoon, and sped away on motorcycles. The incident caused little damage to the walls surrounding the heavily guarded embassy. Em bassy employes repainted the wall.

headline: 200 Laos Civilians Wounded In Bombing Error Are Moved
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 17 (AP)—About 170 wounded civilians have been evacuated from Long Aieng to United States hospital at Van Son, reli able sources reported today.

headline: At Border Crossing Into Laos, the Litter of Troops and History
lead_paragraph: ON ROUTE 9, near the Lao tian border, Feb. 15—Now there is only the garbage of war. Empty C‐ration cans of fruit cocktail and turkey loaf, an empty Pall Mall cigarette pack age, a single khaki sock and two mounds of sandbags are strewn about at the border crossing into Laos on Route 9.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. JURY INDICTS 8 IN ARMY CLUB CASE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17—The Army's former top‐ranking en listed man and seven others were indicted today by a Fed eral grand jury on charges that they plotted to defraud non commissioned officers' clubs in Vietnam.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: NIXON REFUSES TO RULE OUT WIDER AIR ROLE IN THE WAR OR A SAIGON PUSH TO NORTH
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17— President Nixon said today that he would put no limit on the use of American air power in Indochina except that the use of tactical nuclear weapons was banned. He also refused to rule out a South Vietnamese thrust into North Vietnam.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Says Moves by U.S. Pose Threat to Red China
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 18—North Viet nam charged at the peace talks here today that the United States was threatening to ex tend the war to North Vietnam ese territory and by so doing was menacing Communist China as well.

headline: Service Held for Burrows
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Feb. 18 (UPI) —A memorial service for Larry Burrows, the award‐winning lime magazine photographer, was held in St. John Cathedral today. Mr. Burrows and three other combat photographers were reported missing Feb. 10 after antiaircraft fire over Laos brought down their helicopter.

headline: Two Doctors Say Calley Lacked Ability to Premeditate Slayings
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 18—Two defense psychiatrists said today that First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. lacked the mental ability to premedi tate the murder of 102 South Vietnamese civilians during the alleged Mylai massacre.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: ARMY PX INQUIRY REPORTED KILLED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 — An Army investigation of brib ery, kickbacks and smuggling in the post exchange system in Korea was first obstructed and then killed by senior Army of ficers stationed there, a Senate subcommittee was told today.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: DRAFT OBJECTOR GETS A HUNG JURY
