lead_paragraph: A jury failed to reach a ver dict in Federal Court here yes terday in the draft‐evasion trial of a 23‐year‐old graduate stu dent at Rockefeller University who challenged the constitu tionality of the war in Vietnam and refused to be inducted into the Army.
author: By Arnold H. Lubasch

headline: Nixon's Two Audiences: Hanoi and the U.S.
lead_paragraph: News Analysis
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Specialists Doubt Peking Will Send Troops to Indochina
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18— United States Government spe cialists on China voiced confi dence today that Peking would not commit troops to the war in Indochina.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Army Reprimands Officer Who Faked Data on Medals
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) —The Army said today that the officer who ordered fake citations awarding medals to a general in Vietnam had been reprimanded and investigation of the incident was complete.

headline: South Vietnam Puts the Drive Into Laos at 22 Miles
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18—The South Vietnamese command reported today that the forward units of its forces advancing across Communist supply trails in southern Laos were now operating 22 miles from the border.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Richard W. Lyman

headline: American War Deaths Double to 51 in Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18 (AP)— The United States command reported to day that 51 Americans were killed in combat last week in Indochina, more than twice the previous week's toll of 24.

headline: MANSFIELD WARNS ON DRIVE IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 — Senator Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, said today that South Vietnam's op eration in Laos represented “a military gamble” that could lead to an extended, broadened war in Indochina.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Base Under Attack
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Feb. 19 (AP)—A strong North Vietnamese force kept a South Vietnamese artil lery base in Laos under heavy attack today, according to in formed American sources in the northern part of South Vietnam.

headline: ALLIED INCURSION IN LAOS STALLED FOR SECOND DAY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam Feb. 19 — For the second succes sive day, the South Vietnamese sweep in southern Laos remained at a standstill, the military command reported to day.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Troops at Khesanh, Recalling Siege By the Enemy in 1968, Are Digging In
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 19 — Reminders of the marines who fought off the five‐month enemy siege in 1968 are everywhere here, and the Army troops who have reoccu pied the base since Jan. 30 are digging in deeply.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Ribicoff to Propose Revamping Of PX Purchasing Procedures
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 — Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff told American businessmen today that he would urge Con gress to order a complete re vamping of military post ex change purchasing procedures as a result of evidence of ex tensive bribery.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Gets V.F.W. Plea
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) — Herbert R. Rainwater, na tional commander of the Vet erans of Foreign Wars, said today that President Nixon was taking under advisement a VFW request that no more United States troops be with drawan from Indochina until North Vietnam agrees to an ex change of war prisoners. Mr. Rainwater made his statement after confering with the Presi dent.

headline: 13 House Members Oppose Transfers Of 5 Antiwar G.I.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19— Thirteen members of the House of Representatives from New York charged today that five members of the 26th United States Army band stationed at Fort Wadsworth, S. I., are scheduled to be transferred to Korea and Vietnam because of their antiwar activities.

headline: War Protests Set For 12 Campuses Beginning Monday
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 19 —Plans for teach‐ins to re kindle student opposition to the war in Indochina are gathering steam on a dozen campuses throughout the country.
author: By Robert Reinhold Special to The New York Times

headline: Psychiatrist Ousted as Calley Witness And All of His Testimony Is Expunged
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 19 —A New York psychiatrist was dismissed as a defense witness in the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L.. Calley Jr. this morning after the military judge expressed doubt as to the truth of his sworn testi mony.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Wolfgang Friedmann

headline: A Wider War?
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's threat to employ American air power without restraint throughout Indochina and his refusal to rule out a South Vietnamese invasion of North Viet nam remove virtually all doubt that the President still thinking in terms of the will‐o'‐the‐wisp of military victory in Southeast Asia.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — Indochina, ironi cally, is hardly the place to be to learn the results—if, indeed, there are any substantial re sults—of the South Vietnamese drive into Laos to cut the Ho Chi Minh Trail. Compared to the allied drive into the Cam bodian sanctuaries last year, with American ground forces fighting theme for two months, the Laos campaign seems almost invisible from here.
author: —Gloria Emerson

headline: Brewster Sees a ‘Moral Flaw’ in Vietnam Policy
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 20—King mon Brewster Jr., the president of Yale University, declared today that “the basic flaw in qui Southeastern Asian war policy is moral.”
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Art
lead_paragraph: SAIGON.
author: By Peggy Steinle

headline: CAMBODIAN ROAD TO SEA PERILOUS
lead_paragraph: TRAPEANG KRALENG, Cam bodia, Feb. 20—In the month since South Vietnamese and Cambodian troops, with the open support of American jets and helicopters, fought to re open Highway 4, Cambodia's vital outlet to the Gulf of Siam, just two oil convoys totaling 30 trucks have been able to use the road.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Air Base at Danang Shelled
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Sunday, Feb. 21 (Reuters) — Vietcong gunners shelled the air base at Danang early this morning, destroying a C‐130 transport plane used to carry supplies for the attack on the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos.

headline: Antiwar Bill in New Mexico
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N. M., Feb. 20 (UPI)—A bill sponsored by two Democrats and a Republican has been introduced in the State Senate prohibting the use of New Mexico servicemen in undeclared wars, such as the conflict in Indochina. The meas ure, introduced yesterday, was similar to a bill that became law in Massachusetts last year, aimed to rest the legality of the Vietnam War.

headline: Red China Terms Laos Drive ‘a Grave Menace’
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Feb. 20—Com munist China returned to the attack against the United States today, condemning recent ac tions in Indochina and state ments of intention by President Nixon regarding the war there.

headline: Vietnam
lead_paragraph: One might think that we long ago reached the point where there is nothing new to say about the war in Indochina. The lines of debate have been clearly drawn, and each day's new information — to those who can still bear to read and listen — often only confirms what one already knew or expected, or feared. We are mor ally and physically tired of the war; yet the war that wore us down, that drummed us into insensibility or into righteous crusades is not the same war today as it was yesterday, or last week, or last year.
author: By David R. Wyatt

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20—The latest official explanation of the President's Indochina policy is that “he is backing out of the saloon with both guns fir ing,” but there is a catch to this.
author: By James Reston

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: The use of marijuana by American forces in Vietnam had become such a “military problem” by early this year that Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the United States commander, ordered his of ficers to mount a strenuous campaign to combat it. Last week, as part of that cam paign, an Air Force colonel was brought before a court martial, charged with smok ing marijuana, asking a ser geant to get him some mari juana and giving some to four enlisted men.

headline: TIGER CAGE CAMP TO GET NEW CELLS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20—An agency in the United States mission here has contracted for the construction of a prison compound consist ing of 288 isolation cells on Con Son, an island off South Vietnam.

headline: Captain Will Stand Trial On Maiming of Vietnamese
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Feb. 20 (UPI) — The Army has an nounced that it is dropping sev eral charges of murder and as sault against a captain charged in the alleged Mylai massacre, but that he will be court‐mar tialed for allegedly maiming and assualting a suspected member of the Vietcong.

headline: A Major at Khesanh Recalls 1968
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 13—Maj. Tommy Stiner, a Vietnam veteran who is once again in Khesanh, has an old fashioned Army face at the age of 33. It is a big, blunt face, slightly lined, with ser ious eyes, not unlike the faces of the marines under siege at Khesanh in 1968.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: INTENSE FIGHTING AT SAIGON'S BASE IN LAOS REPORTED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20 — Intense ground fighting was reported today on the northern flank of the South Vietnamese advance into Laos, which remained stalled for the third day.

headline: Letters
lead_paragraph: No one would quarrel with the over‐all theme of Prof. John P. Roche's article, “The Jigsaw Puzzle of History” (Jan. 24). In the preface of my book, “To Move a Na tion,” for example, I wrote, “No single person, not even the President himself can per sonally be acquainted with every facet of a large and complicated issue of foreign policy.” But one can make the point without being unfair to men on either side of the policy argument. The de bates were passionate, but, as I also said in my book, “the people on both sides of the argument were honest, intelligent, reasonable and pa triotic men struggling man fully with mean and intricate problems of the highest im portance.”

headline: HODGSON WINDS UP TALK WITH UNIONS ON BUILDING COSTS
lead_paragraph: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20 —Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson ended his meetings with building trades leaders here today without publicly an nouncing progress in working out a plan for curbing wage and price rises in the construction industry.
author: By Damon Stetson Special to The New York Times

headline: Design Called Modern
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19— The State Department said to day that prison cells being in stalled by an American con tractor on Con Son were de signed “according to modern, penal standards.”

headline: EX‐NIXON AIDE JOINS ANTIWAR CAMPAIGN
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 — Common Cause, the new public interest lobbying organization, will begin next week a major campaign against the Nixon Administration's Indochina war policies and has hired a former White House aide as an adviser to the effort.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—President Nixon's news conference of Feb. 17 made clear what skeptics have long believed. His Vietnam policy is by no means one of steadily withdrawing Americans from South Vietnam, then letting the people of Indochina work out or fight out their own affairs. It is instead policy of escalation by American air power and South Vietnamese man power, with the aim of military vic tory.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: FORT DENNING, Ga. — A hypothetical statement of facts —six pages long, prepared by the defense and assumed by the prosecution and the court to be true—and four questions arising from it became the focus last week of the court martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.
author: —Richard Hammer

headline: PRESS‐CURBS DECREE CANCELED IN SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20 (Agence France‐Presse)— Premier Tran Thien Khien has canceled a press decree he signed on Jan. 21, after an outcry by the Saigon press, official sources disclosed here.

headline: Warning by the Vietcong
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 22 (AP)—The Vietcong said today, that any United States military action against North Vietnam would be matched by retalia tory attacks in South Vietnam.

headline: Paris Newsman Found Dead In Cambodia, Saigon Says
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 22 (UPI)—South. Vietnamese soldiers have found the body of a French freelance journalist, Francis Bailly, about. 10 miles southeast of the Cam bodian provincial capital of Kompong Chain, a military spokesman said today. He gave no details of the cause of death or exactly when it might have occurred.

headline: M'GOVERN ASSAILS NIXON WAR POLICY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21— Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, said today that the North Viet Vietnamese troops in South Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos more nearly represented the nationalistic aspirations of the Indochinese people than did American forces in Southeast Asia.

headline: Saigon's Rangers Driven From an Outpost in Laos
lead_paragraph: PHULOC COMMAND POST, South Vietnam, Feb. 21 — A battalion of South Vietnamese rangers was driven from a Lao tian mountaintop six miles northwest of here last night after North Vietnamese soldiers overran their position.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Key Cambodian Road Cut
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 21 (Agence France‐Presse) — Highway 1 between Pnompenh and Saigon was cut last night after Vietnamese Communists damaged a bridge about 35 miles southeast of the Cam bodian capital, a spokesman said today.

headline: On Ho Chi Minh Trail
lead_paragraph: HONG HA HA, Laos, Feb. 21 —On the stony spine of craggy ridge well within the labyrinth of roads and paths that make up the Ho Chi Minh Trail, the Third Regiment of the First South Vietnamese In fantry Division has established its command post.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: LINDSAY IS URGED TO STAY IN G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: Senator Jacob K. Javits urged Mayor Lindsay yesterday not to switch to the Democratic party, asserting that he could advance himself further if he remained a Republican.
author: By Emanuel Perlmutter

headline: 2 Catholic Priests in Saigon Get 9‐Month Jail Terms for publishing Articles Asking an End to the War
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 21—The Saigon Govern ment's disapproval of published articles calling for an end to the war resulted last week in the sentencing of two Roman Catholic priests to nine‐month prison sentences.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Lieutenant Accuses Two Generals of War Crimes
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21—A 24‐year‐old West Point grad uate is carrying dissent within the Army over the Vietnam war to new lengths. His tactics have forced the Army leader ship into a public test of its ability to deal with this kind of dissaffection.
author: By Neil Sheehan Special to The New York Times

headline: Senators Hear General Got $1,000 a Month From PX Supplier
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22—The friendship of an Army general cost Vietnam's leading post ex change profiteer “at least $1,000 a month,” Senate investigators were‐told today.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Further Heavy Assaults Expected in Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 —American officials expect fur ther heavy assaults by North Vietnamese forces against South Vietnamese troops in southern Laos.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: GALLEY, ON STAND, TELLS OP HATRED
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 22—First Lieut. William L. Cal ley Jr., accused of killing 102 men, women and children dur ing the alleged massacre of South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai, took the witness stand today and said that he had been indoctrinated by the Army to treat all Vietnamese, includ ing children, as potential ene mies.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: AIMS IN CONGRESS SET BY DEMOCRATS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 —The Senate Democratic Policy Committee adopted today a broad statement of objectives for the 92d Congress, including withdrawal of all American forces from Vietnam by the end of 1972.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S.Troops in Vietnam Fewest Since Fall of '66
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 (UPI)—The number of United States fighting men in South Vietnam has de clined to the lowest point since the fall of 1966, the United States command said today.

headline: Pathet Lao Role Reported
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 22 (UPI)—The Hanoi delegation to the Viet nam peace talks said in a state ment today that the troops who attacked South Vietnamese Rangers in southern Laos were Pathet Lao guerrillas and not North Vietnamese as they gen erally have been described. However, the statement did not specifically deny the presence of North Vietnamese troops in Laos.

headline: Heavy Fire Continues to Slow Saigon's Laos Drive
lead_paragraph: SAIGAN, South Vietnam, Feb. 22 (AP)—With heavy enemy fire continuing, the South Viet namese drive against Commu nist supply trails and bases in southern Laos was reported stalled today for the fifth con. secutive day.

headline: SAIGON SAYS DRIVE BLOCKED INVASION OF FIVE PROVINCES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 22—While reports from the battlefield indicated that South Vietnam's push into Laos was stalled for a fifth day, Presi dent Nguyen Van Thieu said today that the incursion had already succeeded in deterring a North Vietnamese plan to seize the five northernmost provinces of South Vietnam.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: General Denies Getting Gifts
lead_paragraph: MONTEREY, Calif., Feb. 22 (UPI)—General Meyer, retired, denied today that he had ac cepted expensive gifts from Mr. Crum or provided Mr. Crum with favors in South Vietnam. General Meyer said, however, that he and Mr. Crum were friends and he had. visited Mr. Crum's home in Saigon many times.

headline: HARRIMAN CALLS FOR NIXON DEFEAT
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 22—W. Averell Harriman and former Attorney General Ramsey Clark joined members of Congress, clergyman and others at an antiwar teach‐in at Yale Uni versity tonight.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu and Abrams Confer
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Feb. 22 (UPI)—President Nguyen Van Thieu of, South Vietnam, Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the United States commander in Vietnam, and Ambassador Elsworth Bunker conferred for an hour today.

headline: M'CARTHY SCORES A ‘DIFFERENT’ WAR
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Feb. 22 — Efforts to start an expanded public movement to end the war in Vietnam opened here today by returning to a tactic as old as the involvement of many of its organizers — the university teach‐in.
author: By Bill Kovach Special to The New York Times

headline: Top Saigon General And News week Man Die in Copier Crash
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 23—Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri, commander of the military region around Saigon and one, of South Vietnam's most respected military leaders, was killed today when his helicopter crashed in Tayninh Province, a military spokesman an nounced.

headline: Soviet Keeps Up Attack
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Feb. 22 (AP) —The Soviet Union kept up its (press campaign against Zionism today, giving especially bitter criticism to the Jewish confer ence in Brussels.

headline: Neutralize Southeast Asia Now
lead_paragraph: LONDON—The speed. and scale of America's withdrawal from Vietnam Is impressive by any standard. Po litically more important still, as against 14,592 Americans killed in the last year of the Democratic Administration, only 4,180 were killed in 1970.
author: By Denis Healey

headline: U.S. Evacuates G.I. From Post in Laos Besieged by Enemy
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 (UPI) — A wounded American helicopter crew chief who had taken virtual com mand of a besieged South Viet namese outpost in Laos was airlifted to safety today, the United States command said.

headline: Report of Laos Action
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG. Feb. 23 (Reu ters) — The North Vietnamese news agency today distributed a report from a Vietcong news man who accompanied units that overran a South Vietnam mese ranger post in Laos last weekend.

headline: Senators Hear PX Officials, Aided by General, Ordered Oversupply of Beer
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23—Post exchange custodians, with the help of a general, told their stateside superiors they were running out of Carling's beer in Vietnam when there were 99, 000 cases on hand there and 125,900 more coming in every month, a Senate inquiry was told today.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. AIDES PORTRAY A SUCCESS IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23—The Administration stepped up efforts today to portray the allied drive in Laos as a success though some officials privately acknowledged that South Viet namese forces would have to move much farther across Laos to curtail the flow of enemy supplies significantly.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon's Strategy Meets Obstacles in Laos
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 23—Brooding about pos sible obstacles to the South Vietnamese drive against the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos, senior American military advis ers last week saw three major problems: the roads, the mon soon weather and antiaircraft fire. Yet, over the weekend, in good weather, far from any road, one of the finest South Vietnamese combat battalions was lost to an enemy attack on its mountaintop landing zone five mild across the border in Laos. American helicopters, un able to bring supplies or rein forcements through the curtain of ground fire, returned to their base here while the 39th Ranger Battalion was losing more than half its men.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Muskie Asks That U.S. Troops Quit Indochina by End of Year
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23—Senator Edmund S. Muskie, contending that the Adminis tration's program of Vietnanii zation provides no answer for ending the Vietnam war, called tonight for withdrawal of all American troops from Indo china by the end of this year.

headline: DEMOCRATS SEEK WAR WITHDRAWAL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 —Over the resistance of its hawk ish flank, the Democratic par ty in the Senate went on rec ord today in favor of with drawal of all American forces from Vietnam by the end of 1972.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Excerpts From Calley Testimony on Mylai Killings
lead_paragraph: FORT DENNING, Ga., Feb. 23—Following are excerpts from testimony here today by First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. at his court‐martial for the murder of Vietnamese civillans:

headline: Stalled Rangers Remove Wounded
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 24—The South Vietnamese military command said yesterday that its forces had no intention “right now” of penetrating more deeply into Laos.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Supply Problem Stressed
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 (UPI) — Lieut. Gen. Hoang Xuan Lam, commander of the South Vietnamese forces in Laos, said today the “most serious problem” he had was supplying his units.

headline: Galley Concedes Killings; Says He Acted on Orders
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 23—First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. admitted from the witness stand today that he shot some civilian prisoners who had been herded into a ditch in the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 three years ago, but he said he was act ing under orders.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Route 9, Now a ‘Cemetery’ Hanoi Army Paper Asserts
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 23 (Agence France‐Presse) —The North Vietnamese Army newspaper, Quan Doi Nhan Dan, said today that Route 9, the road over which South Vietnamese forces invaded Laos, had become “the cemetery of helicopters and armored vehicles.”

headline: Action in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, Feb. 24 (AP)—The Cambodian command reported today that Government troops had repulsed repeated attacks by North Vietnamese and Viet cong soldiers on a frontier vil lage for a second successive night.

headline: No Retreat in Southeast Asia
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S. C.—I just re turned from another trip to the Far East which included visits to Korea, Taipei and Vietnam.
author: By Mark W. Clark

headline: U.S. Command Is Seeking Cause of Copter Crash That Killed Saigon General and Newsweek Man
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 — The United States com mand searched in vain today for the cause of a helicopter crash that killed 10 persons, in cluding South Vietnam's best known field commander and correspondent of Newsweek magazine.

headline: U.S. Tells of Tayninh Attack
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Feb. 23 (AP)—One of the sharpest attacks against United States forces in several months was reported early to day in the Tayninh area.

headline: U.S. Copter Will Carry Correspondents to Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)—Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that news correspondents in South Vietnam would be per mitted aboard a specially des ignated helicopter to cover South Vietnamese and Amer ican operations in Laos.

headline: Calley Testimony Excerpts
lead_paragraph: FORT BINNING, Ga., Feb. 24 — Following are excerpts from cross‐examination today of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.:

headline: Drug Users Spur Malaria Revival
lead_paragraph: Hypodermic needles are ri valing mosquitos in spreading malaria in this country.
author: By Lawrence K. Altman

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: We had been aware that many senior officers in the U.S. Army were dis pleased because Lieut. Louis Font, a West Point graduate, filed for consci entious objector status.

headline: Calley Says He Never Questioned Mylai Orders
lead_paragraph: FORT KENNING, Ga., Feb. 24 —The defense rested in the murder trial of First Lieut. Wil liam L. Calley Jr. late today after the officer maintained under cross‐examination that he was obeying orders when he shot South Vietnamese civilians during the so‐called Mylai mas sacre three years ago.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Laos: View From the Pentagon
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24—The Nixon Administration, along With everyone else here, rec ognized today that the long fuse of antiwar protest was moldering again in Congress and on the campuses, fanned in part by the skimpiness of the information from the battle field in Laos and the spreading impression that all is not well there. The Pentagon's re sponse was a 90 minute news con ference on the course of battle, offering some modest and vague claims of success and some careful warnings that more tough fighting lies ahead. Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird finally ended the exchange, long before the questions had run Out. As both the Secretary and some of the reporters made plain, concern about the Gov ernment's “credibility” was once again in the air.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Notes ‘Victories’
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 24 (Agence France‐Press)—De fense Minister Vo Nguyen Giap said last night that the Com munist “victories” in southern Laos “constitute a severe warning to the American imperial ists” against further escalation of the war.

headline: Route 9 in Laos Still Closed
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 24 (AP)—Brig. Gen. Pham Van Phu, commander of the South Vietnamese First In fantry Division, said today that Route 9 in Laos remained closed to supply missions be cause of North Vietnamese ambushes.

headline: Colonel Amends Remarks
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Feb. 24 (AP) —Lieut. Col. Le Trung Hien, the South Vietnamese military spokesman, today amended his statement of yesterday that Saigon's forces had no intention “right now” of advancing any farther in Laos.

headline: G.I.'s in Vietnam Get Heroin Easily
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 24—It is so easy to buy heroin from peddlers in Viet nam wherever there are American troops or convoys that a tiny plastic vial can be purchased for $3 outside the headquarters of an Amer ican general.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietcong Warn U.S. It Risks Peking's Intervention
lead_paragraph: ROME, Feb. 24 — The chief Vietcong delegate to the Paris peace talks, Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, charged today that the United States was preparing “a new military adventure” against North Vietnam.
author: By Paul Hofmann Special to The New York Times

headline: MAIN ALLIED BASE OF LAOS DRIVE HIT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 25—The main allied rear base for the South Vietnamese drive in Laos was shelled by enemy gunners last night for the first time since the operation began.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Laos and the Old Illusions
lead_paragraph: So this time it is Laos. On and on it goes: Who would have thought that instead of the light at the end of the tunnel we would have found a tunnel at the end of the tunnel. The rationalizations are familiar: shorten the war, bring the troops home quicker, protect American lives, improve the morale of the South Vietnamese Gov ernment, serve notice on Hanoi of the seriousness of our intent.
author: By David Halberstam

headline: Panther Trial Scheduled
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 (UPI)—Federal Judge Samuel Conti today set May 3 for the trial of the Black Panther chief of staff; David Hilliard, on charges of threatening the life of President Nixon in a speech at a Vietnam war moratorium rally in Golden Gate Park Nov. 15, 1969.

headline: Laird Says Laos Drive Adheres to Plan
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb 24—The Secretary of Defense and a sen ior military aide insisted today that South Vietnamese forces had deliberately paused in the Offensive in Laos rather than being bogged down as a result of enemy attacks.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The President and the Secretary of Defense have tried mightily to sell the public on their “winding down” of the war. But let's look at the facts, as Mr. Nixon would say.

headline: Laotians Report Clashes
lead_paragraph: VIETIANE, Laos, Feb. 25 (AP) —The Defense Ministry today reported five skirmishes be tween North Vietnamese sol diers and Laotian troops around Dong Hene, on Route 9, about 75 miles west of the South Vietnamese operation.

headline: DOCTORS TESTIFY CALLEY WAS SANE
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 25 — Two Army psychiatrists testified today that First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was sane at Mylei and was suffering no more from battle strain than were any of his soldiers on the day the officer, according to his admission, killed South Viet namese civilians three years ago in the hamlet of Mylai.
author: By Homer Bigart  Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnamization Termed No Quick Path to Peace
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 —President Nixon said for the first time today that the policy of Vietnamization cannot, “ex cept over a long period,” end the war in Indochina.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: NIXON SEES RISK OF ISOLATIONISM IF DISENGAGEMENT IS TOO SWIFT;
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25—President Nixon appealed to the Soviet Union and other adversaries today to join the search for peace, but he warned that he would not be hurried along the road of disengage ment from Indochina or any where else:
author: By Robert B. SempleJr.  Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Delegation at Paris Says Message Lies About Indochina
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 25—North Viet nam declared today that Presi dent Nixon had lied on three crucial aspects of the Indo china war in his State of the World Message.

headline: Newsmen Going Into Laos by Helicopter Will Be Without U.S. Military Escorts
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 25—Military officials in Quang tri said today that no United States military men would es cort correspondents and pho tographers who, in a, reversal of policy, will be allowed to fly into Laos on American heli copters to coyer the South Vietnamese incursion there.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Excerpts From President's Report on Indochina in His State of the World Message
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25—Following are excerpts from the Indo china section of President Nixon's annual report to Congress on foreign policy, which is titled “United States Foreign Policy for the 1970's: Building for Peace”:

headline: New Message Old Doctrines
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's second State of the World Message is essentially a restatement and updating of last year's document. It does not appear at first reading to contain any new thoughts or proposals. Indeed, what is most striking is the manner in which the emerging Nixon Doctrine increasingly resembles old United States policies of the past two decades.

headline: South Vietnamese Base in Laos Reported Under Heavy Attack
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Feb. 26 — Heavy fighting was reported yesterday at a South Vietnamese base in Laos as enemy resistance continued to stiffen against allied efforts to disrupt enemy supply, lines there.
author: By Alvin Shuster  Special to The New York Times

headline: Ex‐Agents Tell of Duplication and Competition in Army ‘Watch’ on Civilians
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 —Two former military intelli gence agents disclosed today details of political surveillance] operations run by Army com bat divisions that duplicated and often competed with the nationwide watch on civilians of the Army intelligence com mand.
author: By Richard Halloran  Special to The New York Times

headline: SOVIET SCORES HIS VIETNAM PLAN
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Feb. 25 — The Soviet Government denounced President Nixon's “Vietnamiza tion” policy today and said the increased fighting in Indochina “cannot fail to affect Soviet American relations.”
author: By Bernard Gwertzman  Special to The New York Times

headline: INVASION OF NORTH FORESEEN BY THIEU
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23—President Nguyen Van Thieu was quoted today as hav ing said that an invasion of North Vietnam by South Viet namese troops was only a mat ter of time.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The State Department's reassurance, which I fully believe, that China will not respond to the Laotian incursion because she knows that we Americans are withdrawing should cause some second thoughts. If. China will resort to arms only to respond to an Ameri can military threat near her frontiers as the reassurance affirms, why then are we in Indochina, at all, and why are we delaying our. departure? [Edi torial Feb. 21,]

headline: Congressional Criticism on Vietnam Policy Flaring Up Again
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25—Long ‐smoldering Congres siongl criticism of the Admin istration's Indochina policy showed signs of flaring up again today as a Republican Senator warned that President Nixon might become a one term President and a group of Senate Democrats proposed a Congressional injunction against supporting an invasion of North Vietnam.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon's Pledge to Shun Politics Being Questioned
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22—“Don't let the Democrats get away with any lies,” Presi dent Nixon admonished as he bade farewell to a White House aide taking a new post with the Republican national committee. Lyn C. Nofziger, the departing assistant, re plied: “Mr. President, I'm not even going to let them get away with tailing the truth.” The recent exchange, which the President is said to be recounting with glee, illustrates more than Mr. Nofziger's quick wit. Mr. Nixon said on Jan. 4 he would not be wearing his political hat this year, and like Mr. Nofziger, politics is supposed to be moving out of the White House.
author: By James M. Naughton  Special to The New York Times

headline: Democrats Say President Indicates an Endless War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26—The Democratic National Commit tee's Policy Council charged today that President Nixon's State of the World Message of fered the “prospect of an end less war” in Indochina.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Colonel Faces Mylai Trial Over Charge of Cover‐Up
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 —The Army announced today that Col. Oran K. Henderson, former commander of the Am erica Division's IIth Brigade, would be tried by a general court‐martial on charges of covering up the alleged mas sacre at the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 in March, 1968.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Calley Trial Suspended Because of Tornado Alert
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 26 — A tornado alert forced a suspension today in the My lai murder trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., interrupt ing a sharp debate over wheth er the Government should be allowed to introduce testimony regarding other acts of al leged misconduct by the young officer.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Dismisses Message by Nixon
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Feb. 26 (Reu ters)—Hanoi today dismissed President Nixon's message on foreign affairs yesterday as “inflated rhetoric” that offered the world nothing new.

headline: Cambodian Asks Invasion
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 26 (Reuters)—Foreign Minister Koun Wick of Cambodia called today for an invasion of North Vietnam by the United States and its allies.

headline: MIDI VIETNAMESE BATTERED BY FOE AT A BASE IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 27—Heavy en emy tank and infantry attacks were reported yesterday to have routed South Vietnamese troops from many defensive positions on a Laotian hilltop.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. AIDES REJECT MOVE INTO NORTH
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26—Au thoritative Administration offi cials said today that the United States has no intention of send ing ground troops into North Vietnam, and they strongly dis counted the likelihood of a South Vietnamese ground at tack on North Vietnam.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu Said to Be Misquoted
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 26 (AP)—A spokesman for Pres ident Nguyen Van Thieu said today that Mr. Thieu had been misquoted as having said that an invasion of North Vietnam was only a matter of time.

headline: Skepticism in Moscow
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Feb. 26 — The Soviet Union reacted with skepticism today to President Nixon's foreign policy message. It found nothing to praise in the document and the Ameri can press was quoted to show that it contained no new ele ments.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Lieutenant Calley's sad account of not having questioned the legality of his superior's orders to “waste” some unarmed Vietnamese civilians chillingly suggests the brutal ity of a war for the “pacification” of whole populations.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: The War In Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Burton R. Tauber is a clean shaven Wall Street lawyer with his own firm and a kind of Nelson Rockefeller aura of capi talist geniality. He is notwith standing the author of a tre mendously effective satire on the Vietnamese war—done in the form of a prospectus for a new corporate stock issue: 225,000,000 shares of common stock in The War in Vietnam.
author: By Marcia Seligson

headline: Plan to Use Rescue Troops Is Denounced by Vietcong
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 27, (Reuters)—The Vietcong today denounced Washington's expressed readi ness to send United States res cue troops into Laos.

headline: H. Ross Perot Pays His Dues
lead_paragraph: This Tesan convert ed a brighi idea into a bil‐uh, 700 million dollars be fore he was 40. Now he wants to spend it “intelligently”
author: By Fred Powledchs

headline: Poll Finds Majority Believe Laos Drive Will Lengthen War
lead_paragraph: The Gallup Poll has found that Americans by a more than 2‐to 1 ratio think the allied invasion of Laos will lengthen rather than shorten the Vietnam war.

headline: PROTEST DIVERTS TELEPHONE TAXES
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Feb. 27—About 75 Bostonians demonstrated their opposition to the Indochina war this week by turning over their Federal telephone taxes to the farm workers’ union rather than the Government.
author: By Bill Kovach Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi's Account of Battle
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 27 (Agence France‐Presse)—The South Vietnamese Third Paratroop Battalion on a hill in the La Thuong region of Laos just south of the North Vietnamese border was over run and taken by “liberation forces” according to an account purporting to be that of a South Vietnamese prisoner made public here today.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — Late last week, in the 26th day of the allied push into Laos, American mili tary authorities finally permit ted correspondents to do what thousands of South Vietnamese troops have done: Cross the bor der in American helicopters. The ban on travel was just one of many restrictions on coverage of the war in Indochina. imposed on top of the most serious in herent restriction of all that it is dangerous.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—Whether as a re sult of advance overselling or an underestimate of North Viet nam's military capacity along the Ho Chi Minh Trail, the Amer ican‐South Vietnamese incur sion into southern Laos looked less successful last week than the image of it created by the advance buildup and the initial advance on the ground.

headline: TV Mailbag
lead_paragraph: To THE EDITOR: Julius Novick's article, “Arthur Miller: Does He Speak to the Present?,” misses the point. Of course Miller speaks to the present. A playwright who can open up the human heart and show what is both ugly and beauti ful and tender in it, speaks to the present. It is fashion able to criticize Miller for not writing about contemporary issues: Vietnam, race, drugs, Women's Lib, revolution. That's like saying let's not produce Chekhov because nowhere in his plays does he write about air pollution.
author: On Arthur Miller

headline: INVASION RUMOR SPREADS IN SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 27—Givral's is a pleasant cof fee house on Tudo Street, the most chic street in Saigon when it was still called Rue Catinat and Saigon was still chic. It serves a rich variety of French specialities, including pastries and fantastic political rumors.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON SAYS ARMY HAS WON CONTROL OF HILL 31 IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 27 — Heavy fighting continued at major South Vietnamese outposts in Labs today and the South Vietnamese announced ‘that they had regained control of a strategic hill position.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: 40 U.S. Airmen in Vietnam Held in Drug Investigation
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 27 (AP)—The United States, Seventh Air Force an nounced today the arrest of about 40 American airmen after a month‐long investiga tion into an alleged narcotics ring at the air base at Cam ranh Bay.

headline: ARMY IN ’ 68 FEARED CIVIL ‘INSURGENCY’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.—A directive issued by the Army in February, 1968, as part of its program to, keep civilians under surveillance, shows that senior officers feared “a true insurgency, should external subversive forces develop suc cessful control” of the racial and antiwar dissidents who were active at that time.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: WITNESS ACCEPTED BY GALLEY'S JUDGE
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Feb. 27—Testimony that First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. shot a woman who ran toward him with her hands above her head, pleading for mercy, is now ad missible, a military judge ruled today.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Law
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga.—It was 4:30 last Wednesday af ternoon when the military judge, Col. Reid W. Kennedy, leaned across the bench and in a gentle voice told an ex hausted 1st Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. that his ordeal on the witness stand was over. For nine hours over two and a‐half days, the 27‐year‐old lieutenant — tense and nervous — had related his story of the attack on the South Vietnamese hamlet known as Mylai 4 on March 18, 1968.

headline: RELIGIOUS GROUPS SEEK PEACE IN '71
lead_paragraph: Representatives of 24 major religious denominations and agencies opened a campaign this week seeking an end to the war in Indochina by the end of this year.

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27—Deep down underneath, all the surface arguments about what we are doing in Indochina something In the American spirit keeps the nation from facing the facts in that tragic peninsula.
author: By James Reston

headline: Kennedy Flies to South Carolina For Address to State's Jaycees
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S. C., Feb. 27 —Senator Edward M. Kennedy made a rare speaking appear ance in the South today.
author: By Roy Reed Special to The New York Times

headline: Chicago 7 Defense Files Appeal Brief
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Feb. 27—The de fense in the Chicago Seven case filed today a 547‐page appeals brief contending that the con victions for crossing state lines with the intention of inciting disorders at the 1968 Demo cratic National Convention should be reversed.
author: By John Kifner Special to The New York Times

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some where in the South Pacific, or perhaps unnoticed in Ma drid, is a stocky, 52‐year‐old man of medium height with a limp, a glass eye, a gin ca pacity of two quarts a day and an infinite capacity for making profitable friendships with the military and the civilians who serve them.

headline: Nixon, With Wife, to Visit 3 Chinese Cities in 7 Days
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 — The White House announced today that President Nixon's journey to China in February would take him to three cities in seven days for “free‐wheel ing” discussions with Premier Chou En‐lai and Chairman Mao Tse‐tung. He will be accom panied by Mrs. Nixon.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: DEFENSE LAWYERS REST MYLAI CASE
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 30 —The defense in the court‐mar tial of Col. Oran K. Henderson rested its case today, but it appeared likely that the jury would not retire to consider verdict for more than a week.
author: By Douglas Robinson;Special to The New York Times

headline: RULES ON WAR NEWS TIGHTENED BY SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov'30 (UPI)——South Vietnam insti tuted new ground rules for news coverage of military oper ations today and threatened to expell correspondents for viola tions.

headline: How Many Secrecies?
lead_paragraph: LIVERMORE, Calif.—Here are three examples: the secrecy of the Kremlin, the secrecy of Washington, and the secrecy of The New York Times.
author: By Edward Teller

headline: New Drive Reported Opened in Central Highlands
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 1—About 15, 000 Government troops have reportedly begun a thrust against enemy forces in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam near the Cambodian border.
author: By Iver Peterson;Special to The New York Times

headline: Wild Blue Yonder Revisited
lead_paragraph: The United States Air Force Academy glistens metallically at the foot of an endless range of lovely mountains near Colorado Springs. The chapel building catches your eyes first as you approach it across the valley. Constructed of steel and aluminum, it tapers from a broad base to a series of points thrusting assertively upward toward the wild blue yonder. It was on the steps of this chapel that I, along with several other people, was apprehended by Air Force Security Police last month for distributing a prayer of St. Francis of Assisi and four quotations from the Bible. The prayer is the familiar one that starts out, “Lord, make me en instrument of Thy peace. Where there is hatred, let me sow love,” etc. The Bible verses had to do with beating swords into plowshares and not studying war anymore.
author: By Harvey Cox

headline: Foe in Cambodia Renews Heavy Attacks
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Dec. 1 (AP)—North Vietnamese forces renewed heavy attacks along Cambodia's northeastern front today and Cambodian troops were reported retreating from two key towns.

headline: Henderson Jury Awaits Three New Witnesses
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 1—The military jury at the courtmartial of Col. Oran K. Henderson marked time today while awaiting the arrival of three, witnesses who it expects will shed more light on whether there was a coverup of they Mylai 4 slayings.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. PRESSES ISSUE OF PRISONER MAIL
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 2—William J. Porter, the American delegate to the Vietnam peace talks, pressed North Vietnam again today to permit “a normal flow of mail” from American prisoners held there.

headline: Heavy Casualties Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 3 (AP)—A 120‐man company of South Vietnamese militiamen suffered heavy casualties yesterday in a clash with North Vietnamese troops 48 miles northwest of Saigon, the South Vietnamese command reported today. It said that 24 troops had been killed and 15 had been wounded in the action near the headquarters for current South Vietnamese operations in eastern Cambodia. The command said the militia force killed 32 enemy soldiers.

headline: CAMBODIA'S DRIVE COLLAPSES IN FACE OF ENEMY ATTACK
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 2 — Thousands of Cambodian Government troops were reported in disorderly retreat today as a major military campaign north of the capital collapsed in the face of heavy North Vietnamese attacks.

headline: 2 PARTY OFFICIALS DIFFER ON ISSUES
lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee said yesterday: that the economy would be the major issue of the Democratic party in the 1972 election.
author: By Alfonso A. Narvaez

headline: U.S. Combat Toll for Week Put at 9 Killed, 78 Wounded
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 2 (UPI) — The United States command reported today that nine Americans were, killed and 78 wounded in combat in Indochina last week.

headline: Vietcong Announces Truces for 3 Holidays
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 3 (AP)—The Vietcong's Liberation Radio announced today that Viet‐, cong troops in South Vietnam would observe ceasefires for the Christmas and New Year's holidays and also for the Tet lunar new year in February.

headline: Skirmishes in East Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 2 (PI) — Only minor skirmishes were reported today in the 11‐day‐old South Vietnamese sweep through the rubber plantation country of Eastern Cambodia.

headline: U. S. Pilots Report First Attack by North Vietnamese MIG on a B‐52
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 2—American pilots here said today that a North Vietnamese MIG fighter fired airto‐air missiles at an American Air Force B‐52 bomber over the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos about 10 days ago, but missed and was chased back into North Vietnam.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Victim of Russian Roulette
lead_paragraph: HARTSHORNE, Okla., Dec. 3 (AP) — While four companions shouted for him to put a pistol down, a young man killed himself today in a demonstration of Russian roulette. The police said that Stephen Carl Gaylor, 21 years old, put a cartridge in the pistol, spun the chamber and fired it, then repeating this twice, despite pleas to stop, before killing himself on the third try. Mr. Gaylor was a Vietnam war veteran.

headline: Podell Tells of His ‘Qualification’—Money
author: By Richard L. Madden; Special to The New York Times

headline: CONFEREES FAIL AGAIN ON AID BILL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — A compromise foreign‐aid bill that would authorize $2.75‐billion in economic and military assistance remained blocked today in a House and Senate conference committee by disagreement over an amendment calling for withdrawal of all United States troops from. Indochina within a specified time.

headline: A Former Chaplain Says He Passed On Mylai Allegations
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 3—A former Army chaplain told the court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson today that a helicopter pilot had informed him of “excessive civilian casualties” in the hamlet of Mylai. and that he had immediately, reported the allegations to his superior:
author: By Douglas Robinson;Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 IN CONGRESS ASK WAR PAPERS RULING
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) — Lawyers for two Congressmen asked a Federal judge today to read four volumes of the Pentagon Papers that are still classified to determine whether they should be made public.

headline: Saigon, Fearing Reduced Aid, May Cut Army
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 1—Afraid of possible cutbacks in American military aid, the South Vietnamese Government has begun seriously studying plans to demobilize 100,000 soldiers next year, and to put others into agricultural and industrial jobs..

headline: More Clashes in East Cambodia Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 3 (AP)—Fighting increased in Eastern Cambodia today as South Vietnam's troops continued their 12‐day‐old sweep, but action fell off in other Indochina sectors.

headline: Mrs. Hulse Plans Bridal
lead_paragraph: AUBURN, Me., Dec. 4— Mrs. Jolin Boucher Hulse, widow of Capt. Richard David Hulse, a helicopter pilot who died in action with the Air Force in Vietnam, plans to be married Dec. 18 in Southport, Conn., to David H. Feila Jr. of Southport.

headline: U. S. Attacks in North
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 4 (AP) — American fighter bombers attacked three air de fense radar sites inside North Vietnam, one of them 95 miles north of the demilitarized zone, the United States command re ported today.

headline: G.I.'s and O.J.'s In Vietnam
lead_paragraph: The space measured about 5 by 10 feet, contained two stacked bunks, a makeshift small chair and plain boards arranged as shelves. A thin wood and cloth partition about 5‐feet high provided only a little privacy from the rest of the barracks, which housed about 40 men. One of the men whose space this was had invited me in to rap about the Army in Vietnam and how E.M.'s (enlisted men) deal with the nonwar war. Others had anecdotes to add, and shortly 10 men had crowded into the space. As the discussion be came more animated, one man pulled out a cigarette and began to roll it between the thumb and forefinger of his left hand. After a while, I began to recognize this as a characteristic gesture. With his right hand he pulled from his pocket a small, greenish vial filled with white pow der and poured it into the partially emptied cigarette. He lit up, took a deep puff and passed the O.J. (opium joint) around. Most of those in the group took a hit, but two or three, including Tom, the 20‐year‐old host who had recently gotten himself off a 15‐vial‐a‐day habit, said, “No.
author: By Norman E. Zinberg

headline: No Survivors in Crash
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Dec. 4 (UPI)—Mili tary searchers today reached the wreckage of a United States Army Chinook helicopter that crashed on a jungled mountain last Sunday and reported there were no survivors among the 33 Americans aboard, the Unit ed States command announced.

headline: Grim Portent in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: The rout of Cambodian forces north of their capital despite strong American aerial support and diversionary maneuvers by the South Vietnamese offers fresh evi dence of the terrible vulnerability of President Nixon's Indochina policy.

headline: Susannah Buck to Wed
lead_paragraph: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Dec. 4 —Mr. and Mrs. W. Porter Buck have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Susannah Buck, to Mitchell K. Furman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Furman of Farmingdale. The prospec tive bridegroom served with the Army in South Vietnam. The wedding is planned for next fall.

headline: U.S. Supplies Bulletproof Vests To Some Asian and Latin Chiefs
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 — Nguyen Van Thieu, the Presi dent of South Vietnam, has a bulletproof vest, supplied by the United States, to wear during public appearances.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu Rules Out an Imposed Settlement
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 4—President Nguyen Van Thieu in a speech attempting to allay widespread fears among Viet namese politicians and officials that the United States and China are planning to impose a Viet nam settlement, declared today that “any solution for the Viet nam war must come from the Vietnamese people.”
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Sailors Who Fled War Duty Are Awaiting Discharge
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 (AP)—Eight sailors who re fused to sail for Vietnam on the aircraft carrier Constella tion and sought sanctuary in a San Diego church are await ing discharge at the Treasure Island naval station here, Navy spokesman says.

headline: REFUGEE PROBLEM IN CAMBODIA LAID TO ALLIED BOMBS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 — A team of Government investiga tors has concluded in a report prepared for the General Ac counting Office that American and South Vietnamese bombing is contributing substantially to the growing refugee problem in Cambodia.

headline: New Troop Cuts Foreseen
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Dec. 4—Authorita tive American officials said today that American troop withdrawals would reduce the number of G.I.'s in Vietnam to 40,000 to 60,000 by next June 30.

headline: M'GOVERN FINDING PEACE A BIG ISSUE
lead_paragraph: WAUSAU, Wis., Dec. 5—The war in Indochina has always been a special preoccupation of Senator George McGovern.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The The New York Times

headline: More MIG Activity Over Laos Concerns U.S. Air Chief
lead_paragraph: PHUCAT, South Vietnam, Dec. 5—The Secretary of the United States Air Force, Rob ert C. Seamans Jr., expressing concern about the increased ac tivity of North Vietnamese MIG‐21 fighters over the Ho Chi Minh trail in Laos, said to day that this year, for the first time, the South Vietnamese Air Force would also be bombing the trail.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: ANTIWAR GROUPS TO PROTEST HERE
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND, Dec. 5—The antiwar movement, worried about the upcoming election year when many of its sup porters turn to the ballot rather than demonstrations, de cided this weekend to hold its next mass protest in April New York; the movement's traditional stronghold.
author: By Agis Salpukas Special to The New York Times

headline: 6 Killed in Upstate Fire
lead_paragraph: LOCKPORT, N. Y., Dec. (UPI)—Five members of a fam ily and a boarder who had just returned from Vietnam died to day when fire swept their two‐ story frame house in Cambria, which is near this seat of Ni agara County. The dead were identified as Charles McLaugh lin, 40 years old, his wife, Louise, 38; their children, Kathy, 15; Charles Jr., 13, and Debra, 8, and the boarder, George Hill, 20.

headline: General Discharges Given to 8 Sailors Who Avoided War
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (AP)—Eight sailors who sought sanctuary in a San Diego church in October when the carrier Constellation sailed for Southeast Asia were given “general’ discharges under hon orable conditions” today, the Navy said.

headline: TIMES WINS AWARD ON PRESS FREEDOM
lead_paragraph: For its publication of the Pentagon papers, The New York Times has been chosen as the recipient of the University of Arizona's annual John Peter Zenger Award for “distin guished service to freedom of the press and the people's right to know,” the university an nounced yesterday.

headline: Final Witness Testifies at Henderson Court‐Martial
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 6— The 106th and final witness testified today at the court martial of Col. Oran‐K. Hender son, and both the defense and the prosecution began to pre pare arguments for the military judge's instructions on the law to the seven‐man jury.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: 18 Killed, Saigon Says
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 6 (AP)—The South Vietnamese command said that air strikes had killed 18 enemy soldiers from 7 to 25 miles inside Cam bodia in a corridor between the Chup and Mimot rubber planta tions. Both plantations are re ported to be base areas for Vietcong and North Vietnamese divisions.

headline: Laotian Retreat Reported
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. (Reuters)—Government forces today abandoned the strategic town of Saravane in southern Laos after an attack by two North Vietnamese battalions, informed sources said.

headline: Wallace Says Electoral College Deadlock in 1972 Is His Second Goal
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6—Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today that “the second best thing” for him as a 1972 Presidential candidate would be to deadlock the Electoral Col lege and exact policy commit ments from President Nixon as the price of his re‐election.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Is Closing Sleazy Bars for G.I.'s
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 6—A quiet campaign to close the city's bars and reduce prostitution now that United States troops are scarcer is being carried out by City Hall at the request of President Nguyen Van Thieu.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Cathedral of St. John Is Site Of a Variegated Peace Rally
lead_paragraph: Norman Mailer saw it as “celebration,” Tennessee Wil liams as an opportunity to ex press his outrage, and the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr. as a true and proper use for a great church.
author: By John Corry

headline: Bodies Recovered in Crash
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam.. Dec. 6 (UPI) — The bodies of 34 Americans killed Nov. 29 in the Vietnam war's ‘second worst helicopter crash have been re covered, the United States command said today. Orig inally, only 33 servicemen were thought to have been aboard. The 34th body was found by a search team last week.

headline: Pressure by Enemy on Pnompenh Is Continuing
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 7 (AP)—Enemy forces kept up pressure near Pnompenh today with rockets, guns and mines. In the eastern part of the country, however, South Vietnamese forces met little resistance.

headline: Saigon May Free P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 8 (AP)—South Vietnam is preparing to release scores more North Vietnamese and Vietcong prisoners of war during forthcoming holidays in the hope that Hanoi will reciprocate by freeing American prisoners, official sources said today.

headline: HENDERSON DEFENSE LOSES DISMISSAL BID
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 7—The military judge at the courtmartial of Col. Oran K. Henderson denied today a series of defense motions that sought the dismissal of all charges against the 51‐year‐old combat officer.

headline: So Little Is Worth Trying
lead_paragraph: LONDON—The war in Vietnam has been a multiple, turning point; also shock to all established habits of political thinking.
author: By Stuart Hampshire

headline: WAR PAPERS PLEA DENIED BY JUDGE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7—A A Federal district judge denied today a suit by two Congress. men to compel the release of all or part of the still classified segments of the Pentagon Papers.

headline: Cambodians Trained By U S. in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: LONGHAI, South Vietnam —“Airborne! Airborne!” the Cambodian recruits holler in English as they crawl and wiggle in the mud under a long stretch of barbed wire.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Jets Draw North's Fire
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 8 (AP)—The United States command today repulsed three air engagements over North Vietnam yesterday, but said that no American jets were hit by the surface‐to‐air missiles and anti‐aircraft artillery fired at them.

headline: Thieu Bids Farewell To Australian Troops
lead_paragraph: VUNGTATI, South Vietnam, Dec. 8 (Reuters)—President Nguyen Van Mien bid farewell to the last Australian combat troops in South Vietnam today as they sailed for home on the troopship Sydney.

headline: Bitter Fighting Reported as Foe Opens Nevv Drive on Pnompenh
lead_paragraph: SRE NGEI, Cambodia, Dec. 8 (Reuter) — Fighting raged outside this tiny hamlet nine miles south of Pnompenh this afternoon as 1,000 Government troops moved to block a Communist advance toward the capital from a new quarter.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Call him Special Ambassador Billy Graham. The evangelist, an old friend of President Nixon's, has been appointed as a member of the official delegation to the inauguration of William R. Tolbert as President of Liberia. The delegation, due in Monrovia Jan. 1, will be led by Mrs. Nixon and will include Bernard J. Lasker, chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange; Mrs. John H. Johnson, wife of the publisher of Ebony magazine; and Samuel Z. Westerfield Jr., the Ambassador to Liberia. Special Ambassador Graham will officiate at a thanksgiving service at Providence Baptist Church in Monrovia the day before the inauguration, which is set for Jan. 3.
author: Albin Krebs

headline: Mills Sees ‘Fighting Chancel’ For Democrats Next Year
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Dec. 8 (AP) —Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, described President Nixon today as a brilliant strategist but said that the Democrats had a “fighting chance” of beating him in 1972.

headline: Tax‐Reduction Bill Is Sent To President by Congress
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9—The first session of the 92d (Congress, fitfully struggling toward adjournment, passed and sent to the White House today the tax‐reduction legislation President Nixon requested as part of his economic stabilizaition program.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Oppose Rehnquist
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9—The forces opposing William H. Rehnquist's nomination to the Supreme Court picked up their second Republican Senator today—Jacob K. Javits of New York—and their first Southerner, J. W. Fulbright of Arkansas.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: M'GOVERN, IN CITY, CRITICIZES MAYOR
lead_paragraph: Senator George McGovern declared yesterday that Mayor Lindsay would be “in rough shape” if he ran for President on his record here.
author: By Thomas P. Ronan

headline: Doctors in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: The following letter, signed by fifty commissioned members of the Medical Corps, was read by Senator Mansfield on the Senate floor Wednesday. The Senator withheld the names.

headline: Pnompenh Troops Dig In, Refugees Flee
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 9 (AP)—Cambodian troops dug in around an important transmitter near the suburban villa of Premier Lon Nol today while United States and South Vietnamese aircraft tried to drive the enemy from positions west and south of Pnompenh.

headline: Vietnam's ‘Korean Solution’
lead_paragraph: The Administration's much‐bruited concept of a possible “Korean solution” for Vietnam appears to be taking on a new meaning.

headline: Laotian Positions Harassed
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 9 (Agence France ‐ Presse) — All Laotian positions on the Soloven Plateau have been bombarded; harassed and immobilized” by North Vietnamese forces, a Government spokesman said today.

headline: 2 Bases Shelled Near DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 9 (AP)—Just south of the demilitarized zone enemy gunners today shelled two South Vietnamese outposts. It was the first such attack in several weeks. The Saigon command said that 50 rocket and mortar rounds hit the two bases, but caused no casualties.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: This year's winner of the Elijah Parish Lovejoy Award, which recognizes a newspaperman of “integrity, craftsmanship, character, intelligence and courage,” is Erwin D. Canham, editor in chief of The Christian” Science Monitor. As the winner, Mr. Canham will address a convocation March 3 at Colby College, which administers the award in memory of Mr. Lovejoy, an 1826 graduate who was killed in Alton, Ill., in 1837 while defending his press against a mob that opposed his editorial stand against slavery.
author: Albin Krebs

headline: 2 Airmen Cleared of Distributing Peace Leaflets at Idaho Base
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN HOME AIR FORCE BASE, Idaho, Dec. 9—A few of the spectators at a special court‐martial exploded with joy, shouting “Wow” and pummeling the back of a young airman today as he was cleared of charges of illegally distributing peace literature at this fighter plane base in southwestern Idaho.
author: By Anthony Ripley Special to The New York Times

headline: Talks at Paris Fail For 1st Time to Set New Meeting Date
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 9—The Vietnam peace talks ended their 138th session today, and for the first time there was no agreement on when to meet again.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: Army Drops Charges Against General Accused of Killing 6 South Vietnamese Civilians
lead_paragraph: The Army announced yesterday that it had dismissed murder and assault charges against Brig. Gen. John W. Donaldson, who, as an infantry brigade commander, was accused of killing six South Vietnamese civilians.
author: By Douglas Robinson

headline: Thieu's Backers Dominate Legislature
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 10—The legislators of South Vietnam's lower house finally made clear the results of last August's elections by organizing themselves this week into voting blocs that left the Government forces firmly in control.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Henderson Case to Be Sent To the Jury Next Thursday
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 10 (AP)—Closing arguments in the court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson will begin next Wednesday and the case will be submitted to the jury Thursday afternoon, the judge announced today.

headline: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10—The Congressional. “Tuesdayto‐Thursday club” isn't what it used to he.
author: By Richard L. Madden Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Residents Finding the Price Squeeze Worse Than Ever
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 8—Truong Hong Bac normally eats two meals a day but he is down to one now, skipping breakfast to save 27 cents a day.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Reports Heaviest Battle Of Its Operation in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 11 (AP)—North and South Vietnamese forces reportedly battled for nine hours yesterday deep inside Cambodia in the heaviest fighting of the Saigon command's three‐week‐old offensive across the border.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: President Nixon presented the Distinguished Service Medal to Gen. Leonard F. Chapman Jr., who is retiring Dec. 31 after four years as Marine Corps Commandant. At a ceremony in the White House Oval Office, Mr. Nixon said the Commandant had “nothing but a record of pride to look back on.” General Chapman said that among his fond memories as head of the corps was “clearly the performance, dedication and loyalty of the 450,000 Marines who fought in Vietnam.”
author: James F. Clarity

headline: Congress Leaders Break Deadlock Over Aid Funds
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10—A deadlock over foreign aid, the last major obstacle to adjournment, was broken today as Congressional leaders agreed to bypass a Senate amendment on the withdrawal of American troops from Vietnam.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Fighter Downed Over Laos By a North Vietnamese Missile
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 11—A United States Air Force jet fighter escorting a B‐52 raid over the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos was hit and destroyed by an enemy surfaceto‐air missile, the United States command disclosed today.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Expert's Bid Stirs Chicago U.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Dec. 11—The president of the University of Chicago rejected this week charges that Gerald C. Hickey, an expert on Vietnam, had been denied an academic appointment because of his association with the Rand Corporation, a private research organization under contract to the Defense Department.
author: By Andrew H. Malcolm Special to The New York Times

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — When American and South. Vietnamese troops supposedly cleaned out the enemy's Cambodian border sanctuaries a year ago last May, the Saigon Command called the invasion Operation Total Victory because it seemed like the time to start thinking about a final solution to the Communist threat from Cambodia.
author: —Iver Peterson

headline: Hanoi Said to Harden Stand on P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) — State Department officials said today that North Vietnam had “completely dashed” Nixon Administration hopes that it had decided to improve the condition of the American prisoners of war.

headline: ‘If You Kill Somebody...’
lead_paragraph: FIRST there was Pavlo, who doesn't make it back from Vietnam. He's killed by a hand grenade thrown into a brothel. His family, such as it is, will never miss him. Then there was David, who comes home, all right, but who leaves his heart with a Vietnamese girl and his eyesight in a field hospital. His mom, dad and brother are so happy to have him back that they wish he'd died there, even in a brothel making love to one of the yellowskinned people they despise.
author: By Robert Berkvist

headline: U.S. Jet Shot Down
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 11 (AP)—An intensification of surface‐to‐air missile attacks against United States warplanes and the first shooting down of an American jet in eight months from North Vietnam could trigger a new round of retaliatory blows against North Vietnam.

headline: Secret Cockfights Persist in Saigon, Despite Ban
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 11—In the 13th century, a popular Vietnamese legend runs, when the Mongols were poised to invade Vietnam, the famous general Tran Hung Dao called on his people to give up their addiction to cockfighting temporarily. The Vietnamese complied, the legend says, and the Mongols were driven back into China.

headline: After the Pentagon Papers—
lead_paragraph: NORMAN MAILER and Rip Torn flounder together in the island grass, Mailer bleeding froni his hammered head, Torn's ear half bitten off. They rise and, exchange maledictions:
author: By J. Anthony Lukas

headline: FOES OF AID BILL MAY BLOCK PLAN FOR ADJOURNING
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11—Plans for Congressional adjournment next week were threatened today when a small group of Senators decided to fight against Senate adoption of a stopgap resolution permitting the foreign aid program to continue until next March.
author: ByJohn W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Attack by Saigon Against Chup Plantation Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 13 (AP) — Six thousand South Vietnamese troops opened a land and nir assault today against the Chup rubber plantation, a major North Vietnamese divisional headquarters in eastern Cambodia, military spokesmen announced.

headline: Carrier Leaves Vietnam, May Sail to Dacca Area
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South. Vietnam, Dec. 12 — The United States Navy's nuclear‐powered aircraft carrier Enterprise and task force of several amphibious ships and destroyers left Vietnamese waters Friday heading toward the Indian. Ocean for a possible rescue of American citizens from the East Pakistani capital of Dacca.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Dec. 12—Record of an imaginary press briefing in New Delhi by the Prime Minister's mythical foreign affairs adviser, Dr. Kishan Jha:
author: By Anttiony Lewis

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Mrs. Pamela Digby Churchill Hayward Harriman, the English born third wife of W. Averell Harriman, stepped before Federal Judge Thomas F. Croake to take the oath of allegiance to the United States.
author: Albin Kress

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: Saigon, reads the dateline, and part of the story goes as follows:
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Moscow Assails U.S. Step
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 13—The Soviet press agency Tass accused the United States tonight of “gunboat diplomacy” and “gross blackmail” against India with its reported movement of an American naval squadron toward the Indian Ocean from the Gulf of Tonkin.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Neil Sheehan of Times Receives The First Drew Pearson Prize
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 —Neil Sheehan of The New York Times was awarded the first annual Drew Pearson Prize for excellence In Investigative reporting today at the National Press. Club.

headline: Thrust in Cambodia Is Deepest in Year
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 13 — South Vietnamese paratroops and armored units reached the southern edge of the Chup rubber plantation today in their deepest penetration of eastern Cambodia in nearly a year.

headline: Amnesty Bill for Foes of Draft Is Introduced in Senate by Taft
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 —Senator Robert Taft Jr., Republican of Ohio, introduced legislation today offering amnesty to draft resisters who are in Federal prisons or who fled the country to avoid service in the Vietnam war.
author: By Bill Kovach Special to The New York Times

headline: JURY IN MYLAI CASE TO HEAR ARGUMENTS
