lead_paragraph: The city's deputy chief medi cal examiner charged yesterday that the armed forces were returning narcotics addicts to civilian life “to steal, indoc trinate other persons” and be come problems for communities that cannnot treat them.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Peter Ungar;Scarsdale, N. Y., Dec. 23, 1970

headline: BLAST HURTS 27 G.I.'S DURING VIETNAM RIOT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 11 (UPI) — All United States Army enlisted men's clubs at Tuyhoa, 240 miles northeast of Saigon, were ordered closed today in a move to cool tem pers following a riot in which a hand‐grenade blast wounded 27 Americans.

headline: U.S. Group Visits Geneva To Seek Help for P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: GENEVA, Jan. 11 (Reuters)— A five‐member group represent ing the “Concern for Prisoners of War” organization based in San Diego, Calif., arrived here today to see the International Red Cross Committee about prisoners of war in Vietnam.

headline: Vietnam Spurs Cambodian Road Push
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 11 (UPI)—South Vietnamese soldiers were reported moving on two fronts today to try to help Cambodians clear enemy forces from key highways to Pnompenh.

headline: Trial Is Told That Hutto's Mylai ‘Job Was to Walk in and Shoot’
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Jan. 11—The defense attorney for Sgt. Charles E. Hutto contended today that the infantryman had entered the hamlet of Mylai 4 on a combat assault “without any intent of killing civilians.”
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Ex‐G.I. Says He and Calley Shot Civilians at Mylai Under Orders
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 11 —Former Pfc. Paul D. Meadlo testified today that he and First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. shot more than 100 unarmed South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai 4 but that they were only do ing their job
author: By Homer Bigart; Special to The New York Times

headline: Air Strikes Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Jan. 11 (AP)—The United States command an nounced new air strikes in Laos and Cambodia today to thwart infiltration of North Vietnam ese men and supplies.

headline: Laird Expects Wider Pullout of Troops
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 11—Secretary of Defense Mel vin R. Laird said tonight that South Vietnamese forces were improving so rapidly that “addi tional thousands” of American troops could be withdrawn this year.
author: By Alvin Shuster; Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnamese Force Arrives
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 11 (Reuters) — A South Viet namese task force commanded by a general arrived today at Kompong Som.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Emerson C. Ives Pawling, N. Y., Jan. 5, 1971

headline: North Vietnamese Shift to Vast Construction Drive
lead_paragraph: THAIBINH, North Vietnam— In what appears to be a cal culated shift of emphasis, thousands of young North Viet namese men and women of military conscription age have been assigned to development of the home front.

headline: Plot to Kidnap Kissinger Is Charged; Philip Berrigan and 5 Others Indicted
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12—Six persons, including the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, were indicted today on Federal charges of plotting to kidnap Henry A. Kis singer, assistant to the Presi dent for national security af fairs, and to blow up the heat ing systems of Federal buildings here.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: Washington: For the Record
lead_paragraph: New Laws. At the west ern White House in San Cle mente, Calif., President Nixon signed 23 bills. Twelve of the bills make minor changes in the Internal Revenue Code. Among the other bills he signed were the following: Extension until July 1, 1971, of authority for active United States participation in the In ternational Coffee Agreement of 1968; authorization of $250‐million in the fiscal years 1970 and 1971 for cer tain defense credit sales of some foreign countries, which repeals the so‐called Tonkin Gulf Resolution of 1964, and authorization for the loan of eight naval ves sels to Greece, Pakistan, South Vietnam and Turkey.

headline: Statement at Hutto Trial Tells Of G.I. Drinking Bout at Mylai
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Jan. 12 — A statement by a South Vietnamese Army sergeant tell ing of a drinking bout by American infantrymen after, he said, they had been told that they were going to kill all the inhabitants of Mylai 4 was read today at the court‐martial of Sgt. Charles E. Hutto.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Thousands of Soldiers Throng Hanoi
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam— Troops throng this capital city, crowding its stores and markets and idling in its lakeside cafes.

headline: Five Officers Say They Seek Formal War Crimes Inquiries
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12— Five young Military officers said today that they were ask ing the Secretaries of the Army and the Navy to convene for mal courts of inquiry into the question of war crimes and atrocities in Vietnam.
author: By Neil Sheehan Special to The New York Times

headline: Moorer Visits Pnompenh
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Jan. 12 (AP) — Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chair man of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, flew to Pnom penh from Saigon today and conferred with Cambodian and American officials on the military situation in Cambodia.

headline: 2d Air Strike in North Vietnam On Friday Is Disclosed by U.S.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 12 — The United States com mand, which previously had disclosed that an American plane mado a “protective re action” attack inside North Vietnam last Friday, said today that there were actually two such attacks that day.
author: BY Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: JURY ENDS INQUIRY ON ATTACK ON NIXON
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP)—The Santa Clara County grand jury says that it has con cluded its investigation into the stone‐throwing demonstration here against. President Nixon's campaign motorcade Oct. 29 and that no felony charges will be filed.

headline: Second Attack Protested
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 12 (Agence France‐Presse)— North Vietnam, which has re mained silent over the Ameri can air attack reported Satur day, made public today a For eign Ministry protest against the firing of an American missile “in North Vietnamese territorial waters” off Hatinh Province.

headline: 4TH NEGRO G.I. HELD IN VIETNAM SLAYING
lead_paragraph: QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, Jan. 12 (UPI)—A fourth Negro soldier has been arrested with the slaying of one white major and the wounding of another following an argument over a loudly playing stereo phono graph, United States military sources said today.

headline: Mylai G.I. Feared Babies Held Grenades
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 12 —Former Pfc. Paul D. Meadlo testified today at the court martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. that he had shot some babies in their mothers’ arms at Mylai because he was afraid the babies might be carrying concealed grenades.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Defense Rests in the Court‐Martial of Sergeant Hutto
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Jan. 13—The defense rested its casé today in the court‐martial of Sgt. Charles H. Hutto who is accused of assault with intent to murder at least six South Vietnamese in the hamlet of Mylai 4.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: HARRIMAN PAYS VISIT TO GROMYKO
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Jan. 13—W. Ave rell Harriman said today, after a meeting with Foreign Minis ter Andrei A. Gromyko, that he was confident, despite “cooler winds” that the United States and the Soviet Union could reach agreements on arms lim itations, the Middle East and Berlin.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Task Force Chief Reported Mylai Action as ‘Well Executed and Successful’
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 13 —Nearly two weeks after the alleged massacre of South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai, the American commander of the attack force filed a report to his brigade commander de scribing the action as well planned, well executed and successful.”
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Laird Bars Airlift Plan
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13— A recent request by the Joint Chiefs of Staff that American transport planes and helicop ters be permitted to help ferry ammunition and South Vietna mese reinforcements to Saigon's forces operating deep in Cam bodia has been rejected by Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: 31 of Foe Reported Killed
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 14—More than 13,000 South Vietnamese and Cambodian troops pushed for ward today in a drive to reopen Highway 4, Pnompenh's only route to the sea, the South Vietnamese headquarters an nounced.

headline: G.I. Charged With Murder Of a Major in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 13 (AP) — A 24‐year‐old American soldier was charged today with murder and at tempted murder for the shoot ing of two majors during an argument over a loud phono graph. An Army spokesman said the charges were filed against Specialist 4 Alfred B. W. Flint of Haines City, Fla. No trial date has been set, he said.

headline: Gulf of Tonkin Resolution Is Repealed Without Furor
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 14 (UPI)—The Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, regarded by Presi dent Lyndon B. Johnson as his authorization for United States intervention in Southeast Asia, has been repealed without any of the controversy it once stirred.

headline: Lon Nol to Go to Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnamese, Jan. 14—Premier Lon Nol of Cambodia is scheduled to fly to Saigon next week for meet ings on future South Vietna mese military support for his embattled country.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. List of Missing Is Rejected at Paris Peace Talks
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 14—David K. E. Bruce, United States delegate to the Paris peace talks, was ridi culed as “a public amuser” to day after he tried to hand to the Communist side a list of 1,534 American servicemen the Pentagon carries as missing in action in Southeast Asia. He said he wanted the North Viet namese and the Vietcong “to provide any information on them.”
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: A Calley Witness Insists Colonel Told Officers to ‘Wipe’ Foe ‘Out for Good’
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 14—Officers who participated in the Mylai incident were chid ed on the eve of the alleged massacre for lack of aggressive ness, a witness said today at the court‐martial of Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Excerpts From Transcript of Nixon Talk on Youth
lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Nix on's speech yesterday after noon at the University of Nebraska, Lincoln, Neb., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

headline: Week's G.I. Casualties Are Lowest Since 1965
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 14 (UPI) — The United States command said today that 27 Americans were killed in action in Indochina last week and 83 were wounded.

headline: Foe Attacks Force on Pnompenh Route
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 14 (AP)—Cambodian and South Vietnamese troops came under violent attack today as they sought to clear a key supply route to Pnompenh, military spokesmen here reported.

headline: Army Clears Hutto in Deaths at Mylai
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Jan. 14—Sgt. Charles E. Hutto, the former Louisiana farm hand accused of joining in the al leged slaughter of South Viet namese civilians at Mylai 4, was acquitted today by a court martial jury of six officers.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Terms Cambodia Airlift Possible
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 — The United States left open the possibility today that it might provide logistic and airlift sup port for the South Vietnamese forces in Cambodia if required by the deteriorating military situation there.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: C. H. Sparks Pulaski, Tenn., Jan. 10, 1971

headline: U.S.SAIGON COMMAND TO BE REORGANIZED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) —A Pentagon spokesman dis closed tonight the United States headquarters command struc ture in Vietnam would be reor ganized, but he said that Gen. Creighton W. Abrams's role as commander would not be af fected.

headline: Briton to Go to Saigon for U.S. Again
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 — President Nixon is sending Sir Robert Thompson, the British expert on guerrilla warfare, back to South Vietnam next month for an urgent evaluation of the Saigon Government's po lice and public‐safety programs, State Department officials said today.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Copter Use Envisaged
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Jan. 15—Military sources reported tonight that American pilots would fly med ical evacuation helicopters into Cambodia to pick up wounded South Vietnamese troops if necessary.

headline: MUSKIE, KOSYGIN CONFER 4 HOURS
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Jan. 15 — Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin told Senator Edmund S. Muskie today, in a Kremlin meeting lasting nearly four hours, that both the United States and the Soviet Union would benefit from peace in the Middle East and Indochina and a general improvement in rela tions.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Richard Kuhns New York, Jan. 8, 1971

headline: GI's Demonstrate in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 15 (UPI) — About 40 United States soldiers chanting “Free Angela Davis” and calling for an end to racial discrimination in the Army marched on Amer ican headquarters today, the birthday of Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Jan. 15 — This month's Barnum prize for ingenuity goes to Jerry W. Friedheim, spokesman for the Defense Department. He was defend ing the Vietnam defoliation program against a profoundly critical report just made to the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Mr. Friedheim argued that the South Viet namese economy might actually have benefited from herbicide.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Calley Jury Told of Bitterness Of G.I.'s Over Atrocity Stories
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 15 — The American force that in vaded Mylal was frightened by earlier losses to Vietcong mines and booby traps and embitter ed by reports of atrocities, a maimed veteran said today at the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. REPORTS RAID ON 3 MISSILE SITES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, Jan. 16—United States Air Force fighter‐bombers es corting B‐52's on raids along the Laotian‐North Vietnamese border attacked three missile sites inside North Vietnam yesterday, military spokesmen reported.

headline: How to End the War
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.—How can we end the Indochina war?
author: By J. C. Thomson Jr

headline: South Vietnamese Report Retaking Cambodian Pass
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Jan. 17 (AP) — The South Vietnamese command said yesterday that a Govern ment armored force had dis lodged enemy troops from a key mountain pass on Route 4 in Cambodia and was pushing] on north.

headline: Le Duan Is Found to Be Popular After Hanoi's Economic Reforms
lead_paragraph: The following dispatch is by Michael Maclear, the London correspondent of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, who visited North Vietnam last month.

headline: That our presence in Vietnam is unwise, absurd and wrong
lead_paragraph: American participation in the Indochina war can be opposed from three points of view: the absolute moral one that this kind of indiscriminate destruc tion of man and nature cannot be condoned on any ground; the deterministic one that this kind of war inevitably derives from a particular economic and po litical system Which must be changed in order to bring that war to an end and prevent new ones of a similar nature; and the pragmatic one that this particular war happens to he indefensible on moral, polit ical and military grounds. The position Noam Chomsky takes here is that of moral absolut ism, supported at least by a degree of economic determin ism.
author: By Hans J. Morgenthau

headline: Miss To Kim Hoa Bride of T. C. Fox
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 16—Miss To Kim Hoa, a social worker, and Thomas C. Fox, a part‐time correspond ent here for The New York Times, were married today.

headline: NAVY CHIEF HEARS ANTIWAR OFFICER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16—A young naval officer, who has asked the Navy to convene an official court of inquiry to study alleged war crimes and atrocities in Vietnam, present ed his views briefly last night at a dinner here attended by the new Chief of Naval Op erations, Adm. Elmo R. Zum walt Jr.
author: By Neil Sheehan Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Says Industrial Output In 1970 Rose 5% Over 1969
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 16 (Agence France‐Presse) —Industrial production in North Vietnam rose by 5 per cent in 1970 compared with 1969, according to statistics published here this week.

headline: 2d Girl Real Daughter, African President Says
lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Republic, Jan. 16 (AP)—The street vender brought to Ban gui in November as the Pres ident's daughter is going back to Saigon because President Jean Bedel Bokassa says an other Vietnamese girl who ar rived this week is his real daughter.

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 16 (AP) — The withdrawal of additional United States units totaling 540 men was an nounced here today.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: John D. Lofton Jr. Publications Director Republican National Committee Washington, Jan. 6, 1971

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: PARIS—A United States‐South Viet namese invasion of Cambodia was under consideration in 1967‐68 but was postponed as a result of Chester Bowles's diplomatic mission to Pnom penh in January 1968. The account of this operation is told by the former U.S. Ambassador to India in his forth coming book, “Promises to Keep,” to be published by Harper & Row.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: (Deleted) Is What G.I. Terms the Vietnamese
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (Reuters)—State Department censors deleted answers to questions about derogatory terms applied by American soldiers to Vietnamese in a Congressional transcript re leased recently.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—Those who have long boasted of the progress of the South Vietnamese forces are viewing with some pride the re cent forays by Saigon's troops into Cambodia. The student seems to have learned the les sons well, and is now hard at work helping out the kid next door.
author: —Alvin Shuster

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga. — Who gave the orders? Who knew what was going on? Was any attempt made to stop it? Who is responsible?
author: —Richard Hammer

headline: Laird Sees Critical Period
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) —Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, returning from a trip to Southeast Asia, says that the next few months will be criti cal for Cambodia but sees nothing to slow the rate of United States troop with drawal from South Vietnam.

headline: 17 N.F.L. PLAYERS TO TOUR FAR EAST
lead_paragraph: MIAMI, Jan. 16 (AP)—Two members of the Super Bowl teams — Mike Curtis, a line backer for the Baltimore Colts, and a defensive tackle, Bob Lilly, of the Dallas Cowboys— will be among 17 players who will tour United States military outposts in Vietnam and the Far East.

headline: Army Spied on 18,000 Civilians in 2‐Year Operation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17—The United States Army fed the names of about 18,000 Ameri can civilians into its computers, dossiers and files in a wide ranging intelligence operation during the tumultuous days of civil disturbances from the summer of 1967 through the fall of 1969.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnamization Plus American Forces
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Vietnamization has become a household word in the United States. We understand that the Vietnamization program is succeeding and that the rate of withdrawal of our ground combat forces may be ac celerated. We hear that the ground combat role may be assumed com pletely by the South Vietnamese some time toward the end of this year. Less well known and given little emphasis is the continued need for other combat forces in Southeast Asia, even after the Vietnamese take over the ground combat function.
author: By Adm. U. S. Grant Sharp

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: (Capt.) B. C. Ewing New York, Jan. 7, 1971

headline: Business in Saigon Is Red Tape, Frustration—and Profit
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam— Doing business in Saigon, say the men who try, requires the patience of Job, the scruples of Machiavelli, a sense of humor and a bit of spare change for crossing the right palm.
author: By Nancy Moran Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. REPORTS RAID ON 2 MISSILES SITES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Mon day, Jan. 18 (AP)—United States fighter‐bombers attacked two surface‐to‐air missile sites in North Vietnam yesterday in the third straight day of “protec tive reaction” strikes inside the enemy's borders, the United States command announced to day.

headline: Point of View
lead_paragraph: WE are in deep trouble in our foreign trade policy. Faced with high rates of un employment and inflation, key sectors of American labor and industry are clamoring for import quotas. Our com petitive position has deterio rated. The internationalist constituency, which once sup ported the liberal trade in itiatives necessary for Amer ica's world leadership, has been demoralized and divided by Vietnam.
author: By Richard N. Gardner

headline: Cambodia Economy Is Hard to Find
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia — When the Vietnam war final ly boiled over into Cambodia, the leaders of the new Gov ernment here realized how badly the deposed Prince Norodom Sihanouk had pre pared the army for war.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi, Many Experts Say, Can Sustain Endless War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Vietnam's economy — bol stered by what are said to be significant food‐production in creases last year, the rebuild ing of some of its industries destroyed in the American bombings between 1965 and 1968 and the annual flow of more than $1‐billion in aid from its Communist allies — appears to be relatively sound, according to sources in Wash ington.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Copter Carriers Operate Off Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 18—The United States com mand said today that two American helicopter carriers had taken up positions off the Cambodian coast and were staging missions for the “inter diction” of enemy lines and the supplying of allied forces fight ing in Cambodia.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: A. Frank Reel New York, Jan. 12, 1971

headline: Text of Announcement by McGovern on 1972 Race
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (A P)—Following is the text of Senator George S. McGovern's Presidential announce ment as prepared for delivery over television in South Dakota and as released here today:

headline: Laotians Report Attacks
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 18 (UPI)—North Vietnamese forces overran three Laotian Govern ment defensive positions in the Boloven plateau over the week end a Defense Ministry spokes man said today.

headline: African Suspects Saigon Plan In the Sending of Wrong Girl
lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Re public, Jan. 18 (Reuters)—In terior Minister Louis Kpado said last night that French agents and the South Vietnamese po lice in Saigon “invited” a 20‐ year‐old Vietnamese girl to change her name to that of the long‐lost daughter of President Jean Bedel Bokassa of the Cen tral African Republic.

headline: An End to Violence?
lead_paragraph: This communication does not ac company a bombing or a specific ac tion. We want to express ourselves to the mass movement not as military leaders but as tribes at council. It has been nine months since the townhouse explosion. In that time, the future of our revolution has been changed deci sively. A growing illegal organization of young women and men can live and fight and love inside Babylon. The F.B.I. can't catch us; we've pierced their bullet‐proof shield. But the town‐ house forever destroyed our belief that armed struggle is the only real revo lutionary struggle. It is time for the movement to go out into the air, to organize, to risk calling rallies and demonstrations, to convince that mass actions against the war and in support of rebellions do make a difference. Only acting openly, denouncing Nixon, Agnew and Mitch ell, and sharing our numbers and wis dom together with young sisters and brothers will blow away the fear of the students at Kent State, the smack of the Lower East Side and the na tional silence after the bombings of North Vietnam.
author: By Bernardine Dohrn

headline: U.S. PLANS TO USE ALL AIR WEAPONS IN CAMBODIAN WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18—The Defense Department said today that the United States intended to employ the full range of its air combat power throughout Cambodia against enemy troops and supplies that “ultimately” might threaten American mili tary men in South Vietnam.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: McGovern Enters '72 Race, Pledging Troop Withdrawal
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 — Senator George S. McGovern of South Dakota opened his Presidential campaign today, 22 months before Election Day, 1972, with a pledge to with draw every American soldier from Southeast Asia if he reaches the White House.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Calley Trial Recessed for Psychiatric Test
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 18 — A defense psychiatrist brought the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. to an abrupt halt today by testifying that the young of ficer had behaved “like a robot” during the alleged Mylai 4 mas sacre and had killed unarmed women and children because of a compulsion to obey orders from his “father image,” Capt. Ernest L. Medina.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. IS NOW FLYING COPTER MISSIONS FOR LAOS TROOPS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19—A further enlargement of the United States air role in Indochina was reported here today as official sources said American helicopter gunships were flying combat missions in Laos in direct support of Laotian ground troops.

headline: McGovern Assails Nixon on Cambodia
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19— Senator George S. McGovern charged today that President Nixon had violated “the spirit and letter” of the Cooper‐ Church resolution by authoriz ing intensive American air activity over Cambodia.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: PNOMPENH TELLS OF ROUTE 4 GAINS
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 19 (AP) — A South Vietnam ese armored force reportedly pushed closer today to a link up with Cambodian troops in the allied drive to clear Route 4, the nation's main supply route.

headline: Futile Cambodia P.O.W. Raid Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19 (AP)—Three hundred South Vietnamese paratroopers, air lifted by helicopter, raided a camp just inside Cambodia where 20 Americans were be lieved held but found it empty informed sources reported today.,

headline: Lon Not Flies to Saigon For Two Days of Talks
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 20 (Reuters) —Premier Lon Nol of Cam bodia arrived here today for two days of talks with South Vietnamese leaders. He was met by the South Vietnamese Premier, Tran Thien Khiem, at Tansonnhut Airport.

headline: U.S Acknowledges a Rise In Cambodian Air Actions
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 — The White House today ac knowledged a recent step‐up in the type and intensity of Amer ican air operations in Cambodia, but insisted that Administra tion policy had not changed from the guidelines laid down by President Nixon last summer.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19—Shortly after American troops went into Cambodia for two months last spring to join South Vietnamese forces in attacking enemy supply bases, President Nixon said at a news conference that “when we come out our logistical support and air support will also come out with them.”
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: LAIRD JUSTIFIES WIDENED AIR WAR TO AID CAMBODIANS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20— Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird today invoked the two‐year‐old Nixon Doctrine and a recent military aid bill to provide the rationale and authority for the expanded use of American air power in Cam bodia.

headline: Escalation in the Air
lead_paragraph: “The only American activity in Cambodia after July 1,” President Nixon assured the nation last June, “will be air missions to interdict the movement of enemy troops and material where I find that is necessary to protect the lives and security of our men in South Vietnam.”

headline: G.I's Reported on Ground
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 21 (AP)—It was reliably reported today that American advisers and South Vietnamese officers were travel ing together on command and control helicopters in Cam bodia and periodically setting foot on the ground — despite Pentagon assertions to the con trary.

headline: Daniel Berrigan Linked to Plea To Weathermen for Nonviolence
lead_paragraph: A tape‐recorded message to; the Weatherman underground, attributed to the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, pleads with the rad ical group to return to non violence, warning that: “No principle is worth the sacrifice of a single human being.”
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: Report Is Discounted
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 — A spokesman for they United States command said today there was nothing new about a report yesterday that the United States was using helicopters for direct combat support of Laotian Government troops. The report, by The Associated Press, was published in The New York Times today.

headline: Saigon Sets Tet Cease‐Fire
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 21 (Reuters)— South Vietnamese troops will observe a 24‐hour cease‐fire at Tet, the lunar new year holi day, a Foreign Ministry spokes man said today. The truce will start at 6 P.M. local time Jan. 26 and end at the same time the following day.

headline: 4 More Officers Seek U.S. War Crimes Inquiry
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20— Four young military officers today called for an investiga tion “of the responsibility” of Gen. William C. Westmoreland, Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt and other United States military leaders “for war crimes” in In dochina.

headline: Hanoi Issues List of Raids; Defoliation Flights Alleged
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 20 (Agence France ‐ Presse)— North Vietnam today published, what it called a detailed list of recent United States air raids on North Vietnam. The raids, in the view of military experts here, are aimed at com pletely isolating North Vietnam from South Vietnam.

headline: Denial by Washington
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20—A Defense Department spokesman today denied a report from Hanoi that the United States was carrying on a bombing of fensive against North Vietnam.

headline: SAIGON REPORTS CAMBODIA LINK‐UP
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 — With a 10‐mile stretch of Cambodia's major supply route still mostly under Com munist control, advance ele ments of two allied forces re portedly linked up today in their road‐clearing drive.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Colonel in Saigon Faces Marijuana Trial
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 (UPI)—A United States Air Force colonel is to he tried by general court‐ martial Feb. 8 on marijuana charges, Air Force spokes men announced today.

headline: Freshman Named Humphrey Is ‘Home’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20— “Which was is the trolley?” asked the man with the high forehead and jutting chin as he peered about the basement of the old Senate Office Building.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21—In expanding American air op erations in Cambodia, the Nixon Administration took the calculated risk that Congress and the public would tolerate such a move provided no American ground troops or ad visers were involved.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Lists Week's Toll: 37 Killed, 211 Wounded
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21 (AP) — The United States command reported to day that 37 Americans were killed in action in Indochina last week, 10 more than the week before.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Roger Montgomery Ithaca, N. Y., Jan. 11, 1971

headline: 64 IN HOUSE SEEK CURB IN CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21—Leg islation to ban the use of funds to “provide United States air or sea combat support for any military operations in Cam bodia” was introduced in the House by 64 Democratic Repre sentatives today as concern mounted in the new Congress over further American involve ment in the Indochina war.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Excerpts From Speech by Mansfield to Senate Democratic Caucus
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21— Following are excerpts from a speech to a Senate Demo cratic caucus today by the majority leader, Mike Mans field of Montana:

headline: Marines on Carriers
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21—An American military spokesman today corrected an earlier statement by the United States command that no com bat marines were aboard two American helicopter carriers off the Cambodian coast that were launching missions in support of the allies on Route 4.

headline: 6 Die in U.S. Copter Crash
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Friday Jan. 22 (Reu ters)—Six United States Ma rines were killed and 16 were injured yesterday when a Ma rine CH‐46 Sea Knight heli copter crashed 20 miles south‐ west of Danang, the United States military command re ported today.

headline: ARMY CLEARS A G.I. OF MYLAI CHARGES
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Jan. 21 (AP)—The Army an nounced today that it had dropped charges against an other enlisted man accused of murdering civilians during an assault on the hamlet of Mylai 4 in South Vietnam in 1968.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Algernon D. Black New York, Jan. 18, 1971

headline: 100th Peace Talks Session: Each Blames Other
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Jan. 21—The Vietnam peace negotiators completed their 100th session today, but the milestone was not a festive occasion.

headline: Lon Nol, Ending Visit in Saigon, Reaches Accords
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21—Ending a two‐day visit here, Premier Lon Nol of Cambodia announced agree ments today to expand rela tions and reduce tensions with South Vietnam.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Pacification Program Is Given a New Name
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 22 (UPI) — Ellsworth Bunker, United States Am bassador to South Vietnam, says that the pacification program in South Vietnam has been so successful that it was being given another name.

headline: Rogers Assures Cooper on Troop Curb
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 — Secretary of State William P. Rogers met with Senator John Sherman Cooper today in an effort to assure him that the Administration was abiding by Congressional restrictions on American involvement in Cam bodia.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: From a U.S. Helicopter Base: Support for Cambodia
lead_paragraph: AT A U. S. HELICOPTER BASE, near Cambodia, Jan. 22 — South Vietnamese officers and American “airborne co ordinators,” flying routinely from this base on a jungled plain in Vietnam, symbolize the direct nature of United States combat support in Cambodia.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: 8 G.I.'s Killed in Copters
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Jan. 22 (AP)—Viet cong gunners shot down a United States observation heli copter today and then downed a larger helicopter going to the aid of the first one, killing eight Americans and wounding three, the United States com mand said.

headline: ARMY CLEARS G.I.'S IN MYLAI KILLING
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Jan. 22—The Army cleared today the last four enlisted men ac cused of participating in the alleged massacre at Mylai 4, leaving only a few officers still charged in the killings.

headline: No Offensive Expected
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 22—High‐ranking military sources expressed doubt today that the devastating attack on Pnompenh's airport fore shadowed any immediate up surge in the Indochina war.

headline: LETTERS
lead_paragraph: To the Financial Editor:
author: Raymond M. Beecroft Vernon, Vt

headline: O'Brien Says Nixon Ignored War and Economy Issues
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) —The Democratic National Chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, accused President Nixon today of ignoring two concerns that “tower above all others”—the war and the economy.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — From the ground, the air war in Indochina had seemed to settle into a pattern. In North Vietnam, daily recon naissance flights and more‐fre quent attacks on threatening mis siles; in Laos, heavy bombing of the Ho Chi Minh Trail and sup port for Laotian forces; in South Vietnam, continuing, but declining, air activity of all types.
author: —Alvin Shuster

headline: Letters
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Daniel E. Teodoru Elmhurst, N. Y

headline: MAJOR FIRE RAGES IN SAIGON SLUM AREA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Jan. 24 (UPI)—Saigon's biggest fire since the 1968 Tet offensive raged through a slum along the city's border with adjoining Cholon today. Flames raced through several square blocks of homes and shops.

headline: U.S. Copter Downed
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Sunday, Jan. 24 (Reuters) — Vietcong gunners shot down a United States OH‐6 spotter helicopter in South Vietnam's northern mountains yesterday, the United States command said today.

headline: The Jigsaw Puzzle of History
lead_paragraph: SOME years ago, in reviewing Arthur Schlesinger's “A Thou sand Days” for Harper's Maga zine, I suggested that there was some resemblance between the volumes then flowing from Schlesinger, Soren sen, Salinger, and other lesser luminaries at Camelot, and the medi eval monastic chronicle. If anything, events since that time have reinforced this prejudice.
author: By John P. Roche

headline: National Notes
lead_paragraph: Portrait of a Presidential can didate: a former seminarian … a low‐keyed, deliberate, speaker … a dove on Vietnam from a conservative farm state with only a handful of electoral votes. Add them all together and you have Senator George McGovern of South Dakota who last week announced—more than a year and a half before the 1972 poli tical conventions—that he was a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

headline: Muskie Criticizes Administration on Economy and Asia Policy
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 23—Senator Edmund S. Muskie criticized the Nixon Adminis tration's economic tactics and Southeast Asia policies today; assuming a more partisan stance than usual.
author: By R W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Edward S. Herman Philadelphia

headline: Janet E. Lee Planning Bridal to Bruce Beach
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, Jan. 23 — Miss Janet Ellingwood Lee, a senior at Skidmore College, plans to be married to Bruce Kershaw Beach, a junior at Dartmouth College who served as a first lieutenant with the Army in Vietnam.

headline: CUT IN FOE'S FLOW OF TROOPS NOTED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23—The rate of infiltration of North Vietnamese troops toward the South has dropped surprisingly in December and January after a sharp rise at the start of the dry season, according to United States military intelligence sources.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Law
lead_paragraph: Once there were 26, Six teen were officers, from lieu tenant to general. Ten were enlisted men, from private to sergeant. What linked them was a hamlet called Mylai 4 in South Vietnam where, on March 6, 1968, perhaps 500 Vietnamese civilians were slaughtered by an American company. All 26 faced United States Army court‐martial on charges ranging from pre meditated murder to derelic tion of duty in attempting to cover up what had happened.
author: —Richard Hammer

headline: SAIGON WILL MOVE 5,300 WHO HELPED IN ROUTE 4 BATTLE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 23—The South Vietnamese com mand announced today that it would soon withdraw its 5,300 troops who helped Cambodian soldiers clear Cambodia's stra tegic Route 4.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam's Presidential Election
lead_paragraph: As South Vietnam's presidential election campaign gets under way, President Thieu's advantages are enor mous. He is a wartime incumbent in control of the mili tary, the police, the provincial governors, a far‐flung bureaucracy and vast patronage in a country new to ballot‐box politics. But the possibility that he might be beaten in the Oct. 3 voting, perhaps by a peace candi date, cannot be totally ruled out. It is that small possi bility that heightens interest in the political maneuvering now going on.

headline: U.S. Order Points to Rise In Raids on North Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 24—United States fighter bomber pilots flying over Laos have been given instructions that foreshadow increased American attacks on radar‐con‐trolled, antiaircraft missile installations in the border re gions of North Vietnam.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Freed, P.O.W.'s Denounce Saigon
lead_paragraph: COMMAND POST CHARLIE ONE, South Vietnam, Jan. 24— Thirty ‐ seven disabled North Vietnamese prisoners of war paddled across the Benhai River in the demilitarized zone six miles north of here today after their captors told them they Could go home.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25—One of the most eloquent passages in President Nixon's State of the Union Message followed his assertion that “as the forces that shape our lives seem to have grown more distant and more impersonal, a great feeling of frustra tion has crept across the land.”
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Saigon's Armed Forces Improving, but Big Test Is Still Ahead
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 18 — The South Vietnamese armed forces are rapidly as suming the major part of the ground fighting in Vietnam. They are doing by far the most killing and dying, and they are doing it with better‐ trained men, more modern equipment and greater mobil ity than ever.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Attacks Near Pnompenh
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Tues day, Jan. 26—North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers launched attacks last night against the defense perimeter of this tense Cambodian capital, which is under dawn‐to‐dusk curfew be cause of an enemy war of terror.

headline: Truce Reported Broken
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Tuesday, Jan. 26 (Reuters) — The Vietcong vio lated their announced four‐day lunar new year truce twice within three hours of its start today, a South Vietnamese Gov ernment spokesman said, with attacks that left six persons dead and 22 wounded.

headline: Saigon to Get More U.S. Jets to Take Over Air War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 — The Nixon Administration, working to equip South Viet nam to take over full responsi bility for the air war within its boundaries once American air power has been removed, has decided on another sub stantial increase in the size of Saigon's air force.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Release of Ill P.O.W.'s Is Proposed by Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 26 (AP) — The South Vietnamese Govern ment proposed today that it and North Vietnam release immediately all sick and wounded prisoners of war, including American airmen held in North Vietnam.

headline: Two American Carriers Off Cambodia Pulled Out
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 25—The United States com mand said today that two American naval vessels had withdrawn after nearly two weeks of operations off Cam bodia in which they were sup plying and fueling American armed helicopters supporting South Vietnamese troops.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Allies Begin Truce To Mark the Lunar New Year
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 27 (Reuters)— United States and South Viet namese forces began a 24‐hour truce last night in observance of Tet, the Vietnamese and Chi nese Lunar New Year.

headline: MANSFIELD BACKS SMALLER CABINET
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26— Senator Mike Mansfield, in a Democratic response tonight to President Nixon's State of the Union Message of last Friday, praised the President's pro posed reorganization of the Federal Government as “a move in the right direction.”
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Calley Calls Mental Tests An ‘Unwarranted’ Measure
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan, 26 (AP) —First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. arrived today for an ex haustive mental examination he calls “unwarranted and unnec essary.”

headline: Laird Again Urges Hanoi To Allow Camp Inspections
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) — Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird today renewed his plea to North Vietnam to live up to the Geneva Convention and permit the International Red Cross to inspect its prisoner‐of war camps.

headline: Pentagon Acknowledges That Americans Landed at Pnompenh Airport
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 — The Defense Department ac knowledged today that 15 to 20 Americans in civilian clothes landed at Pnompenh airport last night to retrieve two damaged helicopters and take them back to South Vietnam for repairs. The men were disclosed to have been carrying sidearms.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu Links Peace Candidates With Communists
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 — President Nguyen Van Thieu opened the South Viet nam presidential and legislative campaign today by indirectly linking peace candidates with the Communists and repeating his own hard line of victory over the Communists.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: STENNIS SAYS U.S. MAY HAVE TO EASE CURB IN CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Senator John C. Stennis, chair man of the Senate Armed Serv ices Committee, said today, after a briefing by Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, that it might become necessary to re lax the present Congressional restrictions on military opera tions in Cambodia.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: People of Saigon Pause For Ancient Tet Rituals
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27—The Lunar New Year began today and found the people of Vietnam trying to hold to ancient symbols and customs while coping with their war‐torn daily life.

headline: F‐100 Lost in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Jan. 27 (AP)—A United States Air Force super sonic fighter‐bomber crashed in southern Cambodia today, ap parently while on a mission near Route 4, Pnompenh's link to the sea. The United States command said the pilot had been killed.

headline: Cambodians Get Boats
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 (UPI)—The United States command announced today that it had turned over to the Cam bodian navy eight river patrol boats under the military aid program.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Thomas H. Greer Professor of Humanities Michigan State University East Lansing, Mich., Jan. 24, 1971

headline: Laotian Base Overrun
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 27 (UPI)—Enemy forces overran a Government base near North Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh supply trail and seized an outpost on the strategic Boloven Plateau in southern Laos, military sources reported today.

headline: S.D.S. Defend ant Sentenced
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP)— Linda Sue Evans, 23 years old, of Fort Dodge, Iowa, pleaded guilty today to two indictments stemming from protest demon strations by Students for a Democratic Society in Chicago in October, 1969, and was sen tenced to three months in the Cook County Jail. She was placed on probation for three years but was ordered to spend the first three months in jail.

headline: An Old Scenario in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: History is repeating itself in Southeast Asia. The in sidious insertion of American military power into Cam bodia in support of a faltering regime ominously paral lels the events of early 1965 which entrapped the United States in a major war in neighboring Vietnam.

headline: Protecting G.L's, Agnew Says
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 28 (AP) —Vice President Agnew said today United States aid to Cam bodia was designed primarily to protect American troops in South Vietnam as President Nixon's troop withdrawal time table continues.

headline: U.S. Admiral Directed Mekong Fuel Convoy
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (UPI)—A South Viet namese convoy in which fuel ships were escorted to Pnom penh was organized and com manded by radio by an Amer ican admiral, allied military sources said today.

headline: U.S. WAR DEATHS INCREASE IN WEEK
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP)—The United States command today reported an increase in American casual ties in Indochina last week, and spokesmen attributed the rise largely to two plane crashes that killed 14 servicemen.

headline: ROGERS ASSURES SENATORS ON ROLE IN CAMBODIA WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 — Secretary of State William P. Rogers assured a restive Sen ate Foreign Relations Commit tee today that the Administra tion had no intention of expand ing the scope of American mili tary activities in Cambodia.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Student Editors Report Nixon Plans Troop Cut
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28— Eleven college newspaper editors discussed American policy in Indochina with Sec retary of State William P. Rogers today and, in an un expected 15‐minute meeting, with President Nixon at the White House this afternoon.

headline: Letter From a Saigon Prison
lead_paragraph: The following letter was handwritten inside a South Vietnamese Government jail on Dec. 21 and smuggled out shortly thereafter. It is signed by three monks, representing some 500 of different re ligions, who are mainly imprisoned for their refusal to bear arms.

headline: U.S. Role in Route 4 Drive
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, San. 28 — The United States command made public today a general summary of American involvement in last week's joint Cambodian‐South Viet namese operation to clear Route 4 south of Pnompenh but refused when asked to provide a specific count of American bombing strikes or other air missions.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: The Screen:'Last Valley' Recalls a Story of Survival
lead_paragraph: "The Last Valley" is a kind of historical movie, a type of adventure drama, a sort of epic, and something of a parable, and it winds up being a bit more boring than is absolutely necessary, considering the possibilities.Experiencing the movie is very much like riding in a big, handsome, old Rolls-Royce that keeps wandering from one side of the road to the other, slipping its gears, speeding up and then suddenly breaking — all because the driver doesn't know where he's going or how fast he wants to get there, although it's apparent he wants to travel in all of the style that money can buy.The driver is James Clavell, the novelist ("King Rat") and film writer-director ("To Sir, With Love"), who wrote, directed and produced this adaption of J. B. Pick's 1960 novel set against the background of the Thirty Years' War (1618-1648), which was almost an anthology of war.Beginning as a rebellion of Protestant German princes against the Catholic Habsburgs, it evolved, over the decades, into a series of see-saw battles, mixed alliances and desperate power plays involving France, England, Spain, Denmark and Sweden, in addition to Austria and the German states. By the time the Treaty of Westphalia was signed, most of Germany had been devastated and about the only thing that had been accomplished was the irrevocable end of the Holy Roman Empire, which was dead anyway."The Last Valley" is a rather dreamlike story of survival set in a magnificent valley protected from the outside world by high mountains. Into this valley comes Vogel (Omar Sharif), a one-time school teacher who has been on the run for years, followed shortly afterwards by a small, exhausted army led by the Captain (Michael Caine), whose men kill and burn and rape on reflex and have long since forgotten what they're fighting for.The Captain, using Vogel as a go-between, effects a truce with the people of the valley, pledging to protect them from invasion in return for food, shelter and women for the winter, at the end of which the Captain goes off to fight another battle and Vogel is evicted, to continue his wanderings. The people of the valley survive, simply by enduring.Like Bertolt Brecht in "Mother Courage," Mr. Clavell, I suspect, sees the incredible horrors of the Thirty Years' War as a metaphor for contemporary horrors, but he seems either incapable of—or uninterested in—developing a physical drama with any kind of intellectual substructure. Vogel, a pragmatic dreamer, and the Captain, a career soldier whose cynicism is not quite complete, talk quite a lot about war and religion but the quality of their dialogue would not embarrass the folks on "Gunsmoke." When, in the spring, the Captain departs to engage in yet another battle, the outcome of which will make no difference to anybody, all he can say is that he must go to the battle "because it's there."So much money was obviously spent on the lavish production—on scenery, costumes, occasional battles and extras—that I suspect Mr. Clavell thought he was making a statement about civilization, and perhaps even Vietnam, that would somehow work as an action melodrama. Although Mr. Clavell, as a writer, has nothing in common with Shaw, "The Last Valley" kept reminding me of Guy Hamilton's misguided attempts some years ago to turn "The Devil's Disciple" into a popcorn movie.It's difficult to judge Mr. Clavell's effect on his performers, except to remark that Mr. Sharif and Mr. Caine, who've never struck me as especially subtle actors, are quite good, while Per Oscarsson ("Hunger"), who is, I think, a great actor, seems to be acting up a storm in a dramatic vacuum. It may be, however, that in his make-up as a slightly mad Catholic priest he looks just a little too much like Charles Manson.One technical point: the film, which opened yesterday at the Rivoli and Juliet 2 Theaters, favors such slow lap dissolves that you will spend what seems like most of the movie seeing double images.
author: By Vincent Canby

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: William F. O'Connor New York, Jan. 21, 1971

headline: ROGERS SAYS U.S. MIGHT AID A DRIVE BY SAIGON IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 — Secretary of State William P. Rogers held open today the pos sibility that United States air power might be used to sup port a South Vietnamese ex pedition against Communist supply bases in southern Laos.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: GENERAL CLEARED OF MYLAI CHARGES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 — The Army dismissed all court‐ martial charges today against Maj. Gen. Samuel W. Koster, the division commander of the troops who were at the ham let of Mylai 4 at the time of the alleged mass killings of South Vietnamese civilians there on March 16, 1968.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Saturation Air Raids Continuing in South Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 29—Saturation raids were flown again today against North Vietnamese infiltration and supply routes in southern Laos, continuing what is described here as one of the most in tensive aerial campaigns of the Indochina war.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: “I renew my protest. I renew my request that our air force mechanics be withdrawn from Indochina. For the good they do, the risk is too great.… We are taking steps that lead our men directly into combat…”
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Vietcong Truce Ends
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Saturday, Jan. 30 (Reuters)—The Vietcong ended their four‐day Tet lunar new year truce early today, and allied reports said that the guerrillas had violated their cease‐fire at least 74 times.

headline: Have You Dug Wall Drug?
lead_paragraph: SOMEWHERE in Vietnam a couple of G.I.'s pose for a picture with a sign reading “12,301 miles to Wall Drug Store,” In Venice grinning tourists hold up a notice in the Piazza San Marco: “6,250 miles to Wall Drug Store.” A sign in the Paris Métro reads: “5,961 miles to Wall Drug Store.” One in La hore, Pakistan, reads: “Wall Drug Store 10,728 miles.”
author: By Roy Bongartz

headline: Purpose of Laos Drive
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30 (AP)—An objective of South Vietnamese incursion into Southern Laos would be to sever the Ho Chi Minh trail, the network of roads used by North Vietnam to send rein forcements and supplies to South Vietnam and Cambodia.

headline: SOUVANNA WARNS HANOI IS BEGINNING OFFENSIVE IN LAOS
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 30— Premier Souvanna Phouma said today that he was convinced that the North Vietnamese were beginning a general offensive against Laotian Government po sitions.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: Two idealists, vis‐à‐vis the Vietnam War
lead_paragraph: First things first — and this book by a young newspaperman who is also a veteran of Army Intelligence is above all a first novel. In its civilized approach to love it might have been written 30 years ago:
author: By David Dempsey

headline: Hanoi Reports Bombings
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Jan. 30 Reu ters)—The Hanoi radio said to day that United States planes had raided North Vietnam for the last five days.

headline: National Notes
lead_paragraph: Only a year ago, Maj. Gen. Samuel W. Koster was one of the brightest stars in the Army's galaxy. Commandant of the United States Military Academy at West Point, he had an ex emplary past—service in World War II, the Korean war and Vietnam, where he commanded the Americal Division, recipient of the Distinguished Service Medal, the Silver Star with oak leaf and other medals. At age 50, his future seemed limitless.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The way Secreta ries Laird and Rogers tell it, any air strike for any purpose anywhere in Southeast Asia serves the Administra tion's ultimate goal of protecting the withdrawal of American troops from South Vietnam, and is therefore justi fied. That means that in the guise of winding down the war, the Nixon Ad ministration is widening the war in the most destructive way.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: U.S. Silent on Speculation About an Invasion of Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30—Ad ministration officials declined today to discuss speculation that the South Vietnamese, with American air support, were about to invade southern Laos.

headline: Clergy to Lobby at U.N. for End to War
lead_paragraph: In modest offices near the United Nations, clergymen of all major world religions have set up shop with the aim of lobbying for a number of, causes: to end the Vietnam war, to promote disarmament, to combat racism.
author: By Kathleen Teltsch

headline: First Army's Chief Censures Gen. Koster in Mylai Incident
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) —Maj. Gen. Samuel W. Koster, cleared yesterday of charges that he had covered up the alleged massacre at Mylai 4, has been censured and could receive further stiff adminis trative penalties, the Army said today.

headline: In Brief
lead_paragraph: “Historians and journalists have more in common than they readily admit to each other,” Henry Graff, the chairman of Columbia's history department, remarks in this book. “The dif ference, of course, is in the length of the perspective they prefer.” In that context, Mr. Graff reviews four sets of in terviews he had with President Johnson and his Tuesday luncheon group, or Tuesday Cabinet as Graff calls it, in cluding Rusk, McNamara, Bundy, Moyers and later Ros tow, Christian and Clifford. Speaking casually to these men between 1966 and 1968, Graff had a precious opportunity to analyze the “decision making process,” as he calls it, as ap plied during a time of increas ing American involvement in Vietnam—and he wasted it entirely.

headline: Allies Clash in Pnompenh
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Jan. 30 (UPI)— South Vietnamese sailors and Cambodian soldiers battled for 15 minutes with mortars and maohineguns in the city center today. The Cambodian army called in tanks and troops to break up the melee. One Cam bodian bystander was killed and 10 other persons were injured. The incident apparently started with an argument between South Vietnamese and Cam bodians.

headline: POLL SHOWS MORE ASK SWIFT PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 30— The Gallup Poll reported today an upsurge of public support for the Hatfield‐McGovern pro posal to end United States troop involvement in South Vietnam by the end of the year.

headline: Television
lead_paragraph: THE tricky issue of men tioning marijuana on the air arose recently in connection with the television show made from film footage of Bob Hope's annual Christmas tour of overseas military bases, and Hope's own remarks about the show as broadcast, The version that finally reached the home screen gave view ers no indication that Hope's wisecracks about pot had evoked perhaps the heartiest laughter among the troops; nor did the pictures on the tube ever confirm what Hope freely told the press and, in deed, discussed earlier and openly with Johnny Carson on the “Tonight” show.
author: By Jack Gould

headline: GROUND FIGHTING IN VIETNAM DROPS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 (AP)—Ground fighting diminished across South Vietnam today, but United States bombers pounded the country's northern front and inside the demilitarized zone.

headline: KY, OUT OF RACE, BUSY IN POLITICS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 1—Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky moved yesterday to get hack the $7,300 he had posted to run in the presidential election. Oct 3, emphasizing that he was out of the political scene.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Log of Mylai Attack Shows Early Reports of 84 Vietcong Slain, Trial Told
lead_paragraph: FORT. MEADE, Md., Aug. 31 —Infantrymen assaulting the village of Mylai 4 on March 16, 1968, reported killing 84 Vietcong during the first hour and 10 minutes of the attack although they did not report receiving any hostile fire during the entire operation.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: L'Oncle Ho
lead_paragraph: The crowd which assembled in Ba Dinh square in early dawn waited patiently. On the platform, a frail figure stepped forward. His beard blowing in the wind, he declared the independence of Vietnam.
author: By Truong Dinh Hung

headline: U. S. Starts the Pullout Of 42,000 More Troops
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept 1 (AP) — The United States command announced today the start of a troop reduction of 42,000 that will cut American strength in South Vietnam to 177,000 men by Dec. 1.

headline: AIDE TO KY PREDICTS RESCHEDULED VOTING
lead_paragraph: An aide of Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam said yesterday that there was “zero chance” that his country's presidential election would take place on Oct. 3 because “popular reaction” to President Nguyen Van Thieu's running alone would force the Government to schedule a new one

headline: KOTOUC DESCRIBES 2 MYLAI MESSAGES
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. —An Army officer on duty at rear headquarters during the infantry push through the village of Mylai 4 said today that he had heard a radio message that a boy was being shot down on a highway near the hamlet.
author: By Douglas Robinson

headline: LAIRD SAYS BONN WILL BUY 175 JETS FOR $750‐MILLION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 —Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird announced today that the United States had agreed to sell 175 Phantom jet fighters to West Germany.

headline: War‐Crimes Figure Loses Assignment As Army Recruiter
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 1 (AP)—An officer who has accused the Army of harassing him has been transferred from a position where he was responsible for reenlistments to another job, the Third Army said today.

headline: Saigon Reports Foe Shelled a Column Near DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 2 (AP)—North Vietnamese gunners reportedly directed a 500‐round rocketand‐mortar barrage at a South Vietnamese armored column near the demilitarized zone yesterday and also shelled five nearby bases.

headline: Vietnam Action Ruled No War In an Insurance Case in Virginia
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Sept. 1 CAP)—The Virginia Supreme Court held today that the United States' involvement in Vietnam did not constitute a war in the legal sense.

headline: Swiss to Recognize Hanoi, Hope to Play a Role in Peace
lead_paragraph: BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 1 (AP) — Switzerland decided today to recognize North Vietnam and indicated she hoped to play a role in ending the war in Vietnam.

headline: Saigon Officially Removes Ky's Name From Ballot
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 — The South Vietnamese Government announced tonight that the presidential election would be held as scheduled Oct. 3 with only one candidate, President Nguyen Van Thieu. The name of Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky, it said, will be kept off the ballot.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: SEOUK CONSIDERS '71 WAR PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 —South Korea was authoritatively reported today to be considering the withdrawal of all its forces from South Vietnam by the end of this year.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: LBJ's Clashing Advisers
lead_paragraph: After being held on a tight civilian leash for three years, the Joint Chiefs of Staff saw the Tet crisis as the solution to the strategic reserves crisis. Not only was there a new event, the Tet offenshre, but the arrival of a new man in the Pentagon held some promise of a new strategic posture for the United States. The nemesis of the J.C.S., Robert McNamara, was being replaced by the super‐hawk, Clark Clifford. General Wheeler, chairman of the J.C.S., and General Westmoreland, the Vietnam commander, hoped that Clifford would be a tabula rasa on which to write their plan.
author: By John B. Henry 2d

headline: White House Comment
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 2—Asked today for the White House's response to President Thieu's decision to proceed. with the Oct. 3 election in Vietnam, President Nixon's press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, commented:

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL, Turkey—The one crisis nobody wants to hear about is Cyprus and yet this familiar little volcano seems to be getting ready to explode again. The world already has its hands full with monetary troubles, Middle East troubles, Sino‐Russian troubles, North Irish troubles, winding down the Vietnam war and winding up the economy. It detests the thought of another headache in Cyprus.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: SAIGON GENERALS SPLIT ON ELECTION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2—A United States intelligence report says that South Vietnam's military leaders are “less than unanimous” in supporting President Nguyen Van Thieu in his determination to run in the Oct. 3 elections even though he is unopposed.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Seoul Denies It Is Weighing Full Vietnam Pullout in 1971
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 21 (AP) — South Korean officials today denied a report in The New York Times that their Government is considering the withdrawal of the 48,000‐man Korean force in Vietnam by the end of this year.

headline: Thieu Terms Vote Test of Confidence
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 2—President Nguyen Van Thieu said tonight that he would view next month's presidential voting as a test of public confidence in his administration even though only his name would be on the ballot.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: 19 U.S. Combat Deaths in Week Highest in Almost Two Months
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 2 (AP) — The United States command announced today that 19 Americans were killed in action in Vietnam last week. It was the highest weekly toll in seven weeks.

headline: NORTH VIETNAMESE BATTLE BIG FLOODS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam (AP) Sept. 2—North Vietnam has mobilized thousands of troops and civilians to fight the country's worst floods since World War II, the Hanoi radio reported today.

headline: Buddhist Monks Quietly Lead Campaign Against Thieu
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 2—In the growing wave of criticism directed against President Nguyen Van Thieu, who will be the only candidate in the presidential election next month, some of the sharpest and most scornful attacks come from the leaders of the An Quang Pagoda. The Buddhist monks keep their voices low, but their followers hear them clearly.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: 40,000 in Chicago Hear President Say Program Will Benefit Farmers
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Sept. 3—President Nixon headed back to the capital tonight in much the same manner in which he left it three weeks ago—pleading for public support for his new economic strategy.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Fighter‐Bomber Attacks Gun Site North of Buffer Zone
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept. 4 (AP) — A United States fighter‐bomber escorting B‐52 bombers on raids against the Ho Chi Minh supply trail in Laos crossed into North Vietnam yesterday and attacked an enemy antiaircraft site, the United States command said today.

headline: Rogers Says U.S. Accepts Thieu Decision on Election
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3—Secretary of State William P. Rogers indicated today that the United States accepted President Nguyen Van Thieu's decision to run alone next month as a test of public confidence in his administration in the absence of a contested presidential election in South Vietnam.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: The Thieu‐Bunker Tragedy
lead_paragraph: The promise of South Vietnam's President Thieu to resign if his political police, military governors and bureaucratic minions fail to stuff the ballot boxes adequately Oct. 3 in the one‐man plebiscite he has substituted for a presidential election would be laughable if it were less tragic.

headline: Ky Vows to Stage a Coup Unless Election Is Halted
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 3—Vice President Nguyen Caa Ky threatened today to stage military coup and “destroy” President Nguyen Van Thieu if Mr. Thieu went ahead with his plan to run as the only candidate in the Presidential elections Oct. 3.

headline: Clash in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: BARAI, Cambodia, Sept. 3 (AP) — Cambodian soldiers, with the support of dive bombers and artillery, killed at least 100 Members of the North Vietnamese 205th Regiment yesterday at a road fork 65 miles northeast of Phnom Penh, an operations commander reported here today.

headline: Minh Aide Says Bunker Offered To Help Finance General's Race
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 3—A close associate of Gen. Duong Van Minh insisted today that among the inducements that the United States Ambassador, Ellsworth Bunker, offered the general to stay in the presidential race before he pulled out Aug. 20 was an unspecified amount of money.

headline: Capital Police Chief Says Force Was Not Ready for Protesters
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept 3 (UPI) — Police Chief Jerry V. Wilson acknowledged today that his department's handling of thousands of antiwar demonstrators last spring was not “the ultimate in perfection” but he defended his tactics and promised to be better prepared for similar incidents in the future.

headline: Cutter Returns Here After 10 Months' Vietnam Duty
lead_paragraph: The Coast Guard cutter Morgenthau, returning from 10 months' duty patrolling the Vietnam coast, received a welcome yesterday morning at, Governors Island reminiscent of World War II and Korean war days.
author: By Edward Hudson

headline: FIGURES ON HEROIN IN VIETNAM DIFFER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4—The picture of heroin use by American servicemen in Vietnam was further clouded today by new Pentagon figures showing that about one‐third of those servicemen first identified as heroin users had not been taking the drug.

headline: The Army on Trial
lead_paragraph: Lieut. Col. Anthony Herbert, a professional soldier with an outstanding up‐from‐the‐ranks record of 24 years of service and a reputation as a top Combat commander Vietnam, has for all intents and purposes been cashiered by the Pentagon. Stripped of his command two years ago, he has since been denied an assignment to staff school and, after a demeaning tour as officer in charge of re‐enlistments for the Third Army, he was last week reduced to a supply job lie expects forced retirement next year at age 42.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: FORD OPPOSES CUTS IN DEFENSE OUTLAY
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4—Representative Gerald R. Ford, the House minority leader, warned tonight that any curtailment of United States defense expenditures as the involvement in Vietnam nears an end would thwart the nation's effort to keep pace with Soviet military advances.

headline: Army Is Shaken by Crisis In Morale and Discipline
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4—The bitter Vietnam experience has left the United States Army with a crisis in morale and discipline as serious as any its oldest and toughest soldiers can remember.
author: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Congress Must Decide
lead_paragraph: Returning to work this week, Congress finds the political scene transformed. Republicans who have ritualistically deplored economic controls have to reconcile their rhetoric with President Nixon's wage‐price freeze. Democrats who have advocated such controls have to decide what to wear politically now that the President has stolen their clothes.

headline: CAMBODIA TO SEEK A SAIGON PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 4 (AP) — Cambodia announced today that she would begin talks next week to get South Vietnam to withdraw its 10,000 troops from Cambodian soil. There are mounting complaints from Cambodian villagers and farmers of looting and brutality by South Vietnamese troops.

headline: Article 2 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA.
author: By James T. Wooten

headline: BOMBERS AND GUNS ATTACK FOE AT DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 4 (AP)—American planes, artillery and warships hammered North Vietnamese positions in the southern half of the demilitarized zone and south of that area today.

headline: Aides Deny Ky Threatened To Depose Thieu by Force
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 4—Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky's office sought today to deny reports suggesting that Mr. Ky had threatened to use force to depose President Nguyen Van Thieu.

headline: The Greatest Trip in the Whole World
lead_paragraph: THE old Willys Jeep, burdened with people and baggage, rumbled through the main checkpoint and, accelerating past the sprawling, Military Assistance Command‐Vietnam headquarters, turned abruptly to pull up and park in front of Vietnam's only international airport. Tansonnhut was a familiar sight to me, but this time it somehow looked different—as Mecca would to the devoted Moslem or Lourdes to the hopeful cripple.
author: By Gerard Michael Corrigan

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—Whatever suspense there may have been about President Nguyen Van Thieu's intentions to run alonein next month's Presidential elections evaporated last week. He knocked Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky's name off the ballot—Mr. Ky didn't want to run anyway—and announced that the, vote would go on.
author: Alvin Shuster

headline: Y.A.F. SUSPENDS SUPPORT OF NIXON
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Sept. 4 — Young Americans for Freedom, the conservative youth group that campaigned for Richard M. Nixon in 1968, voted overwhelmingly today to suspend its support of the President, principally for what it called his “failures” in foreign policy.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: B‐52'S BOMB ENEMY ON BROAD FRONTS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 5 (AP)—American B‐52 bombers attacked North Vietnamese positions across broad fronts of Indochina yesterday and today and the United States command announced the loss of two helicopters as a result of enemy fire. Two crewmen were killed and a third wounded.

headline: KY ADMITS THREAT BUT ASSAILS PRESS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept: 5—Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky acknowledged today that he was the source of news reports that said that he had threatened to “destroy” President Nguyen Van Thieu in coup d'etat.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: SAIGON REFUSES TO FREE WAR FOE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 5 — A petition for the temporary release from prison of Mrs. Ngo Ba Thanh, a leading critic of the war and of the Saigon Government, has been refused by a court here.
